description: 9+ years and counting ! Dosa continues to remain flawless both in the quality of its food and service. It's impressive how they've managed to keep the local discerning San Franciscan satisfied over the years. Loved it when it first opened and years later I still do
author: Noopur D.

description: Fantastic service. Slippery floors. I wish I knew the names of the dishes we ordered. I was pleasantly surprised with the dishes. I don't normally crave Indian food, but the fusion of the dishes was a nice touch. There were many dishes that left my tastebuds
author: Meems N.

description: Absolutely beautiful restaurant, I must say the owners Anjan and Emily really put the interior decorator to work! Food was fresh and taste amazing! I was so curious that I went to their website to read about them and learned that their produce are organic along with the spices, I guess thats what give the food that great taste and of course the chef must be brilliant too. The manager was very kind! She knows what she is doing, super hands on and even served us dessert to our table. We were lucky to be able to meet the owner since as our first time we loved it so much we wanted to let him know, very humble and nice guy. One thing i love about this place is There is no old 90s indian music playing and Indian people can actually take their non-indian friends or colleagues here and be proud to show off the culture and food.   Wish you guys all the best!!!
author: Nadia A.

description: Super expensive, less quantity and so not tasty. Panipuri's Pani felt like lemon mixed with spices no hint of mint. Dosa, completely taste less, and sambhar was salty. One good thing was plate decoration. After paying more than $100 went to in n out to fill up the hunger.
author: Gaurav P.

description: For people who love to dine in a place with good ambience and service, this place is highly recommended. I loved the service and the food. I have visited this place several times with my friends and never got disappointed.
author: Pavani P.

description:
I hate to give a bad review. But the service was extremely pathetic. It was my birthday dinner. 

1) We were seated 1 hr after our reservation time. 
2) Hostess told us that we would be given some concession given that we waited for an hour when we were actually on time. 
3) The server never came to replace our plates. We had to remind them 2-3 times. 
4) they never informed us about the last call to order food 
5) We were waiting for the dessert menu but instead the server comes and gives us the check. We instead asked him for dessert menu once again. His reply was that he is not sure if the kitchen is open. 
6) We approached the manager reminding him that hostess asked to give us concession and that were were extremely disappointed with the service. Moreover, during reservation it was informed it was a Birthday dinner. 
7) After paying the check, the server returned our cards after 10 mins. 

I have no complains for food. However, the service and manager needs courtesy classes. 

Never coming back. PS: I was a big fan. Not anymore.
author: Aaggrim S.

description: Worst service!!!!!!!!! Inarticulate asshole servers and equally idiotic managers. Waste of money. Food is inauthentic and bland. Never again.
author: Reena D.

description: This is an awesome place for Indian food of high quality. They are open if you come with kids and really take care of the family. We always enjoy going her for a different experience.
author: Ashok T.

description:
We were staying in downtown SF and I was trying to find a nice Indian place. I came across Dosa! They had some great reviews from my fellow vegetarian friends. We called to make a reservation and lucky for us they had a last minute cancellation and we got a table at 9:15. 

When we got there we were seated quickly. We got seated on the top floor. The ambience, the lighting and the decor everything was gorgeous. It is indeed a chic and happening place. Our server was friendly and brought our water promptly. They also serve you fried papadums with cilantro mint chutney as a complimentary appetizer. Who doesn't like that :)

Having eaten dosa's and uttapam all my life, I was excited to try out something with a twist. We ordered a paneer and peas uttapam and we wanted to make it spicy so our server offered to add green chillies on top. We also ordered a mung dal masala dosa. Our friend ordered dahi rice and idli with chutney. OMG! I absolutely loved the food. Everything was perfect!!!! Sambhar was perfection. Mung dal dosa was healthy and tasted fantastic. It was crispy and had just the right amount of flavors. I really liked the paneer and peas uttapam. I am glad we added the chillies. It gave it the kick that we love. It was super filling. The idlis looked perfectly spongy and our friend loved his food as well. Our food arrived promptly. I was surprised at how good the service was at Dosa, considering how busy it was. Everything was perfect! 

Parking can definitely be difficult to find, since this place is in downtown SanFrancisco. We got lucky and were able to find some street parking a block away. 

I would highly recommend this restaurant. Please make a reservation, they are really busy.  I cannot believe it took us this long to find this gem. Next time we visit back up north, we are going back!
author: Labdhi P.

description:
I came in with a party of three at 6:45 on Monday. The restaurant was starting to fill up. They sat us right away. By a little after seven the restaurant was pretty full.

I ordered the following..
Mango Lassi - 4.5 stars - one of the best I have had.  Nice mango purée folded into organic straus yogurt.  
Roasted Chile and Garlic Dosa - 4.5 stars - my favorite out of the three dosa I tasted.  Wonderful flavored dosa batter! The chile and garlic flavored come through wonderfully.  The dosa are served with a tomato, coconut and lentil dipping soup.  All delicious!

I also had bites of the following..
Sprouted mung bean and paneer salad - 
Masala
Spicy mung bean masala
Both were very good.  I like the plain masala better!

Our server was Chi!  He was very nice, knowledgeable and attentive.

I will definitely be returning!  I give this restaurant 4.5 stars.
author: Jennifer L.

description: Never disappointed with DOSA as this is my favourite Indian restaurant. Convenient to the the AMC theatre where you can see a movie & have dinner before or after
author: Ed W.

description:
5 stars for Brunch!  Pleasantly surprised at the tastiness and uniqueness of their brunch menu items.  Easy online reservations--this is more often a lunch/dinner restaurant, so get in now while brunch is still under-popularized.  Huge restaurant, especially for this Fillmore location.

Service is attentive, manager is welcoming, and waiter was knowledgeable and informative.

Mango Lassi ($5) - mixed really well, one of the better mango lassi's that the hubby and I have had.  (He ordered this--I opted to wait until after brunch and instead get T4 a block down the street. :) )

Bombay Eggs ($15) - extra flavorful, reminds me of a tastier spicier version of Moroccan baked eggs.  Comes with 2 eggs baked atop a thick tomato curry concoction, a ~half-sized garlic/onion uttapam, and a couple sauces (mild green, spicy red).  Great recommendation from our waiter!  Makes my mouth water just thinking of this dish.

Wild Mushroom & Truffle Oil Uttapam ($15) - flavorful with tender deliciously prepared mushrooms.  Not your typical button mushrooms--these are beech, maitake, and trumpet--yum!  Impressed at how well they cooked the mushrooms, especially considering truffle oil/mushrooms aren't your typical Indian fare.  An uttapam is a white slightly spongy/chewy pancake.  Comes with 2 sauces (including a sweeter and less spicy red sauce) and a cup of stewed veggie curry soup.

Generous, extra flavorful dishes.  Great service.  Easy reservations.  And to top it off, boba down the street.  What else could you ask for?
author: Vanessa O.

description: A must visit place if you are looking for Indian cuisines. Loved the dosa here. The place is super clean, smells nice and the hospitality is supreme!! I strongly recommend this place.
author: Praval J.

description:
Man food is really awesome, so as the ambience & service is great too. Been there 5times but everytime food is just great !! 

And it's not so expensive as it looks very sophisticated .. and people coming there are very settled.
author: Jay D.

description:
5 stars for sure. The number of 5 stars reviews that I write have gone down sharply since I have started writing more reviews. I try to reserve them for something special and unique. This place deserves 5 stars for its combination of wonderful food and amazing ambience. I can nearly say that this place has the best ambience amongst the Indian restaurants that I have been to in the US, till now. 

For people of Indian origin, I would recommend this place for taking non-Indian friends out to and especially if you have to take your parents or relatives out for a meal. This will definitely be a place that will leave a good impression. For everyone, this is the kind of ambience and food that I want every Indian place should have. Gets busy over the weekend so make a reservation. 

Now that I have commented enough about other things let's get to the food. 

Appetizers: order the Fried Idllis, and chennai chicken. Both are nice and good.

Main course: being named Dosa, we had to try some dosa's and they turned out to be pretty good. Over two visits we have tried Mung dosa, Rava dosa, and Paneer Dosa. I liked the Mung and Rava dosa more than the Paneer dosa. We tried some other entrees also: really loved the Prawn masala and the Channa Bhatura. If you don't want to have a dosa I would recommend either of these two. Both had wonderful flavor. 

Sweets: Ras malai was good. 
Mango lassi was also good.

Enjoy the food and the environment.
author: Nipun S.

description:
A fancy $$$ Indian place in Japantown? Given SF's trends of overpriced food, I was a skeptic but got lured by Restaurant Week, when I found Dosa to be the only place with a worthwhile menu. While most other restaurants feature the anti-climatic addition of a salad and a brownie for a 3-course meal, Dosa became an adventurous feast through spices and creative cooking.

[SMALL PLATES]
(++) Chips - You start off with complimentary chips, and it's unlike anything I've ever eaten before. It's light, crispy, and has a handful of seeds thrown in.
(++) Chennai chicken - The expertly roasted chicken maintains a savory juiciness while imparting strong smokey tones, contrasting boldly with the cool cucumber and yogurt sauce. 
(++) Sprouted mung & paneer salad - The varied landscape of flavors was noteworthy, but the texture was truly outstanding. This dish deserves some mindful eating to fully appreciate how the chewy coconut, crunchy pomegranate, and springy arugula simultaneously influence the sprouted mung bean, which ends up tasting more crispy or soft depending on what ends up in that particular forkful. The paneer is interestingly akin to tofu, and I enjoyed the pure taste in contrast to the more pungent versions I usually see.
(++) Beet croquettes - The sophisticated take pulls off a vegetable-based, cream-free, extra creamy croquettes. Not only does the blend of several vegetables create a palatable base; the incorporation of spices, nuts, curry, and a cranberry chutney adds extra layers of complexity.

[CURRIES ETC.]
(+++) Nagai vegetable korma - I chose this somewhat as a chore so we could eat our veggies, knowing that vegetable dishes typically pales next to meat dishes (even at State Bird!) But we (even the boo who is usually carnivorous) were blown away. The perfect spice blends of age-old South Indian cuisine combined with novelty vegetables like marble potatoes and romanesco creates a dish that looks modest but synergistically showcases the magic of fresh produce and ethnic cooking. How Californian :)
(+) Goan prawn masala - I was unimpressed by the portion size of one shrimp per person, and that these were standard-sized shrimp and not prawns. The marsala is constructed from distinctly fresh ingredients, but was dominated by the fiery spiciness.
(+++) Roasted masala lamb shank - In an era when fine dining consists of abstractly small portions, this ginormous leg of a lamb was a surprise and well worth the extra charge. The 5-hour slow braising resulted in fall-off-the-bone tender and had a similar pervasively roasty flavors to the chennai chicken (excellent savory dish in itself, but exacerbates the spiciness of the prawn masala). The mix of spices with the vegetable-based seasoning added subtlety, and the lamb paired well with the fragrant lemon herb rice.

[DESSERT]
(+/-) Sweet cheese patties - Not sure if my expectations had just built up too high over the meal or if the dessert is too advanced for me, but despite the intrigue of rose water I think this was my least favorite. The cheese itself had a limp texture and tasted in between savory cheese and dessert, and the conglomerate of cream/nut/cardamom/floral added to the confusion for me. 
(+) Pistachio barfi - As a whole it tasted like an artisan dark chocolate; however it was too sugary, which overshadowed any fascinations from cashew milk and hibiscus. 

[DRANKS]
(++) Mango lassi ($5) - Good mango flavor, easy to drink and not too thick.

With the tagline "Urban South Indian dining with a Californian sensibility", Dosa exemplifies the unique (and delicious) global-local theme that takes the fusion concept to the next level. 

Presentation is on-point Instagram-worthy for the most part--from the giant fluffy channa bhatura bread that always catches your eye as it passes by your table, to the fine dining-esque display of beet croquettes on a wooden board with a magenta smear. I actually like how there's also a mix of more plain presentation, such as the vegetable korma in the traditional Indian bowl, which tones down any pretentiousness.

Ambiance is swanky, with extremely dim lighting (if good food pictures are a priority, I strongly recommend coming for a sunny brunch instead). The tall ceilings with a half second level and bar along one side reminds me of NoPa.

Although service was friendly, I must say my main gripe overall was the slowness (We arrived at 5:45 and left at 8:45 o.O) (Which meant extra $$ needed for parking; they only validate $2) Ironically, the server checked in with us several times to ask if our round of apps/entrees had arrived, and our answer was that none or only one had come. She also took forever on the mango lassi when boo was breathing fire from the spiciness.

Pro tip: Although the menu is extensively notated with dairy/egg/gluten/nut free/vegan, it lacks spiciness warnings. If you can't handle spicy, I suggest avoiding anything that says "curry leaves" and/or prophylactically getting yourself a glass of mango lassi.
author: Edna C.

description:
Plan a relaxing movie date evening at Sundance Theater, where have the luxury of indulging in a drink while watching your movie. Then headed to Dosa right opposite to Sundance, for a lovely dinner. 

You'll be  surprised as you walk in to this grand upscale Indian restaurant which has a Vegas-like feel to it. The ambiance is classy with high ceiling and huge chandliers. 

On a Saturday night, the place is packed. Be ready to wait for 45 minutes for your table. While waiting, enjoy drinks at the bar table. One of the best cocktail ever is the PEONY!!! Its spicy deliciousness with creamy texture from coconut milk. 

While at the bar, order as appetizer, Vada Pav (veg slider). Pour and mix the ghee(clarified butter) over the gunpowder served on the side and have the slider dipping into the sauce. Its explosion of flavor in your mouth that you'll crave wanting for more!

For the main course, everything in the menu is simply wonderful.
My favorite is the Roasted Chile & Garlic Masala Dosa, if you like little Indian spiciness. 

Undoubtedly one of the BEST restaurant in SF!!
author: Payal B.

description:
Just had brunch here with friends. 

We ordered the Pani Puri to start with. Was fun to put it together on our own and was pretty good. For main course I had the Bombay eggs which was delicious. A little spicy but I loved it. 

My friend had the south omelet and he said it was good. Another friend had the Mung dosa which is what he gets all the time and said it was good. 

Will be back for brunch.
author: Tahima B.

description:
First time dining at Dosa on Fillmore. By seeing all the positive reviews, I decided to go to this restaurant and my expectation reached high. But, this place is more of a ultra posh vibrant vibe rather than serving delicious food. 

Even though this place is classified as Indian restaurant, I feel the food taste is no way near the authentic taste of real indian food. It seems they focussed more on the presentation of the dishes in a unique way. 

I ordered Dahi vada, rava dosa and utappam sampler (5 varieties). Dishes were ok and the food taste was just mediocre. Waited for around 40 mins before being seated. Since we came on saturday night, vibe was good with lots of crowd. I may not visit again given the average taste of indian food.
author: Santosh G.

description:
I wanted to 5-star this spot, just like the one in the Mission.

It's just the little things: I asked the hostess for a table where our little one could have a high chair and not be in the way. She was very accommodating, but then didn't bring us a high chair? I asked for chutneys for the pappadam (the usual coconut and red chutneys we ask for at Dosa on Valencia), and she offered me the chutney sampler). Maybe no one asks for those there? She obliged but seemed kinda annoyed. 

The food was great, although I'm gonna keep it real, and say Valencia still edges them out in the taste and presentation of their dosas.
author: Gabriela W.

description: The dosa is amazing. I haven't tasted anything like that since my last visit to kerala. I adore this place so much for their food but unfortunately, their downfall would be their service. We ordered a couple of things and one of the included a mango lassi. We found it a bit too thick and asked if we could have some ice and when we asked about it,  the waiter convinced us not to get it because of the yoghurt blah blah mixed with water blah blah and refused to get us some ice. It startled us that she didn't understand that no matter what she said, we still wanted to get some ice for the lassi. Mind you, Michelin starred restaurants in India serve their lassis with ice and why would you say no to a guest? Second, we didn't like the private label white wine that was served. When we asked about the notes of the wine our waiter didn't know anything about it and defended herself with the fact that she hasn't even tasted it, EVER. ( this wine was their HOUSE WINE/private label which is sold by the glass ) She went to the bar and asked about it. She came back and said that it was from the alabariño grape and said that there were certain food pairings that complimented it which she did not mention when I ordered the wine in the first place. The white wine just made everything spicier due to the high acidity and I explained that to her. She said that I shouldn't have ordered alcohol at all cause alcohol makes spicy food worse. There are wines that perfectly pair with Indian food and I wish that she suggested the " proper food pairings" for the wine that I got cause apparently she knew about it. Her comment left me pissed quite honestly. I wish the servers knew what they were doing more.  I'm willing to try Dosas other branches and I'm hoping the servers would be more competent.
author: Tamara A.

description:
I had been meaning to make it to DOSA for a while now - I finally paid a visit on a Friday evening during SF's Restaurant Week. When you walk in, you notice how beautiful the space is. The whole ambiance of the place is indeed trendy, as yelp would put it... not an authentically Indian vibe, but still very appealing. A little too dimly lit for me, perhaps also an oddly desirable music playlist - indie electronic hits? Either way, seemed like a great place to be for dinner and drinks at the end of well-deserved week.

My party of 4 decided to go for the prix fix menu (featured as part of their Restaurant Week menu, but also something that they offer on the regular). Each plate was phenomenal and mindfully prepared. Some standouts for me were: the Sprouted Mung and Paneer Salad, Goan Prawn Masala, and the Classic Masala Dosa (the chef was also nice enough to give us an additional Sweet Potato Dosa to accommodate the 4 of us). The curries were spicy even for me, but I love me a good spicy dish - so no complaints from me although that could be an area of concern for many others. Service was okay, found my server to be somewhat aloof and a little confused as well, but you can't have it all, right?
author: Liz C.

description:
Anything with truffle oil --- delicious. Loved the mini moons too. The dessert wasn't that great though. 

I like this location (interior) better than the one in the mission - bigger, more luxurious feeling.
author: Ankita K.

description: Incredible dishes and completely unexpected. I had never tried flavor combinations of this magnitude. Get the dosa and any of the appetizers. You can't go wrong at DOSA.
author: Garner M.

description: The best rockin vodka martini in town!  Great service and food. We just love the atmosphere!  The avocado yumminess and heirloom tomato salad I highly recommend. Sorry I can't recall the exact names.
author: Jules V.

description: I've had DOSA many times in my local Whole Foods, but visited the Fillmore location for the first time recently. The food was exceptional! Everything surpassed my expectations, I can't wait to be back! The grapefruit/avocado chaat was the standout, so unique and delicious!
author: Ali W.

description: Dosa is a Western take on South Indian food with almost no spice. If you want more authenticity, you will need to try a less fancy place. I always go here for the experience and the delicious cocktails. My husband and I used to frequent this place in our dating days and they always have a few seasonal items which could be worth a try. Never leave without trying the vada pav. It never fails!
author: Prabha R.

description: Delicious dosa and everything is fresh and flavorful. Good service and nice ambience. Place got packed the moment they opened. Reminded me of my Bangalore days. Will be coming every time we will come to SFO.
author: Mini K.

description:
Good place. Great ambience.
Indian cuisine with slight american flavor.
author: Padma C.

description:
TLDR - Delicious, flavorful South Indian food. Go for the dosas, maybe the appetizers, and skip the entrees. Definitely more on the fancy/trendy end of Indian food so expect to pay more than the classic Indian joint

Came with a group of 5 for SF Restaurant Week on a Saturday night. Not sure if it was because of SFRW or if it's always like this, but this place was really busy. I could only get a reservation at 5:45pm or at like 9pm a few days in advance. We ended up coming at 5:45 and by the time we left around 7:30, there was a long line of people waiting to be seated.

Ambiance here is very lively and energetic. There's a huge bar and some communal tables on the first floor and tables on two floors. Tall ceilings, dim lighting and chic decor scream nice and trendy.

We decided to order 2 sets of the 3-course SFRW menu, 1 appetizer and 2 dosas to split between everyone for a total of 3 appetizers, 4 dosas and 2 other entrees, which was plenty to share. The menu can be a little overwhelming if you're not familiar with Southeast Indian cuisine. They're known for their dosas, which are large, crispy Indian crepes generally filled with potatoes and/or other fillings, all of which are served with coconut and tomato chutneys and a vegetable and lentil dipping soup. If you can't decide what to get, you can always opt for their seasonal prix-fixe tasting menu to help narrow down your options!

Some of the portion sizes were pretty small, especially the appetizers, so they were a little hard for sharing. The dosas were very large and filling though, especially the masala (potato-filled) ones. I'd recommend skipping the other entrees though. They were still good, but they were much more expensive than the dosas and rather small in portion size.

Overall, everything was pretty tasty. Lots of flavor and all the meat dishes were cooked very well, but most of the dishes didn't leave a lasting impression. Standouts of the night were definitely the Green Mango & Paneer Dosa (from the SFRW menu) and the White Truffle Masala Dosa. Definitely would want to return to try some more of their dosas.

** APPETIZERS **

-SHREDDED DUCK ($14) - 4/5
[spicy vindaloo-style, chiles, ginger, garlic, vinegar, caramelized onion uttapam]
Tender, spicy, flavorful.

-COCHIN CALAMARI ($12) - 4/5
[sauteed with mildly-spiced coconut milk]
Super tender, lightly sweet, full of flavor

-SOUTH INDIAN SEAFOOD CIOPPINO ($17) - 4.5/5
[coconut stew, shrimp, mussels, calamari, scallops]
Delicious! Light, fragrant, coconutty broth with a slight kick.

** DOSAS **

-GREEN MANGO & PANEER DOSA - 5/5
[spicy, pickled mango relish, shredded farmer's cheese, cilantro]
MMM absolutely amazing. I don't know where the mango was in this, but it was lightly sweet and the cheese wasn't overwhelming. If you're not a fan of potatoes, this is definitely a good dosa alternative. Not quite as heavy as the masala dosas either.

-WHITE TRUFFLE MASALA DOSA ($15) - 5/5
[classic masala dosa, truffle oil]
I love truffle oil so I loved this! But only the parts of the dosa that actually had the truffle oil.. The truffle wasn't very consistent in the dosa so a lot of it was just a normal masala dosa. But the truffled parts were delicious!

-LAMB KEEMA DOSA ($15) - 4/5
[plain dosa, side of minced lamb & diced potatoes]
The lamb was yummy, but as a dosa as a whole, it wasn't quite as special as some of the others. Worth a try, but if you're a more adventurous eater, it might be a little disappointing.

-SPICY BASIL DOSA ($13) - 2/5
[masala dosa, fresh basil chutney, cashew nuts, shallots, ginger, curry leaves, chiles]
Meh. Tasted like a regular masala dosa to me. I don't think anyone in my group got any of the spicy basil part of it. No idea where that basil chutney was.. I'd pass on this in the future.

** ENTREES **

-HYDERABADI LAMB BIRYANI ($31) - 4/5
[basmati rice, spiced sauce, raita]
The lamb was soft and tender, and the rice was nice and fluffy. Delicious overall, but for $31, I was definitely expecting a bigger portion size. At least more rice if not more lamb.

-KERALA FISH MOILEE ($32) - 4/5
[coconut milk, curry leaves, ginger, coconut rice]
Wow, that fish was cooked soo well. So soft and moist. The curry part honestly was just okay, but the fish was definitely the star here. Again, small portion size for the price.
author: Jessie L.

description:
Came here at 10:15pm on a Saturday night and we still needed to put our name down for a waitlist (25 min).  I couldn't believe people were still lining up for dinner this late.  This is how you know you're for a mind blowing meal.  

The interior was swanky, but still welcoming enough where the average diner didn't feel too out of place. Somehow I felt soothed the clinky clanky, dim-lighted, up-scale feel.  Once seated, we looked through the menu and decided to go family style with our ordering (we were a group of 6).  There is also a prix-fixe option, but that wasn't for us. 

The food arrived very quickly and everything was absolutely amazing.  I was told that the food wasn't very authentic Indian cuisine and it was more of a fusion style.  Regardless, the food was absolutely delicious and we were starved and tired from the day.  I loved the lamb shank with dosa combo the best.  Our other lamb dish was also really tender and tasty.  

Our dessert, the Rasmalai, was the perfect combo of creamy and lightly sweet -- highly recommend ordering it.  Though dinner was relatively short because it was late and we were exhausted, I would love love love to come back again to try other menu items and enjoy the atmosphere and a nice drink.

Ambiance: 5/5
Food: 5/5
Service: 5/5
Overall Experience: 5/5
author: Elizabeth L.

description: The cocktails are too good. Personal favorite Ginger Ante. Also if you want to explore the cocktails get a seating at the bar the bartenders are friendly and will give you samplers for taste.
author: Hrishikesh M.

description: By far the best vada pao I have had after coming to US. I also tried green moong dosa which was mouth watering. Love the presentation of the food. Great ambience too.
author: Prerna M.

description:
I brought my family who was visiting for Philadelphia on a Saturday night, and the ambiance looked promising. First off we weren't even provided a drink menu. We ordered an assortment of shared plates including Idli fries, vada pav, Brussel sprouts, and avocado bhel. We spoke with the waitress letting her know that my wife was allergic to chickpeas, she confirmed with the chefs and informed us that she could have everything except the vada pav. Turns out the avocado bhel had chickpeas, which we informed our waitress about and later spoke with the manager about. Manager then confirmed that the rest of our dosas and uttapam order will have no chickpeas. Ridiculously, everything contained it. The Sambhar has chickpeas, the dosa potato filling had chickpeas. The manager confirmed with the chefs and they blatantly lied and denied that there was chickpeas. The manager had to show the actual split chickpeas in the filling before they accepted it. Plain ridiculous and unacceptable.

Our waitress was also very slow and did not check up on us. We accidentally spilled water and despite staring right at us did nothing to help. Which for a high end establishment is just plain wrong. 

Apart from those major issues, the overall food was pretty average. Shared plates were good, but The dosas were standard Indian fare, couldn't taste any pear flavor in the pear masala dosa, the uttapams were not fully cooked, and the sauces/chutneys were subpar. 

If you are looking for modern Indian cuisine there are many better options in the city. DOSA was very disappointing and I would not recommend it.
author: Neil B.

description: Fab fab fab! So much fun!! The service, food and ambiance were perfect- I am a regular!
author: Julie J.

description: Expensive cocktail was really good. Fun ambiance as well. Food was amazing but spicy. We had to wait a little for a table even with a reservation but was delicious and would definitely go back.
author: Joseph G.

description:
OVERPRICED  & MEDIOCRE.

I came to Dosa to celebrate a friend's birthday. We were seated upstairs with minimal wait despite being unable to secure reservations for the same time over the phone. I would suggest to sit downstairs if given the choice.

Our waiter greeted us and gave some recommendations of his favorites. However, once we placed our orders, the food would get brought out by another server. Something was definitely amiss because on 2 occasions the server attempted to drop off the same item which was already delivered earlier. We did not get one of the dishes at all. Given that some of the diners ordered the same dishes through the tasting menu and independently, we would have appreciated if the waiter would have brought out the food or at least stopped by to explain who the dishes belonged to and what they were but alas, this wasn't the case.

Given the price point of most entrees averaging between $25-30 and drink $15 and small portion sizes, our group was expecting more attentive and enthusiastic services. Instead, our waiter definitely had a "too cool for school" attitude. 

As far as the food itself goes, I was not impressed. My Marsala dosa was good but nothing to write home about. I did not find the chutneys particularly flavorful. There was heat and saltiness but I did not pick up on any intricate flavors. The chicken korma was one of the blandest I've had to date. I added the chutneys from my dosa for more flavor.

After dropping $60 on just one entree and one Dosa split between me and my husband, we were still hungry. 

PET PEEVE: this restaurant adds a "service charge" automatically to the bill. To ensure that we don't mess this up, we asked our waiter what the service charge was. He was so shady and replied that he is " not sure, but [he] thinks it's the gratuity ." He really didn't want us to know so that we would tip him on top of it. I have no issue with service charges but the waiter's dishonest response was off-putting.

Bottom line: There are SO MANY tastier (&a more affordable) Indian restaurants all over the Bay Area that  Dosa at Filmore would definitely be somewhere at the bottom of my list.
author: Nina M.

description:
I love the food at this place, but we had a really terrible table.  I was hoping to introduce my mom to the wonderful food and beautiful space, but we got seated next to the bar and got views of people's butts the entire time. 

Made reservations too. Hostess should reserve these tables for walk ins and let people know before getting seated. See attached picture of our dinner view .
author: Sharon L.

description:
- upscale but not at level of paying for the dishes.  
- good food but not up to the mark taste, little blend. 
- old fashioned is really not old fashioned 
- portion of the food was good
- less option on curry, of course it is Dosa place.
- some of the food and drink was out of stock. 
- vada pav was great. 
- drink quantity was too less. 

Being indian, i was looking for nice spices and tangy flavor of chennai chicken. Channa bhatura, over fried, request for replacement. Again needs to compromise with taste.
author: Keyur S.

description:
I've been to Dosa on Fillmore probably 10 times now and I've not been disappointed even once! I LOVE THIS PLACE!
The restaurant has a nice decor, it is pricey but definitely worth every penny. The bar is great! The cocktails and wine selection is fantastic! The beers are lackluster and definitely need an improvement since there are are amazing breweries all around in the city. The food is lip smacking, hand licking good. It's consistent every single time. It is spicy and it is done right. Service can improve but it doesn't really matter when the food is so great! So don't wait. Just go there and be in for a pleasant surprise.
author: Nandini S.

description:
Dosa, the Disappointment!
We have enjoyed eating here for special reasons for years. Last Christmas Eve was a lovely and special treat for our family! This year at Christmas week, I wanted to treat my new husband and made a reservation...before we walked in, I told him "prepare to be dazzled"!
well, we walk in and give the hostess our name and she doesn't even look up at us, nor welcome us whatsoever! Even tho we are having an early reservation and there are many tables open, she ushers us to a table next to a family with a baby that is crawling all over the booth...I made the choice to sit an another table right away. We had always been impressed with the professional service, but our server, sadly, must have been a bus-person yesterday. The first 3 dishes we ordered off the menu were no longer being served...it was early in the evening...there was no Indian wine on the menu this time...etc, etc...alas, my husband and I were less than "dazzled" and both ended up with gastric distress later on in the evening even tho we ordered our food mild in spiciness.
...is Dosa going out of business or what??
author: Kay H.

description:
Having visited San Francisco and having lived on non-spicy food for days, we were in the mood for some spicy Indian food. We wanted to avoid the standard restaurants in the South Bay and focus on something in downtown. A friend of ours had recommended this place, so I was completely down to give it a try!

DOSA has a very festive resort lounge vibe. There are huge ceilings with a very spacious bar area, couch seats like Starbucks, and then there's the main dining hall. The hosts were very professional - as soon as you enter, you are ushered in, seated and promptly handed the menu.

I decided to go with the Mixed Chile Uttapam, which is a thick dosa-pancake with 3 types of chili. I was warned this would be spicy! I rounded up my meal with some ginger chai tea, which was great! They do take a while to bring out the orders, but once it came out, it was magnificent. Perfectly cooked, perfectly arranged and the chutneys and sambar they serve with the dosa were impeccable. 

I can't say enough good things about this place. It's bright, vibrant, and hip with good quality food. Whether it be for family dinners, birthday dinners, or casual get togethers, it makes for an excellent place to gather.
author: Steve N.

description:
Overpriced, overrated. We had samosa, masala dosa, and channa bhatura.

The samosas were OK, though they had long strings of crunchy, undercooked carrot slivers that were off-putting. I expected fully-cooked filling, so this was a bit of a surprise. They were also tiny.

The channa bhatura and masala dosa were, to be fair, fine. I don't recall being particularly impressed, but not necessarily disappointed. We also got 3x mango lassi, which were inoffensive, but unimpressive and a bit lacking in mango flavor.

It was more than a bit surprising to end up paying $70+ for this meal. In Berkeley, you'd pay less than half and get more food. (I realize driving to Berkeley isn't necessarily an option, but if it is for you, skip San Francisco entirely and do Chaat Cafe or Udupi Palace in the East Bay. Decent quality food, more of it, more reasonable prices.)

Look, it's San Francisco in 2018. Everything is priced insanely high. Still, there are other South Indian places in the city (Udupi Palace in the Mission, for instance) that have better food and better prices. (And of course, the East Bay is even more economical.)

I think I get the purpose of trying to take a less-common type of cuisine (South Indian) and turn it into a trendy, hip place for yuppies, but there just isn't value for money here, even factoring in San Francisco's ridiculous cost of living. Sorry.
author: A P.

description:
Always a delight to eat here. I have come here a several times. Enjoy the dosas and the uttapams that they serve. The sambar and chutney that comes along the dosas are really amazing. This time we also ordered the madras coffee with the pistachio burfi: its a great combination. Really enjoyed it! 

Please take a reservation. Gets pretty crowded.

I gave 4 stars because while ordering a dosa from the kids menu for my 3 year old they served it with a spicy chutney. Took me quite sometime to calm me daughters palate.
author: Bikashita S.

description:
Dosa is a place that I've had bookmarked for some time.  When a friend suggested it as her birthday dinner locale, I jumped right into the group reservation.  

Our group saddled up to the bar about 15 minutes before our reservation.  The drink "Spice Route Cocktails" menu is unique, filled with hot and cold fruity, spicy, and exotic drinks.  Notable drinks include the Port of Call, a warm drink, and Emerald Monk, a fruity vodka cocktail enjoyed by the birthday girl.

Our table decided to feast family style with a selection of dosas, bhaturas, and three main dishes.  We also split a bottle of Chardonnay and Pinot Noir.  The food arrived in phases and in a very timely manor.  The staff was friendly, knowledgeable, and very attentive.  

The meal began with wine and a bowl of snack chips.  It was long before our first round of dosas and uttapam arrived.  Wow-- these are excellent.  We tried a variety and sincerely enjoyed them all.  I particularly enjoyed the truffle uttapam and the quinoa thinnai uttapam.  All of these were served with a delicious array of chutneys.  

The bhatura arrived, which is a fun giant puffy bun, along with our three main entrees.  The bhatura was a delicious device to soak up  sauces in the main dishes.  I sincerely enjoyed the mango prawn dish, but felt as though the shrimp was slightly overcooked.  Our table enjoyed the Tamil Lamb (I skipped this dish because I don't care for lamb, I sampled the sauce by dipping a piece of bhatura in the entree)

Side note:  I just discovered that this place has a happy hour menu!  I would love to try happy hour here-- the discounted drinks and small plates look like a great deal.
author: Andrea H.

description:
Came on a Wednesday night with a group of about 20 (office holiday party) - they sat us upstairs, so we had a fantastic view looking over the main dining room and bar area. The decor and lighting here is gorgeous!

The house cocktails revolve largely around gin and bourbons (like most of SF), but the rum-based Ginger Ante ($12) was great - dark rum mixed with ginger and ginger ale, decorated with a rosemary sprig. They also have wines, beers, a virgin mocktail list, lassis, and chai. 

The service here was friendly and helpful to our group. We got lots of great drink recommendations, and even though our menu was prix fixe, they were attentive to whether or not there were any allergies or diet restrictions in our group. 

I can't at all speak to how authentic/legit/real the food is - it looked and tasted like real food to me, it just wasn't really anything that I'd be returning for anytime soon. Dosas are essentially potatoes wrapped in crepe and served with chutneys; this carb bomb was by far the best part of our meal, although reading other reviews makes me think I should come back and get my hands on an actual menu. 

Our first course was a brussel sprout dish that seems like it belonged with a Thanksgiving spread, and the none of the curries (lamb and shrimp) were finished. We ended up picking the shrimp out, and left a lot of the lamb. 

While there was good heat in a lot of the dishes we had, the flavors didn't particularly compliment each other, and it was weird receiving all of our food in courses. Given the prices of this place on a regular night, I can't really justify coming back on my own. 

If you're looking for a unique place with a beautiful atmosphere though, check em' out!
author: Laura B.

description:
I had such a good meal at Dosa on Fillmore, which is not usually something I'm able to say about Indian cuisine. You see, as much as I love the flavors of Indian food, my wimpy digestive system can't take to the spices or spiciness too much, to the point where I always have to order "tikka masala" or some other basic bro choice. 

At Dosa, our waitress was very thoughtful about making suggestions for lovers and haters of spiciness alike, and I truly got to enjoy all of the delicious flavors of their food without regretting the meal later... if you know what I mean. 

What I really recommend is the tasting menu- at the time I went in late 2015, it allowed us each to select an appetizer, entree, and dessert, each at a smaller portion than the a la carte version. This made for a fun way to share a little bit of everything and see what we liked for next time. (I'm Asian and need to eat family style and try EVERYTHING, so this was a win for me!) I loved the truffle masala dosa and trying the 5 different uttapams - each had a different flavor, and when dipped in the many sauces they provided, there were so many combinations that the whole meal felt pretty exciting.

On top of the good food and opportunity to sample everything, the ambiance was really purdy- perfect for a date or special occasion. 

The cost was higher than most Indian food, but the service, selections, and atmosphere made it all worth it. (Not to mention they have a pretty good chai tea, too.) Highly recommended when you're in The Fillmore!!
author: Stephen D.

description: Ok was worried it would be white food and not authentic but the white waitress was smarter than I and knew her stuff: kudos. Great food, atmosphere and variety. Hit home while on vacation and needed to get my Indian fix. Happy times.... can't go wrong and well worth it. Great service and great food...
author: Biren S.

description:
Checked in on June 2, 2016.

I went as part of a group celebrating a friend's birthday.  I'd read other Yelp reviews and was glad that I decided to go to DOSA.  Here's my rating:
1) Food - 5/5
2) Service - 5/5
3) Bar/drinks - 5/5
4) Ambiance - 4/5

We ordered:
1) Vada Pao - we ordered two of these to be shared among the table.  It was perfect.  The serving size is big, so it can easily be shared.  Taste was very good.  I would definitely order this again.
2) Spring tasting menu - I might skip this next time and just order of the regular menu.  In the first course I ordered English Pea and Broccoli Soup.  This was probably the only item I was disappointed with that evening.  In second course, I selected Roasted Chile & Garlic Dosa - was very good.  Third course was Karaikudi Chicken Korma.  This was a good dish, but nothing outstanding about it.  Also, the serving sizes are decent, so tasting menu can easily be shared between two.
3) Drinks - various drinks were ordered.  Steph Curry, Peony, Uncut Old fashioned.  My favorite would be Peony followed by Steph Curry.  
4) Rasmalai - very good

DOSA is pricey, but classy.  It's a place to go to celebrate special occasions.  Food is good, but I do not think they are charging us only for the food.  If they were, the prices would be lower.  They charge for the total experience.

Reservations are a must!
author: Anjali A.

description:
This review is only for the waitress who served us on Friday night.. i.usually go.there not only for the food and ambience  but mostly for the service we got...   Claudia was our waitress and had zero regard to waiting on us.. She got us water and did not come back till tge next 15mins.. When our guest asked what single malt whisky they had.. She said "Well we have a big list what do you want"  if thats the case you gotta give us the list.. 

Then she turned at my husband and said besides the whyskey what food n wine would you like, when my husband said chardonnay she said I asked you about the food... we finally gave her our food and drink order...

Anyways she comes back after 10mins said the system went down and we only got the appetizer, can you repeat the rest of the order... well the appetizer came out cold and the rest of the food was good.. our guest asked for a refill of his drink and we haven't seen her or the drink for the next 30-40mins..  

Finally I asked another waitress to check on the drink and she said they ran out of it and we could order something else and got us the list.... In the mean time while the other waitress was telling us the the drink we order ran out, Claudia came in between and acted as if it was someone else's fault,, Claudia who was supposed to inform that when we got the first drink.,  I dont think I am going back to get service that bad and the waitress to show attitude back to me when I am paying a premium price to go there...
author: Sruthi R.

description: Had the vada pav this time around. It was the best dish compared to the others on offer. The potato patty was delicious and goes well with the slightly sweet bun
author: Rakshit M.

description: Fabulous cocktails and service at the bar. Really enjoyed our time, and watching all the beautiful cocktails go by. Bartender did not seemed at all bothered to explain the menu to us, which was nice, since they are very busy. Will gladly return, and hope to sit at the bar again.
author: S. V.

description: Food was amazing. But the service was worst. We reserved the table a day ago for 9.45pm but when we reached we got the table at 10.30pm. Then the food was so late that even if we wanted to order something more , the kitchen was closed by then. Then one girl comes to take our plates in so much anger, as if we made her stay till late to work. Then when our bill came, we were charged extra. Everything went wrong.
author: Likitha S.

description:
I didn't even eat there. I just tried to buy a gift card for someone else.

First, I tried to buy a $30 gift card. Initially, they charged me sales tax on it. So I had to point this out and ask why they were charging tax on a gift card. It took a lot of effort for them to cancel the transaction and redo it correctly. 

Second, it's not a "real" gift card - it expires in one year, they said, which is illegal in California. Gift cards aren't allowed to have expiration dates. I didn't say anything because it likely wouldn't matter to them, but clearly the owner or manager isn't interested in actually researching the law.

Third, they gave me the card but no envelope. I asked for an envelope to put it in, and it took almost 10 minutes for someone to bring one.

I realize it's Saturday at 1 pm and I understand that you are likely busy, but I'm just asking for a little up front honesty here. If you can't give me a gift card, fine - I won't waste both our time. But if you claim to offer the service, I don't think it's unreasonable to expect the same exact gift card experience here as I get at literally any other restaurant.

It took 15 minutes for this whole thing.

I haven't even eaten here. Maybe the food is great! I don't know. After my experience here, I'm not really inspired to find out. Hopefully others don't encounter the same thing.
author: Nick M.

description: This is now my most favorite Indian restaurant that I've ever had ! We have the Vada Pav they were spicy and yummy and different but a great starter !!! I had the DOSA Masala and it's was quite delicious , my dad had the Tamil lamb curry it was super good also super tasty lots of yummy spices! We had the huge bread that looked like a big ball when they brought it out . Waitress was super friendly ! Atmosphere awesome , clean , poppin , good vibes !! Will be coming here again next SF trip !
author: Christina N.

description: I haven't been to the Oakland location yet, but so far this is my favorite Dosa location.  The vibe is trendy and the food is delicious.  Would highly recommend!
author: Ruchi P.

description: Great place for a date night or special occasion dinner. Really enjoy the atmosphere here -- more of an upscale vibe compared to your traditional Indian restaurants. Dosas are reasonably priced, but the curries are definitely on the pricier side. Staff was very friendly and greeted us upon entering the restaurant. They also explained the menu quite well.
author: Rochelle L.

description: Not a big fan of south Indian food but this place has some interesting menu options that you won't find at a normal south Indian cafe/restaurant. It's good for a change and they have a better ambience than typical south Indian restaurants. They do have a bar if you're interested to add some more kick with the spicy items on the menu. Overall, a decent place that I won't mind revisiting or taking family while they are visiting.
author: Varun V.

description:
We arrived early for our reservation for 4 and though the restaurant was empty we were told we would have to wait to be seated so we headed to the bar for cocktails. Just as we sat down the hostess came up and said they were ready to seat us. Odd since a moment before we would have to wait but ok, whatever.  We were seated right next to the kitchen and when we asked to be moved to one of the other tables we were told no becuase of all the other reservations! Really?! Were all of those 15 extra tables specifically reserved for certain Patrons? Doubt it. They were just not accommodating but we rolled with it as 3 of our party of 4 were visiting from out of town and had heard raves about the place.

Our server was competent and good, not exceptional but adequate. The food did not live up to the hype. It was good but again not exceptional. We had the following:
Lemon Chili Scallops 
Taco Frankie- everyone's favorite and wonderfully spicy
Chennai Chicken- moist and tender but lacking flavor
Spicy Mung Masala Dosa- Quite a disappointment in both the lack of spiciness and the fact I saw it on Iron Chef Eats and it was the reason for the entire trip there. The Dosa was perfect but fillings were again rather bland. Did NOT live up to it's hype
Peas and Paneer Dosa - I didn't taste this one but my friend didn't finish it despite saying it was pretty good.

All in all we expected a higher level of service and food.  I will say their private label Rosado was very good but not worth the hassle of reservations and non accommodating hosts.
author: Organic F.

description: This place is worth checking out for the full experience. The food was delicious and filling. Bartender was very engaging and provided good drink recommendations.
author: Yosef R.

description: Total rip off for the money. Ordered vada pav to go. The bread was fully buttered though I ordered with no butter. I asked for extra chutney on side and they gave me raita on side. It was a laughable situation. No Indian would have ever heard of raita and vada pav combination. Tiny couple of bites of vada pav for $7. Not worth it at all.
author: Shraddha A.

description:
I'm a big fan of Indian food and I have been to Indian restaurants all over the world. Dosa was probably one the better Indian restaurant I've been to if wasn't for the noise they called music.
The food was delicious and not too salty. The service was fast and our waiter did a good job explaining the menu and taking care of us. The place was very chic, trendy, and of course packed. The big problem with this place was the background music which was very loud and the kind of music that you would not expect to hear in an Indian restaurant. To top that, they had a really bad sound system that made  their choice of songs sound like a very loud annoying noise!!!!
author: Shabnam N.

description:
we were here for Sunday dinner with a craving for Dosa and Idlis.
It was busier than we thought. wait time 30 mins :O
So I looked up yelp and there is a reservation facility on the app. I reserved and got the table in 15 mins.
Tip: Reserve the table on Yelp prior to you getting there. esp on weekends.
The inside ambiance is very good. Sky tall roofs with antic wall decors.
We ordered Idli Sambhar and Masala Dosa as we started starving. Idli came in no time. You can guess why :p Idli was kinda Okish.
Dosa took a full 30 mins to  make it to our table. I almost lost the appetite for it already.
As I take a bite of it, can tell not fully cooked from inside, li'l bit sticky, but was tasty with Sambhar. Chatnees were OKish. Place with a name Dosa, you would expect the Dosa to be the finest. Nah! thats not the case. I would try this place again for other non Dosa dishes for its ambiance. hopefully will get my plate quicker.. :p
author: Trinadh N.

description:
In the city looking for gluten free vegan options this is the place to go. Written more about Dosa on my Facebook page.

https://www.facebook.com/CookHealNourish/posts/330425104049997
author: Reshma M.

description: Visited Dosa on Fillmore during my trip to SF. A great place with A+ service and great South Indian food. My wife and I ordered ginger garlic spice dosa. It was great. The drinks were also delicious.
author: Abhay S.

description:
I was excited to try Dosa since it's so popular. It's an upscale restaurant with absolutely beautiful decorations and friendly service. Maybe we didn't order the right things but my boyfriend and I just thought the food was mediocre.

They start by giving you a free serving of papad. I liked the crispy texture but I'm not a fan of the taste. We ordered the cochin calamari for an appetizer ($12). The calamari was sauteed and came with a small uttapam (pancake version of Dosa) and salad. The dish was flavorful and unique.

For entrees we each ordered a dosa. It comes with spicy lentil soup and tomato and coconut chutneys for dipping which were good. I got the white truffle masala dosa ($15) since I love truffles. The dosa was huge and crispy. I really enjoyed the potatoes inside but surprisingly neither my boyfriend and I could taste any truffle oil. My boyfriend ordered the paneer & peas dosa ($14.50). It came in three sections and was packed with paneer. That probably wasn't the best entree order since it felt so heavy eating that much cheese and we weren't able to finish the dish. The first few bites of it were okay but I liked the white truffle masala dosa a lot more.
author: Linda X.

description: This place is worth checking out for the full experience. The food was delicious and filling. Bartender was very engaging and provided good drink recommendations.
author: Sabrina P.

description: Food was good except that some of the dishes were very sour to taste - more than what they're supposed to be.
author: Guruguha M.

description:
I came here during SF Restaurant Week and did the special $40 menu with a couple of friends. The food was good but I did think it's a bit overpriced. 

DOSA on Fillmore may not look fancy from the outside, the interior decorations are all geared towards the hip SF vibe. Even though we had the special menu, unlike some other SF Restaurant Week participants, DOSA had a great combination of dishes. Since everything is severed family style, we were able to try a variety of different Indian food styles. I enjoyed the Classic Chicken DOSA and Vegetable Korma the most. Their dessert choices were pretty decent as well.

With drinks/tax/tip, we ended up paying about $65 per person. To be honest, this price is fairly reasonable for a semi-fancy sit-down restaurant. The portion is not bad and service is standard. I don't have anything particularly negative to say about it, but neither have I anything positive to highlight. I guess I'm just not in love :/
author: Angel C.

description:
Decor was well done and clean. 
Fantastic service, attentive and good suggestions. 
Food was quite good - had an extensive sampling of many dishes shared with friends. Most everything we had from various sections of the menu were really good. 
The Basil dosa was not as good as I would've imagined. 
Needed a bit more flavor from the filling. 
The Goan shrimp curry and Lamb curry were very tasty. 

Breads: The Paratha, dosa and Puree were great. 

Great place to go for quality South Indian food.
author: S J.

description:
Pros :
- really good food 
- dosas and sambar are perfect (texture 10/10 taste 9.5/10)
- friendly staff 
- the ambiance 
- the attention to detail in each dish
- the reservation/waiting list is modern

Cons:
- everything is overpriced (everything costs 3 times as much as it should) 
- small portions 
- the alcohol menu is a joke 
- ~1 hour waiting
author: Suryaa R.

description:
Ambiance (5/5): Walking into this place, I had no expectations. My gf just said it was a nicer Indian restaurant, so I just expected that. Boy was I wrong. This place is super chic. Besides the cool artwork hung around the area, or the chandeliers above, I was enamored with my experience here just looking around. My personal favorite was the automatic door in the front. Definitely a nice surprise.

Service (4/5): Our server was extremely sweet. She was very patient with our decision-making process on what to order as well as checking in with us from time to time. I did like how since we did order more than our table could hold, she actually staggered the meals so that we could have ample space to enjoy one, and promptly have the next one as soon as we finished. Also, another kind gentlemen came by for our drink orders while we were waiting to be seated. How rad is that to be treated well even before your seated.

Food (4/5): We shared the idli fries, sweet potato dosa, and lambed keema dosa. The fries were coated with this powder, which had a nice kick to it. The sweet potato dosa came out first and I loved the presentation. The sweet potato filling was hidden inside the nicely wrapped dosa. I liked the sponginess of the dosa, rather than the crispy sections. But that's just my preference. The sweet potato still had a savory flavor to them that I really enjoy. Plus the chutneys that came on the side also was a nice touch. We were pretty full by the time the lamb keema came out. I was a tad disappointed since the lamb was really finely diced, so you don't get the texture of the meat, but you can still taste it. It was a bit spicy, but we did enjoy it as well.

Drinks (4/5): I normally don't order drinks, but somtimes you have to treat yo'self. Being a huge Warriors fan, I knew I had to go with the Steph Curry. My gf also ordered the mango is the new black. I will say these drinks are strong, so you do get your moneys worth. But I did enjoy both drinks and I could see why Steph Curry has been one of their more popular drinks.
author: Alan N.

description: The shared plates were expensive, and not enough for two people. The food came out fast and the staff was definitely accommodating. Wonderful service but too expensive for the amount of food and not really that authentic.
author: Kim N.

description:
Basically this place is regular mediocre food served in a fancy setting. The decor gets full marks, the food disappointing at best. Just the name says dosa, but the dosa/idlis are no good.
The garlic and chile dosa wasn't any good. The idli and vada was cold and horrible. The bhutura was sweet and very oily, and tasted weird. The sambhar wasn't any good as well.
The paper dosa and paper masala dosa was the reason I give the one star.

Maybe the curries are good? Don't visit for any dosa or idlis. 
Management, please change the name to "Everything but dosas"...

Update:
Spoke to management about how I didn't like the food and I felt the management was genuinely interested in getting my feedback, which is reassuring. 
Maybe I will revisit.
author: Yash D.

description:
I've been to both this location and the location on Valencia. This location is newer and bigger and looks more high class, but the homeliness of the Valencia location offers up its own sense of charm.

-1 star because they took away the Mango Habanero Dosa. That was one of the best menu items despite being super spicy. None of the other "spicy" options live up. (I've had spicy basil and mung bean)

I came here during lunch and overheard a group of people who were non-Indian and unknowledgable about Indian food complaining that this was "not-authentic" because they didn't have naan or samosa on the menu. I felt it was necessary to state in my review that this is an AUTHENTIC Indian restaurant with fusion dishes but primarily focused in the South Indian region. Educate yourselves before you consider yourself an Indian cuisine aficionado. 

The mushroom uttapam is to die for. The rasmalai is extremely flavorful, something that is usually lacking in most Indian restaurants. All the dishes made here taste authentic and have a fusion flair. You can't miss out on this San Francisco charm.
author: Deepti N.

description: Looking forward to an early quiet dinner, we arrived at 5:30 and were seated in their spacious dining room that, I think they want to double as a nightclub. The music had a steady beat beat beat that drove all 4 of us crazy begging the wait staff to lower the volume. It truly ruined our experience. The food was also disappointing and each dish pretty much tasted like another...I had been there about 9 months before and loved it dragging friends back to join me. We were all disappointed and felt like it was a real missed opportunity. We won't be back.
author: Ruth F.

description:
We were famished after a long walk around the city. We were craving for some Indian food, and DOSA on Fillmore popped right up on Yelp! We order vada pav for appetizer, and it was a good start. The tamarind chutney on the vada pav complimented the chili/caramelized onion relish. It's very different from what you get in the streets of Mumbai, but sumptuous nonetheless. For the main course we ordered Poori, Asparagus Utthappam, and paneer butternut squash dosa. The Poori was the only mediocre dish, but the others were finger licking good. We rounded it off with some Rasmalai, which was easily the highlight of the course.
One star off for the Poori, will definitely visit again.
author: Bala R.

description:
This one star goes to the service at front desk and their take out order processing. I ordered a take out that had a missing item. 

1st Call:
Called back to tell them about it. After 5 minutes of getting all the details from me, the hostess says she would pass the phone to manager and then promptly hung up.

2-4th Calls:
Goes straight to voicemail 

5th Call:
Another hostess picks up. Asks again for the details. Kind of plays down the fact that one item is missing from that I paid for. Then tells the manager will tend to it as soon as possible. I say OK, I'll wait and she says no, call back after two hours. I argue with her that's unacceptable, finally she puts me on phone with the manager who took 20 seconds to confirm that I'll now be charged the right amount.

I understand it's hard to run a busy restaurant, but that's no excuse for poor service like this when you charge $6 rasams and $4 chais. Not asking for gold platters, but serve what customers pay you for and when you get it wrong, be apologetic, gracious and not make the customer jump through hoops and wait 2 hours for a refund.

P.S. did I mention that the take order of uttappams didn't have a single chutney included? And that's not the missed item.
author: Varun K.

description: Fantastic experience, from fusion cocktails at the gorgeous naturally light filled bar, to Kerala inspired tasting menu of 10-11 selections, from the crab-puri starter to the dosa finish. The small courses were well selected between seafood, poultry and vegetarian. Chicken sorry with coconut rice was divine.  Order the Steph Curry if you like Bourbon.
author: S A.

description:
I was really split between giving this place a 3 or 4 stars, but eventually I decided I had to go with a 4 -- it was good food, after all. 

DOSA is a great place to try out some authentic South Indian food and as someone from that part of the country, I really liked the food but one thing bothered me. 

The portion size. 

We ordered the Thali and got very little rice. So little there wasn't enough to mix it with most of what was provided with the meal. When I'm paying $20, I'd expect more than just one tiny cup of rice and the fact that you can't get refills just makes this terrible value, imo. 

The taste and service were top-notch. I see there are some mixed reviews about the service here, but maybe I didn't dine during a peak hour. We constantly had someone taking care of us and recommending stuff to try out.
author: Gouthaman K.

description: I cannot rave enough about both the food,  remarkable service, and chic ambience of this place. The dosas were better than the ones I've had in India. The onion dosa, especially. The drinks were fantastic, very flavorful and packed with a punch.
author: Tara K.

description: Total fan of Indian cuisine and spice. Had dinner on a weekday, made a reservation for 6:30 pm arrive 15 minutes early and was told to what at the bar. Highlights of items ordered spicy mung masala and spiced carrot cake.
author: Gigi H.

description:
Being an Indian food fan, I am so happy I have finally come here.  We came for my husbands birthday, had a great night.  The service was absolutely perfect.  They make you feel special, and you can tell the servers here love their job.  

We started with cocktails, they were so good, there is a reason they have a good reputation for cocktails.  South Indian food is so tasty.  We had the uttapam sampler, the rava masala dosa and the famous chicken dish.  The starter was the papadem chips with the delicious chutneys.  Everything was so good, I can't wait to go back.

The atmosphere is really beautiful, great spot for date night, very romantic setting.  The bar is beautiful, just really well done.  This will be my new spot to take friends, especially friends from out of town.
author: Carole W.

description:
Few years ago your food was great and carried the depth of South Indian flavor. 

Now it's watered down an insipid. What happened?
author: Joe V.

description:
Yes. Yes! Yup. Mhm. Yep. Do it. Eat here. 

Plus it's like the only thing open past 9. 

- Chennai chicken - really good! Like popcorn chicken but more flavor, less batter, and more skin left on the roof of your mouth
- Masala Dosa - like a thin crispy pancake with potato filling, delicious
- Chili uttapam - coated in jalapeño and habanero and guaranteed to make you lose your sense of smell for a bit. It takes its time in doing so. Good thing the napkins are big and absorbent
- Mango lassi - fantastic and a must, if you'd like to cry less post-uttapam
- Coconut basmati rice

In total it was about $30 per person, plus we couldn't finish. Very reasonable for a night full of incredible flavors. 

The service was also outstanding; our waitress explained what each category was, recommended how to order, and explained each dipping sauce. At 10pm. Graciously.
author: Connie L.

description:
Great food - the Idli fries being my favorite. Chutneys were very fresh and flavorful. I tried the chef's 5 utthapam sampler - loved it. The rasmalai was mediocre - probably made using nanak's ras malai ready to eat - the taste and shape were exactly the same.

The ambiance is pretty upscale and so is the service. Would love to visit again.
author: Namrata J.

description: Favourite restaurant in SF  Satisfies those spice cravings with a twist on the usual Indian fare
author: Aditi A.

description:
Been here a few times.
Dosa - always good.  Coconut chutney could be better but the other accompaniments are good.
Spicy Uttapam - good, no joke on the spice, highest tolerance needed.
Spicy Avocado Chaat - meh.  It's basically just avocado in some watery spice mixture, with an odd mix of grapefruit pieces on top and very minimal crispy shavings.  Nothing like a traditional chaat if that's what you're thinking.
Vada Pav - good, some zest. 
Mint Lemonade - good.
Ambiance - good.  Seem to usually be busy even at not-busy hours, or at least they say they can't open a table at 5:30 even though you can see empty tables...
author: Ro C.

description:
This is an awesome restaurant and we absolutely love the food. Finally an Indian restaurant that's super clean, great service, clean restroom, and excellent service. 

Also, they didn't have any incense burning which is very common in South Indian restaurants.  

We would love to come back here and try other items on their menu. 

Great experience!!
author: D B.

description: Dosa catered lunch and dinner for my wedding at the Westin St. Francis, and they did an absolutely amazing job. First, Ashley, their wedding coordinator, is completely lovely.  She's a great communicator and she really knows her stuff.  Second, they worked with us to create unique menus for each lunch and dinner, so nothing felt stale or repetitive.  Third, their execution was flawless.  We had a very mixed crowd at my wedding and everyone, without exception, raved about the food.  Everyone was able to find something they enjoyed, and the freshness of the ingredients and inventiveness of the dishes was really impressive.  I was slightly apprehensive about having Indian catering at my wedding, but these guys really brought their A game and made it work, and made it really memorable.
author: Salini N.

description: This food makes me feel ashamed of being South Indian. Ironic how the complimentary saunf they give you to get rid of the aftertaste was better than the actual food.
author: Aditya V.

description: The food is great here. Obviously don't expect the most authentic south Indian food but they have a lot of creative options. The drinks are good too. Be sure to make a reservation on the busy nights.
author: Nav R.

description:
Food: Close to perfection. Innovative dishes, well thought out to preserve authenticity. 

Service: We had a reservation for 7pm. We came in first at 640 and waited till 730 to get a table. I really thought we had a reservation.

The receptionist seemed hardly concerned about keeping up with our reservation. After reminding her twice we finally got a table. Taking our orders took more than 15 mins, we never got our waters which we had to go to the counter to get. At the end no one seemed interested in getting us the check. We went to the reception to pay.

Ambience: it was alright until they put up a new table half a foot away from ours that made it harder for themselves to serve us. Not that they seemed too keen on doing so throughout the night.

The quality of the food pulled our rating up from 1 star to 3. I wish the rest of the staff were as interested in doing their jobs as the chefs.
author: Do J.

description:
I am so sad to be giving this place just 3 stars. Here's the run down -
I understand this place gets crazy busy but not a good enough excuse to completely neglect your table. The staff is friendly but I was dying for a refill on my water and a second cocktail but they placed us on the upper deck and pretty much forgot about us. 
At a table of cocktail lovers, they really dropped the ball and missed some solid revenue because we were excited to try all of them! 

The FOOD though. It's so good. Hands down one of the most delicious Indian food restaurants I've been to. Try all the variations of dosa - cannot go wrong with any of them. Also, try to vada pav and chennai chicken. I also recommend the #sarinotsari cocktail since like I said, I did get to try just one. 

One tip - please don't forget about your tables even if you place them upstairs. Thanks!
author: Kay A.

description: We thoroughly enjoyed their delicious and presumably healthy tasting menu and appreciated that they were happy to swap out the shellfish dishes because of an allergy. I feel perhaps we would have left not quite full if we hadn't stuffed our faces with the delicious pappadums (slightly disappointing that we had to order chutneys separately). Dosas not really my thing but will definitely return for the curries.
author: Sarah G.

description: Overall, the food and service were great. We got the Vada Pav and chutney platter -- was a bit surprised they charged for chutney  For the main course, I had a Paper Masala Dosa and my friend had a Chilli Garlic Dosa and they were both excellent. My Dosa came out a bit cold, but they replaced it immediately and all was good. Reserved via Yelp Reservations and the experience was seamless. A bit pricey, but hey, this is San Francisco. I'd recommend this place for a special occasion or a nice night out - but reserve in advance as it tends to get full and you may end up having to sit at the community table.
author: Aditya V.

description: Despite the wait and many of the recommendations I have heard about this place I was very disappointed.  Both the wait and the food were really unimpressive.  I do need to advise though that this place is not your typical regional indian cuisine that most are used to.  The flavors, aside from that, were not working for me and the plates were not too exciting to temp your palate and excite the curious consumer.  If you want more of the traditional (one you are more accustomed to) indian food there is one a couple doors up Fillmore.  I would only go back if someone was treating me.  Otherwise, enjoy the decent atmosphere and the pre/post stroll up and down Fillmore street.
author: Mike M.

description: Wonderful ambience and friendly staff at this Indian Fusion restaurant.  The chicken curry was very good.  It was enough to share with my wife.  The gravy that it came in was especially tasty and the almonds added the extra..!  I'm glad we made the choice while visiting San Francisco - I see myself coming back on my next visit!
author: Kenny M.

description:
This DOSA is at a beautiful location with high ceilings and stunning chandeliers! The bar area is half the restaurant so the wait for a table can be quite long. 

We started by eating appetizers at the bar. The Brussel sprouts and samosas dishes were both colorful and beautifully plated. The Brussel sprouts also had an interesting fusion of flavors and nuts. The samosas are smaller triangles and only came with the green sauce-- the tamarind sauce was just a small dripping on the plate. 

The dosas were good! We had the spicy pear dosa and the rava masala dosa. At first I wasn't sure if I had received the pear one because the potato flavor overpowered the light pear taste in the wrap. But eating more of the wrap by itself revealed the lightly sweet taste

Overall, the service here is not great. The waitress would come interrupt us repeatedly mid-conversation to check in. But when we wanted to get the attention of the waitress, she wasn't around. When we asked someone else for help, she told us we had to ask our own waitress
author: Jenny K.

description:
While the food here is fantastic, beware of the management and service. 

I would definitely not recommend this restaurant for a larger group. Any group over 13 people requires rental of a semi-private place in the mezzanine - and this comes with an astronomical price tag.

I called to make a reservation for a birthday dinner for 16 people, including a toddler that would not be eating. The price tag for this reservation was a $2,700 food and beverage minimum and a mandatory fixed menu. Say what?!?! This would come out to nearly $180/head, which puts this restaurant in the Michelin star category, which it clearly is not. While the food a good, it is a far cry from being worth $180/head! If we were not required to order off of a pre-fixed menu and book a semi-private room with a minimum, there is no way we would spend anywhere close to this amount. The price of a dosa is less than $20!

When I questioned the per head fee, noting that the mandatory fixed menu cost would be $45 per person for a vegetarian menu and explained that over half our party doesn't drink so consuming wine would not make up the price gap, I was given no other alternative. The catering director was rigid, rude, and inflexible. She basically said we could rent the space or not be given the opportunity to reserve a table.

She then went into detail about how she had to turn tables at a certain rate to make a profit so I suppose our family wasn't worth taking up a precious table at this establishment. The pretentious attitude made me sick - clearly all these people care about is making a profit. They don't care if it means turning away customers that aren't as "profitable".

In a city of numerous top notch restaurants, there really is no need to frequent this place. They have lost some of their most loyal customers, as we will not be returning. The food is good, but not good enough to put up with terrible management and service. If you want a good Dosa, try just about any of the hole in the wall restaurants off EL Camino in the South Bay. You will pay far less, the food will be far better, and they will appreciate your business more than DOSA will.
author: Neelam P.

description:
Pretty exceptional. Our dosas were super good, probably best Indian food we've found in SF.
We had a short window as we were catching a movie - the Kabuki is right across the street!
Anyway the service was very responsive and got us served very quickly.
Also for the quality of food and ambiance we found their prices very moderate.
author: Jonathan G.

description:
