author: Joys C.

description:
I'm Indian. Great dosas, with a modern twist, good cocktails. But for a dosa, it's pricey. 

I've gone 5 or so times, and really enjoy it. But it's definitely dosa's done upscale.
author: Dimple B.

description:
This restaurant is really beautiful and the drinks are excellent. I highly recommend the peony!  A little sweet but it has a kick. The hostesses were great and we were promptly seated upon arrival (reservations recommended). The food was good- not great- but good.

My main issue with Dosa was the service. We came here for my girlfriend's birthday, and I put that on the reservation and informed the hostess upon arrival. I had requested a special dessert to be brought out after dinner. We bought 4 cocktails, got the tasting menu (spent a good chunk of money-not the most but decent) and we were treated like afterthoughts. The waiter hardly acknowledged us, never brought out dessert, and it was just really disappointing. I won't be back. Really disappointed after reading all the great reviews :(
author: Sophia D.

description:
Oh my oh my oh my. The Dosa's alone are worth crossing the city for. Try the Masala Chutney Dosa and share around the table (or hoard it for yourself!)
The food here is creative, fresh and flavorful. It's also pricy but maybe that's just the Filmore neighborhood? Take my advice, spend some time with the drinks menu, the mixologists here are fantastic.
I saw a couple of reviews here that complained about the service, but it was fine for me and everybody tells me I'm the worst service critic around. 

For the person who complained that people kept joining the table and then wanting to order? That's service nightmare, How would you like to try to get all those orders in and then have to add, add, change, add and then the customer wants all the food together? Jeez. Get over it, the problem is you not the servers'. 
This is why restaurants don't seat a party until everybody is there. Simply rude.
author: J F.

description:
I've often walked by this place wanting to try it based on how great it smells and the crowd.  I finally did last night and meh.

Hostess was great.  Full of energy and smiles.  Our table was delayed but not a problem, off to the bar we went.....I liked the sound of their mango drink but without gin.  I asked if we can do it with another alcohol and I got an instant NO. WE'VE CREATED OUR DRINKS TO TASTE GREAT AS IS.  Understood, extra chilled martini it is.  Reluctantly he poured me one stating that martini's are chilled.  

We are seated where we ask the waitress to please guide us since we aren't too familiar with the food and are open to taste anything.  'Do you just want a chicken and rice? It's good' that's it.  That's as far as her recommendations got.  We added the prawns, raita & chutney.  We received the chicken and rice, 20min later the prawns where we asked if we can have warm rice since it was now cold.  They returned with that where I asked if she can check on the chutney for us... 20min later received that.  We were surrounded by 3 open tables.  It wasn't packed.  Though management kept visiting the table next to us, no one noticed our empty drinks for at least 30min.  I tried one of their 'great tasting' signature cocktails and it was syrup in a glass.  I left it behind.  We didn't mind the high bill in the end.  The food tasted good though cold and served with large gaps of time in between.
author: Ange M.

description: We had the best time at DOSA on Fillmore!  My friends and I (group of 8) came here for dinner during SF Restaurant Week and were treated like royalty by the amazing staff.  The food and drinks are amazing and the service is impeccable.  I'll definitely be coming back here often!
author: Robert H.

description: Great, great food and service was good even on busier day. It's best so far South Indian food i had in SF.
author: Ankita C.

description:
Late review.  Dined here a year ago with my husband.  Nice ambiance with high ceilings.  They transformed this building to a nice one.  I think it looks better than the one on the mission.  Be careful with their floor, it can get slippery especially with heels on.  
We decided to their Menu prixe.  I don't remember what was included but it's a great way to try their dishes.  I like how they use local ingredients.  Definitely worth a try.
author: Claire J.

description:
I got here around 5:45p on a Thursday, and managed to get a table for 4 at the bar for happy hour instantly.  FYI--Happy hour is Monday through Thursday from 5:30p-7:00p  It got busy quick, and by the time my party of 4 left around 7:30, the bar was pretty packed.  So get here early!

Disclaimer: I never finished my PhD in Indian cuisine, so I cannot attest to the authentic-ness of the food here, but I enjoyed Dosa's food along with the chic-lounge atmosphere.

My happy hour beverage of choice:
-Chili-margarita! ($6)  Your basic margarita with a spicy kick.  I'll take two!  It might not be on the menu when you go, because I think the happy hour drinks rotate.

Happy hour menu choices:
-Samosas 'North and South':  Maybe it was the chili margaritas, but I couldn't really tell the difference between North and South (i'm talking about the food here, not my motor skills).  Regardless, the dipping sauces are what really made this dish.
-Chennai chicken (2 orders): I love the popcorn chicken at Tapioca Express, and that is basically what this is, minus the spice.  Served with a creamy, tangy yogurt sets this apart from your typical TapX chicken.  The chicken was crunchy on the outside, yet juicy and tender on the outside.  One order should be sufficient for two people if you are sampling other goodies.  
-Vada Pav (vegetarian slider):  Two sliders per order.  Not my favorite dish of the night, but definitely worth a try.

Dosa choices:
-Paper masala:  Delicious!  Pretty simple dish consisting of a paper-thin crepe served with Indian potatoes and dipping sauces.  This is a definitely a staple dish that I order when I go to Dosa. 
-White truffle masala:  Delicious x 2.  Essentially the paper masala, but with the Indian potatoes drizzled with truffle oil and stuffed inside the crepe.  I'm drooling just thinking about it.

At $34 per person, this isn't the cheapest happy hour I've been to (then again I've probably dropped more at other happy hours on booze alone), so I take back my statement.  Overall, a fun place to go for happy hour--great food, delicious drinks, and a chic atmosphere!
author: Matt S.

description:
Dosa was a unique restaurant 

When you walk in, you notice the beautiful high ceilings and long chandeliers, impressive art work. The piece behind the main bar is 12 feet with has writing in Arabic and other languages. 

The food menu was reasonably priced and quite the variety of spices and flavors. I had the shrimp masaqa and it was delicious! 

Wine menu was tasty as well..Service was excellent! 

Will defiantly go back next time I am in SF!
author: Nawar F.

description:
Looking to experience the finer side of Indian Dining, my friend and I decided to make a trip out to Dosa.  We didn't make reservations so we had to make 45 minutes (not really a problem since we were able to explore Japantown a bit).  

Once seated we knew knew we were going straight for the Duck Vindaloo and Prawn Masala.  We need help with the Dosa selection though because wel, there are so many.  We ended up with the White Truffle Masala.

The Duck Vindaloo was quite good.  The Vindaloo sauce itself had the typical spicy/sour taste, but unlike the ones you get at "lesser" Indian places, the flavors truly danced on your taste buds.  I didn't get to taste the duck breast, but ended up with the leg instead.  Honestly, it was just okay, but I have always preferred breast of drumstick.  The Prawn Masala was also quite good.  Another dish that was enhanced with the use of higher standard ingredients.  The flavor was familiar, but more sophisticated.  The Dosa was delicious, and the white truffle oil really stood out.  Flaky, crispy, and chewy all at once  Best pairing is with the lentil soup, which I thought was amazing!

We also had a couple of drinks.  My friend got the Peony and she thought it was on the sweeter side.  I got the Winter Smash and thought it was quite delicious.  So delicious I got another.

Service was quick, friendly and helpful, and really compliments the more sophisticated Indian atmosphere.
author: Veasna H.

description:
I've been to Dosa every time I have visited SF. There are several reasons for this:

- The food is always good
- The food looks beautiful
- The drinks are always good

The most memorable dish here has been the White-Truffle-Oil masala dosa. I would have never thought that truffle oil goes so well with masala dosa. Also, their chutneys and sambhar have always been very good.

The last time I visited we had the dahi bhalla and it was a masterpiece - both in terms of presentation and taste - so kudos!

The cocktail menu is competent and the staff know their stuff.

In the end, I would recommend Dosa in a heartbeat and visit again.
author: Aprameya R.

description: Awesome place for date night and taking friends and family to an upscale restaurant. Vada Pav is the best!
author: Dhruti D.

description: I did a large group birthday party here and it was really easy to reserve for up to 14 people (using Yelp SeatMe) and even change the size (as people confirmed or just showed up - the usual SF group dynamics).  The service was great and the food was awesome.  Usual issues with large groups and splitting the bill but other than that was great.
author: Daniel Y.

description: Good ambiance, service is outstanding! Servers actually take the time out to listen to u. Awesome place to take a date. Amazing food and drinks. Be aware it can b pricy about 15-20$ per dish on Avg. i love their 40$ family menu. Includes like 3-4 items.  Its worth it tho.
author: Sean J.

description:
Great date spot. The indian food is definitely made for a western palate but it's executed well and the ambiance can't be beat.

High ceilings with a swanky bar area. The food here is substantial to say the least. Definitely share. and definitely get a Dosa (they're like giant samosas without the fried skin).

Unique cocktail list "made for spicy food". 

Don't come here expecting an authentic indian experience. but DO come here to hang with friends or on a date because it won't be a controversial choice.
author: Alice Z.

description:
Is this place overpriced, yes; there's no debate there. But that's the ONLY con. So if you can get past the price, stay tuned, because everything else is so damn good. 

Ambience? Great. Two stories, great service, romantic lighting at night, bright during the day/for brunch. 

Cocktails? Truly some of the best in the city, if you're looking for interesting flavors and new combinations. The Peony w/ coconut milk, gin, and fresh chilies is my go-to, and you can't really get anything similar elsewhere. Same goes for many of the other cocktails. 

Beer/Wine? List is huge, and includes hard cider and multiple sparkling wines by the glass. 

Food? Fantastic california-indian food, that's fresh, interesting, and well presented. You can get your basic masala and rice, or get adventurous and pick something you've never had before; same goes for dosa. They also do a very relaxed brunch on the weekends, that has great dosa filled with scrambled eggs and indian spiced potatoes on the side. 

If you're a first-timer or a little worried about heat, I'd get the panner & pea dosa; even kids could have that. But if you want to branch out, do the tasting menu; it's totally worth it. The salad they had during the spring with fried goat-cheese balls, watermelon radishes, and curry vinaigrette was REALLY GOOD. The biryani are also great, as are any of the dosas. The uttapams are small, compared to everything else, but are a nice snack or small plate. 

If you're visiting SF, want a great night out, or want to take an adventure with food, this is totally the place. Use OpenTable to book a reservation online, as it's a busy place and the wait can be 45+ mins on a Fri or Sat night, without a reservation.
author: Laura J.

description:
In short: Good ambiance and good service, but overpriced for the decent food quality. 

We have been here only twice. The service has been good, specially on the most recent visit. The ambiance is a little too dark in some zones but still good. The food quality is decent but not on par with similarly priced restaurants in San Francisco.
author: Fardad H.

description:
Wow! A little envious of the San Franciscans for having this fantastic restaurant so close in proximity! 

I love Indian food and since I've moved from Washington DC to LA its been hard to find authentic Indian food. All the places in LA are extremely casual and nothing too exciting. 

Enter, the perfect opportunity to eat some great Indian while in SF! Dosa on Fillmore is Southern Indian. I had never had southern Indian before and it's different dishes than the Northern Indian but same flavors and perhaps more spicy. 

We ordered a lot of food - in hindsight, way too much food! We started with the chennai chicken - a glorified and much more flavorful version of the chicken nugget. This nugget had it going on! It was organic (yes organic at an Indian restaurant!) marinated in organic yogurt with cumin and coriander and fried. But they really didn't taste fried. 

For entrees we ordered the lamb chops (omg these were good), the chicken biryani and the white truffle dosa (a potato filled crepe). The lamb chops came with a mildy spiced lentil sauce that had a sweetness to it that I loved. The chicken was shredded and tender mixed into basmati rice with caramelized onions, peas and cashews and was tender and amazing! The dosa smelled of white truffles but didn't really taste like truffles much, which was a bit of a let down.  

We also got the bhatura - this large puffy bread that reminded me of a donut in the best possible of ways. Yummy! 

Everything was much spicier than I anticipated. I was really feeling the heat, which I loved, but I know for someone who is spice averse this would be a turn off. 

I would have loved to try their desserts but I was SO full that there was no chance. 

The space is big, open and modern. It was very lively on a Wednesday night at 9pm. I Will definitely come back here when I am back in SF!
author: Brittany F.

description:
In my opinion the highest quality Indian food in SF.  Ambiance is great, food is always high quality, great service.  

Great for sharing plates.  Also a great date spot, but probably want to call ahead and make a reservation as it very popular.  

My favorites: Veggie sliders, truffle dosa, chana bhatura, all amazing!

Kudos Dosa!
author: Paul H.

description:
We ordered basil dosa and karaikudi chicken korma. Both the dishes were tasty with good enough quantity. The food was tasty but nothing exceptional. One star less because they served frozen parathas - one you get in Indian stores. Clearly!!!!!

.
author: Rini R.

description:
Modern appeal to authentic South-Indian Cuisine. 
Staff is polite and efficient. 
They use fresh ingredients. Good Quality and Quantity.
Must go - again!
author: Namrata S.

description:
Good Food, good presentation, friendly staff. We sat at the Bar. It was great. 
Thank you Binod,
author: Dylan R.

description: Great food with a variety of breads.  Will definitely go back...
author: Andrew G.

description:
This is an upscale Indian place that specializes in Southern Indian cuisine (their own description). The ambience is nice and romantic. Well, but that was ruined because we were seated at a communal table, across from each other. On our right side, one guy and two women in their middle ages were talking about some serious mid-life crisis stuff (at some point, they talked about an ex-wife who did voodoo right in front of her son). On our left side, a couple was dining and talking about some classy movie stars like Keanu Reeves. It was amusing to umm not intentionally overhear everything they were saying, but it definitely did not make a great date spot (the communal table, that is).          

They offered a $42 three-course meal that can be shared between two people, and my boyfriend and I took the deal after making very quick calculations. 

It was definitely enough food for two. We ended up getting:  

1st course: Seafood vada - not recommended. This was more like a seafood pancake that doesn't really taste like seafood. They could have told me it was a potato pancake and I would not have known the difference. Get something else! 

2nd course: Dosas with lamb (+ we got masala on the side). Meh. Dosa tasted like a not as tasty version of Ethiopian sour dough rolls. They provided two types of chutney with dosas, but that wasn't flavored strongly enough to complement the sour taste of dosa. The lamb was okay, and the masala was okay. But I didn't think anything was great or amazing. Also, they only gave us one roll of dosa and we thought given the price, we would have liked one more.    

3rd course: Chicken Xacut. This was actually pretty good. It was spicy (pretty spicy), red Indian curry with chicken in it served with rice.  

All in all, I thought it was a good one-time experience. But I would not seek this place out again, especially at their price.
author: Wonhee P.

description:
Staying in Japantown for the weekend, looking for something tasty -- score!   The place was nearly full, and we had no reservations, but we lucked out.  (Many thanks to the hostess!)   There were three of us, so we decided to splurge and order a bunch of things to share -- good decision.

Started with the chutney sampler -- everyone found a new favorite.
  
North and South samosas -- North were some of the best potato samosas I've had, but the South was delightfully sweet and savory.  Warning -- that innocent little side salad has something quite spicy in/on it.  The tamarind chutney had been in the sampler, but cilantro chutney was different, and not scary spicy.

Bhatura - big, poofy, and delicious -- with or without any of the many chutneys available on the table by the time we were done.  (It lasted pretty much the whole meal.)

Lamb boti kebab -- yummy, but if we weren't splurging, it wouldn't make the cut.

Chennai chicken was delightful with and without the yogurt dip on the side.  Lots of finger-size pieces, perfect for sharing.

The lamb dosa had the lamb on the side, along with two more chutneys, different from the others, and the sambar soup.  Definitely will get that again.  So flavorful.

The potato dosa was good too, but again, if we weren't splurging, it wouldn't make the cut.  Same sambar and chutneys as the lamb dosa.

So much food, but we figured it wouldn't hurt to look at the dessert menu.  Glad we did.

White chocolate pot creme -- next time, we'll get two.  The perfect contrast to all the spicy foods that preceded it.

Coconut custard cake -- not sure why this is called cake.  Tasty, but the pot creme dessert took the blue ribbon.

We don't get to the City often, but this will be on our list for a return trip -- with reservations next time.  And definitely when we have vegetarian friends along.
author: Susan R.

description: Great place. Gets my 5 star rating.
author: Prashant U.

description:
While the food and drink at Dosa are amazing, these five stars really belong to our server. I can only imagine waiting on our table of many-a-loudmouth to be a bit like herding cats, so my hat is off to you, bespectacled gent with great taste in cocktails. Sadly, I forget your name. Happily, I have not forgotten anything about the food. 

We all opted for the three-course tasting menu, so I was able to pinch off of my neighbors plates to get a better sampling. It all started with a fabulous Chicory and Pear Salad: so fresh, so bright, so thoughtfully put together and then dressed with the single most delicious cilantro dressing I've ever had. I also nipped a bit of the shredded duck which was rich and decadent and totally special. However, my next course was the absolute stand-out: Winter Uttapam with caramelized fennel, sun-dried tomatoes and a smattering of root veg. The star was the actual pancake -- dense without being doughy and subtly flavorful. 

Where I ran into a bit of trouble was course #3, the Chicken Xacuti. Now, I like spice. I like spice this side of hot. I can throw back, seriously. This, however, was the kind of snot-inducing, drool-triggering, heartburn-churning heat that my wee Scottish stomach is just not built for. I silently suffered until I saw my colleagues around the table fanning the flames, as well. However, if you are a scoville scholar and enthusiast, this is the dish for you. 

Another component worthy of noting: the drinks! I stuck with my favorite, a bourbon Old Fashioned but several of my fellows wadded into the creative cocktail pool and all were delicious and refreshing. They're quite unique, so this is where your server will come in handy -- just ask and (if you're as lucky as we were) you'll be perfectly paired with a terrific tipple.
author: Hilary H.

description:
As our home-base was Japantown in SF, my fiancee and I looked for something new for dinner on a Wednesday night. After some Yelp sleuthing, we came upon Dosa on Fillmore. 

Something that we haven't tried before? Yep!
Something that isn't Japanese food? Yep!
We didn't require transit to get there? Yep!
The meal wouldn't break the bank? Yep!

So with that information in tow, we walked 5 minutes from our hotel to Dosa on Fillmore. To our surprise, the restaurant was quite upscale, but still retained a casual feel. We were greeted by the friendly hostess, who quickly led us to our table (booked on OpenTable). 

Of course, we couldn't go to an establishment named after a food and not try said food item. So along with a Masala Dosa, my fiancee ordered a Paneer & Cheese Uttapam and an order of the Chennai Chicken to start. 

First came some homemade lentil chips. It was a bit oily, but burst with flavour (surprising, since the chip itself is very plain from what I assumed was ground lentils). I could only have a single chip, but oil aside the flavour was great. 

Soon after, we received the Chenna Chicken, which was served in a bowl on top of a bed of red onions along with a savoury yogurt-based dipping sauce. This was my favorite part of the meal. The chicken pieces were breast meat, but still remained juicy. The seasoning had a substantial spicy kick to it, but when paired with the yogurt dip the flavours all came together and only really nice touch of heat remained at the end of the bite. 

Next came the dosa, which comes with 3 dipping sauces: a spicy lentil soup, and a pair of tomato  and coconut chutneys. The lentil soup by itself explodes with flavour. The chutneys were both very delicious as well. As for the dosa itself- the dosa is basically a large, thin crepe folded in half with the filling inside. The crepe had a wonderful sweetness to it that mixed very well with the dipping sauce flavours. The filling (in this case potatoes, onions and cashews) was also very good, but was a touch heavy (since it's almost all starch). That said, all the flavours came together really well, and no one ingredient overpowered any of the others. The variety in dipping sauce flavours kept each bite different from the next, so overall it was a very engaging meal. I honestly thought we didn't order enough and insisted we order something else (the uttapam), but after the dosa and chicken starter my fiancee and I were stuffed. However, the uttapam came to the table so we couldn't ignore it. 

The uttapam is basically a pancake with various ingredients embedded in it, and sliced like a pizza for your enjoyment. The same dipping sauces that accompany the dosa are present, providing the same flavour variety you get with the dosa. From what we could finish, the uttapam was delicious as well. The paneer (cheese) was mild, and added a nice creaminess to the dish which otherwise would've been a touch on the dry side. 

I was really glad my fiancee decided to try this place. While she doesn't share the same enthusiasm as I do with the meal, it opened my eyes to another delicious aspect of Indian cuisine that I never knew existed. I just hope that the few dosa eateries in Vancouver are as good as this place was.
author: Vincent A.

description:
A very nice upscale South Indian restaurant offering a variety of Dosas. We tried the Uttapam platter, Paneer Dosa, Medu Vada and the Mimmosa. The uttapam platter and paneer dosa was really very good. Found the Medu Vada to be decent.

I would recommend to make reservations at this place.
author: Bhanik S.

description:
This is such an amazing place. We ran into this place by accident, when we were hungry. We just walked in (apparently, this place is so busy. We just got lucky that day). It was Cherry Blossom festival as well so the place was super crowded. We ate Truffle dosa (chef's advice), Kesar dosa and Thali. All tastes really yummy. I strongly recommend this place. 

The only reason i gave 4 stars is because they did not want to take a reservation for 14 people, when i want to take my friends on a weekend. I think considering how big the place is, and how good the food tastes, they can really take big group reservations. Not sure, why did they turn down that day. But with a small group, any time and any day i will go. No regrets!!
author: Venugopal V.

description:
We came here for the first time in a whim when deciding SF Restaurant Week spots to hit up. RW just started a day ago and we were in Jtown. Perfect.

We sat down expecting to order from the RW menu, but we did not. It was $85 per person for 4 courses each. We ended up ordering 4 plates ala carte and walked out with food left over for $85 total.

The samosas (chicken and potatoes) were great. Probably the best I've ever had. The chicken filling was especially flavorful. The lamb keema dosa was also memorable. The dosa was crispy and light. Perfectly paired with the lamb.

The fiancée was also feeling adventurous and ordered the chili uttapam. It's got Serranos, jalapeños, habaneros and Thai chilis. It was extremely spicy for me, but the heat and the flavor just left me going back for more. Make sure you get your water refilled often! The green coconut chutney helped cool it down as well.

My disappointment of the night was this chicken dish under the curry menu. Chicken chennai I think? The curry it came in was more like a gravy. Obvious cinnamon taste, but it's salty. My first impression was literally WTF. Salty, creamy, cinnamon-y taste. I did not have more than 2 bites of the uttapam that I dipped in this.

Extra points for accepting apple pay through open table!
author: L M.

description:
3.5 stars

No drafts, all bottled.  Complimentary chips of some kind, a bit salty for my taste but hubby liked it.  I didn't see the non alcoholic drink menu until after we ordered.  I would have liked to try their chai.

Sudwerk Lager - $6.5
Sam Smith organic apple cider - $10 - tasted like Martinelli, maybe a good way to start drinking
sardine - $12 - 2 whole sardines fried w/ a bit of pickled veggie salad.  
Rasam - $4 - spicy broth, lots of spices and flavors
South Indian Moons - chef's choice of uttapam - $13.5 - there were 5 or 6 uttapam, that are like mini pancakes.  hubby said they are all a little different but they tasted the same.  There were 3 sauces - only wish the waiter or the person who brought the plate over could have told us what they were.  There was one large cup that was hot with a hint of curry and other Indian spices and two small cups of chutney/spread?  One is sweet with a very strong coconut flavor and the other was a bit more subdue with Indian spices.  

May have a different experience if we came with someone who is more familiar with Southern Indian cuisine. 

While tasty, walked away feeling a bit unfulfilled...and wanting some meat!
author: Gloria H.

description: Food is excellent!!!!  Service was terrible.  Manager running around taking care of the patrons that are being ignored by the wait staff.  Manager is very nice and trying so hard, but I think the wait staff needs some serious training.  We had separate checks four our party (2 checks) and our waiter messed them up.  He brought the corrected receipts to sign and all was fine, until I saw my bank account.  A $55.00 dinner was charged $192. and overdrew my bank account causing NSF fees.  Now need to take the receipts into my bank and get them to remove the charges.  Anastasia made it right by reversing it all, however, it doesn't reverse right away.  Other than that, the food and atmosphere is amazing.  I would have given it 5 stars had it not been for this.
author: Mary H.

description: Excellent food and cocktails! Tried four different types of dosas and cocktails, all equally fantastic. Fried idli was delicious as well.
author: Rahul A.

description: This reataurant definitely deserves the rave reviews. The food is Excellent! My favorites were the chicken shanai, the kale crisps, and the lamb dosa. Our waiter was very helpful and didn't let us over order.
author: Bahar S.

description: 3 points for the ambience and service.  The food isn't as pleasing as it looks to be.  Not a authentic Indian food.  I got fooled over by the descriptions in their fancy menu.  Masala potato was a huge mistake. Madra coffee-No!!! Not even closeeee!!
author: Velina P.

description: This is easily one of my favorite restaurants in San Francisco. The food is excellent, the cocktails are inventive (and delicious) and the staff is attentive and very knowledgable. DOSA never disappoints!
author: Melissa D.

description:
This might be a misleading review as the 1 star rating is specifically for the Paratha (I would actually give it NO stars). I expected it to taste "home made" and authentic with the 3.50 price tag, instead it was the basically the Paratha you can get from any Indian/Arabic store and I think its like 2-3 bucks for a packet of 8-10. Really Dosa???? Don't get me wrong the other food I tried from here was really good but store bought flat breads? and that too it was over cooked. Ridiculous.

The other food (chicken, potatoes etc) were really good.. but the overcooked and dry store bought flat bread killed the flavors really quickly. Skip the Paratha, get the Rice (or Naan if they have any).
author: hanzal M.

description: Food is fine but overpriced. (I prefer Udipi Palace at half the price.) I'm Parsi Indian and have lived in South India so the prices can be slightly amusing to me. But I get it -- we're in SF and everything at DOSA is decadent and exquisite. I can appreciate that. And honestly, I don't go to DOSA for the food but for the atmosphere, the decor, the presentation. Their "Peony" cocktail is excellent.
author: Camille L.

description: Yet again, Dosa has impressed me with their customer service. I placed an order for pickup by phone; when I arrived I realized I had made an error with the order. The manager revised my order with no problem and my food was ready quickly. When I got home, I saw that one of the items I'd paid for was missing. I called and the dish was delivered to my home promptly. Thank you, Dosa!
author: Eve F.

description:
Jazzy, spirited, upscale South Indian dining. 

Dim lights, soft tones, gorgeous lighting and chandeliers with jazz melodies playing in the background. That''s Dosa. We heard we had to go here so we listened, we cabbed it, we conquered. 

Anxious to get started on some dosas, we skipped appetizers and dove right in to ordering our entrees. One thing I will say, the complimentary papadum served as we waited was perfectly crisp and I filled up a little bit too much on that alone. Delicious though -- some of the best papadum I've had.

My hubby and a friend indulged in some spicy cocktails and were definitely quite pleased.

Once our food arrived I knew I was going to like it.  I could smell the white truffle oil before the plate even reached me. I admit, my previous experiences with having dosa were all very traditional versions so I was very jazzed about the white truffle twist.

So yes, I loved.  My husband devoured his meal and as I watched the beads of sweat roll down the sides of his face, at the end of his cleaned plate, all he could talk about was the sambar he just had. Although it had a no-joke kick to it, he wanted more of it.  

I highly recommend Dosa on Fillmore to anyone interested in having delicious South Indian food with a twist.  

Dining in a fine establishment like this was a definite treat from the crappy, dingy and hit-or-miss Indian restaurants you'll find in Seattle - what a shame because we need something like this here!
author: Tanya J.

description:
Ok! It's about time! Dosa is one of my favorite restaurants in SF. You can't go wrong here / the ambience - the food - the drinks - perfect! Especially if you love spice and exploring. 

Get ready to experience a meal filled with spices, favors and fresh ingredients. I love love love the sambar here! And that's my test for good South Indian food - so there!

Other favorites - the Brussel sprouts that's on their seasonal menu, the Mung and watermelon salad, the paneer and mango dosa and the seasonal utthapams. If you have a craving for curd rice (I know I do once in while!) Dosa has one that will more than satisfy that craving!
author: Shruthi N.

description:
Dine About Town is here!

My gf has been wanting to try this spot and since I haven't been back in awhile, how could I pass it up?

Their DAT menu is short, with only 3 choices for starters and 4 choices for the main dish. She opted for the Chennai Chicken to start and Lamb Kofta for main.  I wasn't that hungry, I had a huge bowl of oatmeal for breakfast, so I just opted for the Paneer & Peas dosa. 

Our Chennai chicken app came out quick, it's boneless, it's fried, it's tender!  seasoned with coriander and cumin, it had a smokiness to it and   I was surprised it didn't have that much heat.  It was served with an asian slaw.

The Lamb Kofta was absolutely tasty and served with saffron rice.  My Paneer and Peas dosa was filled with shredded farmer's cheese, peas and cilantro.  You can dip your dosa in your sambar, which is a spicy lentil soup with veggies.  Or you can dip this into your tomato or coconut chutney.  I chose to eat my sambar separately and had sweat beads on my forehead by the time I was done. Everything was delicious. 

The resto was full with every seat in the main dining room occupied and some people at the bar, but we didn't have any problem with service, although I had to ask for a water refill in the end as we paid the bill.

The DAT 2 course menu is $17.95 and is offered Wednesday thru Sunday. Don't forget, they add 4% SF healthcare charge to your bill.
author: Janice C.

description:
PROS: Delicious chutneys & desserts, nice ambiance
CONS: A bit pricy

Wow! These are the best chutneys I've ever had! The green mango paneer dosa was really good too! Don't forget to order a dessert --- the coconut pudding and saffron cheesecake were out of this world! Double thumbs up! :)
author: Monica L.

description: Very disappointing, OVER priced Indian food. This was my second trip to Dosa, the first I had lunch and wasn't impressed but wanted to give them a second try, I regret having dinner at dosa a few days ago. The server was pushy and not attentive. The was was just not good. The dosa masala was the worst thing of the night. So disappointed for I love Indian food, the buffet down the street was much better.
author: Ricah B.

description:
I digs me some Indian food, so when the group plan was to go to Dosa I had no objections. While I've had many a plate of vindaloo'd and masaala'd items, I'd never partaken of a dosa so I knew that's what would be going in my belly.

Part thin, crispy pancake and part stuffed crêpe, I'm glad I went with the namesake dish. Wanna know the truth? I actually looked around the table and had order envy of the non-dosa menu items that were ordered. There was a pepper meat dish that I got to try and it was mighty fine, and the duck vindaloo looked something delectable.

Double love (amor por dos-a?) for the restaurant's ambiance. Nothing wildly fancy, but too often I find myself in divey Indian places so it was nice to get a good sit down meal with Indian faves.
author: Jeffrey S.

description: Was looking forward to our meal here after hearing alot of rave reviews. We arrived at 8 pm on sunday and promptly were shown to our table. We ordered the chennai chicken and idli fries both very yummy and  arrived promptly. The service delays then started to creep in. For a group of 5, the kids meal arrived first but our orders of 3 dosas and the fish curry didnt showup for atleast 30 mins. We cancelled one dosa order in the meantime. Finally the other 2 dosas showed up but not my fish curry. The paneer peas dosa could have been more flavourfull. The truffle dosa was a great fusion dish.  Btw my paranthas were already cold on the table. In between the nice server offered us free desserts.   My fish curry arrived after an additional delay of 15 mins which was no doubt very tasty but i dont think it was worth the wait.  The place is classy for south indian food hope they improve on their service
author: Preeya K.

description: Utterly delighted to know someone out there is spending time, money and energy to make Indian food elevated and fancy. And not losing the essence of good taste and exceptional variety that Indian food offers. And yes, am one of those to order Dosa at Dosa. Keema dosa it was...not divine but was very happy with it after a long walk and accompanied by good folks in SF. The best on the table was the very well presented Dahi -bhalla. The cocktails were innovative but not many vodka choices. Emerald Monk was spicy and punchy. I'd be happy to recommend Dosa to anyone- it showcases the wonder of Indian cuisine well to any global gourmand.
author: Yavnika K.

description: Love that it's near Kabuki Springs and the movie theater. With a great menu of dosa, small plates, drinks, and curries, every experience here has been delicious. Reservations are recommended although seating in the bar may be possible.
author: Emme O.

description: Delicious food and drinks . Drinks definitely have a uniqueness . I absolutely loved the decoration and photos placed inside.  classy yet casual.  Besides the fact that two of the dishes we ordered were not available , everything else was great . Customer service ,ambiance ,music was on point !  will definitely visit again .
author: Neha K.

description: Love coming to Dosa! If you looking for upscale restaurant with great ambiance and exceptional service look no further. It is a hidden gem.
author: Rup B.

description:
Excellent cocktails and generous, shareable portions. Chicken biryani was delicious. 

Atmosphere and decor are warm but impressive.
author: Kira G.

description: This is the first dosa place I have visited where it took 1 hour to get seated. Not to mention they ran out of idlis. Unbelievable! I don't I will ever visit this place again.
author: Vivek P.

description:
It was Nirvana on a plate!!! Everything was so good that we kept saying "Yuuum" throughout the whole dinner. The ambience was great too. Trendy, ethnic, and in a fun neighborhood. Nice bar area as well!

My menu items:

Drink- The emerald monk: Delish!!! Nice and strong too! This is a must! I was relishing every sip!

Appetizer- Chennai chicken: This was so good! It was like fried chicken tenders with an idian twist!

Main entree- Spicy mung masala: Waitor told me that it was his fav. I'm so glad I took his advice. It was amazing!! Enough spiciness to the chutney and the dosa was to die for! I still keep dreaming about it! (Big sigh)
author: Sue J.

description:
Wife and I decided to hold our Indian family baby shower here this past weekend and we had the most wonderful experience. Dan Dowdell was our point-man and he did an incredible job. Our group was about 50 people (including a couple of kids) and Dan helped us create an incredible brunch menu of apps and dosas. On the big day, Dan and the entire staff provided simply incredible and attentive service. Everything was delicious and the food was served perfectly warmed and seasoned. Dan kept a watchful eye on the crowd and ensured that no one (including the kids) were without food or drink. We had reserved the private room upstairs and it was the perfect mix of intimate and yet roomy with tall windows overlooking the gorgeous restaurant and Post St.

We couldn't have wished for a better experience. Thanks so much Dan and the entire crew at Dosa. We'll definitely be back for moer.
author: Mihir P.

description:
This is not your typical Indian restaurant. The menu is very creative, so you have spinoffs on typical Indian dishes, often with non traditional ingredients. There are also some typical Indian menu items that frequent diners to Indian restaurants would know about. The portions are appropriate, so you could easily be full with one entree, but could stuff yourself with an entree, & splitting an appetizer & dessert. The menu's core is South Indian but some North Indian dishes are offered as well. They do not have traditionally associated with other regions of India such as Gujarat. Vegetarians & vegans will not have problems here as the menu has marked items & the staff are familiar with ingredients as well.

My wife & I have had:
Great beet croquettes, rava dosa, the winter uttappam, masala dosa, kale fritters, the 5 mini uttappam combo & the desert rasa malai.

3 things I do not like are:
* tables are very close to each other so it can be difficult to hear the person in front of or next to you that you actually want to hear
* reservations are hard to get, though you can walk in &  possibly get seated
* the salt lassi drink was extremely thick & salty.
author: Mihir M.

description:
Dosa is going to be my inaugural entry for my new list: Places to Eat Alone and Not Feel Like a Dork. Yes, I'm single-handedly bringing back the word Dork. So there.

Dosa has a regular bar where you can eat, but I love the big community table just past the hostess station. It makes you feel like you're still part of the bigger restaurant as a whole, but you don't feel like you stand out when you're eating alone. I will often dip in somewhere to grab a bite, as the teens have all their activities and I've sometimes gotta kill some time and it's mealtime.

So Wednesday night, came in around 7:30 and no problem to sit at the community table. Very friendly, very competent service. After asking a few questions, I landed on ordering the Bhel Puri and just the straight up classic Masala dosa. When the Bhel Puri came, I had completely forgotten what was in it....but it was so delicious that I gobbled it down pretty quickly. Looking at their online menu now, it was puffed rice, roasted parsnips, potatoes, tomatoes, onions & tangerines, flavored with spicy mint and tamarind chutneys. I highly recommend it. Then the dosa came...and it was just fine. It's not the first time I've been here, and not the only place I've had dosas, but it had been awhile so I was somewhat surprised when the filling seemed to be all plopped into the middle of the crepe-like outside. No big deal - I spread it around as I tore it off and dipped it sauces. But just a little odd. 

Anyway, of course I started chatting up the ladies who were seated across from me, as we had seen each other in line at the film festival we just came from, so I spent most of the evening talking with them....so never felt like I was alone. But if I had never talked with anyone, I still would have felt extremely comfortable here eating alone.
author: Laurie H.

description:
I love white truffle dosa here. The prawn masala and halibut moilee are fantastic.
I accidentally ate a chili pepper and the staff was super nice. She gave me the mango lasi which effectively removed the burn in my mouth. Everything is fantastic here starting from location, atmosphere, restaurant decoration, food, and staff.
author: Pim H.

description:
Here's a game for you to play if you find yourself eating here. Attempt to have everyone at your table get an empty glass of water for more than 2 minutes. I have never eaten at a place that refilled water with a such a religious fervor. Water was refilled with an urgency that made me suspect my glass would explode if it was left empty for even 5 minutes. Anyway, on to the important things. Dosa is potentially the hippest restaurant I've ever dined at. The dim lighting and the night lounge like decor made me realize that I've been dining like a 40 year old. It's a nice place to bring your 20 or 30 something year old friends, but not such a great place to bring your grandparents unless you're also going to bring a flashlight so they can read the menu.  I made a reservation for Friday night, and when we showed up, our table wasn't ready. I think reservations should be thought of as granting a shorter wait time rather than no wait time here. It wasn't too bad though. We were seated ten minutes later. People without reservations waited about an hour. 

We chose items off of the dine about town menu. To start off, we had the chicken chennai and the coconut seafood soup. Both were amazing, but the soup was better. It was full of humongous scallops, prawns, mussels, fish and squid cooked in a delicious coconut milk broth. I'm not normally much of a seafood person, but this was fantastic. The dosas came next. Between the green mango and paneer and the truffle masala, the truffle was better. If I came back though, I'd probably skip on the dosas altogether. They were good, but not worth paying full price for. I'm not sure if it was because the dine about town menu had smaller portions or because this is their normal ratio, but my dosa was about 25% filling, and 75% just empty wrapper. The soup that came with them was too salty and spicy for me to finish. For our last course, we had the hyderabadi lamb and the prawn masala. Both were delicious. This course was a tie. Lamb was tender, prawns tasted fresh. You wouldn't go wrong picking either one. 

I did take a peek at the full price menu. Entrees here run between $20-$35. They also do validate parking if you park in the Japantown garage. Validation should give you free parking and not just parking at a reduced rate.
author: Tiffany N.

description: Amazing dosa and sambar. Ambience was classy and upscale.
author: Arpit S.

description: I'm not sure why anyone would go here for actual dosa ! If you crave a cute restaurant with good ambience, sure try it. If you want a dosa, don't do it.
author: Zara R.

description: Upscale indian food and a great place to grab a bite before a movie. The dosa with dipping sauce is always a win. I have only eaten at the bar, but everything we have had we enjoyed.
author: Alisa S.

description:
the dosas and uttapams are incredible here. so many choices, such great variety and consistently delicious.

the food here is very heavily spiced, probably not great for those with a sensitive stomach. highly recommended is the coconut seafood soup, lamb curry and kerala fish.

great service, excellent ginger beer, will definitely be back to try the huge variety of dosas and uttapams.
author: Judy L.

description: Dosa is the best Indian Restaurant in the Western Hemisphere!  The food, the service, the vibe is the best.  They care and it shows in everything they do.  Their menus changes with the season so I try to go to either restaurant whenever I'm in SF.  The irony is that I am not a huge fan of Indian food, even though I love all kinds of food and have been in the restaurant business for decades.  This is a unique place.  What I do know and can feel is when a kitchen cooks with love, I can taste it; it always tastes perfect.  When it comes to service, we all know when servers care and when they are just going through the motions.  The staff and management team at Dosa are amazing.  If you only go to one Indian restaurant in your life, try Dosa.
author: Jim C.

description:
Awesome Indian food...what else can I say?

The ambiance is perfect for a date or an intimate get together. The noise level isn't too quiet but it's not loud like a bar either...perfect loungy atmosphere.

Ordered three dishes and shared them family style: chicken biryani, some lamb kofta and mango prawns. All were amazing. Coconut rice to go with the dishes and bhatura which I didn't know about but was an amazing bread dish. Drank a mango lassi and some type of beer/cider to wash it down. Ended on a perfect note with a dark chocolate cake.

Most Indian places are either 1. hole in the wall and good, 2. shady and gross, 3. a street cart or 4. Naan and Curry. It was nice to see an upscale Indian restaurant for a change (kind of like Typhoon in San Diego but even nicer). Definitely better than Gaylord.

The prices are a little on the higher side but you are paying for the ambiance. I think the quality of the food is also better but only marginally than some other good hole in the wall places (I'm thinking Chutneys here). Probably wouldn't come back regularly but definitely if I'm in the mood for some good Indian food and don't wanna make it down to the Tenderloin, will probably hit it up here.
author: Julia P.

description:
Seriously always delicious!  The food is so good, the quality is amazing, the atmosphere is fantastic, as is the service.  You should definitely make a reservation but if you have time to kill, you can wait at the bar for your table.  It is totally vegetarian friendly, and just delicious!  Love.  It is pricey but you get what you pay for--so that is a deal!
It is great for a romantic date--the Kubuki Theatre is across the street, go for dinner and a movie--bingo!  It would also be good for work dinners or whatever!  Just go, it's yummy and lovely.
author: emilie p.

description:
Fabulous ambience-check
Great service-check
Novel dishes aka spicy basil dosa-check
Ridonkulously tasty food-check
Yummy cocktails-check
Natasha+All of the above= Blissful camper
author: Natasha I.

description:
So delicious! The dosas were crispy, the fillings were rich and well balanced. My girlfriend had a hot toddy; it had saffron and was tasty.

The space was open and bright, perfect for lunch time. No idea how it is at dinner.

The staff were happy to accommodate us when we were in a rush, and I really appreciated it.

Would definitely come back.
author: Matthew C.

description: 1 hour for 2 orders of dosa and then served cold. Service was really poor and the food was cold. That's not what you expect from $$$ restaurant.
author: Darpan D.

description:
Great Place ! Definitely worth a try. It is a fancy place and is expensive but you won't regret spending money on good food. This is not a place you would eat every other day or every weekend. I was there two days ago. 
We were 3 people and ordered their 3 course tasting menu. It was $42 per person, by the end of third course (small portions) we were full (right amount). I am used to eating lot if food so it was not enough for. Food was still great.
author: Sanchit W.

description:
This is an upscale indian restaurant in SF. The place looks really cool when you enter inside. It has a full bar and there is no way you can imagine this place serves indian food. I have tried the watermelon, panner and moong salad, vada, uttappam and panner dosa. All of them were really very tasty. Dosa is served with two different types of chutneys: coconut and tomato chutney and also with Sambar. 

Its an upscale and elegant place. I could call it a fine dining probably. The food is very expensive compared to the same quality of food in south bay. However, I think the price is only for the location. Something to try when you are in the SF area.
author: Mohan G.

description:
Had valentine evening dinner here.

Good ambiance. Tables are too close to each other, you are paranoid that you accidentally don't start eating from your neighbors plate :) . 

Food was ok, just too much hype. Appetizers are very very expensive with very small serving size (samosa's and bhel). Chili garlic dosa was ok, not great. 

Will not go back.
author: Hemant D.

description:
Every time I come here I have no idea what to order because there are so many delicious options. 

Being that I am gluten intolerant Indian food is always an easy go to for me...even though I spent most of my time resisting the delicious naan and dosa. Usually when I come here I either have to bring an Indian friend with me or ask the waiter what I should order. I could probably come here every month and never order the same thing! 

Everything I have ever had here is delicious and the atmosphere is just Devine. The waiters are always helpful and attentive which are the two most important things that I look for in customer service. So if you haven't been here before I say go and give this upscale Indian a try.
author: Jacqueline C.

description: The owner reached out to apologize, much appreciated. Have since gone back and had a great experience. The food was delicious and drinks were equally good!
author: Michael O.

description:
Dosa on Fillmore (DoF) is a very peculiar Indian restaurant. Our waitress recommended the house special flat bread creations: two dosas and one uttapam. Presentation is gorgeous. Flavors are spicy and potent. The house chips and a pale ale from Paso Robles saved me from overload. I can't handle much in the way of hot hot food, and I slipped in under the danger zone tonight at DoF.

The included soup is too intense, but I managed to consume half of it. The included green chutney is mild and pleasant, but the red sauce isn't.

Decor and furnishings are spectacular. Sit in a corner booth if you can for comfort and people watching.

Take the advice of your server. One dish each is plenty filling, especially when you share. The overall trend is quite spicy, but you will survive with your server's assistance.

I had the huge sweet potato dosa, and it was impressive and flavorful. My wife had the summer uttapam that was attractive and delicious. My favorite was actually our friend's spicy chile dosa that was not too spicy at all, and had excellent flavors and texture.

Salted caramel ice cream was fine for mini-dessert, but the toasted cocoanut sorbet was a total dud: grainy and lacking in cohesiveness.

Not sure if we'll return any time soon, but it was very memorable and high quality.
author: John N.

description: Vegetarians go nuts at this place :) Vada pav and dahi vada, best ever.. Dosas are superb too :) Must visit if you are in San Francisco :)
author: Nagabhushan H.

description:
I wanted to take my wife to dinner on her bday @ SFO where vegeterian is good.  The two restaurants i could think of were Amber India and Dosa. Amber, its a good one too but we have been there before. I have also been to Dosa on Valencia but not the one on Fillmore. I came to know that the Fillmore was a very good one. So we went to Dosa @ Fillmore. The moment we entered in, i could only say "wow". The ambience was perfect. We got a table on 2nd floor and it was perfect. Food was really tasty and service was simply superb. We could complete all the dishes we ordered leaving behind the empty containers. If you like indian Chai dont foeget to order the masala chai at the end. I felt very refreshing after having it. Perfect spot for a date. Ambience, Service and Food were fantastic, what can one expect more than this.
I would recommend this place a must go.
author: Arvind V.

description: Excellent food, service and ambiance. Little bit pricy but well worth it. Would recommend reservations as it is really busy.
author: Nikhil C.

description: It's a perfect blend of traditions and cuisines. Veggie or not - you will not regret the visit. Whatever we ordered, served nicely and more importantly, so delicious. Would love to go again and again.. whenever I will get next chance. :)
author: Vab B.

description: Taste and food was good. But funny thing is you need to mention get the food fresh and hot. I had ordered a dosa and it was so cold, I had to ask them to replace it with a hot one. Very late service even on a weekday.
author: Karthik S.

description: Food was not as good as many other times I ate there. Their dosas as the best, yesterday the sauces did not seem so fresh. I made reservations for a 4 people business dinner party. The service was slow, it took forever to get the food, then the check. Finally, we paid, we were wrapping up the meeting and a lady (restaurant manager?) approached our table and asked us to leave because she had another reservation waiting. Super rude.
author: Aninha F.

description:
Good sambhar, best vada pav, and everything else yummy! Each item that we ordered was made without shortcuts. 

I wish they open in other locations.
author: chess t.

description:
A very Dosa-pointing experience!  A group of eight of us went on a Sunday for brunch and while the service was good,  but there wasn't a single thing on the menu that wowed any of us.  I've been to the Valencia location a couple of times (now several years ago) and I had good memories of the place which does not translate to Dosa on Fillmore.

First of all, we have a four year old and we told them this from the get-go an asked whether or not we should look elsewhere because we didn't want to inconvenience anyone by bringing a toddler.  They said 'come on in' - Dosa is a kid-friendly place.  That  might be true in terms of service but there is not a single thing on that menu that a kid can eat because of the ridiculous amount of spice in everything.  They brought us some $10 version of a grilled cheese sandwich and the kid hated it.  I didn't like it either.  They brought us a bowl of coconut rice that was super spicy. And then they made a mistake and brought us popadoms with pepper in them.  So, the kid was not happy.

Now, onto the adults.  We all ordered different stuff from tasting plates to Dosas to udapams and the consensus all around is that all you could taste from one plate to the next is spice , spice, spice.  There's  no reprive from the amount of heat from one dish to another so pretty soon everything tastes exactly the same.  Maybe this is how people eat in India - I got the schpeel from our waiter - but you've got to tone it down, Dosa.  We don't eat Chinese food in America the same as in China because Americans don't like that kind of food.  You could say the same about a lot of ethnic cuisine.  You have to make the food work for the palates of the people you are catering to.  And none of the eight SF-foodie gringos at our table liked what you had to offer or your prices.  $15 for a pancake and a smattering of cheap ingredients.  Give me a break!!!

It was a disappointing few hundred bucks that we spent and I'll stick with my Indian favorite - Mehfil - the next time we decide to go Indian as they pack huge flavor into their stuff without overpowering the spice factor.  I recommend you do the same!  And don't ever bring a kid there.  Big mistake!
author: Carmen C.

description:
Grilled Calamari (Seasoned with cilatro, cumin, chiles, onions, & lime) $10: Calamari was on the rubbery side, but the sauce had a hidden kick to it. Note: add the lime juice on top, it completes the dish. http://s3-media3.ak.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/2ewj00VyUYsjQUdX6l9RdQ/l.jpg

Samosas 'North & South' (Savory pastries filled with caramelized onions & vegetables (South) and spiced potatos (North) $9: I liked the North Samosa better than the South. The North was more flavorful. I didn't bother using the two sauces they provided with the samosas; however, the South Samosa was a bit bland and needed the extra sauces. http://s3-media1.ak.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/R653VFSV512ZnYNPyrTHLA/l.jpg

Hyderabadi Chicken Briyani (Bone-in, natural, basmati rice with an aromatic spiced sauce, caramelized onions, cashews, peas) $20: Hrm... not worth $20 bucks, but it was the spiciest briyani I have had so far ( I say that in a good way). There is something in the dish that they forgot to remove because it made the first couple of bites unbearable. After the weird taste went away, the rest of the briyani I had was good. http://s3-media2.ak.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/YLymH6ELzBpoqJ7plqIN7w/l.jpg

Duck Vindaloo (Spicy, goan curry, red chiles, malt vinegar, ginger, cumin, mini potatoes, curry leaves) $19: mMmmm duck! we got two drum sticks and a couple of mini pieces of meat scattered around. The meat was very tender and the sauce was ok, but as an entree dish the portion was small.  http://s3-media1.ak.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/WBWJyQCbRgXCr-4ZuNyQHA/l.jpg

Mango Prawns (Reductions of coconut milk, red chiles, ginger, red onions & spices) $17: This was by far my favorite dish of the night. My favorite dish of the night. The shrimp was cooked to perfection with the addition of fresh mango cubes and sweet sauce... it was the bomb. http://s3-media3.ak.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/5oHecZLq6L8vkl42-QcRnA/l.jpg

Coconut rice ($3): You can definitely smell the coconut, but you can't really taste it. I do recommend ordering this if you are getting a curry entree. 

Roasted Chile & Garlic Masala Dosa (Masala dosa layered with spread of spicy chutney) $11.50: This dish was very interesting, Dosa is the thin crepe like layer over mashed potatoes. The dosa itself was very spicy and when dipped in the sauces provided, it was pretty tasty! I didn't taste the garlic, but over all, it was really spicy and interesting to eat. I would recommend trying this dish if you ever come here. http://s3-media1.ak.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/Xiut_pQXN78kdPfHcaEBDA/l.jpg

Service was disappointing, I think I waited 20 mins before the waitress came to explain what dosa was and other unique dishes they had. Then another 10 mins passed before she came back to take our order. Between meals, it took over 20 mins to get our main dishes. Even trying to waive someone down to pack our left overs and requesting for our check was difficult.
author: Erica T.

description:
I've never had a bad meal at DOSA. I've never had bad service at DOSA. I love that they change up their menus at times, yet also keep my favorites. Mumsy and I came here for our post-massage, birthday treat. 

Mumsy is a bit hard of hearing (when she wants to be!) so we opted for the mezzanine - the high vaulted ceilings (I'm told it was formerly a bank) is not conducive to intimate convos, but upstairs the acoustics are better.

Our waiter was very helpful and all the staff will help you with any food decisions. We went all vegetarian with the Seasonal Squash Pakora (I think I inhaled the first three), the Dahi Vada (which was beautiful and delicious - I wish I'd taken a photo!), and the Paper Masala (two small plates and one dosa). It didn't seem like a lot but it was so filling and so delicious that I continued to eat after I was full. 

Also, I left a paper bag with some odds and ends at my table and the waiter ran after us chased me across the street in the rain to return it to me - so sweet!
author: Mi M.

description:
Order the rack of lamb and it was amazing. All the flavors on the plate complimented each other and the lamb was perfectly cook.  Came here late one night without a reservation and had to sit at the bar.  However, the bartender was very friendly and very attentive to me and my partner.  He took our order and recommended the tacos.  The recommendation was the perfect appetizer! He even had the kitchen add an extra taco to the plate, no extra charge, so that my partner and I didn't have to split the third taco.  
The service was great as usual and it was perfect for a rainy night.
author: Theresia A.

description:
My favorite indian restaurant in the city. Conveniently located three blocks from my new pad in Pac Heights, I've become a regular. I came here for a dinner meeting and was able to kick it at the bar with a friend while we waited on our party.

The service was great, and the girl to guy ratio was unbelievable. There were literally 15 girls at the bar and then my friend and I. Ow Ow. They seamlessly transferred over our tab to the table which usually comes with an eye roll, however they were extremely polite.

We must have ordered seven appetizers to share and they were incredible. Forgive me for not remember the names of everything, but whatever item was bread filled with potatoes was insane. If someone could drop me a line if they remember what it was called I will update my review!
author: Jason M.

description: amazing food and ambiance. We ordered the moong dal dosa and parota with egg curry. Everything was delicious.
author: Kavya S.

description:
Note: I'm half Indian and a lot of this is me nitpicking and offering constructive criticism. If you're reading this on a phone and don't want to read my novel length review, here's the short version: Delicious! Go here!

After all the hype, I knew I would have to try one of the fabulous Indian places in SF--and as it happened, one of Dosa's locations is right down the street from the Hotel Kabuki, where I was staying. It also happened to be right across from the theater I had been planning to see a movie at later that night. Dosa and then the Hunger Games--it seemed as if it was meant to be!

The building took me by surprise--I was expecting classy, but not this much grandeur! Our waiters were helpful, though somewhat socially awkward--not really picking up on our cues and there were definitely some awkward silences that were a little weird. Overall they were helpful and good natured, however, and were happy to explain everything to us.

I am half Bengali and have been to India several times, but I have only been fortunate enough to make it south once. I also lived in Los Angeles for a long period of time, and frequented Artesia, so I'd like to think that I know my way around south Indian food pretty well.

I was intrigued by some of the cocktails, but the waiter sold me on the Ginger Ante, which was quite good--had the warmth and the bite of ginger, rather than just the taste.  My boyfriend and I decided to make the most of our experience and try a little bit of everything. We ordered the South Indian Moons (5 uttapam sampler) and a tasting menu with the things we had read the most raves about: Chennai chicken, the white truffle masala dosa, and the mango prawns.

In all of my experience, South Indian food is sort of like an inferno of deliciousness in the mouth. This definitely seemed like the white people version, with the spice toned waaay down. The dosa itself was sour, but not quite at the level you usually get. That does not mean that it wasn't delicious, though! I was having a love affair with that potato filling, like that annoying pop song by September. "No I can't get over, and I don't know why..." Seriously tasty. The sambar was right on par and the chutneys were delicious as well - the coconut lime one went exceptionally well with the delicateness of this one, I think.

The Chennai chicken was pretty good, but again, I was wanting more spice! I used to get samosas every day when I was in Calcutta and their Northern interpretation was good--they came to our table a little less than piping hot, and if they're anything less than piping hot then the breading can seem a little heavy handed. The southern version was fantastic, though--creamy sweet onions and very well spiced.

The uttapam sampler was one of my favorite things. They brought out sunchoke, paneer, tomato, potato, and green bell pepper (?). The sunchoke was pretty good--the crunch from the sunchokes was a playful element, though at times the pieces would fall out so it seemed it could be a little better married (maybe smaller chunks?). The tomato and potato were my two favorites, with the potato definitely coming out on top - a light, fluffy, slightly sour dream of an uttapam. The paneer I left to my boyfriend because I cannot eat cheese, and he said it was good though it did convey the sometimes spongy quality that paneer can have--nothing wrong with that per se but he is picky about texture. The green bell pepper--question marked because I am not sure if that is exactly what it was--was delicious, whatever it was, crunchy with small enough chunks that it was a seamless part of the uttapam. It had the freshness of green bell pepper without the bitterness, which was really wonderful.

Finally, we were served the mango prawns. The prawns themselves were succulent, the coconut rice fragrant. It took me some time to realize that the chunks were actually mango, though that should have been obvious. If you get this, try to eat them with the prawns--they are quite intense on their own. Overall, no complaints on this one--I was full to bursting and still ate half of it.

Overall, we had a really great experience. Dosa makes South Indian elegant, and while I was missing some of the fire, it was still a delightful experience.
author: Lynne S.

description:
Went here for 2013 Dine About Town.  It was okay.

Food:  The highlight was definitely the scallop appetizer.  The remainder of the meal was okay - nothing exceptional, but not horribly bad.

Ambience:  Pretty sweet. If I came here again, it'd be for the ambience and bar.  The chandeliers are beautiful with various conversation pieces throughout the restaurant.  Definitely a cool place to hang out.
author: Nancy T.

description: This place was great!  It's much more spacious, and we didn't have to wait on a weekend evening, which was great since we walked in one hour before our movie at Kabuki!  Compared to the Valencia location, parking is better, and there is a much larger waiting area (at Valencia, it's super cramped at the bar and it's hard not to feel like you're sticking your behind into someone's meal next to you).  Service was great too!  We sat at the communal table and got quick service.  Ordered the sweet potato dosa and my friend ordered a spicy chile and garlic dosa.  Both of us devoured them.
author: Vivian W.

description:
Really great food! I enjoyed it and might come back.
IMHO bit pricy
author: Uriel C.

description:
Dosa sf is expensive indian fare. They have a lot of good things going for them. 
Pros:
Great ambience. 
They have the best vada Pav dare say better than the ones in Mumbai. There I said it. The trick - Carmelized onions and perfectly spiced. 
Their warm toddy is absolutely amazing. 
Pumpkin soup is awesome. 
Uttappam and sambar is amazing. 
The papad that is given free is soooo good. 
Moong salad is very nice. 
Coconut rice and stew is out of the world. The spices sort of make love in your mouth in a very nice way :)

Cons:
Expensive indian food and drinks. 
Dosa is ok.
author: Yateesh B.

description:
I am going to set the record straight for DOSA.  This place is really good! 
My husband and I come here as often as possible. 
I have read some of the other reviews about DOSA and can't understand that anyone would rate this place lower than 4 stars.

ATTENTION DINERS: Indian Food = Spicy Food - - - DUHH!  :P

If you do not like spicy Indian food, then this might not be the best choice for your ultimate dining experience!
I am an American; raised on pasta, pizza, & fried chicken - but LOVE the wonderful way the chef creates his Indian dishes. Always delicious!  My husband is from Bangalore; raised on spicy South Indian (vegetarian) food and loves everything about this place too - - He craves the vada sambar.....

The PROS and CONS of this restaurant:

PROS: 
1. Convenient Parking in the Japantown Parking Garage at Fillmore/Post
2. Beautiful Ambience - soft lighting & nicely decorated
3. Delicious South Indian dishes (mostly vegetarian) but also lamb, chicken, & fish
4. Some North Indian choices - like chaat
5. Wonderful bar - unique drinks with the flair of India! With or without alcohol...
6. Great service
7. #1 Chef(s)
8. Great for a "date" if both like spicy & delicious food (and if you're vegetarian)

CONS:
....I can't think of any.

I have never dined here in the evening (only during the lunch hour on the weekends) so I can't give you advice for the evening crowd.

I have had almost everything on the menu at least once, and can honestly say that EVERYTHING I've ordered was enjoyed ~

If you like bland Swedish food - - go to Harry's Haufbrau.
author: Renee T.

description:
As always and expected, DOSA on Fillmore lives up to its name and reputation. Named after a famed bread of South India, DOSA rocks this jazzy part of town night after night with its curries and beautiful South Indian flavors. The restaurant is stylish, chic and innovative. It is upscale for sure. But nice to know a place prepares delicious dishes that combine fresh ingredients and uncomplicated layers of flavors. DOSA is no bs -- it tells you that Indian food does not have to be difficult. This restaurant not only provides inspiration for food lovers or a self-proclaimed foodie like me and easy- to-eat dishes that begin with basics for those who are less assured in an Indian restaurant. With its visually enticing plates, this place makes a great place to share a great time and good, I mean really good Indian food, with your friends. As an enthusiast cook who specialize in Indian food myself, I believe good food is a combination of fresh ingredients and uncomplicated layers of flavors. When you start with quality produce, a few simple flavors will just complement and contrast with your base ingredients to create the perfect taste experience. Think of food with passion, not anxiety, and feel free to substitute as you please. This is often how personalized culinary masterpieces are created. That's DOSA. Tonight, just like everytime, the dishes were spiced, flavored, curried and cooked to perfection and all arrived lavishedly drizzled or bathed in light raita and sauce. Getting in, we knew what this place is all about, the air inside flavored unmista
y... We asked for two major curry dishes and  the go-withs -- the lemon and coconut basmati rice, and four other small plates including its biggest star -- the dosa itself. It is truly a star dish to say the least -- favored so beautifully to perfection, light, crispy, fluffy and folded perfectly on a flat white plate. Scratch it gently with the fork and the flavors burst out... The other small plate that I truly enjoyed tonight is the scallop dish -- perfectly seared and served over a light raita sauce. Coming from Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia, where Indian food is everywhere, my girls know the delicate southern taste of India and were pleased with their maincourses and side orders tonight. The craftcocktails were unbelievably delightful, too. I am giving them another double thumbs up! We ordered the vodka-based Peony, Half Moon, Hanging Gardens, and Ginger Ice Tea. They are DOSA's prize fighters and truly refreshing. If you are a light weight like me, tell them because each kicks in nicely and warms you up almost instantly. Tonight, the food/drink pairing was spot on--light lamb and fish curries were beautifully paired with sweetened cocktails instead of its famed Sujata wines. The service was really sweet to say the least -- by that I meant relaxed and unhurried. Drinks unpushed. 
The noise level was good. The price? A little pricey but it is an upscale restaurant and a great place to celebrate with loved ones. Go!
author: Ambrose A.

description:
This place was hyped up to me and while it was good, it was not outstanding. As Yelp would say "it's OK, not A-OK". Let's go through it point by point.

THE ROOM - Beautifully decorated but there are so many tables jammed together, it's extremely loud and there is very little chance for privacy. 3 Stars

THE SERVICE - Nice folks but very haphazard, long stretches of no service, then four different people in under two minutes asking us if we were done and could clear our plates. They also screwed up the bill and double charged us. 2 Stars.

THE DRINKS - All three of the "Spice Route Cocktails" were hits. We tried the King Louie, Wry Rajah and Lucky 7, excellent. They also have solid beer & wine choices! 4 Stars

THE FOOD - A little disappointing, everything was mild (even the "extremely spicy" dishes). We tried, the CHUTNEY SAMPLER (great), DAHI VADA (best dish of the night), CHILE-CILANTRO FISH (disappointingly bland), PRAWN MASALA (great sauce, rubbery prawns), DUCK VINDALOO (the waiter said it was the spiciest dish in the house, it was not, at all), TAMIL LAMB (good but the flavors didn't pop). For dessert we shared the RASMALAI (pretty good). 3 Stars

OVERALL - A low 3 Stars. Great looking room & cocktails. Decent but not amazing Food but inconsistent service. DOSA still seems to be a big favorite in town and I am willing to give it another shot as I still have to try their actual "dosas" and see how they are but it didn't blow me away.
author: G C.

description:
Dosa is AMAZING!!!

We came here for dinner on 12/27 expecting it to be a little slower after the holidays.  Thankfully we had a reservation because it was packed solid - from the bar to the door!

Whenever a restaurant offers a tasting menu, we tend to go ahead and order it, expecting it to be the best they have to offer.  It was $35 per person for a 3-course menu, plus an additional $18 for the wine pairings.  Very reasonable, and they did not disappoint!  The food was amazing, the wine pairings were perfect and the service was excellent - our server was very attentive, our water glasses were never empty (which is important here because the spices start out mellow then catch up with you!) and the courses were pefectly timed.  PERFECT!

Everything we had was amazing.  Indian is one of my favorite cuisines, but I've never had a dosa before.  It's basically a filled crepe.  We shared both the spinach & fennel dosa and the white truffle masala dosa.  It was so good, I'm still dreaming about going back again that white truffle masala dosa!  Also highly recommend the halibut curry with the coconut rice, and the duck - not something that you'd expect at an Indian restaurant, but they did an excellent job of it.  The entire dessert menu looked amazing too! 

We're definitely going back for the Bhatura.  It wasn't offered on the tasting menu but it seemed like the thing to order since all of the tables around us had them.  It looked like an amazingly huge ball of bread (naan on steroids) on a plate.  Some of them may have been 12-15 inches in diameter, they were that impressive.  I can't wait to get back!
author: Kimberly J.

description:
Glad I finally got a chance to try Dosa out, after walking by regularly and hearing about it so much. It's very elegant and beautiful inside, with high ceilings and big wooden tables, but still maintains a comfortable and kwasi-casual atmosphere. 

We had a drink at the bar while waiting for the rest of our party, which is very open and sleek. I had the Bengali Gimlet, with curried nectar and lime juice, which was exquisite. I love the use of curry- very inventive and flavorful. We had made a reservation for Sunday dinner for 4 only a few hours before but they seated us with no problem in the cozy upstairs dining room after the other two had arrived.

Food! I tried:

Prawn-Chili Fry - I thought this was just okay, but one really loved this.

Samosas - Very tasty, I do love me some ground, spiced veggies stuffed in fried 
pastries and dipped into varying flavor-packed sauces. Nailed it! The other star here was actually a small side salad, dressed in what seemed to be some sort of lemon-cumin vinaigrette. I wish I could order more of this as an entire dish as well!
