description: The food is consistently excellent. They change their menu seasonally and are very creative with their dishes. I recently discovered they're open for brunch on the weekend. The Fillmore location is so much larger and more comfortable than the Valencia Street location. I only wish they would open an East Bay restaurant.
author: Leslie K.

description: Decent ambience. Ordered idli fries, masala dosa and lamb kheema. Except for the lamb dish, everything else was good. Had to send that one back after taking a couple of bites.
author: Tangerinegate A.

description:
Dosa is ridiculous. Bhatura is probably one of the most memorable things I've eaten this year - basically a crazy inflated naan. I've never seen anything like it. All the plates we tried were solid. No question it's pricey, but well worth it. 

I'd come back.
author: Jeff F.

description:
Eating here left me really confused. I was baffled because it was a miss on all levels - the food was not authentic, nor did it do a good job of bringing in a fusion element to the different items. In my opinion, everything I tasted just fell flat - no flavor, no element of surprise, no nothing, FLAT.

I'm a South Indian. I know the food. I ordered a pesarattu or the Spicy Mung Masala. What I got was not really a pesarattu, I make better pesarattu and I won't even pretend to be a good cook. Others on my table ordered:

Paneer & Spinach dosa -  marginally better than everything else that we ordered, but still not on par with dosa I've had in other bay area establishments. 

Okra Kolambu - no flavor, I was hoping for a nice coconut kick to the whole dish, but apparently it was too much to expect

Persimmons & Iddiapam - we were warned that the dish was sweet, but we were intrigued by the usage of persimmons in an iddiapam preparation and wanted to try it out. Will not make the mistake again!

Overall, it was a very disappointing, uninspired and expensive meal ($73 + tax for 2 entrees and a drink, per couple). I don't think I'll ever go back. And I don't know how this place has such great ratings, especially when there are so many more great South Indian restaurants in the area *facepalm*
author: Harini S.

description:
This place is amazing!!! Their version of a margarita is Devine. As well as the chennai chicken.  I could eat two orders of that chicken. 
Sat at the bar and Terry was a very informative, brilliant bar tender. Tx for making our meal even better then it tasted. 
My boyfriend and I will be returning for sure;)
author: Katrina S.

description: Very hyped up place . Went with high expectations . Nothing extraordinary to hype this place as much . We tried dahi vada , did not taste good . I liked the vada pav . Masala dosa was soggy and not good . I have eaten at lot better places . The ambience is good . This place is very pricy for the food they serve . Will never go back to this place . 3 stars for the ambience and service.
author: Ashish A.

description: 4 stars for the food and service.  3 stars for take out. Food was great and obviously the dosas were delicious.  The shrimp curry was also on point.  Seemed legit based on the clientele - always a good sign when you see people of the same ethnicity populating an ethnic restaurant.
author: Anthony S.

description:
The best Dosa experience ever period. The place is great, has a high-end experience but not very expensive.

My favorites are the paneer-moong-watermelon salad, kale pakoras, all of their dosas.
author: Abhishek S.

description:
I am not a vegetarian, but I do love my vegetables. 

So, my pal P.S. Bookman and I were kicking around and he suggested Dosa; I acquiesced, after speaking to the host taking our res and explaining my allergy to capsaicin and foolishly asking, "Can the kitchen do something with no spice? Like, saag paneer?" 

"Paneer, yeah, ummm... the cheese? Yes, we can do that. We have that."  The tone was set and sealed with those words...
 
Reservation for two; right when they opened at 5:30pm. We arrived early and scored a parking spot; kicked around and  waited until they opened the doors; I was HUNGRY. 

The dining room was empty; we were literally the first guests for dinner and the host asked for our name. "Bookman, party of 2". Without blinking, he asked, "And... what WAS the first name?" 

Grammar police. "The name is P.S." I guess they were expecting the Bookman Family Reunion that night. *shrug* It could happen. We were directed to the bench, NOTgiven menus and advised that we would be seated shortly (less than 10 minutes later). 

I am far from a saint, but I also know that I should have been offered a menu to peruse because it was my first time eating at Dosa and when I previewed the menu displayed outside, I was anxious because every descriptor included the word "spicy". I nervously groped inside my bag for some Prilosec. 

Our drink orders came out late and were incorrect. To our server's credit, he apologized and quickly corrected it at the bar. Sadly, this would be the first of many "oops" moments during our dinner - which were clearly happening in the kitchen, not front of the house. 

I thought the decor was beautiful, and appreciated the bold photography and soaring ceiling height. We were seated in the center of the main dining room at a 4 top and I gazed longingly at a smaller table along the back wall. 

The menu was extensive, and a bit overwhelming for me, a first-timer, unfamiliar with Southern Indian Cuisine. So it took more than 15 minutes for us to actually place our order. The pappadum that came out were greasy, much to my dismay; you could actually see the liquid pooling in various spots. Hmmmmmm. 

The paratha were pleasantly chewy and of generous proportion as a $4 side - I stuck to the accompaniments deemed safe for my allergy (raita and tamarind) and was jealous of P.S.'s ability to enjoy the broader spectrum of flavors. 

He ordered the Dahi Rice at a modest $6 for a very large portion and the Mysore Masala Dosa. After consulting again with our gracious and long-suffering server (Zachary?) I committed to the Spring Dosa, no cilantro, hold the red onion. Which, unfortunately, arrived at the table choc full o' cilantro and red onion. My dietary restrictions also banned me from experiencing the sambar, so the dish was dry and with multiple errors from the kitchen did nothing to better my impression of this experience. 

Super-Server immediately offered to make the order right in a sincere and gracious manner, which was much appreciated. 

I ordered a salad: Persimmon & Idiappam : Lightly spiced, house-made rice noodles, pearl sago, reduction of coconut milk, mint chutney for $11 - how could I not be intrigued? The dish was more puzzling; the coconut milk was dessert sweet; the rice noodles a flaccid tangle and virtually devoid of taste. I also couldn't reconcile the chunks of red pepper floating in the concoction: is it a dessert? Salad? Noodle dish...? The flavor profile was so chaotic that I abandoned it after only 3 puzzled tastes and another disappointment. 

Bookman and I left the majority of our meal on the table and no inquiries were made as to whether we enjoyed our dining experience. While our server was professional, he did not offer to take any of the errant items off our ticket. 

I applaud the corrections, but was vexed that nothing was done to account for the multiple missteps on the BOH side or the dishes that were wonky and clearly not to our liking.

Lovely ambiance; just wish the food matched. I will return to the more humble establishments I've grown to love: full meal for two under $20, instead of an $80 ticket before gratuity. 

Namaste-la-vista, baby!
author: Kim D.

description:
Great southern indian food!  Lots of vegan/vegetarian options in the heart of
the mission.
author: Adrian S.

description: I loved loved loved (!) my first time at Dosa last night. It felt like the ultimate place to be. The decor was hip and swanky and the service was efficient and comfortable as well. We ordered some drinks first, which were all so well done. The Steph Curry made me change my mind about Bourbon. I'd start drinking Bourbon for sure if it all tasted like Dosa's Steph Curry. My drink, the gin-based Peony, was excellent and frothy, but it was pretty sweet. Flower Child was ethereal and beautiful looking and tasted just as delicious as it looked. We then ordered some small plates and salads, dosas following, and then entrees for a family-style dining experience that worked seamlessly for our long, comfortably-paced meal. The spice level across the board was a little more than I am used to- but I took it as a friendly challenge that yielded great results. The goat cheese & little gem salad reminded me of salads I've had before from other cuisines, but it was deliciously dressed. The goat cheese balls were melt-in-your-mouth tasty and the spiced walnuts sent me to honeyed heaven. And the scallops- perfectly cooked and perfectly spiced. I didn't eat the duck tacos, but those in my party who did said they were amazing. My father remarked they were his favorite part of the meal. We had the sweet potato dosa which was deliciously sweet; it paired well with the white truffle dosa. The mango prawn entree was soooo delicious; as a pescetarian, I relished in the fact that they had such a delicious seafood dish. I enjoyed the fragrant coconut rice that complimented the sweet and spicy mango sauce. My fellow diners had the lamb chops- I heard they were good but 6 of them split 3 chops (1 order) and each portion didn't seem to be more than one bite of lamb- fortunately that didn't affect me. Our waitress Jenny was calm, kind, and very helpful with the menu. She expertly gauged how many dishes we'd need for our party size, and everything turned out nicely. It was a smoothly paced dinner that felt luxurious and magical- all due to the spectacular food, alluring decor, and personable service. I'll definitely be back- and urging my friends to go too!
author: Rebecca H.

description:
Had an enjoyable time at Dosa.  We had a few smaller plates so that we could try more things.  The Vada Pav stood out for me, but the star of the show was definitely the Mushroom Truffle Utapam.  It was so flavorful, so savory, unlike anything else I've tasted before, I just wanted to keep stuffing my face with it.

Next time I go, I'm going to order just small plates and skip the entrees, they take up too much tummy space.  If there is one complaint I have, its that the desserts tend towards the 'western' side.  But then, after all the good food, I'm not sure if there is still space for desserts.
author: Paul N.

description: Love this place... Great dishes and nice spicy drinks
author: Nikhila R.

description:
Reading about this place made me very excited to try it.  The location on Fillmore is very nice, beautiful in fact.  It's a very handy location for dinner and a movie at the nearby Sundance Cinema.

Tried the seasonal tasting menu, 3 courses for $35.  Not sure if this is really a bargain, but I thought it seemed like a good way to quickly get a survey of what they had to offer.

The food was exquisite.  I loved the vibrant flavors and perfect spice balance.  Some heat, but nothing overwhelming.  I ended up eating the sauces with a spoon, completely clean plates.  This was fine dining, Indian style.  A reviewer called this place Indian food for White People.  Maybe it is, but this gringo loved it.  Total bill was just about 50/person.
author: Patrick S.

description: Good ambiance. Dosas are good, Sambar was very authentic and Kulfi is EXCELLENT! Did not try the bathuras but they looked absolutely scrumptious. Highly recommend. Must try !!
author: CHET M.

description: Great Food and great Ambience. I love the sprout salad here real Yum one of the nicest Indian Restaurants in SFO
author: Rashmi S.

description:
Meh

I don't know many authentic Indian places that don't serve Naan let alone Chicken Tikka Masala. I guess I'm"m a bit old fashioned.

Overall this place is very Fancy Shmancy. Nothing wrong with that though, It would be fun for a great night out with your Boo. But me and mine were not quite looking for that. We did however love the samosas, and the bread that came with the dipping sauces. One of them was like a soup and that is exactly how we ate it. I must say that soup/dipping sauce was the best part.
author: Theresia D.

description: I'm a fan of Dosa in the Mission and equally a fan of the one on Fillmore.  The interior space is stunning - high ceilings and gorgeous artwork. I'd recommend the seared scallops to start (holy heck, were these good), and the prawn masala.  Throw in a bhatura for good measure.  They have no beer on tap, but do have a decent bottled selection.  Also, the cocktails are fantastic.  Give Dosa a shot for a lovely date night + movie at the kabuki!
author: Angela R.

description:
DOSA has a great atmosphere and everyone there is extremely friendly.

First off, MAKE RESERVATIONS.  party of 4 was seated. We saw groups that were standing at the bar when we got there and were there when we left!

Their drinks are little unique, I had the Whiskey drink which was good (but you can only have one or two). The first dish we got was the dipping sauce sampler. That was great, my favorite was the Kale dip (good for snacking). 

I also had the spicy Roasted Chili & Garlic Masala and my girlfriend had Mysore Masala. They both were moderately spicy (not as spicy as it sounds on the menu). 

It was a tad pricy, about $77 for the couple (not including drinks) but we were stuffed after that! It is a great place for a date (or double date as we did). I had a great time and encourage anyone to give it a try.
author: Ryan R.

description:
16-September, Sunday:
I imagine that in my former life as a lady of the manor in my estranged green-card marriage, my boudoir must have been outfitted in the same fashion because this place felt oddly familiar and cozy even though it was new territory for me.

I was completely taken by surprise by Dosa on Fillmore, it is a stark contrast from its more casual Valencia location. The 'white table cloth' atmosphere here boasts high vaulted ceilings, a lower level of seating upon entry, an upper level that is more intimate, along with an option to sit along the fully stocked bar. 

I enjoyed a subtly tart mango prawns that had just a subtle tinge of spice to it, although I do not proactively crave curried things I will admit that this was quite the exception in my book.  Especially when served with aromatic lemon basmati rice.
author: Ty T.

description: Dosa was great last evening; I go there frequently.  The food quality is consistently excellent and they are able to take care of Vegan diners with ease. Service was fast, friendly and professional.  The room can become a bit loud when the restaurant is full--but overall the loudness is not a big problem.
author: Tom B.

description:
I had the truffle dosa and it was delicious! The fusion of Italian and Indian ingredients made my experience super interesting and keeps me wanting to try more on the menu. Oh also, the dosa's are gluten-free which is convenient. 

The dim lighting and soft music makes for a romantic evening. The food was great, our server was nice. I will definitely come back!
author: R. K.

description: This spot is money. We did basil and green mango paneer, pani puri, and the omelette. All were absolutely scrumptious. Oh, and they make one of the greatest gin tonics i've ever tasted.
author: Ed P.

description:
I love Dosa's food. I really really really do. This review is not to judge their food AT all. Their dosas, appetizers, and drinks are all delicious. Indians are very picky on our own cuisine but we do love coming here. 

This review is only for my one encounter last night at Dosa. My now husband and I wanted to take our families out after our civil marriage ceremony at City Hall. I made a reservation 2 weeks prior for a group of 14. I knew we would end up having a little bit more people so I called the restaurant a few days later. They happily bumped up my order to a table of 16. They offered if we wanted to have a group dining menu and I declined. I was about to get married, I don't want to pick what other people would have for dinner. I thought everything was set.

I got a call driving to City Hall from a very sweet lady saying that her chef/mangers were asking to change our dining to a tasting menu to better accommodate our large group. I again declined claiming I know my family, I know how they are, they won't be happy with a tasting menu AND if I would have known this, I would have booked something else. She put me on hold and said, don't worry about it, we will see you when you get here. As we get to the bar, my father and friends are ordering some drink. A manager came up to us and told us maybe we shouldn't order because "we have a minimum for the space upstairs and we won't meet the minimum if order drinks here". I again told him we were never told about a minimum, are ordering off the regular menu, and was a little frustrated that we were discussing this AGAIN. We went back and forth for a little bit until he realized he was confused on which party we were then let it go. 

It was not terribly inconvenient or maybe I was just so high of endorphins I really didn't care much but it did put a little damper in our happy day. Regardless, our entire family was happy, everyone left full, and we had a great time. I think they could work on their group/larger dining experience and work on their clear communication.
author: Ankita T.

description:
I eaten here twice, both on special occasions when both the ambiance and food were important. I'm a huge fan of indian food and love a chance to enjoy it in such a beautiful setting. I love the tasting menu but it is quite pricey so not something I could do on a regular basis. There are wonderful and plentiful vegetarian, gluten free, and vegan options on the menu, and they even have a separate list that itemizes these dishes so it's easier to choose from (great when you're dining with people with food allergies and restrictions). The Dosa menu is fabulous, but I'm not a big fan of the uttapam personally, so I would stick to the Dosas.. 

Looking forward to my next visit!
author: Tiffany L.

description:
I"m going to say Dosa is a 3.5, a little pricey for what it is but the food is definitely good.

We started with a few drinks and it was all delicious. I had the ginger ante and my friend had the Peony. they're both good. The ginger ante was refreshing, both drinks had a lingering spicy taste, perhaps it's the ginger.

For food, we got the spicy basil dosa, pepper chicken curry and the duck spinach masala & paneer. We took Dosa's recommendation and ordered a lemon rice with both of the curries. Both of the curries had a good spicy kick which the waiter told us about. He also brought over some yogurt to help with the spiciness. Everything was good. It was weird that the food came out within 10 minutes of ordering? 

The one complaint i have about my duck dish is that it did not look appetizing at all - see photo! 
http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=fUEWDn-YYYdN1WCMuG29eQ&userid=FHe8iR0zF5zt3NSiFyAk7w
author: Terry C.

description:
I mentioned I went to Dosa to a friend, and he smiled. Good food but it's not authentic. I don't know if I really care that much. But yeah, the dosa with truffle oil is probably not an ancient recipe.

Our threesome ordered from the tasting menu, ordered different things and shared family-style. Everything was delicious, especially the aforementioned truffled dosa as well as the lamb curry. A couple of us ordered the wine pairing. Because the flavors in the food were so bold, the wines did not stand out or bring anything new in the pairing.

The decor of the room is gorgeous and our waitstaff was friendly and attentive.
author: Joel A.

description:
One of my favorite restaurants in SF! The Fillmore location has a nicer ambiance and more parking options than the Valencia location. It's a great date restaurant, especially because the movie theater is right across the street. The menu is a little pricey for Indian food, but well worth it. We come here about twice a month for dinner. Some of our favorites are:

- Vada Pav **Get this. You won't regret it**
- Masala Dosa
- White Truffle Dosa (my bf thinks it's heavy, but I love it)
- Bhatura

My favorite chutney is their coconut chutney. I don't even like coconut, but the flavor is not overwhelming at all.
author: Mo A.

description:
Such a great place -- authentic ethnic food with awesome upscale ambiance not typically found with Indian restaurants.  Service was great, drinks were great, food was great, pricing was great.

The ONE drawback was the amount of salt they used in their food -- must have been shoveled in... X____X.  Hopefully it was just an off night.

I ordered:
--Lotus Steam Day Boat Scallops ($12) -- highly recommended.  4 big and perfectly seared scallops served w/ crispy chips of lotus stem (for anyone that doesn't know what that is, its the starchy root that grows under water, beneath lotus flowers)
--Duck Vindaloo w/ Coconut Rice ($19, +$3 for rice) -- pretty darn spicy but meat is very tender and super flavorful.
--South Indian Moons Uttapam ($13.5) -- good sampler of 5 uttapams, super soft and thick savory pancakes.  It wasn't mind blowing and  I'll probably go w/ the dosa next time (crispy and thin), but glad to have tried it.

We came with a big group for a birthday dinner -- worked out so well.  Open Table made it easy to reserve, we had a booth that was both private and comfy, delicious drinks made toasting a blast, and Dosa even coordinated a special birthday dessert for the bday girl at the end.  Thanks, Dosa!
author: Kendra W.

description:
Upscale Indian done right.  The food is elegant and satisfying and is great place to go with friends or to bring your parents.  The menu is a little complicated so it is helpful to have your waiter walk you through the menu.

My friend had a cocktail that was wonderful and the wine list was good too.

Make reservations as it is hard to walk in.
author: Vanessa B.

description: Beautiful ambiance with good food. I think it would great place for happy hour with some friends.
author: Sheila T.

description:
My first time was definitely better than my second, but nevertheless, it's a gastronomic adventure. Gorgeous restaurant, friendly staff, and great ambiance. I took my girlfriend here this past weekend and she had a great experience!

I highly recommend the meat dishes over the vegetarian ones here; they have better flavors, showcases the ingredients well, and the spices are just incredible! The Chennai Chicken and Bhel Puri are great appetizers for 2-4, but I recommend staying away from the Rasam Fire Broth Soup (you're going to get sambar with your dosa anyway). 

As for entrees, the prawn masala was delicious-- 10/10 would order again. I also tried the chicken and eggplant curry, paneer and peas dosa, roasted chile and garlic masala dosa, trumpet mushrooms uttapam, and the mixed chile uttapam. Everything was really good except for the mixed chile uttapam! While I love spicy foods, the habanero was a little overwhelming and I couldn't taste anything else. 

I was too full for dessert the second time, but they have a changing dessert menu that will pique your interest. So if you decide to come here, stick to the meat dishes, order a dosa, and save some room for dessert!
author: Johnny K.

description: This place is awesome maybe even an addiction! My favorite hangout place when I want home food. You can't go wrong with anything on the menu. They have great wine list and cocktails to add to your dining experience. Tip: make a reservation, this place gets packed and you may have to wait 45-60 min otherwise. Service is fantastic and ambience is upscale. They even have a happy hour. So check it out ;)
author: Rishabh J.

description: Had a dosa and world class service when I wandered in here after a spa day and kept dreaming of coming back.. I did it was busy I had to go to the bar to even buy a drink, not enough wait staff set in a crowded seat and not attended to.. Ordered the prix fixe menu but the worst part wasn't the taste it was an Ok meal. I afterward along with my family member felt like I had an inflammatory response to the food, as in MSG or some type of chemical reaction like I was very swollen feeling.. So if you go just order a Dosa not sure what else is safe if your a food sensitive person.
author: Kimber W.

description:
We went to Dosa for Valentine's Day and I have to say this is one of my new favorite Indian restaurants in the Bay Area. We had the fixed four course menu, which was an excellent deal.  Our courses: seafood soup and bhel puri (first course), lamb dosa and sweet potato dosa (2), kerala fish moilee and chicken (third course), apple tart and lava cake (fourth course).

I loved the seafood soup, it was fabulous, so much so I've asked my mother-in-law to recreate it.  My wife enjoyed her bhel puri, but as her family is from Bombay, she thought it could have used more sauces. The dosas were sada dosas with a stuffing, mine was lamb, hers was sweet potato.  The lamb was delicious, my wife thought the sweet potato was tasty and unusual. The third course was the real winner, the fish was delicious and her chicken was superbly spicy (even for her).  We also ordered a bature to go with it (delicious, on the thicker side, but delicious).  The fourth course desserts were tasty but not authentic.  My wife was sad they didn't have an interesting kulfi on the menu.

All in all, I think Dosa was delicious, the drinks we had were refreshing and the atmosphere is impressive.  The only disappointing thing to us outside of the food was that we were seated next to the server station, which meant the clanging of dishes sometimes meant it was impossible to hear each other speak.  But, it was a really enjoyable experience.  Will go again.
author: Marvin P.

description:
Curiosity killed the review.  Oh no, that was the cat.  Maybe it is expectations that killed the review.

The service:
I only had one beer.  And my dinner companion only had one glass of wine.  Why?  Our server was basically absent.  After taking our order, he did not check back to see how our meal was proceeding.  And when the food was dropped by, it was quickly deposited on the table.  It seemed like a race.  Overall, for fine dining, it was some of the worst service I have witnessed in some time.

The ambiance:
This was the strong point of the experience.  It is a very nice room.  I have to say the high ceilings, the decorative touches, and general overall styling of the room comes together to create an exotic and elegant space.  However, even here, the tables along the wall are placed too close together.  There is no sense of privacy.   I would not want to be sitting at one of these tables for a date.  

The food:
Overall, the food ranged from mediocre to slightly above average.

We selected the four course tasting menu.  I think this is where we may have lost our server.  After we told him we were each going to order the tasting menu, he became disinterested. 

Even for a tasting menu, each of the portions were relatively small.

Starter:
She selected - Grilled Calamari (the calamari was overcooked and tough)
I selected - Chennai Chicken (this was actually pretty good.  the chicken was tender and the spices were nice)
We shared.

Mini Dosa;
She selected - Masala Chutney (This was good but not outstanding.)
I selected - Spring (This was their take on a spring roll.  It was also good but not outstanding.
We shared.

Each came with a trio of sauces - 
Tomato - I liked it.
Red Bean - She liked it.
Coconut - neither of us are big fans of coconut.

South Indian Curry:
She selected - South Indian Lamb Kofta (This was my favorite dish.  the lamb was tender.  The sauce was mild but had a very nice combination of spices.)
I selected - Prawn Masala (The prawns were overcooked and rubbery.  The sauce was pretty amazing.  Another relatively mild sauce with an excellent blend of spices.)
We shared.

Dessert:
She selected - Gulab Jamoon (Neither of us liked this very much.  it was rather bland.)
I selected - Banana Cream Pie (While it was a very small portion, it was actually very tasty.  It reminded my of my mom's banana pudding.)
We shared.

Overall:

Based on feedback from multiple friends and  reviews, I had high expectations.  However, on this particular night, Dosa on Fillmore did not meet these expectations.  If I graded them as a run of the mill Indian restaurant, they would score 3 stars.  However, as a fine dining experience, they rate at 2.5 stars and, in this case, I am rounding down.

Service = 1 star (graded against fine dining expectations)
Food = 3 stars
Ambiance = 4 stars
author: Mark D.

description:
A little baffled as to why these ratings are so high. I've had FAR better indian food than what I experienced at Dosa. Both the food and service was extremely lack luster. I went with a group of friends, really with the intention of just doing drinks and grabbing  a bite or two. 

So naturally, we started at the bar, but then made our way to an actual table. We reviewed the menu, and since many of us weren't tryna order a huge meal, settled on some dosas to tide us over. the store manager was rude, rude, RUDE. He came over to take our order, and upon learning we just wanted some dosa's to go with our drinks, he kept trying to majorly upsell us. "how about the chicken dish?" "what are you, vegetarian?" "How about this?" "How about that?".... me: "How about we just order?". I've never felt so forced to buy something. Like... if I wanted the chicken... I would've ordered it without you breathing down my back. SO RUDE.

Definitely not coming back here. There's WAY better indian food elsewhere, especially in SF.
author: Jennifer O.

description: We tried the sweet potato dosa and moon uttappam assortment. Food and ambience were great.
author: Rakesh M.

description:
You would be hard-pressed to find something amiss at Dosa (well, I'm sure there are those out there who could find it...but then, they're just cranky!).

This restaurant has something for everyone! Sexy date-night spot? Check! Fun space for groups? Check! Happy hour with friends? Check! A place to impress out-of-towners? Check!

The food is wonderful...not your traditional Indian fare...but oh-so delicious and a perfect way to comfortably ease your non-adventurous food friends into trying something besides meat and potatoes!

Everything on the menu is wonderful...a must have is the paper masala dosa. They have the most wonderful, flavorful and rich curries and sauces. They even have some tasty items for the no-meaties in your life.

The drinks are wonderful! 

Yeah, I'm a total fan =)
author: Christy L.

description:
After driving all day to the lovely city of San Francisco, we were famished. My hope for trying the up and coming State Bird Provisions was immediately dashed as they were fully booked even on a Tuesday evening. Thankfully our local hosts had good alternatives, and as it was nearby we headed over to Dosa who graciously accommodated us last minute. 

Dosa is gorgeous. It's a stunning space, the room is expansive and atmospheric with beautifully rendered art that blends old and new. In effect, it's a representation of the Southern Indian dishes available that are both authentic and modern. The food pleasantly reminded me of Vij's in Vancouver, the best Indian food I've ever had. Anywhere. This isn't quite at that level, and its not as consistent but then what is? For the most part, the food was jaw-droppingly good, though interestingly my least enjoyable dish was the namesake dosa. 

Before I forget, the bread is amaaaaazing here. There is no naan (wrong part of the country), but you won't notice. Bhatura is a must order. It's a giant, light fluffy piece of edible pastry heaven. Pretty sure I could live off of it. Papadon was equally good, one of the best I've come across. Light and lovely. Paratha was also quite nice.

Samosas North and South are wonderfully prepared here, perfectly crispy. Bookended with two different but equally divine sauces, especially the sweet one.

Lotus Stem Dayboat Scallops were exquisite. Again balanced by two ridiculously addictive sauces, this was my favorite dish of the evening.

Rasam Fire Broth was interestingly named, because it wasn't particularly fiery but it was extremely tasty. It had a moderate kick, but a very good and interesting flavor.

Roasted Chili and Garlic Dosa was exceedingly hot. Almost unpleasantly so, but keep in mind I like moderately spicy not hair curling hot, so if you like really spicy it might be wonderful. 

Mangalorean Prawn Masala was nicely prepared. Great flavor, nice balanced spice. Quite enjoyable.

Duck Vindaloo was very good. 

Sun Choke Uttapam wasn't that successful for my palate, possibly it was the version we chose, but I don't think I'd visit that dish again.

Surprisingly we ended with a fantastic dessert. Pistachio Dacquoise with chocolate chili mousse, salted caramel and cocoa cookie. If that sounds good on paper, it was even better on the tongue. 

Overall, this was a delightful beginning to our trip. There's nothing like a complete lack of expectation to allow for immense pleasure, and since we knew nothing beforehand, every great moment was enhanced. Had it not been for the two missteps, this would have been an easy five star night for us. In fact, even with them it really still was for me. 

Best Plates: Day Boat Scallops, Rasam Fire Broth, Samosas, prawn Masala, Duck Vindaloo, Bhatura, Dosa, Pistachio Dacquoise with Chocolate Chili Mousse

Palate: moderately exotic

Food - A-
Ambience - A+
Service - A-
Value - A-
author: Forrest D.

description:
I love dosas, and I love Dosa too!  We went here for lunch, and the place was pretty empty when we arrived.  

We had the lamb frankie and the paper masala dosa.  The lamb arrived wrapped and cut in half, perfect for sharing.  That was probably my favorite part of the meal.  When the dosa arrived, we stared at how big it was.  We couldn't fit it on the table for 2 without spilling over to the nearby table.  Good thing no one was sitting next to us.

Food was excellent.  The only thing preventing 5 stars was the price.  Love the high ceilings and ambiance.
author: The Bottomless Pi T.

description: Can't get enough of this place. Amazing dosa's and uttapams. And not to forget the best coffee :)
author: Priya R.

description:
First, we had a 9:15 reservation and were sat at about 10. Ok, not a great start. 

Food was good... when it came. The service was GLACIALLY slow. We were sat, then 10 mins for someone to come over. We ordered everything at once since we had been there a while. We had a few pretty simple questions about ingredients, and the server had zero idea what was in any of the dishes. 

Apps came out before we got wine or even water at the table. We had to ask multiple times about the wine. It was late and the bar was slammed... OK but we got a bottle can you just go snag it yourself? 20 mins for drinks is not acceptable no matter how busy it is. By the time we got started on the first dishes (once we finally got drinks) everything else started coming out all at once and they just dropped dishes all over, barely attempting to bus anything. 

Like I said food was very good but not worth the mediocre service. I'd like to give it another shot -- maybe I need to go on a Tuesday at like 6 pm when they aren't busy? Seems like they can't handle what looked to be a normal busy Saturday night.
author: Tbone M.

description: The food is amazing here, but my rating unfortunately has to do with the service, specifically in seating. We came as a party of two and watched for an hour and a half as parties of two who came after us *without a reservation* were seated before us. I don't understand what their algorithm is for seating people but it seems simple enough to me--seat people in order they come in and as tables fill up. Pretty frustrated and would absolutely not recommend coming here unless you have a reservation or are prepared to wait. Sorry DOSA, maybe next time!
author: Monjari V.

description:
We walked in 5 minutes after their afternoon closing time, the super nice Manager and hostess let us grab a table and order, they were honest about setting the expectation we had to order quickly since the kitchen was closing, very fair, I value straightforwardness.

We ordered a number a things, I cannot remember a single dish name, but every single of the 6-8 items we ordered were AMAZING. This was my first time trying southern Indian food, which apparently is a deviation from the usual dishes. 

Nevertheless...

Food: is fantastic, the best Indian i have ever had. Their 'breads' (chips and the like) were to die for.
Service: the staff was super nice and attentive, they all seemed happy which makes a tremendous difference.
Presentation: very nice, orderly and clean.
Quantity: proportional with price, this is not a cheap Indian buffet but it will get your stomach what it needs to survive while pleasing your palate.
Price: its expensive for Dinner, but very moderate-average for lunch.  
Ambiance/Decor: modern, very nice and clean.

I am SO coming back!
author: Carlos L.

description: I really enjoyed the Autumn Tasting Menu. Every course was superb!  My favorite was the paneer and peas dosa.  So delicious!!!  Highly recommended!
author: Linda S.

description: Pricey but worth it for once in a while. Yummy dosas. I ordered paper masala and loved it. If you haven't tried dosas before, they will explain the dish and help you decide. Was slightly disappointed with the Madras coffee though, they could have served it hot.
author: Shrikant K.

description:
Fabulous Anniversary dinner at Dosa!  I love Indian food but feel like my experience of it is limited to "hole in the wall" type places or general greasy take out.  Ms husband booked this reservation based on rave reviews from his Associates.  What a treat to go somewhere that felt hip and upscale but SO authentic.  I loved trying all the dishes that were new to me and not just my usual Chicken Tikka Masala or Saag Paneer (not even on the menu!).  

We each got the tasting menu because we felt like we wanted to taste lots of different things.  It was ALOT of food and we didn't come close to eating at all.  So I would only recommend that choice if you really want a taste of everything.

Hard to point out highlights because we loved everything we tried.  We loved hot hott all the food is, but if you happen to not love spicy food--speak up!

100% going back my next time in SF!
author: Valerie M.

description:
An incredible culinary experience of authentic Southern Indian food at it's finest.
There is something for everyone here, even if you don't like Indian food, you will LOVE this place. The chef has made these stunning concoctions that will blow your mind and palate, everything I tried was top notch, finished off by the best mango lassi I've ever had. Can't wait to go back to try more!
author: Dan B.

description:
This is my FAVORITE Indian place of all time! I am a huge fan of dosas!

Had the Paneer and Peas dosa, Uttapam sampler, and Spicy Basil dosa. 

A dosa is kind of like a thin crepe filled with delicious goodness. My favorite is the Spicy Basil, and I've eaten it two days in a row. I love the sauces that come with the entrees, and dosas feel a lot lighter than your typical Indian food (e.g. butter chicken, lamb vindaloo, etc).
author: Sophia L.

description: This is our favorite place to take out of town guests. I love this place. Must try the paper dosa with all the great chutneys. There is also an amazing chicken dish, the chennani chicken which is a little like spicy fried chicken. We've had most of everything else as I love to try new things, and everything was worth it. Be sure to make a reservation.
author: Leah B.

description:
AUTHENTIC AND GOURMET: Sometimes to find authentic cuisine, you have to sacrifice atmosphere and go to hole in the wall. But at Dosa, they manage to serve delicious, authentic South Indian food in a top-rate upscale environment! The food, service, atmosphere, are all excellent. Also, they try to use organic and local ingredients where possible.

INSIDE: I prefer this to the other Dosa location. Located in a smaller space, it's a little more intimate feeling. The tables are spaced close together, but that can be forgiven.

FOOD: Free papadum appetizer - order the chutney sampler to make it more interesting. The masala dosa is a staple and a must try. They have a number of small plates, like "north and south samosas," as well as great entrees like mango prawns. At lunch, try the Thali for a sampling of different items (although some of the offerings are an acquired taste). Check out the drink list for elaborate and pricey cocktails. They now offer interesting egg dishes for brunch. I recommend going family style, and having a feast!
author: James W.

description:
Absolutely love the place . Only place my husband loves South Indian food. 

South Indian with twist...  Never though dahi wada could look like an art :) 

Must try
author: Shachi D.

description: We ordered the keema dosa, prawn masala, channa batura and the hyderabadi chicken biryani. The dosa with keema combo is spot on. Prawn sauce is great with naan or other breads and the chicken biryani is solid.
author: Aman B.

description:
The food is flavorful, service is prompt, but really expensive! We made a reservation through OpenTable and were seated right on time. My favorite dish is the vada pav, and I must say that it tastes pretty close to the street food in Mumbai! My wife and I really enjoyed our meals both the times that we've been here. The host staff are really prompt and patient. 

The negative part is that the place can get really loud and cozy, as tables are literally stacked next to each other. The folks on the neighboring table would be right in your 'bubble' or personal space. I love to have my food spicy and asked the waiter if they could make my Biryani spicy, to which they responded that the Biryani is generally not as spicy. They didn't even try :)

Verdict: I would totally recommend this place, if you need to catch up on some flavorful Indian food and do not care much about the price tag or personal space. I would not recommend this place if you need to catch up on a date or peaceful family dinner.
author: Sunil J.

description:
So dissatisfied with their service. Called at 3 to try to get a 6:45 reservation. Was told they were booked, but to come in, they always have a few open tables and bar seating. Showed up at 6:30 and asked about the aforementioned 'Open Tables'. The blonde east European-accented hostess literally laughed when she sneered,"Open tables at DOSA on a Friday night?"

The reviews may be rave, but sorry, that attitude doesn't fly for a non-Michelin restaurant. Get over yourselves.
author: h m.

description:
Upscale-y, bistro-y Indian that still has a soul. Dosa is as sophisticated as any place on Fillmore, it has a very lively, young bar scene and it has killer Indian food. Not a bad combo for a change of pace. If I had a nit it would be that it could be spicier, meaning hotter. The flavors were great, but I kind of expect duck vindaloo to light my head on fire. Dosa's tasted great, but there was no fire. Oh well.

The signature item, dosas, are really very nice and they come with wonderful dipping sauces. My wife and I said that next time we might just make our dinner several dosas and leave it at that.
author: Rick H.

description:
I went here with a group of friends and it was a great place for groups.  Good cocktails and service.  The restaurant itself was very cute and swanky.  If you're looking for a scene, this is for you.

As for the food, we had tried a number of items being a party of 8. The keema did not taste like any keema I've had and even so, it wasn't very good. The chennai chicken and the tamil lamb were my favorite items. The dosas were just ok.

If you're looking for good indian food, there are far better options, especially in the city, not to mention for far less $. It's a bit overhyped in my opinion but if you're looking for a fun place to try and don't care for the best food, it's a good option.
author: ami s.

description: Consistently terrific, delicious food and consistently mediocre service. Seated for 25 minutes. Order placed. No food in sight (at least not on our table)! Hope we make our movie start time across the street at Sundance Kabuki.
author: Sally C.

description:
My buddy told me about this place and so we decided to have some lunch here.
The set up and theme is awesome.

The food was great!!!.

I had their appetizer plate of vegan sliders (vada pav i think it was called).

Then had a Dosa with 3 different types of dip. 

Then had some of their chicken.. very good!

The price is moderate, but well worth it!!

Staff was very friendly and welcoming.

Parking can be tough.. I parked in the Japantown garage.
author: Roger A.

description:
I am ready to book my next flight to SF just to enjoy another meal here - truly, madly, deeply.

DOSA's food is the best southern Indian food I've had in a very long time (family cooking aside, of course!).  Mmm....I'm salivating just thinking about it (not that those words help the review at all; I'm just sayin').

Beautiful space, lots of tables, and the tall ceilings allow a vibrant atmosphere to come alive; especially at night.

We tried a myriad of dishes, and all were phenomenal.  Soups, salads, dosas, and uttapam dishes were fresh and exquisitely flavoured.  Favourite?  Paneer, of course.  I really should have ordered a second dish to have for left-overs, because there certainly wasn't any crumbs left on my plate...Oh, and another plus?  Incredibly priced for the food, service, and location.

Seriously, I'm buying my tickets NOW!
author: Maureen C.

description:
I went to Dosa last week with my boyfriend and it was very disappointing. Admittedly, I have been there twice before and had a great experience, but this time that was not the case. I had made a reservation for 7pm, but when we got there the hostess said that our table wasn't ready and that we would have to wait "a few minutes". Twenty minutes later, they finally seated us. 

We ordered a few things, and the waiter was initially helpful in telling us which items had cilantro in them, since my boyfriend can't eat cilantro. However, he neglected mention that the side of rice we had ordered had cilantro in it, so when it arrived my boyfriend couldn't eat it. Also, my boyfriend ordered an appetizer that never arrived and was not on our check. Other than that, the food was delicious, and the drinks were fantastic. I got the channa batura and my boyfriend ordered the mulligatawny chicken. We shared an egg dosa, which was surprisingly good (I was a bit skeptical about the eggs). 

Then the bill came and the total was over $90, so our damage was over $100 with tip. I know this place is expensive, and the food is really great, but for that much money I expect stellar service, which we did not have. I give them four stars for food but two for service. I can only hope that it will be better next time-- if we go here again.
author: Lee A.

description:
Best place in SF to get India food. It has the small restaurant vibe with brilliant service and great food. 

Must try: Masala Dosa
Not to try: Garlic Masala (only if you can chew habaneros)
author: Ravi P.

description: I love this place, and every time I go in, the food is magical and the service is great, but the bummer is that every time I go in I swear it gets more and more expensive. Such is SF I suppose. Definitely worth a visit, but expect to spend some dough.
author: Jane F.

description:
There was a long wait to get seated but they were able to get us to the community table earlier. Food was just okay. It was like eating Indian food cooked by a non-Indian chef. Nice presentation but lacking the zest and taste that Indian food especially the South Indian food is known for. 

Definitely not a good choice if you are seeking good authentic South Indian food. And over priced.
author: Sandip G.

description:
I eat Indian about 3-4 times per week (mostly made at home). When I first visited Dosa I was suspicious because most of the diners were white folks.  And I was shocked by the sticker price; it's certainly the priciest Indian restaurant I've eaten at.  It certainly doesn't have the atmosphere of your typical Indian restaurant, but in this case I'd say that's working in Dosa's favor.

But I have to give it 5 stars, as it's also one of the best restaurants I've enjoyed.  Between my wife and I, I've tried about half of the menu so far.  Everything has been good.  It's all so flavorful and just tastes so bright and fresh, I'm not even sure how to describe it.  Most of the dishes are prepared in an authentic way, though a handful of them show some creativity by the chef(s) that could be called Indian-fusion.

Almost every time we pass through the city my wife wants to stop there to eat (she's from Hyderabad).  And if it weren't so pricey, we probably would.
author: Ryan C.

description:
Definitely not the typical indian restaurant im used too!

Price tag is on the high side for South indian food, but the menu options are pretty unique and not something you can easily find. 

Ambiance - 5 stars
Drinks - 4 stars
Food - 4 stars
author: Sangeeta L.

description: Back for Sunday brunch.  It was a literal explosion of flavor in my head.  Wow!  Wow!  Seriously, while at my spice threshold, this was amazing. I can barely describe all the things I tasted.  Curried Bloody Mary, Papadum, lentil soup. sauces, omelets, and more ... You will not be disappointed.  4.5 stars!.
author: David L.

description: Rare to find a fine dining for Dosa accompanied by drinks to celebrate. Great ambience for cozy dinner and admirable taste. Do try their idly fry and jalapeno chilly uttapum.
author: Sonal P.

description: This place is quite impressive. The food is very good. I ordered basil spiced dosa. I would definitely recommend it. For anyone who cares, the decor is up there as well, and one can say same for the service.
author: Dinesh K.

description:
Really nice and professional service.

Otherwise, pretty overpriced and nothing out of the ordinary. I had shrimp curry, which was delicious, but not mind-blowing. It cost $30 (with a mandatory side). I can find equally delicious shrimp curry elsewhere in SF for half the price.

I guess the main draw of this restaurant is that it's convenient (it's right next to Kabuki).
author: Maggie N.

description:
I LOVE the food. Amazing food. Some authentic, some nouveau. Intriguing cocktails, great space.

But generally mediocre service. Otherwise, would have been a 5.
author: George B.

description: Dosa is amazing! If you want some flavorful ethnic food in the city-dosa is your place. We came here for Valentine's Day where they had a special menu. Absolutely loved the lobster & vegetable uttapam. Also, they have a fabulous cocktail menu! I loved the pink peony - very tasty & unique!
author: Christine K.

description:
GREAT food!

I ordered Vada Pav for an appetizer, which is a MUST !  Then I ordered the White Truffle Masala which was really good! I am a mushroom lover, and the hint of truffle oil on the dosa tasted so good with the masala! 

The South Indian Monsoon drink was very light and refreshing!

I can't wait to go back again!!
author: Isheeta B.

description:
DOSA!  I'd been wanting to go to this place for a long time.  The food was excellent.  They had a 3 course pre-set menu that my girlfriend and I ordered with a wine pairing.  The only negative thing that happened was that I wasn't done with my second course and they brought out my third course.  Rather than the server acknowledging his mistake, he asked me to move what remained of my second course onto the plate that had my third course.  Rude.

But- the food was great, atmosphere was great, and the service was really good with only that one exception. I would definitely go back. 4 stars.  Would have been 5 if not for that service incident.
author: Tyler P.

description:
This place shares virtually nothing with your stereotypical indian restaurant in terms of decor and ambiance... BUT the food is incredible.  While the dosa might not be as good as in India, it's very close; and the difference is more than made up with in their more fusion-y/modern features.

Specifics:
(custom-made) Blade Gin and (house-made) tonic: Wow.  Better than Blade's normal offering, this gin is a must-try for anyone who likes the london dry or intl/modern style.  They also offer some 20 other gins (mostly of those two styles).

Lamb Kebab: Incredibly tender with just the right amount of spicy.

White truffle masala dosa: Just... order this.  You won't regret it.  The dosa 'skin' is a little too crispy and not quite fermented enough for my taste but the truffled potato masala is more than enough to make me not care.  Excellent sambar too.

Pappy van winkle, 20 yr: Ah, the ever hard to find van winkle.  For less than $20, I couldn't have been happier to see this on the after-dinner drinks list (which is quite extensive).

This place is perfect for groups of 8ish or fewer and dates.  The hip-ness makes it a little awkward going solo, but the food is well worth it.  Truffled dosa and van winkle bourbon are already enough to make me come back.
author: Eric L.

description:
I've been here twice and love the concept of upscale South Indian dining. This restaurant is really pretty, and the flavorful, delicious breads and sauces hit your tongue in ways that not many types of cuisine can. When I came here the first time, I enjoyed the ambiance and food even though we had a waiter who was rather aloof. So imagine my surprise when I got the same exact guy more than six months later, and he was possibly even worse of a server than before. My purpose is clear: the Yelp review gods have summoned me.

Our group of five was seated upstairs, which I was excited for since I sat on the first floor the last time. However, our circular table was positioned smack dab in the middle of all the others, and as we settled into our seats we had to take care in dodging our neighbors' elbows and back-leans. It was just way too cramped and they should have set things up better, considering we had made a reservation.

Next we dealt with Mr. Surly Server. A couple of us were new to the restaurant so someone asked if he could explain the menu (anyone who's been there or has eaten more typical North Indian dishes knows that South Indian food is pretty different). Bored, he simply suggested how many appetizers, main dishes, dosas and uttapams he thought the five of us could eat. We tried again, asking him for recommendations, and without direct eye contact he indifferently named a few. We told him we needed some time, and some of us ordered drinks. "You?" he head-nodded me curtly when I hadn't said anything. I told him I was fine. When really I wasn't... in fact this guy's sourpuss attitude was pissing us all off.

Consistent with my first visit, the food was delectable. The dahi vada (lentil dumplings in a spicy yogurt sauce), prawn masala, and pea and paneer uttapam were my favorites. Seriously, it pains me to rate a place so low when the food is soooo good. But our server was just such a douche! While our table was bussed numerous times by staff, he never once came by to check on us the entire meal. Much to our chagrin, gratuity was added automatically. We considered asking to have it taken off, but by that point we were tired and just wanted to go. Had we been given the initial choice, we would not have tipped him. 

In sum, it seems as if yummy food and a chic décor have allowed this restaurant to get away with some crappy service. I haven't been to Dosa on Valencia, but I'd cross my fingers that it treats its customers a little nicer and give it a try just to taste that zesty chutney again. I will not, however, return to the Fillmore location.
author: Kate V.

description:
Now my rating is based on my own ignorance of Indian.  So please forgive.  Of course I have eaten Indian food before...many times but the highest level of sophistication has been random buffets and other locations such as "Naan and Curry."

Now walking into the establishment was very cool.  I love their ambiance and layout.  The only thing I might complain about is the lighting.  It's WAY too dark.  I had to use my flashlight phone app to see the details of how good the food is supposed to be.  A great restaurant should not what to hide it's pride and joy...ie - THE FOOD!  Though granted we sat upstairs on the mezzanine level.  I believe the lighting is much better at the bar and main dining area.

We started with the Idli Fries which were unique.  The outside texture starts off like any ole steak fry but the inside is soft and crumbly like rice.  Very intesting and tasty.   Nearly at the same time the FIVE Moons came (South Indian Moons).  They are 5 small vegetable pancakes with 3 dipping sauces and seemingly ginormous one...or maybe it is a chili soup?  The dipping sauces were not that fantastic but perhaps more for the subtle palate.

Our mains were the duck vindaloo which is their spiciest curry (AND IT IS!) and masala.  The duck was tender and good quality though I felt the extreme spiciness of the curry left my palate burning and wondering if the duck was good.  You're probably saying I'm stupid for saying such things.  Perhaps so.  Anyways, I did still like the dish.  Probably would've gone better with their recommendation of rice instead of uttapam.  The 2nd main was masala...an super-sized pancake folded in half with a filling that tastes like the inside of a samosa.  After the 5 moons, my utappam, and now this huge pancake...I was pretty much carbed-OUT!  Ever bread item seemed to taste the same.  The filling was good but I had had enough of the breads....We were full.

As you see my ignorance of the cuisine has subverted a probably very fun time.  It's a great looking restaurant.  And I'm sure if we ordered a more diverse assortment the experience could be better next time.  Hopefully, the server could be more helpful in this regard and stop us from doing that next time.
author: Cary L.

description:
The ambience is great for a date or family get togethers. We had to wait 10mins on a Saturday evening even though we had a reservation.

We ordered these:
1. Vada pav - excellent, must haves, especially tastes awesome with the gunpowder chutney.
2. Kaju Paneer Masala - the paneer was tasty  but the paratha was basically the 'Kawan Paratha'  (anybody who shops at Indian grocery stores would know) which disappointed us a bit since it wasn't 'home made'.
3. Paper Masala Dosa - the dosa and masala were regular, nothing out of the ordinary (being an Indian and having eaten dosas growing up).
author: Shrenik D.

description: Disappointed. Overpriced for what they offer. Unique and creative menu but i just don't think it's worth the prices they charge. Service was great. Wouldn't return.  There are better indian places.
author: Boogie K.

description: Perfect environment, Great service but costly.. I would love to come back at this place
author: Amit P.

description:
The food here is fantastic! I love Indian food and the dishes here are very well done. The dishes I tasted were:

APPETIZER:
The North and South Samosas: savory pastries filled with caramelized onions and vegetables (South) and spiced potatoes (North). These were very good. The pastry was lightly crisp and the filling was hot and flavorful. I liked the Southern samosa more. The dipping sauces they come with complement the samosas very well. 

Dahi Vada: Lentil dumplings topped with cool Straus organic yogurt, piped with tamarind and mint, mildly spiced. Freaking delicious! The presentation is very eye catching as well and matches the amazingness of this dish. All the flavors just work so well together. Yum! You absolutely must try this. 

ENTREE:  
Prawn Masala with coconut rice: reduction of coconut milk, red chiles, ginger, red onions & spices. Delicious! This is a curry entree and I love curry. The medley of spices really enhanced the flavor of the prawns but none of the flavors were overwhelming each other. You can definitely taste the heat in this dish. I'd describe it as medium spicy. When you order any of the curry dishes, they don't ask you how spicy you want your food. So if you don't like spicy, make it clear to the server how hot you want your curry when you order. The whole table ordered curry dishes and they were all on the medium spicy side. 

DOSA (ENTREE): 
Paper Masala Dosa: This is basically a crispy crepe served with spiced Indian potatoes, onions, and cashews. This is an entree sized dish but the whole table split it. The dosa is absolutely massive. Think of a size of a log. The dosa was perfectly crisp and not at all oily. 

Masala Chutney Dosa: Classic masala dosa spread with spiced chutney of blended baby eggplant. I don't have much to say on this dish. It was just okay for me. Slightly too salty. 

DESSERT: 
Dark Chocolate Cake: topped with creme brulee, over 3-spice creme anglaise. All their desserts have an Indian flair with spices to enhance the flavors. The chocolate cake was pretty good. One of the spices is star of anise. Unfortunately, I found that out the hard way. They garnished the dish with a whole clove and I ate it thinking it was chocolate! Ick! Not pleasant. It's like eating a piece of licorice flavored wood. If you order this, don't pop the star shaped object into your mouth because I had to spit it back out. The star of anise is found in chunks in your cake. I think the cake would've tasted much better if it were infused in powder form. It just didn't work as well for me because of the textural difference and feeling random bits of spice stuck on my tongue. Aside from that, everything else was good. 

I'd recommend coming here if you're looking for a more upscale Indian restaurant. Good for a date night or catching up with friends. The ambiance is very trendy. Think dim lighting, cocktails, beautiful people, elegant Indian decor with a lot of soft browns and gold, and plush leather chairs. The chairs were soooo comfortable. You just sink right in and you won't want to get back up. The service is okay. Our water glasses were constantly filled. The food takes awhile to come out so have some patience. The bathrooms were also clean. As far as pricing goes, I felt that it was reasonable for the quality of the food and the area. Definitely check this out if you're looking for a fine dining experience around Japantown.
author: Nancy C.

description:
Upscale Indian restaurant. Went on Saturday morning for lunch. Loved the ambience and the food. 
Service was bit of miss - they goofed up on order and billing but made up with complementary desserts.  Hence not taking off a star. 

We ordered a bunch of dishes from the ever popular Chennai Chicken, to Vada Pav, Puri's ( for my 3 year old), Frankie ( ordered Shrimp but got lamb instead as they mixed up our order), Medu Vada and 2 mini dosa's ( Which come with a side of salad).

The salad was huge and filling. The dosa's were tasty ( masala dosa and a uttapam) and crisp. 

The desserts ( rasmalai, tea flavored mousse and beetroot cake) were all stellar. 

Would go back in a heartbeat. Hopefully service will be better this time!
author: Rutuja K.

description:
Dosa had such a great atmosphere, vibrant but still intimate.  The food was delicious and the specialty cocktails were exotic.  My husband and I ordered a few appetizers and a cocktail before going across the street for a movie.  

The watermelon and paneer salad was excellent as were the samosas.  My husband loved the chennai chicken, but I am a wuss so it was a tad too spicy for me.  

Definitely going back, next time I will try to get a reservation because trying to get a seat at the bar was very competitive.
author: L. B.

description: I made rereservation on Open table, you earn points for doing so.  Overall I liked my experience here, the food was well prepared and tasty.  I had the pineapple chicken which was good.  My friend that was visiting had a few other dishes off their gluten free menu (you can request for it).  The restaurant is large with upstairs &downstairs seatings.  A little dark, couldn't see my food.  The service was great!  Located right next to a parking garage.
author: Trynh K.

description:
I love the food. I always seem to eat too much. The dosa pancake is a big hit amongst my family members. But boy is the food salty. So salty. I am soaking up water all night and all next day. My face is puffy too.

The duck vindaloo was quite dry, not living up to the expectations. The prawn masala was delicious and definitely my favorite. My father favors the lamb curry. 

The food is very salty. If it wasn't so salty, it'd be much more delicious.
author: Janice H.

description:
Dosa is great and offers southern rather then northern Indian cuisine which seems much more common in the US, the flavors are complex and the food really comes to life, the drinks are great and the service is right on par with everything else here; I recommend Dosa! 

Order the Papadum with Chutney sampler as it is the best I've had and Chennai Chicken is delicious as well.
author: Tim P.

description: Good cocktails. Better Dosas. Best channa bhatura I have eaten in a while.
author: Mahesh M.

description:
Growing up around some of the best dosa joints in South India, I gotta say - this place feels like home! All of the items I have tasted so far, taste very authentic and even the new age-inventive ones are really good. You know how annoying it gets when foreign cuisines taste completely different in the U.S because they have been modified for the American Palette? That has NOT happened here. What i mean is, you will not find either bland or extremely stereotypical - spicy curry like food here.  That being said, I can only vouch for the dosas, idli, vada and the other typical south Indian dishes. I have not and will not try other dishes here ever. 

White truffle masala and fried idli (appetizers) are especially good. There is usually a long waiting time if you go without reservation. Even if you have to wait for an hour, I think it will be worth it!
author: Sofi H.

description:
Awesome place. Love it!!!!!! Highly Recommended. 

I grew up in chennai, i am really picky about my south Indian food. I really loved it, will go again soon. 

Here is what we got:
* Vada Pav - 5 star
* Watermelon, Panner, Moong, Salad - 5 stars
* Dahi Vada - 4 Starts
* South Indian Moon - 5 Stars
* Sambar - 5 Stars
* Ginger Ante (Drinks) - 5 Stars
* Pistachio Dacquoise (Dessert) - 5 Stars
author: Vishal C.

description:
My trolley broke down on the way here, so I'm going into this place with a bad mood already.

First off, I'll note that I am fairly wowed by the interior as I first walk in.  This is probably the nicest Indian restaurant I've ever been to decor wise.  I proceed to sit at the bar cause it's just my sweet self here on business.  I order the spicy paper masala dosa.  It's about a foot long, so I think I'm going to be stuffed, but no it's mostly papery dough, which is good.  The filling for of vegetables like onions and potatoes tastes fresh and homemade, but it's missing something.....................................meat.  As a man, a meal is not a meal without some organism that eats another organism in it.  It's my fault I suppose.  But the dish does deliver, even if I do like more spice than what the dish came as.  

Also, if I was teetering giving this place 4 stars, I kept it at 3 based on the crap mango lesee.  Skip it.  It has the texture of a Cadbury Cream Egg filling.
author: Stewart K.

description:
Coolest indian restaurant in SF.
Really really awesome ambience (a lot nicer than their valencia st branch) + pretty good food too (same menu as the valencia st branch).
Previous to this, the most ambient indian restaurant award went to Amber (the sf one), but the food there was pretty sad, so I am glad this place could take that honor away.
Had vada pavs, which were pretty good, and my friend had a standard masala dosa which he seemed to like a lot.
They have a pretty awesome bar as well!
Great decor, service and food.. need to come here more often!
author: Aditya M.

description: I really like this dosa location. The food is also always delicious. The best dish I've ordered here has got to be the channa bhatura. It comes out as a large puff dough thing. It's definitely not healthy but it's really good. If you haven't tried it you definitely should! They allow you to reserve a table via opentable which I really find handy. As a pac heights resident, this place is on the top of my $$$ list.
author: Michael S.

description:
For 1st  timers,  this will be hard because you never know what you're going to get !   I suggest going to their website and get acquainted with the Indian cuisine offered. Some of our plates were extremely good,  others were just plain bizarre. 

There was a 4% extra tax added on the bill to cover the Obamacare healthcare mandate costs they offered to their employees.  You see,  nothing in this world is for free.  I was uncomfortable with that charge,  but quietly paid it.
author: Richard M.

description:
Eating at Dosa is like a foodsplosion. Although Dosa has great ambiance, I don't really care at all about the decor, the atmosphere, the paucity of indoor stroller parking spots, or the uuns-uuns dinner techno. I care about the food.

If you've eaten Ethiopian or Eritrean food, you might be familiar with injera. Dosa is like that. Less similar, but similar in concept, are roti, tlayuda, tortilla, pizza, etc. Dosa is the food and the utensil. There are several kinds of batter available, and some dosas are smeared with chutney. There's mung (MOONG) bean, semolina, wheat... They offer vegan and vegetarian dosas.

If you really want to get adventurous, get the Thali. It's a variety of incredible little dishes including rasam, curry, a rice thingie.

Disclaimer: I'm white. If I like it, yes, you might like it too!
author: Klevin D.

description:
Alright, so rolled into Dosa at the least optimal time. It was about 4:30 on a Sunday afternoon while they were prepping for dinner. Fortunately, me and my main gal prefer to post at the bar so that wasn't a problem and sampled the bar menu.

Had some beers and tried everything on the bar menu and would have to tip the cap to the fried chicken bites. Fortunately the main dinner menu opened up and we were able to roll up the sleeves. 

The duck vindaloo is an absolute joke - so good. Just fall off the bone duck served over some basmati rice. The heat was solid but not overwhelming and just couldnt have been more tender - literally shredding off the bone. This was my first experience with this regional Indian cuisine and it was money. 

Definitely recommend giving Dosa a try but bring a benji at a minimum. 

Also had the mushroom nan - not my bag but my D8 loved it, so there's that.
author: Andrew S.

description: Arrogance at its worst! Arrived here on a Tuesday evening while visiting SF a little before 5:30pm. Restaurant Yelp timings say 5-11pm. The lady at the check-in said the "floor" hadn't opened yet ( opens at 5:30), and we could sit at the bar and have a drink. Then she proceeded to ask if I had a reservation. I said no, and asked if I could get one. She shrugged and then it looked like we could. My older parents said they didn't want a drink, so I stepped out of the restaurant while my mom, tired from a day of walking around the city, sat at a nearby table in the empty restaurant (other than a few people at the bar). The lady rudely asked her to get up and sit at the bench since the table was reserved. When my dad came outside and mentioned this to me, I decided not to eat here. Very unwelcoming and rude employees!
author: Nan M.

description:
Wow i really liked this place.
It is expensive though and the potions are small.

However the flavor was faaaantastic!

Ask the waitress/waiter for recommendation for spiciness level, because their dishes can get super hot.

Also get a variety, because everything has its own great taste.

High ceilings and fine dining.
author: Steven F.

description:
Pleasantly surprised to find this place last week. This was my first introduction to dosa, which is a type of savory Indian crepe. I ordered the spicy basil dosa, which was basically a gigantic, crispy triangle. It was pretty delicious on its own but the side sauces were key; they let you experiment throughout the meal and balance the spiciness to your liking. I also ordered the lamb meatballs, which were a bit expensive for what they were. 

Luckily, we got there right before the main crowd and were able to secure half of the large communal table in the front after waiting at the bar, which was also a step up from most Indian restaurants. Another difference I noticed: very few if any Indian people actually work here. Make of that what you will, but this is definitely not your classic Indian curry joint, more like a modern interpretation of the usual cuisine. 

Really cool decor and ambience. I'd go back for sure.
author: Jacob S.

description:
I thoroughly enjoyed myself here, it's overall the best Indian food experience I've had.  The restaurant is nicer (and bigger) than most other Indian joints I've been to in the city, so this does translate into a bigger bill than you might be used to for Indian food, but it's worth it when you take into account the ambiance and quality of the food. 

I went with a group of four and we all tried each other's dishes, with everything being absolutely delicious.  We were seated upstairs along the railing so we had a great view of the rest of the restaurant beneath us.  Admittedly this was one of my favorite parts, so I suggest you ask to be seated upstairs.
author: Javier M.

description:
My wife and I went to dosa last night for the first time.  I don't feel like writing a long review so here's what we ordered and how each rated:

Samosas - 5
Lamb skewer - 3
Truffle dosa - 5
Prawn masala w/ coconut rice - 4

This was plenty of food for two.

Overall we really enjoyed the food.  The service was very good, but I did get the feeling they were trying to rush is through.  I was hoping for our dinner to last a bit longer.
author: Tony B.

description: Food was excellent.  Service is marginal.  We made reservations ahead of time online, noting in the comments section that it was a special occasion, so we were surprised to be seated in the bar when we were really hoping for a romantic table maybe upstairs or at the back.  I am not a fan of the process which dictates that the waiter/waitress takes the order but does not deliver the food - when it arrived, we had questions that the busperson could not answer, and he was unable to get our waiter over to help answer the questions.  The waiter did not come by to check in with us until we were halfway through the dish we had questions about.   So basically, we had no objection to paying the price for the food, but the service and attention to detail is sorely lacking at this place.
author: Lilian A.

description:
My favorite restaurant in SF.  I usually make a visit about 2-3 times a month.  They have the perfect equation for a restaurant:  great food + great cocktail + Great service with a dash of a colorful ambience and great decorations.  

My fav dishes are:  Vada pavs (the best indian sliders in america), the Chile Uttapam (be careful, you will feel it the next day); the chana butura is good, not great; and of course the dosa's are very good.  A hidden treat are the idlli fries..

Basically, cant go wrong here with anything.
author: Shekhar P.

description:
I am not the biggest fan of curry but I really liked it here.  The food was really lovely and not sloppy at all!

I did book way in advance though for Valentine's Day and got seated rather disappointingly in the bar area.  I think it would have been much better to have been part of the restaurant opposite or upstairs.
author: Harriet P.

description:
Pros:
Fantastic south indian food, and great ambiance.  This place just has some sort of positive magic in it that keeps me coming back.  Suggested orders:
South Indian Bhel Puri
Poori
Rasam Fire Broth

Cons:
If you order rotee, which they have a lot of, it's mainly just a whole lot of bread (and in my opinion not too flavorful--only the sauces are), so if you are going for low carb that's not a great option.  I would recommend just ignoring the rotee section of the menu and focusing on the much more flavorful and diverse items like the ones I suggested.

Fun:
At one point we had 12 unique types of sauce on our table.  I took a photo and uploaded it to yelp.  Amazing.
author: Mike G.

description:
Waitress was a little awkward, to say the least. I politely asked if I could sub a different booze in one of the house cocktails. Her answer "No!" in a very abrupt, loud voice. Now, having been a waitress, I totally understand that not all bartenders/chefs are okay with subbing, which is why I asked, but I would never have said it that way. It left a bad taste in my mouth, which was exacerbated by the fact that we weren't asked how our food was until after we were almost done, and the bus boy/food runners did most of the actual checking on us/filling our waters/clearing our plates (they were great by the way, so we slipped the most attentive one extra cash on our way out). 

Service aside (which had been good the last time we were here), the food was awesome. We had a kale/carrot/cashew salad and lentil patties with an awesome yogurt sauce as appetizers. I had fish moilee, which was white fish (don't think the menu specified the type), with a really flavorful sauce over curry leaf rice. It was one of the best Indian food dishes I've had in a long time. Hubby had duck vindaloo, which was really spicy, but delicious, and the coconut rice was creamy and delicious. 

Atmosphere is nice - pretty decor, comfortable chairs, etc. 

The food was definitely 4.5 stars, but I've rounded down for service, which was more like a 2/3.
author: Natasha D.

description:
Great food + good service + Good ambiance = great evening!

I love south Indian food & this place does it with a twist that's quite interesting (Like an uttapam made non-traditional ingredients like broccoli!). The Sambhar (which every one knows, can make or break the deal) is very tasty; & my husband thought their pepper lamb was to die for.

Their desserts are very creative too. Besides, you start out the meal with a bowl of their complimentary fried papad :) Oh, & did I mention that they have a top shelf bar with really tasty cocktails too.... Whats not to like!?!  :)
author: kinnari m.

description: Never failed to impress.. It's like my fav place to eat in SF.. Wish there were 6 stars to give!! I wanted to update favs in this place.. Idly fries are so unique! So amazing yet so light.. And the chicken biryani was mind blowing..!! So soft and yummy!! Thank you for being so awesome!!  best dinner ever!!
author: Sarah G.

description:
I just finished my leftover Dosa and am currently regretting not having ordered more food for leftovers while I was at the restaurant last night. I had the spicy basil dosa which is apparently the most popular dosa on the menu and rightly so because it tastes fantastic!
