I was not a fan of their sambhar (seemed to have too much curry powder) but their coconut and tomato chutneys went along really well with the dosa. My hubby got the Uttapam sampler which was also pretty good except for the mushroom uttapam.. the mushrooms were too chunky and they did not go well with the rest of the uttapam. We also had -- 

the Mung salad (which was decent)
the squash pakoras (they were alright)
the dahi vada (vada was on the dry side even though it was submerged in liquid yogurt and chutneys.. not quite like the fresh home made vadas!)

I would definitely go back here, but mainly for the uttapams, dosas and sweet lassi.
author: Shrelp T.

description:
Great food. Love the cilantro fish and prawn masala.
Ordered the paneer peas dosa and chennai chicken  which was good too.(not great).
Overall a great experience. Has to be one of the best restaurants in the bay.
author: Shiv R.

description:
Great drinks. I mean they're serious about their drinks and have every right to brag about em. I mean the Peony alone is worth a first born. The bartenders are cute, knowledgeable, nice, but not too chatty--perfect.

Then, the food. Everything we've ordered has been scrumptious. I mean really, this place is down. The only reason I can't do 5 stars is it's crowded, expensive, and has kinda strange hours. Happy hour could be a lot more creative, but I am hoooooked.
author: James S.

description:
Great place if you are into those chik modern places.
Small portions, good quality and taste.
Loud and noisy, date place...

Bad place if you are a carnivore, you will go away hungry wanting for more (as the food is good just small portions), like 5x more.  

Food is good, service for us was mediocre, as there was a ton of people there.

BTW:  The place is so popular, they will even charge $15/head on a credit card needed to book, will charge the CC if no shows (disagree with the rebuttal as this was what I was told).
It also took me about 4 phone calls and an email just to get a table, then they couldn't accomodate the 9 person table and squeeze us into a smaller table.

Service needs to be improved.  
Even with mediocre service, missing food, we were still charged 20% with a large party.  Most restaurants charge much less for large parties (i.e. 15%).  Why should we pay more when we had mediocre service.

Customers especially in the restaurant are fickle.  Kindness earns loyality!
author: David H.

description: I was in a jam finding a venue for 26 people the night before our company holiday party when our previous restaurant wasn't able to accommodate a few last minute additions to our table.  First of all, I lucked out, but Daniel was super helpful in planning our party the blink of an eye and everyone really really enjoyed the food and ambiance.  THANKS FOR SAVING THE DAY!
author: Taress H.

description: Good food and good decor. A great place to come for the elegant dining experience and good South Indian food, a rare combination. Lots of menu options for both the eclectic eaters and those seeking good Indian food. I ate the mixed chili uttapam (pretty spicy) and the channa bhattura.
author: Rea R.

description:
I am a HUGE fan of Northern Indian food so I figured I would like southern Indian food. 

Late Friday evening my Man I and I decided to give Dosa a try. We were immediately seated in a cramped two person table between a couple on a date and a family with a little girl who kept coming to close for comfort. Not an ideal set up for our date night. 

My Man saw a table in the corner open up so we switched seats. Much better. The server at our first table had informed us he didn't eat Indian food when we asked him about the menu. *forehead scratching, what?* The server at our other table was much better. He was helpful answered our questions and had some great suggestions. 

We started with the North & South Samosas. I loved the northern samosa and thought that the southern one all though still good was filled with too much onion. We ordered the Chennai Chicken, which tasted like amazing spicy boneless chicken wings with an Indian flare.  The mint dipping sauce was yummy! 

Next came our main courses. The Lamb Kofta Balls were a little dry on the inside but the sauce on the outside was still amazing. The Coconut Jasmine Rice that accompanied it was delicious. The dosa was like a thick crepe filled with cheese. It was a little too rich for me but still good and it paired well with the dipping sauces. 

After our dinner came our server switched (which I totally hate). We ended up getting the server we started with. This coupled with my full tummy made us skip our dessert which I seldom do at a new place. 

Overall the place has a great vibe and the food is yummy but we will probably just come back for drinks and appetizers at the bar.
author: Caro S.

description:
This restaurant is a high-quality establishment offering top-notch indian food in a very unique setting. I love the idea of communal tables in a restaurant. My fiancee and I had the pleasure of being seated at these tables and making a solid connection with a woman on a business trip who lived in the same area back home. We ordered and shared food and life experiences over the course of our stay at Dosa on Fillmore, which was definitely a highlight of our trip.

We enjoyed selections from the drink, appetizer, dinner, and dessert menu, all of which were highly delightful. Sweet potato dosas, kale pekora, coconut custard, oh my. I would return to SF for the sole purpose of eating at this restaurant.
author: Seth T.

description: Interesting twist on Indian food. The dosas are huge! You must order the dahl vada with its layers of flavors. The decor is colorful, but still feels airy.
author: Crystal S.

description: I love South Indian food, and prefer it to Northern which tends to be heavier. However, it is harder to find South Indian food in the city, although there is no shortage of such places (joints) in Sunnyvale. That said, Dosa's is South Indian fare, tasty, delicious. I am no expert on this cuisine, but I know what I like. The dosas themselves are huge and crispy and delicious! Similar to those served at Vik's (Berkeley), Udupi Palace, but more expensive (I guess you are paying for the nice decor and high rents in SF). The sambars and chutneys were also fantastic. They also know how to market well. They have prepared a separate menu for picky eaters, dividing the foods into columns--vegetarian, vegan, gluten free, etc. Overall, a great place, but I'd rather go to a less expensive place for the same food. I am not much for paying for atmosphere, unless I have to.
author: 和子

description:
White truffle masala dosa. That's all you need to know. We order one at dinner and another to-go. Seriously. Order it. Oh, and the spicy basil dosa...yummmm.

The apps and curries are also tasty...haven't had anything we don't like. The tasting menu is a great way to explore for sure, some great picks. Or ask your waiter, of course. The whole fish they recommended was excellent.

Great "date night" or "impress a long lost friend/family member" kind of place  :)
author: Tysen C.

description: Great ambience and service but the food left a bit to be desired. The Dosas were good but very very oily. The Sambhar was the best part of the meal.
author: Anks K.

description: Authentic South Indian, compares to best Indian restaurants in U.S.. Highly recommended to try masala dosa, vada pav and poori.. Pricey but worth dining once in a while!!
author: Srini V.

description:
I LOVE DOSA. Their cocktails are amazing as is their food, though you should be forewarned that it is very spicy (says the white girl)! 

The -1 star is for the price, you could easily spend $75pp for a nice dinner here.

Try the Emerald monk cocktail--it has chile agave and is awesome!
author: Clara N.

description:
Went to Dosa with a friend who'd eaten here before, and what a treat! Very flavorful, with an occasional kick of heat, but mostly the "spiciness" was about the unique ways they blended what one might consider to be traditional Indian tastes.  Do NOT miss the chennai (sp?) chicken; next time, I'm just ordering like three orders of that and calling it an evening!  We did the basic masala dosa, which was fine (next time I'll be more adventurous!); the sauces make the dish.  We had the duck, which was delicious and was perfect with lemon rice.

Excellent service -- to be honest, it's so trendy-looking, I was expecting snooty staff (once a New Yorker...).  But our server, David, was lovely and attentive. And I always tip well when someone calls me "miss" instead of  "ma'am"...

Will definitely return to Dosa -- truly gourmet Indian food.
author: Elizabeth S.

description:
I don't know a whole a lot about Indian food. I know that the occasional times I've had it, I've usually enjoyed it & that I wish I would have it more often. 

That being said, I recently had dinner at Dosa with a group of 12 for a friend's birthday. The birthday boy and his girlfriend were the only ones who had ever been here before, but it was with a much smaller group. We were all pretty dumbfounded on how/what to order for 12 people. I didn't get involved in the whole process of what to order since I'll eat just about anything (I hardly even glanced at the menu, actually). In fact, I'm not sure if anyone I dined with had much of say in what we ordered. The birthday boy asked our waitress (who was wonderful!) what/how much we should order and she took care of us. 

Honestly, I can't tell you the name of even one thing I ate since I didn't order it or look at the menu, but I do know everything we had was delicious! Our waitress did a good job of picking out a variety of food and did an excellent job of staggering out when each course came. 

The restaurant itself is very nice, and there's plenty of seating on both levels. I had a couple beers with my meal, but some of the cocktails on the menu sounded delicious (I DID peruse the drink menu...of course)! The couple who had been here before actually knew a guy who used to be a bartender here, and they both said that the signature cocktails are yummy! 

The service here is also excellent! Our waitress was very helpful and patient serving 12 people & and we had no issues (and I believe no extra charge) for cake service (the birthday boy's parents brought in there own cake). I thought this was very nice on the restaurant 's part. 

I would like to come back to Dosa with a smaller group and maybe have more of a say in what I order (even though like I said, everything I had on this past visit was excellent) as well as try a cocktail or three!
author: George A.

description: I loved the options for vegetarians.. well obviously it is an indian restaurant but with good ambience. We were a group of 12 and we were provided a very crowded seating .. one of the reasons for 4 stars and not 5. Loved the food ... all the dosas were amazing. Coming from an indian who grew up in dosa heartland.
author: Madhuri G.

description:
Dosa is a staple on Fillmore and a great place to hit up before a movie at the Kabuki Theatre. 

You can't go wrong with any of their Masala Dosas, but you can learn from my mistake and avoid the Mixed Chile Dosa, it's labeled 'spicy!'. I guess I should have known when the entire kitchen staff came out to watch me eat it.

Indian spice you win again.
author: Patrick H.

description:
How can I have lived 3 blocks away from here AND NEVER KNEW ABOUT IT?

Went here for the first time just recently with the boy and his friends. Very classy interior, albiet a bit on the dark side. 

We decided to share an order of Grilled Calamari (spicy!), regular Dosa, Paper Dosa, and I think it was the Masala Prawns-- they were all fabulous, but I really liked the Paper Dosa. The spiced potatoes that came with the dosas were AMAZING. 

Waitstaff was really helpful and friendly.
author: Jessica Q.

description:
Albeit a bit on the pricey side, Dosa offers delicious Indian food that's a bit more unique than your typical Chicken Tikka.   They are known for their south Indian dosas (you'd never guess, huh?) and the Paper Masala Dosa is the delicious treat they are now famous for - and listed in the Top 100 foods of SF (by 7x7).   I

'd recommend a tasting menu to try as much as possible, except this specialty is often left off their prix fixe menus.  Come with a large group so you can maximize the variety - it's all soo good!

Great atmosphere with high ceilings and unique decor.  Gets surprisingly busy even during the week, so definitely make a reservation.
author: Greg B.

description:
OMG how did I not come here sooner?? I guess because when I'm hungry, I don't pick Indian food as my first choice. I came here for lunch last weekend and immediately fell in love. 

Complimentary lentil chips as you sit down and endless chutneys, veggie options and dosas galore. I tried the Masala Dosa and it was big enough to share among three people but the bf and I stuffed ourselves to finish it. We also had a little of the Paneer (not dosa but the thicker pancake kind) and that was good too. Since it's a thicker bread, it was more filling so we didn't end up finishing it. We also tasted these onion pieces dipped in a chickpea batter (forget the name, hehe) and they were reminiscent of the Awesome Blossom/Blooming Onion at Chili's and Outback. 

Service was outstanding and the servers were very hospitable. Very prompt  on food, checking in on us and refilling our water. Will be coming back again soon!
author: Joy A.

description:
When you first step into Dosa, it is a stunning restaurant, but you will be continuously impressed by the service, the food and the experience.  I love the lamb meatballs, fire broth, the calamari, the prawn masala with coconut rice, the dosas.   Truth be told, I have not ordered a bad dish here - everything smells and tastes wonderful with spice and flavor.  

Side note: Dosa is ahead of their time with thier nut menu - which features every dish and outlines which nuts are in which dish - which is super helpful to those with nut allergies.  Rest asured.
author: Jenn D.

description:
We just love everything about this place! The ambiance, the pipping hot madras coffee, the perfectly spicy thick sambar and the beautiful picture of a south indian dancer on the wall!

Our SF trip is never complete without a stop at Dosa :-)
author: Foodierock n.

description:
Dosa is a solid choice and they always seem to have an open table in a pinch. The restaurant is spacious and the atmosphere would work for a business lunch/dinner or a night out with friends. 

I'm usually good with a paneer dosa and the dahi vada lentil dumpling and yougurt appetizer.
author: Joe M.

description:
Way way overpriced!  
Pretentious, small dishes at outrageous prices. $10 for a two-bite desert. $20 for kofta with three little koftas (and you need to pay extra for rice) 
The only thing that is somewhat reasonably priced is the dosas. But much better - go to Udupi palace instead.
author: G Y.

description: The staff at DOSA are incredibly accommodating and friendly the entire time, making sure everyone was comfortable and satisfied. I had to make a reservation for 16 people and they were very helpful with recommendations and even upgraded our dining room, I felt like I didn't need to do anything other than tell them the basic information. The food is always fantastic and all of our guests enjoyed the tasting menu. Five stars! Thanks DOSA staff!
author: Jen F.

description:
Good cocktails, excellent appetizers. The Chennai chicken and lamb kabab were real tasty. The chicken biryani was up to the mark but would have preferred it without the raisins. The spicy basil dosa was a little soggy when we got it but tasted good. We tried the spicy chile uttapam, the one with 4 different chilies, its not for everyone, stay away from it and enjoy the other relatively milder dishes.

Good restaurant in a good neighborhood...would definitely recommend it.
author: Rit U.

description:
My friend invited me to meet her here after work on a Friday evening for drinks in the Fillmore. I arrived seconds before she did around 5:45 and we were seated immediately at the communal table near the bar (we were the first to sit at this giant table).
I didn't read any yelp reviews prior, so I only knew it was going to be Indian food. When I peered at the menu, I was a little bit shocked to see the prices (~$30 for curry). Since it was my first time, I only wanted to test the waters and thankfully my friend didn't intend on eating a full dinner either. We each got one drink and shared an order of lamb keema dosa, which was super delicious. It was flavorful without being overwhelming, and it didn't make my stomach hurt like most Indian food did afterwards. Also my friend got the peony gin cocktail, which she swears by. I'm totally getting that next time. I got a virgin drink that had mint and a bunch of stuff in it, reminded me of a mojito.
What really blew me away was our waiter. I think he worked at the bar. Even though we didn't order a whole lot for a typical evening at Dosa, he still was super nice and friendly. He even asked complimented me on my nail polish and asked about who did it. (Um, yeah that would be me... And I just did it to cover up old gel polish I didn't have time to go get removed). He was so sweet, you swear you were high school BFFs. Thank you! You were so fun!
I didn't end up getting the bill, since my friend was treating me (and wouldn't let me pitch in), so I don't know how much we tipped. But for the friendly service and tasty food, despite the cost of the food itself, I would totally return!
author: Jeanne M.

description:
We came in on a Saturday afternoon with a 1:45 reservation. We were there 1:42 and were told to wait and we waited until well past 2pm to be seated. Bad start. The place looks decent, nice a big, but the seating is squished into a smaller section of the large room and hence is quite congested. The tables are quite close to each other and we could eat right off the plate of our neighbor if we wanted to. 

Now granted this is not rare and there are several places with space constraints, but not Dosa, they have a huge area in the center going completely waste. They could've easily spaced the tables out more and made things a bit more comfortable.

We placed our order for 1 Vada pav (clearly stated one, not two), a Thali and dosas. 

The Dosa's looked decent enough, price is a bit high, sambar was flavorful but lacked body, chutney was "okay" have had better more innovative ones. The Masala was completely devoid of any flavor at all, its just a huge pile of BIG chunks of boiled potatoes. This is not how its done, a good dosa masala has smaller chunks, green chillies and a lovely hint of spices and heat, with ginger giving a finishing kick. 

Onto the veggie thali, This one is a complete head scratcher. It comes with one small cup of rice (this makes no sense whatsoever, rice is the core ingredient in a thali that holds the whole thing together, in India, the rice is not even served on the plate so as to not fill up the plate, its either on the side on a large bowl or served seperately by someone who will give you as much as you want!)

The combination of dishes on the thali made no sense either. There was one idly (again makes no sense, not only is Idly usually not served in a thali, no one gives ONE idly, its practically unheard of). One uthapam which was decent tasting, but then there was what appeared to be a Veg Kurma which wouldnt go with anything on the plate. 

Then a really odd tasting Pineapple Pachadi (Pineapple with Yogurt based sauce) which was really absurd tasting and one vegetable, yogurt, sambar and a sweet. All small quanitities, which is sort of ok but badly thought out. Its quite clear the person has possibly never had a Thali in a South Indian restaurant before. You have a certain order in which you eat  a Thali, and hence the dishes are all laid out in a logical manner to accompany the base items (Roti, dosa, rice) and you move along one after the other until you complete all dishes and end with the dessert, instead here we were left with hardly enough to make sense and unsatisfied.

We got our appetizer midway through eating our dishes and were given 2 Vada pavs instead of 1. This was actually quite tasty, but had way too much grease from butter/ghee and hence hardly qualifies as an appetizer IMO, especially if its served after main course!

Overall, its really nice to see someone bring South Indian cuisine with a fine dining approach, and while the namesake Dosa is decent, the core taste, culture and tradition seems to be lost. Sure modern day Restaurants requires everyone to come up with creative dishes to stand out and make an impact, but you need to get the basics right and the core concepts and ideals correct and then improvise on top. Clearly this person is filling a niche and taking advantage of pricing the cuisine beyond anywhere its been, but not quite comprehending the core cuisine.

Price : 1/5
Ambience : 2/5
Food : 2/5
Service : 2/5

Overall 2/5
author: Rekha A.

description:
Oh ma gah!  Sooo good!  This is actually my favorite restaurant in the city.  I have been here at least 10 times and have never been even a little bit disappointed (except for the time that I showed up on a Friday w/o a reservation and found the bar full).  

My favorite dishes are the vegetarian sliders, the samosas, and the curries (which my boyfriend and I usually share with a big fluffy bhatura).  The bhatura alone is worth the wait for a seat at the bar.  I dream about it.  And while we're talking about the bar, they have a really innovative cocktail menu, too.

I can't even talk about it without salivating.  I have to go back.  Maybe tonight.  Definitely tonight.
author: Emily H.

description: Very yummy dosa but be ready for some high spice. The lassi was great too. The menu split for folks with food sensitivities is a nice touch.
author: Khalid N.

description: Excellent food, ambiance and service. Finest dosas and curries served in style. I appreciate their conscience for selecting local and organic ingredients and sustainably caught fish.
author: Sonali S.

description:
"You like dosa, right?"

"Uhhh..."

"Stuffed Indian crepes that you dip in stuff."

"Then yes."

That's pretty much the extent of what I knew going into my first dosa experience at a restaurant whose name clearly shows off their focus. For those of you not yet introduced to the addiction, you're basically looking at massive crepe creations wrapped around masala potato fillings. You can order any number of varieties and then get to dipping them in a variety of sauces from coconut to curried lentils. So pretty much the best thing ever.

Dosa (the restaurant) is gorgeous particularly if you nab a seat in the upper loft that shows off the many fine details they sank into the design. Staff are very professional, attentive and helpful when it comes to first-timers. There was a bit of weirdness when we ordered several bottles of wine to share for the table - i.e. they were only bringing them out one at a time... - but otherwise smooth sailing from start to finish.

The massive portions are best served up to share. Three people can easily be bested by two dosas although feel free to go nuts in order to try more flavours. The only one you'll need though is the white truffle. Seriously. It may be the only food I ever want to eat again.
author: Ben B.

description:
5 Star for Dosas and "Dan" - its manager. We had made a reservation via Open Table to avail the $20 off promo via its app. When the app did not work as expected, Dan covered for the promotion by giving us a good will discount. Dan, we are extremely humbled by your gesture and will keep coming back to Dosas and recommend friends and family as always to dine at your awesome restaurant.

The food we ordered was excellent. Try the Vada Pav and Mushroom Utthupam in Truffle oil. Its amazing. The dessert 'Rasmalai' was the best we have ever had.

The hostess - can't recall her name - for Table 233 for a 7:45 reservation on June 5- was also very nice and service was fast.

The ambiance of the restaurant is great.
author: Piyush H.

description: The quality of food here has gone down from a year or two ago. I went here thrice over the last few months and have always felt really queasy after the meal. Something is fishy with the oil they use. Looking at all the recent great reviews, I may have just been unlucky. Well, its three strikes for me and I'm not going back.
author: Vin A.

description: This place sucked the life out of me. Way too much pomp and circumstance!! They hide their mediocre food, horrible service and crazy attitude behind a long menu, fancy names for usual Indian food, glittering decor and big price tag. The woman who stands behind a computer screen and has the power to give you a place to sit had way too much attitude and wouldn't put us on a list to get a table. Either sit on the communal table or get out. OK, we drove a long way in evening traffic to be here so we will sit at the communal table. NO NO.. those seats are reserved you will have to move to those other seats.. OK.. NO NO I meant those two seats.. Come on get down from you ivory tower, get your act together and move your lazy legs before we sit down. That basically killed the experience. Then the service was way too slow... it took 20 minutes for them to get the order in.. followed by silly food that didn't taste as good as it looked. I wouldn't recommend this place even to my mother in law!
author: Mack M.

description:
Elegant, loungy atmosphere. 

Incredible service!!! 

We walked into this place at the start of the dinner shift which can certainly be a time to get scattered service, but not with this crew. They had a calm demeanor. Each one. The hostess, bartender, food runner and busser were equally hip, friendly and warm.
Dahi Vada - lentil dumplings topped with organic yogurt, tamarind and mint. Makes me wonder what other incredible treats I have been missing! Yum!!

Next up - Samosas - they were served as a duo- one from the North, one from the South. An incredible tour without leaving the comfort of our table....

We ordered a classic dosa. Hmmmmm they really made this perfectly. The combination of aromatic spices danced on this dish!

Our entire meal was vegetarian however, if you are a meat lover, the table next to us raved to the server about the lamb chops. He said "they were the best he ever had".

Love this place! The atmosphere, knowledgeable service team, great wine by the glass list and food prep makes for a new favorite! 

It's restaurants like this that make me wanna go out, everyday, for all three meals!
author: Miss M.

description:
we're from seattle and this was our first time here. 
the bldg space and ambience is very nice and chic. super high ceilings, nice décor.
i had a mint lemonade at the bar before we were seated, which was very good. they serve papadom too that you can munch on while at the bar.
we ordered the truffle dosa which came with potatoes on the inside and 3 sauces; the hailbut moilee which came with some coconut rice and eggplant; and the spicy masala prawns. all were amazing and perhaps the best indian i've ever had.
my gf accidentally ate a whole chili which caused her to choke. CAITLIN a very nice server came by and noticed and grabbed her some mango lahsee to help with the spiciness. She was very attentive and answered all of our questions with detailed explanations. The service was exceptional. 
we want to go back again before we leave town!!
author: Juliet D.

description:
I am South Indian.  And this is by-far one of the best South India restaurants I've been to anywhere in the world including London, New York, and South India.  The food is absolutely delicious.  I did the prix fixe.  Except the seafood vada which was so-so, everything was near perfection.  The ambiance is higher end for a typical south Indian place, but some of it still came off a little cheap.  

As an aside, I would recommend ordering a lambrusco by the glass (it's offered so rarely in restaurants in the US).
author: Sri B.

description:
After a taiko workshop, we came here for some late-night grub.  It was a nicer place that serves South Indian food. They don't allow bikes to be kept anywhere inside, so when we came here with a friend who had a bike but no lock, we were a bit disappointed, but ended up just putting it in one of our cars.  The waiters seemed a little bit snooty, but I guess that's what happens when you walk into a nice restaurant in athletic attire.  But come on, we were there late, and not that many other people were there at the time.  We had a large group too.  Oh well.  

We sat down, and they gave us these crazy chips that were really flavorful and healthy seeming, which I thought was good.

If you've never had a dosa, it's just like a very thin but very large disk, that's kind of crepe-like.  They put whatever type of filling you order in the middle, folded over so that you can tear off a piece and grab the filling and eat together.  I ordered a white truffle masala dosa, which was really really tasty.  Very mild, which is good for me because I'm a lame-o when it comes to spicy things.  They also give you dipping sauce for it if you want that - one was spicy, and the other was mild, so it was really good.  It's a bit pricey, but I think it's worth it, at least for the dosas.
author: Jenna L.

description:
Delicious wine list at an Indian restaurant! I wanted to shout that out because that can be hard to come by, and it definitely adds to your Indian experience. I dined here with a large group, and they were accommodating and able to handle the party with ease. 

This is definitely a fancier Indian experience, not your hole in the wall Mom and Pop spot, and that tends to make me nervous, but I am happy to say the food was delicious. We started with samosas that were fresh and spicy, and the rest of the table happily inhaled some sardines!

For my main course, I had the seasonal vegetable curry, and I had no problem finishing every last drop happily. It was filled with large, fresh vegetables, and for $13, I thought it was a good deal especially for a SF dinner. 

Note: They are true to your spice requests, so they will definitely kick it up if you like heat.  I was happy to taste that!
author: Misti Y.

description:
Ohhhhhh... -SNAP!-

Add the "peony" cocktail
+
lamb chops to the hit-list.
(and while you're at it -- throw in their crazy-affordable-get-anything-I-swear-it-will-be-a-flavour-fest-in-your-mouth divine tasting menus)

I'm serious. Do it like, tonight.

....I'm sorry, what was that?!
Oh, sure -- You're welcome.
author: Anjali V.

description:
What hasn't been said in the over 1200 reviews already?! I'll do my best to keep this simple and easy.

I came here with a large group of co-workers and Dosa was more than accommodating. Not only did the server introduce herself to the group and offer some fabulous dinner suggestions, she was also quick to offer some great wine pairings. There's nothing better than being waited on by someone who is both friendly and knowledgeable.

A big fan of Indian food I'd somehow never tried dosa before. With the suggestion of the white truffle Dosa I could barely wait to get my dinner! In almost no time at all we were served a number of lovely appetizers. From lamb kebabs to samosas, it was all delicious. Then out came my dosa. WOW! It was massive, it was light and flaky and it was de-double-licious. Just thinking of it right now makes me want to hop on a plane back to the Fillmore and get another plate full. The server had mentioned it was her personal favorite item and boy was that a great anecdote. I can't wait to come back and eat more. The portion was huge and I shared with with friends.... but it was SO GOOD I'll probably come next time and eat it all for myself.
author: Katy H.

description: Fancy Indian food.  It was good but do I really want fancy Indian food? Is it better? It feels smoother, cleaner and more sophisticated. It was great food, but not sure of price point.
author: christopher h.

description: The food was very good and service was great. Our food came out quickly. They even have a separate menu if you're vegan or have a dairy allergy. The white truffle dosa was tasty- light on the truffle though. The mung salad was good too.
author: Sarah P.

description: Food was FANTASTIC!!!! The mushroom truffle pancake was delicious and the other small plates, including the samosas, were wonderful!!! A fantastic dining experience. Our waitress, Caitlin, was one of the best waitresses I've ever had! Great wine and food recommendations!!!
author: Evan H.

description:
I think this place ought to hang a sign on the front stating "stupid white people please come in and enjoy" because that's about all that will really find this place to be the bomb. The owner is from East India not South. The food is totally different in the two regions. There are only a couple of South Indian cooks. Look in the kitchen they are the dark skinned ones. You will only see maybe 2. All the other cooks were your typical Mexican or Chinese looking. Most of the patrons were white. White people in an Indian restaurant is not a good sign. Indians go to really good Indian restaurants, Indians know how to cook and are not going to pay to eat lousy food. Especially $11.00 for a dosa. 
In short I think the Mumbai/Bombay owner needs to thank all you stupid whities for making him so bloody rich.
author: Maggie S.

description: This upscale south Indian cuisine. Loved the food here. So yes, it's pricey, but worth the trip. We found service bit slow, however once we got the servers attention, it was all good.
author: Deven P.

description: Great place. Good food. Expensive though. Dosas are close to being authentic. Sambhar is amazing and unbelievably good.
author: Hari K.

description: DOSA was a wonderful place! I haven't had Indian in quite some time and it was delicious. The food presentation by each waiter was great, especially with the different sauces and how each will bring out different flavors depending on your taste. We tried the lamb, chicken,  squash dosa, and a delicious salad. Everything paired very well with the wine recommendation. Since it was Halloween it was added fun being dressed up and watching all the trick-or-treaters walk by! I highly recommend this restaurant. Also wonderful location right on Fillmore Street!
author: Emmy L.

description:
I am Indian and we indians tend to be a bit hard on indian restaurants.

The plus sides of this restaurant are that most the dishes are sufficiently authentic. Often times when you have an indian restaurant that is not 'dhaba' style you get this odd fusion type indian food which I hate.

The only letdown ironically (besides that there's only 2 non-veg dishes on the lunch menu) are that the dosas themselves were a bit bland! Arre! For a south indian restaurant thats almost criminal! But there are a lot of non-dosa dishes to choose from.

I had a kati roll (which they call a 'frankie', why god only knows) that was very good.
author: Ash S.

description:
I like Indian food, but when Lester W. told me that we'd be ordering all vegetarian dishes, I was a bit skeptical.  I'm a girl that likes my meat, but I was willing to give it a shot.

We ordered Samosas 'North & South' for our appetizer.   The dough was nice and crispy and the filling had so much flavor.  They give you two dipping sauces which helped bring out the flavor in the samosas.  

For our main dishes, we went with the Paper Dosa, Paneer & Peas Dosa, and Tamil Vegetable Curry.  All of the dishes had their own unique flavors.  We liked all the food, but our favorite was the vegetable curry.  We pretty much wiped the dish clean with our paper dosa.  The portions are definitely very filling.  Its probably better to go with three or four people so you can get a variety of dishes to share.

I guess eating vegetarian once in a while isn't so bad after all.  Good food and good service.  I'll be back for more of that veggie curry!
author: Patra I.

description:
Made a reservation for a Friday night, sadly Dosa refused to honor it.  Half an hour after the reservation they "kindly" offered to seat us in the communal area, but weren't interested in giving us menus or a waiter.  The loud, throbbing music was a plus while waiting.

Excellent food.  Not!
author: Alex Z.

description:
If more Indian food was like this then more people would like Indian food.
To be clear, this is food from India, not First American.
Also, lots of gin.  You like gin, don't you?  No?  I don't like you, either.
author: Rick D.

description:
Loved every dish we tried.
We tried chutney and bread (do not remember the name :)), chicken and veggie dosa and something else too... 
All in all - was great, a bit pricey, but good!
author: Nastia R.

description:
One of my favorites.

You can get a great steak a few places in the city but a dosa, only here. Everything that I've tried so far is incredible. I came in expecting some bomb Indian food but... it was so much more. It was nothing like I've ever tried. It was new, it was different, it was delicious. I suggest getting help from the staff in deciding what to get because this isn't your typical Indian food. 

Also their drinks... just as different and delicious. I tried the Peony, spice & milk mixed with fun (its not for everyone though).
author: Eduardo R.

description:
My favorite destination for quasi Indo-American fare in SF. Mrid and I have been frequenting this restaurant once a month on the average for the last couple years. So this review/rating is not based on just a single visit, but more like 30.  It is that good and lives up to its five star reputation. Great ambience, outstanding selection of cocktails, Chennai chicken and lamb chops are most excellent and have been very consistent in their preparation. I'll give their rava/paper/sada dosa a 4/5 -  Being the dosa flavorist that I am. Being said, I do look forward to come here every chance I get! Oh and their staff has been very accommodating and helpful. 

Tip: this is NOT your average Indian restaurant where your clothes smell of food and your curry floats in grease. There are other options for that.
author: Rajiv R.

description: 4 1/2 stars. If you haven't tried South Indian food, start with this place. The service, dining, drinks and food are all well executed. Dosa does not have that err.."authentic" feel when you walk in and I'm ok with that because this restaurant is legit. We had the chennai chicken, idli sambar and spicy basil dosa--all delicious. Make a reservation and don't miss out.
author: MissM R.

description:
TOP 10 REASONS TO DINE AT DOSA:

10) SPACE! (Unlike the Valencia location, which makes you feel like a sardine.)

9) Ambiance (Any Indian restaurant that isn't a hole in the wall, doesn't make you order at the counter, and can be described as upscale, classy and romantic gets an A+.)

8) Service (Friendly, attentive and efficient.)

7) Entertainment (Get a kick out of watching unsuspecting diners who are unfamiliar with the spiciness of Southern Indian food down their glass of water in 2.5 seconds.)

6) Your homemade Indian food never turns out this good.

5) Tasting menu (With all savory courses to choose from! Mango prawns for dessert? Yes, please.)

4) Chennai chicken (Yes, yes, please!)

3) Duck vindaloo (Yes, yes, yes, please!)

2) Dosas! Duh. (You can't go wrong with any of them, except the white truffle oil one just seems like a crime against humanity. Just saying.)

1) You're a glutton for punishment 'cuz it hurts so good! (Spice wimps, stay home.)
author: Anastasia B.

description: Not my cup of tea. The lamb chops were fatty. Everything is very spicy. Even with reservations we waited a little while for our table. Our waiter was very personable.
author: Geri S.

description:
It's HARD to get in here on weekend nights! Even to sit at the bar. :( I think we walked in on a weeknight around 8:30 and were able to squeeze in for a 2 person table. It's a classy venue--great for a night out or a fancy dinner before or after a movie at the Kabuki theater!

We got the Duck Vindaloo per Yelp reviews, but it was a bit spicy..even for my Indian boyfriend's tastes! 

The truffled masala dosa was very interesting--frighteningly oily to the touch, but tasty in moderation. A little heavy after a while. If heavy foods are not for you, share with one or more other people.
author: Vivian C.

description:
3.5...but not  fair because I'm not exactly a fan of south Indian food. Gorgeous, spacious interior.The GIANT fresh sardines were delicious, lightly fried with a small side of sliced vegetables. The Masala dosa with greens was interesting, the 3 dipping sauces, yum, especially the pure red sauce. The minty lemonade, refreshing. The guy liked the lassi natural mango drink.
 
The pani puri are what you might call a fun delicious flavor burst...small hollow crispy breads to be filled with the contents in 3 separate little bowls and doused with the liquids in 2 other bowls.. . I would go back for pani puri.

The guy had summer squash and potato, wild sea beans, carrots, peas ,cauliflower and lentils with coconut rice.  Very rich, more  of a winter dish.
author: Bleep S.

description:
I always thought of Dosa as a fancy shmancy restaurant with over-priced Indian food - why pay that much when I can get some cheaper food in Berkeley??? I was so wrong...

Everything was seriously a flavor punch in the face. To start, we had the chennai chicken and the lotus stem day boat scallops. Chennai chicken all the way! Great texture, spicy (use the raita to cool down) and good size portion too! The scallops were really fresh and I loved the two different sauces on the plate. We also tried the white truffle masala dosa and tomato and onion uttapam. The dosa was the clear winner between the two. How can you beat potatoes?! The dosa itself was crispy and actually kinda fun to eat. The coconut and tomato chutneys were really tasty too. The uttapam was yummy but not memorable. For main entrees the bf had the lamb kofta and I had the pepper chicken. Both were super yummy but I liked the flavor of the lamb dish better. The pepper chicken did make for some awesome next day lunch leftovers.

Dosa on Fillmore also has a happy hour until 7pm where they offer some of their drinks and bites for $6.

Service was on point and the decor is so pretty!

I haven't written a five-star review in awhile, nuff said.
author: Kim-van T.

description:
This was my 1st real indian food experience and I thought it was very legit. Food was great, tasty and the ambiance is fantastic! Filmore street is famous for having great restaurants and Dosa doesn't stay behind.

I came here with a group of girls and we were all very happy about our food choices. we ordered a few items and shared, so we tried more items from the menu.

The bar is pretty sweet too if you just want to come for appetizers and drinks.
author: Niley B.

description:
California meets India at Dosa.  I went to Dosa with a business friend, who knew and loved the place.  I live in Fremont - which is really more of the working class center of Indian life in the Bay Area.  Our Indian restaurants are very practical, very hands on (lots of buffets).

Dosa is Indian fine dining at its best.  We had the "sliders" which were amazing.  The waiters were superb.  I highly recommend it as a "high end" Indian dining experience, but really it is something entirely different from the massive Indian buffet culture which dominates Fremont and the South Bay.

Two very different worlds, two very different worlds.
author: Jason M.

description:
I loved this place! I thought it would be a very casual location. I was very surprised with the decor, the setting, the ambiance. It was wonderful. The service, quality and the food was excellent!  Multiple choices, the portions were large for me, but I shared which was nice.
Mango lassi was very tasty.
author: Neelam M.

description: Love the food here, and great service too. Went with a girlfriend and sat at the bar on Friday night; ordered a bunch of plates. Yum!  A bit pricey, but delightful. Oh, and they made me a really delicious drink... I definitely recommend trying something on their cocktail menu if you're up for an adventure.
author: Lyza L.

description:
The food was yumm, but maybe I had expectations set up too high, and so I got a bit disappointed.  it was good, but not awesome!
Sample of Uppadam, 4 stars. Paper Masala dosa, 2. (even if it was on the 2012Big eat list), chicken curry, 3stars. vada pav, 5 (2013 big eat list). Desert (chesecake), $9, good, but  sooo small.
author: Maria G.

description: Amazing restaurant from start to finish. Everything has such a unique touch but still the authentic flavors. The drinks are very well crafted and interesting, and they do not skimp on the alcohol! You definitely get your money's worth and most have a unique twist that you won't find many other places, many drinks making use of Indian spices or flavors. The Steph Curry was the most unique, but if you aren't a bourbon drinker go for something more fruity such as Peony. The selection of gin drinks is outstanding if that's more your taste. For the food itself I don't even know where to begin. It is best to get several dishes and eat them family style. It is absolutely necessary to try the namesake and get a dosa. The white truffle dosa was particularly good. There are also many options available for those looking for a spicy adventure. If it says spicy, believe it. The calamari masala was the biggest surprise in terms of spicy, but the flavors were amazing. Of course there are plenty of fantastic options for vegetarians as well!
author: Alan S.

description:
As someone who has tried to coordinate a number of large group dinings in San Fran from afar, it can be tough. Pre-set menus, price negotiations, one time I had to promise that our group would vacate within 1.5 hours. Jeesh. But that wasn't the case at Dosa. Service was outstanding, right from the get go. I was warmly received, and promptly responded to. And when it came to the evening of our reso, the manager even came over to shake my hand. I like that level of service. 

Now, I need to warn you, listen to your server. The dosas are entree sized. They're sharable. After appies, two dosas for 3 people is probably a sufficient amount. Each dosa comes with 3 dips - and you know, I'm just a gal that loves dips so I was in heaven! 

Food highlights of the evening include the sardines - wow, they're huge, samosas, lamb kebab, and of course, my dosa - the original with chutney. Flavour? Awesome. Just go, just dip, just laugh. 

As a large group, it was great to have a separate area that felt like it was just for us. If I were arranging another group here, I'd request the mezzanine again. Tis a beautiful space to enjoy some mighty fine dosas!
author: Crystal H.

description:
It's the most upscale Indian place I've been to.  Food is good but can be ridiculously spicy!  We had the chennai chicken, pepper chicken, and the Tamai lamb as main plates.  I have to say, the chennai chicken was my favorite.  It reminded me of chicken karage but with heat!  Very crunchy and moist.  The lamb portion was huge.  Lots of chops and the sauce was decent.  As for the pepper chicken, the heat catches up with you later.  It feels like habanero peppers.  The sauce for the pepper chicken was nice and the flavor reminded me of a plum sauce.

As for the dosas and poori, I could stuff myself all day with them. Even though everyone was full, we still manage to eat more of the breads.  The dosas come in all sorts of ways with dipping sauces.  Make sure you order them.

Overall good experience.  Clean, relatively friendly service, but noisy.
author: MTBer I.

description: This place is the bomb. Food is delicious and unique. Interior is stylish and so are the other diners. Servers are friendly, knowledgeable, and not at all snobby. We started off at the bar (where I got a very generous pour of bubbly rose), and ended at a table, hours later. Waits can be long, but once we ordered, the food came in reasonable time. We visited on a Sunday, and snagged a free street parking spot just a block away (on Geary).
author: Jenny R.

description:
Hello Awesome South Indian Food! 

For a restaurant that has no aroma/feel/look/waiters/host or any thing even close to being Indian(except for the Natraja Statue at the entrance) they serve some damn good Indian Food. Especially South Indian Food! Seriously! 

We had the following:

Appetizers -

Bhel Puri - Spot On!
Vada Pav - the best Vada Pav in SF
Samosas 'North & south' - pretty good!

Entree -

White Truffle Masala Dosa - Mind Blowing! Seriously!
Channa Batura - Spot On!
Masala Dosa - Spot On!

Drinks -

Divya - Pretty Good!
The Stowaway - Could be better!
author: Akshay K.

description:
Went here for the 1st time this week on a Wednesday night. We sat at the bar and order some happy hour drinks and app's. The wine they had on happy hour was good. The food I enjoyed however the guy sitting next to us ordered "the dosa" it's a popular dish here and it looked amazing. So I had to order it! We got one the marsla one and its basically a HUGE crepe with potatoe filling. Really good!! The soup it comes with we used it more as a dipping sauce. Yum. 

Ok now I have to mention this. The bartender man (tall white guy) he was either having a bad day which is understandable or he is just a moody guy.  He said some snarky comments to the lady next to me, and a couple to us. Hopefully he doesn't scare off business for Dosa.
author: Jess O.

description:
I celebrated my birthday here with my family. I would consider this restaurant more of an Indian fusion restaurant than just  an Indian restaurant, but that's not a negative at all. The food is South Indian, so it's not the same kind of food you're going to get in most Indian places which typically serve Northern Indian food.

The reservation website said that everything was full when we tried to make a reservation several days in advance. When we called to inquire whether we could get in for Saturday they told us the internet system has errors sometimes and that if we got there at 5:15 we would most likely be able to get seated at 5:30, when dinner service starts. We got there around 5 and went to the bar. I ordered a cocktail with rum and ginger. It was delicious and you could hardly taste the liquor, though I definitely could feel the effects. We were seated at 5:30 almost on the nose.

Everyone at the table ordered a variety of dishes. I tried a little of everything. I personally ordered the Spiced Pumpkin Soup (which was everything I had hoped for) and the Masala Dosa. I think the Masala Dosa could have been a touch spicier, but I am saying this as someone who can tolerate a lot of heat with Indian foods. The Masala Dosa is the standard dosa, though they had other varieties to choose from. If you've never had a dosa, you really should. It is a large piece of very flat, crunchy bread that is folded over with a filling in the middle. The filling of the Masala Dosa is potatoes and vegetables with curry spices. You dip the dosa into different dips - at Dosa they provide you with a tomato dip, a mint dip, and a lentil dipping soup.

My brother and my dad ordered the tasting menu, which is a $35 3-course tasting menu. You get a smaller version of the appetizer, an entree, and a dosa/uttapam (the uttapam is a thicker pancake with different toppings). The duck vindaloo we were told was the spiciest curry in the house. It was definitely not too spicy and was absolutely delicious. 

The atmosphere of the restaurant was beautiful. It's low-lit, there's a lot of fancy light decorations, and while the music is loud, it's not overpowering. Rather than the standard Indian music you would expect in most Indian restaurants, there was a lot of pop/R&B music playing. But given the ambiance of the restaurant, it seemed to fit perfectly.

This was a great place for my birthday dinner and a place I would absolutely go back.
author: Ellie C.

description:
The Goodwill used-to-be is now an exotic, dim lighting/romantic, great photo art decor restaurant. Bring a date!

and they pour ruby red grapefruit for my greyhound, that itself deserved a couple of stars...but,

Where's the naan? Ordered a few appetizers...only the tangy calamari was good. everything else was overdone (scallops) and way too spicy for my tastebuds...i had to swallow spoons of yogurt to calm them down. 

it's just ok for me....
author: Vee V.

description: One of the best South Indian meals I have had to date - and I am South Indian. The food is authentic but with a twist to make it interesting. The flavors are the right balance of heat, spice and sour. We ordered the kale pakoras, rasam, mung dal dosa, garlic and chili dosa and all were excellent. I had a cocktail (can't remember the name but it had tequila, cucumber and citrus) which was good too. We ordered the white chocolate turmeric pot de creme for dessert and I said I was only going to try a taste because I was full and I ended up eating every last bite. We enjoyed excellent service - granted it was Friday lunchtime so maybe not as busy but there were plenty of customers. All in all a great experience and I plan on a return visit.
author: Chitra J.

description:
Sorry, but Dosa on Fillmore is going downhill. Loved it at first, not anymore -- I think they're getting complacent.  

Our most recent experience suggested that service and food prep both need rejuvenation. Four of us were in the neighborhood this past Tuesday evening (March 10) and called around 7 p.m. about a table. We were told over the phone that yes, a table was available if we showed up soon. Easy enough, and it was true. But soon after arrival we were told that we only had 1-1/2 hours before the table was needed for a reservation. It's unprofessional to set a time limit on tables, especially when the service turns out to be slow and mistake prone. We had to remind our server several times about the exact dishes that we ordered, and despite our request for straightforward coursing the dishes were brought to us haphazardly. Our drinks arrived well after the first (partial) set of dishes, and then it took a very long time for the additional dishes to arrive. The drinks were weaker and the dishes blander than I remembered, and due to the erratic service several dishes were served well below the ideal temperature. Our server maintained a very cheerful demeanor throughout this comedy of errors -- frankly, a bit of contrition would have been nice (we *were* comped an extra dish, which did us little good at that point). And to top it all off, the food made my wife queasy later in the evening (a very rare occurrence!).

All of this suggests a restaurant that's getting sloppy in its complacency. They're riding a built-in clientele wave at the moment, but if they don't tighten up the operation soon, they will have problems. I can't recommend it at this point.

UPDATE ON 3-14 (next day):  I received a very nice message from the restaurant (presumably a manager), apologizing and extending an offer if/when I visit again.  That's definitely a plus, so I added a star to my review, to make it 3 (neutral to my mind). Other recent reviews suggest that my experience was somewhat unusual, and it's reassuring that the restaurant directly addresses customer satisfaction.
author: Rob V.

description:
Food is insanely delicious! Great place to take someone from out of town.
Very attentive and over-animated waist-staff. Go and eat!!!
author: Grace C.

description:
4.5 stars

Now this is yelp, the thank you economy, and pure customer service done right. The owner reached out to me regarding my A-OK review and welcomed me to come back and try a few appetizers on him. I literally live 4 blocks away so my roommates and I stopped by here on Tuesday night for dinner.

Their dinner offerings were excellent. All the items provide very generous servings and they definitely kicked up the spice a notch with these dishes. We got the following:

Chaat -- Mangos in chaat? Who would have thought. Apparently this is a South Indian norm to put fruit in chaat and I don't know why us Northerners haven't picked up on how good that is.
Dahi Vada -- Amazing presentation and great taste. They really know how to take Indian street food and make it classy
Pakora -- To be fair, I'm not a fan of these generally so I have a bit of a bias against this dish. Clever take on the chutneys mimicking ketchup and mustard.

Paper Masala Dosa -- Solid traditional dosa dish. Ask for extra of the orange chutney. Nom.
Basil Dosa -- 3/4 of us are Indian and have grown up with all this goodness. This dosa made all of us take a step back and admire how they made this. It's like pesto meets masala. Very good.
Channa Batura -- Seriously, the batura was bigger than my head. INSANE. The channa was excellent. The batura was definitely a little oily for my liking but that tends to happen when its deep fried.

Needless to say, I definitely had my mind changed and cannot wait to make this a neighborhood regular. Cheers to your restaurant, Anjan.
author: Raina B.

description: Great food! Waiter was attentive and made good suggestions along the way. (Mike) asked him for both drink recommendations and food. Chicken korma was rich and delicious.  Scallop appetizer was great as was lamb and vegetable dishes. Restaurant has a bustle and is a bit noisy, but not too much so. No naan bread on the menu but the alternative is good and the rice was excellent. I don't think you can go wrong here.
author: Thomas R.

description: Overall, great dinner. Perfect for date night. Sexy dining room with double ceiling windows overlooking Fillmore and Post Streets. Service was way above average. Our server, Caitlyn, was knowledgeable, efficient and super nice. The food was fantastic...every dish was done well. The lamb sliders should not be missed. Extensive list of wines and spirits. This restaurant hits on all cylinders: food, service and ambience.
author: Rita G.

description:
Outstanding. 

FOOD: 
App: Chutney Sampler. Standard, but delicious. Good portions and reasonably priced. 

Spiced Pumpkin Soup. Absolutely delicious. Tons of flavor. Perfect for a cold fall day. 

Lamb Chop: Order this and high five me later. Well worth the $$$ given that the plate is huge. It blended everything marvelously. 

SERVICE:
Food came out at odd times, but I'll chalk that up to a kitchen mishap. The waitress was apologetic. She also knew her wine paring and nailed the malbec with the lamb. Bravo.
author: Ryan O.

description:
My most recent experience at Dosa on Fillmore was quite pleasant. I'd visited both Dosa locations in the past and had a preference for the Valencia location because it felt cosier and more inviting. I'd commented to several friends in the past that although the Fillmore location looks nice, the combination of the high ceiling and the size of the restaurant makes it feel less private and more exposed.

However, on my most recent visit I was seated in a little area on the second floor just next to/behind the bar. Sitting up in that area I felt far more cozy and far less exposed. (It would also be an ideal place to people watch.)

The food at both locations is good. As their name implies, they make many different kinds of dosas, but they also a few other dishes like curries. I sampled a soup, a duck curry, an uttapam, and a lamb dish on my most recent visit and was quite satisified.
author: Glen G.

description: I may be biased as I'm just not a fan of Indian food (although this is Indian food with a fusion twist or something and it is higher quality than what I normally experience). Good spice levels which I enjoyed, although some on my party who can't handle the spice struggled. But like most of my Indian food experiences, my stomach was not quite right the next day, if you catch my drift
author: Ross I.

description:
Ordered the 7x7 list choice: paper masala dosa.

The boy and I decided that it's a great place to eat, high class Indian food. The dish was fun to eat with your hands and while it would have been nice to have been given some hand sanitizer, it was fun. We decided that it was a great place for a 3rd date or something. You don't mind the small touches and it's a great way to break that touch barrier. Anyways, we have too much fun talking about relationships and other people's relationships. He ordered a pomegranate mimosa, and I ordered the Mango Lassi. Delicious. The lassi that is. Very creamy. 

The paper dosa is like a really really really really really thin piece of naan. There were great potatoes that came along with it. Two different sauces too. One was red and had some heat, the other was green, coconut flavor and really cooled down. It was a really great way to get one of the 100 list down, and a great dish to be shared by two for lunch.
author: Nina Y.

description:
I had been wanting to eat at DOSA for a long time so I was excited to have dinner and drinks.
The restaurant is beautiful. The decor is very sleek and it has a great bar area. The dining room is nice but I had a problem with the noise level and the crowded seating arrangement. It's so crammed and I was practically sitting on top of the woman next to me. The sound definitely carries and you can hear the conversation next to you. 

Aside from that the food was great. Curry, coconut rice, dosa. I will definitely dine at DOSA again but may try the location on Valencia. 

Good stuff!
author: Denise S.

description:
01.26.10

Hurray for no one falling off chairs this time around!

Seriously, this place is too popular.  I feel so uncool walking in here that I immediately had to order a glass of $10 wine to calm my nerves.

We started with the samosas again.  They were still fabulous.

I tried the tamil vegetable curry with cauliflower, green beans, potatoes, carrots, cherry tomatoes and coconut rice.  It was SO delicious and complemented the glass of sauvignon blanc well.

And, number 67 on the 2010 7x7 100 Things to Eat+Drink Before You Die list - paper masala dosa.  My word, this thing could feed a village!  A definite order, every time.

Dosa is also known for their delicious cocktails.  We had the Emerald Sound (Domaine de Canton, rye whiskey, mango gastrique, absinthe rinse, mint, shaken over ice) and the Peony (No. 209 Gin, hibiscus masala nectar, coconut milk, lime, orange flower water, kaffir lime leaf, birds eye chili, up).  They were both quite tasty, and with a kick to boot!

Positive experience all around.
author: Jenny L.

description:
Dosa is not what i'm used to when i think good indian food, but i'm not complaining.  Mainly because of the ambience and decor, but doesn't bother me so long as the food is good. which it is. 
Dosa definitely has an american twist to it, but it's still pretty good. great for family style, good selection of alcoholic beverages, and great location.
perfect for dinner b/f or after kabuki :)
author: Sandy K.

description:
When coming to Dosa, I had high expectations. Having grown up on Indian food, I unfortunately can be a little picky when eating at Indian places. From the moment I entered, I smelled a familiar aroma that assured me that I was not going to regret this experience.

FIrst off, we went around 8 and maybe because it was a weeknight, we did not need a reservation. To start things off, we ordered some Mango Lassis. These didn't taste like the Lassis I've had in India or Sri Lanka, but they were still pretty good. We then received some complimentary papadum which was good (to be fair though, it's really difficult to screw up papadum).

So for the main dish, I ordered the Paper Masala Dosa since it was on the 7x7 list while my housemate ordered the South Indian Moons Uttapam. For both dishes, we were amazed by the presentation. The Paper Masala Dosa was so long that they had a difficult time figuring out how to place it on the table. As for the South Indian Moons, it was the envy of all the tables surrounding us as we had constant questions from those around us asking what that dish was. Both meals definitely tasted quite delicious and you can bet that we'll be back again.
author: Gajan K.

description: This is one of the best, if not the best, Indian restaurants in SF. I have now gone three times and would go again any time in a heartbeat. Everything I've ever ordered has been delicious and the ambiance is terrific. Great decor, and the noise level and table spacing are just right to ensure you can enjoy your party's conversation, but not everyone else's. I can't recommend a specific menu item, because every single thing I've had has been terrific. In summary: eat at Dosa. It's super-delicious.
author: Kathryn M.

description:
We are regulars here and love the food, ambiance and creativity of the menu.  But Saturday night when my friend and I arrived right on time for our 8:45pm reservation we were told they're running 10 minutes behind, unfortunately 10 minutes turned to 45 which was annoying and we were hungry.  I might accept this at a new restaurant but at this point they should be experienced enough to not have issues like these and plan better.  

Since she knows the owner and he was apologizing for the wait, she mentioned we should get a few glasses of wine on him, being that we are regular customers and by that I mean we come at least once a month.  He said he'll send something out and the host said that they would send out an appetizer on the house.  Unfortunately neither happened and then the waitress told us to save room for dessert because that was on the house.  Unfortunately we had no intention of ordering desserts since we were full, but we got two of them and had a few obligatory bites.

Lesson, here, don't promise things and don't deliver and if a regular client is a bit annoyed and asks for wine on the house, it's probably a good idea to do that, it's a good idea to do it regardless as a practice if someone with a reservation is waiting 45 minutes to sit down, and we shouldn't have to ask.

Now on the food, we had the vegetarian slides, which were amazing, we could have had more of them, they were tender, flavorful, unique in taste and just an amazing culinary surprise.  

The duck I had was very forgettable and not up to par with the other dishes I've had here.  The tomato rice was good, the duck itself was cooked to perfection and falling off the bone, but the sauce had no flavor, it didn't taste like spinach and was too refined and creamy and lacked texture.  The cheese chunks were odd in size, they were long and rectangular, at first when I cut into one I thought it was the duck.  

Will we return?  Of course!  Hopefully without the long wait next time.
author: Inga W.

description: Food is very good, but small portions for the price. Prefer Northern Indian, so not a great place if your used to more of a North Indian/Pakistani taste, not as many curry and naan style stuff, no tandoori or vindalu, etc. But decent food and nice ambience. Nothing to rave about.
author: Kay C.

description: One of my favorite restaurants in the city. The panear and peas dosa with a dipping stew, incredible! The drinks are unique very tasty. Also, give the Channa Bhatura a shot, incredible and super fun.
author: Benjamin K.

description:
We stopped in to pre-game prior to a karaoke night with some friends and all i can say is WOW. 

The drinks here are exceptional.  If we stayed any longer, we may have covered a third of the top two drink categories on their bar menu.

The bartenders were exceptional.  I can't think of a place I'd rather start the night.
author: Mike V.

description:
I came in here last night after a comedy show at the Fillmore. We were seated immediately on the upper floor without a reservation. Score! The food came out very quick, almost unbelievably quick. 

Masala Chutney Dosa: ($11.50) good. Not what I was expecting for a chutney. It was a rather dry filling. I will try another type of dosa next time I'm there. 

South Indian Moons Uttapan: (13.50) an array of their different uttapans. I would suggest getting this and deciding what types you like best for the next time you come in.

Dessert: Coconut Custard Cake - do NOT recommend this. Overly sweet and just not worth the $8

Prior to this visit I had come in and eaten at the bar before a movie at the Kabuki and had entrees and small plates. I would say the uttapans and dosas are a better choice. Great drinks the last time I was here too.

Service was ok. The decor is great and I will definitely be back anytime I'm attending shows in the area! P.S. They serve Mexican coke!
author: Mickey M.

description:
I definitely don't get out to eat Indian food as frequently as I would like. And it's one of my favourite cuisines! So of course I was stoked to hear that reservations had been made for Dosa. The menu was curious (I have this thing where I get major anxiety when I go out for dinner and I don't look up the menu beforehand). No butter chicken, only a couple of curries, and a major selection of dosas. Majah.

The place is GORG. Let's just get that out of the way. Our table was kind of upstairs in the loft-type space and we looked out over the rest of Dosa. Ambience, atmosphere, and staff are great. Love it.

Our appies were quite tasty. I'm not the hugest samosa fan but these were pretty darn tasty. Awesome lamb kebob, too.

I didn't go the dosa route and ordered an entree instead. My pepper chicken, and I mean, I guess I should have expected this, was super spicy. I like kick....I love kick. But this had way too much kick. Delicious, but I couldn't finish! (A combination of too much spice, and being too full from the tasty appies.)

Overall a good night, but I'll do the dosa next time.
author: Brittany K.

description:
Ambience: A+
Drinks: B+
Food: C+

Average: B+

This place doesn't taste unbelievably authentic to me, so if you're going for the food, please go somewhere else.  But the atmosphere is so lively and fun that I couldn't help but love it.  Even my dad, a 60+ Indian man enjoyed being there.  

It really boils down to one question-- Would you go back?  My answer: you betchya!
author: Pia K.

description:
This place is AMAZING!  I had the Potato Pea Croquette & South Indian Samosa as an appetizer.  It was delicious.  The croquette was something I'd never had before.  It reminded me a little of an egg roll, but was much more interesting.

My entrée was the Paper Masala.  Again, something I'd never had, but could not have been more pleased with my selection.  When the dosa came out I was surprised that it was about 2 feet long.  The potato, onion filling that was on the side was amazing.  Even when I couldn't eat anymore of the dosa, I couldn't stop eating the filling and finished it with a fork.  The coconut chutney was something I would have never expected.  It was delicious as was the tomato chutney.  The lentil dipping soup was amazing as well.  It was another part of the dish I finished with a spoon even when I was too full to finish the dosa.

This place is definitely a party in your mouth.  I will definitely miss the flavors and dishes that this place has to offer.
author: Christine B.

description: Food and drinks here are STELLAR. Always an adventure. The bartender is always grumpy so 4 stars.
author: C. S.

description:
Definitely upscale overpriced Indian food. Great ambiance in a great location bumps the prices up I suppose. I came with a friend for dine about town and so we went off the pre fixe menu. The scallops were deliciously spicy but you only get 2, the chennai chicken was ok - chewy, basically boneless chicken wings - ended up handing those over for my friend to finish. As for the main courses the mango & paneer dosa was kindof blah - like a crispy pancake filled with cheese that you dip in a bunch of sauces, and the tomato & onion uttapam looked exactly like an omelette with veggies - tasty but small. The pepper chicken curry was delicious but by this point I was stuffed with wine and the appetizers and would have preferred a dessert option instead. 

As for the wine, the $18 tasting flight is a rip off as we were told you only get about the equivalent of one glass of wine. So we ordered a bottle of one of the less expensive redson the menu (still 40 something) and it was barely drinkable, but we didn't want to be those people and send it back. 

I suppose if you have the money and/or a special occasion this would be a great place. I'm a big fan of the open and airy space with upstairs seating and service was excellent, but not sold on the whole dosa concept. Major negative points for the SF health tax. I think if I want Indian food in the future I'll go to the $10 buffet down the street.
author: Natalie H.

description:
I have read some of the bad reviews of this place and they should be ignored on the basis of their ignorance of indian food and the intense labor required to prepare. 

This is the first place I have been to where I felt the price matched the quality of the food. This is expensive, but where are you going to go and find a upscale restaurant with high-end decor that offers traditional south indian food that is healthy. 

I frequent Darbar in Palo Alto and that restaurant pales in comparison to DOSA. I have never been to a South Indian, or any Indian restaurant that serves healthy meals and uses organic or locally sourced ingredients and free-range meats. 

DOSA is by far the best south indian restaurants I have visited because of how they prepare their dishes. Most places you go, the dosas are beyond greasy, the "masala" (spiced potato filling) is either bland or too spicy and lacks in complexity of flavors. DOSA makes their masala dosa's with your health in mind. The dosa I received was amazing, the filling was delicious and the chutney served along side the sambar was amazing. 

Once thing to note: the sambar is super spicy, however, this is to be expected with south indian food. I had two bowls of it and wanted more, but my tongue was already on fire. This is not the restaurants fault, this is traditional south indian cooking at its finest. the only negative was that the sambar was a little heavy on the tamarind, though I didn't complain as I loved the gorgeous color.  

We also ordered the Kale Pakora (we ordered two rounds of it) and that was equally amazing. 

The couple who started this restaurant knows what they are doing and understands their clientele. They know that San Franciscans appreciate fine dining and healthy cuisine. San Franciscans have a plethora of ethnic dining options and will frequent those that use ingredients found at DOSA.
author: Devin M.

description: Love Indian Food but be warned this place is really expensive for cuisine that is supposedly common to the common folk. The food here was just really good and I mean with all aspects. The Na'an is plentiful, fluffy and crispy and damn good. The Curry dishes were just so flavorful mixed with the Basmati rice and Na'an just really is all the way spot on. The only complaint about the food is the cracker they serve as a tasting or a snack is a little salty but who the hell cares? I wouldn't go here every week but on special occasions and if you're in the neighborhood I highly recommend stopping in right at the beginning of dinner otherwise plan on making reservations because you'll be waiting for a bit. Luckily there is a bar available while you wait. They got this on lock for sure and the wait staff and the ambiance are just quality.
author: graham c.

description: The dosas here are really good !!! Great ambience and good service too. The vada Pav was delicious too, very flavorful. The dahi vada looked very pretty, great presentation , average on taste. Perfect dosas !!!
author: Shradha S.

description:
From the outside, this restaurant looks like an over-sized, imposing box. Inside, it is gorgeous, if a little too dark. The menu is a mix of dosas (obvi), curries, and other dishes, along w/several smaller plates. Are you veggie, vegan, or gluten-free? Guess what, there is a special and extensive menu just for you! This allowed me to give Dosa the 4th star!

Stars awarded:
1 star for atmosphere
1 star for the beer list which included many locals brews and one of my faves from Firestone!
1 star for the vegan options!
1 star for the service
But, I have to minus one star for the price! This place is expensive! Not outrageous but too much for Indian food. I realize that it borders Pacific Heights, and the food is good but this is SF where Indian food that is just as good can be purchased for much less. 

Go here when you need to keep an eye on the line at the Sundance Kabuki across the street, when you need added fanciness to your Indian food experience, and when you have two wonderful dining companions who don't seem to mind the finer things in life.
author: Valerie L.

description: One of the best South Indian Cuisines in SF Area. Ambiance adds a little touch to the experience. Definitely a must go.
author: Sahil C.

description: third visit - started off rocky, couldn't be seated until 15 minutes after rez time, then literally didn't have a server for another 15 minutes, but all was good after this - server was very friendly and extremely knowledgeable - food was attractive and, more importantly, excellent -the huge puffy bhatura was fun for all - we went "family style" and ordered several appetizers and entrees for the table - the halibut, prawn masala, tamil lamb, etc were all wonderful - we even tried the mixed chile uttapam for grins, but it will destroy your tastebuds and, combined with wine, will light you up, so eat that last! - great selection of wines to complement spicy and flavorful food
author: Doug R.

description: I am a little surprised at all the negative reviews. Staff was friendly and helpful, and seemed passionate about the food. The food was yummy. We got a couple of different sampler style plates to share. Super flavorful and yummy. Also, surprisinly big portions in this era of tiny bites. My only regret is that there were so many other great places to eat at that we didn't make it back to Dosa's before heading home to Seatle. Minus one star because the chai was not to our liking at all.
author: Sara H.

description:
Dosa was a new experience for me.  Came here for DAT and was pleased for the most part.  I'm not very knowledgeable of the different types of dishes from southern india, as this place is known for.  Speaking of which, my friend was shot down when he asked for naan!  Haha.  

The restaurant inside is very nice.  I really liked the high ceilings and modern decor.  The people who work here were very friendly and answered any questions we had.  

On to the food...

I had a 2-course meal, chennai chicken starter and lamb kofta.  The chennai chicken was delicious!  I was expecting it to be hard and dry, but it was actually really moist and flavorful.  And it went well with the yogurt / salad.  The lamb kofta on the other hand was sorta dissapointing.  I think it was just all over the place in terms of flavor.  It came with yellow rice, which in itself was very flavorful, almost tart. The lamb/curry were very good, but really spicy and a little too powerful too eat with the rice.  The yogurt was sort of just left there by itself, didn't really pair up well with the rice or the lamb IMO.  I want to give this place more stars but the main course didn't impress me enough.
