Seems like an upscale south indian place and I was not sure how the food would turn out, but everything was excellent.  We had masala dosa, vada pav, bhel puri and the chutneys were all delicious! Will absolutely go there if I land in SF again..
author: R K.

description:
I was really looking forward to eating here. I have driven past this place a few times and had admired the chandeliers and the nice bar. The fact that it always seemed so crowded was a positive sign as well. 

We had a 9pm reservation and were there on time as usual . They were backed up and we had to wait around 15 mts to get our table. While we were waiting for our table, we soaked in the ambiance which was pretty nice. They had obviously taken some effort to set this place up as a hip and trendy place. I like the music and the paintings. Noticed that it was very loud and that they had packed in the tables which does not bother me. We got a couple of drinks while we waited and the bar tenders were very nice and friendly. 

We were seated upstairs and we looked at the menu which was surprisingly sparse. I have eaten at several South Indian restaurants and love dosas and know that there are ton more options than what they had listed here. The food was pricey but not not surprising given the location and the setup. 

I liked the papads (similar to crackers) that they served while we waited for our order. The Kerala fish curry was a little too fishy for me. The lamb kofta was spicy but yummy. The rice dishes and the dosas were good. The rasmalai that I had for dessert was pretty good. In hindsight, I should have gotten their fixed price 4 course menu which would have been a better deal. I almost forgot our waiter. He was nice but seemed a little loopy. 

Overall, it was an OK experience. Nice place to hang out and grab a few drinks and try some pretty unique food. There are a few South Indian restaurants in the Peninsula that have better food but not as chic. I will go back if I am in the area.
author: Sunil R.

description:
We drove up this time for a special menu advertised as only being available through Blackboard Eats - five recipes featuring hot peppers.  There was a refreshing corn and chili salad, a flavorful lamb curry served with lemon rice, breaded and deep fried peppers stuffed with a liquid peanut sauce that spurted out when you tried to cut them, huge pan fried peppers stuffed with chicken meat, a very spicy uthappam.  As usual, the food was excellent ( though my companion, who eats whole habanero peppers raw, insists that it "wasn't very spicy").

I have a theory that Dosa is the type of restaurant that happens when you have a wonderful chef who cares so much about the food that he disappears into the kitchen and lets the rest of the operation more-or-less run itself.  The food turns out wonderfully, the restaurant is a beautiful space.  There are just so many little things that are not quite right.

It's a popular place, for sure.  We've twice made reservations, and twice now been directed to wait for our table when we arrived on time.  The wait has never quite been enough to get settled in with a drink at the bar ... just long enough to think you'll have time to do so and order a drink.  So twice now, with largely full drinks precariously balanced in hand ( no, the did not offer to carry them ), we've schlepped upstairs to the same small table which is just a little to close to a much larger table and in front of a window overlooking Post street.

Our server was knowledgeable about the menu, and estimated about ten people a night had ordered from the special Blackboard Eats offer.  He made some decent drink recommendations as well ( The Charlie Chaplin is really a well balanced cocktail, and my companion's Pink City was amusing.  I'd suggest ordering from the list of Revival Cocktails they offer rather than the more Indian-themed ones. ).

A few rough edges:  Charges for rice, which was listed as included on the menu, appeared on our bill, though they were quickly removed when we asked.  Service was adequate when present, but there were long waits on occasion, and times when no server was in evidence for a good five minutes or more.  Our leftovers were cheerfully packaged and bagged, and presented to us with the check.

It's much larger and more upscale than their sister restaurant on Valencia.  Overall, the food is very good, the bar makes a decent cocktail ( though they have neither draft beer nor Flying Horse ), the facilities are good looking, but the service is disappointingly uneven.  I'd have no hesitations in returning for some delicious, upscale South Indian cuisine.
author: Albert H.

description: We had a great experience at Dosa last night. Great food and really nice service from the staff of the Saturday evening shift. There were some rude customers disrupting the restaurant and the staff were both friendly and accommodating to our table in spite of the extra stress. We will be back.
author: M G.

description:
I love Dosa! 

I always get their dosas and some appetizers and I am always happy. 

This time, I really liked the grilled calamari. It came with a little baby octopus. So tender and delicious. The trumpet mushroom uttapam was also amazing. So many mushrooms, so much flavor. Didn't even use any of the sauces they brought. 

The dosas this time were ok, I think I'll need to try one of the entries next time.
author: CatsPjs Z.

description:
i LOVE Dosa on Valencia and have never been to the Fillmore location until last night. after catching a movie at my beloved Kabuki Theater, a friend and i decided to finally try this location out.

my initial thoughts: this place is fancy, but not stuffy or pretentious. i'm okay with that. it's a lot bigger than the Valencia location and would be great for a special occasion like a birthday or anniversary dinner.

we ordered two small plates (the coconut seafood soup and the shredded duck) and one dosa (the white truffle masala; my favorite!). for dessert we got the pistachio dacquoise with chocolate chile mousse. the shredded duck was good, but too spicy for me. after a few bites, i had to throw in the towel (but i'm wuss when it comes to spicy eats). the soup was delicious and had a good amount of seafood in it, which i always appreciate. the white truffle masala dosa has long been a favorite of mine, but this time it wasn't as flavorful. for that dish, i'd go to the one on Valencia for perfection. the dessert was probably the highlight for me--an enjoyable mix of textures and a perfect balance of salty and sweet, with just a touch of heat from the chocolate chile mousse. i highly recommend.

service was great. our waiter did a wonderful job of describing dishes we had questions about and recommending things based on what we were craving.

the food was good, but for me, not as memorable as the food at the Valencia location. it was almost like the flavors here were more refined, which suits the decor and overall vibe of the restaurant, but next time you'll definitely find me at Dosa on Valencia.
author: Dee A.

description:
Everyone knows Indian food is delicious but Dosa really raises the bar! If you want to know what exquisite, upscale Indian cuisine is like, you've come to the right place. The interior of the restaurant is impeccably designed with a minimal, elegant vibe. This restaurant would impress business clients as well as a first date.

My husband surprised me for my birthday and invited about 12 guests which were seated behind a short wall so when we first walked in, I still thought it was just us on a dinner date. When I walked around the corner and saw a table full of familiar faces I was pleasantly surprised. I think it's great that the servers and staff were accommodating and enabled my husband to surprise me in this way. Service was superb and I felt like a queen the whole time I was there.

First timers: be sure to try 1 or 2 of the dosas. They are amazing. I had the Paneer and Peas dosa and it was scrumptious! The prices are fair for what you get. Portions are on the large side, but there are small plates as well as many appetizers and salads to choose from. They also had plenty of vegetarian options for my veggie hubby.
author: L. L.

description:
We had lunch at Dosa, Fillmore recently wanted to share our experience. We decided to go to Dosa, Fillmore because of really good Yelp reviews and also based on what we had heard from our friends. Let me start off by saying that this review may be a bit biased because I am originally from Bangalore, India where Dosa is staple breakfast and the bar for Dosa is really high for people from Bangalore and Mysore.

Let me start off with what I liked, the ambience is good, the place is huge and tables are setup with people's privacy in mind unlike most other indian restaurants where they put tables really close just to maximize profits, this is where the good part ends!.

The service was ok, though I expected more for the price, oh did it say it is priceeeeeey, our waiter looked really stressed and forgot a few things we ordered but was quick to fix it. 

Now, let's talk about the food, if you are brave enough to name your restaurant Dosa, you got to make sure that your Dosas are absolutely the best especially if you are going to charge $15 to $20 for a Dosa. I am absolutely cool with paying that kind of money if the quality and taste is up-to the mark, sadly it isn't. I and my friend ordered the Mysore Masala Dosa, these types of Dosa are suppose to be bit thicker, crispy on the outside and fluffy on the inside, it was thin and soggy, it was horrible, I can get better dosa for less than half the price in south bay!. The chutneys were not made fresh and quantity was tiny, Dosas are eaten with a lot of chutney, this place needs to double or triple the quantity of chutney they serve. If you have never had Dosas before, you can try this place, if you know what good Dosas should taste like, avoid this place, save your money and pick any hole in the wall south indian restaurant, you will be more satisfied!.
author: Chethan V.

description: Been a regular customer ever since the first shop opened in SF. Its always a great treat. So happy that its easy to get reservations now with the expansion.
author: M S.

description:
The waiters are super nice but I do wish somebody would tell them the correct way to pronounce "lassi."
It is not supposed to rhyme with "sassy."
The service is caring and attentive - the waiter hovered over me, pointing out the coconut and tomato chutneys on my plate of spinach and fennel dosa... and the chai is actually pretty good, with a light fragrance of star anise, which is something you don't see every day.
But -- feel free to call me an asshole -- it's just not as good as the food in India. The dosa was soggy, with no crunchy bits; and the "sambar" (really, a very thick and un-sambar-like dal) was two-dimensional, with plenty of high and low notes but no nuance. The taste of the "sambar" completely overwhelmed the fresh spinach and delicate fennel.
OK so now I've experienced Dosa. Next time, I'll go back to Tirupathi Bhima's.
author: Lisa T.

description: I really love eating the masala dosas and vada pavs here (when they don't skimp on the onions, mmm) but the mixed drinks made by the head bartender are usually toxic.  I've learned the hard way to just not order them, but the other day I guess I forgot that it was a lost cause and just ordered a simple gimlet.  It was truly horrible and it's only like three ingredients.  Personally, I'd recommend staying away from the cocktails here and just getting beer.  Blegh.  Weirdly, the bartenders at the Valencia location are totally awesome.
author: Amy M.

description:
It could have been 5 stars had our main course arrived on time, but still highly recommend:

We were dining after a movie right next door at the Kabuki.
Our reservation was for 9:15, we were right on time, and our table was 100% ready.
We were seated at the upstairs section, which was very warm initially, then they opened a window, eventually I needed to put my (sports) jacket back on, though my date didn't mind, and they'd even asked us if it was too cool (we weren't the closest even to the window.)

Our waiter was super attentive, and hyper knowledgeable. I like to ask for opinions , explaining we were going vegetarian, and we wanted a salad and some other starter, naming our initial choice for each. He went into detail on the three salads and we picked accordingly. He also gave an overview of the menu, which was helpful.

I was disappointed that they said they pooled the tips, esp since our waiter really made our experience, but the other staff was constantly (and appropriately giving us new plates, silverware), perhaps a function of sitting in the relatively small upstairs.
author: Matt B.

description:
I am not a big fan on Indian food but this restaurant may have changed my mind!  If you are craving a cocktail, I highly recommend the "peony." Yum!

I can't wait to go back!
author: Vanessa L.

description:
I don't know if I was tired from Bay to Breakers or not, but I am not sure of my feelings towards Dosa. Fortunately for them, the boyfriend loved them so 4 stars!

Had the Paper Dosa and Shrimp Wrap.

Paper Dosa was HUGE and the spiced potatoes and lentil soup that came with it were YUMMY. the coconut and other spicy chutney were nice dips for change in taste. 

Shrimp wrap was pretty good! I liked the lightness but savoryness of the wrap. 

Had a party of 8 so there was a gratuity in our bill. Came out to $30 for the two of us. Not bad. Great atmosphere.
author: Kelly G.

description:
Really awesome Indian.   I went with a group of four and we shared the meal family style.  

Small plates : Samosas and Dahi Vada - The samosa were really fantastic.  Just the right amount of spicy.

Entrees : Lamb chops and Chann Batura - The lamb chops were good.  But the Chann Batura was my favorite.  It's served with a fresh puffy bread that is ripped and dipped into the chickpea masala.  Truly delicious. 

Dosa : Masala - This was my first time trying dosa and it didn't dissapoint. 

Uttapam: South Indian Moons - A chef's sampler of 5 different uttapams.

Dessert: Almond Pear Tart & Tearamisu

Every course was better than the last.  The waiter was amazing, offering suggestions when asked and hitting it dead on every time.  The pre-dinner cocktails were outstanding I had the Divya, a coconut vodka and pineapple juice drink that tasted like the beach. Overall an entirely enjoyable experience.  Make sure you make a reservation.  The place fills up really quickly.
author: Kristal D.

description:
I now know I prefer Northern Indian food. Dosa does Southern. The beer list is small, but good. The decor is interesting and the vibe is fun. The food is a step below okay. I dined with 3 others and none of us loved our food. I didn't like anything about mine other than the Raita. I ordered the Paneer & Peas dosa. It tasted like a bland egg and cheese crepe from a diner. I tasted the masala dosa and it wasn't much better. 

As other reviews have noted -- no Naan. Rather than naan they serve something called Bhatura which is "oversized, soft, puffy white bread". It's bigger than a basketball until you pierce it with a fork and it deflates. It was bland, greasy and reminded me of Elephant Ears from a Midwestern state fair. 

I would only eat here again if I weren't hungry and was in the mood to drink my dinner.
author: S T.

description: Unfortunately, dinner at Dosa was a big let down for me.  We had the coconut seafood soup, which was the best part of meal, the chennai chicken, truffle masala dosa, green mango & paneer dosa, prawns masala, and Hyderbaldi lamb.  The saltiness overpowered any spices used in the curry and sauces to the point where I was downing more water than usual. Service was impersonal and aloof. I left the restaurant disappointed and very dehydrated.
author: Kellie C.

description:
This is South Indian cuisine and they try to make you very aware of that in case you were looking for items on their menu that are cooked in a tandoor oven.

I had never had a dosa or uttapam before coming here, but I have now seen the light.  South Indian cuisine has a new fan.

A lot of choices on the menu but didn't really want to do the prix fixe four course.  Ordered the mango and goat cheese salad to start.  Nothing extremely special about the salad though it was good; the mango sweet and the goat cheese mild.  Our next three items came essentially at the same time -- the Fox Island mussels in a spicy coconut milk broth served with uttapam, the prawn masala curry, and the paper masala dosa.  I really enjoyed the broth in the mussels dish, dipping the the uttapam in the broth was delightful, but the mussels themselves didn't taste right.  Prawn masala curry was pretty good and spicy though not too spicy.  The paper masala dosa was excellent and was the star of the meal.  It came to us hot and crisp, rolled up like a massive Sanskrit scroll or like a giant version of those chocolate wafer sticks you sometimes get in your milk shake when it's topped off with whip cream and a cherry.  When it was placed at our table I couldn't help but laugh because the dosa was literally longer than the width of our table.  It came with three different things to dip it in as well as some curried potatoes.  I had no idea where to start.  No one else around us ordered this dosa.  Maybe they knew better, or maybe they just don't know!  Probably the former.  Regardless of the spectacle that the paper masala dosa can be, I really enjoyed it.  Ordered the banana cream pie for dessert and loved every bite of it.

Although I liked everything we ordered, next time I would probably just skip over the first part of the menu and just order up some dosas and uttapams as I really enjoyed those most.
author: Erich D.

description:
Came here for a late lunch and was generally pleased with the meal.  Service was great overall, and gf and I both enjoyed our dosas (paneer and the egg breakfast one).

However, the place is a bit pricy for what you get.  I understand that it is in SF and the place is decorated beautifully (in an Americanized fashion...) but when I'm looking for good Indian food, decor and ambiance isn't generally at the top of my list.  The dosas, while good as stated before, didn't blow me away either, and I'd probably just stay in the South Bay and get some equally delicious (if not better) dosas for lower prices.  That said, if ambiance and a trendy place to get food/drinks is what you are looking for, by all means hit up Dosa on Fillmore.
author: Andrew K.

description: Low bang for your buck. Food is mediocre at best and the place is shabby and not in the cute and atmospheric kind of way. Not my style
author: Beini S.

description:
Loved everything about the meal and experience at Dosa.  It is beautifully decorated, good music but not too loud, great service (over-the-top great), and FANTASTIC food.

I loved the beet and cumin soup in particular, but really everything we had was great, including the drinks.
author: neon m.

description: I really enjoyed the Masala Dosa.  very similar to one I recently ate in India.
author: Cheryl M.

description:
Dosa serves delicious, high-quality Southern Indian food,  fancy cocktails, and boasts a beautiful, warm ambiance. It's pricey, but it's not NOT within reason. 

If you want a fine dining experience, try the pre-fix menu paired with wine... YUM. You can definitely go cheaper though - try a cup of asparagus soup or a vada pav (veggie slider) for an appetizer and their namesake, a dosa (read: Indian burrito. I enjoyed the peas and paneer but there are other varieties)  with a Bengali Gimlet. 

If you're spunky and spicy, this is a great dinner spot.
author: Amber K.

description:
I had been wanting to try this place for quite some time. The place is GORGEOUS. 

I had the paneer dosa and the uttapam. I was in a rush to catch a movie at the Kabuki so didn't have time to order several dishes. Everything I ordere was awesome. The dishes lend themselves to be shared so I would HIGHLY recommend it as a date place.
author: Carlos A.

description:
Yes, the food is delicious, but the cocktails here are fantastic as well. The space is huge and the atmosphere is really nice and lively, but not incredibly loud. They seemed to have a descent sized bar area, so I might come back here again just to grab a drink. They have great options, but the Wry Rajah is something I will order every time. Its a whiskey-based drink with vermouth and cherry/mango flavors, but the bird's eye pepper is what really makes it special.

The menu has a huge selection. It is different from any other Indian cuisine menu that I have seen. It actually took a little while to decide what I wanted because there was so much to choose from, but I was very pleased with what I ate (can't really go wrong with any of the Dosa *Paneer & Peas is great!). They have a tasting menu for $35 a person and I think I will do that next time.

Good Food
Good Drinks
Good Atmosphere
Good Service
Good Selection
Good Time
author: Frank J.

description:
I have been wanting to try Dosa for ages after hearing rave reviews from friends - so, four of us went on on Friday before a show at the Fillmore.  Being the difficult one - vegan and allergic to legumes (lentils and beans make me nauseous), it was a bit of a challenge to figure out what I could eat that didn't have ghee or lentils.  

Our server was truly a gem and provided outstanding customer service - he brought me ingredient lists and consulted the chef.   After a misunderstanding with the chef - the Rava Masala came out without the potatoes because the potatoes had lentils mixed in - I was given a wonderful veg curry that more than made up for the additional wait.  My appetizer was a thinly sliced hachiya persimmon with a delicious coconut reduction and house made rice noodles that were crispy-chewy like the rice from the bottom of the thai sticky rice pan. 

One of my friends is sensitive to capsacin - our server provided her with great recommendations for dishes that were more mild.  The other two friends were the "easy" guests and were delighted with their dishes.

The mixed drinks were also fantastic!   Try the "Peony" or "Bollywood" - they have great lemonade, too.
author: Jenn C.

description:
I had a fun meal at Dosa Fillmore.  The space was as beautiful as I was expecting.  Staff was top notch as well, right out of the gate.  Get the tasting menu -- you get a ton of variety if you go with a friend who likes to share.  We worked our way through 2 of each of the 4 courses.  Some were absolute hits (crab cakes, uttapam, lamb curry), while others were merely good (prawn chile fry, potato dosa w/ eggplant chutney, fish curry).  Cocktails were excellent and the beer list was fun too.  Great time out.

Makes me wonder why i'd ever go out for a plate of pasta somewhere at a boring Italian restaurant...
author: Laurence W.

description:
Loved my experience at Dosa, totally different than the Mission spot (one of my favorite restaurants in SF).

Service: impeccably attentive. Very helpful with the wee-bit confusing menu. A manager came by "just because" and helped me decide between a French or Chilean red - she was armed with vino knowledge like no other.

Food: scrump-diddly-umptious. A bit different than the Mission spot, I welcomed it. We had the goat cheese salad, duck dish (score! Duck in Indian cuisine?!) and the semolina/onion/potato dosa (carbolicious!). Their brunch menu looks amazing, I am very much looking forward to coming in on a Sunday morn.

Ambiance: zexy! Great date place. Or business dinner. Or business dinner that may turn into a date ;-)

As a Bavarian actor  now-governor once said, "I'll be back."
author: Meredith R.

description:
Five stars for the food, three stars for the service.

First off, the food here is wonderful! Dosas are excellent and curries are great too (although I do find it a bit "cheap" that they charge for rice to go with a $20 curry).

My only hesitation with this restaurant is the service. I've been here twice and both times I've experienced the same problem. In spite of this being a nice restaurant, they don't have their timinng down when it comes to serving courses. Last time I came here my husband and I ordered beers and apps upon sitting down. Our app arrived after 5 minutes, but still no beers. We ordered dinner (dosa and curry) and our dosa arrived 5 minutes later....but still no beer. After over 15 minutes we finally got our beers. However, the curry we ordered didn't arrive for another 15-20 minutes after the dosa arrived. I found it extremely strange that they served one main course 15-20 minutes before the other main course (effectively one of us was done eating before the other even got his meal).

If you're coming here for dinner, stick to the bar and stick to the dosas or other quick food items. The curries are good, but both times we've ordered them they arrived way after the other main courses, definitely not worth the awkwardly long wait.
author: Alicia B.

description:
Great food, great venue, awesome service.  Our server was very friendly and knowledgeable.  He helped us navigate the menu and provided wonderful suggestions to help us pair dishes.

We started with the Spicy Sweet Day Boat Scallops and Dahi Vada -- both had amazing sauces.  For entrees we shared the South Indian Lamb Kofta (highly recommend this), the Channa Bhatura and the Paper Masala Dosa (on the best of 2011 7x7 list) -- each dish had great spices.  Our only regret was not getting a dish to balance out the spices of these items.  For dessert we tried the Dark Chocolate Cake per our server's recommendation -- excellent choice.

An added bonus was that Dosa's bar serves Basil Hayden Bourbon, which made for excellent Manhattans.  All in all, a wonderful meal.  I can't wait to come back!
author: Ashley C.

description: I've been here several times over the years and it never disappoints. It's my favorite Indian restaurant in the Bay Area by far. The primary reason is that they have very creative and tasty dishes. There is nothing wrong with Tikka Masala, Butter Chicken, and Tandoori Chicken, etc. However, they represent less than 1% of the wonderfully diverse cuisine of India. If you want to see what else India has to offer, go to Dosa. On our last visit we had Chennai Chicken (we generally order this every time) and Idli Fries. (Dahi Vada is another favorite). For mains we had the Spicy Basil Dosa and Tamil Lamb. The curry had just the right amount of heat, leaving a warm afterglow in one's mouth. I have a sweet tooth, but as much as I love Indian food, I have never been that keen on their desserts. Dosa is the only Indian restaurant that I bother to order dessert. They used to have a fantastic chai pot de creme, but alas, no more. They have a new pastry chef and the desserts we did have last week were very nice. Dosa also has some creative and tasty cocktails. I have always found the service to be attentive. On our last visit I mentioned that we had a time limit because we were going to the movies. The waiter did a great job of adjusting the timing accordingly. The ambience is classy, but not stuffy by any means. Finally, there is cheap underground parking available across the road in Japantown.
author: A P.

description:
DOSA on Fillmore is a top-shelf Indian place with a few surprises.  The decor is very modern and sensual.  

The tasting menu provided an excellent overview of the main appetizers, entrees and desserts available--at a fairly reasonable price.

The only negative part of my dining experience was that the wait staff seemed aloof and not very talkative (at least until it was time to present me the check and then the waiter actually smiled for about 3 seconds to solicit a better tip).  The most friendly member of the staff--besides the bartenders downstairs--was the manager.  At least she showed a personality and acted friendly.

Hints:  Try to get seated upstairs for dinner.  The noise level is a bit lower up there and the view down to the first floor is a nice feature.  Also, try to get to the restaurant early and have a gin-based cocktail at the bar.  The staff there is very knowledgeable and can steer you towards the right tasty adult beverage.
author: Terry F.

description: Great atmosphere, great service, and great food. Obviously try their dosa. Don't know which one? All the staff is knowledgeable and can set good recommendations.The waitresses are super polite and not to mention,really attractive.
author: Tommy T.

description: I came over to this place for the first time and man the food is damn good. I think when ever i m coming to sf i m gonna come to this place.  Highly recommend it to all yelp readers.
author: Sarun S.

description:
I've been wanting to try this place for a while now and was super excited once I was seated. Unfortunately I sat there waiting for an extensive amount of time before my waiter decided to graciously appear at our table... but over the course of our dinner his personality and patience with explaining the menu to me made up for it.

On to the food - it was good, not great. The curry duck and dosa we ordered were alright; nothing I would ever crave or found very exciting. I don't even have much to say about it... that's how memorable it was. We ordered a scallop appetizer... $16 for 3 scallops and it came out overdone/ rubbery. For $5 a bite... I don't expect it to be exquisite I just ask that it not have the texture of a rubberband. 

The interior was lovely and you don't come out reeking of Indian food. 
For the price and based on all the reviews I expected a bit more.
author: Karen C.

description:
I really enjoyed my meal but everyone else I went with thought it was just OK. 

paneer masala with coocnut rice was DELICIOUS!! I would definitely recommend it!

the coconut cake is also delicious if you're looking for a dessert. lots of levels and textures of coconut. the syrup was a little on the sweet side but very enjoyable!
author: Melanie F.

description: Jus had the spritzer and it was very refreshing. The dosa masala with the 2 dips and spicy soup was amazing! ! All the spices and curry flavors were delicious! Not a fan of papadum although I do like the crispy texture! Will be back for cocktails!
author: Ingrid J.

description: The menu is not the standard northern Indian fare that I'm used to but the waitress did a great job explaining and recommending dishes. Everything was delicious and presentation was excellent. This is definitely not your average Indian restaurant.
author: Tim G.

description: Great ambience, service and food!  South Indian dishes were good.  They accept payment through OpenTable/ApplePay which was awesome! Would love to visit Dosa again.
author: Utpal S.

description: What a wonderful surprise ! Came here on  Tuesday February 18 for dinner. The staff are super friendly and attentive.. Steve the bartender guided me through an amazing dinning experience .. Great wine list with wines from all over the world. The food runner described every dish articulately with passion making me want to order more.I had the tasting menu and the flavors were warm and comforting. Sweet potato Dosa and Lamb were particularly delicious. Can hardly wait to bring my friends .They get it and do it right! Fantastic !!!
author: Mona L.

description:
Grab a spicy lunch here and get your weekend off to a LIVELY start! My bf and I found ourselves by Dosa on Fillmore today and decided to give it a whirl because we really enjoyed Dosa on Valencia. 

First off, hellllo SPACE! I have never been inside Dosa on Valencia and it makes Dosa on Fillmore feel and look like a walk-in closet. Whereas Dosa on Valencia is dim, intimate, and cozy, Dosa on Fillmore has soaring ceilings, floor-to-ceiling windows, and light, light, light! Add to this, a beautifully decorated interior to enjoy a Sunny SF day in the Fillmore.

We started the meal with complimentary fried crisps/chips with fennel seeds. I'm not sure what they were, but I would liken them to some kind of Indian "tortilla chip" but much thinner and lighter. Yum! I wanted another bowl!

We split a Prawn "Frankie" (spiced sauce, marinated onions, cucumbers & cilantro chutney wrapped in Roti, w egg-white brush) and a Spicy Mung Masala Dosa (mung lentil dosa with green chiles and spiced potatoes). The server noted these items were SPICY! 

And SPICY they were....but enjoyably so, allowing the complex flavors of the entrees to still sign through. The Prawn Frankie was similar to an Indian "burrito" (Curry Up Now lovers, rejoice!). Juicy prawns in a red fiery sauce wrapped up in a soft roti wrapper. 

The Spicy Mung Masala Dosa was also very tasty. The earthiness of the mung dosa was a tasty vehicle to enjoy the savory spiced potatoes and spicy chiles inside. I enjoyed experimenting with the tomato, fresh coconut chutney, and sambar (lentil dipping soup made with vegetables). I tried the Paper Masala (a thin, crispy, pliable dosa) at the Valencia location and prefer that because I like more texture in my food, but this was still very good. 

Spent about $30 for 2 people, including tip.
author: Monelle A.

description:
Great ambiance, high end establishment. I recommend trying the Sweet potato dosa, its unique, delicious and not too spicy. Monsoon madness beverage was refreshing but had more ice than I would have liked. Service was decent, however the waiters changed from the beginning to end of our meal. 

Even though I was wearing tennis shoes the floor was slippery where we were seated. Due to cozy distance between other tables whenever waiters passed by they kept tucking in so we are closest to the table, like we are little kids;)
author: Dev A.

description:
High class preparations for authentic vegetarian Indian food. 
Chana Bhatura was fantastic. 
Desert carrot halwa was outstanding as well
author: Anil A.

description: Great ambiance and excellent service.  I would say this is probably the best Indian meal I have ever had.  I ordered the duck vindaloo with bhatura.  The duck was cooked perfectly and flavors were rich and complex with just the right amount of spice.  I went with 2 vegetarians and they were equally impressed with their meals.  Next time I am in S.F. I will definitely come back.
author: Joel W.

description:
Weird awkward service.  I went here to celebrate my sisters birthday.  I was excited to try this place out because, I love Indian food, and I've heard great things about it. 

Let's start with the food.  The food was pretty good, it was presented beautifully, but the portions were on the slight smaller side.  I loved the colors, the dipping sauces, and the huge balloon pastry puff.  

The service was on the shoddy side.  The gentleman that was serving us, did not let us know what was put on the table nor did he teach us how to eat it.  He wasn't mean, he wasn't rude.. he was just doing a below average job.  I didn't ask us if everything was okay, gosh, I was not expecting it to be this crappy here.  I guess I could say he wasn't warm and he did not make us feel welcomed at Dosa.  

There were so many wrongs at this place, that I could just add two more to finish off my experience.  I asked the gentleman to take a picture.  He took the most terrible photo EVER.  He took it so far back that our faces were blurry and all you could see was the sunlight in the background.  JEEZ.. He just handed the camera back and did not say anything.  No.. "is this okay? Should I take a closer one?  Sorry for the photo, but the light was too bright out, maybe you guys can move a bit.." and etc.. 

What made the worst lasting taste was he did not say thank you as we left.  

-5 stars for the service.
author: anita h.

description: Excellent service, large delicious dosas, great ambiance. We had the classic and the sweet potato dosas. Also had a Wry Rajah cocktail which was super delicious!
author: Bill S.

description:
I'm a big fan of Udipi cuisine generally, and was keen to see how they had put a spin on it. We ordered dishes with the most unusual ingredients - truffle dosa and sunchoke uttapam. Both were excellent, though the uttapam could have been thicker.

The cocktails were also very innovative and quite delicious.

The one disappointment was the coffee. It was tepid and not nearly as frothy as good South Indian filter coffee should be.
author: Aniruddha G.

description:
MOST RECENT DATE/TIME VISITED: Sunday, February 3, 2013 at 2:45 PM
COMPANION: The hub. He *loves* this place.
OCCASION: Alcohol-free South Indian lunch

::: [ OVERALL RATING ] :::

 ::: FOOD ::: 

   - Flavor: 4/5
   - Presentation: 3.5/5
   - Innovation: 3/5
   - Value: 3.5/5

 ::: AMBIANCE ::: 

   - Service: 4/5
   - Decor: 5/5
   - Music: 4/5 (Bollywood oldies & songs I know well thanks to aunts & cousins.)

________________________________


::: [ THE SPREAD ] :::

    * CHENNAI CHICKEN - $11
        - [4.5/5 - Beautifully seasoned and served with a watery (but tasty) raita. Sometimes it's tender, other times a touch chewy.]
    * ORGANIC CHICKEN 'FRANKIE' - $12
        - [3/5 - My bar might be a touch too high for this dish. At home, we used to make a lot of frankies. We also had a favorite restaurant called "Queens" in Jakarta with truly delicious frankies. Still, it's one of the better ones I've ever tried here.]
    * MASALA DOSA - $11
        - [3.5/5 - Standard masala dosa. Consistently good. They season the potato appropriately, and the sambar is always good.]
    * SOUTH INDIAN MOONS - $14
        - [4/5 - We always get this for the variety. Getting 5 different mini uttapams mean getting to sample more each time, some more veggie-clad than others. We usually have 2 favorites that we save for last.]
    * SAMBAR (served with the dosa & uttapam)
        - [4/5 - The sambar really does matter when you're eating South Indian food. Seeing as it's the standard "dip" for both your dosas and uttapams, it needs to be properly seasoned and just thick enough to stick without necessarily being as creamy as your standard curry. This sambar is good.]

________________________________


::: [ THE DRINKS ] :::

    * MANGO MIMOSA - $9
        - [3/5 - The ratio needed some work. Maybe a more concentrated mango flavor would've helped it taste more like a mango mimosa should than champagne with a faint hint of mango.]
    * NATURAL MANGO LASSI - $5
        - [4.5/5 -  I love their lassi. It's more sweet than sour, and though I usually like it to be a touch more sour, this was still very delicious.]
author: Asha S.

description:
I'm actually really disappointed to give dosa three stars as I love Indian curry and sf is in bad need of a decent Indian place. I was really looking forward to this meal! I'll start off by saying that I actually liked the atmosphere. It's super casual, a lively bar scene, and plenty of space. A little bizarre eating a nice meal next to a huge burger king but they can't really do much about that. 

For food we did the tasting menu which seemed like a good deal and we were able to taste several different options. The meal started off great with the chicken chennai and minced lamb. Both very good, amazing flavor and spices, ( spicy) but  not overboard. Then we proceeded with the truffle dosa and spring uttupam. Again both tasted great and something really different! by this point we were super excited for the curry! Big letdown. Holy heat in my mouth! Way too spicy I could not enjoy this, and there was practically zero meat in the curry. There were literally 3-4 bites of chicken. The whole meal was something different and exciting but by the end my mouth was on fire, and I don't mind spicy food. We got a dessert that I liked but actually forget the name.

The downfall really is the price of the meal. 70$ plus dessert and 2 drinks each and your looking at 150$ for Indian food......Wayyy too much.  I think next time we won't do the tasting menu as it's a lot of food. Great to try several options the first time there though. the service was a bit strange. When our server was actually at our table she took time to go through the menu with us and explain everything which was helpful, but she was  difficult to get a hold of. Drinks took a long time as well. Not really sure about the whole experience, Id like to give dosa another try but maybe will continue my search for good curry in this city.

Side note: the floor is super slippery and that has nothing to do with the beer I ordered being poured on it by the server.
author: Kate N.

description: I LOVE this place. The food is amazing, the service exceptional and the cocktails fabulous. Many of the cocktails you will not find anywhere else because they are made with Indian spices and ingredients. The dosas, of course, are great so is the chicken korma. I had never had Uttapam before, pancakes with savory toppings, and it's now a favorite of mine. The ambiance is fun and hippy. I love sitting at the bar. This is a great place for date night.
author: Sarah K.

description:
Don't expect to walk in and be seated at this sophisticated Southern Indian restaurant!  The management knows their loyal customers well and they strive to seat everyone precisely, but not before, specified reservation time.
In the meantime, enjoy the soft violet coloring of the space, take time to notice the beautiful details that went into the design of the airy main rooms.  Be transported to modern Chennai. Order one of their special mixed drinks.  I once had a violet liquer cocktail that was like nothing else I've ever tasted.  It's seasonal and not often offered, but if it's on the menu, I recommend it as an iced sip of heaven. 
When you are seated, take time to peruse the extensive menu, especially the Dosa listings.  If you are like me and you've had your fill of Americanized Indian restaurants, seek out the unusual items on DOF's menu and feel confident in ordering absolutely anything.  If you like lamb as I do, order the Dosa with Lamb Keema.  Your mouth and your tummy will thank you.
author: A W.

description: We make it a point to go to Dosa whenever we are in SFO.  Service is great, food is amazing. Just go. Enough said.
author: Mike G.

description:
So this is where all the cool Pac Height yuppies go for Indian food huh...

Fillmore St definitely needed a better Indian restaurant. The only option before Dosa opened was the $9.99 Indian Palace buffet a block away which may have been a liiittle bit too dirty for the Marc Jacobs wearing Pac Heights crowd. 

Not sure it's worth the one hour wait but the food is solid. Sipping my Gamay Noir from Andrew Lane at the bar wasn't so bad though. 

Dosa does Southern India cuisine very well. The Vegetable Curry was one of my favorites since it's mild and I heart veggies. The Coconut Prawn Curry was a bit on the coconut-y side for me. The Pepper Chicken Curry was okay but next time I would probably go with the Chicken and Eggplant Curry instead. 

For starters I definitely recommend the Somoasas "North and South". I loved the South one with carmelized onions and veggies. 

Huh? No naan? No worries. They have poori which is this delicious light and airy piece of fried bread. Good but don't expect it to fill you up because it's 90% air. 

As for the Dosas I recommend the Cilantro and Mint Dosa. The lentil dipping soup and the chutneys were yummy. I love Dosas because it always turns into finger food.

Dosa is a cool place for a nice dinner out with friends. I recommend making reservations!
author: Debbie C.

description:
A South Indian Restaurant with an ambiance, I'd take it.

We ordered Chennai Chicken, which comes with a yogurt dipping sauce, absolutely perfect with the spicy chicken. Either the portion was small or it was super yummy for us to have devoured it, in no time. 

I got the Paneer Dosa. I struggle with the fact that Dosa's have filling right in the middle so most of the time I have work my way from the middle to the edges. I was happy at Dosa, since the Paneer Dosa was sliced up neatly in pieces, not messy for finicky people like me. Loved the Sambhar and the Coconut Chutney it was served with.

My friend got the Chana Bhatura, incredible in taste and rich in flavor. 

The ambiance is great and the staff is very attentive, I need to be back more often to try other entrees. They do have an interesting menu.
author: En J.

description:
This review update is for their bar only.

I went to an event there last night..and had the opportunity to taste 5 of the delicious drinks on their menu. 

The Juhu Palm, with Gin, coconut milk, lime juice, birds eye chili served with a "spanked" Kaffir lime leaf was sweet and refreshing. The coconut milk was not overpowering.

My favorite is the Batsman: Gin, Darjeeling tea cordial, lemon juice and ginger beer over ice with a mint sprig..so drinkable that I can easily have a pitcher of it! 

If you have a hard time getting into Dosa for dinner....stop by for a delicious cocktail!
author: Mimi T.

description:
I went to Dosa to celebrate my 30th birthday and had a party of 16. The customer service was excellent. They helped me customize a menu to meet the needs of all my guests and even brought us menu's with my name on them. I called several popular restaurants in SF before choosing Dosa based on the service they provided.

I've eaten here several times before and have found everything that I order to be delicious.
author: Tori W.

description: We decided to check this place out on a Saturday night. It was jam packed. The decor of the restaurant  is gorgeous. It looks like one of those swanky restaurants on Sex and the City.We were told without a reservation we would have to wait an hour for a table. However, the host was able to seat us in about 30 in the bar area. The food was awesome. We went with some recommendations from our waiter. It's a must if you're in the city.
author: Alexia S.

description: had an amazing meal the other night. shared a bunch of small plates and bites.  first time here. seasonal dosa was amazing! service was excellent. food full of flavor and not so hot that you can't enjoy all the wonderful flavors. place packs up, we were there on a Thursday night full by 8pm. nice wine options. will for sure be back!
author: Jodi M.

description: Never have I been disappointed when dining here - food is great, service prompt and friendly, and the atmosphere hip and happening - will always return.
author: J L.

description: Oh gott I love that place for lunch. The dosa's (filled pancakes) are so yummy! The service is very friendly and on the weekends or for dinner you need a reservation. If you like to try something new, because its south indian food (only two currys on the menue and dishes you never heard about it before) go to this place!
author: Nadine B.

description: Love this restaurant! It has lovely decor, always crowded and the desserts are really good.  I usually come here when I need my chai and rasmalai fix!
author: Snoopy C.

description: Eat here. Now. Don't hesitate. Just go and get anything. I enjoyed the lamb chops and duck. The old fashioned on the drink menu is superb. Had no complaints when eating at the bar, but would do a table reservation next time.
author: Jacobus B.

description:
Went to Dosa last night just before trying to head to a show at the Fillmore as it's just down the street. The show was sold out and sort of a bust, but the food at Dosa certainly wasn't!

We got there at around 6 or just after and it was packed already (it was a Saturday, just after Thanksgiving, so could explain it). The wait for a table was 90mins, but the hostess put our names down for the communal table and said she thought it wouldn't be long for a spot for 2 to turn up. 

We got a couple of drinks at the bar, I had their house Gin and Tonic, which is made with a homemade tonic water, it was pretty good, and my friend had their bourbon/chili cocktail which was actually excellent. 

Took about 20 mins for a spot to turn up on the table and we weren't disappointed. We ordered a couple of spicy Dosas and the seasonal vegetable curry - all were amazing. My friend said she knew I was enjoying them as I stopped talking and basically inhaled dinner! True. 

Bar and wait staff were really friendly and chatty, and the food was really tasty and pretty reasonable. I think with drinks and quite a lot of food we were at 30-35 a head.

Will be heading there again!
author: Paul G.

description:
After my first lackluster visit here a while back, I had an excellent meal here last night. The space is beautiful, and it's quite the Pac Heights hotspot.

We started with the Crispy fish pakora, perfectly fried moist fish, and well seasoned. It comes with two dipping sauces, one of which was really spicy, so I loved it.

The Chennai chicken was fine, an Indian inspired fried chicken, but in the world of fried chicken, this wasn't the best. Nice flavors though, and served with a yogurt sauce.

The South Indian lamb kofta, meatballs, in a delicious tomato sauce, was really tasty, especially with the lemon rice.

We ended with the Roasted chile and garlic masala dosa. NIce and spicy as advertised, and with an even spicier sauce in the trio of sauces served with it.

The cocktail menu is quite inventive, the Batsman was really refreshing after a hot day.

I love how they don't hold back on the spice here, so I'll be back for sure.
author: Derrick V.

description:
Had a great time here last Saturday night. Great venue to have an intimate dinner party in...

We had a 5 or 6 course meal (can't really remember, because there was a wine pairing and we all got kind of lit up). the dosas are delicious as well as the curries we sampled.  this isn't your hardcore indian cuisine, but if you like ambience and beautiful people it's a great place to go.
author: Bill Y.

description: Can I give it 6 stars!? I LOVE this place! The wonderful experience begins as you walk through the door. The place is gorgeous, the staff is really friendly and helpful. But I would come back if neither of those were true. The food! Oh, the food! I started with the kohlrabi and cauliflower soup and my wife had to restrain me from licking the bowl. The North and South samosas were also excellent (the South was my favorite... caramelized onion... yum!). Then I tried several different dosas and each gave me a different experience of flavors... subtle and dare I say, complex. Run, don't walk to Dosa on Fillmore. You will thank me.
author: Dayna V.

description: Ok I realize I am giving it 4 stars compared to the other million 5's. Here goes my reason, the price they charge for a dosa does not seem reasonable. Dosa unlike a prime steak or things of that nature that deals with pricey raw materials, does not cost all that much to make. So when I think of the folds of profit they make on an item, it does not seem to add up. Well on the flip side, its more of an upscale locale with a great decor. The waiters seemed seriously concerned about my satisfaction which is always nice. The dip dishes was intense. I am from south India where this dish originates and no kidding they have nailed their sambar recipe.
author: Ambu S.

description:
I made a reservation for Sunday brunch for my birthday.  I basically informed whoever took my call that their tasting menu sucks and that to force a vegetarian to order from it on her birthday would be cruel and unusual and that I didn't want to waste $40 of my hard earned money on it.  Then the guy very politely informed me that they don't make you do the tasting menu at brunch no matter what the party size.  :P

Everything about this place is pretty...the bar, the decorations, the staff, the food.  If there's anything that makes me happier than pretty, it's shiny, or smellerific, or tasty.  This place is all that and a masala bloody mary.

Even Mr. Amy R seemed to have a hard time finding anything to complain about.  I did get one grumble grumble, "If this is a South Indian restaurant why are they playing North Indian music?!"  Um, honey, I'll tell you later.

I liked the music.  I liked everything.  The masala dosa I ordered was excellent which, having eaten masala dosa all over the world, I feel confident in labeling myself an authority on.  My sambar was great, as was the great love of my life, my little coconut chutney.

I also ordered dahi vadas and to my great relief they weren't the nasty Gujarati sweet ones that some restaurants have.  They did come with tamarind sauce and mint chutney on them which looked really nice.  I kinda felt like I was eating chaat, but it was really good nonetheless.

I'm really glad I chose this spot for my birthday brunch.  They also have a really shiny bar that I would probably stop by for.
author: PrincessPeac H.

description:
I heard so much about the dosas here, and my friend and I wanted a quick dinner before going to Yoshi's jazz night. We went there right when it opened for dinner and got seated fairly quickly. 

The service was good, though might have been too quick and attentive because it was a bit weird when the server immediately asked us what we wanted (haha so much pressure to decide on dinner). 

We ordered two masala dosa (the spicy basil one and the traditional with chutney). Both were good and the three dipping sauces (the soothing coconut one was really good) complimented everything well. However, for the price to quality, I wasn't too impressed. I love the dosas and masalas I used to eat in Berkeley for half the price, and those had so much more flavor.
author: Tif L.

description: Great cocktails, tasty Indian food...and definitely worth a try but a little on the pricier side.  This fine city offers better options for the buck in my humble opinion.
author: Grant K.

description:
For at least a few weeks now I've been passing by Dosa on Fillmore, just blatantly staring at the customers eating what looks to be delicious southern Indian food. Oh who am I kidding, I'm staring at the light fixtures. I'm secretly a moth, which probably explains why I run into sliding glass doors a lot.

But last Monday I called up a friend and said that, since I was famished and couldn't walk more than a few steps from my car without passing out, we should totally check out Dosa. Being the gentleman he is, he obliged and we met at the bar. It was pretty obvious that he and I had absolutely no idea what to order, because we're used to french and italian food, and this is *clearly* not either of them. Of course, he HAS to ask the bartender why a French wine has a German name (the Gerwuzientalksdjfalkfjder). Whatever, I'm having the cab. 

We decide to get the samosas, the steamed rice ball thingie, a cheese dosa and one that starts with an M that is third down on the menu...amazing I can remember shit like that but NOT the name itself. 

The samosas and the sauces were delicious--get them. The steamed puffed rice was wonderful but then when the dosa came out, I expect them to have different sauces--they didn't. All came with the tomato chutney, the coconut chutney, and the broth type looking thing. It was all wonderful, but I like a little variety with my sauces. So four stars. My friend kept saying the cheese one looked like an enchilada. Apparently, he ALSO has taco bell on the brain. What is it these days with wanting taco bell and then going to a fancy restaurant instead!?

And negative stars for me putting my umbrella on the stool and waiters kept apologizing for knocking it over. It's my fault that I did that! Please stop saying sorry!
author: Jaime L.

description:
What a wonderful experience we had at Dosa on Fillmore!  My dining partner and I had been to the Dosa on Valencia a couple of times a few years ago when it first opened.  We both love Indian food, and it was our first experience eating dosas and uttapams.  We were a little underwhelmed with the blandness of these (starch filled with more starch) and, given the difficulty of getting a table there, didn't go out of our way to return.

However, a friend told us to try Dosa on Fillmore, adding that he thought the dishes other than the dosas were superior.  We couldn't agree more.  We were surprised with dishes with complexity of flavor.  The restaurant itself, while a bit of a hipster haven, is quite spacious and the mid-century design is well done.  Also, the menu is different than the restaurant on Valencia.  Now to the food.

My partner had the tasting menu:
Chennai chicken, which we joked is the Indian version of buffalo wings.  Savory fried bits of chicken with a delightful spicy crust.
Sunchoke uttapam:  A nicely presented pancake, but the bell peppers overwhelmed the rest of the more subtle flavors.
Lamb kofta:  Fabulous meatballs in a tasty, tomato-y sauce.

I had the Channa bhatura, a chickpea curry with a super delicious, puffy piece of bread that is as big as a soccer ball until you puncture it with your fork.  This was a subtle and slightly sweet dish that went very well with the bread.

Because we enjoyed our entrees so much, we decided to share dessert, and we were not disappointed with a sublime fig, honey and cardamom gelato.  We had the chickory coffee which we were surprised wasn't more like a chai (with the nutmeg, cinnamon, cardamom, etc.), but if you've had chickory coffee in New Orleans, this coffee will be familiar and have you craving beignets.

One thing that surprised us was that the dishes weren't spicier.  We really enjoy hot food, but none of our selections was very spicy.  Not a complaint--the flavors were complex and carefully combined--but I had read on Yelp that the food set off some people's spice meters.

Service was exceptional and the pricing (except for the pre-dinner whiskey, which was exorbitant) was more than fair.  We will be back.
author: Barbara C.

description:
Highlights- Vada pav a unique one that i had not tasted anywhere else.
Food - Very good since the vada pavs, thalis and their selling point Dosas keep up with their mark. Does not have million choices on menu, but keeps with good minimum choices.
Service- handling is done very well even during bigger crowds.Does not display that elitist behavior for being in a posh area. also clean.
Location- bit away from the usual buzz area. Thank god the setup was not as naive as any other Indian restaurants.
author: Pawankumar H.

description: Great place. Vada pavs are really good
author: Aaditya D.

description: One of the best ambiences for an Indian restaurant. Food was decent but the dessert was awesome. Must try the coconut custard cake.
author: Ashutosh T.

description:
I'm not crazy about these people.  I have been here many times and the first visit's sour taste has never left my mouth.

We went in on a Thursday night... no reservation... I get it...popular place, good food and all.  They told us a certian amount of time. That time came...It was not to be...they told me another amount of time... I gave them my phone number, expected that was going to bring us to our table,,,nope,,, Upon checking later with her there was nothing for us and she was very rude...the way she presented our table seating time felt to me like it could be forever...

I did not get the feeling like the hostess (who is probably overworked, I know) gave a shit that she ruined my night... and my first experience with what should be a restaurant of great prestige...


 I'll probably end up in here over the years, have been several times since that one time with HER... eating food that doesn't quell or impress me.

it's an institution I guess....
author: Kerstin A.

description: We had ordered paneer & peas dosa and Chile uttapam. Food is a bit pricey but taste, decor and quality was superb.
author: Mrunal U.

description: I thought this was just OK. It was not bad, but basically to me you seem to be paying a bit more for food that you can get elsewhere for cheaper and perhaps even better tasting. The decor is very nice inside, but again I do not think its the best food available. Good just not great.
author: Jamie K.

description:
I've become a bit of an upscale Indian food diner.  As snobbish as it may seem, I've realized that most cheap Indian food joints and lunch buffet places are very, very mediocre while expensive restaurants invest on quality and authenticity.  This location of Dosa feels very welcoming, especially with the high ceilings and roomy space they have.  

The food is delicious!  I had the green-colored dosa", also known as pesarattu, relished in Andhra Pradesh and usually had with an accompaniment of spicy chatnis and sambar.  I did however enjoy the addition of the "masala" to it but ended up not finishing the potatoes - 'cos really ..... mung dosas are kinda heavy!  My other dining mates ordered delicious looking food and I did get a taste of the spicy Mysore dosa with an additional garlicy spice.  Very delicious, mouthwatering and spicy.  

I was a tad underwhelmed by the vada pav appetizer.  If you've eaten on the streets of Mumbai, you'll know what I mean!  Why did they put caramelized onions in it?  Anyway, I do appreciate an effort to be creative but I'm not sure tempering the taste with something sweetish or caramelized is the way to go. The Bombay frankie roll was delicious but again lacked the crucial ingredient of pickled small green chilies ... a traditional Indo-Chinese item that's always used in frankies.  

Definitely worth a visit.  Great drinks too.  I had the Bloody Curry which was a deliciously prepared drink.  Try to come weekday afternoons ..... less rush!
author: Aditya R.

description:
1] Food: (A++) I'm in love with everything here. What can i say? I can eat their Sada Paper Dosa + Sambar for DAYYSSSS.
2] Dessert: (A) Rasmalai yum, custard yum, gulab jaman yum
3] Drinks: (A+) Mango Lassi yum, mint lemonade yum
4] Service: (A) Always helpful and trendy
5] Ambiance: (A+) Trendy, stylish indian, cute, and ethnic.
6] Price: (B) 2 drinks, 1 app, 1 fish dish, 1 lamb dish, 1 dosa, 1 huge roti bubble, 1 dessert = all shared for $65

FINAL: FAV INDIAN for groups and social settings
author: Monalisa M.

description:
We were introduced to Dosa on this last visit to the city and am already sad that we don't have anything as good here near Baltimore/DC (so it seems).  I sampled the three-course tasting menu enjoying the Red Beet Croquette, White Truffle Masala Dosa and Lamb Kofta, which was a great sampling of the menu for a first timer here.   

The white truffle masala dosa had a great truffle flavor, and was a great savory combination.  I had never heard of a dosa prior and I have officially fallen in love.  The lamb kofta was just spicy enough for me, and all of the corresponding chutneys that were presented with the dosas at the table were lovely to try.  At our table we all ordered a different selection from the dessert menu and were not disappointed, mmm blood orange & ginger sorbet.  

Dosa is definitely a must enjoy on our next trip to SF, I can't wait.
author: Suzanne J.

description: Brunch was the best! We had appetizers, dosa, and thalis. Everything was so flavorful - almost exotic. The manager spent a lot of time with us, explaining all of the foods and how to eat the thali. I have been to many Indian restaurants, and no one has ever spent the time with me to explain the menu is such detail. The restaurant was beautiful and was light and airy. By the time we left, it was full. The service was outstanding, and the prices were reasonable. I will definitely return for dinner. This is the best Indian food I have had in the Bay Area. I highly recommend Dosa.
author: Marcia H.

description: This is a really awesome place to have a meal. We came here for lunch, and was very impressed with the food and the surroundings. The restaurant is very cavernous (big high ceilings and windows). We shared the vada pav (veggie sliders) which was really tasty [and I like eating meat] with the onions having a nice touch; chennal chicken (nice dish), and the mysore masala (mild but good). Overall, a solid 4.0 stars!!
author: Derek N.

description:
Love it!
This place doesn't disappoint...
I can taste the spices and flavors beyond the spiciness - awesome!!!
Their Grilled Calamari is the best appetizer - a dish I'd order again and again.
Came in with no reservation and still got a table - a sign of a good host who handles her floor and reservations - Thank You!
author: Kali F.

description: Excellent dosas. We ordered through doordash and food was great. The mung masala dosa and Sambar was awesome. Samosas were good too. Lemon rice was yummy. A good spot to taste dosas. Try the Sambar there it's yummy!!
author: Maheswari N.

description:
I took a night off from Yelping. A savvy friend recommended for a special date night we go to Dosa on Fillmore for dinner followed by a cozy balcony level movie across the street at Sundance Kabuki Cinema. It was our anniversary in October, and since I'm the planner of the two of us, I made reservations on Opentable and bought our movie tickets online as well.

It was hard to pick what to order because everything looked tempting. I love that they use local, organic and sustainable ingredients as much as possible. We ordered the tasting menu so we could try a good variety. Mr. L had his tasting menu with the wine pairing and I ordered a Peony cocktail (Right Gin, hibiscus masala nectar, coconut milk, lime, orange flower water, birds eye chili, served up). 

I had a fresh corn soup, vegetable dosa, halibut curry, and coconut sorbet. This was one of the best meals we've had and the Peony has become a new favorite cocktail. We're both fans of Indian food, and didn't know it could be this vibrant, light, fresh, and bold.

Since it was our wedding anniversary, I squelched my impulses to photograph the restaurant and our food. It was a special occasion and my husband deserved to be out to dinner with his loving wife, not the obsessive Yelper who would ask him to wait while she photographed his food. As a result, we had a relaxing meal without him rolling his eyes at my Yelp antics. I didn't need to ask how many stars he'd give this restaurant - this is a slam-dunk 5 star swanky joint. The bright flavors and exotic cocktails leave me yearning to go back.

Service was seamless and prompt. The only thing I would've preferred was if the waiter had recommendations when we asked. He said everything was excellent, and perhaps he spoke the truth. 

It was a memorable meal and afterward we walked across the street to see a movie on the "21 and over" balcony level of the Kabuki where there are little tables in the movie theatre and you can drink wine with your movie. I wonder how I'll top this for our next anniversary.
author: Jennifer L.

description: Service was great - the waitress explained the entire menu for us! Food was good - not too heavy, but flavorful. Nice ambience and affordable wine.
author: S C.

description:
I was visiting for the weekend and tried to get a reservation on a Saturday night for a group of 4, but wasn't able to get one till Sunday. Even though the place was packed when we arrived Sunday night, we were seated quickly. There is a cool vibe and a more upscale ambience than what I've experienced in the Indian restaurants I'm used to going to ( the kind that serve the inexpensive lunch buffets). I liked the variety on the menu - in addition to the curries and vindaloos and variations of lamb, there are dosas and uttapam. I have to admit I hadn't heard of the latter two before, so of course that's what we had to try. First though, we decided to go for the cocktails. I chose the "peony" because peonies are one of my favorite flowers and I thought it would be interesting as a drink - wow, it was delicious and unique! From what my companions said about their drinks, this would definitely be my choice again. 

Instead of bread, we had pappadums (or at least that's what I thought they were) - kind of like Indian tortilla chips and really addicting. For dinner, we started with an appetizer - we went for the standby North and South Samosas, which were basically yummy as you would expect. We also ordered the Vada Pav (vegetarian sliders) on the recommendation of the server, but those didn't show up until we were nearly done with our dinner so we just brought them home. As I said, the restaurant was crowded and maybe that is the reason for the spotty service, but it seemed they should not have charged us for something that was their error (we didn't ask, but if a restaurant has really good customer service, you shouldn't have to). Since the entrees tend to be expensive and the name of the place is Dosa, I think it's a good plan to go with ordering dosas for your meal - very filling!  My choice was a Spicy Basil Dosa, which came as all the dosas do, with fresh coconut and tomato chutney as well as sambar (lentil dipping soup) - delish! My friend loved the dips so much that even when she was done with her dosa, she scooped up the rest with her spoon and enjoyed every drop. We were all too full for dessert. Overall, Dosa was a great experience for the food, and hopefully the service will be better next time.
author: Nancy V.

description:
Came here with a group of six before a movie and they were magically able to seat us without a reservation. Service was efficient and friendly and they were able to make great suggestions.

One person in our group really liked the drinks and they were definitely strong and floral in a good way. We probably could have gotten away with less food but everything was generally good.

Since it is called DOSA half of us decided to get some version of it. The chicken buriyani was nice and creamy but the dosa's were definitely the best part. Sauces were good and the 'bread' was tangy and interesting - a great accompaniment to the spicy fillings.

We loved the giant puffed bread, bhaturra i think, that we shared as an appetizer and left full and happy.

Will come back to try other stuff!
author: Sam H.

description:
So pretty, so spicy, so YUMMY!

The only one thing I've noticed is that there isn't too much meat on the menu, BUT they make up for it in POTATOES!  Which I heart.  Love all their varaiations of dosas, and samosas and their chicken items.

Great and friendly service to boot!
author: Jennifer H.

description: Oh my goodness. This place is just delicious. And the atmosphere and vibe are awesome as well.  Dropped in after confirming over the phone that there was no wait for the community table. Everyone from the hostess to the bus servers were extremely nice and helpful with suggestions. Got to try my first DOSA and was shocked at the size and how much I loved it!  I can't believe i went this long without trying Dosa before!
author: Anna S.

description:
Great spot for folks looking to get away from Indian food that solely consists of "Chicken Tikka Masala".  Dosa's take on South Indian food is great - everything has so much flavor.  Our favorite was the Paper Masala Dosa and Duck Vindaloo (very spicy).  We always end up ordering way too much food.

Only negative is that the service can be a bit slow, but that's it.
author: Justin G.

description:
No surprise that the sister location of le original Dosa on Valencia is a superb establishment. Took the family for a late dinner (only reservation available was 830 and up) and the place was packed and still bustling when we left around 11pm. Beautiful space with a great loft dining area on the second level. 

The Dosas are an obvious must try at any point of a visit and we each opted for the pre fixe menu which included a mini dosa course. The salads and dosas were so fresh and delicious. The mung and masal dosas are both fantastic. I had the vegetable curry with rice and could not have been happier with the spice, flavors, and portion. The lamb curry dish was said to be very good. 

The best dessert is one of the newest and a must try: the sesame gelato (made in house as are all of their desserts). Great staff and wonderful vibe. 

Everyone at our table couldn't stop talking about going back. 

$25 corkage fee 
Great cocktails
author: Theresa T.

description:
Definitely a classy and unique place. I'd go back for more. 

I met a couple friends here before heading out to French Tuesday's and found the menu very interesting. I've eaten a lot on Indian food but wasn't quite sure what a Dosa was or what was the thing to order. The menu and staff was very helpful in getting us oriented. The Dosa's were actually very good as well. 

The ambiance and atmosphere is great to. Interesting and fancy decor but not to pretentious or cliquie. Overall I'd give it 4 stars but 5 stars for finding a type of restaurant that hasn't already been done in San Francisco.
author: Lauren B.

description:
I recently met a professional food critic and the conversation made me realize how deficit most of my restaurant "reviewing" is. A fair review requires a good concept of "what good looks like" and not just "what I like." With this concept in mind, I realize I am more or less a hack at this, but I will try my best to comment on Dosa on Fillmore. 

The highlight of the meal was the coconut basmanti rice which was semisweet and perfectly cooked. I also enjoyed my before dinner cocktail which was the ginger ante - tangy with ginger.

The fried fish starter was mediocre - more or less fish sticks accompanied by three condaments: a mild green yogurt sauce, a spicy chilly sauce and chutney of chili and cilantro. The chutney was chopped individual vegetable with no cohesive identity. 

My mango prawn curry dish was yawn-worth. The sauce had a good flavor, but it didn't really "jump out" and was the exact opposite of the chutney. In other words it was an amalgam of flavors with no real standout of high notes and lows.

The Nilgiri Chicken Korma was my shared dish and was good, but felt a lot like what it really was...a curry stew prepared ahead and heated for serving. 

On service; it was only adequate. I'm not an Indian cuisine expert, but I was surprised to find no naan (traditional flat bread) on the menu. Maybe this is because its Southern Indian cuisine - I don't know and I didn't feel compelled to inquire on this point. After we spent 15 minutes pouring over the menu multiple times, the server should have been astute enough to ask if we had dined there before. We asked enough questions to figure it out, but it was more work than it needed to be.

Finally for value...two drinks, two glasses of wine, two entrees and bread: $120 including tip. Hmmmm. The overall sensation of the meal was that the plates were prepared for us, but the meals were not.
author: J T.

description:
I went here yesterday with my husband a few friends of ours who were visiting from out of town. A few months back, we had gone to Dosa on Valencia and thought to give this location a try as we really enjoyed the food and service at Valencia.

The service was extremely poor. The management seemed to have checked in and taken care of seating us and making sure our orders were taken on time, however attention to details from our server was highly lacking. He placed the initial plates of papadum at our table and never brought out the tamarind and chutney sauces to accompany it. We looked around to locate him, however it seemed he was too busy to even drop by and check on that detail. Additionally, I had ordered a chai at the start of our meal and I had finished the chai during the course of my meal. 

When we finally decided to order dessert, I requested the server that I would like another chai and he took my cup and came back with more chai in the same old cup I had used previously in the beginning. To make it look even worse, my opened sugar packet and used spoon was STILL left on the saucer when he returned with the "new" cup of chai. My friends and I had a good laugh at this in the moment, but it was terrible to receive an old cup I had used previously and not be given a new cup with the chai I had reordered. It just looked really bad.

I then requested another individual to kindly take back the cup and give me a new chai with a new cup and spoon. He did. Throughout the closure of our meal, while we were finishing dessert, the bus boys would interrupt and cut through us to wipe the table (while we were seated) and clear plates. A few times of doing this was fine, but it happened several times at the end when we were finishing dessert and we felt rushed and interrupted too often. They didn't even say "excuse me" when reaching their hands between us to take plates or clear/wipe the table. 

I was highly disappointed with the service and we won't be returning to this location. It's a good thing the food is good, so we'll be taking our business to Valencia where the service was more professional and detailed.
author: Sandhya R.

description: Best Indian I've had.  Tried the Vada Pav (really awesome and interesting), duck vindaloo (delicious and super spicy), and the mixed chile uttapam (super spicy).  We also had a few cocktails a piece that were awesome (mango is the new black, ginger ante).  Can't wait to go back to try more of the menu.
author: Bradley H.

description:
Yelp should really consider allowing half stars.  I'm rating Dosa 3.5 stars, but am rounding up because the chutneys were better this time.

It's been over 2 years since coming to Dosa on Fillmore, and I'm glad to report that the food seems to have gotten better.  That being said, I still like Udupi Palace in the Mission better.

The food:
We started with the Dahi Vada and Vada Sambar.  The presentation on the Dahi Vada is very nice, and at first I had no idea what I was looking at.  It took me a second to realize that the dumplings were hiding underneath the yogurt, tamarind, and mint sauce in a very pretty pattern.  Yummy and refreshing.  The Vada Sambar was also very good, but it would have been  much better if the dumplings were completely soaked int he sambar.  It was obviously it has just been covered with the sauce about a minute before serving.

I got the Rava Masala dosa, which was tasty. The tomato and coconut chutneys are better than I remembered them being, much more flavorful.  The sambar was good like last time too.

My friends ordered a spicy mung masala dosa, which was also very good but not as spicy as I thought it would be.  The roasted chile and garlic masala was also good and spicy!  At first I thought it wasn't spicy at all, but the longer you wait the stronger the burn gets.  I really enjoyed it.

The service was pretty disappointing.  It took us awhile to even figure out who our server was, yet there is an army of people nearby to clear your plates and bring you water.  Our server was friendly enough, and I don't consider our experience his fault.  I think the whole service system at the restaurant needs a healthy dose of efficiency.
author: Naoko M.

description:
Dosa has always been one of the restaurants that I most regularly frequent.  About a year ago this rating would be at least 4 stars, but lately I have been unimpressed with the hospitality.

The food is great... 3 stars at the very minimum.  It's a bit pricey, but the flavors are magical.

The atmosphere is absolutely beautiful... 4 stars.

The hospitality, unfortunately, is closer to 1-2 stars.

There have been more than a few occasions where I felt like I may be an inconvenience rather than a paying guest.  Let me add that this criticism is strictly related to the bar area, not the main dining room.  I completely understand that the bartenders and hostesses are multi tasking.  Perhaps they are a bit too stretched thin?
