But wait, I was there when there was hardly anyone else there (they had just opened for the evening) and I felt that I was interrupting their socializing time by ordering a drink and something to eat.  Thankfully (for them) I was quick and they promptly went back to joking around with one another.  And it did help that they were more invested in catching up with each other as I didn't bother to order another cocktail, which resulted in me spending less money that I was prepared to spend.  So a savings, of sorts, there.

I am the type that understands that there can be an "off night."  I usually wait to see if it happens again before I say anything.  Unfortunately, this seems to be a consistent aspect for the past three times I've visited.  When meeting friends, we do tend to go when it's not a high octane night (Fridays, Saturdays) so perhaps there is a more engaged staff on those nights?

Again, this is strictly related to the bar area.  The times that i have eaten in the main dining room have always been lovely.  Dosa used to be one of those places where I would always suggest to friends that we meet up.  It's not that place any longer.
author: Miranda O.

description:
I live for their white truffle masala dosa. It's vegan, gluten-free, and really, really good. 

If you have dietary restrictions, ask the host for their special menu. They created an incredibly helpful chart version that indicates nut, dairy, egg, and wheat-free menu options.
author: Aimee H.

description:
Since I have such a great attention to detail, Dosa on Fillmore, exceeded all expectations in all areas from the eyes to the taste buds. 

From the moment I walked in, I took notice of the amber lighting which  beamed from these intricately designed chandeliers. Colors of the room with Indian-esque decor illuminated the restaurant nicely. The dishes I ordered were all flavorful and appetizing from the naan to the chicken dish to the dessert which was gulab jamoon. By the end of the night, I really thought my senses were heightened.
author: C M.

description:
I have been wanting to try Dosa at either location for a long time. I love Southern Indian food, but most Indian restaurants feature food from the north. I was really excited when the gals and I decided to come to the Fillmore location for dinner. With such great company, well, and so many yummy drinks (do try the Bollywood Hills!!), it was hard to pay too much attention to the food, but it was mostly good! The staff could use some work, though.

We had decided early to order the tasting menu, so I didn't even look at the regular menu. The three of us each ordered something different and we all tried each others' dishes--the best way to go, IMO. When I asked a question about one of the dishes I was ordering, the server gently informed me that a description was in the menu under that section. Um. OK. I didn't read it, so can ya just tell me? Also, he described the masala dosa as filled with eggplant, not potato. So when I got it I thought I had the wrong dish. Which wouldn't have been surprising since multiple servers tried giving us another table's food three different times. We even got entrees delivered to our table after we had dessert! There was some serious disorganization going on. 

All of our dishes were very good, but my fish curry stood out to me as very good. I thought it was incredibly overpriced, but will try going again and ordering off of the regular menu. 

I should also mention that the restaurant itself is beautiful.
author: Amy B.

description:
Being a transplant from Boston (we only have a handful of decent Indian food places) this place has consistently blown me away. 

The drinks are creative and with a wide range of Whiskey/Scotch I could not have been happier. 

This particular night we were crunched for time as we were catching a movie across the street at the kabuki theater. We put in our order for Samosas and some Dosa and with in no time we were speechless with the quality and flavor of the dishes.  While not cheep the value and quality is well worth it. I am sure there are other places in SF that you can get great Indian but this is pretty impressive.
author: Ryan B.

description:
Went there with my mom and girlfriend for my birthday dinner. Awesome, yummy food! Had the chennai chicken for starters (always my fav). Dinner consisted of the Biryani (the best in the bay area), Paneer dosa and Tamil lamb (lamb left a lot to be desired, was just ok), with generous sides of lemon rice (yum). Overall I loved it! 
We had a Asian waitress who was ok for the most part. The thing that irked me was when she dropped off a check without asking for desserts!! Fyi- It was a non busy weekday night around 9pm or so. I understand that you have to turn your tables to make more money, but it was my birthday night and I wanted to finish of our good food with some sweet dessert. I left irked.
author: Blue C.

description: Great ambience and good food! It's one of the fancier Indian restaurants in San Francisco. There is generally a long wait during busy hours and so it's highly recommended to make a reservation in advance. I liked the vada paav (sliders) and of course dosas.
author: Nikhil D.

description: Stick to dosas which are awesome btw. Idli and other starters were not that great at all. Dosas were amazing. Chili, moong and rava dosa were great. I would totally come again. Dinner has more options such as North Indian dishes as well.
author: Vatsal S.

description:
Sometimes even a restaurant with a zillion ratings deserves another.  

This place is great in every way: service, food, ambiance, wine list.  

They even serve late (we had dinner there at 10:30 PM on a Wednesday) without complaining even if the kitchen is closing.

So stop reading and run here.  You're hungry after all, aren't you?

(Note, that when they say "spicy" for a dish, they mean it.)
author: David A.

description: Five starts for food, drinks and service.  Something happened with our online reservation so it never actually went through.  They were able to accommodate us with only a 45 minute wait.  Their bar area with warm ambiance and great cocktails made this wait pass by super quick.  Their gin cury spice cocktail is outstanding!  The same could be said about the food.  We split the lamb entree and the basil dosa, both of which were outstanding.  Also the coconut custard is delicious.  Overall, if you like spicy food, interesting and/or southern Indian food, this is the place to go!  Great experience form beginning to end.  I'm excited to come back.
author: Tanichka B.

description:
Good things:
- Nice looking decor
- Interesting cocktails (hit or miss, but definitely interesting)
- A few very good dishes (particularly the chicken biryanni, which I know is not spelled right)

Not-so-good things:
- Too expensive for Indian food
- They do not serve traditional naan at all, and if you want any other type of bread and/or chutneys, you have to pay for them!
- Dessert menu lacking some traditional Indian staples, such as gulab jamun!!
author: Chris C.

description: I got the watermelon salad, crispy fish, spicy basil dosa, and the mango shrimp. The salad and spicy basil dosa were amazing. The gimlet drink I got was refreshing and spicy-one of the better drinks I've ever had. I've never had dosa before and the waitress took us through the hold menu the server explained everything on how to eat it and the service overall was wonderful. Very fun experience and ill definitely be back.
author: Jesse B.

description:
Great dosas!

My wife and i have sampled dosas all over the Bay Area and the two we had today at Dosa were spot on.

Both dosas were dark brown and crisp.  The fillings (masala and keema) were tasty (especially the keema).  The red and green sauces were delicious.  And even the soup was good.
author: Deems P.

description:
We went here last night to celebrate my parents' wedding anniversary. From all the reviews on Yelp, magazines, foodies' blogs, etc., I had pretty high expectations for DOSA, though I already knew it was far from being authentic South Indian cuisine. 

Don't get me wrong, I really enjoyed my dinner and loved the ambiance, the menu and the presentation...but the food didn't really please me as much as I had expected it to. Hmm, I guess I'll just say...the food was good and the compositions were quite unique, but nothing really stood out taste-wise. The curries and sauces were on the thicker and creamier side, but they were still very flavourful; the lemon-rice was too strong (sour) but the coconut rice was delicious; the dosas were tasty and appetizing, though they all sound similar; the desserts we had were just mediocre (read: not enough sugar and cream); 

3 of us did the tasting-course and these were the things we chose:

Starters:
1. Crab Vada 
2. Cochin Calamari 
3. Paneer & Romaine Salad

Mini Dosas:
1. Spring
2. Spinach & Fennel (x2)

Entrees:
1. Peppered Chicken
2. South Indian Lamb Kofta
3. Kerala Fish Moilee (this was good)

Desserts:
1. Chocolate Chai Gelato
2. Passion fruit tart with coconut tapioca
3. Rasmalai

My dad opted for regular dining and got the Sweet Spicy Scallops for starts and the Manglorean Prawn Masala for main. I tried a little bit of both and thought they were better than the items I had chosen. We also ordered two Mango Lassi's and I heard they were yummy - not too thick and not too sweet.

The best part of the meal was the pappadams - they were crispy, thin and delicious. More spices would have been perfect though.

The service was excellent; attentive, friendly and efficient staff. 

Since I really liked the atmosphere of DOSA and the food is decent, I definitely see myself going back there.
author: Grace C.

description:
Dosa!  More like delicious!  

Ladyhawk and I went here for dinner and a cocktail last night and I thought it was wonderful (though most everything is wonderful when I'm with her)...

Man, the spicy cranberry chicken with dahi rice was sooooo good.  The contrast been the mild yogurt rice and the spicy chicken in sauce is brilliant.  Tiff's Dosa was filled with really delicious spicy potatoes as well.  I was stuffed full when we finished our meal.  

This is definitely a place where you need a reservation for a table, but if you are comfortable sitting at the community table, the weeknight wait shouldn't be more than 15 min if you walk in.  

Drink a batsman for me.  That gin and ginger beer drink is super refreshing.
author: Nicholas N.

description:
Dosa is a fabulous place for dining - to go on a date or with a group of friends/family.

My absolute favorite thing about my meal at Dosa was the Rasmalai (sweet cheese dessert).

My least favorite part of the dinner was our server - who was deliberately ignoring my friends and I. This place deserves a 5 star rating for the whole experience (ambiance, decor, on time seating, and tastiness of food), but unfortunately the service was not on par.
author: Tania D.

description:
Plus a half. This was the closest I have come to a five star meal, in my limited Yelping and dining experience. I was extremely happy with our server. We sat at the social table, as the wait for a table was at least 45 minutes. What a great space, first of all. Hip and classy at the same time. Back to our server, he could tell right away that we were first timers. We perused the menu, and he helped out with explanations about certain things. We got two starters, three if you count the fire broth. Our meal was a dosa and an uttapam. Wow, that pretty much sums it up. I am neither a food critic, nor a writer, so I won't go into awesome detail about the textures or flavor pairings or spice or anything like that. What I will say is, go here now.

PS
One of the reviews on here complained about the server saying that he took a horrible picture of them and didn't check in to see if it was an ok shot...Are you flippin kidding me? That has nothing to do with his job or the level of service that you should be reviewing. And who the frick asks their server to take their picture? 

PPS
We, as I said earlier, were at the social table. Turns out that the man at the table across from us was the director of The Cove. Holy shit Miss Agnes, what a trip...got to talk with him about his life and times and I didn't even know until my wife told me later who he was
author: David G.

description:
Great food, but service was lacking.  

We arrived for late lunch and it was about 1/2 full.  The hostess was also the waitress... and that combo didn't really work.  She seemed really rushed and distracted.  She asked what I wanted to drink, but forgot to ask my partner.  She started to leave, but we were able to stop her and order a tea.  A few minutes later she came back to re-confirm the beer.  

Well, tea showed up, but the beer didn't arrive.  We then waited quite a while for the food.  After another 10 minutes, still no beer and no server.  Food runner finally dropped off food, but no beer.  

The two dosas we had were very good (spicy basil & spinach):
- Flavors intense and rich
- Coconut dipping sauce was wonderful
- Red sauce (forgot name) was too bitter
- Lentil soup... OUTSTANDING!

Halfway through the meal, our server and beer was still a no-show.  I finally got tired of waiting and I hailed down another food-runner to ask the status of my beer.  Turns out it was sitting on some counter (somewhere) for the past 30 minutes.  Come on!   It shouldn't have been that hard, it was just a bottle of beer.

For the price, it really should have been better service.  The food was the ONLY reason it got 3 stars.
author: Tony S.

description:
The decor = five stars.
- Wow, stunningly beautiful!  The colors are awesome, and the lighting, chandeliers, photographs and other artwork make for amazing eye candy!

The cocktails = five stars.
- The Mission Dosa has no cocktails, but the Fillmore Dosa does.  My wife and I tried several of the new signature cocktails, which are unique, spicey, and quite tasty, including Bollywood Hills (with saffron vodka and allspice), Juhu Palm (with coconut milk - yum!), and Faux Swizzle (damn, that was good).

The food = five stars.
- We had a couple of favorites, including the coconut and cauliflower soup and the lamb curry, and tried two new dishes. The Mustard Halibut entree was prepared perfectly where the fish just melts in your mouth - I will definitely order it again. I'd happily eat the Chettinad Cauliflower dosa anytime, even for breakfast.

The service = five stars
- Considering that we were there for the first night in business, I was terrifically impressed by the staff, all of whom were at ease, very familiar with the menu, and professional.  We learned from our waittress that the interview and new hire training process were the most intense and detailed of any restaurant she'd ever worked at.  

The attention to detail, in all aspects of the experience, was incredible.  I'm confident that Dosa on Fillmore will be a smashing success.
author: Will T.

description:
I was SO WRONG about this place. I've avoided Dosa because I hate paying $$$ for Indian food I can make at home. I feel the same way about paying more than $10 for spaghetti, so I rarely eat at Italian restaurants. 

I can not make any of the food served at Dosa, it is unique and very delicious. A friend and I go for Sunday Brunch, I get the Spring Dosa and the Corn and Pepper Coconut soup which is so delicious and distinct it would take me years to describe it. The weird thing is that their chai sucks. The service is impeccable and the decor and ambiance is gorgeous and serene. This entire time I was missing out. Hopefully I learned my lesson. 

P.S. I am not sure of the dress code. When we go for Sunday Brunch, I am wearing my gym clothes but everyone else is dressed nice. There are many people wearing beautiful saris. I suggest NOT wearing gym clothes (but I have no shame so I'm not embarrassed).
author: Mitsi M.

description: Amazing foood!  Hella delicious.  Definitely get the masala dosa if you go, you'll love it :)
author: Amala N.

description:
We finally came here on a double date with my best friend and her boyfriend who were visiting from NYC on a Saturday night. Not having made reservations in advance, we ended up with a 10pm seating.  

The decor of the restaurant is wonderful, the perfect combination of classy, exotic, Indian. You could tell the light fixtures, the mosaic tiled bar, the adornments and even the textures of the wall were all carefully selected.

Dosa is unique because it is South Indian cuisine and as my colleague told me that most Indian restaurants in the US are north Indian, Dosa is different in this way.

We ordered a variety of dishes family style to share: 

1) crab vadas-small crab cakes accompanied by a tamarind and cilantro sauce. this tasted good but the portions were just tiny.

2) chennai chicken-this sounded better on the menu than it tasted on the palate.

3) duck spinach masala and paneer-the spinach sauce is quite heavy and it didn't compliment the paneer as well as I thought it would given the fact that I love saag paneer.

4) pepper chicken-advertised as 'falls off the bone' this it did not. the flavor was good but we thought it was going to be much more tender.

5) masala dosa-GREAT! if you come here, definitely order this. a crepe like sheet encased with potatoes, spice, peas, and a variety of dipping sauces, this was truly delicious.

6) peas and paneer dosa-also very tasty, this one is like a filled crepe and had the same sauces.

Definitely order the dosas if you come here. They were great. Everything else we just thought were average. On the way out, we also a dish called "South Indian Moons" which is an assortment of Uttapams. That dish looked tasty! 

If we ever come back, we will definitely try that.
author: Betty C.

description: Awesome food! Chennai chicken, bhelpuri and Tamil vegetable curry are my personal favorites! Great ambience and excellent service, this restaurant is a must-try! Being an Indian, I have to say that their food is authentic and full of flavor! Thumbs up!
author: Purnima A.

description:
Dined here last night with two girlfriends, and I was in complete heaven.   Started off with a "Batsman" drink (perfect combo of gin, tea, lemon juice, and ginger beer)---very refreshing on a summer day. 

The three of us ordered family style:
fox style mussels
tamil vegetable curry with side of coconut rice
masala dosa
Bhatura

The mussels were to die for, the flavoring was nothing I had ever experienced and i was so happy to be sharing this lovely dish with my lovely girlfriends.  The Tamil vegetable curry was so tasty and paired perfectly with the coconut rice.   Curry was so flavorable, we weren't at all dismayed by the lack of protein.   Dosa was also yum and fun to dip in the variety of chutneys.   I could have skipped the Bhatura but still a nice side dish to pick at.

Finished off this heavenly meal with a second cocktail, i ordered the bengali gimlet. Very citrus and i enjoyed it very much.

Would love to come back.  Defiintley pricey for indian food, but you pay for the trendy and hip ambiance too.
author: Jackie D.

description: vada paav was great and so was basil prawn and Tamil lamb , but you should go with med spicy as it can become spicy
author: Vijaya L.

description:
Good food but not honest. 

We went there and paid 120 for 3 dosas, and 1 uttapam and 3 non alcoholic drinks. The manager came and said the tip was included. We were a party of 5. 

The part that sucks about this is that I didn't get to look at the bill. It was my fathers treat that evening and he didn't question and look at it properly. :( he then felt something was fishy. Out fault for not asking! 

Overall I feel like we got cheated and I don't trust this establishment. It's not a good feeling. This happened on sept 22nd so it has been a few weeks but this image of dosa has still stuck in my head. 

I just wanted to warn people out there when they dine at dosa on Fillmore.
author: bhavna p.

description:
Dosa on Fillmore is a beautiful restaurant that serves straight ahead indian food. They do a solid job and serve some dishes that I don't see at restraunts often but remember from my childhood.

I think their execution, flavors, service and decor all make for a great experience.

What drags the score down for me is that Dosa bills itself (both in hype and price) as much more. This isn't your corner indian joint, it shouldn't be serving just good straight ahead indian food. With all the pomp and circumstance (and $$$), I expected the food to be off the charts with creativity (like Aziza does with Morroccan food out in the Richmond).

I was expecting Dosa to push the envelope a bit by utilizing indian flavors in new and creative dishes. Instead they just wow diners who've never seen Baturas before. The only place they managed to do anything creative was with their cocktails. The cocktails were great and were unlike anything I'd had before.

Dosa is a place to go for solid indian food when you feel like dressing up and not much more. Hopefully the chef will take a cue from Aziza and step up her/his culinary game to match the epic service/decor.
author: A.J. T.

description: This is my first Indian food experience (we have gone three times now) and do not have anything to compare Dosa to. However, we love their food, the atmosphere is great, and the service is impeccable. Glad we found it and we look forward to adding Dosa to our restaurant rotation.
author: David H.

description:
I keep going back to Dosa hoping I can have a great meal like the first few times I went.  But no!   The consistency is just not there.   :(

A year ago I had their pepper chicken....it was brilliant.  Flavorful, light and tasty.  Last night we ordered it again.  It was horrendous.  I asked the waiter why it tasted so different.  Grainy, thick, bland and really dark in color.  He said they have 11 chefs in total who rotate and come in the mornings to make the main dishes / sauces / sambhar using their memory.

What??!!!  So that's why I get this level of inconsistency.  Who runs a kitchen like this.  I want my pepper chicken...who was the chef that night?  I would follow your schedule!!.   I have noticed their sambhar also changes when I order dosa.  You cannot do this.  

Also, what up with needing to order the rice separate for an $18 dish?  Not good DosaSF.  Alas, Dosa has once again disappointed me for the last time.  I think Udupi shall be the place I go for south indian food for a reasonable price and consistency.  

Bummer.
author: culinary q.

description:
Still have a soft spot for the original location on Valencia, but the Fillmore locale is also quite nice.  Totally different vibe though, b/c it's so trendy and spacious ... seems like it would fit in nicely in NY or LA.

But the food is the same - as good as ever.  Started with the Vada Pav (veggie sliders) that were amazing with its creamy, fried potato patty.  Can see why these are such popular street food in India.

But the dosas,  naturally, get top billing.  I recall the the classic masala version to be great with mashed potatoes but this time we chose something with more kick - the roasted chile & garlic masala version.  Delicious!  And definitely has some heat.

Liked the coconut and tomato chutneys but the star was the spicy sambar (lentil dipping sauce).  Before I knew it, my mouth was on fire!

The green mango and paneer uttapam, which vaguely resembled a frittata, was perhaps even more delicious!
author: F. P.

description: Ambiance and decor was very nice, and the bar seemed to be very lively.  However, my family and I came here for dinner and were extremely disappointed with the food. Three out of the four family members got sick from the food.  We ordered the duck plate and all they have us was the dark, leg meat of the duck; very small and cheap pieces.  Would never come back to this restaurant for their food, maybe the bar.
author: Francesca M.

description: My fiancé and I came here on our anniversary a few months ago. When we first walked in, I noticed how dark it was inside. After my eyes adjusted to the lighting,  I was able to make out the beautiful decor. We were seated after 10-15 minutes in the upstairs dining area. We ordered some super spicy dosa item and shrimp Marsala. The dosa was extremely hot. Spicy hot. The sweet waitress tried bringing me a yogurt dip to help with the heat and then she brought me a mango drink to cool me down. Didn't help much. But my shrimp Marsala was great. I would like to try them again.
author: Linda W.

description: If you like Indian cuisine and are not real familiar with all the dishes, this is a great restaurant to jump right in and taste the many spices and flavors of India.  Try the three course offering which offered excellent choices for any palate.  The second course offered dosas with 3 dipping sauces which were terrific.  The lamb entree was delightful.  If you are on the fence in trying Indian cuisine, give this place a try because it's not overwhelming or intimidating.   Service was excellent, and the restaurant was very busy on a Friday evening.
author: Greg B.

description: Food is interesting and above average. Great service and easy to plan group events here. The ambiance and decor is romantic, modern and has a slight Asian feel. Great place for a date or a group event.
author: Nancy S.

description:
I was very impressed with Dosa. I walked in and the first thing I thought was "wow, this place is pretty for an Indian restaurant." I mean, sure, I have seen pretty Indian restaurants before, but they hadn't had the reputation for good food. I was very excited to see what Dosa dished out. 

In order to get a reservation for 7, we had to be there at 6:30. Even 4 days beforehand, there was no way to eat later. We walked in at 6:30 and the place was already packed with an older crowd. Every table in the fairly full restaurant was taken. 

We were walked upstairs to a nice table by the window. It was a bit load but pleasant. The waiter was nice and brought out water right away. I ordered a Bollywood Hills ($9) which was made with saffron vodka. Just that description (although the rest went on for ages) sold me on the drink. It knocked me off my feet though. Before my dinner arrives, I was already happy and giggly.  

To start, my friends and I had multiple starters which I can't remember. The chicken stood out as really great. It came with a yogurt dipping sauce that brought out the flavours of the fried chicken. I was sad to see it disappear.
 
I had the paneer and peas Dosa (around $12). It was fantastic although a bit on the heavy side. It tasted so good though that, even though I was totally stuffed at after about half, I cleaned my plate. The spices and the cheese just made such a perfect taste that I couldn't help myself. 

I really want to come back here soon. I remember staring at the menu going "I want EVERYTHING!" so I want to go back and see what else can make my taste buds tingle.
author: Mariko F.

description: WOW, the food here is amazing the decor beautiful. I like the change and up-lift of Indian food. YUM I will be back for more!
author: kylie w.

description:
Such pretty restaurant filled with so many flavors and spices! Everything, literally EVERYTHING I ordered was a treat for my taste buds. 

We ordered:
- Scallops: Really good and flavorful sauce. It was grilled so had a nice little crisp. 

- Chicken chennai: 2nd favorite! It was spicy and tender and the sauce they had to accompany it soothed the heat. Even after eating a lot of pieces I never tired of the flavors. 
- masala dosa: This thing is huge! At first I was skeptical about how it would taste, but it was really crunchy and tasty. 

- Lamb: #1 favorite! So tender and tasty! I brought it home and ate it for lunch the next day, STILL DELICIOUS. Highly recommend!
author: Jackie M.

description:
Delicious!!!! Full bar in an Indian place is an unusual plus. 
One star off because seriously: Indian cuisine is meant to be for caste system folks, not San Franciscans who like to over-spend like us.

That being said, everything is delicious and I love the atmosphere. Never have to wait long for anything and the server was really sweet "e-lem, ilem"(?)

They have one in the mission that's great too, but less seating. 
Love it.
author: Tim L.

description:
We heard about this place after it was featured in Check Please Bay Area. We were there for lunch on the weekend with couple of friends. Initially I was not sure if this place would have authentic Indian food. I was totally impressed after I tried their food.
We initially ordered four to five small plate dishes like Vada, Samosa, Idiappom, and Madras chicken and all these dishes were very good. We then ordered four different types of dosa to share. We picked masala, rava, paper and uthapam. The waiter was great In helping us pick popular dishes. All of us were impressed by the taste, quality of ingredients used, the way food was presented. We finished off the lunch with a order of India chai and Coffee.
I would highly recommend this place if you are in the city and near the Fillmore area near Japan town. The location is great to walk around after the lunch or dinner. It was not crowded during lunch and we could sit for couple of hours to socialize with friends. They also have a full bar and they make some good cocktail.
author: Raman S.

description:
My friends and I were eager to try the new Dosa location shortly after it opened. The restaurant is huge - much bigger than the Mission location - with really high ceilings. My friend didn't particularly like the space (she thinks it has deviated too far from the Mission location), but I liked it. It's spacious and feels relaxed. 

We had the lentil dumplings to start (which was probably my favorite) and also ordered the paneer and pea dosa, chef's selection of five uttapams and the lamb curry. Everything was good with lots of great dipping sauces, though the lamb curry was my least favorite as it stood out the least. 

Our service was good overall, though it was a bummer that they didn't identify the uttapams for us when they delivered them. It seems like one of the purposes of getting the chef's selection of uttapams is so that you can try different ones to find your favorite uttapam. So I did have a favorite; sadly, I don't know which one it was!

Dosa is relatively priced compared to the other options on Fillmore.
author: Wendy L.

description: This is the first time I've had dosa, and the only way I can describe it is mashed potatoes in a crepe. It's a weird combination in my mind but works deliciously. To start off, we got the chennai chicken, which was a slightly spicy fried goodness. Then, we had the duck vindaloo and white truffle masala dosa. They were both good, but overpriced and overhyped. In addition, the food did not sit well in our stomach that night and the day after :/.
author: Peggy L.

description:
Given the success of their location on Valencia, Dosa 's on Fillmore restaurant has always interested me. Why go through all the trouble? Why deviate from a good formula? 

Well as everyone else knows, they've created a great environment. Service was excellent. Music and decor felt really good. And after going to an 8pm show, we wanted dinner on the later side.

Our server was very patient with us, thankfully, because we couldn't focus on the menu; the night was already underway, if you know what I mean. She recommended the heirloom tomatoes, a salad, a dosa and I added the duck paneer.  

The food tasted good but not great.  Turns out that a dosa place wouldn't be expected to make a good paneer.  I love Indian food typically and rely on others to steer me to their favorite restaurants.  This place feels like more of an event place rather than a foodie place.
author: Mike H.

description:
We had a subpar, disappointing experience here tonight.  I selected Dosa because my sister and her new boyfriend were visiting from New York and they wanted a nice Indian food meal at a moderate price.  I'd visited both the Fillmore and Valencia locations before and had a good experience, so I wanted to show them that SF could do good, creative, fusion food at a $$ price point.  To walk through the disappointment, blow by blow:

1.  We had a 7 PM reservation, but were kept standing for more than ten minutes waiting for our table -- this was bizarre in light of the fact that there were many available tables in the row of tables in which we were ultimately seated (i.e., the restaurant was not waiting for slow diners to leave.)

2.  One person was interested in ordering chai, but wanted to know with what it was spiced (the waitress did not know) and how much it cost (the waitress made up a price, which turned out to be inaccurate).  She also gave us the impression that these were odd questions to ask.  We eventually found the information on the bottom of the last page of the menu, but really, the staff should either know this information or know how to obtain it quickly and accurately when asked by a customer.

3.  We each ordered the three course prix fixe; two of us ordered drinks a la carte, and one person ordered the wine pairing.  There was then an awkwardly long delay before our first course arrived.  

4.  Two of us had ordered the scallop appetizer.  While the scallops themselves tasted good, the blend of sauces was unfortunate and did not work for me at all.

5.  Our forks and knives were taken away after the first course.  When the second course arrived, we were not given replacement forks and knives until we asked for them.  The person with the wine pairing had to request the wine pairing for the second dish to come out; it was not served automatically.

6.  One person in our party had ordered the paneer and green mango dosa as their second course, and they were disappointed with the mix of flavors, ultimately concluding that the mango and paneer did not work when paired together. 

7.  The waitress did not bother to monitor the status of our dishes, and the third dish/main course was dumped on us before I had finished the second course.  Extremely poor move service-wise.

8.  We each had the lamb as our main course, which was acceptable, but ultimately forgettable.

We got out of there as quickly as possible (which still took two hours) without havng dessert and high-tailed it to Michael Mina for dessert, where at least I knew I could promise my guests warm and consistent service.  Extremely disappointed with this subpar experience, more so because I invited out-of-towners here and felt chagrined as the evening of mediocre food with horrible service unfolded.  I don't intend to return to either location of Dosa, and I intend to share this experience with my local friends and encourage them not to return.
author: B L.

description:
Maybe I am biased but I have always felt strongly that Asian and Indian food should not be priced like fine dining experiences except on rare occasions. Especially when it comes to Indian food, I am especially more biased because most of the ingredients are economical to attain and are very basic. Dosa has mediocre food that is presented in a very elegant manner. If that's what you pay a premium for I rather go a couple blocks down for India Palace buffet. 

The chicken appetizer was overly spicy and small. The best thing was the dosa paper masala which is like a think crisp Indian pancake you dip in curry and coconut sauce. I can see why its unique and on the 7x7 list but if that's the best thing they have to offer (pan-fried dough) then that might be a little bit of a problem.

The wait was long even though we made reservations and service is mediocre as they forgot one of our dishes. To leave on a positive note, the construction of this restaurant is gorgeous. Great bar and loft overlooking the venue. This place would make a great night lfe venue.
author: Ed L.

description: This is one of the best south indian places that I have eaten at...We had the dosa, the uttapam and the chennai chicken. The dosa and uttapam were really good..but the chennai chicken was absolutely world class. The service was also really good. Definitely will be going here again, the next time I am in SF.
author: Ss S.

description: Incredibly innovative and beautifully presented Indian food in a lovely space (eat upstairs at the balcony tables). I could literally eat here every single day!
author: Lena H.

description:
DOSA is the bomb!

When I visit my friends in SF and they ask me where I want to get to dinner, they get the same reply.... DOSA. 

I don't get tired of their delicious creative food and could care less about all the new hot spots that try to draw me away from my favorite restaurant in SF
author: Lee O.

description: Finally dined here after hearing good things about it from numerous friends over the years. The happy hour hands down is the way to go. Beer, wine and cocktail specials, plus a handful of appetizers for $6. Happy hour also goes until 7 p.m. which seems later than most.
author: Lee H.

description:
I had wanted to eat at Dosa for years and finally did and I am hooked.  Lively atmosphere and beautiful decor.  Friendly and helpful staff.  And the food, oh the food.

First, Taj Mahal beer is a must.  Second, the salad with goat cheese, walnuts, mango, and cilantro dressing is a MUST.  For entrees, you have to get the paneer and peas dosa, SO GOOD.  The paper masala dosa is okay, even though 7x7 ranks it as one of the 100 must-eats on The Big Eat 2011.

Gotta go again!
author: Chad S.

description:
I mostly love the food here. It is delish. So many spices, masterfully wielded. 

I also love the fact that they have so many gluten-free options, and will provide a menu with all of the dietary restriction information spelled out.

I was disappointed today, though. I had the Chicken Xacuti for lunch with a friend there a few days ago and it was absolutely delicious. Hoping to share the deliciousness with my mother, I took her to Dosa this evening. Sadly, this Chicken Xacuti was made with so much hot pepper that it hid the delicious spice mixture of non-hot pepper spices like cardamon that made the Chicken Xacuti that I had for lunch there sing. It was very sad that they are inconsistent. When they aren't inconsistent, they are golden.

Both dosas that my lunch companions and I had, the spicy basil dosa and the spring vegetable dosa, were very good, and the sauces that they came with are marvelous.

The surroundings are beautiful, but the music is a little too loud.
author: Emily A.

description: This place is legit. Great atmosphere. Restaurant week menu offered good variety. Favorite dish was the truffle dosa and green chili dosa. Great Indian food, wine, and drink menu.
author: Sean S.

description:
SF Yelpers--your favorable reviews led us here. Bordering the Japantown district and spanning nearly half a square block, we had no problem finding the industrial styled edifice, flashing "DOSA" in bright orange block letters across the top. Dosas - the hallmark of legit South Indian cuisine- are normally served in enviroments with quick turnover--get your seat and food fast, get it good, and get the hell out. This place is the antithesis of the "hole in the wall", offering enough mood lighting, high ceilings, dramatic artwork, and pebble adorned toilet seats to keep the entire yuppy fillmore district happy. Really though - A+ for ambiance. But be forewarned, our wait time without a reservation on a Monday night was 50 minutes.  

Now on to the tragic part of the evening-the food. Like the guy who is perfect on paper and adores you, i REALLY wanted to like it, but left feeling disappointed and jipped. The concept seemed fun and interesting - elevating South Indian classics (dosa, uttapam, currys) with westernized elements.  The plates looked scrumptious, garnished beautifully with vibrant colors and emitting pungent aromas. Somehow  though, nothing tasted good. We ordered a variety of items on the menu and I didn't want to steal anyone elses food - it was all bad. From over seasoning to under seasoning to spiciness that dominated my entire palate. The uttapams and dosas were measly looking, a disappointing sight for someone used to dosas that stick out of your plate a foot on each side. Generous portions fail. 

Other things to take note of: Slightly pricey, great drink selection and bar area, excellent service.
 
Not sure if the guys in the kitchen were having an off night, or if their taste-buds died and stopped working, or if this is par for the course. However, if you're craving a delicious and satisfying Dosa, go to that Hole in the wall that you know and love. i don't want to say that you shouldn't mess with the classics; DOSA has a lot of potential and judging by the hype, it's lived up to it. My take: if you want to have a sensory experience (not including taste), yummy drinks, and mediocre food , go to DOSA.
author: Amisha S.

description:
Snazzy little Indian joint.  Felt like I should have gotten up to go dancing at the bar after devouring some curry. 

I think overall Indian food everywhere is pretty pricey and this wasn't any different but maybe $2-$5 dollars more.  The food itself was just OK.  At least I didn't think my dish was wonderful and usually when it comes to Indian food, I can never control myself.  I walked away from here only finishing a quarter of my dish.  What?!!

I got the Duck Spinach Masala & Paneer and I thought it was just ok.  The tomato rice suggested to pair up with the curry actually didn't go well together. Instead of finishing my dish, I ate my cousins Lamb Kofta because it was too spicy for her and perfect for me!  Love the extra spice.

If I go back, I would get that.  The wait for this place is a little silly given that its just alright.  I suppose its a good place to be seen.  If ya know what I mean.
author: Nho C.

description: OMG! Food is great, so is the ambiance. Also, the dishes which have 'spicy' in the name are actually desi hot.
author: Vaibhav P.

description: Tried dosa and a daily cocktail. Liked both . Sambar was good but more spicy than I thought. Will visit again
author: praveen d.

description: Yum!  Very interesting food and decor.
author: Stephanie G.

description: Trust this review I'm Indian. This place is really good and you can tell because the place has mostly Indian people eating inside. You can always tell if a place is good if you see native people eating there. Best to go during lunch because they have thali which is amazing. Nice atmosphere.
author: Aakash X.

description: Wow. Now I'm no Indian food connoisseur but I do love to experience cuisine from all over the world. Dosa surprised me on so many levels, I don't even know where to begin. Similar to the way I felt when first looking at the menu, the size of a novel. Our waiter recommended what we needed to try as first timers and what could wait until our next time around. Her selections could not have been more spot on. Started with the grilled calamari, followed by the dahi vada, spicy basil dosa and ending with the mango prawns. Our meal was such a perfect combination of Indian flavors, cool and spicy, I don't know how I could order anything different next time. Can't wait to go back.
author: Jessie S.

description: Great food, great service, great drinks... this place can do no wrong! We had been talking about hitting up Dosa on Fillmore a number of times and finally snagged reservations this past weekend. We grabbed a drink at the bar while we were waiting and we were off to a good start: the Bengali gimlet is AMAZING. Their drinks are creative and delish -- we tried a few and they were all exceptional. The ambiance is also pretty awesome -- somewhat ornate; perfect for a date night or for bringing out-of-town guests. When the food came -- wow, wow, yum. We started with an app (vegetarian sliders are phenomenal) and then split an entree and a dosa. The prawn masala stood out to me as being exceptional, but everything was great. The food is spicy so be ready for some heat!
author: Shannon E.

description: Dosa on Fillmore-You Rock on multiple levels. Great food and exceptional service. I never knew south Indian food could be mashed up to this dizzy heights of flavor. The food is spicy and right. Visit this gem.
author: Ashu R.

description:
I am always really happy after I go to dinner at Dosa and the movies at Kabuki. The food is always yummy (though I love Indian Food and don't come here when I feel like eating Indian Food) and the service is great. 

It is fancy without being too fancy. I do always leave feeling like it is a bit expensive for what it is.
author: Deb J.

description: Great decor. Good food. (Mostly) South Indian cuisine cooked and served with a flair. I'm a fan.
author: Aniruddh M.

description:
So the two stars on this review is only because of the food. I have to note the service was absolutely AMAZING. We were heading to the Kabuki on opening day of Harry Potter (just after work) so we had wanted something close by. When I made the reservation, I was honestly slightly irked that they took my credit card number down (there were six of us), it seemed a little elitist to me but people have raved about this place, I had to give it a shot.

The waitress was awesome, she was prompt and the service was so fast. We had told them we were limited on time so she hauled for us. I also thought it was cool that she informed us that gratuity was already included in the bill. 

So the food, it is definitely pricey. And its not bad at all, but if you're looking for flavorful, close to authentic Indian food. I feel like Dosa has "americanized" their food and taken out the spices so it loses the authenticity of Indian food. I also didn't like my paneer "dosa" came as a wrap. I wasn't expecting that. I'm Indian and when I hear "dosa" I think of the typical Indian dosa. For the price and that flavor, I probably won't ever go back. Its the bay area, there are a ton of other more authentic Indian places.
author: Analisa S.

description: I love DOSA. Friendly staff, delicious, hand-crafted cocktails, fresh and flavorful food, all in walking distance from some of my favorite music venues in SF. Also, atmosphere is great, with a lively crowd but not so loud you can't have a conversation. Upstairs is a bit romantic!
author: Jessica J.

description: I don't know where to begin to rave about this place. One of the finest places to go to dig into some exotic South Indian cuisine..this place has a. different vibe and the decor and food is to die for . A little pricey and extremely busy over the weekend but worth every penny for this high end indian fusion food :)
author: Aparna K.

description: I love this place so hard... I don't know whether it's the cocktails (which are some of the best I've had), the food (which is marvelous), the decor (which is almost but not quite classy enough to be pretentious), or the waiters (who are cute and good humored), but I think I've officially found a new restaurant to visit when I desperately need to drown my sorrows in food and liquor.
author: Kathleen P.

description:
Great open decor.  Ordering was a bit tricky because we weren't familiar with this type of food.  But the waiter was patient and able to provide a lot of suggestions.

Can't really remember what the food was like...just all flavorful, loved the variety, and the ambiance.
author: Janet L.

description:
I am from Mumbai, Wife is from Bangalore and friends from Gujarat and Channai! We six visited Dosa last weekend. 
The place was packed on Sunday night at 7 Pm food, thanks to Opentable we got the perfect seating in the corner-booth. 
Well Service, ambiance, pace with we were served, all 5 starts by default. Every individual who serviced our table knew what the menu is all about, even when it comes to the french pressed Moksha coffee to end the evening in style. 
As a Mumbaite, I always miss our staple snack, Vada Pav. I must mentioned, in all the restaurants (mostly hyped once) I tried in the bay area, Vada Pav sliders at the DOSA is executed almost to perfection by the Chef. Not exactly Bombay style but the recipe has its own merits. Superb start to the dinner! We ordered various " Virgin drinks, although Dosa has really good collection of sprits & Bar. My fav. drink was Southern Monsoon. It is worth trying for sure. 

Now to the main course, we ordered variety of Dosas, Spicy Basic, Chile-Garlic, Moong dosa and so on. Different taste, very good presentation. Actually some of us felt that we are eating in some eatery in south India :) Sambar was chennai style, again fantastic! Uttapam moon Platter is amazing :) 

All in all it was wonderful evening spent with friends and some authentic, spicy indian food and some good fusion music tracks to increase the tempo for the evening! 

MUST VISIT!!!
author: Mandar S.

description:
We had a private event for 60 people here this past weekend and it was AWESOME!  Andrea helped me choose a great menu, was really helpful when it came to pricing of the event, and all in all the event was a huge sucess.  The only drawback (but not really) is that I got most of the credit when really it should have gone to the Dosa staff, especially Andrea Arii!!!

The food here is exceptional, their drinks are great and delicious, and my parents who have sworn off Indian food can't wait to come back! That says a lot, esp for those of you who aren't sure if an Indian restaurant is the way to go for an event.  It is!

The mezzanine for a private party is a beautiful space, as would be the entire restaurant for larger events.  Highly reccommend coming here for a small dinner or hosting a bigger event!  

Thanks Dosa and Thank you Andrea!
author: Sarah X.

description:
The food gets a solid 4-stars. The service gets a solid 2-stars.

As with most places in SF, it's always going to be the service that sets you apart, regardless how good your food may be. The service when I went here killed the experience.

We got there and there are tons of empty tables, but since we didn't have a reservation we ended up at the bar. Usually that's awesome, you get some attention being right there. You never have to wait for a drink, you can order whatever you want quickly - but not at Dosa.

We sat at the bar and waited. And waited. And waited. Finally a we asked the bar back to help us to order, so he told the bar tender who was standing right there that we wanted to order. 

We asked for his recommendation on some glasses of wine. He couldn't give us any, so we ordered a few different glasses. One was good, the other was bad. Like bitter gone bad, bad. So I ordered a dirty martini, which the guy had to ask me how to make. *sigh*

After waiting a loooooong time, we finally were able to order some food. Now the food came out extremely quick, even though they forgot one of the 4 dishes we had coming (which the kitchen also fixed ASAP). That part of the service made my very happy. They kitchen staff was on it. Too bad the people at the bar were not. I really felt like the bar staff were blessing us with their service, rather then them wanting to make the paying customer happy. 

Well back to the food. The currys we had were pretty good for being a little less traditional then the Indian food we're all accustomed to. The Samosas were a bit chewy, and I was shocked they didn't have any naan, only some kind of fried bread (umm, where in India is deep dried bread from again?). The things they call DOSA's, aren't Indian food at all, but from Eastern Africa (go try Ethiopian or Somalian food). But they were still pretty good. Other then the fact the food they serve here should be called "Indian Fusion", not Indian IMHO, it was overall pretty good. Not greasy, pretty flavorful, and fresh.  

The atmosphere for the place doesn't really fit the food either. The look and feel of the place is more modern, like you would see at a fancier place. It didn't really fit the Indian Fusion vibe. 

I guess if you can get over the service and want to try a different spin on Indian food, I'd say give this place a try. If you're in the mood for more traditional Indian, I'd say stay away.
author: Erik B.

description:
Dosa

Decent food, beautiful place, a little pricey.  The four starts are due to the lack of menu entrees.  Great Dosas.
author: Bela M.

description:
I love Indian food, but my husband isn't crazy about it. It took a little convincing, but ultimately we were both totally thrilled with our meal. 

We ordered the tasting menu, had a couple drinks, and dessert. I loved the coconut curry corn soup, my dosa, the vegetable curry, and had a blueberry sorbet that transformed the color of my mouth while also being delicious. 

Service was good, ambiance was exciting... the price was what you'd expect in SF. Best of all, my husband has a new appreciation for Indian food!
author: Elisabeth Y.

description:
8 people eating family style = a great way to try a lot of dishes! :D I love Indian food, so i was really excited to try this place. I never tried a Dosa before so it was a great treat! 

We walked in with no reservation and our wait was only about 30 min (we all expected a lot longer especially for a group our size and it was a long weekend. The time flew by while many of us grabbed a beer from the bar, admired the beautiful decorations, and just chatted a bit. 

Everything we ate was great and I would definitely go back again if i am in the area! 

Dosas: 
(all of them were served with coconut chutney, tomato chutney and sambar, a lentil dipping soup. *my favorite was the sambar) 

Paper Masala - Thin, pliable and crispy variation, served with spiced Indian potatoes, onions, and cashew nuts 
*of the four Dosas we tried this was my favorite one! 

Spinach and Fennel Pooriyal Spiced, diced filling with spinach and fennel stems 

Spring Masala Dosa combined with fresh vegetables including peas, carrots, cabbage and red onion 

Paneer and Peas Dosa filled with spiced and shredded farmer's cheese, lightly grilled, peas, and cilantro 

Entrees: 

Channa Bhatura Chickpea (garbanzo) Marsala served with an over sized, soft, puffy wheat bread or vegan poori 
*of the two entrees I liked this one better. Super flavorful and the puffy wheat break was about the size of a person's head! 

Chicken Korma Boneless, organic, cauliflower, peas, coconut milk, fennel, mild (we got it with the plain Basmati Rice)
author: Michelle H.

description:
Finally checked out this place after all the raving. It's crowded as heck, parking was a mess (some foodie truck event in J town) and luckily we had rezzies. The decor inside is beautiful, especially from the top level. The waiter was a little pretentious and offered little when asked about some of the meals. He explained that Dosa were easy to share, saying that they were individually wrapped. It turns out they're huge crepes with filling in the center. Everything was quite tasty, but be warned that this food is spicy. I got a mango lassi to wash it down, but the lassi was so thick it was difficult to suck through a straw. 
The desserts were quite tasty as well, coconut ice cream and raspberry sherbet. Can't complain about the Madras coffee.
The food, the decor and the vibe the restaurant fit the area, with Kabuki next door. It's a place where you go when you have money to drop. I prefer for the food, not the decor to be the focus of dinner.
author: Naomi K.

description: Watch out for the bartenders here - if you are not a personal friend w historical rapport - you will not be served!  Never seen anything like it!  We and a few other groups stood at the bar for a full 20 minutes watching the guy manning the bar in disbelief as he smiled and served his various friends as they came in (after several groups) with glee... Finally after some objections by a few groups, he stated "I don't know who's next" as though he was throwing a steak to the dogs.  That was enough for us to head down the street, go to a much more crowded bar and get a drink within 5 minutes.  Never going back!
author: Steve C.

description: I went here with as a group of 3 on Saturday at about 5 pm on Saturday while the Fillmore Street Fair was happening.  It was great that we got seated right away in their beautifully decorated restaurant.  We each had a specialty drink, shared the Samosas for starters, the Chicken Biryani entree and 2 Dosas - Paneer and Peas and Lamb Keema.  Then we shared a pistachio dessert.  All were excellent.  Oh, I forgot to mention the tasty chips that are on the table before the meal is served.  Yes, the service was excellent too!  I will be back.  Our total bill with tax and tip cost each of us $52.00 so it is not a place to go to all the time but certainly worth a trip back.
author: H. D.

description:
I think the food and definitely the ambiance is better at the Fillmore location (versus Valencia).  

We came here for a Sunday lunch/brunch so it wasn't very crowded.  In fact, it was almost empty.  We had reservations for a party of 8 and were seated right away.

I was going to give them extra props for having a habanero dosa (habanero mixed into the dosa wrapper) because OMG it was hot!  Real habaneros.  I generally don't like raitas but when I was eating this I was regretting not having any.  The potatoes were plain (aka no habanero) so if I got the ratio of wrapper and potato right then it was manageable.  When I passed it around the table people tried it but no one could really eat it because it was so hot.  To be fair, the waitress warned me when I ordered it.  I was pretty impressed because usually you can't get real hot Indian food in SF.  But now I see they've taken it off the menu probably because it was too much.  No props for you!

Although I still think it's a bit overpriced for street food, they've definitely improved the flavors (not so bland) from their initial Valencia opening and the nice decor/ambiance at the Fillmore location seems to justify it.   

I'm curious to come back here for dinner.
author: Jean K.

description:
My friend insisted that we try this place and initially I was skeptical over the hype for dosa.. But this place is awesome!! It is v upscale and the decor is soo beautiful.. Their drink menu was also interesting.I had the South Indian monsoon and I loved it for its ginger and mint with pomegranate/mango combination.My friend loved her peony drink which had hibiscus masala and coconut milk.
 For appetizers, we ordered dahi vada (which came plated so beautifully that i dint want to eat it!), vada pav. For entree, My favorite was basil dosa.. Just the combination of indian spices and basil was wonderful. I also loved the uttapam and masala dosa..
This is a pricey place but worth it.
author: Priya A.

description: Tried this place for the first time and found the ambiance, service and food to be stellar.  The corn soup, lamb kebabs and calamari (all on the small plates/apps menu) were incredibly delicious - complex and balanced flavor palates in each.  These three items, along with the fall poriyal (brussels sprouts, squash and sweet potato) and the chutney sampler with papadam, were more than enough to satiate the two of us.  I will definitely return.  Actually, I'd have to say I had a food-gasm when the lamb hit my tongue.  Amazingly tender and flavorful, grilled to perfection.  A truly memorable moment.  And the corn soup, as simple as it sounds, should not be passed up.  Just trust me on that one.
author: Gina L.

description:
I dont know ... maybe I'm not an Indian fan ... but I love Tiki Masala, naan, samosas, gulab jamun , ... those are the indian food I crave for...  but for some reason, I am not liking DOSA at all :(

Their food looks better than it taste... and when they say spicy, oh boy ... do they mean uber super mega dooper burning SPICY. The spices that I love in Indian cuisine were hardly there. 

The place looks fabulous and the staff are nice ... but I know for sure, we are not coming back to Dosa when we crave Indian food.
author: RED C.

description: The services was very slow at the bar for early dinner. The bartenders was to busy talking to each other. We really smell like Indian curry after stepping out from the restaurant.  Food was Ok but the smell really gave me the headache.
author: Angkana P.

description:
Went for dinner here before seeing Aziz Ansari at the Fillmore this past Saturday night.  Not gonna lie, I kinda suggested this place in honor of his Indian-ness.... is that wrong? I love dining in groups of 4--it just seems to work out so well. Originally made a reservation for 5 and they didn't give me any crap about only have 4 people show up. I appreciated that. We kind of sampled everything so here's a rundown:

The waitress was great--she took the time to explain to us the difference between the southern and northern Indian cuisines. (It is nothing like naan n curry!)

Appetizer:

-Heirloom Tomatoes & Idiappam: SOOO good. great combo on flavors and we split one between the 4 of us so it was only a few bites, but it was delicious. The waitress warned us the heirloom tomatoes are starting to go out of season but ours were delicious.

Entrees (we did it all family style):

Vegetable curry: extremely flavorful and goes great with their coconut rice. The coconut rice was alright--not the best i've ever had, but then again this isn't a Thai restaurant!

Masala Dosa: Not gonna lie, i didn't get much of the inside of this cuz I was the last person the plate rotated to but the crepe-like outside was delicious! My friends enjoyed it though!

South Indian Moons Uttapam: It was a sampler of 5 of the chef's favorite Uttapams. Uttapams are just like the Dosas except all the ingredients are mashed together to form sort of like a fritatta texture. They were my favorite!

side of Dahi Rice: it was basically yogurt and rice with some other flavors--it reminded my friend's bf of cole slaw. It's a nice palate cleanser for the mouth in between tasting all the different flavors. However, the serving size could have been about 1/2 that size because you really only want a little bit...

Dessert: (we split 2 desserts between the 4 of us)
-Banana Cream Pie: It was so light and the carmelized bananas were delicious
-Gulab Jamoon: Soft, lightly-fried milk-dough balls, warm, cardamom syrup --a little too sweet for me, but it was good if split between 4 since we only had a couple bites each


I dont recommend any of their spice route drinks--im not a fan of my cocktail tasting like curry....sent back my "peony" and got a mojito instead. good choice
author: An-Nhien L.

description:
You'd be crazy not to order a dosa here. 

I love a good masala dosa (check my profile if you don't believe), and they certainly know how to make a great one here. I went with a big group, so we were able to split a few other things as well. Some other favorites include the chicken biryani, vegetable curry, spicy grilled octopus, goat cheese salad (lil' heat in the dressing!). With the dosa, this was just the right amount of food for four hungry girls. 

The cocktails? Ya-hum. Order the one with Darjeeling and gin. Trust.

Atmosphere? it's just plain gorgeous. Very modern, with a high chic factor.

I'd skip dessert. I didn't mind the coconut custard cake, but the ras malai was pretty bad. I don't know if it's Dosa's fault, but it was my fault for not remembering exactly what ras malai tastes like and convincing everyone to order it. There's a reason why India isn't known for its desserts, and ras malai isn't usually a favorite of mine to begin with.
author: Annie D.

description: Just left the restaurant after dinner...food is fine and ambience is great however, our server was HORRIBLE and totally ruined our anniversary dinner...his name was "Chihoa"..i wanted to complain to the manager but didn't wanna waste my time...this man never came back after taking our order to see if the food was good or not, and we had told him we wanted to order something else when we placed our first order, but he never came back to even ask if we wanted to order more...he never gave me a spoon to eat with either! We asked a random server to get a spoon and one more random server to ask about another dish we wanted to order and a third random server who was really nice and actually took our order for something else we wanted to order ..so basically we were calling random servers walking around for our needs since our server never showed his face again! ....ridiculous!!!!!..by the way he did show up in the end to dump the bill on us without a thank you!...and never asked us if we wanted a desert (which i did but thanks to his attitude we ended up going to ghiradelli for desert)..by the way all the other servers that we got help from were veryyy nice and one server who even got apricot chutney for me to try...so it's really just CHIHOA who ruined our experience ..this man has some real attitude and  customer service issues...I hope the manager of this location is reading this and does something about this..but if u wanna eat here just make sure to request on the front that u don't want CHIHOA as ur server else u gonna be scrambling trying to get help...all other servers are great
author: Tina P.

description:
Oh, Dosa. You're opened my eyes to what is possible in a higher-end Indian establishment. Get in my mouth.

Your swanky decor and killer service are just the start. Your cocktails? Impeccable. (Although the pisco/rhubarb/black pepper one? I'd skip it. Sounds inspired, but totes weird.) Your food? Delightful. Fantastic. You? Oh, you...

I know it sounds like I'm in love. And I'm pretty far in like, to be sure.

Dosas = delicious. The green chile garlic dosa? To die for. The OG thing? Good, but that chile garlic... hot dang! 

Also, not to be forgotten = lamb meatballs, scallops, and the cheese/pea filled dosa. Yum.

Having come here for a work dinner, I didn't end up footing the bill... but I did notice that the price factor would've most certainly been a consideration had I been doing so. 

Get the Buffalo Trace cocktail, the lamb, and the green chile dosa. Freaking set, you will be. Happy in your tummy and your mouth, unequivocally. Yoda speak, unnecessary it is, but hey... sometimes backwards is okay. Or whatever.
author: Rachel F.

description:
How this restaurant can have the same rating as Urban Curry is a complete mystery to me.  It makes me seriously question Yelpers' taste in India food.

Everything about my meal here was flawless. Great food, excellent service and a lovely ambiance with soaring ceilings and warm, relaxed lighting all added up to a memorable evening.

We arrived 10 minutes early for our reservation and were asked to wait on the designated benches or at the bar. For a popular restaurant like this, I appreciate the amount of spaces dedicated to waiting guests.  We found a spot at the bar and ordered a few cocktails. I was pleased to find that they serve high quality tonic (Fever Tree) to go with their high-end vodka.

Right at reservation time, we were led up the stairs to a lovely table on the railing overlooking the bar and the street.  The lighting was a bit dim for our older eyes, so the waitress brought us an extra "candle" and showed that it was electric and could be used as a small flashlight on the menu. Very helpful!  Overall the service was both gracious and efficient. We felt taken care of and never rushed.

We ate:

Spiced Mango and Goat Cheese Salad with organic mixed greens
Fiery Fruit
Prawn Masala with basmatic rice
South Indian Lamb Kofta with lemon rice
Paratha


Everything was fresh and delicious with the perfect balance of spice and seasoning.  I'm not normally a big fan of paratha, but this version was pan-fried, making it light and crispy and very flavorful.

I'm already planning my next visit.
author: Martha M.

description:
Appetizers: Chennai chicken and lamb sheek kabab. Main course: 5 moons uttapams, shrimp curry and coconut rice. Dessert: dark chocolate cake! Wow!
Excellent meal, great ambiance and amazing service.
author: Vidya R.

description:
After receiving a note from one of the owners, I'll change my review to say that you're not paying for just the ambiance you're also paying for:

- We're the only Indian restaurant that uses primarily organic and sustainable ingredients which are more expensive. 
- We also use freshly ground spices that are shipped from India and are quite expensive
- We provide everyone with a decent living wage for standard of living in San Francisco! 
- We provide health care to all our employees

So now you know.
author: Corey V.

description:
Dosa, I want to love you.   But you make it hard sometimes.  You have pretty good food and vegetarian options, but:

1) Your coconut rice is just *ok* when really it should be great because it pairs well with everything.
2) Your appetizers and small plates are decent (mini dosa, spicy prawns), but they are quite small and difficult to share with groups of 3+.
3) Your ceiling is just a bit too high, such that I never feel cozy in here. 
4) Your service can be lacking.  (I actually got spilled on once here).

On the upside, I enjoy the dosas, and it's not too hard to get a reservation here.  But last time I went, my group decided to head across the street to Burger King for dessert, rather than staying here - an unspoken rebellion against Dosa.  That pretty much says it all.  And yes, it also says something about the company I keep.
author: Jayne H.

description:
Had lunch at Dosa's on Fillmore for the first time yesterday.  It was truly a wonderful experience - the food was tasty, the service was great, portions were generous, and the dining area was airy and spacious.  The place was really inviting and had good ambiance.  I also liked the music they were playing in the background.

This was my first time trying a dosa and the server explained how to eat it and which dipping sauces to use.  There was 3 containers of sauces - the two smaller sauces included a green milder sauce, an orange spicier sauce.  The container in the middle was sort of soupy and was made with 20 different herbs and spices (or something like that)  The flavors really melded beautifully in that sauce.  

The mint lemonade was fair - I think the lemonade was made from a bottle (versus freshly squeezed) but the mint was fresh.  

I had the masala dosa, which is a good choice for a novice.  Next time I will try other things on the menu.  

This place was easy to get to, had plenty of street parking, good food and service - I will definitely return.  Great place for a first date or to catch up with friends (I was doing the latter).   Other reviewers have mentioned that it is pricey but I thought that given the beautiful surroundings, and food portions, it is worth it.
author: Bebe W.

description:
What a gorgeous place to enjoy a drink and a meal - love the decor, ambiance and music! 

While I waited for my friend to arrive, I studied Dosa's menu and asked the bartender for recommendations. I had a couple drinks and a happy hour appetizer too -- you must try their cocktails as they are very original and Indian spice inspired. My drinks were laced with a curry sort of taste and a ginger spicy taste - yum! I also tried their Chennai Chicken happy hour app which was completely doused in spices including coriander and cumin - hot sssss! I had to drown the chicken in the accompanying yogurt sauce to balance out the spiciness because I was sweatin' (but it was sooo good!). I enjoyed the greens that were on the side too. 

My friend arrived (she went to the original location on Valencia first, after comparing the two she said the Fillmore location is much bigger).  I had the Paneer & Peas dosa (spiced and shredded farmers' cheese, peas and cilantro) - yum & very filling! We had to cancel the rest of our dinner order because we were both so full just after eating our dosas. 

Nice, friendly service and great big portions to fill your tummy & curiosity! 

2 drinks+1 happy hour app+tax+tip = $31 
1 dosa+tax+tip = $16

Once-a-week dinner w/ Geraldine # 7
author: Maile N.

description: Get the rack of lamb it's really good. Good place to eat before the movies, if you like ethnic food this a great place to try. The lamb was great, the drinks were nice and strong, and the service was good, lots of food to choose from and if you have a question the staff knows their stuff, definitely going here again before going to a movie at the Kabuki.
author: Jose T.

description:
Dosa is OUT OF THIS WORLD GOOD.  In an area where there are a lot of great options to eat, DOSA is one of the best I  have dined at in a long while.  Yes, the food was very good, but so too was the service and they sure do have a great wine list.  Bravo for your wine selections.  

Our server was able to explain every dish we asked about.  We ended up sharing some appetizers including a lentil dumpling...beware this is not what you think.  i liken it to an indian version of a mexican layered bean dip.  Same colors too...different flavors all together though.  We love the papadams.  We also loved the 'fries' that we dined on.  Each of us selected a different entree.  All of them came grandly wrapped in a thick or thin dosa which enticed us before it even was placed before our drooling mouths.  I had a masala dosa.  This is a basic spiced potato mixture served in a large wrapping...similar to a crepe or burrito.  It is accompanied by a sweet tomato sauce, tangy green sauce and delicious spicey soup.  Another of us chose the egg dosa...its ALL ABOUT THE EGG.  It too came beautifully presented only open face this time.  Beth had a paper Dosa.  It was thin and crispy rather than chewy crepy.  And so much more.  We all enjoyed the dinner so much.  We cannot wait to return.  I saw a puffed bread walking by that I will have to try next time....its a big balloon bread filled with steam.  They bring it to your table inflated and then you get to stab it and let the steam out.  Again...the wine was devine and well priced for the quality.  We had a CabFrancis of some sort...wish i could remember!  Beth took a picture of the label I will have to get the name.  Anyhow...we loved it so much we ordered another for $48.00.  In another restaurant I bet you would have paid much more than this.  A meal with appetizers and wine came out to 350 or so...two bottles and gratuity included.  I don't know why anyone gives Dosa 4 stars when they can give them 5.
I almost forgot, they have a tasting menu with wine parings for something like 40.00 or so.  Out of this world.  :)
author: Erin S.

description:
Woah!

Let me be straight up honest here, you can order anything off the menu and it's excellent. Extremely high quality ingredients & dishes have numerous subtle well balanced flavors.

The specialty house drinks are also fantastic. Ginger Ante and the coconut one were spectacular. 

The only downside is the price. This place is not cheap--but I knew what I was getting into when I walked in so I'm not going to take away any stars.
author: Thor Z.

description: We decided to have a drink at Dosa and I am glad we did. The décor of this restaurant is really inviting. It is clean, open, and airy and has great picture windows. The bartender, Steven, was outstanding. He was friendly, knowledgeable and a mellow but cool personality. We tried the Rasam soup and the Papadum chips. Both were delicious.  This place has a nice long bar, is situated in a great corner location and I will definitely return for dinner.
author: Chocoolate I.

description:
A cozy yet casual, intimate yet fun place and experience. I came with two girl friends on a Monday night around 7 and were seated immediately by the window. We stuffed ourselves and I am now a fan of Dosa and am so so glad that the 7x7 list brought me here! 

Good things (so pretty much everything we ordered)

Appetizer:
- Vada pav (veggie slider): Okay so the name really doesn't do it justice, mostly because I love meat and think all sliders should be made with beef patties, but this was SO flavorful and delicious. The bun is sweet and the caramelized onions provide a nice contrast to the dry but perfectly seasoned potatoes. The dish comes with gunpowder, which is this spicy chili powder that you mix with melted butter to form a chili spread. It's really fun to make haha. BTW this is also super spicy.

Main courses:
- Channa bhatura: Probably my favorite indian dish ever. This gigantic fried, puffy dough comes out and hot steam actually comes out when you tear into it. It's such a wonderful sight! Then you dip the bread into this wonderfully flavorful chickpea dish and you can expect what my roommate calls a "food baby" for the rest of the evening. So worth it. I've had this dish at Vik's Chaat in Berkeley, but the puffy thing is overly greasy there. It's actually quite light and flavorful here.
- Paper masala dosa: This is what I came to try, the infamous paper masala dosa. It's actually humungous so, if you can visualize, three girls at the smallest table possible with the giant bhatura and now this long dosa too. I think we were in a little over our heads when we ordered :) So our waiter advised us on how to eat this, by tearing off a piece of the crispy dosa and dipping it into the potato mixture and then dipping it into one of three sauces: sambar, a tomato sauce and a coconut sauce. We ended up mixing and matching everything on our table, which was an extremely pleasant experience for our tastebuds haha. The only complaint about this dish is that the dosa itself is a little salty, so dipping it is kind of necessary to offset the saltiness.

Dessert:
- Rasmalai: I don't know how we managed to do this because we basically had carbs for our entire meal, but we ended up picking this. It's a surprisingly light dessert even though it's creamy and has the texture of panna cotta but is made of CHEESE! The rosewater fragrance is really nice and the pistachios add a great texture. Perfect way to end such a heavy meal.

The total came out to be $60 after tax and tip. The best part was probably our waiter who explained how to eat everything haha. Definitely coming back to try all the other different dosas...and to have something with meat.
author: Shira C.

description:
Fabulous flavors, good service and great space/decor.  Really enjoyed my dinner at Dosa.  The server walked us through the menu and best ways to order and share plates to make the most out of our meal.  We tried the chennai chicken as an appetizer.  Delicious!  The chicken was spicy, but calmed a bit by the dipping sauce.  When we next added a squeeze of lemon and then lemon and the onion.  Each made for great combinations and different experiences with every bite.  We shared the lamb kofta with a side of lemon rice and the roasted chile & garlic masala dosa - hot and spicy, LOVED this!  The lamb kofta was also really nice.  

This is a fantastic spot to try before heading across the street to enjoy a movie at the Kabuki!  Can't wait to try more of Dosa's exciting dishes.

All in all, memorable food and flavors that necessitate return visits for sure.
author: Janelle C.

description: Tried only the egg dosa - only thing worth mentioning is the red chutney. I did not like the chennai masala - the chicken appetizer. Amazing ambience - good for a date
author: Varsheeni R.

description:
This is the place to come if you want to take your non-indian (or your indian friends from out of town) friends for a taste of india in San Francisco. 
Great ambiance and really great service. The food is decent - there is nothing to complain about but its not the authentic, yummylicious food you get in the south bay (or India or your mom's kitchen).
