I take almost every visitor to this place and everyone loves it (the experience everything). The only people who complain (!) are people who are pickier about their south indian eats (like sambar and the dosa). My mom and dad for example thought the place was just OK. I mean my mom makes better dosas and sambar than this place, so why pay a premium to eat that, right?

On the other hand, i dont! so i love it enough to go here, but we mostly visit this place when we have out-of-town guests.

My favs - dahi vada, the masala chai, uttapam. I am not one for egg and dosas but my friends have loved the combo. The husband and others like the chicken chettinad and the frankies. I love vada pav, but the one here was too sweet for my liking. 

They have good cocktails too (that are different from what you may have had previously).
author: Sapna E.

description:
Dear Dosa, thank you for making my second night in San Francisco a night to remember! 

Aside from the political bar talk I had with two random strangers who almost wanted to shoot me because I told them I was from Orange County, the food at Dosa was interesting, unique and amazing.  The food was unlike anything I have ever tried and very spicy...which I LOVE!

We started our dinner off with vegetarian sliders and then went on to order the Spicy Mung Masala Mini Dosa, so awesome, so spicy!  The ambiance is great and the decor was beautiful. I would say a definite must have if you live in the San Francisco area or just visiting.
author: Jessica C.

description: Pricey, pricey, but the food is good. I got to eat a whole bunch of different kinds with a large group of people. Great for a special occasion.
author: Yoko S.

description:
If we didn't have to wait a good 5-10 minutes just to be greeted by our waitress and if they didn't get our orders switched up, I would have given this place 5 stars.

We had 8:45pm reservations before seeing the 9:55pm showing of Harry Potter in 3D over at the theater across the street. We showed up a little bit early and ended up waiting about 5-10 minutes to be seated at our table. Walking in, this place is super trendy. Past the plain wooden door, a fancy chandelier greets you at the hostess' podium. Tall ceilings draw your eyes up to the balcony area that was reserved for a private party at the time. Then your eyes immediately go to the expansive dining area filled with hip bar seating, circular tables for groups, and smaller tables for more intimate dining.

Once we sat down, we looked over the menu for a good 5-10 minutes, put them down on the table, and then waited another 5-10 minutes to be greeted by our waitress. Meanwhile, we got not just one, but TWO glasses of water EACH! How did the guy put down additional glasses when he saw that we already had water?! A little miscommunication right there. When the waitress noticed this, she picked up the glasses on her way to the kitchen. Anyways, my friend ordered a drink, the grilled calamari appetizer to share, and the Paneer & Peas Dosa (since according to other fellow Yelpers, the Dosa is the thing to get!). I ordered the Spring Dosa and decided to save my alcohol consumption for the movies :)

In lieu of bread, they presented us with these things that looked a lot like tortilla chips but were lighter and airier. I forgot what they were called, but they're mighty tasty! Then our grilled calamari came out. It was a simple dish, but pretty good. When our entrees came out, they mixed up our orders and put mine in front of my friend and my friend's in front of me. We didn't realize this until we bit into it... Fortunately, we like to share food and just switched plates after that (also, fortunately, none of us have any food allergies). Since neither of us had dined there before, the guy who served us our food gave us the suggestion of how to eat the Dosa (dip it in the large bowl first and then in either of the chutney's). Both of us preferred the green chutney, and in fact, I didn't like dipping it in the large bowl of sauce first... Just the green chutney was perfect. It was very refreshing. My friend's Paneer & Peas Dosa was really good with the spiced cheese, but I also liked the lightness of my Spring Dosa. The crepe-like carbohydrate was the perfect thickness as to not be overpowering of the filling. I had never had Indian food like this, so it was a great experience. 

Finally, since we were in a bit of a time crunch, we asked for the check and tried to get out of there quickly. The service was okay... I could tell they were trying to be very personable and attentive, but maybe it was just too busy? For such a trendy place, though, I would think that it's this busy on a regular basis.

Overall, I had a great dining experience. I don't know if I would come here again just because I wasn't blown away... It was definitely unique and I love going to a classy/trendy place every now and then, but there's so many other choices in the area, I think I would have to try one of those first before coming back to Dosa.

NOTE: The other entrees were in the $20+ range, while the Dosas were about $11-12 and each serving was plenty to fill me up (I didn't finish my plate). If you want something atypical of other Indian restaurants, and want to save some cash, order a Dosa!
author: Leana L.

description: Truly the worst service I have experienced.  I just called to try to place a to-go order.  The menu Dosa has on its website is not current. I have a severe dairy allergy and the first two things I tried to order (which are dairy-free) are no longer offered. I asked the order-taker if he could suggest some other small plates that are dairy-free. Two of his suggestions are not on the online menu and he was not able to describe them. Then, he told me that he only had another minute in which to take my order.  Imagine being at a restaurant in person and having the waiter tell you that you only have a minute left to order!! Incredibly rude! Life is too short to be a customer at restaurants that are rude!
author: Kristin R.

description:
Our 2 person party dashed from the Yelp Elite event and ventured through the steep incline of Fillmore street (Did you know part of the sidewalk has stairs on it? I really don't know jack about certain parts of SF.). We were practically gasping for air once we arrived here to meet with friends. 

My partner in crime ordered a bottle of champagne (like a boss) to share with some of the group while I ordered Chennai Chicken and samosas to split. Felt the kick from the chicken and the samosas had a flavorful blend of veggies and spiced potatoes. I don't have Indian cuisine very often, so it's crucial that I pick something good when I do. Dos thumbs up, Dosa.
author: Rhia R.

description: This is my 2nd trip to Dosa in a few months and it delivers.  The food is fantastic, the drinks delicious, and the service is fast.
author: Sarah W.

description:
Last night I ventured into Dosa on Fillmore to have dinner with a friend that I haven't seen in 20 years... being that I'm 27, we were wee little ones when we knew each other.  It was the perfect venue for basically a blind date (as it felt like one).  The music was a perfect level - not to loud, everything was sharable, the drinks were delicious and the food was just perfect.  Our waiter was very nice and let us linger for a few hours while all our food came out.

All in all, a great place for a date, friends dinner, parent dinner, business dinner... just about anything.  I cannot wait to come back on my next visit to SF.
author: Justine M.

description: Was in dosa last Friday night. Loved the food, so delicious. Proper Indian, not that take-out crap! The staff were so lovely and helpful with explaining the menu. The only fault I would have with the place is that they rush you a bit. We had starters, main course and tea and coffee all within an hour and 15mins!
author: Jenny M.

description: Contemporary flare on South-Indian.  Good food and good drinks.  Definitely get the Dahi Vadha and Rasam.  Do not eat here before going out on the town though.
author: Ashwin G.

description: Nice decor in a huge building. Our waitress was friendly and helpful- a vegan menu was perfect for my wife. The food was incredible and reasonably priced. We went with the dosa and uttapam, avoiding the more traditional Indian fare. But the table next to us ordered curries and they smelled delicious. We will be going back for moe
author: Trey H.

description:
I initially read about Dosa on the 7x7 list.  The Fillmore location has a full liquor license, and the decor is modern, kind of lounge-ish, with a fun atmosphere.  

For a group, you can do a 4 course tasting for $39 a person, but we decided to just order small plates and large plates off the regular menu to share family style.  The menu has a Southern Indian flare with a modern twist.

As the restaurant name implies, you should try the dosas.  They come in less typical flavors, including masala chutney (with eggplant spread), a lighter veteable (spring) version, and also an open faced version. All come with spicy sambar and other dipping sauces.

For appetizers, the sprouted mung bean salad has a nice crunch. The mango and goat cheese salad was a good ratio of fruit and tender leaves, scattered with pomegranate seeds.

The scallops were seared, sitting on top of a red spicy sauce; they were sweet and garnished with just a few micro greens.

For entrees, the lamb chops are amazing. I don't even eat lamb, but it's so tender, and the sauce is really good with rice.  Chicken korma is rich and not creamy and overly heavy like the traditional kind.  The mango prawns were sweet and plump, with a fruity sauce fir the accompanying coconut rice.  The bread with the channa was slightly sweet, slightly crisp, and the garbanzo beans was addictive - I couldn't stop eating it even though I was stuffed.

Our server was super informative and helpful in navigating the menu. With all the courses we ordered, we left too stuffed for dessert. Wines by the bottle start in the $30 range, and you can definitely leave very satisfied for less than $50 a person (all inclusive).
author: Marilyn T.

description: I have only tried their cumin-beet soup with creme-fraiche and it's okay... I have heard a lot of good things about this place though so i'll be sure to check it out soon.
author: Minks M.

description:
They held our reservation for a few minutes even with a packed house. Nice! Light level and music: lounge-ish, but not too dark or loud to obstruct conversation or make me feel like I was on a date with my bf's uncles.

We came with recs from some Dosa vets and the waiter's favorites validated the first few things we were going to order anyway. perfect mind meld! it must be true.

chennai chicken app was kind of like spiced chicken fingers with yogurt sauce. i mean super yummy chicken fingers, of course.

we had a couple of dosas. One of the simple ones with potato. yummy sauces. too bad it was in a triangle. I like when they are giant and rolled. 

prawn masala and lamb kofta were yummy. I pretty much just wanted the sauces on the rice, which was yummy on its own. I was happy to leave the prawns for others, but when I got one, it was great!

dahi vadi was like a spider web of yogurt and chutney with a surprise of lentil cakes or something at the bottom. on the blander side, but my eyes were satisfied, so good show.

we paired all this with a couple of bottles of dry riesling (yes, a riesling!). it really cut the heaviness and spice. good choice!

we had desserts (coconut cake and passion fruit custard) which were ok. the little coconut cookie and shortbread triangle that came with were the best part of that. and the paired port. lip smackingly sweet! (we probably should have foraged across the street for a japanese sweet.)

great service and atmosphere too. lovely art and our expresser was overjoyed to be bringing us our food.
author: Joanna G.

description:
Skip their $39 four-course tasting menu and order a la carte instead. You get a much better selection of dishes and you'll end up spending a lot less.

I've been here a 4-5 times already and I also recommend skipping all of their "meat" dishes. None of them were very memorable (except I remember that they were over cooked and very dry) and you can get much better dishes at other Indian restaurants throughout the city.

However, their Paper Dosa and their Tamil Vegetable Curry are FANTASTIC. These two menu items will always be included in my order whenever I go here....and probably the main reason why I keep coming back.

Negative points for charging a 4% health care charge and then trying to write a letter/note to justify this on your website. Include this in your menu/food prices instead and I'll respect you more. This just means that you never provided health care to all your staff workers prior to this SF law.

...they'll also automatically charge a 20% gratuity on parties of 5 or more. But so far my experience with their staff has been pretty good so that sounds about right. I just hate that its automatic.
author: Lester W.

description: This is the first and my favourite Indian restaurant in SF. Love the interior decoration, the high ceiling, spacious room, love it!  Food is authentic and awesome!
author: Shell J.

description:
Came here for my birthday last week.  This is such a gorgeous restaurant!  Love the chandeliers.  I ordered the four course tasting menu.  Though I really enjoyed the Chennai Chicken and Prawn Curry, I think the mini dosa (I had the 'Spring') and dessert (I had the 'Rasmalai') were just okay.  Granted, I'd never had either before, so maybe I'm not the best judge.  

The Bollywood Hills and Peony cocktails were outstanding, and our waitress recommended a fantastic wine to accompany our entree course.  Overall, I had a great time and would recommend this restaurant to a friend.
author: Emily P.

description: Overall I loved the food and the atmosphere reminds me of a bigger city like Chicago or New York. But it was loud and the tables are really close together. Overall a great spot but don't come for an intimate evening
author: Lizzie S.

description: This is the perfect spot for a hot Saturday night date.  Make a reservation (it gets super busy) and be prepared to get a bit overloaded by the very large drink, appetizer, and dinner menu.  Once you maneuver your way through the beast of options, it is smooth sailing.  Ambiance is great, food delicious, and overall a nice intro to Indian cuisine.  Highly recommend making your way over to Sundance Kabuki theater for a late-night movie post date.  #soliddatenight
author: Jessica J.

description:
The restaurant is absolutely beautiful, but the service could use some polishing... One of the guys was like a bull in a china shop with the way he threw our glass plates on the glass table top. The food was good, but there are definitely as good, or much better options  at the hole-in-the-wall Indian spots in Berkeley for half the price.

Great experience to try once.
author: P K.

description:
Great decor. Average food. Some inpsiring cocktails.
Staff was distracted by their smart phones. 
Willing to go back for gorgeous decor, and hope to get better service and food.
author: Kenzie D.

description:
went with one of my friends for brunch yesterday - she had a mango mimosa and i had the non alcoholic- South Indian Monsoon- which we were both happy with !
we decided to share the Dahi Vada plate and were very impressed with the presentation ! we ordered the Broccolini Dosa and the Green Mango and Paneer Uttapam - the Uttapam came out a little on the burnt side- but it wasnt bad and the mango flavor was awesome ! the Dosa had too much filling - but we enjoyed it  - was greasy though , as any Dosa should be ! :)
over all it was a very enjoyable meal and will go there again  for sure .
author: Madhulika G.

description: Undercooked Dosas, pulpy Oothappams and overpriced everything. Sure, the ambience was great, but would I pay $50+ for that? Nah.
author: Shyamala L.

description:
I'm not really sure how to grade this restaurant since I loved the layout but the food seemed too spicey for my taste.

I did like the mint chutney and their dosa's are pretty good but once again left me on fire afterward.
author: Jafar Amir Hanovic Ismailov M.

description:
Worst restaurant experience in a long time. Went to Dosa for dinner on a Tuesday night. The restaurant was 60% empty. So we were seated immediately. The slap in the face was that the waitstaff there enjoying themselves and never had the decency to cater to their customers. We are locals, and I can't say I have ever been treated so poorly. These people have such a bad attitude. We chose to leave before we "inconvenienced" anyone to pay an ounce of attention. IMO the only thing Indian about this restaurant is their rude waitstaff.

From a previous experience, everything here was too salty, but entrées were over the top salty and otherwise over seasoned and cooked for the wrong amount of time. Without the hype, I think their food still deserves 2 stars but because I hate hyped up places that can't deliver to the amped up expectations, and with a complete lack of customer service, Dosa's only receiving a single star, and that's only because Yelp wouldn't let me do anything less.
author: Jake M.

description: After several failed attempts at trying to come here for Dine About Town, I ended up eating off their regular menu which had something similar to DAT but was 4 courses and cost only slightly more. I'm not crazy about Indian food but everything was pretty tasty. I had the calamari, spring dosa, chicken curry and some strange soapy tasting drink for dessert. It was my first time trying dosa and I am now a fan! Chicken curry was also yummy. I didn't like the calamari though because I was expecting fried calamari and it turned out to be calamari in its original squid form. Though that was really my fault for not understanding that "Grilled Calamari" does not equal "Fried Calamari". The dessert drink was also pretty awful but I blame the waitress because she recommended it. When in doubt always go for the gelato, can't go wrong there.
author: Queena T.

description:
Delicious Indian food and great people watching. I was pleasantly surprised that even though the restaurant is always full, it's not stuffy. It must be all the space and the high ceilings that help maintain fresh air.   

I am not a big fan of their coffee as it doesn't seem to taste like one, but then again - one doesn't go to an Indian restaurant for coffee.    

I don't think it's a good first date place. Too noisy, although not nearly as noisy as some other places. 

The staff is attentive and efficient. All in all, this place is popular for a reason.
author: Arkady I.

description: Excellent food, poor service. Requested the vegan chutney option for the sampler and was given a non-vegan chutney. Entree, which was a dosa, was very tasty. Waited a long time for the bill and the waitstaff rudely and hastily cleared our table.
author: Beth C.

description: We are spoilt as we have lived in the UK for many years before relocating to San Francisco and UK is the best for Indian food, but DOSA is the best you can get in San Fran (or the best we have found so far). The deco is great, people friendly and food is good.
author: Gosia R.

description: The ambiance of the place was already worth the price - the staff was extremely friendly and responsive. In addition, the Bollywood music really added a great touch (was definitely jamming to a few). The food was great and tasty (in particular the sambar was just the perfect amount of spicy). I got the masala uttapam which, as mentioned by our server, the spiciest dish on the menu - it certainly lived up to that. The taste was phenomenal and just a great experience all around; I highly recommend this place.
author: Anand S.

description:
Decided to try this since I've been hearing so much about it.  Perhaps the expectation was set too high...thought this place was just good, but not such a wonderful dining experience to make it on my "must return" list.

DECOR -- 3.5
While the striking chandeliers take your breath away, other details of the restaurant somehow don't pull together.  The general feel of the space felt a little odd: where right by the stairs/bar/route to the restroom was overcrowded, the entry by the kitchen behind the receptionist was oddly empty.  The ceilings were so tall that it felt really spacious, and yet, a little too much so. At the same time the tables are so crowded that you can enjoy your neighbor's conversation.  The crowded feeling extended to the tabletop -- when both of our meals arrived, with the water glasses, water bottle, lassi and wine glass, every inch of our table space was taken up making it hard to enjoy the meal.

FOOD -- 3.5 stars
We ordered the original Dosa and the fish curry (Keralasa Fish Moilee I think?).  Both dishes were good and tasted really fresh and we enjoyed them.  However, we were not blown away by it.  Again, perhaps the expectation was set too high.

SERVICE -- 3.0 stars
Our receptionist was friendly -- we had a reservation and was seated promptly after a little wait since we arrived early.  Our server was also very friendly.  No complaints.  The low rating goes to the pacing of service: our food arrived literally 3 minutes after we ordered, while we were munching on the yumming crispy freebie treat (don't know what it's called).  First was the Dosa, then 2 minutes later, our fish curry arrived to join the party on our table top.  While we appreciated the quick service, I felt a little jarred as it would have been much nicer to finished the dosa, then enjoy the curry.  But we didn't specify that to our waiter, so not their fault, but nonetheless, the food came out so fast that we felt rushed.
author: Stephanie L.

description: Everytime I go to SF i have to get one of their DOSA...they are huge and flavorful! They are the only restaurant that can match me star per star in terms of spiciness! The place is very nicely decorated and the staff is friendly. It can be a little dead during lunch but dinner is nice!
author: Sin T.

description:
First time at Dosa and I gotta say, I was impressed.  It is definitely on the pricey side, but you're paying for the ambience, and the service.  The place really pretty inside and the servers are on top of it.  

Came with 3 other people so we ordered a bottle of sparkling wine, an appetizer, and 4 entrees, more than enough food for all of us.  I've never had Dosa before but it is pretty good!  Thin and crispy dosa, lots and lots of potatoes and good curry too!  

A great place to check out if you're in the city, I'm definitely coming back to try more!
author: Grace L.

description: Great food and drinks!  Spice was nice and staff helpful to navigate the menu.
author: Mike C.

description: The place is  really fancy, and even during the week it might be a hard to get in without a reservation. We had to wait 45 minutes to share a table, and it was a week day. The food is really good, don't miss the appetizer with the yogurt . The service it's so and so.
author: MyName M.

description:
I love the interior design of this place. You walk in to a restaurant with high ceilings and soothing orange walls with some artwork on it.  I also noticed their lovely chandeliers and their sophisticated looking bar!

I came here twice, both for lunch, it wasn't packed so we got seated very shortly.

In my last two visits I've tried:

CHENNAI CHICKEN: good, but spicy for me.  Dip it into the yogurt to ease the spice.
MUNG SPROUTS: not your typical salad. consisted of lentils with a mix of chopped veggies. very refreshing

SAMOSAS: a delicious savory pastry filled with flavorful filling of either vegetables or potatoes.  I loved the flaky outside crust. One of my favorites.

PRAWN CHILE FRY: i love prawns, but this was too spicy for me.  It was very beautifully presented and there were only about 4-5 pieces of prawns.

BLACKENED SARDINES: YUM! wasn't too fishy, nice crispy skin. pretty good.

NATURAL LAMB FRANKIE: it was alright, nothing too special. Maybe i just don't like wraps.

ROASTED CHILE AND GARLIC MASALA DOSA: it was too spicy for my liking. filled with potatoes and spices.  I had to dip it into the coconut chutney to help ease the spiciness.

SOUTH INDIAN MOONS UTTAPAM: 5 mini different pancake-like bread with savory toppings.  I loved trying the variety of flavors it came in. Each one was very flavorful and addicting. Great for a party of 4/5, that way everyone can try a piece of each flavor.

TAMIL VEGETABLE CURRY AND PARATHA: it wasn't too spicy, which was perfect for my liking. i loved the big chunks of potatoes and the paratha (fried bread) was amazing. i could have just ate the paratha alone. very delicious dish.

Overall, great service, loved the decor, nice ambiance, and good food!!!

I came with people who love spicy food, which is why we ordered a lot of the spicier foods.  If you like spicy this is the place to go, but if you don't there are a variety of dishes you can try as well!
author: Sarah F.

description:
It wasn't busy when we walked in. Just people at the bar. This was 6pm on a Wed. We were greeted promptly and seated. The table we sat at was wobbly, and once we informed our waiter (who was great!) He sat us at the closest table that worked for us. 

I had the Batsman drink, which was terrific!
 Summery with gin & lemon & And garnished with mint!
We had the mussels which were delicate and amazing!!!!!!!! I

We had the panneer & Pea dosa which was fantastic! It came with a soup that was great! (Startchy, baley, yummiess!)
Then we had the lamb meat balls which which amazing which my boyfriend loved after he wasn't even so sure about the restaurant!

I would highly recommend this  restaurant and will return again!!!
author: Katrina M.

description: My husband and I stopped here one night before catching a flick at Kabuki. I absolutely love the décor. It was so hip yet traditional. We started out with the Chennai Chicken. I highly recommend this. It was tender and had a nice spice. We then ordered the Masala Dosa and the Prawn Masala. We loved the Prawn dish and the sauce was fantastic! The Masala Dosa on the other hand was not a huge favorite. I think it was the spice that they used that was off putting. Not terrible but not good enough to finish. Overall I would say our visit was pleasant (service was great) but it won't be a spot we will be hitting often. I might venture back with a girlfriend or two since the bar looked lively and fun.
author: Bri R.

description:
More like 3 1/2 star.
The food was good, nothing spectacular. The chutney's were awesome though. I had the mini-moon or something mini utthappam dish. It was ok.
The decor is hip, the space has open feel and the music jazzy. 
Service was basic. They made sure to not make eye-contact while speaking to us. Just to let us know, they were so on top of this, they didn't have to look at us. The one thing remarkable of our attendant was his earring :)
The drinks menu is good though. the bar is cool too.
author: Swati R.

description:
Great, classy indian restaurant in SFO! We stopped by for dinner and discovered they have a happy hour from 4 to 7 pm. Vada pav was yummy! The chili garlic masala dosa was huge! The masala filling was good for two people. Hot sambhar and chutneys spiced it up.
I heard their dahi vada is excellent too. A tad pricey, but what else can you expect from a classy restaurant in the city? Awesome service. They serve complimentary papad as well.
I left my cap behind, and the kind waiter had handed it over to the front desk, where it was waiting for me when i went back for it. If you crave a dosa, you know where to go!
They are open only for dinner on week days.
author: Shantala A.

description:
Came to Dosa's for a friend's birthday celebration.  We had a great time and really a new eye opener to Idian cuisine.

There is an option to choose a 4 course tasting.

I.  Starter - I had the south indian corn soup. Grilled corn with coconut milk and curry leaves all pureed to a smooth bisque like consistency.

II.  Mini Dosa.  I had the Paneer & Peas.  Dosa (crepe like) filled with Indian style cheese with peads and cilantro in this wonderfully flavored and spiced sauce.

III.  Kerala Fish Moilee.  Fish prepared in a fragrant sauce made of coconut milk, coriander, cumin, shallots, and mustard seeds served with coconut rice.

IV.  Dessert - I had a refreshing sorbet to cleanse the palate after all the different tastes and textures.

My favorite was the mini dosa and fish.  It was absolutely delicious and I would go again.
author: JJAMZ C.

description:
Our go-to Indian restaurant - love the South Indian spices, and dosas are just to die for. The Chennai chicken is a must try.

I'd give it 6 if I could.
author: Romey B.

description:
Although it's nice to have a southern Indian restaurant as an option, I have to agree that this place is less than memorable.  Honestly, it would probably only be getting one star except the service was very good.  The decor left much to be desired with its Jorge Pardo knock-off lamps (Pardo is great; the knock-offs are cheesy) and "Klassy" faux candles.  If you're seated in the loft at the two-tops, you'll be closer to the stranger next to you than to your dinner companion, and you'll be better able to hear the next tables conversation as well.

The food and drinks were decent, but over-priced with NO substitutions allowed due to the owners fascist demands (what??!! the staff wanted to help, but said they would be fired!). Apparently if you have any specific dietary restrictions, you must visit the website first, and if you still want a substitution, you have to get up and ask the owner, if you're there at time when he happens to be in house, and he's feeling generous.  

My friend had three medium sized prawns in the entree, somewhat tasty but VERY skimpy!  You can get better coconut gelato at your local grocer. Theirs was grainy.  The best thing I sampled was the paneer and peas dosa, but the bill was pretty outrageous for cheese and peas. 

The place seems to have gotten better reviews from others, so, hopefully my experience was a fluke.
author: LIsa Y.

description:
Great for the adventurous.

Uttapam is pretty tasty. Reminded me of a crepe/pancake with Indian flavors. Get the one with Mushrooms.
author: Jenny J.

description: Great authentic South Indian food. Excellent, fresh tasting sambar and chutney (which every South Indian restaurant should be judged by). The utthappam's where cooked properly. Really enjoyed the idly fries. The ambience and the service were great too.
author: Nandini V.

description:
You know, didn't do it for me.

Let's start with the "Dosa." What arrived at the table was a freakin' trident missile of a crepe laying on its side, which we were disappointed to find out contained a payload of about a half-cup of goodness somewhere in the middle. Pretty much the whole table felt disappointed and we spent time searching thru the yard-long thin, crispy casing to find the good stuff and figure out WTF was up with this pipe laying on a plate. We even asked the waiter if this was normal, and he said it was. If that is normal - PASS on the Dosa.  One diner commented it was a like a poster rolled up - basically that big, and mostly full of air.  

The rest of the meal was average - decent flavors, small portions. The lamb meatballs fell in this category, as did the calamari.  Just ok - not great by far. If I want braised calamari, I'm going to Barbacco. No nan bread here mind you.  Wine list was marginal - not over-priced, but did not dig the selection. I did find the ginger-based cocktail tasty.

Basically, if I want Indian food in SF, this is not my 1st choice. I wouldn't fight a group who wanted to drag me here, but it won't be a choice I make.
author: Josh B.

description:
Beautiful and hip, but a little over-hyped.

If you are looking to impress a date or an in-law with good taste, then this is the place to go.  I've been here twice and the food is solid with a wonderful atmosphere and amazing staff.  

Why I knock it a star?  Because the food is great, but not amazing.  There isn't anything here that knocks my socks off or totally justifies the price tag, but you are paying for the whole package and that makes it worth it.

Dosas are delicious!  Drinks are perfect!  Definitely worth trying a few times if you need some swank in your life!

Tasty:  
*Crispy Fish Pakora - Sustainably-caught fish, marinated in chile, cumin, ginger & garlic, fried, served w/ chile & cilantro chutney
*South Indian Lamb Kofta -  Natural lamb meatballs, rich sauce of tomatoes & mild spices with plain rice.
author: Christine K.

description: Love this place every time!  The sliders are great, corn soup was excellent & drinks are always on point!  Great place to get Indian food!
author: Liz A.

description: I love authentic Indian food and good unauthentic food... and this is the best place for unauthentic Indian food.... Good presentation, great service, good taste... and best desserts... :)
author: Raman D.

description: Altho the staff was nice the place was dark & difficult to even see my food! And what's with the techno music??!!! It was hard to carry on a conversation with my fellow diners!  The food we ordered was done well & flavors were good but I'm giving it a one star because of the atmosphere!
author: sandy t.

description:
Oh Dosa.  I'd been meaning to go here since it opened and now I kind of wish we never went!  Popped in after a movie with friends at the Kabuki on a Saturday night.  Staff was supernice and seated us right away.  I was floored by the decor - gorgeous, sleek, and so stylish!   I also loved that our fellow patrons seemed a cut above the usual SF crowd.  We relaxed, sipped some lovely cocktails and I thought about how many great dinners we'd have here in the future.

Then the food showed up, surprisingly fast.  (Like, maybe 4-5 minutes later, tops.)  All of us had ordered different things, yet everyone's plate looked the exactly the same.  Not good!  We shared around but the texture of everything was gooey and reheated tasting.  It seems like they just had different vats of different proteins in different sauces simmering for hours, to be scooped out with a ladle when someone ordered.  Naan bread was tasty and fluffy, but that was about it.  The waiter also recommended a "dumpling" dish that was very pretty (looked like a napoleon cookie) but really gross.  One of my friends described it best when she said it was "like eating a bowl of mayonaise."  Yuck.

Two stars for the decor and drinks, but that's it.  I'd come back for a drink but wouldn't do dinner again.
author: Jaimie M.

description:
Took here 2 guests from out of town, this one of my favorite places to take out of town guests, it's not too fancy, not too expensive, interesting take on indian food and the atmosphere is really good.
 
As usual the food was great, service was good and we all had a great experience.
The only issue was that it's very dark on the 2nd floor and we had some problem reading the menu (especially the older)
author: Tom S.

description:
If you want dosa, this is the place to come. I have never been disappointed by their dosas or uttapams. Sometimes they have too many customers so when the dosa comes to you, seems like it had been sitting for a bit, so not too too crispy, but still delicious.

Key to have a good dining experience:
- Must make a reservation: walk-ins are available but be prepared to wait for an hour at least (staff is super nice about it but still, waiting for an hour is sometimes too much)
- Just get the dosas or uttapams. I find the other main dish just ok
author: T H.

description:
Oh maaaaaan so good! The high points were the kick-butt paratha, the amaaaaazing drinks (Ginger Ante!), and the Dahi Vada. 

The lamb meatballs were good, but not rave worthy, and the poori could have been more crunchy, although it was huuuuge!

I loved the decor of the space, and the service was nice too!
author: Scott L.

description: Great atmosphere and so yummy. Vegan friendly!
author: Emily H.

description:
This review is solely for their desserts.

Passed by on a Friday night looking for something small to much on while waiting for friends to get out of work.

We were very impressed by the decor, which enticed us to go inside.  The lights are gorgeous! It is a very romantic setting, and the bar has an aesthetically pleasing feel to it.

We ordered two desserts:

Chai Float: Indian spin on a root beer float.  It was a chai milk ice cream with cola. Very disappointing.  One thing I know now is that cinnamon and coke DO NOT mix well together.  The spice flavor was extremely overpowering.  The chai ice cream was good on its own, but drinking the cola with it made me cringe.

Rasmalai:  sweet cheese patties in milk cream.  The description sounded delicious!  After trying one bite, I had to control my urge to gag and spit it back out.  The texture reminded me of wet paper and it tasted nothing like cheese.  My roommate loves any sweets she can get her hands on, but she told me that this was the first time she had to force herself to eat a dessert.

We should have listened to the host and tried the chili chocolate cake--which sounded pretty good, but was a bit pricey for what we were looking for.

Not sure how the regular food tastes, but definitely will NOT get dessert if I'm ever back there.
author: Michelle W.

description: A friend took us to Dosa while visiting San Francisco in early August.  Wow we loved it!  The Dosas were unlike anything we have ever had.  Indian food is not new to me but this experience definitely was.  The staff was stellar, very friendly and informative.  They asked what we liked and guided us thru the menu.  The food went from mild to triple ding ding spicy based on our preferences and it was perfect.  the dipping sauces blended perfectly with the food.  Specialty cocktails were tasty as well.  We arrived a bit late but that was no problem with the staff   LOVE LOVE LOVE this place, nothing like it back home in Dallas.  Check it out when in San Fran.
author: Leslie L.

description:
WOW this was a wonderful place. We went the day after Valentine's Day.

We had the chips with the different sampler sauces. All sauces were so good. I really loved the kale sauce. The cilantro fish and the duck were both delish and SPICY and flavorful. Yes, pricey! Hope we can go again soon.
author: Jackie H.

description:
A nice chic place . What really stands out is the whole ambience , cozy/chic and yet Indian . The food is good . We went with kids and probably we were the only one with kids . Not a very kid friendly place but otherwise pretty good . 
Ordered south Indian food and all of it was perfect , nice .fesh . Aromatic . The way I like  ;-) specially liked the sambhar and chutneys . 

Highly recommended . But slightly expensive .
author: Amit V.

description:
South Indian Cuisine 

Made dinner reservations for a party of 8 but you'll need to leave your credit card number to them. We were seated promptly upstairs. 

SERVICE - attentive and courteous. 

(APPETIZERS ORDERED: Nothing outstanding)

CRISPY FISH PAKORA -
BHEL PURI - 
CHICKEN KEBOB

ENTREES (Not Wow'ed by any of these dishes) They were good but not great and memorable. 

KERALA FISH - Coconut fish $28
BAKED FISH CHUTNEY/CILANTRO SAUCE $29 (it takes 18 min to prep)
MANGO PRAWN
MASALA DOSA


SOUTH INDIAN MONSOON DRINK - not wow'ed by it. 
I think I would've gotten the plain LASSI instead without the mango. THAT TASTED GOOD. 

DESSERTS: 

FRESH COCONUT CUSTARD CAKE - pretty good
PAYASAM and CARROT HALWA - warmed. Pretty good as well but not as good as the COCONUT CUSTARD CAKE
House Made Gelato 

Our check came to $55/per person including tip.
author: Jboogie L.

description:
It was love at first sight, and after my second visit, I am even more smitten.  I've always loved Indian food, but since having to go on a strict Gluten-Free diet, have gotten nervous about just what goes into all those wonderful curries and lovely fried things that I've enjoyed for years.  

Turns out they have a special card which lists the whole menu, identifying which dishes contain any of several major allergens: diary, eggs, nuts, and wheat.  

Our waitress was super-accommodating and even told me that the pappadam was made with some bizarre grain that I had never even heard of (and I know most of 'em!), which may contain trace amounts of wheat.  Having eaten the stuff for years with no problem, thinking it was all lentil flour, I was amazed at how tuned-in she was to the needs of a Celiac diner.  

Everything was wonderful.  I wish I could buy the asparagus soup by the gallon.

The Pepper Chicken is my favorite - its sauce is so subtly and delicately flavored, with a fiery heat that sneaks up on you.  The heat rises slowly, taking your tastebuds on a real roller-coaster ride.  

I could eat their dosas every day and never get tired of them.  So many yummy fillings and variations.  A plain "side" dosa is a great substitute for the Naan I can't have with my Indian food because of the wheat flour.  The regular and paper dosas are gluten-free, look out for the wheat ones.  The cook them all on the same surface, but wash it in between - your call if you're willing to take the cross-contamination risk.

Yummy yummy yummy Rasmalai for dessert - everyone else at my table thought it was the most bizarre dessert they'd ever tasted, and I guess for American palates it is kind of odd.  But until you have experienced the joy of fluffy paneer cheese balls swimming in sweet creamy rosewater-flavored condensed milk and dusted with pistachios, you don't know what you are missing.

Oh, and it's gorgeous - hip, relaxed, elegant, and fun.  Love it.
author: Todd B.

description: Very elegant, clean and friendly place. The food is very good and tasty. It's a little bit prizie.
author: Conrado A.

description:
I've had a couple snacks here before, and the food is great, but it's the cocktails that keep me coming back.  The signature cocktail list is full of winners, and their gin revival menu is an exciting contrast to that spicy list.

Dosa is also one of, if not the best designed bar/restaurant space in San Francisco.  The lighting is incredible, both in the effect it has on the room and the design of the fixtures themselves.  The art is both bold and tasteful, each adding a bit of intrigue to the atmosphere, and the furnishings are stylish without being audacious.  

My only complaint is that the some of the staff seem a little full of themselves.  For example, our bartender Sunday tried to tell my date that he wouldn't make substitutions or alterations to anything on the cocktail list.  Not sure what he thinks his job is, but he's in a service industry, and when a customer orders a drink, he could rightfully try to warn her that the drink may not be as pleasing when made as requested, but in the end, you make the drink that's being ordered. I've been there.  It's part of the job.
author: Quinn S.

description: The food was exceptional, delicious and overall extremely yummy. However, the service was awful. My friend arrived earlier to an empty restaurant, as I was running late and was greeted by the host. The host told her to wait for the rest of your party as the restaurant was "full". Okay. Interesting. Then our waitress was in somewhat of  a rush or maybe just in an awful mood because she was so eager to take our drink order that we couldn't even ask question? I am not a big tequila drinker but I ordered the "Khalessi" drink as part of their HH and I asked if I could substitute the tequila with vodka instead. The waitress rudely and arrogantly replied that "all of our drinks are pre-made with a specific liquor for a better flavor quality"...Okay. Weird, but whatever. When I  made the reservation, I left a note to the restaurant to sing happy birthday to my friend. When I requested it from another waiter (so my friend didn't know), the waiter responded that he didn't know where our table was or who my friend is. Talk about excellent customer service. Overall, the food was great. The drinks were nasty and the customer service was very strange. Don't think I'll come back again to this location.
author: Sandra V.

description:
Mother's Day Lunch!

Amazing! The food was excellent.
We had the Mother's tasting menu which had most of the popular items and great to get an overall feel/taste for South Indian food.

App:
Asparagus & Kohlrabi Soup - light and very flavorful. However I think it would have used a little bit more salt.
Chennai Chicken - OMG! Oh yeah its that good. It comes with a slice of fresh lemon and red onion... its better with the squeeze of lemon. This was the WINNER all around!
Samosas "North and South" -  great dish. The North has a major kick... very yummy. The South is crispy, light and loaded with fresh vegs.

Entrees:
Pepper Chicken - good, but I think it would have been better... would't order it again.
Tamil Lamb - very very good. The favors of the masala really brought out the richness of the lamb.... could order seconds!!! 
Channa Bhatura - my parents loved it. I think its a great opion for vegans.

Dosa:
Rava Masala - yummy yummy! this was the winner all around. Everyone loved it. Loaded with spices.
Spicy Mung Masala & Mustard Green - yum... both came in at a tight

Desserts:
Pistachio Dacquolse w/ Chocolate Chille Mosusse - This was my favorite. The mousse had a kick!
Payasam & Carrot Halwa - Overall everyone's favorite
Rasmalai - NO! didn't like it at all. It tasted like it can out of a can or something... not a winner
House-made Geleto - Chai Chocolate - very very yum! This was really good. We would order secounds.

Our party was somewhat large - 14 people. Our waiter and other servers were on point. Answered any questions we had on the menu and anything else.
Our waiter was also very chill... with our little one acting up. And very considerate. 

They changed out sliver wear and whipped down the tables after every course... Job well done. 

Thank you for the wonderful service!
author: Meeta C.

description:
If Dosa were just a bar, this would be a 5 star review. When we arrived for our reservation on a crowded Saturday night we were informed that our table wasn't ready yet and pointed towards the bar. Perusing the cocktail list I noted several gin drinks that sounded interesting so I asked the first bartender whose attention I could get to make me his favorite one. I ended up with the Peony ($10) which featured hibiscus masala nectar, coconut milk, kafir lime leaf and birds eye chili. It was the best drink I have had all year. More complex and delicious than even that celery tasting thing I love at Alembic.  I hope that if I pop in on a Wednesday afternoon before a movie at the Kabuki or something that there will actually be space to sit at the bar. 

So impressed with my five star cocktail, I was very disappointed with the food once we were actually seated. Were I only reviewing the food, I would give two stars. Please do keep in mind, when reading any of my Indian food reviews, that I spent four years exiled in Vancouver and I have yet to find any Indian food in San Francisco that compares. Places I used to love now seem terribly bland. 

Anyhow, we ordered the Dahi Vada (lentil dumplings) to start. They were kind of bland, drenched in way more sauce than necessary (hey, why are you wasting that good Strauss yogurt?) basically unremarkable. 

Not feeling terrible enticed by any of the vegetarian entrees we each ordered a dosa. While the dosa fillings were fine, I'm used to dosas being served like crepes with lots of crispy edges to dip into delicious chutneys. Dosa's dosas were served like burritos, soggy from their fillings. The sambar that came with was ok; the chutneys were again, very bland. We finished with an onion rava dosa which I was curious to try. Unfortunately the onions weren't caramelized as described and the raw bite of them overwhelmed the dish. 

Service was excellent, and again, five star drinks.
author: Jenn W.

description:
Neat and delicious!  I haven't had such good Indian food in a long time - then again, I always limit myself to those interesting buffet places, cheapskate me!  The modern feel to it is a bit disconcerting and all that house music, though plain awesome woomp woomp, may not convey that feel of authenticity you may want from what is branded as a traditional southern India spot. But, not bad. 

Definitely try all the dosas and uttapams, protect yourself with some good ole lassi drink, and finish off with something different like the payasam with halwa.
author: Paolo D.

description: Consistently good food and helpful staff. The staff always tries to find you a seat, whether at the bar or a table. The food is not traditional Indian food (so don't go here if you want your usual). But, the food is well done and in my opinion, delicious. I've gone to Dosa twice and left happy both times.
author: Amy L.

description:
With the beautiful chandeliers, high ceilings and ambient lighting, Dosa is the setting for a perfect date night.  I was there with a girlfriend tonight for dinner and it was still a great experience.

We shared two apps and an entree:
~ Chennai Chicken: since so many people on Yelp recommended it, we had to try it.  OMG...the chicken was sooo tender and seasoned wonderfully
~ Potato Pea Croquette & South Indian Samosa: lovely flavors but sooo dinky!
~ South Indian Moons: chef's selection of 5 Uttapams.  We had Caramelized Onion - my favorite...so delicious!, Spring - I only noticed the carrots in it but it was super yummy, Masala Tomato & Onion, Chile & Cilantro...from the description but it tasted the most bland of them all.  It was fun trying the different Uttapams and pairing them with the three different dipping sauces.  However, I found that they tasted best as is.

Although the portions are very small at Dosa compared to other Indian restaurants, it's actually great for those on a diet and need help with portion control.  Both my friend and I were stuffed from the food we ordered and really enjoyed our meal.  Usually Indian food is light on the wallet but not the stomach...well, it's definitely reversed at Dosa, lol.
author: Katelynn L.

description:
I've been here for dinner and for weekend brunch. The food is excellent and the interior is beautiful. 

The vibe is livelier for dinner than for brunch. If you're looking for a quiet brunch, this is a good spot for you. I'm a fan of eggs for brunch, and this is not your typical eggs and bacon place! Their brunch dishes seemed a nice creative fusion.

As a dinner spot, I love the vibe and the food. 

If you are in the mood for Indian food -- definitely go!
author: Susan W.

description:
Do you want to die? If not then you should. This makes total sense if you are going to Dosa for crazy south Indian food. Wow this place is satisfying. Like ridiculously satisfying. Organic and sustainable foods and an insanely bad ass seasonal tasting menu here, with four people, you can sample the entire thing to you hearts content. But we went à la carte and ordered Hyderabadi Shammi Kebabs (Minced lamb, cardamom, peppercorns, ginger, fennel & lentils, pan fried with mint raita), Hyderabadi Chicken Biryani (Bone-in, natural, basmati rice with an aromatic spiced sauce, caramelized onions, cashews, peas), Duck Vindaloo (Spicy, Goan curry, red chiles, malt vinegar, ginger, cumin, mini potatoes, curry leaves (great with coconut rice)), 2 orders of the South Indian Moons (Chef's selection of five different uttapams), a side of Raita, and some green mango Acharr. And then we died. And then the food came. It was delicious. Dunking the uttapams in sambar was the best part; they are a bit thicker ans smaller than dosa and hold the stew well. Super delicious. The biryani was spicy. Very spicy. And very delicious. Bone in chicken kind can be a hassle but it tastes better so it's a worthy trade-off. The mango acharr was nice and tart, I polished it off little by little with each bite of everything. I do wish we would have ordered more lamb kebabs to start, those were really good, and the plates were smaller than expected.

I also got this weird drink called the South Indian Monsoon. Ginger and mint with pomegranate and mango juice + soda and citrus. It killed me.

Ambiance is sick. If you can get a table next to the rail on the second floor do it. It's an amazing view of the busy bar and 1st level. A beautiful chandelier hangs from above. The interior is very warm and they did a good job of using color, it really pairs well with the cuisine. Goes to show how amazing food plus great design can really complete a dining experience. 

Overall, I left stuffed to the point of dying. Seriously, I haven't been that full in a really long time. Great experience.

Parking can be a bit of a hassle but you'll figure it out. Dosa is also close to Japan Town so that is an added bonus if you're in SF.

also I want to know who made the rule that we have to capitalize the first letter of every sentence. it's a dumb rule. i'm not doing it anymore.
author: Amik A.

description:
5 stars for the habanero dosa.   

If you fight w/ the server a bit they will make it seriously spicy.   Real habaneros.  Lots of them.  One of the few non-chili dishes that can use habeneros and yet are actually  tasty.

Interior was cool.

I can't vouch for the rest of the menu.  I have a couple of  friends that don't like this location.
author: D E.

description:
I LOVE South Indian food.  Even in Chicago, it's hard to find one that does it justice, so I was really looking forward to trying Dosa in SF.  

We tried the Bhel Puri and the Samosa as an appetizer. The portions here on both were on the smaller size, especially for the samosas.  For dosas, we tried were the peas and paneer and the roasted garlic and onion.  The peas and paneer was excellent, the roasted garlic and onion which was very good, but wasn't really very spicy.  In fact, both could use a bit more heat, or at least the option of adding more for those that aren't as spice adverse.  The dishes we tried where the lamb kofta and as well as a chicken dish (unfortunately, I can't remember which one).  I can't say it everything was as authentic as I had hoped, but they did a great job with the dosas and the accompanying chutneys and sambar.  

I wanted to give Dosa five stars, but the lack of spice in some of the dishes really left me wanting more.  You can get more consistently authentic food  for less elsewhere, but overall the service, ambiance and drinks really made for a great dining experience.
author: Raana A.

description: The most unique Indian food ever! Great to introduce to your friends who think Indian food is just curry and nan. Spicy Basil is my favorite and paper dosa is kind of fun too! Totally recommend to bring your significant others for anniversary and even parents for family dinner.
author: Hyejin K.

description:
Delicioso. Wait a second, that's kind of Spanish. This place is Indian, make no mistake. And it's well worth a visit.

Cool atmosphere and good service. Looks like they had a full bar, too, but I just drank water and tea.

My buddy took me here for dinner after an afternoon of street photography and we were tired (good tired) and hungry. My friend was treating, confirmed if I'd be down for anything, and asked the waiter to "surprise us" (in a good way, of course).

We were surprised, in a great way, and had some lamb chops that were divine. Never had that at an Indian food restaurant, but they were the bomb.

Everything was good. Sorry, I don't remember the names of everything. But we ended up with surf, turf, and veggies. Washed it down with a couple of mugs of hot chai tea and I was a happy camper.
author: Greg J.

description: Mmmm. I love this place. I hadn't been here in a while, and coming back made me wonder why. Great food, great service, great ambience. We got the chutney sampler, which was a LOT of chutney, and found ourselves going back to it between bites of our entrées... it really made the meal. The dosas are good too, but I'll be back here for the chutney.
author: Safeer J.

description:
My review is both a praise and apology. Last night a group of us came
in to celebrate it being the end of the week (as you should!), and had
a great sampling of what Dosa has to offer - dosas, curries, wine, &
of course, cocktails! Our server Zach was really knowledgeable about
what dishes went well together, what to start with, and recommended a great bottle of wine(so good, we ordered three!).

We were having a good time until one of my friends, in her not-so-glorious drunken stupor, happened to reach across and grab our
server's ass as he was helping another table nearby. We all
immediately berated her, mortified that she pulled that off during a
busy dinner time. Zach totally took it in stride and continued to show
a classy attitude, and even joked with us for the rest of teh evening.
So for that, we thank you and are very sorry about our friend's
behavior. It was out of line, but definitely hilarious. We'll be back
for more great food, cocktails, & hopefully less ass-grabbing:)

5 stars!
author: Jenz y.

description: Must visit @ SF! great food... Ambience... Service....Pricy but worth it! Sambar Idly - best in the bay area.
author: VP M.

description:
I'll start with the caveat that I'm no big fan of Indian food. Don't dismiss me right away; I'm pretty much a fan of any cuisine in the book, but I just can't get myself to love Indian. With that said, I was pleasantly surprised with the quality and price at Dosa.

Let's start with the fact that reservations mean practically nothing at this place, which you kind of expect since it's ridiculously trendy. But c'mon, we had a table for 8 well in advance, and it takes you 30+ minutes to seat us? This wouldn't be so bad if there were ample waiting area at the bar, but walk-ins+reservation waiters jam overstuff this area. It didn't help that my vodka on the rocks cost $12-ish for what seemed like less than a shot. Dosa's got a nice mixed drinks menu, but I'll pass, thanks.

However, once we sat, everything was gravy. We had post-dinner reservations elsewhere, and conveyed that message to our waitress, who was happy to oblige. Service was prompt, and the view from the second floor was incredible. Their dosas aren't too expensive given the large portion size; I went with the rava masala. The same can't be said for their appetizers, which are really a two person max and were decent at best. The other main courses around there table were delicious as well; I particularly favored the lamb curry.

All in all, I'm docking a star for the start of the meal (pricey drinks and a prolonged wait), but strongly recommend this place if you're looking for trendy, delicious Indian food.
author: Jeffrey C.

description: I appreciate the vast and varied menu and the waiters' willingness to help you through it. We tried something from nearly all of their categories, as it was hard to settle for one. The food itself was okay. I was expecting a bit more, both in terms of flavor and quantity. It was an enjoyable dinner, bit not one that I'll be rushing to repeat.
author: Brett B.

description: Great service and love this spice! Just a little pricey for lunch...$20 at least per person. Great, hip ambiance. Extensive selection of GLUTEN-FREE entrees!!
author: B B.

description: The very best Southern Indian dining experience in SFO. Excellent service. The 3 course summer sampler is indescribable...exotic...rich...stunning. If you love curry, chile, range fed, and all organic, look no further. Many beers and wines, and exotic mixed drinks. This is mostly a locals and business travelers place to meet and indulge...excellent choice after a long day in the most beautiful city in the world!
author: Ed H.

description: Nice twist on traditional South Indian food. The food is surprisingly spicy considering the clientele. One of the best in the area. Will definitely eat there every time I visit San Francisco!
author: Rami S.

description:
THE BEST INDIAN FOOD I'VE EVER HAD.

Highly recommended. They specialize in Southern Indian cuisine. Having never tried it, I was pleasantly surprised with all the dishes I tried (spring vegetable curry, dosa, coconut rice).

The service was amazing as well!
author: Annie L.

description:
im a big fan of Dosa on Fillmore, much more so that on Valencia...the venue is cleaner...youre not packed in tight like a can of sardines...oh, and theres enough light so you can actually see your food...

like just about every time i go out for drinks at a restaurant...i end up eating...ALOT at that...

grabbed a glass of jameson and soda and took a look at the menu...id been to the Dosa on Valencia a few years back and all i remember was that i wasnt too fond of it although i love indian food in general...

we ended up ordering a handful of things...

couple curries, couple dosa crepes, some calamari, a chicken dish and a tomato and onion Uttapam...

the Dosa Crepe's are what Dosa is known for...large (XL) crepes come served up to your table...rip into it, dip it in curry, wrap up whatever meats they bring out to you...a very simple and easy food to enjoy...indian food to me has always been about big, bold, and spicy...the cooks at Dosa keep their food on par with those flavors...

staff is very friendly and accommodating...all around service is pretty good...if youre sitting at a table and dont mind walking to the bar to grab a drink, id definitely recommend to do so...several times we ordered drinks from our server and it took a lot longer than it should have...luckily, i was too busy gorging on curry to let it bother me...

great experience...will definitely be back for a curry and crepe fix sooner than later!
author: Kyu L.

description:
We really enjoyed our dinner here, although the portions seemed a tad small.  I feel like its better than Udupi palace. 

 There were four of us, and we ordered the crispy fish pakora, seasonal vegetable curry, a masala chutney  dosa as well as the south indian moons uttapam. 
 Fish pakora reminded me of fish sticks.  It was just ok.  The dosa didn't seem to have much filling at all. The flavors in the dosa were excellent though, I just wish there had been more filling.  My experience at Udupi Palace, the dosa was PACKED with filling making it a meal for two.  The south indian moons uttapam was disapointing in my opinion.  The uttapams were very small, although I should have expected this.  I enjoyed them but I would probably avoid sharing this dish on my next visit. 
 My dinner companions had a hard time with the heat of all the dishes we ordered.  They also felt there should have been more cooling sauces to calm the heat.  Honestly, that didn't bother me, but I like heat.

For dessert we ordered the chocolate cake and the passion fruit custard.  I was quite surprised here, the chocolate cake had so many different flavors it was out of control.  I felt like the pastry chef just couldn't decide what direction he wanted the dessert to take.  This was surprising to me.  I NEVER say things like this about chocolate.  I mean, I will DRINK chocolate if I can I love chocolate so much.  This dish really hit below the mark for me.  The passion fruit custard was out of this world though, I mean really really great!  This dish is definitely a keeper.
 
Primarily we were impressed with the service that we received.  This was a Saturday night, and they were ridiculously busy.  Even though this was the case, we never had empty water glasses, and we did not feel like they hovered over us either.  The watress was knowledgeable, and had that ability to manage multiple things but still see in the corner of her eye if we needed something.  In general the entire wait staff at Dosa on Fillmore is stellar from my experience.  
  The only real drawback to the evening is that we didn't stick around and have drinks after dinner in the bar.
author: jessica b.

description: Eh. That was my impression after leaving Dosa. I love (and I mean LOVE) Indian food - add to that a cool, modern environment and you have a great thing. However, the food was just ok - nothing truly memorable. I've had better (actually much better) and even ordering something "medium" hot was almost too hot for me. I was there with three others and we all kind of felt the same about this place. I would try it again, but maybe order something different?????
author: Shannon H.

description:
What a great dinner! Reservations were made without any problems. Karla K. and I arrived for dinner around 6:40 (yes, I felt like a senior citizen) because we were headed to a show at The Fillmore. I can just say that service is impeccable and completely professional. Food presentation is divine; I don't know if it's the lighting, the decor, or a combination of all put together.

Four-course tasting menu:
Prawn Chile Fry -- incredibly spiced, but not at all spicy. Splash some lemon on them and they come alive as if they were still swimming in the great big Ocean (or wherever they came from).
Cilantro-Mint Masala -- This is one of those dishes you wish were bigger and easy so you could make it every day at home. The 3 dipping sauces (or chutneys) were perfectly paired with the herby flavors of the masala. The coconut ended up being my favorite, sambar (lentil + vegetables) second, and tomato chutney third.
Chicken and Eggplant with a side of lemon rice -- There's nothing bad I can say about the chicken and eggplant. I only had 1 slice of eggplant so it would have been nice to have more. The lemon rice on the other hand ... I'D KILL FOR THAT RECIPE. The most flavorful rice I've ever had. Ever.
For Dessert: Gulab Jamoon. I'm sorry Gulab, but you disappointed me. I took a risk ordering something I wasn't familiar with, and failed. It was too mushy, which is a shame because the flavors were pretty good. Sweet and warm syrup with chopped nuts cannot compensate for a mushy Gulab (think: doughnut hole).
author: Alyssa G.

description:
Vada Pav - a must have!!

We have been here for both dinner and lunch and prefer the dinner ambiance. The food is great, but the place does have a long wait for dinner. I'd recommend making a reservation for dinner. Its pricey for the small portions!
author: S N.

description: I do love this place. They have a smart bar and food hat is creative and appealing and consistantly good. Its one of my top 10!
author: Andrea C.

description:
I was looking forward to an amazing dining experience so i was pretty underwhelmed. The food was just OK. Everything was good, nothing stood out as great, which is what I expected considering the price. We had the chennai chicken, lamb kofta, prawns massala and one of the dosas. I can't say it lived up to the rave reviews. By the end of the night my group was wondering if the $10 indian buffet next door would have been the better choice...
Aside from the food, the decor is chic and trendy. The drinks are strong. It's a great spot if you are looking for a fun, sexy bar atmosphere. If you want quality food, I'd skip it. You can get better Indian food for a fraction of the price at your local hole in the wall.
author: Bianca J.

description:
A girlfriend and I had a friend in town, and she recommended we check out Dosa. We arrived to find out that we had about a 40 minute wait-- no problem, though, because we could have a drink at the bar. They each got a mango lassi (which I tried-- so refreshing and flavorful!), and I ordered my favorite Indian beer, Flying Horse. We took in the scene: huge, bright windows and trendy, new decor. Very chic.

25 minutes later, the nice hostess stopped by and asked if we'd be willing to sit at the shared table, which was a long, tall table next to the bar. It meant we wouldn't have to wait any longer. Sure! We were seating alongside two other dining parties, but not crammed in at all. 

The waitress was helpful, suggested a few items off the menu, and promptly took our order. My friends got the Spring Dosa, and I tried the Spicy Mung Masala. I love spice in general and I loved this Spicy Mung Masala! (On a second trip to Dosa, I got the South Indian Moons, which was a chef's selection of five different Uttapams-- I recommend that if you like to sample. A little pricier at $13.50, but worth it for the variety.) 

For the elegance of the restaurant and the fun of the food's presentation, I was surprised by how affordable Dosa is, at around $10 per plate. Ingredients seemed very fresh, and each dosa is served with several chutneys to flavor your dosa choice and cool off your mouth (if you happen to find something too spicy). 

I returned here with my boyfriend for a date night, before heading over to the Kabuki theater for a movie afterwards. Great place to relax, with plenty of seating (they have an upstairs, too). During the week we had no wait. Be sure to ask lots of questions if you don't know what to order, the waitstaff in general is very well-informed. 

I only wish I lived walking distance from Dosa. Can't wait to go back!
author: Lauren M.

description:
Dosa has an excellent atmosphere.  We could have sat at their communal table right away but decided to wait 30-45 minutes for our own table.  I guess this is nice that that offer this but we wanted more of a private setting.  If you are going on a weekend you might want to make a reservation.

Our waiter was very attentive and offered some suggestions and explained some of the entrees.  

My husband and I split  2 appetizers, a Dosa, and an entree.  The Dosa and entree were amazing.  I would probably just stick to one or no appetizers next time for 2 people.  I would not order the lentil dumplings appetizer again.  They come cold and covered by a bunch of sauces.   Not exactly what I was expecting.  

Overall, I will definitely be coming back to Dosa for great atmosphere, good service, and excellent food.
author: Erica H.

description:
We were craving indian food and was just going to go to one of the hole in the walls, but spontaneously decided to go here.  We walked in, had no reservation, but the wait was only 20 minutes.

We aren't too familiar with indian cuisine, but know a little.  We ordered:
Samusa and calamari for appetizer - both were delicious with the sauce.

We opted to share small plates so we ordered the fry bread (inflated like a UFO!!), another type of bread with potatoes inside, lemon rice, and a chicken plate.  OMG!!!  we couldn't say "yyyuuuummm" enough.   People may have thought we were having an orgasm - it was that great!!!  Try all of the dipping sauces that comes with the dish - soo delicious.

You can tell when an Indian restaurant is really good... There were MANY Indians there with their families. 

I don't think you can go wrong with any of the dishes here.
author: R M.

description:
Absolutely loved this place! 

I recommend making reservations for this place. 3 Hours into the evening and there was still a 1 hour wait for a table. We ate at the bar which got really packed around 8pm onwards. 

I'm surprised at what a good job they did with a south indian menu. The food tasted authentic for the place being so contemporary. Very delicious Dosas. I first ordered the Roasted garlic and chile dosa which i found to be extremely HOT! My mouth and tongue were on fire, so then i ordered the mysore masala dosa and it was very good. The Roasted Garlic and Chile is a good choice if you can handle the spice. 

Drinks are pricey but good selection of drinks. The bartenders were very helpful in helping us select good shots. We had a shot called the batsman. I TOTALLY recommend it if you want to do shots. I've never had something like this before. It's gin, vodka and ginger beer. It goes down smooth. I also had the lime soda which is on the non-alcoholic but asked for it to be a vodka lime soda and it tasted very refreshing. 

Good Service! 

Look forward to going back again.
author: Ms C C.

description: Dosa on Fillmore is definitely not your typical Dosa place because of the chic atmosphere but the food surprisingly tasted authentic even their chai. We tried the paneer dosa and lamb kofta, which were delicious. I really enjoyed the fast service.
author: Naveen K.

description:
I was looking for a restaurant that we could take an out-of-town friend for his birthday. He's vegetarian and loves Indian food so I immediately thought of Dosa Fillmore. 

I loved the upscale schwanky decor and the sexy sensual vibe to the restaurant.  And the staff was very attentive and pampering. And the cocktails are decadent. . . 

The tricky thing for me is that I am allergic to legumes so I can't eat chickpeas, lentils etc. My server was super helpful in finding out what dishes I could have.  She would go back to the kitchen to ask the chef about the ingredients in the dishes to find out what I could eat.  I really felt taken care of and knew I could trust her to make sure I had the perfect dish.  I ordered the Prawn Masala and the Chicken & Eggplant bharta.  I couldn't just decide on one for me!  YUM YUM!  Unfortunately, I had to abstain on the dosas (chickpea flour) but my fiance and the birthday boy loved their dosas. 

I was so pleased with our meal that I didn't realize that I could completely knocked over by the Chocolate Chile Pie for dessert.  OMG -- dark chocolate kissed with chile.  I didn't want to share!  I wanted it all to myself.  But I was nice and let the birthday boy have a good portion but in my mind, I was scheming on how I can get a piece to myself.  Next time, I'm ordering it just for me.  Best dessert I've had in SF.
author: Freida N.

description: Some of the best indian food I have ever had.  On par with Rasika in DC.  It is what they call a southern indian cuisine.  If you are looking for a typical north indian heavy, creamy, overspiced food, this place is not for you.
author: Alex G.

description: Heard a lot about Dosa, and finally made it there. Wow. Very very nice. Loved everything we had ( I know not what it was...I was fortunate enough to be there with Dosa veterans, so I just got to sit back and eat whatever came across my plate). It was not cheap, but thats totally okay. I'd probably goWTO 4 1/2 or 5 stars but Vic's in Berkeley is just as good, if not better, for way less money. damn reference points.
author: Eric C.

description: This is the best Indian restaurant in San Francisco, particularly if you like Southern Indian cuisine. For a huge space that is sleek and modern, the restaurant still manages to create an intimate ambiance. The servers were attentive and knowledgeable, particularly when it came to sizing portions and drink selections for a large group. There was also a bold and large artisianal cocktail menu, particularly for those larger parties that were looking to get after it a bit on a Saturday night. I recommend their 'ginerade' drink, and any of the chicken and fish of the day dishes paired with the dosa.
author: Culinary C.

description: Best Indian food I have ever had!  All of our dishes were insanely good.  There were 4 of us and we shared 3 small and 4 large dishes.  Each one of them was unique and delicious, exploding with flavor.  I was a little leary when I opened their wine list but what surprise!  I give them an A plus for creating a list that includes a great selection of wines that pair well with Indian food - all at very reasonable prices.  We had two great bottles of wine, an Alsacian Dry Riesling and an Argentinian Malbec, both under $50.  Dosa will definitely be on my list anytime I'm back in SF.
author: Bob G.

description:
Wow, great space, decor, ambiance and service, but this is the worst meal I have had in years - especially in SF.  I'm not a food snob, but I do have an experienced pallet.

So, I ordered the Mung Musala, and here's what I got:  an extremely salty, salt lick dosa - f!@#$#$ horrible.  The salt over-powered EVERYTHING about this dosa, and it was totally unedible.  Additionally, the lental-based soup which attends this dish was extremely spicy and also unedible!  I can handle indian spice, but I'm not Indian so Dosa should know their audience and tame it down a bit to make it edible.  The third indicator was a side of chicken at the recommendation of the bar tender (nice, friendly bartenders by the way and extremely good cocktails; try the Ginger Ante, but don't eat there).  He never indicated it was spicy, and it was so very spicy and also beyond edible.  I was floored by this awful, over spiced, over salted meal on three accounts, and I'm bummed I even went there.  I came home and had to eat a bowl of cereal to get some food in my system. 

Thus, be extremely leary about what you order at Dosa, or better yet, go for drinks only, then eat somewhere else.
author: Chris C.

description:
We had fantastic food and service. Spicy lamb kebabs, trumpet mushroom uttapam, and broccoli dosa were all particularly out of this world.  Our waitress was attentive, informative, friendly and fun. The servers always let us know what was coming next and would inform us when our next course was about to arrive.

The drinks also tasted delicious though the drinks were rather tiny in volume while overly large in price.
author: Kirbologix J.

description:
nice stratosphere. Tried plain Dosa first time! love the yogurt dressing. Chennai Chicken appetizer is very tasty. 

It's super awsome that they open till 12am.  I went there late night after the Dita Show at fillmore! Will be back to try more
author: Vicky F.

description:
My best friend took me here and I'm so glad she did.

Their entire menu looks delicious, everything we had tasted great.

For me the best part were the cocktails. Being a flower lover I ordered the Peony. This is now my new favorite drink, I've already hunted down the recipe. The color is a perfect peony pink. It's a little creamy from the sweetened coconut milk, and it has the perfect touch of spice and lime.

Oh yeah - the service was great, and the ambiance is delightful. Good lighting.
author: Sophia v.

description:
**very gluten-free friendly**

This place was awesome.  The food was good, the drinks were tasty, the ambiance is nice, *and* they had an allergy list on their website that I was able to print out and take with me to determine what I could have to eat.  That was probly the best thing about the whole experience.  *Thank you* for thinking of those of us with food allergies!  

I had the Spring dosa, which was delicious.  Pricey place to eat, but very worth it!
author: Missy W.

description:
The food they come up with feels appropriately unique and delicious for the price, I liked it a lot.  They say it's spicy, but only for upper Fillmore clientele - I wouldn't consider it that spicy.

The wait staff has been pleasant to deal with both times I have gone, but a little bit inattentive.  I don't know whether they were understaffed or not, but they could have checked up on us a little more.

The drinks are meh - pass on them.  I'd highly recommend the Idly Fries.
author: Andrew K.

description:
3.5 stars today.
I wasn't so enthralled with Dosa's on a 2nd visit.  We celebrated Jr. Yelper's birthday here and JY #1 enjoyed the prawn masala (5 pieces) which was what I tried before but JY didn't like the coconut rice.  Hubby had the duck and spinach with basmati rice & enjoyed it.  I ordered the spicy chicken and eggplant and thought it was OK.  JY #2 re-ordered the lamp chops ($28) but thought it was too spicy this time.
