The 2 piece samosas were delicious (1 of each type) and we shared 2 Dosas ($11 each).  The paper dosa (a huge thin, crispy edged crepe rolled into a tube) served with a bowl of delish seasoned mashed potato with an intermittent cashew here and there was good.  3 sauces came with it but I liked the coconut scented one the best.   The rava was a flatbread shaped crepe with garlic/onion mixed into the batter.  It was good and hubby liked it better than the paper dosa.  Their broken pieces of papadum are very good, served comp.  I enjoyed my mango lassi ($4.50).  We skipped dessert and took the leftovers home which were even better the 2nd day!  

The decor is lovely as usual and service was pleasant (over $4 for health tax).   Mostly all adults were dining there this time altho' I've seen families before.   The price can be costly for a meal ($140 for us) considering we didn't have alcohol.  After we left, we passed a hole in the wall Indian cuisine restaurant just down the street, $9.99 for all you can eat.  Hummmmmmm.
author: Ry T.

description: Went to Dosa after two years yesterday. The service was very poor. We had a 30 minute wait between our appetizers and the main course. The server offered no explanation even though we asked her a couple times about the food. She should have comped one of the entrees. I'm sad to say I'm not going back . I'd rather spend $100 some where else.
author: Purva G.

description: Nice atmosphere and decent portions. Service was good. A bit over priced.  Particularly the non-alcoholic drinks were a bit steep in price.
author: Ghengis G.

description:
Dear Mr. Prawn "Frankie,"

You completely rocked my world yesterday at lunch. Forget DAT, I just needed you and all your deliciousness for $13.

I would best describe you as a skinny, long, Indian burrito. You ooze with delicious curry-ness with your potatoes, prawns, onions, and whatever else is going on inside that fluffy, yummy, dosa-like outside. 

You are so filling...that you forced me into a 2 hour nap post devourment. 

Yum.
author: Misha F.

description:
We came here after catching a movie over at Kabuki.  I can't believe it but I think this was the first time I've tried Southern Indian food.  

We started with the Samosas and Spicy Sweet Scallop.  The samosas came two to a plate and were good but nothing special.  The scallops were delicious!  There were 3 of us and 3 scallops, perfect.  

I ordered the Spinach & Fennel Pooriyal Dosa and it came in 3 rolled of crepes with lentil soup and two dipping sauces.  The waitress encouraged me to use my fingers which I eventually did.

My BF ordered the Paneer & Peas Uttapam.  We thought he was getting a pancake like base with stuff topped over it but actually the description was incorrect.  The paneer and peas were cooked into the batter so it came out in one flat pancake with the same dipping sauces I got.  

My friend got the South Indian Lamb Kofta which he thought was excellent.  I didn't try it but it looked really good.  We ended our meal and shared the Passion Fruit Custard with Coconut Tapioca.  That was super good.  The passion fruit custard was at the bottom and it was topped with the tapioca.  There was enough for 2 guys and a girl to share but I only took a couple of bites after polishing off my plate of food.
author: Rosalind S.

description:
I've been to Dosa about a half dozen times and feel that I'm finally ready for a review.

This is one of those instances where I wish I could give three and a half stars, but I'll just err on the side of four.

The place is gorgeous. It's big, moody and has a nice bar area with solid beers. The bartenders are cool.

Wait staff is hit or miss. Sometimes they are fun and easy and other times they are stuck up and have this look like they're snickering at you. Mostly they are nice.

I don't eat meat, and I think the veggie and fish options are solid. The Scallop app is really tasty and while their samosas are only ok, the tamarind sauce is insane--sweet and tart.

I haven't had a bad dosa there yet, though the curries can be hit or miss.

Is it overpriced? Yeah, mostly. Is it tasty and fresh and fun? Yeah, mostly.
author: Paul C.

description: Tasty food. Nice ambience.... Not a kid friendly place as its very silent. But food and service is really good. Go here if you like spicy food. They can tune the spice level for you.
author: Senthil A.

description:
The only thing authentically Indian about this place are the people in the pictures hanging on the wall.  

Go to Dar Bar on Polk or Little Delhi on Eddy if you want authentic.

As for pricing, we spent $300 for 4 of us.  $12 dollar drinks add up and $25 - $30 dollars for an entree of Indian food is fn absurd.
author: Naveen S.

description:
I love the atmosphere and the interior design is gorgeous. The wait staff is attentive and personable. Although the seating layout is very compact, the low lighting allows intimacy within your table.
 
We ordered:
Samosas "North & South" - Comes with one northern style samosa, one southern samosa, small side of greens and dipping sauces. Both were delicious. The exterior was crispy while the inside was savory and flavorful enough that the sauces can be omitted. The greens were freshing to the fried pasty shell surrounding the samosas.

Sada Paper - A thin dosa with out the filling. The menu says large but I never expected it to be quite that large. The dosa was about 2 feet long. It comes with 2 dipping sauces and 1 dipping soup (sambar). Not only is the dosa delectable, but it is also a great icebreaker. Definitely a smile maker.  

Mango Shrimp Curry -  We order this with a side of coconut rice which was a perfect pairing. Delicious and savory yet with a slight sweetness from the mango which also brought out the flavoring of the rice. 

I am a fan! Warning though. Many items are spicy so if you're like me and have no tolerance for spicy foods, just equip yourself with a Yummy Mango Lassi like I did.
author: Jess H.

description:
Have been wanting to try Dosa for a while now and had dinner here a couple days ago. 

Ordered:
-chennai chicken 
-mango prawns w/dahi basmati rice
-paper masala dosa
-one scoop toffee-sesame seed sorbet
-one scoop dark chocolate-chai sorbet
-isabel (drink)
-wry rajah (drink)

The chennai chicken was so good! a little spicy but def would order that again. same story for the paper masala dosa. It is HUGE when it gets to the table but its thin and light. The chutneys and sauces were all really good. some hot some cold.

The mango prawns were okay. Nothing exciting. I do NOT recommend the dahi rice. I had never had it before. I didn't know what to expect. So this is my complaint: it is yogurt and rice and it just freaks me out. its sweet and wet and gross. ew. It did nothing for the meal. Since I ordered a dosa anyway, i don't know that i even needed rice at all. 

drinks were so-so. the wry rajah is spicy. the isabel is strong. it also comes in those stupid glasses. i dont know the name. theyre  short and bowl shaped. a lot of handshaken-type drinks are served in these glasses. like gimlets. i hate those glasses. the drink was mehhakjld.

youll have to ask for the gelato and sorbet flavors. i think they're seasonal. they're really good. there's no sesame seeds in the toffee-sesame but it tastes just like a sesame ball.
im big on desserts. but nothing else appealed to me.

cute decor. sat on the upper level. there were a couple families. a few groups (birthdays i think). mostly couples. its a good date place if you share food. 

great service!
author: Tessa P.

description:
The food here is beyond AMAZING!   

The decor is elegant and modern.  The wait staff are friendly and quick to serve.  My recommendation: order a dosa.  I've also had the lamb meatballs, eggplant chicken, coconut rice, and a fried ball made of flour and sesame seeds.  Of all the things on the menu, I enjoyed the dosa the most.


The only down side of Dosa is the wait.  Rush hour (dinner) waits can range anywhere from 30 minutes to 2 hours!  Also be aware that the time they quote you is usually off by 15-20 minutes.  Just tack that on so you know what to expect.
author: Christine K.

description: Food was ok, I remember it being better. Service was strangely slow, with many mistakes. We had to haunt down drinks and menus more than once. Gluten free menu had nothing from the daily menu. Server just said they need to update the gluten free menu...
author: ozdema b.

description:
Service was excellent, as well as the food. Everyone has gushed about both as well. I liked my mango lassi (thick, creamy, and leading me to believe all other mango lassis are needlessly diluted with water), and the cool lighting fixtures in the restaurant.

The only new thing I have to add is that the hand dryers in the women's room (XLerator) should be replaced by Dyson air blades. That is all.
author: Angie C.

description:
If you are going there, do not go for just Dosa. you will love all dosas there.. and much more. 

They have better things there. 

1.  Appetizers - Sardines
2. Entree - Duck Vindaloo - Coconut rice
3. Dessert - Fresh coconut custard cakes infused with Curry leaves

A no no is 

1. Rasam ( fire broth) :-) no way it can be called Rasam 

Ambiance is very classy.The customer service is 3.5/5. Some of them can be really better. They can be little more friendly.
author: Sree S.

description: As bit pricey, but good.
author: Michael E.

description:
1. Beautiful restaurant
2. Amazingly delicious food
3. Outstanding service
4. Very well priced

I can't say enough good things about dosa. The food is wonderful. I make my own dosas - I know! But even better is that I brought my almost 2 yr old daughter and the staff was so friendly and anticipated things before I requested them. Magically a booster chair showed up in a second, then the waiter brought a plastic cup with cover and a straw. Every staff member passed by with a smile. I like that!
author: O O.

description: Fancy interior. Sub par food quality. And way overpriced. All in all not worth trying out.
author: Abhi M.

description:
I find the original Dosa a bit more personable. I think because of the guy with the spikey hair who remembers everyone even if they haven't been in, in a while. But the atmosphere of the Fillmore Dosa is certainly more fab. High ceilings, big community table...a hip color pallete. It was great for a group dinner.

I came here for a dinner with the girls, and while the food was good, and service attentive I wasn't blown away. Certainly good quality food and a positive dining experience, but most of my girlfriends agreed they weren't feeling it much.

Think I'll stick to the mission location for brunches, which never disappoint.
author: Nikki M.

description:
South Indian food is completely underrated, but utterly delicious cousin to the North Indian/Punjabi food that everyone is used to. This place isn't the most authentic, but it's not trying to be; it doesn't have to. if you just are curious what a dosa tastes like then go to Udupi Palace and pay $7. If you want to go go out on the night and grab a nice drink and eat some wholesome food this is your place. 

I'd recommend Channai Chicken for the appetizer, and Masala Dosa, Rava Dosa, or Paper Dosa for mains.
author: Artur R.

description: Food= 5 stars!!! Amazing amazing amazing. White truffle Dosa is where it's at. The Marsala prawns are incredible as well. Bar = 5 stars!! The bartenders are so knowledgeable, fast, and damn - some of the best drinks I've ever had. The servers= 2 stars. I've been here two weekends in a row and have had the same unfriendly, unwelcoming, and rude service from 2 separate servers. The server we had tonight approached our table, didn't introduce herself, and the very first thing she said was "what can I get for you?" Not a hi, welcome to dosa, do you have any questions... My name is... Nothing. I asked if she could recommend vegetarian options. She said "everything is vegetarian except this and this" as she pointed at the menu.... Um I can read, I know what vegetarian is. I asked her again to recommend something. She quickly lists a few things, obviously irritated. Last weekend, same thing. Our server never introduced herself, didn't review anything on the menu and was very mechanical. When you're serving fine dinning and especially with a genre of food that is a little off the grid.... Help a sista out!! Love the food love the drinks so I think I'll eat at the bar from here forward. They are true professionals
author: Shelly P.

description: Excellent restaurant. The food was delicious, especially if you like it spicy. The service was also good. I would suggest making reservations because it was very busy.
author: Nicholas B.

description:
Dosa is beautiful inside, high ceilings, interesting lights, gold colored metallic cut-out artwork, one particular large photo I  really like with a woman in red bending (in prayer?) on tons of little red and orange flowers. 

The food is pretty good.  I had a Prawn Masala dish, I've had a fish dish of some sort last time, and I've tried a few appetizers.  I tried a cocktail tonight called the "Peony" that I really enjoyed, it comes in a martini glass and is sweet and refreshing and pink, with coconut and ginger in it, among other things.  (I always order things with coconut, any chance I get.)  Oh yeah and I like saying "Peony".  For dessert I shared a passionfruit something with coconut tapioca. .  very good, not overpowering coconut (although I wouldn't have minded). . good for sharing.  My only complaint is that it's kind of annoying to have the tails still on the shrimp when it's in a thick sauce that makes it hard to find the shrimp you've "de-tailed" vs the ones you haven't. . but whatever.

I've only been to this Dosa 3 times but the staff is always polite and helpful with explaining the menu.  This is the first time one of us ordered a dosa instead of rice (I of course choose the coconut rice with my entrees if I can, but there are other kinds) .. and that dosa is REALLY big!  Ha, my mom's face was hilarious as they put the plate in front of her, I swear that dosa was at least as long as my elbow to the end of my hand.  BIG.  

I also had a "Sauvignon Blanc & Semillon" for my dessert drink.  Very nice, sweet of course.  My mom had a mango lassi, I tried it, pretty good, although I've never tried one anywhere I didn't like.  

All in all a little bit pricey for Indian food but the atmosphere is really nice.  I wouldn't mind going for just a drink and an appetizer at the bar sometime.
author: Muriel D.

description: Love, love, love this place! The food, the tasting menu, drinks, ambience, sense of space, customer service (most of the time), acoustics (given the amount of tables in this restaurant, you can still enjoy an intimate dinner with your party), da da da-da da-da.... The only thing I miss is the paneer and peas dosa which was replaced by a paneer and mango dosa -- still delicious but I miss the former. Anyway, they have to keep it fresh so i won't dock them for that. My go-to Indian restaurant when Im craving a southern indian meal with a bit of swank.
author: Claire G.

description:
Random discovery, and so glad we walked in.  Comfortable spacious tables, upstanding service... and the food. I want to go back already and start working through that menu. Both food and cocktail! i had my first ever Dosa, and it was simply delicious.  I love eating with ritual involved.  Now, the cocktail. Peony. We go nuts every weekend trying out cocktails around the city, but this is the first cocktail to really grab my attention here so far. Another please!!!!!!

We WILL be back... and I can tell its going to be many. Thanks Dosa staff!
author: Monica C.

description:
So originally I was gonna go to the one on Valenica, but I heard this location is a bit more mellow. And I was exhausted but still had to go out. Ambiance is great, decor is simply gorgeous. Food amazing esp since I haven't had Indian food in quite some time. Staff, attentive. 

Samosas- I like the North India ones better than the South
Scallops- Perfectly cooked!
Bhatura- puffy and golden
Brazino- I love Brazino, hate the bones

---PEONY drink. Fabulous!!!!

Waitress informed us it was last call for food and drinks. Asked if we needed anything else, we said no, but thought dessert menu was on way...NOPE. A little bummed since I love my desserts.
author: Lola D.

description: Good Indian food with numerous variety of dosa....
author: Nami S.

description: Been to Dosa on Filmore a few times now.  The food is exceptional, even though the prices are a little above price. Ive done both the prefix and normal menu, the prefix is over priced and you get only a small portion. Great ambiance, perfect noise level, and food.
author: Dara S.

description: So good for both food and cocktails. Channa bhatura and masala dosa are solid recommendations.
author: m t.

description: Great south Indian food. The Dosas were a bit spicy but everything else was great! Very very busy on a Saturday night, and service was a bit slow. Our app came out before our drinks. Overall very good though!
author: Krystal M.

description:
This is a solid 4 star for Dosa, leaning toward the non-existent 4.5 mark. I decided to come here for my birthday dinner since I had this on my go-to list for quite some time. Within the past year I have been turned on to South Indian cuisine and make somewhat-freqent trips to Vik's in Berkeley for lunch, so I am quite familiar with what is widely considered to be "good" South Indian food.

Knowing that reservations are not always a given at this location, I was pleasantly surprised to hear that they would be able to accommodate my group of 12 on a Saturday night given just one week advanced notice. 

I started with a fantastic cocktail: The Bollywood Hills - and tried a few sips of other interesting drinks - all of which were unique and tasty. It would be worth it to come here just for cocktails if you are only up for a drink and want to take in the vibrant atmosphere.

It is the atmosphere that sets Dosa apart from any other South Indian restaurant that I have been to in the past. Unlike other establishments of similar cuisine, the decor and vibe of the restaurant is one that would be suitable for bringing out of towners or clients, or great for a girls night out.

The most important aspect of a restaurant is obviously the food - and Dosa does not disappoint. I tried my Vik's staples, the Dahi Vada and a Dosa (I selected a spring dosa) and was please with both the presentation and taste. The Dahi Vada - "Lentil dumplings topped with cool Straus organic yogurt, piped with tamarind & mint, mildly spiced" was beautiful. I don't think it quite lived up to Vik's version of the dish (not as spicy) but it was still enjoyable and worth ordering again. The Spring Dosa (think large filled crepe) - "Masala dosa combined with fresh vegetables including peas, carrots, cabbage & red onion" was different than the normal potato filled version and I felt that it was prepared tastefully - not leaving me feeling heavy or unhealthy. 

Service was attentive and everyone else at the table seemed to enjoy their meal. You don't have to be a hard core ethnic cuisine lover to enjoy this restaurant. There's something on the menu for everyone and I look forward to going back and trying something new!

(note: I did go back just two weeks after my first visit and ordered the Spring Dosa again...but I really will try something new some time...my Vegan friend - plentyof vegan options available - said she couldn't stop thinking about her meal...)
author: Katie S.

description: Love this place! The sliders, the cocktails, and truffle dosas are truly one of a kind. The curries are decent, but slightly overpriced for what you get. The pappadum appetizers pre-dinner are also great and highly addicting. I've already been twice and can't wait to go back again to try some more small plates, the chicken biryani, and the different dosas.
author: Payal A.

description:
Ever go to dinner with a bunch of people and everyone is wondering whether or not to share and then you decide that you are going to all share a bunch of starters and then get your own entrees and share bites of those with each other, only you get your entree and it's so damn good that you don't want anyone else having it and you really don't care about tasting anyone else's because you know you already ordered the best and you shouldn't have to share anyway since it's your birthday and you're also kind of a selfish bitch anyway? 

Yeah, me neither. 

The cocktails here are delicious. I really like the Peony. And the Smoked Cup. So creative, so refreshing. 

We shared a bunch of starters. The mung sprout salad was good - and had quite a kick. We also had some spicy chicken appetizer which was really good. But the star of the course was the spicy sweet scallops. 

But my entree was outstanding. Lamb Kofta. Little lamb meatballs in a spicy cream sauce. The perfect amount of kick. And the lemon rice they recommend compliments it wonderfully. I got a side of uttapam to go with it and wrapped that around small bites of lamb balls and rice. Mmmm. Delicious. When I finally came up for air and realized I couldn't finish the whole thing, I offered small bites to the rest of the table. SMALL bites. 

So go with a bunch of friends. And share a bunch of appetizers. But keep those bitches away from your lamb kofta.
author: Suge K.

description:
Dosa was like the man who was too good to be true.

Comfortable in his skin, without a thing to prove, Dosa delivered amazing ginger cocktails, spinach fennel dosas, garbanzo salad, and some sexy rasmalai. 

While I believe that "authentic" cuisine is just as limiting as essentializing race, I also am not down for "fusion" cuisine that involves sticking a sprig of cilantro on some bland ass food and calling it ethnic. Dosa confidently takes desi food and sometimes adds its own twist but knows when to leave things perfect the way they are. 

Creative, spicy, and swank, Dosa has me crushing.
author: anjou k.

description:
Excellent food, excellent atmosphere, excellent this, excellent that...

However... please take that Beet Box drink off your menu. I ordered it for the Canton, but I didn't taste it at all. I love you Dosa, but girl, this tastes like Vomit.
author: Faffy L.

description: Nice ambience with a good selection of drinks, cocktails. Busy all the time, have been here several times now. The appetizers are good! for the main course I had the chili uthappam! My tolerance for spicyness is pretty good and that was really spicy, Not sure many people can eat that spicy! All the Dosas's are pretty good. Food's pretty expensive here, that's why 4 stars. Otherwise a winner.
author: Ramki K.

description:
My friend and I have been waiting many anxious weeks for our reservation at Dosa tonight.  We both have never been yet and was totally looking forward to it, especially with such the hype and good reviews.  I'm not really a fan of Indian food to begin with, but I was very willing to check out Dosa for myself.

The food was actually ok and some dishes were very yummy, but very doughy for the most part (at least what we ordered I guess).  So we got full very quick.

BUT....

Customer service sucked beyond my understanding.  The hostess was friendly and nice though.  But our waiter....omg our waiter.....he was not helpful nor friendly whatsover.  Looked more annoyed than trying to take our order.  He seriously looked and acted like he hated life altogether.  To top it off, while we were literally still eating and sipping on our wines, he drops the bill in the middle of our table.  Never once did he ask if we needed anything else.  Never once did he ask if we wanted to see the dessert menu.  Oh and yea, by the way, we WERE planning on getting dessert, but obviously didn't care to anymore.  Ooook buddy, that goes your tip, like seriously!  

Dosa is a beautiful place and the ambiance is definitely warm and lively.  We were looking forward to a fun and new experience, but instead, ended up walking out greatly disappointed.

I might give Dosa a second chance in the future and if I do, I'll head over to the Valencia location instead.
author: Carmen Y.

description:
i've never had dosa before, here or anywhere else. dosa, where have you been all my life??? 

this particular dosa was delicious, safely gluten free (very little risk of contamination), vegan, filling portions... this was just an awesome dinner. 

the wait staff was really friendly and understanding about all my millions of questions about the food just to make sure it was truly glutenfree.

whatever you order, make sure you get tamarind chutney on the side, because it was delicious.
author: Jennifer A.

description: Amazing! I spent about a month in India eating Southern Indian food and this place does it really well. Loved the selection of entrees, dosas and the flavors. The food was amazing. I need to go again.
author: Karin Z.

description:
Overall as a restaurant I will give it 4 stars.
For the food I'd give it a 3-3.5.

The restaurant itself is beautiful and the service was great. There was also a very unique drink menu which was a plus.

In terms of Indian food, I don't know what it is, but nothing really amazes me. Everything really tastes the same to me. The Dosas were all pretty good and the chicken curry was good, but it was nothing really mind blowing.

I would definitely come back if I was invited and try some more things, but as indian food goes, I'm still not convinced.
author: Thomas D.

description:
WOW. I. love. this. place.

We came here for our Valentine's dinner. We got a very decently priced four-course dinner, tons of leftovers, and lots of time to bask in the restaurant's very chic ambiance (and kind of weird modern pop music). Our food:
- Lotus stem day boat scallops. Perfect.
- Masala dosa. Classic but sooo good, guys. My boyfriend basically drank his sambar, and then mine too.
- Trumpet mushroom uttapam. That note of truffle was perfect. It's a good dish, but I'd want to try something new next time.
- Lamb vindaloo and chicken biryani: The meat in both these dishes was crazy flavorful and tender. Boyfriend did note that the lamb was a tad salty.
- Pistachio d'acquoise. Earthy and decadent, but no contest for the...
- Red velvetine truffle. MY GOD. This is probably a special occasion dessert, so I'm hesitant to let you know what you may be missing. Well -- there was white chocolate mousse, red velvet, chocolate flakes, and a perfect strawberry involved. The boyfriend isn't even really a sweets person and he was flipping out about its deliciousness.

5 stars for food. -1 star, unfortunately, for the service. Granted, it was a busy night, but we waited a very long time between courses, which wasn't the case for the people around us (shout out to our runner, the only person who apologized for the delay). Still... we are more than willing to come back on a slower night and let Dosa redeem itself!
author: Julie D.

description:
I went here last night.  Got there a bit early, so we moseyed on to the bar.  I really wanted to try their specialty cocktails.  I had a young raja, which had a great sweet and spicy kick to it.  Wonderful.  Followed that up with a ginger ante, which had a delightful and complex ginger/rosemary flavor to it.  

For dinner, we shared with the north&south samosas which were excellent.  My entree was the channa bhutara, which was a little too chili-hot to enjoy and pretty ordinary.   It came with vegan poori which was fun to pop and eat.  The portions were large, so our stuffed stomachs skipped dessert.  

Staff was really friendly.  3 stars on the food, but the cocktails made it worth it.  I'll come back and try the dosas next time.
author: Chris W.

description:
I finally got my butt to DOSA on Fillmore - Dine About Town's lunch deal made an easy must try..... 2 courses for $17.95.

The was as good as expected - unique, full of flavor and I loved it.
The ambiance is great too - what a nice place, I kept imagining having a private party in that cool upstairs area. Or sitting at the full bar and sharing something with a friend. 

The chickpea/avocado salad with spicy citrus dressing was good - with a real kick
The fried chicken app - with yogurt sauce and unique slaw was great.
The Paneer DOSA - good
The lamb meatballs with saffron rice - great.

My BF and I loved everything. My tummy did not and doesn't want me to go back there - my mouth however, is arguing that very hard....
author: Jessica L.

description:
I really wanted to like this place, after all the hype around it.  First time for the family for a Mother's Day Brunch.  In one word, DISAPPOINTING.  The server was professional but generally disinterested.  After a slow start, service was good.  The Chennai Chicken is very oily.  Stay away.  The Idli is stale and microwaved.  The Vada is the same.  No crisp on this Vada.  Beet Croquet-Excellent.  Mung Sprouts-Could be good, missing some Zing.  Sambar & Chutney's are awesome.  Paneer Dosa-NoNo, Chicken Frankie-NoNo, Rava Dosa-Good, Cheese Dosa for Kids-NoNo because the server should have warned us about onions in a kids dosa.  Plain Dosa-Good.  

All in all, we left thinking WTF is the hype all about.  Will not be returning.
author: A K.

description: I loved Dosa.  We had the Chenai Chicken, Veggie Curry, and Masala Dosa.  I also tried the Peony cocktail.  All was very yummy.  This was my first southern Indian food and I will be back.  It is a pricey restaurant so not a place I will return weekly, but great for a larger group and they take reservations.
author: Christy L.

description: The Service was horrible. We were made to wait an entire hour even though we had a confirmed reservation. They did not have a table ready for us and made us wait 45 minutes at the bar. When enquired about the table after waiting so long, the waitress blatantly lied saying that since the entire party is not here we cannot seat you. Why was this not informed to us upon arrival or even when making the reservation. The most horrible service you can ever get if you waited for an hour before being seated.
author: Rashmi A.

description:
What is this giant restaurant doing on lower Fillmore...The first time I went here I wondered this and by the third time I'd been here it started to feel slightly more cozy (maybe the cramped seating?). Yes the interior does feel like it's in the wrong city or at least neighborhood but the food and beverages are fantastic.

I've been persuaded to try a Riesling here that was actually well balanced, delicious and not akin to drinking sugar water. The sampler Uttapam plate is delicious lots of great flavors and three different condiments are always a plus. The Dosa's of course are delicious and great for sharing. I've been here numerous times and always had a delicious meal. The service is consistent as well and the price point is reasonable for the area.
author: Kacey H.

description:
This place seemed overly decorated at first and I was hestiant that the food didn't match the showpiece chandeliers and high cielings. The scene definitely had a Vegas-y feel to it and it was a little dim...

Even with my high expectations, I was pleasantly delighted with the extremely flavorful food. It's definitely helpful to know what to order or you feel like your taking a South Indian cultures class.

Nonetheless, these were perfect choices:

1. Chennai Chicken - Tender and moist, Indian style chicken wings with a cool lemony sour creamish dip to balance the spice.

2. Bhel Puri - Refeshing mango crispy salad that was fresh and impactful.

3. Duck Spinach Masala & Paneer w/ tomato rice - Even more tender duck with a dense/creamy spinachy curry with blocks of cheese. Intensely flavored, great in small bites and a must with the tomato rice.

All in all, a unique harmony of spices located right across from the Kabuki and a nice break from sushi.
author: Ash T.

description:
This was my first time having southern Indian food. I really liked it. Dosa is really nice and has cool drinks. We went with a group and just ordered a bunch of things to share. All of them were really tasty.  I can't remember which Dosas we ordered, but they were great. We also had the prawns and lamb meatballs that were great.

The service was really good as well.
author: Jimmy M.

description: This Dosa is larger and more upscale than the one on Valencia. The quality of the meals seems the same--very good. The menu is also varied, with choices for vegetarians and meat-eaters. It's possible, too, go easy on the spices (I've noticed that people who shy away from Indian food seem to think it's all very spicy.) The person who seated our party of four took some time to deliver a kind of mini-lecture on the nature of the cuisine, etc. That seemed a bit odd, but probably it's welcomed by diners unacquainted with Indian food. Overall, the experience was very good--not overly loud, no rushing, hearty fare, etc.
author: Henry S.

description:
This is a really nice Indian restaurant, upscale and clean.  I haven't been to Dosa on Valencia, but I hear it isn't as chic as the Fillmore location.  
You sit in a great open, airy dining room, with a long bar along one wall.  Booths are available, and large "one way" windows look out on Fillmore street.
As for the food, it is delicious, and not overly pricey considering the cool  ambiance.  This is a great go-to brunch spot.
We had the 'South Indian Moons' (a collection of Uttapams, great for sharing), the Dosa Masala (spicy, yum), and Prawn Frankie.  All were excellent and I highly recommend them.
author: Glen G.

description:
I really enjoyed Dosa on Valencia.

But Dosa on Fillmore was a little disappointing.

The mango prawns was good. The only problem is Dosa charged $3 for the first bowl of rice. Usually the first bowl of rice is free. Hello, curry goes with rice. It's like charging extra for butter for bread. Just real TACKY. 

I will probably not recommend any "Dosas"  to anyone. It's just 3 pieces of flat breads with minimal goods and will stuff you full real fast. I'd recommend you to get another large plate or small plates. 

Service was good.

And the Mango Yogurt drink is deelightful. Watch to balance the spicy flavors.
author: Ken C.

description:
This is a unique place. Has quite the atmosphere with super tall ceilings. (I love super tall ceilings).

The food is really good. The scrambled egg was super unique. It was so soft and well cooked. The curd-rice was also impeccable.
author: Prashanth R.

description:
rating? 3.5/5

Well i came here Friday evening for Dine about town and i just wanted to let yelpers know what it is like here. 

Think Osha thai but for Indian food. This ain't your normal northern india meal with Naan and normally curry it is Dosa and there is some curry. 

Food was fresh and good and if you sort of want a hopping scene in the fillmore this place is ok. 

But lets be honest, this place is a factory, my dining experience (not food) just wasn't up to par and i'm probably not going to come back here. Tables are set so close that i heard both conversations to each side and i didn't' even want to have a conversation with my date because if i can hear other's conversations they can hear mine. 

But food and service both fine. Food fresh, service nice and quick and attentive. Feel the restaurant is like a factory and makes me feel as if the restaurant has no soul. I will have to try the mission one because i heard that one is much better.
author: Benjamin L.

description:
Oh, Dosa, we are soooo over!

We had a reservation for 8:30 for 9 people. They didn't seat us until 9:15 cuz our table wasn't ready. They didn't really give us updates on the situation, we had to keep asking, and then at the manager(?) apologized but, no, he didn't comp our drink or offer appetizers since we had waited so long.

The service at the table was slow. I asked for a sampler of their sauces/chutneys for the pappadum. They've given it to us before. The waitress made a face and it took forever to come out. 

So finally after 2 hours of slow service, mediocre food, and waiting the 45 min for the damn table the other manager(?) offered free dessert. By that time half our group was on the verge of missing their movie so they left. Three of us got desserive and the chocolate cherry cake sucked.

PS I think they're racist against all Indian groups.
author: Tuppence D.

description:
Nice atmosphere, great Dosas.  I'm not an expert on Southern Indian cuisine; but what I ate, I LIKED.  Chennai Chicken, Mysore Dosa, and the South Indian Moons a.k.a. chefs choice mini-uttapams, and lime soda.  Lentil soup and chutneys are pretty good but I think Udupi Palace's is slightly better.  I like my soda a little sweeter too.  Still, overall--great food!  Can't wait to return to try more of the menu.  

It's loud, but lively and fun.  It's a "date" type place, so dress to impress as a courtesy to your fellow diners.  Dining room is nice, but Osha Thai on Second Street is even hipper, if you like that kind of thing.  Bar/Lounge at Amber India is nicer too, but I digress.  

Service was competent and professional--no complaints.  Extra points for opening until Midnight on Saturdays, but call ahead for a reservation and allow extra time for parking.
author: Stephen F.

description:
Dosa on Fillmore is doing something absolutely amazing with their cooking. I have often eaten Dosas, cuz it is a wonderful dish. But this restaurant has taken the entree to a new level and finesse, besides adding some very interesting and original ingredients.
 
The decor and atmosphere inside is very classy and refined. As for the owners, Anjan and Emily, they are wonderful folks. The staff too is both polite and very informed on the food. Me and my group noticed that the staff was always very attentive to the customers, in the sense that wine glasses were never left empty and plates were picked up as soon as the meal was completed.

In conclusion, I found Dosa on Fillmore to be a very pleasant dining experience. Great food, very affordable prices, attentive service, classy interior, subdued lighting and an overall excellent dining experience !!!
author: Raj D.

description:
Trivia....

What's plump, doughy, slightly steamy, and full of spice?

If you answered me getting out of a hot shower after mexican food night you are wrong.  

Close.

But wrong.

The answer is the Masala Uttapam at Dosa.

I could eat 12 of those bastards and not even flinch.  

I have been here a few times and have experienced the same each time.  

Strong drinks, spicy foods, and a cool atmosphere.  

Do not miss the crab cakes.  

Speaking of crab, I would LOVE to see "Deadliest Catch: India" on discovery channel.  

I am sure the witty banter between the fishermen would be a sight not to be missed.

Footballs.
author: Archie R.

description: Loved the food and the atmosphere! The price not so much. We got three drinks, an appetizer, and one entree to share and it came out to about $90. The food is good though. We got the chennai chicken as an app, spicy and very flavorful. Next we got the truffle masala dosa..YUM. I could taste the hints of the truffle in the dosa and loved the chutneys that came with it. I enjoyed the creative drink menu, had a hard time deciding but I went with their "Mango is The New Black" drink, I would definitely get it again if I went back. Gorgeous atmosphere and very large space for SF. Overall, this is a fancy date night type of place, good food but be prepared for a large bill.
author: Ashley R.

description:
On Sunday afternoon, I ate at Dosa for the first time.  What a lovely spot to eat, with its earth toned walls, high ceiling, and very large centerpiece of a chandelier.  The service was attentive and prompt; the food was delicious; and the portions were generous (in fact, I was so full from the lunch I didn't eat for the rest of the day).

I had the Pea Paneer Dosa - a dish with grilled peas, spices and rice wrapped in a light bread (the dosa).  There were 3 sauces that came with the dish and an order of Raita rounded everything out.  For dessert, some chai and banana cream pie was especially yummy.

Thanks to the staff for keeping the music down so that it didn't compete with our conversation.
author: Brechin F.

description: The food was excellent. Service was excellent. The prices can get kind of steep, but this isn't your average bay area Indian restaurant. This is the type of place you bring that special someone to eat a nice meal and soak up the ambiance before heading out on the town, or to the beach (if it's a nice day which is rare in SF) , or back home. There is plenty to chose from (a lot of Vegetarian options) as well as some fusion dishes for the adventurous of heart. If you're looking for a traditional Indian restaurant, then this might not be the place for you.
author: Diani B.

description:
I used to go to Dosa on Valencia all the time. I knew there were certain things to get and certain things not to. It had been awhile since I'd been to any Dosa, and I was really excited to finally check out the filmore location. 

Firstly, it is a beautiful beautiful room, but I feel it's pretty tough to get a table where you're not cramped around other people. Fortunately, the service is so efficient that you don't feel neglected by your server at all, but it is sometimes tempting to listen to other's conversations -- they're like two inches from you after all. 

Back to service. It amazes me how fast our service was, and so attentive. I was impressed. The restaurant was cramped and we never felt forgotten. I asked for quite a bit, and I got everything in an instant without the slightest bit of annoyance. I was impressed. 

Now to the food. I feel like it is really not there. I don't know if it's just me or what, but it was like some of the taste was zapped out of the food. I ordered the Dahi Vadi, my usual safe bet, and found it way less flavorful than usual. The balance of yogurt and chutney taste wasn't there - the yogurt taste won. 

My friend ordered a coconut fish dish. His was the winner. I ordered spinach and duck curry. It came in a thin sauce that was very spicy but didn't have that creamy flavor that I usually expect from spinach curries -- usually I order this and many other things at Indian restaurants with the expectation that I'm about to do my body a great disservice. This is something I accept and am even excited about. I felt that the sauce was bland, and asked my friend if I had accidentally ordered the chicken dish instead of the duck because I couldn't tell the difference. Sad face :(

We got a great sounding dessert, a sorbet with cardamum and some other flavors. It was good, but really watery compared to what I was expecting. 

All and all, i like the idea of these restaurants (both locations), and that it ascribes to be healthy, but I can't help but realize that I never finish my food when I go there.
author: Alexandra M.

description:
I was a little wary about this place walking into a dining area of ... um... white people holding utensils.  My friend told me to try this place being that I LOOVVVE Indian food, but I'm more accustomed to North (Punjabi) food. I've had Dosa once at a wedding, so I can't really compare.  Overall, the food was VERY good and perfectly spicy but when you factor in the wait (on a WEDNESDAY night), the unattentive service, and the price,  the restaurant was, eh, OKAY. The food did come out fast, but it was hard to hunt down our waitress for anything extra and the check.  

Our menu: Samosas, Chaat, Lamb Kofta, Mung Masala Dosa, & Paneer and Peas Uttapam. We were too full for dessert! Oh, I forgot to mention, the cocktails were delicious!
author: Melissa V.

description:
This review will seem like a slam, but I do like this place.

Food is spicy but pricey.

Ambiance: Yes, it's Indian, but I felt a WASP undertone. I noticed the accents around the front door were not really Indian. The chandeliers must have cost a fortune--they definitely make the room opulent. I love the picture of the Indian woman in a sea of flowers. Love the high ceilings, but I think they could done more to the ceiling than just white tile. Perhaps some brushed metal henna pattern or something!

Bar area was well planned. Good traffic flow, and airy. Definitely come for drinks--Bengali Gimlet, wow.

I had a hodgepodge of dishes, so I don't know exactly what I had. All I know is that the spices were very crisp, clean, and full of flavor. I did not expect the dishes to have so much kick--a pleasant surprise.

I had the rasmalai for dessert. The rose water was subtle and not too overpowering. Oh BTW, the waiter did not pronounce rasmalai correctly.
author: William H.

description:
I went to Dosa for Dine About Town.  The food was great!  My coconut soup was a little too spicy for me, but the rest was really delicious.  My Paneer & Peas dosa was really, really good.  Next, I had their Pav Bhaji, which was super delicious but I had to take it home.  I was getting full and definitely had to leave room for dessert.  (I had the Pav Bhaji at home the next day, it was super tasty!)   I had their Rasmalai dessert, which is a sweet cheese with cardamom and rose water.  It was heavenly!  I was very happy with the food, and so were my friends with their plates.  BTW, I'm a vegetarian and was very happy with my selections.

The location's beautiful.  It's hard to believe it was a Goodwill store before.  It's essentially a very large room, so it gets a bit loud, but that's part of the fun.  It's also great that it's on Fillmore and the Sundance cinema is right across the street.  This would be a great place for a date or for friends to simply hang out.  It's a perfect combination of casual but cute.
author: Elena I.

description:
I rarely give five stars and DOSA deserves all five stars.

when I first walked in, I automatically knew that this was going to be a good night. HAHA.

The waiters and waitresses were attentive to our needs and also gave us newbies suggestions on what to order.

I started off with the Potato Leek and Rice soup. I was quite surprised when it came in a greenish color, but nonetheless, that didn't stop me from eating it. I'm a big fan of potato leek soups and I gotta say---it was on point. The rice added a great texture to it as well. Perfect blend of rice and soup, without each other overpowering one another.

Our table also shared a few appetizers. We ordered the Dahi Vada, which is Lentil dumplings topped with cool Straus organic yogurt, piped with tamarind & mint, mildly spiced. 

The dumplings were like a hard doughnut, yet it matched perfectly with the cold yogurt. It was also blended with some spices. Put them together in one bite and it's perfection.

We got another appetizer but I forget the name! But it was good...ahhaa.

As for entrees, we each got different entrees and just shared it. 

1. Channa Bhatura Chickpea (garbanzo) masala served with an oversized, soft, puffy wheat bread or vegan poori.
- Oversized doesn't cut it, it was HUGE, it was like a huge balloon, then they popped it and deflated it. You tore into it and dipped it into the garbanzo masala. Delicious.

2. Chicken & Eggplant 'Baingan Bharta' Organic boneless, Fulton Valley, roasted & pureed eggplant, peas (great w/ lemon rice)
- This was one of our favorite dishes. The lemon rice definitely hit the spot.

We got two types of different dosas, all of which were great!

The soundtrack that they were playign throughout dinner was amazing as well that my friend and I had to ask the waiter to ask for the song titles.

Overall, great experience, great food, every dish had a different taste to it and its the diversity of that really stood out.
author: Carissa E.

description: While waiting for a table to open up for dinner at another restaurant we spent a very pleasant 90 minutes sitting here at the bar. Dosa is a high end Indian cuisine restaurant but the bartenders are awesome as is the bar menu. They even sampled a few really nice gins so I could decide what to drink. Very high class but not high priced.
author: Alan G.

description: Best Savory Crepe I've ever had. The Veggie Thali is definitely worth trying!
author: Melanie H.

description: I'm especially a fan because their gooey delicious bread-like dish was gluten-free. The decor is chic, and the ambiance was great.
author: Karen S.

description:
The atmosphere of the restaurant is that of fine dining and elegance.  Post modern and modern lamps drop from the ceilings and look as if glowing creatures were hanging upside down.  The hustle and bustle of the place shows that this place is doing a fine job of entertaining their customers.  Casual dress or dress it up.  Parking is a bit tough so park in the Japantown lot if you have trouble finding street parking.  We made reservations and I would highly suggest RSVP

What we ate:  

Crispy Fish Pakora - Sustainably-caught fish, marinated in chile, cumin, ginger & garlic, fried, served w/ chile & cilantro chutney
(Nice flavors, the chutney was spicy!  Although I wouldn't say the fish was crispy, more like fried but soft.)

South Indian Lamb Kofta -  Natural lamb meatballs, rich sauce of tomatoes & mild spices with plain rice.
(The tomato sauce really took over the the flavor of this dish with subtle hints of the lamb meatballs.  Overall it was tasty and I would order again.)

Masala Chutney Classic masala dosa spread with a spiced chutney of blended baby eggplant.
(Never having a dosa before I found this quite tasty with the chutney and sauces that accompanied the dish.)

Drank: Batsman- Plymouth English Gin, Darjeeling tea, lemon juice & ginger beer, served tall over ice.  (Tasty drink)

All in all the experience was excellent.  The water glasses were kept full and the waiter was prompt.    

Decor:5
Food:5
Service:4

Would I go back?  You bet your pastrami I would!
author: Kelson H.

description:
So I went over here when a colleague suggested this place. 

Samosas - Yummy!

Bhatura - Loved this and with the dipping sauces below

Coconut Ginger Fish in Banana Leaf - Not so good and the coconut rice was so so and I don't all dente.

South Indian Lamb Kofta - Too spicy and not a fan  of the lemon rice.

Some other bread with 3 dipping sauces... The bigger dipping sauce was okay, the orange once was yummy! The yellow one no one touched.
author: Helen V.

description:
We ate here just a few weeks after they opened and we didn't enjoy our meal at all. Either Dosa in the Mission is far better or they were still just working out the kinks. The food wasn't as vividly flavored as at the other location and it wasn't fully hot when served.

I think the makeover is the best part about this place. It was turned into a hip space from a boring old Goodwill store. Impressive renovation.
author: Marina N.

description:
Beautiful environment, pretty exquisite and unique Indian food. The halibut was amazing. The breads are wow. LOVED the mango goat cheese hazelnut salad. The dosas are crazy big and so good. 

The service was kind of spotty and weird. Got a drink order at the bar and then was brought to table - the drink was TOTALLY forgotten. (dropped ball) Then our servers were switched mid-meal, which was weird. It felt like nobody really was in charge of us or cared. But it was fine, not disastrous, but hardly attentive. 

I would totally come back though.
author: Susan I.

description:
So many people told me to go to his place, but to be honest it was just Okay. I defiantly think the ambiance is nice and so is the staff.

The appetizers were the best, vada pao and idli fries.

The dosas were okay, nothing great.
author: Swati K.

description:
Pros: Great food & drinks, nice ambience
Cons: overpriced & stingy about "extras", can be over-crowded

Their food is finger-lickin good (desi ishtyle, not kfc), and surprisingly reminded me of great authentic food which I've eaten in India.
I enjoyed their chennai chicken (starter), spicy mung masala dosa, lamb kofta and pav bhaji (small bread buns served with a mixed vegetables entree).

One complaint about requesting a little extra portion -- the 'pav bhaji' dish came with 4 bread buns, and one of the buns accidentally fell off the table, so I requested the server to get me another one, which on the bill was charged for $1 as 'open food'!  That's for one small roll/bun of bread!
I suppose if Wendy's can charge $0.25 for an extra slice of tomato, why should Dosa on Fillmore abstain from ripping us off??!

Anyhow they've got a nice wine selection, and from their cocktails I loved 'Juhu Palm'.
author: VadaPav B.

description:
In a time when most restaurants skimp the pretty and go for strictly utilitarian/cheap chic interiors, it's wonderful to enter a beautifully decked out spot like Dosa. The huge chandeliers and tastefully eclectic interiors  conspire to make you feel special, even though the food is actually quite affordable.The staff is fantastic, well informed and friendly without being too "hover-y",  which is an automatic 2 stars and 2 thumbs up for me. 

We got  dosa to share (classic masala... deee-lish), a fish pakora (a bit greasy but it's fried fish so what do you expect), lamb chops (YUM) and chicken korma (oh-K but nothing to write home about). Also got a round of cocktails, which are highly recommended as they cut the spicy food perfectly. Mine had ginger in it. Ginger makes me happy.

Dessert was actually my favorite part - an unbelievable chocolate chili mousse pie (chili+chocolate=tears of joy) and Gulab Jamoon, which I can only describe as 2 spheres of happiness swimming in a syrup made by the gods. Hooray for new food experiences that don't disappoint!
author: Michi V.

description: hmmmm they've got enough positive reviews that i won't go into detail about the food in general. it's obviously good. what i want to talk about is the big huge puffy bread like thing that comes with the channa bhatura. take a look at the picture i've posted. when it initially came to the table it was bigger than my head and made my eyes change from normal chinese eyes to huge anime eyes. soon after we took that pic it deflated into a slightly crisp, slightly chewy awesome vehicle for the chickpea dish.
author: Regina C.

description: The food is good, the wait is long, the service is just okay.  Overall I like the restaurant and the food is definitely worth it, but it feels rushed when I'm there and it's no place to enjoy a long sit-down meal with friends.
author: Young P.

description: My wife and I love this place.  Got the 3 course with the Spicy Duck.  Delicious...but, was paying for it for three days... Worth it.  We made reservations with open table, they called to confirm, and upon arrival we were seated immediately.  Great Service and Great food!
author: Arthur M.

description:
Here is my amendment, having taken Anjan's thoughtful comments into consideration: 

I do not know much about Southern Indian cooking.  Perhaps it is radically different from Northern India and not spicy, in which case I would suggest that anyone going here should keep it in mind that the food is not spicy and not what most Americans think of when they think of  "Indian", nor what one might find if they went to Northern India or Pakistan. I like my Indian food to make me feel a slight burning in my gut that leaves me full and a little sick even when I don't eat that much.  I also like to be surprised when very simple dishes turn out to be really exciting because of the spices.  Not so here.  This is more like Peruvian food, where the flavors come from the sauces everything is doused in. There are some very delicious sauces and the ability to combine them is exciting, but this makes the food a little more like Mongolian or chem lab- not just the simple: indianfood+naan= delicious.  It also means that I have to remember what I liked or didn't like, which wasn't always easy to do, as by the main course there were about 8 sauces in front of me.  

Second, the prices are high enough that it will keep the riffraff out of all ethnicities.  This is definitely aimed at the Pac Heights crowd, where the cost is not a deciding factor.  While it is great that they are using organic and local foods, $17 for a garbanzo bean soft taco is difficult for me to justify very often.  There are no two ways around this.  As a small, thin woman who loves Indian food, I need two or three dishes and this has ended up being too much to spend on take out that was ultimately not that interesting as a vegetarian-- which Indian food really ought to cater to given that 25% of the country is veg.  

And to answer Anjan on that point of local/sustainable: being vegetarian is the most sustainable thing any of us can do and Dosa does not cater to vegetarians.  A quick look at the menu confirms this.   

Here's my rundown: 

Veggie Sliders: soft food+soft roll = mashed potato sloppy joe
Samosas North and South: one is your trad delicious samosa, the other was inedible 
Mysore Masala Dosa: tasty but not spicy and a little awkward for delivery/take home. 


That said, the staff were friendly when I went there, the ambiance is beautiful, and I would take a person there who doesn't like spicy food but does want to eat Indian and has a lot of money.  That just hasn't happened yet. 

*******      ********
What's really going for this place is the ambiance.  If you are an American through and through but want to feel like you have done something  vaguely "ethnic" but are afraid of poor people, this is a great choice.  

Anyone who has ever been to India should not be impressed.  The food is not spicy.  It is expensive.  There are only a couple vegetarian options.  I thought the Southern Samosa was a preposterous food item. I cannot justify the pricetag on this place.
author: Sarah S.

description:
Service is pretty good. Fairly clean place. Nice job on keep a sweet atmosphere. The place is actually pretty cool looking. Lighting is pretty.

I was there for drinks. They have Fin du Monde which is awesome. No Chimay, though. Bummer. 
Somewhat on the expensive side but nice to experience such a place/ambiance. I recommend it but not the type of place I could afford to go to often. But yes, thumbs up.
author: Tania C.

description:
Would put 6 stars gladly. 
Decor rocks, drinks are strongggg (winter smash hmm hmm good), food is out of this world and cheap. 
I mean really. 
Oh and service was great and we werre a table of 11... 
Tried the chicken chennai, the crab, the lamb chops, the dosa with potatoes, the yogurt apetizer, (didn't like the calamari but just subjective they were not bad) and plenty of other stuff I declare this place my new headquarters!!!!!
author: Carpe D.

description:
Stopped in at this place as passing by and glad i did. It was busy but we were seated quite quickly with polite, kind service throughout. 

The food was also very great. I have experienced some better dosa's in a couple places in vancouver, this was the first time i've had a dosa here. They were on the small side compared to traditional dosa's I've had which are far too big for any plate. But these will do a good job of filling you as well. 

Check it out for some good south indian cuisine and a nice ambiance.
author: R S.

description:
The staff was very pleasant and helpful.  Unavoidably we could not make the reservation time, called and they were very good about it.  When we walked in my Canadian brother said that he loved the place already - he liked the upbeat ambience. We ended up with a table upstairs (Yea!) and got to look outside as well as onto the main floor.  The waiter was friendly and very good in helping to make selections.  I had the pepper chicken - I love spicey and this hit the spot.  My brother had the lamb curry that he fully enjoyed.  Their beer selection is quite good and he had an Indian beer which he said was very good.  Unfortunately we could not try the desserts at this time.

Another positive is the location - the Fillmore.  We had a great meal and then ended up in a little piano bar down the street.  I got an email from my brother after he had arrived back home stating that he had loved Dosa and will return there on his next visit to SF.  Also, he was surprised that the bill for two was so reasonable.
author: Lynda C.

description: This is my first dining experience at Dosa Fillmore, I had been to their other locations many years ago.  The Fillmore restaurant is very well designed and looks elegant without having a real formal, stuffy feel.  Our party of four all opted for a special tasting menu (around $35/person) along with the wine paring (add'l $18/each).  At first I was a little skeptical about ordering the tasting menu rather than off the normal menu, but was not disappointed at all as each of the courses was excellent and by the time I worked my way thorough appetizer, main, and dessert, my hunger was satisfied for many hours to come.
author: Kent W.

description:
Ambiance - Great

Service - Great

Food - The food is sssssoooo tasty.

Went out with a group of girlfriends. Made reservations at 9:45 pm and we were seated at 10:00. And this place was still busy with a nice energy.

We ordered family style and every single thing we ordered was great. 


Loved this place!
author: LinLin L.

description: Food is great.  Beverages are obnoxiously priced.  At the bar, "a Ballast Point IPA and a glass of pinot noir please" comes to $25.13, pre-tip.  Sheesh.
author: Nicholas R.

description: I came here for a friend's birthday earlier this year. While Dosa has a cool ambiance, I wasn't particularly impressed with either the food or the service. Despite having made a reservation for our group, we were made to wait almost 45 minutes before getting seated. That's pretty unacceptable for wait time, especially with a reservation. The masala dosa I ordered was not very authentic, and, while it was interesting, I had a hard time getting into the somewhat watered-down cocktail I ordered. I did think the restaurant space itself was great for birthdays or nights out...if only the contents of the package (food + service + reservations system) were up to par with the nice interior.
author: Sarah T.

description: Great and unique ambiance! Great food - although the 3 course meal can be a lot of food so be fairly warned! I especially loved the duck vindaloo!
author: Puneet S.

description:
I never imagined visiting eating dosa with wine, but then I saw that in this place. Loved the ambiance, liked the food and the service was also pretty good.

It's better to wear formals for this place or party formals. 
Definitely would recommend taking someone here on a special occasion ;)
author: Akshay V.

description: Service and Food were great. I totally recommend the tasting menu if you have a large party. You get to taste everything on there. I love the shrimp and lamb, it was spicy. Lighting needs to be alittle more brighter so i can see the menu instead of using my flash light on the phone.
author: Pauline L.

description:
Fancy with some sweet light fixtures. 

I've only been here once and I feel like I might have to go back and try another dish.

I had the duck spinach masala and it wasn't bad but I think I would enjoyed another dish a bit more. The dish I had was a bit rich and lacked something that I can't really put my finger on. However, my girlfriend had the classic masala dosa and it tasted great! 

Our server was fantastic and the overall atmosphere was great! I'll definitely have to go back and try something else.
author: Brandon D.

description:
Delicious Southern Indian cuisine that probably wont give you a heart attack (immediately). Which is sort of a bummer, since that means less buttery goodness. 

The mango lassi seems to be fresh! Major bonus, since I can't help but drink at least 2 of these...
author: Courtney H.

description:
I've had a craving for dosas ever since the epic dosa experience of Favorite's monstrous, table-crushing ~3' crepe of mind-imploding goodness, so the trek to Dosa began.

It's got the feeling of a trendy-indie-night club but feels less awkward in the company, but the same number of beards. Carolynne K. and I were seated next to a fairly talkative group, so prepare for the conversation volume-level wars to ensue immediately on receipt of your menu from the hostess. I liked their selection of mixed adult beverages, but what really grabbed my attention was their "Mint Lemonade" sans the alcohol. For a "dosa place" I felt conflicted as to why their menu was both small and all-encompassing at the same time. Perhaps a "customize your dosa" is in order?

We started off with their rendition of what was clearly a Casear Salad that hit us with a disappointment of "garlic" and watery salad. The flavors were an odd accompaniment to any Indian dish. What made my night though was the endless orders of Papadam that we quickly devoured with their (extra) chili/garlic chutney that would probably force me to surgically remove my tongue once I started consuming it tasty spoonful by fiery spoonful.
 
If the chutney wasn't enough to make the drive from the East Bay worth it, the bowl of Rasam (Fire Broth as they call it) was one of the best tomato based soups I've ever had. It was difficult to share in its dominating power of flavor seduction, but I guess we will just have to order 20 bowls next time.

I received my dosa soon after finishing said Rasam, and became increasingly confused as to what Dosa (with a capital D for DSupersmalldosas) was giving me. It was filled with a spiced potato mixture that was unnecessarily lumpy for a "rip-it and dip-it" dinner experience, although the flavors of both the batter and the potatoes were supreme. I guess my hopes were set too high, but Dosa delivered on flavor.
author: Kyle R.

description:
This review started at 3 stars and went down to one star after receiving emails from the owner.

**A service fee of 20% of the pre-tax check will be added to parties of five or more **

This is tacky.  The service was not worth 20% for our party of 5 last night.  And yet we were forced to pay it.  Tacky.  The solo diner nearby observed what was happening and volunteered he thought it was tacky too.  

Food is well prepared & presented.  

The table cleaners are too quick to move you along....wanting to take plates that have been on the table only a few minutes & still clearly have food on them.

UPDATE:  After an email exchange with the Owner that he began, I feel the need to say I worked in foodservice for 14 years and fully understand the concept of tipping.  His emails were argumentative, presumptuous and served to lose me as a customer.  I had to ask him not to contact me again.

UPDATE #2:  I received this note from Guthrie H. re: my review of Dosa.  Down to one star.  

"Guthrie H.
San Francisco, CA
Send Message

For your review of: Dosa on Fillmore

There are few rules in the Internet baby...if u dog a place and someone's livelihood, expect trouble.  Be an ass next time And do not tip. So glad there is one less ass hole to deal with at work! Yes, I said it"
author: Yelper H.

description:
The staff is pretty awful, from host, to servers, to manager.  They clearly don't want to be there, and you get the sense they'd rather not have you there either.  We were friendly, ordered wine, apps, dinner, etc.  It wasn't us.  It was them.  At the end when we asked to split the 5 person bill down the middle on 2 credit cards, they retroactively added a 20% tip to the tab.  Classy.  

(valencia location has more reasonable staff)
author: Jason H.

description: So far this is one of my favorite indian spots in the city,  the dosa are really good for obvious reasons but they have so many other delicious dishes, the lamb kofta is amazing! Drinks are another stair way to heaven, I enjoyed the Bengali gibson was flavorful.  I am looking forward to going back and trying the different things on the menu, the food and spices they use are on point!
author: David K.

description:
One star docked because the portions are kinda wimpy. It may have been our own fault, though, for opting for the uber-touristy four-course tasting menu. We clearly didn't take the time to think it through.

Here's what we ordered:
-Prawn Chile Fry + Crab Vada (starters)
-Cilantro Mint Masala + Spicy Mung Masala (mini dosas)
-Pepper Chicken + Lamb Kofta (South Indian curry)
-Galub Jamoon + Rasmali (desserts)


The amount served on the "tasting menu" is about 60% of its a la carte menu counterparts. How did we know this? We were being nosey Asian folks who gandered at all the dishes that arrived at every adjacent table. That's how. 

We then stared back at our own dosas and currys and noticed that we got jipped (or "gypped" if you prefer to side with racists). The dessert portion was a joke. I mean, I literally laughed when my Galub Jamoon arrived. It was a solitary ball of puffed dough floating all by its lonesome in sugar syrup. Sad sad sad. 

To be fair, other than the disappointing elf-food portions, Dosa serves scrumptious, well-prepared dishes. Just be sure to skip the tasting menu and order directly from the full menu. The waitstaff is friendly and knowledgeable, and the decor is beautiful. Also, note that the kitchen is open late- until midnight on Fri/Sat, 11pm on Sun-Thurs.
author: Elaine T.

description:
If you love pancakes with a plethora of veggies cooked in curry, this is the place to you.
 My friend and I did not know that "Dosa" apparently is the name of a common South Indian (which is the type of Indian place this is) food, like a pancake.
 If you love meat, don't come here, cuz there isn't a lot.
 My food was okay, but not worth the price. The atmosphere is pretentious, and if you are expecting your 'typical' indian foods, you will not find them here. Almost everything is pancakes. And they got my friend's order wrong. 15 bucks for a wrap, like a shawerma, at lunch time.
 Don't think I'll be back! But a lot of folks come here, I got the vibe that it was the 'thing to do', not that the food was at all spectacular.
author: Bonifatius B.

description:
Come for the Bar, stay for the Food.

This is exactly what we did, wandering the local neighborhood we noticed the hopping bar and decided it was time for a drink or ten.  

Based on the crowd and great atmosphere, we decided to stay for a bite to eat. Honestly, we had no idea what type of food was being served (I suppose without the 4th drink we would have surmised from the decor), we took the lazy route often traveled by patrons of this restaurant and went with the tasting menu (as some of the yelpers have noted, it really is just tasting sized servings as well). I was even lazier and allowed the waiter to go with his favorites.

With a bottle of wine for the table, great company and sharing what life had brought us over the past year, my friend and I totally enjoyed the experience. The waiter was spot on, just attentive enough but not annoying, the restaurant is comfortable and the food was great.
author: Bob S.

description: Indian restaurant for white people. Food was plain. Service was plain. You can get the same stuff or better at a Mom and Pops place for half the price. Prices are ridiculous. If you're into the free-range pretentious yuppie over-priced Whole-Foods experience, this is your place. There was absolutely no charm, ambience, nothing. Never again. And geez, at the very least, teach the waiters how to pronounce the damn names of the food!
author: B R.

description:
So I went over to goodwill to sell some old clothes and maybe buy something I can wear ironically and damn, look what they've done. with the place. It's dim and elegantly decorated now. I didn't know it was possible to make a 10,000 square foot building feel intimate, but they've done it. And it doesn't smell like old people anymore. 

And they're serving South Indian food. If you go you'll want to try the lamb kofta with rice on the side as it has this kind of lingering spiciness that I've only tasted at the dosa on valencia. They recommend the lemon rice as an accompaniment, but I'd go with plain basmati rice if I were doing it again; It isn't bad, but I don't think it adds much & the flavor of the lamb (or anything else on the menu, I imagine) will stand on its own.

I sampled the spring uttapam as well. It's good by itself, but its real value is as a delivery mechanism for the coconut chutney, which you may even want to scoop out of the ramekin with your fingers if you're not all hung up on social conventions.

Service is good, not jaw-droppingly so like at the other dosa, but good. And they don't want anything to do with your bag of old clothes but they're nice about it.

But it's a little steep, and I primarily come to goodwill because I'm low on funds. I mean, if I'm gonna drop seventeen on a little bowl of lamb meatballs, you could at least throw the rice in for free. 

It's worth a try if you haven't been there yet. And it turns out goodwill is actually across the street where they corner store with the weird taxidermy used to be. And that place still does smell like old people.
author: matthew r.

description:
Just delicious.  My brother was in the hospital for 2 weeks at UCSF down the street.  My dad and I went there three times during his stay.... everything is delicious!  A lot of it is flaming hot but paired with an Indian Beer you can't go wrong!  Best Indian food in the city.    It is cheap too with a really cool atmosphere.  Totally worth coming!  Don't miss this Fillmore restaurant!

It does get bust though so maybe make a reservation!
author: Jessica J.

description: Whenever I think of dosa, I think of this place. It is absolutely delicious and I'm so sad there's not a location in Chicago!
author: Shruti M.

description: Unlike others, service wasn't the downfall.  Our waters were constantly filled, our server checked in all the time.  The food on the other hand, was perhaps just a bit bland to me.  I know we ordered a dosa, but all I could recall is the uttapam sampler.  There were four different ones, but they were so similar, they were nearly indistinguishable.  I'd like to give them another try at some point, but my impression was that Dosa is an expensive place (with great service and ambiance) for Indian food that I might very well be able to get elsewhere for less.
author: Jenn C.

description:
I went here recently for the first time to celebrate my birthday after making reservations on OpenTable, and it's wonderful. The interior is beautiful and contemporary, and the seating is comfortable.

We started dinner with the Red Beet Cumin soup, and it was incredible; creamy and well-spiced. Great way to start the meal! Also tried the Rasam Fire Broth, which was good, but not as good as the beet soup.

We shared the Tamil Vegetable Curry with coconut-flavored basmati rice, which was also fantastic! So delicious. Then, we each ordered our own dosa. I ordered the Egg Dosa. It was really good, but I think I'd try something else the next time as it didn't blow me away like some of the other dishes.

Loved that there were so many options for vegetarians and vegans.  Service was solid. Overall, a delightful birthday dining experience!
author: Jamie T.

description: Honestly, I don't know what all the fuss is about.  The food is fine, but not amazing, and the wait is ridiculous.  The prices aren't great.  So, good food, yes, but worth it? Not sure.
author: Tarah D.

description:
I can always count on the Fillmore Dosa for a great dining experience.  Great food.  Fabulous cocktails.  Good atmosphere.  Good service. 

I recommend the Tamil Curry w/ Bhatura and the Batsman cocktail.  YUM! I don't actually love their dosas. 

The dishes are very filling so I suggest ordering less than you think you need.
author: T S.

description:
Gave Dosa on Filmore a second chance and they totally redeemed themselves! This time the food was just as good as the one in the Mission and the Filmore space is even lovelier than the one on Valencia. I think my previous experience was during this location's infancy, but they are all growns up now! 

Whew- sound sigh of relief here...
author: Michelle D.

description:
The food is mediocre...nothing to rave about...I've had better.  Should be two stars but got a extra star for the decor and ambiance.

What I had...

- Grilled Calamari...Seasoned with cilantro, cumin, chiles, onions, lime.  It was good...just didn't wow me.

- Spicy Sweet Scallop...Sautéed, mustard, chiles, maple syrup, cilantro, roasted red bell pepper coulis.  Best dish I've had here...

- Spicy Mung Masala...Mung lentil dosa ('pesarattu') with green chiles & spiced Indian potatoes.  Super spicy!!  The waiter had to bring yogurt out to calm my fired up palate!  Didn't finish and told the waiter to take away quickly.

- Duck Spinach Masala & Paneer...Sauce of shallots, tomato, coriander, fennel, cloves & cinnamon with lemon rice.  Nothing special...I've had better...way better...

- Spiced Lamb Chops...Free-range & natural, mildly-spiced lentil sauce, spiced potatoes & cauliflower, with lemon rice & raita.  Waiter said it was their best dish at Dosa...hell NO!!  

Definitely a place of overpriced Southern Indian food with nice decorations.
author: Patrick C.

description:
Yum! Had dinner here tonight with a friend. We ordered:
1) Mango prawns - Delicious
2) Tamil Vegetable curry - Yum!

To finish off the meal, we skipped dessert, but had the flowering Jasmine tea, instead, for digestion.

This place is very special. I'd definitely be back to try their other items...Good food and service!
author: Annette L.

description: Good place, clean and a wonderful ambience. Mixed bag when it came to food - some wonderful dishes like the dahi wada and bhel. And some of the dosas were very good. The chutney (which is the soul of a good dosa) left much to be desired - didn't expect it in such a fancy place to be made of dedicated coconut. The Frankie's were mediocre at best. Overall expected slightly better quality for the price.
author: Anand E.

description:
I just don't understand all the hype. Super expensive for what you get  and the food is only ok. I have had much better Southern Indian elsewhere for far less!
The decor and ambiance are nice. The service is friendly but slow. 
Portions are small. Food is rich and just nothing spectacular.
For all the hype and exorbitant prices I expect a lot more than DOAS is providing.
author: Kelle K.

description: amazing atmosphere and really great dosas! we shared a lot of the items and it was an enjoyable experience. the green mango dosa was my favorite!
author: Rachel L.

description:
It feels like I've been dying to eat here ever since this location opened, and finally, last Friday I had my first delicious experience! My girlfriends and I sat at the bar where a very helpful and knowledgable server/bartender named Kevin helped us make all the right menu choices, even down to the order in which we should eat things. 

What we ordered: Mungsprout salad, North & South Samosas, scallops, and the paneer and peas dosa to share. 

First we ate the scallops and the samosas. The scallops were the best I've had in San Francisco. They were the perfect size and I loved all the different sauces on the plate to drag my bite of scallop through. Then the samosas - delicious and again with fun dipping sauces. 

I have to admit I didn't know what to expect with the mungsprout salad but it was one of the most refreshing and healthy (in a good way) things I've every tasted. It complimented the more heavyness of the dosa perfectly (Thanks for the tip Kevin!). It was crunchy and light, perfect.
