Now for the dosa - I love paneer so this would have been hard to get wrong, and it was oh so right. I enjoyed every bit and was perfectly satisfied with all of my tastings of food. 

I can't wait to come back and try more!!
author: Lindsay A.

description:
I've been wanting to try Dosa for some time now and finally got around to it. My overall feeling after dining here? I don't love it or hate it but doubt I'll be returning. 

It's definitely the most elegant & upscale Indian restaurant I've ever been to. The host and servers were all nice and not snooty given the high-end feel of the place. Our server was busy but overall prompt and nice so no complaints about the service.

My dining companion and I ordered the Prawn Masala and Chicken Masala with plain Uttapam. Our entrees came out very quickly and our overall thoughts on our orders? It's "ok" but nothing that moved either of us. Be prepared because the curry was darn spicy which was not what our server told my friend when she informed him that she can't handle spicy. 

We both agreed we'll stick to more low end Indian restaurants that has Naan bread and Chicken Tiki Masala the next time we're craving some Indian food!
author: Soozie H.

description: This was not my first visit to dosa but it was so terrible that I am writing about it. We arrived at 10PM on a Wed night and were seated at a table closer to the kitchen. Imagine my shock when during our dinner , one of the waiters(guy with braids) carrying plates back to the kitchen bumps the back of my head (plates/elbow not sure) and doesn't even apologize. We asked the waitress who was serving us to move us to another table since it was terrifying to constantly watch/wait for another/same clumsy waiter to do it again walking back and forth between the tables and the kitchen. Since it was almost closing time  and the tables on the other side were now empty, she dragged our table and us out of further harm rather than change tables .  Come Saturday morning I still have a nasty painful bump at the back of my head . Hadn't realized it was that bad till the next morning. Wish I had given them a piece of my mind the same evening. Didn't want to spoil our anniversary dinner and let it pass. Food was meh. It was better during my previous visit.  They need to take a look at training their waiters better or  not have so many tables.  Either ways zero stars and warning of physical injury.
author: S C.

description:
I've been here twice and everything we've ordered has been delicious.  Sharing family style is definitely the way to go.  Family style sharing with a pescetarian is easy since a lot of the dishes are vegetarian and they have a few shrimp dishes as well.
Definitely order a dosa or some sort--dipping sauces are so good and they can be eaten throughout the meal with other things.  Coconut rice is good and not overpowering.  Lamb was great--the boys fought over the last piece! 
Definitely recommend as a nice change to the regular casual Indian places you frequent.  Not a super huge fan of the modern decor, but I do like the lights up front that look like squids.
author: M. C.

description: We ordered paper dosa and masala dosa. Loved the food and ambiance.
author: Prashant P.

description:
Outstanding food!

We came to SF for a concert and to visit some fellow Yelpers; they recommended this place after confessing that they enjoyed it enough to give it a repeat visit.  

Here's what the four of us ordered and my thoughts on the dishes:

STARTER:
- Prawn Chile Fry (dry-rubbed in chile powder...spicy and wonderful.) 

DOSAS:
- Roasted Chile & Garlic Masala (very hot...prolly the hottest thing I've ever eaten and enjoyed.  Phenomenal dish)
- Chile & Cilantro (Uttapam)  This one disappeared incredibly fast, and was probably the tastiest thing on the table.

ENTREES:
- Mangalorean Prawn Masala w/coconut rice (outstanding with the rice)
- Pepper Chicken w/lemon rice (wonderful)

*Note: prolly not the place to go if you can't handle spicy food.  

*Second note:  I had forgotten my concert tickets at my hotel, so I asked the manager if I could borrow their printer to reprint a new set.  No sooner than I could get the request out of my mouth was the manager writing down her email address to which I forwarded my ticket information. Minutes later, the tickets were delivered to my table.  Even if the food was average (which is most certainly was not), this alone was enough to earn the place a  5-star rating.  Customer service is a dying art!
author: Jeff C.

description:
LOVE THIS PLACE.

I've been to the one on Valencia too, but this one is the nicer, upscale one. The decor is beautiful, classy and trendy. 

Dosa is what you make of it. I think you can eat there fairly inexpensively, the portions are big, but if you want to order the good stuff, it might cost you a little extra. 

I've had the four course tasting menu here. It's a little pricey but you get to try a lot. The stand outs were the dosas (obviously) and the sustainable fish. The fish is AMAZING. You can't get that at the Valencia location either. I probably wouldn't get the tasting menu again because now I feel confident I know what's good, and dessert at Dosa doesn't really do it for me.

Definitely go here for a nice night out with good food.
author: Abbey S.

description:
Went there for a late dinner on a Sunday. Really cool decor, nice waiter, fun atmosphere, somewhat eclectic wine list.
We were a little overwhelmed by the menu, there are a lot of choices and if you are not an Indian food buff you can get a little bit lost. However, the waiter told us what to order and we were all very happy with our food!. 
The Sunchoke Masala was soo good. My favorite thing was the chips at the beginning of the meal.
I definitely recommend it and cant wait to go to their location in the Mission!
author: Alexandra K.

description:
I took my wife here tonight. As we walked in The space was large ,open and had large white modern looking chandeliers. So far so good. This is where it went all down hill. They sat us on the smallest bench table against the wall right smack up next to another couple (almost like we were sharing the same table).  Ok still not too bad I can live with it ,not happy but lets see how it goes. As I was wondering how anyone could fit two plates and two glasses on this toothpick of a table I couldn't help but hear the entire nightmare of  a conversation this couple was having. Not only were we in the laps of this strange awful un-intelligent couple with a hack for a laugh but we had to endure their presence for an entire hour. At one point I got up and went to the restroom just to get away from their awful conversation.This completely ruined the entire evening.I couldn't wait to get the hell out of there! I could'nt even have a private /romantic conversation with my wife without having to listening to these peoples awful exchange. Have you ever been jammed in to sit next to the worst couple and after enduring their mind numbingly braincelless overbearing conversation for an hour to find out the entire resturaunt has emptied out and you are sitting in these peoples laps in an empty room? What an experience! I swear to god I prayed they wouldn't get desert  but when they did  my wife and I looked at each other with telepathic powers and.... .We'd had enough. Long story short
wait staff = very attentive  no problems
seating  by the wall 0 stars
food  =2 stars I had the fish plate  undercooked and overpowered by curry and lemon. My wife had the lamb balls, Spicy but didnt taste like lamb .
we ordered the pre fix meal for 35 dollars a person . plates were very small  and mango lassee is $5 a small glass.
We spent $100 and thought it was way over priced. aside from the bad seating  and mediocre food the glitzy decor was nice. well thats what my wife said , I was facing the wall. I came out feeling like I paid 100 bucks for a bad experience. Sorry Dosa I won't be coming back :(
author: Jay B.

description: Fantastic food. Restaurant is clean and trendy. Large selection of cocktails and beer. Appetizers are delicious. Highly recommend the chicken samosas and masala dosa.
author: Mike J.

description:
Dosa features small, expensive portions of sometimes tasty, sometimes bland, and sometimes very overseasoned south Indian food.  A bland dish is the Spring dosa, which is vegetarian.  A tasty dish is the Biryani.  An overseasoned dish is the lemon rice.  The owner says the food comes deconstructed so that you can add just the right types and amounts of sauce and flavor to the main course.  

Not knowing this, we were expecting just a hint of lemon in the lemon rice, but the rice tasted so tart it seemed like the chefs squeezed a dozen lemons in there.  Another issue was the hard peppercorns in the rice.  If we took a bite of rice with some of the roast chicken, it was difficult to tell if we had bits of a chicken bone in our mouth or just peppercorn.  

Also our waiter seemed overworked and pretentious, which seemed especially strange as he was not Indian and probably knew little about south Indian food before getting this job.
author: J. O.

description:
The place had a good nice decor and I was impressed when we entered.  The food was great.  But the only thing that really was horribly wrong was service.  First they made us wait at least 20mins for a table for 2, even though we had a reservation.  Than our server gave one of us a water glass that was cracked, our appetizer and one of our entrees, came out at the same time.  The beer didn't come until after we were done eating the appetizer and one of the en-tree's even though we asked for it twice.  All they had to do was open two bottles of beer and bring.  Finally the second entree came after a long wait.  The servers were pretty lax and seem to care what was going on around them.  I looked around and it seemed we were not the only ones given this treatment.  The table next to us kept waiting for almost 15mins for the rice for the entree which they got.  

Overall the food tasted good, but I am not going back because of the service.
author: Aman B.

description: Came here on my birthday and loved their appetizer. It was just big fluff pastry thing. Obviously I forgot the name and is too lazy to go search for it. Their entrees were delicious as well. Will be back :)
author: Lucy T.

description:
I don't usually think of Indian Food when I think of high-end restaurants, but Dosa is the best Indian Food I've ever had and a great dining experience in general. 

First off, just the inital view of the restaurant is impressive. Very nice decor, very cool feel, looks like something you'd see in a vegas casino. 

From there, the menu is outstanding. The cocktails were unique, the soups and appetizers were inspired and everything on the menu had a nice touch. They don't just serve meatballs, they serve Lamb Meatballs, which I had and which were fantastic. We also had some Dosa (how do you not order the namesake food?) and that was amazing as well. I don't really know what else to say. I had no real complaints, and I felt like almost everything on their menu would be well worth the price. 

This would be a great date spot and is a really good place for a double-date as well (not always things that coincide.)
author: Devin K.

description:
It was cold, windy, and after checking out the New People J-Pop complex which was the closest thing to Tokyo's Harajuku district I've seen in The City, we were in the mood for something warm, spicy, and ethnic.

None of the wait staff was Indian but we walked by a bunch of Indian cooks standing outside. Whew.  It's bad enough I have old Chinese people staring at me because we all know that's just what they do, but now I have Indian people staring at me because my bf is one of them. Yeah, I'm down with the brown. You know, I actually agree with Russell Peters about one thing and that is, in the future we will all be beige http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=aDl8unyFE0c

It's difficult to scrutinize your dish to make sure you don't bite into anything that could be extremely pungent like a huge cardamom pod or part of a cinnamon stick when eating a dark curry in a dark environment. I would prefer the chefs to pick them out before serving but that's just a personal preference. Yes we tried the Dosas, and no they were not spectacular. 

This was the most expensive Indian meal I've had. A dim lovely environment, a lackluster waitress, and authentic yet mediocre food. We had high hopes but all of us agreed Dosa wasn't our favorite.
author: Jen Y.

description: Who knew an Indian restaurant in Japan town can be this legit.  Though this place may seem pricy, but it actually isn't that bad.  I would suggest getting some roti, paratha, and/or the fried bread/naan thing plus one tasting/trial course.  Actually a couple can split one tasting course which consist of almost 4 entrees.  Avoid the Samosa and definitely get the Dosa.  The dosa here is very very delicious.  Done perfectly and served with the right accoutrement.
author: John W.

description: Great Service, good yet niched flavors.  Not the same kind of indian food flavors you are used to seeing in your everyday buffet.
author: Price L.

description:
I really didn't expect to love Dosa as much as I did. I typically have a hard time with Indian food due to the spice; I'm very sensitive to it. When we sat down and looked over the menu, we all were just like, "duh...." like, no idea what the hell to order. 

The server was super helpful and started offering suggestions. We still just looked at her with a blank stare that said, "I'm not processing a word you're saying." My friend interrupted her and said, "Ya know, we don't know what the hell you're talking about so could you just order everything you think we would dig?" 

I will give both of them credit for this because 1) that was definitely the way to go and 2) everything she chose was AMAZING!! I'm not going to lie, I can't remember a single name of any of the dishes with the exception of the Chicken Korma which was friggin' awesome, btw. 
None of it was all that spicy (if I can deal with it then it must be pretty mild) although I believe they can alter most of the dishes to your preference. 

The interior is amazing with these beautiful delicate yet large chandeliers, modern furnishings, spacious bar and high ceilings. It reminded me of some of the restaurants in SOMA; it had a very grand feeling to it. The cocktails were also ridiculously good and unique. The mango drink I ordered was sweet at first taste and finished with a spicy kick. YUM!!!! 

I can't wait to try the one on Valencia as well! I've heard rumblings it's even better which I find hard to believe!
author: Julia N.

description: Girlfriend and I sat in the bar area. I don't remember exactly what I ate but the restaurant is beautiful and the menu selection was good. Really good drinks and the service was top-notch. Definitely recommend this place- even if it's just to share small plates and have a fancy cocktail.
author: Sarah A.

description:
Went to Dosa in the Mission. So much better! Service was great.

Food was again ok. Definitely better spice. But I still feel like these restaurants are not doing dosas quite right.
author: Merrill S.

description: Great indian/fusion food. Great taste, good ambiance.
author: Sal. A.

description:
I've never been disappointed here. Been here many times, and its always been fun. 
They have really good Indian food. The Chennai chicken is awesome, so are their other small plates. 
Service and ambiance too deserve 5-stars. 
Last night they refused to replace the whisky in my cocktail because the drinks are made to suit the specific drink mentioned in the menu, the manager also came up to me and explained this, i was more convinced after I had the drink. Their cocktails are very different, excellent.
Will continue to take my friends there whenever I can.
author: Nitin K.

description:
I'm not a huge fan of indian food, though i will eat it from time to time.  Came here with a large group of friends for a birthday dinner and must say that it was a good experience overall.  Let's start with the decor: 

very airy and pretty inside, dark woods, leathers and these absolutely gorgeous chandeliers that look like massive jellyfishes. Really pretty! We had a large table reserved right by the bar and service was attentive and the food came out quick. 

They only carry Indian beers here, so give it a shot if you're feeling up to it.  I had the Taj Mahal beef - light, like a hef. $6.50

Cilantro-Mint Masala Savory rice-lentil crepe, spiced Indian potatoes, cashew nuts, spread of cilantro-mint chutney - $11 the rice lentil crepe was savory and flakey, the potatoes inside were delicious and filling, the spreads it came with really enhanced the flavors. 

Prawn Chile Fry Fried prawns rubbed in ground lentils & chiles over organic micro greens $9.50. my absolute favorite dish that i ordered.  Came with 6 prawns, slightly on the small side, but the spices on it were amazing. Has a definitely kick!! Yummm!!

Duck Spinach Masala & Paneer Sauce of shallots, tomato, coriander, fennel, cloves & cinnamon $16 - the duck comes on the bone, but is very tender..the sauce was very dark, very smoky.  The paneer was really yummy with it as well, though in all the dark sauce, it was hard to tell what was what. *the server tell you that the lemon rice is really good with it, but it doesn't come with. :(

Passion Fruit Custard with Coconut Tapioca Cool fragrant custard topped with warm coconut tapioca pudding - this custard was good, tart and the texture takes some getting used to, its a tapioca pudding, but the tapiocas are large, larger than a rice grain, almost like small peas. it was yummy, but not worth the $8 price tag. :/ 

All in all, the service was attentive and the food came out quickly even though we had a very large party.  Our server was nice enough to also give separate checks so no one is stuck with a way-more-than-they-ordered-$$. 

I would definitely come back here again and try other entrees, though i will definitely order the prawns again!
author: Lulu C.

description:
Did "Dosa for dummies" & would do it, again! 

The tasting menu (dubbed Dosa for dummies by our good natured server) & wine pairing was the way to go! 

4 beautifully presented courses of Southern Indian: 
1)chili prawns - with delish crunchy slaw //calamari with coconut milk 
2) Dosas: paneer & peas // spinach served with some tasty chili chutney & yogurt dips 
3) rich Tamil lamb curry (my favorite!) // tender chicken korma 
4) tart & sweet saffron yogurt w/ fruit // coconut sorbet 

Dosa is gorgeous &cool ambiance is an awesome contrast to the hot *spicy spot!
author: heather s.

description:
This review is way overdue...about six months old, but better late than never.

The BFF & I came here specifically for their prix fixe menu a few months ago to sample several dishes, since it was our first time here. 

The decor really swept me off my feet; it's romantic & modern & very chic. The huge chandeliers, the tall ceilings & the rich, bold colors don't exactly scream out "India" to me, but there's no denying this is a beautifully decorated restaurant with gorgeous details that elicits good table conversation.

I always go with vegetarian options when I am trying new cuisines and/or restaurants. I started with lentil dumplings & had the masala dosa as my entree (spiced potatoes-yum!) I don't remember what the BFF ordered or exactly what I had for dessert, only that it was an ice cream that I didn't care for. 

The prices are surprisingly inexpensive considering the experience & portions you get. Definitely a fabulous place to get decent Indian food.
author: Fancypants X.

description:
We went to this place for Lunch. Very good ambiance and we were warmly received. Waiters were also very polite and knowledgeable. Food was good .We had Dosa and Wrap. Both were good.

 However we found this place to be very expensive. Dosa for $11 which you can find at other restaurants for $3.00 so on pricing we will give it a two star 

Thanks
ks
author: Ken C.

description:
The decor is lovely! The ambiance is very pleasant and relaxing, albeit on a weeknight...I don't know about the weekend crowd.  

The menu of the the Valencia restaurant was more to my liking but I had a nice shrimp curry which was delicious and didn't bother my stomach as most Indian food does. 

The heirloom tomato salad was to-die-for!

This is a great place to take out of towners!
author: Nilu r.

description:
I had dinner with my friends on Friday night. We had to wait almost two hours to get a table. I don't know how their reservation system works but there were a couple of empty tables up front. 

In any case, the food was good. I had spicy Dosa that I liked and Peony cocktail. Loved both! The restaurant had a nice interior design and is great for larger groups. I would recommend it but just make sure that you are willing to wait longer for a table.
author: MS K.

description:
If I could give this place negative stars I would!

I live close, and always saw the line of people outside. As some one who loves Indian food, I though this restaurant would be perfect for an evening out. I made reservations, because the wait time was at least 30min every time we came as walk ins. We were seated quickly, in a very nice table near a window. The interior was gorgeous, the colors and the walls, it's very well decorated. I eat Indian food all the time, but I had a hard time even deciphering the menu. So we decided to order a few dishes and share. The waiter was NO help and was totally spaced out.

we ordered Veggie Curry, and a Chicken rice dish.
They were under spiced, and tasted exactly the same. The curry was like a horrible version of Japanese Curry. The rice was a plating disaster. it was a pile of rice with a chicken drumstick sticking straight up, very unappetizing. 

This food is NOT indian!

for half the price you can go down the block to Indian Palace and for about $10 have all you can eat buffet.
author: Jennifer F.

description:
I've heard so many great things about Dosa. I'm glad I finally tried it. Bf and I came here for happy hour which is from 5:30-7pm so we could try a variety of dishes Dosa had to offer. Turns out they only have four tapas sized dishes during HH for $5 each. We figured, might as well try all of them. 

Chennai Chicken - fried boneless organic chicken with coriander and cumin served with Straus yogurt. The chicken was so tender and juicy! I loved the spices on meat. I especially appreciated the smokiness and heat from the cumin since it made the chicken that much sweeter and delicious. The yogurt was a perfect compliment, cool and refreshing. YUM all the way! 

Blackened Sardines - rubbed and fried with green chiles, coriander, cumin, onions in lime juice. I was never really a big fan of sardines but these were super meaty and cumin again was a big factor in the taste department. The meat was cut diagonally so you could easily fork it into your mouth. 

Blackened Spiced Corn - grilled sweet corn, rubbed with cayenne, salt and lime. This corn was spicy HOT but the lime and sweetness of the corn was a nice contrast. I don't normally enjoy food this spicy but I did like this one. However, the portion was pretty ridiculous. Did I really just pay $5 for an ear of corn? 

Mung Sprouts - sprouted lentils, tomatoes, cucumbers, ginger, grated coconut, seasoned with chile & mustard seed oil. Maybe I just don't like lentils that much but this was kind of a blah dish to me. It was nicely refreshing with all the spicy dishes we got but there wasn't anything really special about it. I didn't taste any coconut either like it promised on the menu. 

We still wanted a little bit more so we ordered an entree to share: 

Tamil Lamb Curry - Free-range and natural lamb, fennel, tomatoes, poppy seeds, caramelized onions and spices. SO DELICIOUS! The lamb was perfect: succulent and sensational. I honestly think I could eat this everyday and not get sick of it. The side of lemon rice we ordered was more citrus than just lemon. I'm glad it was recommended with this curry. 

On top of the wonderful food and the beautiful atmosphere, Dosa is environmentally concious about their food, equipment, furnishings and even bathrooms. Yay for Indian food and going green!
author: Julia T.

description:
Not impressed.  It didn't seem like true, authentic Indian food to me.  I actually prefer more hole in the wall types AKA Shalimar and Indian Oven.  

The only item I liked was the soup, which was on the tasting menu.  It was a cream soup with cauliflower and lots of delicious Indian spices.  The dosas were just ok; a bit heavy as an appetizer and the lamb did not impress me in the slightest after hearing only rave reviews.  First off, it was not tender.  Secondly, the sauce was starting to thicken up as it was brought out to the table.  Lastly, the plate was only half full, since it was part of the tasting menu, so it just looked straight up weird.  The consistency and coloring also reminded me of something which isn't too appetizing, so I'll refrain from bringing that up in my yelp review.

The desserts were gross.  I don't even want to get into it. Maybe I just do not prefer Indian food for dessert.  I will probably not be convinced to go back, unless we do not order from the tasting menu and get all new items I haven't yet tried.  

Drinks, ambiance, and service is quality though.
author: Jenny W.

description:
I'd never had a DOSA before.  Indian food makes me fart.  All those people who say that women fart perfume and sh** flowers are terribly delusional.  I fart, I'm not afraid to admit it.  But, once I eat something that doesn't agree with my stomach I tend to stay away.  I don't like to fart.  They smell.  I like to smell good.  Smelling good makes me feel pretty, and feminine.

And so it goes I NEVER eat Indian food.  I haven't eaten Indian food in years.  Seriously.  My friends RAVED about Dosa in the Mission but, they said it's impossible to get seated there sometimes where it's super busy.  They were so excited to try this place.  Myself, however, was approaching the adventure with a bit of trepidation.  We still had to share a car ride home.  

I wasn't even going to order anything.  But, my generous friends decided to treat me to my first dosa, which is a rice and lentil crepe filled with goodies.  And, it was delicious!  I didn't doubt it would be.  I was just scared for the aftermath.

Light and mildly flavored, my Masala dosa came with spiced potatoes, onions, and cashew nuts, which were all mashed together inside. The mild flavors blended perfectly with with the tomato and coconut chutney that came on the side and the sambar, (a flavorful lentil dipping soup made with vegetables) which i was told should be put on the dosa but, truthfully it was just too yummy I ended up eating it just like a soup.  

I held my fingers on the way home in the car with my finger perched on the window handle just in case.  But, I made it home safely!  Phew!! And, I even made it to bed that night home free!  

I've rediscovered Indian food.  Today was a good day.
author: Jacquie L.

description: This place is way to classy to be owned by an Indian person. Indian people are cheap and this was a two story restaurant with a chandelier. The greatest shortcoming was with the food, some dosas came precut for us, and it wasn't very filling for an Indian person in general. You can find the same quality food with a better portion at any other south indian place. I really like the environment and service though, and also the uniqueness of the dishes, it almost makes up for the food.
author: Jiten P.

description:
The worst service in forty years!  The server spilled smelly sauce on a brand new purse.   One "manager" came out and said that she didn't know what to do.   Eventually another "manager" named "Sarah" came out.  She offered to have the purse cleaned.
My guest told her this would not work since 1. the purse is not meant to be cleaned, according to the manufacturer and 2. she had chemotherapy for cancer and does not want to be exposed to cleaning fluids.  Sarah kept saying "sure" and "sure" like a stoned Valley girl on a bad hair day.  My guest was from out of town, and asked about a purse.  Four days later: no purse, no apology, not even a free dessert! STAY AWAY!
author: clark f.

description: We had a nice dinner at Dosa on Fillmore yesterday. We opted to try the tasting menu. I ordered lamb kofta, fennel/mustard greens dosa, and prawns masala. Wife ordered puri, mushroom uthapam, and duck vindaloo. The highlights were the kofta, dosa, puri, uthapam, vindaloo sauce, and sambar.  The food was well spiced and very fresh. Prawns were overcooked, and the chutneys that accompanied the dosa and uthapam were very disappointing. Too much yogurt and not enough flavor and spice. Wife got a couple of interesting cocktails. I opted for the wine pairing which was nothing exciting. Service was decent, but nothing spectacular. Would have wished for a friendlier waitress and hostess. The layout of the restaurant is very efficient and open.
author: Robert G.

description:
Cocktails for lunch anyone? I was having a particularly languid morning until I met some friends at Dosa and one thing led to another and next thing I knew the I had the Bowler in hand, and pisco, mango and a kick of spice that sent me into another orbit altogether. 

Johnny of Absinthe put together their drink menu, and I can attest that it's one you won't easily get bored with. Luscious juices and exotic spices from other lands take your tongue on a wild ride through mysterious place and tempt you to order just. one. more.

Luckily, a round of frankies brought us back down to earth. I can see why this traditional Indian street food is so addictive. The roti bread was soft and warm and the sauce was comforting and tangy. The Mung Sprout salad was delicious and refreshing and the perfect counterpart to the lovely comfort food.

They should definitely jump on the street food bandwagon with a cocktails n' frankies cart, no? How does one get a license for a cocktail cart anyway? *sigh*
author: Nicole G.

description:
They have this tomato thing with coconut milk ... I wept openly when I had it the first time. 
Love sitting at the bar & nibbling before a movie at Sundance Kabuki.
author: Eric W.

description:
Ok so I don't write reviews because i wait tables for a living and i know how people can be..........but I got treated in such a way that compelled to write this.

I went to lunch around 1 oclock today... just me alone on my only day off in weeks, and want a cozy warm place that had great atmosphere and spicy food and I new Dosa was the place to go.  I walk in their it was dead i want to sit at a table in the bar the host dude tells me he has reservations for that table (inside myself i know he is lying) So I go and come back 15 minuets latter and sat at the bar to eat.  I left Dosa at 3:30 and the table never got sat as a matter of fact the whole place emptied all the bar tables where empty.  He never offered me that or another table.  In this economy i think in a dead restaurant you would let people sit where ever they wanted to but not this guy I guess.  On a good note the bar tender i had (who was filling in for someone who did not show up for their shift)  Was wonderful and professional a real STAR.  The food was great and I loved the wine.
author: grace j.

description:
Finally an Indian restaurant with good food AND great ambience! The drinks were not so hot but every dish we had was great. If you like spicy food, this one's for you! Coming from someone who gets great Indian food at home, this is high praise indeed!

PS this is South Indian food, so don't come expecting tandoori or the standard indian fare ...
author: Man M.

description:
RACIST and very bad bad service by "Lauren" since she got 20 percent gratuity for our party of 5. If you are BROWN SKIN, don't go to this DOSA, go to the one on Valencia..never had problem with them.
And they LOST MY CREDIT CARD. Can you believe...they lost a credit card in the 5 minutes they had my card. Imagine the hassle of changing auto bills etc.
Another highlight....friend of mine had her bday and these guys took the desert someone else on our table ordered, put a candle in it, and pretended it was 'complimentary' from them. We all did the singing bit and the other friend waited for their desert, to be only told curtly that the one with candle was the ordered one. THATS SO CHEAP!!! WE ARE PAYING OVER 250$....AT LEAST TELL US IN ADVANCE SO WE CAN ORDER MORE.

Also does anyone wonder, why in a Indian restaurant, there are no Indians working? You really want me to believe that no "qualified" indian ever applied for a job here? A job which involves cooking and serving Indian food?

Anyhoos...me and my 250$ tab go to less racist restaurants with better service who don't loose credit cards.

**** UPDATE TO OWNERS COMMENTS *****
I did not come in there simply to write a bad review on Yelp....that's not how i choose to spend my holiday weekends
I came there to have a good time and good really bad vibes and bad service. So I am calling a spade a spade....

best of luck to Dosa.....I never denied food is great....it's the other stuff that's making me take my business somewhere else.

**** Another update ****
the owner is responding to me with HATE MAIL....

EXCERPT BELOW FROM THE OWNER......
"Btw, we have an opening for a busser position if you'd like to apply.  I'll put you on the floor as our token Indian! "

YIKES!!!! Sorry, I ate at your establishment.
author: Vineet K.

description:
Hands down, Dosa has the best Indian food in the city! Personally, I prefer the ambiance at the Dosa on Valencia Street, but both locations have great food and service. 

We ordered the Vegetarian Slider. It really is like a burger slider without the meat. Instead of burger, you get a spiced potato patty inside a bun. The coolest part is that they give you seasoning to sprinkle into the ghee (butter) so you can dip your slider into it. Yum! 

I also recommend the South Indian lamb kofta and the Massala Chutney Dosa. Unbelievable! 

If you aren't a germaphobe, go family style and don't be afraid to get your hands dirty. You'll be glad you did. 

The only negative is that it is a little expensive. But Dosa claims to be the only South Indian restaurant in the city, and there is a big difference between South Indian food and the other Indian restaurants in the city. South Indian food seems more like banquet style cuisine.
author: Anne Marie F.

description:
The food was good, the service was good, and the atmosphere was good. 

The paper dosa was crispy and I particularly enjoyed the spiced pototaos/onions it came with. The Channai Chicken was tender and complimented the yogurt. I particularly enjoyed the coconut rice and would probably skip the lemon rice (it was too tart for me).

Overall it was a nice dinner, but a bit on the pricey side. However, sometimes paying a little extra for a comfortable and enjoyable experience is a good treat once in a while. But....I probably won't be going as often for the sake of my wallet.
author: Stephanie K.

description: Stopped in for a late dinner after seeing a movie at Kabuki. We were lucky enough to get sat right away. We shared the white truffle dosa and mango prawns. Both were delicious. I love the ambiance there, the colors, and chandeliers are beautiful.
author: Christy Z.

description:
My family took me here last night for my birthday.  We had reservations for 7PM and were promptly seated.  The space was very nice, but got a bit noisy as the 8PM crowd showed up.

I was a little worried that my dad wouldn't like the food here because he's not a big fan of spicy Indian food.  He ordered the lamb chops and proceeded to lick his plate clean.  Then he finished off the rest of my sister's pepper chicken and a banana cream pie.  

My mom and I were a bit more adventurous. We split the spicy sweet scallops, masala chutney dosa, the paneer and peas uttapam, and a bhatura (a giant puff of bread that's fun to try to flatten and eat). The chutneys and sambar that came with the dishes were loaded with spice and very tasty. Plus, it's always fun to get to eat with your hands.

My only complaint about this place is the clientele. Wow, talk about pretentious. There were the people at the bar who randomly complained to us about not being seated fast enough. Then the people sitting next to us were very loud and nitty picky about everything little thing.  I felt bad for their server.   Also, there was a group of girls in the bathroom who had clearly being doing blow.  Sorry ladies, but wearing sunglasses inside at night does not fool anyone into thinking that you are sober. If I go back to DOSA again,  I think I'm going to try the one in the mission.
author: Lara O.

description: I love this place!  What a great way to have a unique and excellent meal before going to the movies at the Kabuki Theaters across the street (with reserved seating).  It is southern Indian food with a bit of kick in the spice but there are always some less spicy options.  I particularly loved the grilled squid (with a sweet, spicy sauce), the duck vindaloo with coconut rice and the seasonal vegetable uttapoms (like dosas, only slightly thicker).  Much nicer and easier to get into than the Valencia Street location and it has a vibrant bar scene.  Indian food is traditionally shared among everyone at the table.
author: James T.

description:
I wanted to eat here ever since seeing them featured on Malou Review.  What a beautiful space, what a fun energetic vibe, what professional service, what small portions for the prices.  In their defense the dosas are good sized but $10 for a persimmon salad the size of an eyeball, $10 for a 10" crepe-thin uttapam topped w/ a few tomatoes & onions, $15 for pepper chicken that came w/ 2 small drumsticks & 1 stray miniature drummette -- pretty appalling to serve that scrawny piece of nothing -- and $28 for the kerala fish moilee less than half the size of normal $28 fish entrees is ludicrous.  The sauces were too salty so you really need the side orders of rice to balance out.

I'm all about eating in a gorgeous fun space w/ good energy and paying for good food but I can't help thinking Dosa's kind of a rip off.
author: Jeannie C.

description: We ate here over the NYE holiday and had to fight for a seat at the bar, which I suppose is typical in the city over a holiday. The food was great, but not mind-blowing, which I thought it should be for the price. When we asked the bartender for recommendations, he simply recommended all the most expensive items, which I thought was a little contrived. Our meal was delicious and the interior is very nice - sleek and elegant, very swanky, and being able to walk right to the Fillmore to see a show afterwards was great as well.
author: Kirstin G.

description:
I've been really looking forward to trying this place for awhile, as I'm an Indian food connoisseur, but I was truly disappointed. We ordered 5 dishes between 2 people- nothing was memorable.. 
The restaurant is in a great location and the service is good but the food really doesn't cut it, especially for the $$$.. If this place were in a mall food court and was under $10.00 out-the-door I would approve, unfortunately this is not the case.
author: Zach D.

description:
Decor - Very good 
Food - Very good (it doesn't have stereotypical strong Indian flavor) 
Price - Expensive  
Service - Very good
author: M M.

description:
Went to the restaurant for Dine About Town, and chose their prefix menu. We were there at 5.30pm and got seated almost immediately...always a plus, but to be expected at such an early time.

The waitress was with us fast, we didnt have to wait long for the food, and although the portions didn't look any big to the eyes, they were more than big enough for the stomach! We were so stuffed by the end of all the courses!

Only minus was the desserts, we tried different ones, and I did not like any of them. Other than that, a decent restaurant I would recommend coming to. I liked the layout of it.
author: Martie K.

description: I finally got to try this place!!! I have been really wanting to for awhile now!!! It was a friends birthday last weekend and we had a large group for dinner. They were great about it... service was good... food was good. In a large group there is a prefix menu... three courses... I couldnt finish my third course... flavors were good... everyone loved their food and drinks... was great all around! Id def go back I'd like to try other items on the menu...
author: Jennifer A.

description:
I went there tonight for a friend's wedding party.
Those indian fusion food is amazing, I thought it is just like regular 
indian restaurant. not true. it is more like Indian fusion, food is so good.
I never give a 5 star in other restaurants in Yelp. But this Dosa does get it.
The decor is very nice too.
Definitely need to go there again sometimes. Though, it is so crowded on saturday night around 8:00pm. I got sitting because my friend book the whole upstair for wedding reception party.
author: Chi L.

description:
Was in town for a convention and had dinner with a friend at this place.  We were quickly greeted and seated by the hostess and was very helpful in recommending dishes since it was my first time.  Of course she recommended various dosa dishes and we did end up trying one or two.

I have to be honest though, I thought the food was enjoyable at the time but not really memorable.  We ordered the Cilantro-Mint Masala Dosa and Chennai Chicken.

One thing I do remember is that its very hard to find parking by there.  Since I'm not from SF I can't really say if that's the norm.  We ended up finding a space a couple blocks away.
author: Rose O.

description: Love this place! Its a great upscale restaurant to enjoy delicious South Indian food.
author: Priyanka D.

description:
This place has GREAT decor and ambiance. That's the first thing I noticed when I walked in. I really loved the chandeliers and the artwork on the wall!  

The food was decent and quite expensive, but I suppose that is to be expected from a restaurant in the city.
author: Ami S.

description: Absolutely abysmal.  Service is atrocious.  Manager is a completely rude.  We came with a group and they charged us $1,800 when we ordered $600 worth of food and drinks and refused to give us a itemized bill.   THAT IS ILLEGAL!!  Manager reminded us of a used car salesman.  Absolutely ridiculous.  Do not give your business to these scam artists.
author: A.J. M.

description:
Sat at the bar, devoured the cocktails and attacked some tasty nibbles.  I had never tried the Chennai Chicken and holy Lord, what I was missin'.  Wow.  Also mowed through the prawns masala with coconut rice and the onion rava.  The tropical and refreshing cocktails were the perfect compliment to the spicy dishes - what the hell was I doing drinking wine last time?
I still assert that I probably wouldn't think of Dosa when I'm craving Indian food, even though it is, but it's a great place to grab a bite at the bar before catching a movie across the street.
author: Jennifer D.

description:
Dosa is so over priced and over hyped. If you want to eat good south indian food - go to Udipi Palace, next to Dosa on Valencia.

I have tried most of the stuff here. The sambhar was extremely salty. The dosa filling was terrible. And horror of horrors - when my friend ordered the  Parantha with Tamil curry- they actually served a pre frozen parantha which you can buy in any Indian store.  

The idli was hard as a rock. I do not recommend the place at all - go to udipi and pay half for much better food.
author: Megha L.

description:
Hurray for Bollywood! A gorgeous glamarama setting brings spicy fun and full on flavor for dinner on a lively Saturday night. Fragrant spices envelop you upon entering, like an olfactory elevator transporting you to a sensual South Indian feast. 

BF and I both chose Bengali Gimlets for a pre-diner cocktail. Concocted with Tanqueray Rangpur Gin, 'curried' nectar, Kaffir lime leaf and lime juice served up with a wedge of lime, the result was a luscious, tingly elixir. I had another with dinner and it paired perfectly.

Portions were super generous (sharing is definitely the way to go) and service was smooth. Our meal started off with coconut & roasted bell pepper soup with cauliflower, cumin and chilies. Wonderfully delicate and so delicious, it was my favorite dish. 

The Chutney Masala Dosa was huge and satisfying. A meal in itself to be honest. The Jumbo Prawns Masala Curry was spicy enough to make you salivate but not overly so to make you sting. Finished off with something sweet and pleasant that I can't seem to recall at the moment. They were out of Galub Jamoon so they subbed something else and we ate it. Happily. 

I left glowing and satiated, feeling like I had experienced more than just a great meal. It was an elegant evening immersed in a magical environment; an award winner for sure.
author: wendella a.

description:
I have yet to sit down and try something off of their "more formal" menu but the gin drinks, masala dosa and bhatura that we consumed at the bar were really enjoyable.

The dosas and gigantic puffball bhatura make for a fun and interesting eating experience and cost like $10-15 each so you can throw more money at the bar.

The ambiance is definitely the big selling point for me though - dosas don't really stir me up into a frenzy but sitting under GORGEOUS lighting fixtures certainly does.
author: Krystle S.

description:
I have been wanting to go to this place for awhile and finally I made it an boy am I glad that I did! I am a south indian food lover and this place can beat many of the south indian restaurants in south india!

The best south indian food I have had in the bay area!
author: Sumit G.

description: I like the smaller Dosa on Valencia.  Last time I went to Dosa Fillmore before a film at Kabuki (~6 months ago), it felt like too much of a cattle call for my liking.  The food is tasty, but over-priced for what it is, in my opinion.  Easy to find lots of better down-scale (or divey) places around SF.
author: carol d.

description:
I visited Dosa with some Indian co-workers and they were disappointed with their meal, calling it "ABCD food". I was expecting a more traditional approach to the menu, and was surprised by how bland my Masala Dosa was.  At the time we were eating, every other patron was white and yuppie. Now there's nothing wrong with that, but I usually would expect more members of the ethnicity to dine at a restaurant that served the ethnic food.

I love Indian food, especially South Indian. I was really excited to try Dosa after all the great reviews. My meal (and a good portion of the menu) was "fusion" South Indian food without all the great herbs and spices that make Indian food fantastic.

I'm pretty sure an Egg and Cheese dosa isn't really a traditional Indian meal :)

The ambiance in here is nice, although the waiter and attitude seemed really snooty. Seems more geared toward people who love "fine dining".

I thought the meal was not worth the money I paid. If you're in the mood for cheaper, more authentic Indian food, try Darbar over on Polk street.
author: Jay S.

description:
SO-SO

Taste 1:  (Paratha)  interesting chutneys, nice raita
Taste 2: Chicken kabob- they were alright but suprisingly came with same sauces as Taste 1.
Taste 3: Dosa/Masala Chutney. Came with the same  sauces as Taste 1 and 2  plus potatoes.
Taste 4: South Indian Moons, so called chef's variety of 5 different Uttapams. They all tasted the same to me-just greasier -pancakes very similar to the  above Dosa dish and tasted like tastes 1, 2 and 3.

SO: Think potatoes, lentils, fried... potatoes, lentils, fried...potatoes, lentils, fried...potatoes, lentils, fried....potatoes, lentils, fried-EVERYTHING! ..with some rice, and the same chutney, raita, etc with every dish. Not too exciting-eh? I got tired of chewing. At the end all I tasted was salt. 

SO: This is Southern Indian cooking?? maybe for Americans who don't know the difference- I've had better- more flavorful and distinct regional dishes- just across the bay in Berkeley.

Redeeming qualities: Very attractive space and a nice bar. Have a drink with a friend when you're on Fillmore St. Maybe ONE appetizer to soak up the alcohol and then go down the street for better choices.
author: diana l.

description: Cool decor and excellent food! We had the duck, lamb*, and scallops. They were all on point. Only negative about this place was our waiter was not the most attentive person. We asked for him to come back for us to review the menu a little longer and he came back like 10 minutes later. It's also very dimly lit so you will literally need your iphone to read it. Overall a good experience, just a few pet peeves.
author: Michael P.

description:
Everyone loves and talks about this place. This is a place where a lot of my friends bring in out-of-town guests. And then even the out-of-town guests go to this place on their own (later).

I like this place too. This weekend, we spent a couple of hours here with some of our friends. We spent a good two hours there, way more than what I spend on dinner at other places. We definitely liked the ambiance, the presentation, the creativity of the menu. But actual implementation didn't quite stand up to the expectation. And I was certainly not evaluating the food on authenticity criteria, because I totally love the experimentation they do with the recipes. But I was disappointed because of some basic problems with the food. The vada in "Dahi Vada" tasted leathery, the sambar had too much salt and my wife's "Rava Dosa" was cold.
author: Star G.

description:
Came here on Friday after work for a snack and a drink before catching a movie at the Kabuki. I was a little put off when I sat down at the bar and asked for a happy hour menu and the barback told me it was Monday through Thursday- when I had called an hour prior to going there and the host that answered the phone said they definitely had it going on. So... anyways- The happy hour is Monday through Thursday. 

We ordered the Chennai Chicken appetizer and also Roasted Chile & Garlic Masala DOSA round of drinks. I have to say the chicken was very good. The DOSA was pretty spicy so beware. 

The food was super yummy and will be back to try more.Just wish the phone hosts wouldve given me correct info - I wouldve given them another star.
author: Tara M.

description: My friends and I came here for lunch for the first time and really enjoyed the great South Indian food, the Dosa's were exceptional.  Our waiter recommended the dishes for us and each dish was fabulous and it all paired really well. We ended up staying for about three hours, our waiter and the rest of the wait staff continue to provide exceptional service the entire time...you can't get better service than this. This is a beautifully designed restaurant and great ambiance for a gathering. The Japan Town parking garage is across the street from Dosa which makes it very convenient.
author: Zoe P.

description:
Four Jews walk into an Indian restaurant.

Nope.  Not the beginning of a joke.  Just my life.  Which is kind of a joke, so maybe this is fitting...

Four Jews did walk into an Indian restaurant and it was a totally lovely experience. 

But I am not a lovely kind of girl, so...

See raunchy review of the decor below:

Dosa is probably the most beautiful restaurant I have been in for years.  I was literally speechless when I first arrived.  It is dark and warm and has the most beautiful chandeliers everywhere with hipster grooves coming in softly over the speakers.

I want to live there, or get proposed to there or get married there.  Or at least have dirty sex in the bathroom there.

That's NOT below me.

You know, Indian food isn't the most romantic food.  Half the time it kind of looks like vomit and half the other time it gives you incredible gas and or the dreaded D. 

But goshdarnit if they didn't rise above the Indian food curse at Dosa on Fillmore!  

It's romantic and aromatic and beautifully presented and if you do get proposed to there and you and your piece of soon to be married ass go home later and have "We just got engaged" monkey sex, you probably won't have to keep excusing yourself  to the loo every ten to fifteen minutes because the food is clean and lovely and healthy to boot.

*I can not be held responsible if Dosa does in fact give you the shits.  You shouldn't have ordered your curry so fucking spicy, idiot.  Way to ruin a perfectly decent night of sex in restaurant bathrooms.

Which, in fact, will be how I celebrate my engagement.
author: Rachel G.

description:
So this little socialite has clocked her share of hours at places like Tao Las Vegas, Le Cirque, and Asia de Cuba (LA and SF), and on and on...when I want good, honest Indian, I want it without the bells, whistles, and over the top decor that this Dosa location boasts. I also want to pay Indian restaurant prices, not French Laundry prices. I also want service that gives a damn and no, I do not wish to pay $5 for an extra sprinkling of paneer on my Uttapam that we all know was nowhere near worth the $15 I dropped on it (pre-$5 charge for paneer).

Don't get me wrong: I love Dosa Valencia and I love their wine list, innovative and creative cocktail menu, and all-out delicious cuisine. I just can't get down with $17 lamb kofta biryani PLUS $4 for a side of rice. I call shenanigans. The environment is nice, and as Eli B pointed out, it's an SF rarity:  a place where the patrons look like they put in a little effort before leaving the house. The waitstaff are also professional and pulled together, if less than friendly. 

The papadum is to die for and I really can't get enough of those lamb balls. Skip the $8 samosa starter (seriously...$8. Samosa. Enough said) and go straight for the spring Uttapam, the lamb balls, and a salad. $100 and something later, you can take comfort in the cheap and classless Goodwill store or dollar store across the street. I still pick Valencia location, hands down.

**Since Anjan (owner of Dosa?) took the time to email me about my review (ummm...I thought it was overall a pretty nice review of a restaurant whose cuisine I enjoy immensely...), I thought I would take a moment to update. As he pointed out, the food is organic and locally sourced for the most part and their animals die happy, politically correct deaths. Of course I'm happy to pay extra for that and kudos to Dosa for their commitment to the environment. That aside, I prefer the Valencia location. 5 stars for the food, 4 stars for capable service and ambiance that enhances the dining experience, 3 stars for what I happen to think are exorbitant prices. 5 + 4 + 3 = 12. 12/3 = 4. I'll throw in an extra star based on science and mathematics.
author: Autumn K.

description:
Loved the chandelier and atmosphere.  The food was good but, I guess it's not the type of food that I would crave. 

I heard this place gets really crowded on the wknds and has a pretty good bar. It's right across from the Kabuki theater so, I'm sure they get the pre-show crowd as well.
author: Mina B.

description:
This review is in anticipation for my upcoming next visit there, and I am SO looking forward to it.

First, the decor is gorgeous.  The chandelier lights are exquisite, and the feel is cool, modern, yet exotic.  The friend who brought me here could NOT stop talking about how it was once featured in Playboy magazine.  I think he was hoping a bunny would jump out from behind the bar or something.

I'm really not sure why yelpers have voted this a "spendy" spot.  Sure you can go all out on their delicious cocktails or more indulgent options (e.g. $39 four course tasting), but for dinner alone there are plenty of affordable options (e.g. $13 veggie curry).

The peony cocktail stands out, and so will your evening here.  For busy nights be sure to call ahead for a reservation, as it does get pretty packed.
author: Yushan K.

description:
Overall: Nice ambiance, dimly lit.  Good food, but felt *very* rushed.  Server wasn't too friendly. We had the wine pairing, she just sorta threw down the wine.  Desserts were the low of the food.

Service: Big complaint --we felt highly rushed. Servers kept asking if we were done, ready to take plates away when we had food left.  They brought out the next dish too quickly, were hovering over our table, like a cue to hurry up and finish. Since the table was so small, i felt compeled to shovel the remaining food down asap. They need to slow it down.  For the prices, please make the timing more pleasant!

Ambiance: Dimly lit, great date place.  Only thing to beware of is the two top tables are fairly tightly packed. We could hear our neighbor's conversations on both sides of us.  It wasn't a loud restaurant, but felt like i was on top of my neighbor.
author: Caroline I.

description:
The look of the place is beautiful! And so cozy! Unfortunately, the food was not good. We got papadums first - they were not crispy but kind of doughy and not very flavorful. Then my chai tea got there - lukewarm, not spiced at all. 

My bf got the tamil lamb curry, with the recommended lemon rice - 1) mild, 2) lacked depth - it tasted like it was just one spice (maybe too much anise or cardamom?) and nothing but that spice.  I got the South Indian Moons, Chef's selection of five different Uttapams. The uttapams looked different but tasted all the same and way too much onion in some. I didn't finish, even though I was hungry b/c I really didn't like them.

If you want better Indian food, even though it's from a different region, go to Roti in West Portal. (The atmosphere there is nice too.)
author: Katherine C.

description:
This was a fantastically beautiful restaurant.  Every little detail was thought out.  Since eating with one's hands is foreseeable, they have motion sensors on the sinks in the bathrooms.  There is hammered copper decorating the interior, and the door is like something out of a movie.  Huge.  Immense.  Meaningful.  

For each table there was a waiter/ess, a food runner who explained what things were and how to eat it, 2 bus boys who strived to keep the papadum crumbs from littering the table like birdseed.  Our silverware and flatware was changed 3 times.  

We order the Dosa and it was delicious.  Just the right spice.  The Spicy lentil soup to dip it in was phenomenal.  The potatoes were bright hi-lighter yellow.  And I ate it with my hands with gusto!  

The samosa were interesting.  One from the North, one from the South.  Tasty.  And I liked the sauces.  

We got the Tamil Lamb curry. THe meat was tasty and tender, but the sauce was riddled with herbs.  Not the finely ground ethnic herbs, but more like, "Chew, chew, bite into an anise seed or corriander or something also really pungent and makes my stomach curl."

The Chana Bhatura was impressive but seasoned almost like a desert.  So much nutmeg and cinnamon. The bread itself was also sweet.  

The dosa was the best bit.  I was very very full afterwards.  

And, I paid through the nose for it.  There was a lovely SF Health tax added to the end.  No wonder why the service was so good, it's added on top of the price of the food.
author: Christina C.

description:
This place has to be one of the BEST dosa places or Indian restaurants in general that I have been to.  It shows because the place was absolutely packed and Im so glad I had the foresight to call ahead for reservations or I would have to wait and stare at other people while they ate.  

The place is in a decent part of SF but the restaurant itself is gorgeous.  Very classy, and not cluttered. Some of the artwork was absolutely amazing.  The hostess was really nice when we arrived and seated us a bit early since we got there 10 mins before our reservations.  

Food!!!  YUMMMMM....and so creative.  I had the Chilli Garlic Dosa which is not reallly spicy but has a kick to it for sure.  I also had the rasam which had a great taste and best of all, it was nice and hot, just how I like it.  My husband had the paneer (cheese) dosa and it was really good as well though I preferred mine.  The chutneys were really good as well...nice and thick and tasty.

The price is not bad, especially if you are just having the dosas.  For a beautiful and happening place like this, it was a great value.  There was also a bar but we were there for dinner.  It looked quite packed as well. And this place is open late which is a big plus in the city.
author: Tina A.

description:
I must admit, I was rather skeptical when I walked into Dosa and saw that it's so frou frou and modern looking. I'm a big proponent of hole-in-walls for really good Asian food so I didn't quite know what to expect from Dosa. I also grew up eating South Indian food in Asia so I can tell what's authentic and what's not. 

I was pleasantly surprised that everything we ordered was really good! The paper thin dosa with potato was cooked exactly how it's cooked in Asia (perhaps with less spice in their sauce). We also ordered chicken curry and chickpea curry, which both had a kick of spice to them. Everything tasted really authentic too!

I'm not giving it full five stars because of how expensive everything was. I'm not an "atmosphere" diner, I don't need the fancy decor and statues, etc. I know the price covers all that too.  I guess it's definitely great for those who want to have a full night out because you can order fancy drinks there as well (martini with elderflower, etc).
author: Heather T.

description:
I came for dinner with my boyfriend and had a wonderful experience.  We had dined once at Dosa on Valencia before trying Fillmore, and I would come back to Fillmore 10 times before going back to Valencia.  Why?

1.  Our server really listened to our preferences and tastes and requested thoughtful dishes that ended up being perfect for us.  I think this is incredibly important when dining at a non-American restaurant with dishes and ingredients that one isn't completely familiar with.  Our server at Valencia must have been having a bad night because her recommendations were disappointing.  We are experienced Indian foodies and like super spicy food, and our Valencia server recommended really basic dishes that weren't adventurous or spicy at all.  At Fillmore we had : Samosas North & South, Mango & Goat Cheese Salad, Goan Prawn Balchao w/ dahi rice**** (which I highly recommend for the spicy food lover), and the Spicy Mung Masala.

2.  We made a reservation 48 hours in advance, came early to have a cocktail at the bar, and were seated at a lovely large and intimate table near the front window.  We had a great view of the whole restaurant and weren't sandwiched in with 20 other couples at side by side tables.  Maybe it was luck of the draw, or having a reservation, but we very much appreciated it!

3.  The cocktails are wonderful - definitely unique with Indian ingredients that add extra flare, but refreshing and delicious before settling down to a bottle of wine with dinner.

We had a memorable dining experience at Dosa on Fillmore and I look forward to coming back soon.
author: Alice H.

description:
I thought the food was terrific. Very different from any Indian food I had experienced. The dosa was made of lentils and there were many other non-wheat selections (they even have a gluten-free menu) which I appreciated. The prices also seemed moderate for an ample amount at lunch. 

It was conveniently right across the street from the movie theatre at Japantown where we went afterwards. All in all a pleasant experience with a nice atmosphere and helpful wait staff.
author: Sally O.

description:
very airy and pretty inside, dark woods, leathers and these absolutely gorgeous chandeliers that look like massive jellyfishes. Really pretty! We had a large table reserved right by the bar and service was attentive and the food came out quick. 

They only carry Indian beers here, so give it a shot if you're feeling up to it.  I had the Taj Mahal beef - light, like a hef. $6.50

Cilantro-Mint Masala Savory rice-lentil crepe, spiced Indian potatoes, cashew nuts, spread of cilantro-mint chutney - $11 the rice lentil crepe was savory and flakey, the potatoes inside were delicious and filling, the spreads it came with really enhanced the flavors. 

Prawn Chile Fry Fried prawns rubbed in ground lentils & chiles over organic micro greens $9.50. my absolute favorite dish that i ordered.  Came with 6 prawns, slightly on the small side, but the spices on it were amazing. Has a definitely kick!! Yummm!!

Duck Spinach Masala & Paneer Sauce of shallots, tomato, coriander, fennel, cloves & cinnamon $16 - the duck comes on the bone, but is very tender..the sauce was very dark, very smoky.  The paneer was really yummy with it as well, though in all the dark sauce, it was hard to tell what was what. *the server tell you that the lemon rice is really good with it, but it doesn't come with. :(

Passion Fruit Custard with Coconut Tapioca Cool fragrant custard topped with warm coconut tapioca pudding - this custard was good, tart and the texture takes some getting used to, its a tapioca pudding, but the tapiocas are large, larger than a rice grain, almost like small peas. it was yummy, but not worth the $8 price tag. :/ 

All in all, the service was attentive and the food came out quickly even though we had a very large party.  Our server was nice enough to also give separate checks so no one is stuck with a way-more-than-they-ordered-$$.
author: Veronika A.

description: Overpriced considering the quality and quantity of food you get. It's Indian street food for the most part packaged fancily. I went for Dine About Town and thought it was mediocre.
author: Niven S.

description: Had an amazing evening here the other night. I took my girlfriend out to a movie at Kabuki and then we headed over to DOSA. The place is beautiful, especially sitting on the second floor looking down over it all. We had a really friendly waiter ( Jack? I think he said) He actually offered to just ordered for us, and we were blown away. I have to say I lived in S.Inda for two years and this food is just as good. The Dosa was so fresh, and curries really flavorful. I will be back !
author: Leon B.

description:
Went here for a friends birthday dinner. We had reservations and arrived on time, but we still had to wait quite a while for our table (maybe 30 minutes). We all went to the bar and grabbed a drink while we waited. They have a lot of interesting tasty drinks which was a huge plus. We did the four course tasting menu which was more food than any one person should ever eat at one meal! It began wtih a starter, then a dosa, then a curry dish, and then dessert. Everything was so fantastic, I couldn't even pick a favorite. Between all of us, we had tried pretty much everything that the tasting menu had to offer and everything was really good.  They have plenty of options for vegetarians as well.

They were pretty good about accomodating our large group.  They did require that we do the tasting menu since we were in a group which was about $40 per person. They have an upstairs portion to this restaurant and our group of about 15 took up most of that area. 

The decor is really nice. There are some really funky ethnic art throughout the restaurant and it has that dark romantic lighting. This place would be great for a date!
author: Raheleh K.

description:
To; the server girl that was working on Sunday; 

"Look, i know you're tired and all that weight on you isn't helping your ankles but you dont have to rush our dinner just because you want to get off from work" 

My experience here wasn't up to par with what i expected. I brought my boyfriend out to SF and specifically had plenty of 'birthday dinner' options, but decided on this one because i saw all the great reviews. 

First of all- the dosa's are soggy. They look like burritos! So i think Dosa truck from LA and 'Dosa on Fillmore' should sell burritos instead. 

Food was okay and service made it worse.
author: Aidan V.

description: Ahh...it was ok. I probably wouldnt go back again as I didnt particularly like most of the food. The service however was A+.
author: Trent B.

description:
I'm a huge fan of South Indian food, so even a South Indian restaurant of poor quality would probably rate highly in my book. Nevertheless, Dosa sets itself apart with great service and a nice atmosphere inside. Didn't have a reservation and was told over the phone that it would be a 35-minute wait, but when we arrived 10 minutes later we were seated immediately ... nice. The dosa was light and crispy on the outside and all of the curries were solid. Uttapam very good. I will say that my partner rated the mango lassi below that of Shalimar, so, money can't buy everything I suppose.

Overall a very nice night; hope to return soon.
author: Brian B.

description:
i'm indian. I grew up eating this food. This is as authentic as it gets. Its clean and the service, in my experience, is really good. 

There's a few negative reviews for this place.Some understandable, the rest bizarre.
1. "Not authentic food"  -If you've spent your life eating in Indian restaurants in the US, you don't  know what authentic Indian food tastes like. South Indian food is very different from what you'll find in shitholes like naan'n'curry
2. small portions- really, do you need to eat larger portions??? 
3. "bad service' - If you've had bad service a low rating is fair enough..although i've never experienced this myself.
author: amit s.

description:
One word, BOMB!!!! That's all I gotta say.
Each dish causes my palate to have the biggest orgasm you could possibly have from food. Num num num.
author: Kehaulani K.

description:
If you like actual Indian food, do not eat here - you WILL be disappointed. If you have never had real Indian you might like this place. It is "fusion", which means its American food that looks like Indian food. Moreover, its American food with a bunch of pepper in it to make it "spicy".

I do not recommend this to anyone who is in the mood for Indian. I do recommend this place to anyone who doesn't like Indian food but wants to pretend they do.
author: Rachel B.

description:
Heaven for my eyes and mouth!

My boyfriend planned a suprise dinner date here last night because he knows how much I love Indian food and how I have been wanting to go to Dosa ever since it opened (on Fillmore).  Although we did have to wait 45 minutes, the food and ambience of the restaurant was well worth the wait.

We ordered a bottle of Shiraz from the Paso Robles valley to pair our food, and what a good choice!  Although the wine was a little pricey, the food was moderately priced for such a nice restaurant.  

We ordered the masala dosa to start with - super yummy!  I ordered the vegetable tamil and was not disappointed.  This dish had a kick to it, and anyone who knows me knows how much I love spicey food - especially when I don't even have to ask for it.

I loved this place and cannot wait to go back!  Beautiful food, restaurant, and wonderful service!
author: Dana B.

description:
Okay okay, so I slammed this place when I first visited their other location a few years ago and while I do still think its pricey for potatoes and lentils (neither of which I'm assuming are organic), the execution is well above average and the place is very nice, and not just by Indian restaurant standards.  Servers are professional and well informed, food comes out fast and hot, though the Dosa's themselves can be somewhat limp.  The cocktails are well crafted and have unusual flavors that mix well with Indian spices.

I would go 5 stars , BUT the last time I wrote a review for this place the owner starting badmouthing another restaurant that I had given a higher rating to, a restaurant whose owner had actually recommended  Dosa to me.
author: Raj M.

description: What a wonderful experience. There's even a wonderful selection of gluten-free, dairy-free and nut-free options. The food is delicious. The sauces are wonderfully nuanced and the dishes are balanced and inventive. The staff is friendly and service is attentive. A new home away from home!!!
author: Claire S.

description:
Phenomenal.   

You're right, I am neither conoisseur of Indian food (South Indian to be even more specific), nor does anyone truly care about my opinion; but here's what I am:

I am someone who has a serious problem patronizing and wasting money where there is no "experience" to be had nor food to knock my socks off.

That being said, here's where Dosa fits the latter:

As I (knew) nothing about this cuisine, our fantastic waitress took the time to explain South Indian food, how it differs from other regions and made recommendations as to how we should best experience our first time with this food.  We deviated a bit from her specific recommendations and went with her  "general guideline" (1 dosa, 1 entree, 1 app b/w 2 ppl).  Everything below is an absolute repeat; I'll just have to come with more people to order more food!

Started by splitting the crab vada- (crab cakes).  These literally melted in our mouths which was a problem given that they came surrounded by two different chutneys that leave one wanting to lick the entire plate clean.

Next up we split the namesake Dosa- opted for the Chutney Masala.  Potato filled crepe would be the crude laymen's way to identify this creation.  You can practically taste the time this filling's spent stewing- mouth watering blend of creamy potatoes with some pretty surreal spices.

In retrospect, we should have stuck to one entree; however as we were starving, we went for the Channa Bhatura (chickpea masala) and Prawn Masala.  

The Channa came accompanied by a basketball-sized puffed up wheat bread-practically a facial when the burning air steams out.  I wanted to compare this $14 Channa to the $3 Channa I always order at hole-in walls, and let's just say; it earns its dollar figure.  Again, the spices! Not as greasy as some other Channa dishes- one negative is beans felt a little undercooked.

The Prawn Masala was hands down the piece de resistance of the meal.  I like that most of the ingredients seem to be yogurt/coconut milk based (rather than heavier creams other places use)- definitely easier to digest!

Service was efficient (I can see how this could be perceived as rushed), but having worked in this industry, let me tell you it's not called rushed, it's called efficient.

I haven't even discussed drinks!  Coolest cocktail menu!  My mom enjoyed the Batsman- a Gin based, ginger beer infusion with Darjeeling tea I think?  

Obviously a knock your socks off, fantastic experience.  This is looking to be my longest review yet, and I absolutely plan on adding to it once I go back for more!
author: Gabrielle J.

description:
The lovely JP got us into a free event here with drink samples and 10% off dinner, and this veggie was very happy to accept an Indian veggie meal and drinks at a nice price.  Dosa doesn't disappoint.  Service is quick and professional for the main meal, and the flavors of drinks and dinner were spot on.  One of the drinks we ordered outside of the free tasting (actually both) were pretty spendy for what they were, but considering we were getting free samples, albeit slowly, it wasn't so bad.

     Spiciness abounded in every dish, and we had the greens, mango, and goat cheese salad to start, and I had the egg dosa, which was enormous, paper-thin, and delicious with the lentil dipping sauce.  Quite tasty.  They do everything possible to use organic and sustainable ingredients, which is a big plus.

     I'd go out to Dosa if I was with friends in the neighborhood or treating an out-of-town visitor, but we're spoiled for Indian options in Berkeley, Oakland, and on Solano that are just a little more affordable.  But Dosa is worth trying for anyone, at least once!
author: Joe B.

description:
I have dreams about the paper dosa here.  The texture and the different chutneys that come with it are great. I really like the different uttapams there . The waitresses are really friendly and suggest great dishes too ....they really want customers to try everything! 

I also got a kind of chat...that was little fried dumplings you pop in your mouth...it was a mouthful of yummy tamarind, yogurt and ...lentils? The presentation was awesome and they were so good. 

I miss it and I want to go back...now...
author: Wendy L.

description:
First of all, I have to say - if there was ever a need for a Yelp business to consumer case study, this might be one of them.  After experiencing a really frustrating time trying to set up a friend's bday bash, I wrote about it in great detail on Yelp (hoping to help future birthday bashers from avoiding the same peril).

In a nutshell, Anjan (the owner) contacted me and apologized for the experience.  What's more, both he and his wife were kind enough to treat the birthday -- er, guest of honor -- as well as myself and other co-party planners to a meal at Dosa.

I have to say that this was not only a very congenial way of dealing with an unsatisfied customer, it was also very classy.  Anjan made sure to contact me after the dinner to see how things went, and his wife even stopped by to say hello (and kindly give us a copy of a recipe that was being served that evening).  

Sure, some people may say that the Dosa on Fillmore doesn't have the same laid back feel as the original one in the mission - but after this encounter, my faith in them has been restored.  I hope that they can prevent future mishaps so they don't need to un-ruffle feathers of future patrons.  However, for me, I was impressed.

As for the food - DEFINITELY get the DOSA.  Although other things are good, there is a reason they called themselves Dosa.  The Chicken Biryani from my first visit was a little to spicy for my taste, and I had to douse it in yogurt to calm it down for my palate.  

So thumbs up, Dosa on Fillmore.  I'll definitely retract my earlier qualms, and I hope you have better successes with large parties.
author: Shay F.

description:
Came here last year for the Dine About Town lunch, and again this year to try other items off the menu.  Food was good -- oil / spice / salt did not overpower the taste or type of dish.  Had to bring this review down one star due to the restaurant's prices.  DAT is around $18 for a 2-course lunch, and regular dishes are around $10-15 each, while drinks are $3-6 each.  They do serve alcohol for lunch and dinner --saw a lot of people grabbing the fruity drinks.  

Dishes to try are the pancakes (uttapams [sp?]) and dosas.  The masala ones are good and so is the plain long dosa (it's this huge, thin, crepe-like roll served with chutneys --dipping sauces).  The mango lassi was delicious, creamy and quite thick --so consider sharing.  Chai tea is a favorite as well.  So, although all the food was overall good, there was one dish --sambar, which came with both pancakes and dosa, was extremely salty.  The lunch companions didn't care for it and thought the other dipping sauces were average and either too thick or too watery (coconut and masala).  

Decor here is Ikea-classy with a clean airy atmosphere which isn't typical of the mom-and-pop indian places down in SJ, or the naan-n-currys in the city.
