It's definitely a step up place where you can have a relaxing lunch and not come out smelling like spices and oil --service is attentive and pleasant.

Would be back if I'm with a group and am craving both an upscale / modern atmosphere and Indian food.
author: Jennifer Y.

description:
Personally, the food is good but not great.  I've had a couple of their dishes including:

- Cochin calamari: ok
- Habanero dosa: spicy, pretty good...tho no longer on the menu I believe
- Classic dosa: good. Not great
- Selection of uttapam: again good but not great
- Poori: pretty cool to look at and eat but not what you call delicious

Maybe I'm just not that into South Indian food but I'm not impressed, though some of the dishes are presented very artistically and the decor and ambiance is beautiful.  It's also close by my apartment so that's also a plus.
author: Jessica T.

description:
It was the eve before the Fillmore Jazz Festival 2012, the largest free jazz festival on the West Coast.... I wrote the following 1-star review exactly a week ago and 5days later my critical opinion of Dosa was deleted by Yelp HQ... due to my graphically descriptive personal assumptions.  Well I'm pretty sure that the person that I wanted to read it did, along with the vast people that were on Fillmore that wkend looking for somewhere close to eat.  Since I received an email from the owner, (proving that Dosa does care about their customers) I have updated my review to 3-stars.  The following is that review... revised.  

As I was picking up the foul feces that my dog just dumped, I was reminded of the shitty service that I just experienced last night at Dosa. Did the owners or management of this restaurant that I once raved about, change recently? I have been here before a couple of years ago... and even Yelped it 5 stars back then.

My review today is purely based on the bumptious hostess, Noel... that exuded the worst customer service that I have experienced in a long time. Lately it's rare that I have been to a restaurant in the city with less than 4 stars. 

Most likely a majority of their clientele are film buffs, since Kabuki is conveniently across the street. So after reading some of the recent Yelp reviews, we came earlier than our Open Table reservation... to make sure we had enough time before catching our movie.

The tone of her voice and lack of sincerity in her half-ass smile was so blatantly rude.
I let it go when she smuggly said that she had to seat the people in front of us. So as we stood by the open inviting bar, I noticed a couple entering after us... saying they did not have reservations... So I naturally thought as I walked back to Noel, that she would give us the same common courtesy that she gave those in front of us. But as I approached, the couple that just came were being seated at the very table that we should have been taken to. Wow. I definitely called her on it... but she just patronized that we were being seated now. As we followed the guy she gave the menus to, he was leading us to the very back towards the stairs... when there were many empty tables on the main dining area... Normally that wouldn't have ticked me off so much like it did, but my friend just got back from her doctor and has a broken toe... She was wearing flip flops, when she always wears heels. I stopped following him, and luckily there were seats open at the bar.

So the food hasn't changed; still flavorful and delicious as I remembered. And the bartenders were attentive.  Unfortunately the beautiful decor pales in comparison to the unpleasant service that I received initially from the hostess, which dampened my entire dining mood.
author: Myra M.

description:
My experience at Dosa, on two separate occasions, was tarnished by their horrible service. In the first instance, the waitress would correct my Indian pronunciation of the South Indian dishes with her warped Americanized notion of how they are pronounced. In the second instance, the waitress acted like I was wasting her time.

I really really wish that the owner would have a sit down with his staff and address the basic issue of how to be gracious around guests. 

And if you don't care about being treated like shit--the food is good.
author: Arpita K.

description:
Like any good American, I'm on an endless quest to silence my thinking. I'm plagued by profound thoughts. I hate it. My brain keeps asking questions with no quickly attributable answers.

"Why are we here?"

And while I could drink and smoke myself silly, or watch Spiderman 3 again, my brain would only cease for a few hours at best... and the hangover would suck.

"Is love just a rationalization of chemical reactions?"

Enter, brunch at Dosa on Fillmore. Sunny. Conveniently located (to me). Large, with ample service. Great service in an ambient and beautiful interior that will make you feel like the sultan of some third-world country whose name I can't pronounce. 

"Are the farmers of Argentina being properly represented?"

I can feel it go. A vacation for the brain. The Mini Dosa and side combination allows one to sample a variety of dishes. Our host rightfully recommended the Mung Sprouts salad (amazingly refreshing and light) and the Coconut and Roasted Bell Pepper soup (smooth and flavorful). 

"I wonder how much of the stuff in the Goodwill across the street is made in Taiwan..."

I greatly preferred the Chutney Masala Dosa to the buckwheat-based, Rava Masala Dosa. Much smoother. Honestly, though, I didn't really taste anything but potatoes inside. Oh, well. 

"That one dips in brown sauce before white sauce seems to represent the social inequities of race... The hostess is pretteh..."

Perhaps most fantastic was the Chicken "Dumm" Biryani - Savory organic chicken falling off the bone on a perfectly seasoned bed of basmanti rice with chilies, onion, garlic, ginger and spices. 

"Ginger tastes like the word "zing!" Whee..."

If you're still coherent after that oral stimulus package, the Toasted Coconut and Saffron Barfi will seal the deal... and you'll be left dumbfounded and smiling with your belt buckle broken and your finger up for the check.

"Food in mouth... good..."
author: Keane L.

description:
I'd give this place a 4.5 to be more exact.  

I plan on coming back just so I can have the prawn masala again.  We got to the restaurant really early since we didn't have reservations.  The restaurant was empty when we got there but apparently all the tables are reserved so if you're going to eat there make reservations unless you don't mind sitting at those communal tables like we did.

Anyway, after you order they serve chickpea/cumin chips which are fantastic.  I got the grilled calamari appetizer which is good but something I'd pass on the next time.  The lamb kabob appetizer which is more like a mini lamb meatloaf was pretty good.

The dosa was great.  To be honest I can't remember which one we ordered but I think each of them comes with a selection of dipping sauces.  The food has so much variety.  Crunchy, creamy, sweet, mellow, spicy, hot and cold.  Its such a wonder combination.  The food here is anything but boring.

The mango lassi is extremely thick.  So try not to think of it as a drink!  I ordered it in the beginning and sipped on it through the whole meal.  Its very good but I definitely needed water to quench my thirst.

The server was prompt and very helpful.  I would recommend this place to anybody.  The music is louder than I expected and from the outside I thought it would have been a more quiet low key place but its very lively.  So if you are looking for quiet and serene this place isn't it.
author: S T.

description: Our first eat out on our SF trip & it started out so good.  Good ambience, mouth watering dishes & equally good service. Idly, dosa, vada with excellent sambar and my personal favorite being Idiyappam. Highly recommended & would love to be their again :-)
author: Ratish K.

description:
There are certain things in life that in my opinion make me among the luckiest people on the planet. It is not money or fame (neither of which I possess in great quantity unless you count my Yelp Elite '11 status) but rather the luxury of eating what truly must be some of the best food in the world right here in my own city. I have become so spoiled by this that I rarely even get worked up anymore over the latest hot spots. Dosa though has me back in that place where I am just in awe of how awesome food can be if done right.
As usual I won't go into boring details about service or ambience. To me what matters is what comes out on the plate. I have been a fan of Dosa both on Valencia as one of the early followers and on Fillmore but have not been a regular in a few years. I can only describe the food as some of the best you will ever have anywhere, and if you are a fan of Indian, quite possibly the best you will ever experience. It is gourmet, beautifully presented and jaw droppingly delicious, every time.
New on the menu: white truffle dosa and spicy basil dosa. I tried both and was lost in ecstasy. Food can't possibly be this good but it is at Dosa. Can't wait to go back.
author: Matt H.

description:
I rarely give a 5 star review but Dosa is deserving. It is a fabulous Indian restaurant. I've now been fortunate to eat there 3 different times. Each meal has been equally good with excellent service. 

The restaurant is gorgeous. I remember when the location was a crappy Goodwill so it's very impressive what they did with the interior remodel. 

I've tried many different things on the menu and the Dosas are some of my favorite items. They are big so make sure to ask the wait staff about suggested portions for the meal. We were there for New Year's Eve and had a 4 course meal. I can eat a lot but there was way too much food. The good news is that everything was delicious. Another favorite is the Red Beet Croquette. They also have wonderful coconut rice. I could go on and on about the food.

I hope to have many more great dining experiences at Dosa and to be able to try more items!
author: Rachel M.

description:
This review is for an engagement party that I recently threw at Dosa. I cannot say enough about the food, service, and professionalism of the staff. We worked closely with Dosa's event manager Daniel Dowdell, who is FANTASTIC. Daniel was kind, friendly, responsive to emails/calls, and always gave us an honest opinion about various aspects of the party. As a result, we had a fabulous menu, exceptional decor, and all of our guests had a blast. It went off without a hitch! Daniel was also present for the duration of the party and frequently checked in with me to ask how things are going, and ensured that the entire event went off smoothly. His bartender and wait staff were also awesome - very attentive to our guests and super accommodating. One of the children at our party had a serious nut allergy and the staff went to great lengths to cook her specific food that was nut-free, child-friendly, and still delicious.
I would definitely throw another event at Dosa and if I could, I would give them ten stars!!! It is a perfect, beautiful venue for an engagement party (we had the upper mezzanine - very private), and the food is awesome.
author: M S.

description:
Hats off for creativity!

This has got to be one of the BEST Indian-fusion places in town. The thing that makes the food here mind-blowing is that while all the flavors are authentic South Indian, there is also a slight twist that always come as a delightful surprise to my husband and I who simply love this place. We always order the Vada Pav and I love their Paneer Watermelon Salad and their Idiyappam. Of course, we never forget to try one of their dosas - which have never failed to disappoint with their crispiness and taste!
author: Kalpana G.

description:
I wanted to suprise my husband with a date night. We have a nine month old, so we rarely get time to ourselves.
My husband has been wanting to try dosa since the new one on fillmore opened up
 to make a long story short
the foood was amazing the service was absolutely horrible. We saw our waitress once that was to order our food , The only people we came in contact with were the bussers. after we were finish eating we waited about 15 min. and still no waitress. i had to get up and go to the hostess desk to ask for our check.

our waitress finally comes back with a nasty attitude and drops ( literally drops) the check at our table no eye contact just kept walking.
A bad waitress can really ruin your dining experience 

i love the food but i will not be coming back
author: LaNiesha P.

description:
A very good meal. I went with a few friends and each had a bit of the set course menu. Together we sample a good portion of the menu. To be honest I can't recall many of the names of the dishes, but I can say all of it except the dessert were delicious. The desserts were universally bad. Portion sizes are erratic going from slightly large to huge to reasonable. I would advise ordering off the regular menu and skipping dessert.

Cocktails were hit or miss. We tried nearly the whole list and two or three were quite good. The others were flat, too sweet or just didn't taste good.

Service is lackluster. Justifiably popular tables are awkwardly squeezed near a over crowded bar. Drinks and plates are taken before we were finished often without so much of a "Are you finished?" As they have their hand on my plate or glass.

Still I would certainly return for another meal.
author: Marcus F.

description:
Yikes!  I'm still in shock from the bill.  I opted for a movie night across the street at Kabuki for a low-cost and alcohol-free night.  Major FAIL!

Enticed by the immense structure, my hungry friend and I walked in and sat at the bar for a light snack.  4 drinks each, 2 appetizers and 1 dessert  later, we rolled out of there....tipsy and a with a much lighter wallet.

I have expensive taste, no doubt.  Bypassing my usual anything-Rioja rule, I opted for the only glass of red from India on the menu. It was well worth it!  2 glasses later, my friend concurred.  We sampled enough to prove that they have a fantastic wine menu. 

Starting off with a cocktail, I had the Bowler.  A spicy concoction made with pisco and mango, it was a perfect way to perk up.  

The appetizers were fantastic yet small portions made me happy that we weren't that hungry.  Dosa definitely had an original take on calamari. Instead of the typical fried version, it was cooked in a tasty curry sauce. Yum!  The samosas were delicious but I have had better elsewhere.

We topped it all off with dessert: toasted coconut rolled in filo pastry and topped with kiwi & caramel.  It was good, but I would try something else next time.

4 stars for an original and delicious menu along with a fantastic wine list but -1 for small portions and the price.  (the bartender poured us 4 glasses of the same red without offering to charge the price of a bottle).  He was from San Diego and fun to talk to though so I don't hold it against him too much.
author: Lauren C.

description:
This place ROCKS!!! We have been in the US for the past 5 years and this was the BEST, I MEAN IT, the best Indian food we have had in the US. The Egg-Masala and Rava Masala dosas were great. Authentic Indian Chutnies. Totally satisfying and reasonably priced for a decent location in San Francisco.

Highly Recommended and will definitely go many more times :)
author: Aussfchi R.

description:
Dinner here last night teetered on the edge between a 3 and 4. Defining moments that keep my rating restrained include consistently slow service ... and a gross stir caused when James Van Der Beek entered the restaurant. I cannot, in good conscience, issue four stars to any establishment whose patrons become audibly excited by anyone from 'the Creek.' However -- despite his inattentive moments, our server was extremely knowledgeable, and the $39 per person, 4-course tasting menu is a great way to sample a variety of offerings (if you're with a group). But the real star of the show is the ambiance. It's SO warm and beautifully appointed inside that it is downright compelling to anyone passing by. Walk by and see for yourself how it makes you just want to be a part of the action inside. Hands-down, this has to be the most impressive 
transformation of any former Goodwill store on the planet.
author: Gregor G.

description:
This place is all show and no substance. The FOOD IS OVER-PRICED and average in taste. The flavorless chennai chicken costs fucking ten dollars and is just three tiny pieces of chicken . They add some random chutney to make the plate look full but seriously?? Ten dollars for that bullshit. NOT WORTH IT.

The dosa here is again some strange concoction. Nothing like the Dosa from India. Please go to Udupi Palace for a taste of what Dosa is really like. The DOSA'S DOSA IS YUCK!

Moreover, their service needs much to be desired as well. They think they can distract their customers with the chandeliers and ambiance but you know when your server does not give a fuck. Mine didn't. She kind of hated being there it seemed. SERVICE SUCKS. 

You know what this place is--it is a token Indian restaurant for the rich white SF people. It serves India, or rather, an altered image of India (the kind those rich white people want to envision --the India of the Maharajas and the elephants) and serves it on a plate--in a flavorless but much exotified manner. 

No Flavor, no authenticity, awful service, awful place!

Boo to you, Dosa.
author: Shriya J.

description: Really delicious food, different flavors than I was used to, I didn't really know what to order looking at the menu so our FANTASTIC waitress Marlese talked with us about what we liked and helped us pick out some delicious items to share.
author: Ilana H.

description:
You feel as though you are walking into a hip restaurant in Manhattan ...  bustling with the clatter of people, clinking of glasses, the music thumping in the background.  

The service:  Mixed bag.  The night my friends and I dined here it appeared as though we got better service from the waiters assistants rather than our waiter.  And I'm sure "waiters assistants" isn't the correct terminology, but those guys that bring you the food, ask if you need anything else, etc.  Basically the ones that do the real work!  ;)

The food:  Yumm!  Just a glimpse of some Dosas ...

Paneer & Peas Dosa:  Dosa filled with spiced farmer's cheese, cilantro and peas.  Quite tasty.

Habanero Dosa:  Watch out this one is SPICY goodness!  The spicier the better as far as I'm concerned.  

And everything is better with a side of the green spicy sauce.  Yum. Yum.
author: Nicole Rynee B.

description: I've been meaning to leave this review for awhile, but just got around to it as we will be in the neighborhood next week and looking for dining options.  We love Indian food and were so happy to see all the great reviews on this place.  We made reservations and after seeing a movie at the local Sundance Kabuki theatre, made our way to Dosa.  Despite having reservations, we were directed to wait at the bar.  This was OK as the decor is beautiful and we are never averse to a pre-dinner cocktail.  What transpired was a horrible experience at the bar.  My husband requested a VO Manhattan.  The bartender stated they didn't have VO and suggested another Canadian Whisky.  When my husband declined his suggestion, he appeared to be intensely angry.  My husband then requested Glenlivet Scotch and he stalked off and came back with the drink.  He never even acknowledged my presence or asked if I would like anything.  You could see him angrily gesturing and talking about us to another bartender.   When he returned with my husband's drink, I ordered one of their specialty cocktails and my husband asked him what we had done to offend him.  Apparently he must have been having a bad night because he immediately gave us a couple of free appetizers (which we wouldn't have ordered otherwise).  By the time we got to our table, we had lost our appetite because of the hostile experience and the gratuitous appetizers.  Food was OK, but overpriced (even for San Francisco).  We'll be returning to the Kabuki Theatre next week but will never be returning to Dosa.
author: Deonna T.

description: This one star review isn't for the food service at Dosa, which, though overpriced, is great.  This review is for the snotty bartender who WRONGLY corrected my pronunciation of the word "malbec".  It is pronounced "mahl-behk".  The "A" should sound like the "A" in "stall", not the "A" in "valley".  You were wrong, not me, you jerk.  Your manager needs to fire you so you take some classes and learn how to pronounce the names of the wines on your menu correctly, and someone needs to slap some sense into you to make you realize that it is your job to NEVER correct a customer's grammar in such a condescending, inappropriate manner.  I was absolutely offended by your unprofessional behavior.  If I wanted a wrong lesson in English, I could have asked your mother or one of your grade school teachers for it.  All I wanted was a glass of wine without the lip.
author: Louis S.

description:
I could tell from the get-go that Dosa was going to be really, really good. Our interest peaked by the beautiful chandeliers, we walked across the street to peek in the windows. Every table was filled late on a Friday night, and everyone seemed to be eating happily. 
We called for a reservation the following afternoon, and were told that we couldn't be seated until 10:00. Wow, talk about popular. 
We eat got the tasting menu, which turned out to be much bigger portions than we were expecting. Everything we eat had was amazing. I am a huge fan of Indian food, and I would recommend this place to anyone, either a newcomer to Indian food or a seasoned veteran.
author: Katie K.

description:
A lot like Dosa on Valencia, but with fancy decor, more noise, and
more people. Meh.

To be fair, the decor is great, but... 's a bit over the top for Dosa. Not a fan of the service, either. I prefer the Valencia version, preferably off-peak.
author: Max R.

description:
Dosa was fantastic. My boyfriend and I ordered off of the pre-fixed tasting menu, which was a little less daunting than the main menu. For the appetizer, I got the seafood vada. It was alright, not a HUGE fan, but I liked it for the most part. The mini dosa was probably my favorite part of the meal. I got the Paneer and Peas dosa, which was not only the perfect size, but the chutneys were incredible! Such succulent flavors... I also tried a bit of my boyfriend's Cilantro-Mint Masala and it was sooo good!

I also had the vegetable curry, which was kind of unmemorable. It was too spicy for me, but I guess I should have anticipated that with South Indian food! The dessert was SOOO good - I got the passion fruit custard, and I would highly recommend it. 

Overall, the decor inside was absolutely beautiful. We came without a reservation on a Saturday night, which was not smart. I would definitely recommend making a reservation beforehand. However, we only waited about 10-15 minutes before two seats at their large communal table opened up. Within half an hour of sitting down, the restaurant had cleared significantly. Last, Dosa's location is perfect for a date night, because Kabuki Sundance Theaters are right across the street! Great night and great food. Thanks, Dosa!
author: Catherine C.

description: Always enjoy design flair and the yummy food immensely. We had a great waiter this time, although most of our experiences at dosa I find myself dreading an unfriendly waiter.  I used to be a waiter when i was younger, so I think i'm not out of bounds with this.  I dont ask for to much, a little friendliness is all.
author: Sevin P.

description:
A few weeks ago, I was outed as someone who "writes novella-sized reviews that often mention his genitalia or gay sex" in an SF Weekly article about Yelp.
 
Granted, none of this is bad -- in fact, it's pretty accurate (though for the record I talk more about OTHER people's genitalia). But I was surprised to be in the article since the author never met or interviewed me. Had she done so, she would have seen that I'm sweet, well-mannered, and considerate (to a fault) in real life. Okay, so I talk about dick from time to time. Shut the fuck up.
 
I tend to speculate, so I wondered what it would have been like if I had been interviewed. Say, if I met the author for dinner at Dosa on Fillmore instead of my friend. Surely she would have seen that I'm not this raving cock-starved lunatic with a perma-erection and Tourette's, right? Then I remembered journalists are people. And, like most people, they have already made up some bullshit narrative about you. Once ossified, very little can break the lineaments of character, even if they happen to be untrue. I could have been more charming than Oscar Wilde or more cultured than a milk product, but her story about me still would have prevailed.

Me: Wow! I think the folks at Dosa have done a great job making a very large space cozy and welcoming. I approve.
Article Author: "I met Darin over drinks and dinner at Dosa. Always cognizant of the merits of making a grand entrance, he quickly sashayed through the heavy wooden doors like Liberace on coke, trailing his scarf behind him. As he took in his surroundings, he squealed with glee and mused that the large, open dining area reminded him of his distended asshole after getting tag-teamed by the Mormon Tabernacle Choir."

Me: Aside from the different art mediums on display here -- photography, painting, sculpture -- I truly love those marvelous LED light sculptures/chandeliers designed by Sharon Marston, you know, the threaded metal ones resembling dust clouds in the front window? Beautiful and environmentally responsible to boot.
AA: "Those chandeliers make my dick hard. FUUUUUUUCK."

Me: The North/South Samosas are very good. The only problem? I had a hard time tasting the difference between the "North" Samosa (spiced potatoes) and "South" Samosa (caramelized onions and veggies).
AA: "Clearly unimpressed with the samosas, Darin stuck his hand down his throat and tried to puke it up for the server in order to register his disapproval."
 
Me: Now, the Mysore Masala Dosa? Top notch. The light spread of the lentils within; the spongy Dosa bread as it absorbs the spices from the sambar -- Good God! If it wasn't for the refreshing coconut chutney my mouth would be on FIRE right now.
AA: "The Mysore Masala Dosa reminded Darin of the time an overzealous Rice Queen spread Sriracha cock sauce on his anus. 'Surprisingly,' he said, 'it had a numbing effect. Which, really, was the best thing because I didn't give a fuck about this guy and the less I felt, the better.'"
 
Me: My Tamil Lamb Curry is extremely well-prepared, though fennel detractors should avoid it since that's the strongest note. But the chunks of lamb are sizable and very tender.
AA: "Ever fuck sheep?"
 
Me: I really loved our server, Jenny. She was professional, helpful, informative, and friendly -- excellent service. Totally fine with leaving a sizable tip on the $78 bill. It's a little pricey, but considering we ordered enough food for 3 or 4 people, completely acceptable.
AA: "When the check came, Darin glanced at it and started fuming. 'I'm sorry, but why weren't we comped for anything?' he asked our hapless server. 'Do you motherfuckers have any IDEA who I am?!? I AM IMPORTANT!! ME! ME! ME! I'M DARIN I., BITCHES! HOW DARE YOU NOT GIVE ME A DISCOUNT!! YOU BETTA TELL YOUR MANAGER TO DRAG THEIR ASS HERE BECAUSE, YEAH, YOU FOLKS ARE GONNA HAVE A BIG FUCKING PROBLEM ON YOUR HANDS WHEN I START SLINGING ONE-STAR SHIT ON THE INTERWEBS UNLESS I GET THOSE FUCKING SAMOSAS REMOVED FROM THIS BILL!!!!!'"
 
Anyway, I highly recommend Dosa on Fillmore. And I challenge the author of the article to a mud wrestling match...TO THE DEATH.
author: d s.

description: I neglected to add an update that after I posted the review I got a nice note from the manager apologizing. I really appreciate that and would definitely give it another try.
author: Suzanne L.

description:
I came here during ad:Tech SF with one of our account rep - he said it was one of his favorite restaurants. :) OK...I'm not picky when it comes to food and I'm always up for trying something new!

Now, I'm no Indian food rookie, so when people mention it, I'm always game. He suggested DOSA on Fillmore as the place to meet. I'll admit...I was enchanted from the moment I walked in the front door. Everything was tastefully chosen and every aspect of the decor blended seamlessly with the next. I also learned that the entire restaurant was designed with eco-friendly characteristics (from the wood accents to the "XLERATOR" hand dryer in the bathroom).Since our rep was friends with the owner, we basically went "omakase" with our order...and compliments to the chef! I don't remember exactly what everything was called, but in summary... we had some great dishes (this isn't everything, I just really can't remember!): beet soup, a whole fish, lamb chops (which had GREAT flavor - almost kalbi-esque), coconut gelato and mango sorbet. 

Good stuff. I'll have to return! Dhanyavaad, Dosa!
-
author: Dawn S.

description:
Great food, a bit pricey, but the terrible service killed the whole experience.

It started out so promising, as our waiter guided us through the menu, suggesting some dishes that turned out to be fantastic, like the dosa sampler and the whole crispy fish.

But we lost him somewhere between the starters and the main, and he didn't show up until it came time to sign the check. How convenient!  We had to ask another server for the dessert menu, order dessert from the hostess, ask another server for our check, and then walk our check up to the cashier station. Shouldn't I get a discount for self-service?

Don't order the chocolate gelato unless you specifically ask if they've fixed their supply or storage problem. It came out melted, yet icy, and powdery. I don't know how you can do that to Ciao Bella gelato.

I really wanted to like this place since the food is so good, but it will be difficult to return because of the poor service.
author: Michael S.

description:
So usually when I go to Indian food, I don't order - I make whoever I'm with order (esp on Brick Lane) and I'll just pick at the curry until my mouth is about to explode (which is pretty soon....I don't do to well w/ spicy foods) and thats about the end of the story.

Came here to meet up w/ my friends' friends from Denver... didn't know what to expect because I didn't know them and I thought this was going to be some foo foo place where I had to sit proper and not be able to be myself (aka: laugh). 

Not the case at all.

We get here (parked at the Japan Center Garage and did a few sake bombs beforehand). First impressions: chic, trendy, nice bar, smells hell of good, dim, NOT quiet, super fun looking place.

Started with drinks, I had the Juhu Palm at the suggestion of someone from our table who had tried it before. It tasted like a sherbert. DELISH! Also tried the Bollywood one (v good too) and the Mood Indigo (way too bourbon-y for my liking). 

What to get at Dosa? DOSAS of course! All vegetarian!! (Are all dosas suppose to be vegetarian?!) Crepe like dish (I think it's made w/ rice and lentils?? Don't quote me on that) wrapped in various veggies. Tried the Chutney one which had eggplant and it was SO GOOD. Came w/ the sambar and 2 dipping sauces, one coconut and the  other i can't remember. I'm not going to lie, my mouth was kind of on fire after barely dipping it into the sambar, but trust me, that's just me being wimpy.

First time trying dosas and I am OBSESSED!

By the way, we were literally having the freaking time of our lives in this place and no one cared. Thanks Dosa!!!
author: Stephanie Z.

description: Yummy food!  Good and easy platters to share.  Only downside is that the service can be slow so prepare for the meal to take some time.
author: Grant S.

description:
While Dosa is nominally an Indian restaurant, it shouldn't be confused with the lunch buffet places in Silicon Valley that are quite common and not all that interesting.

Dosa is more "Indian Fusion" with fancy cocktails, great service and original dishes with an Indian flare. 

The ratings for this establishment definitely suffer from SF snobbery. This would be a five-star restaurant anywhere else in the Bay.
author: Richard P.

description:
Unfortunately, this will be one of those "I'm not familiar with the roots of this food nor have a sizable sample size for comparison" but damn were my meals here amazing. I've probably tried most of their Dosas and I haven't really found one that I didn't like. In fact, I like the Paper Dosa the most and really love their Sambar. I would highly recommend that you try this place out for a tasty adventure into a less-than-common type of Indian food in a swank atmosphere. 

Don't forget to get your parking validated.
author: Andrew H.

description: Very poorly coordinated. First, they told us the wait will be 30 minutes. We ended up waiting for 1.5 hours. Seemed like they didn't keep of track of wait list. Food was pricey and not that great.
author: Akib K.

description:
Just went to the Fillmore location and have to say it was ok. I always enjoyed their place in the Mission and really like dipping the crepe stuff into the curry stuff. 

Always thought this place was a bit on the high dollar side though considering: 

a) I just had a couple of drinks, couple of appetizers and an entree for $100+! 
b) Some of the other options around Japantown are less expensive.
c) when it comes right down to it, I'm just buying spicy flavored potatos and bread after all, right?! :) 

Alright, I'll admit it's a bit more than just potatos, you get the flavors and culture and atmosphere. And I will say the food is quite tasty and my date really enjoyed it. And I totally get the whole "experiencing South Indian cuisine" thing. It's all good. I liked it.

They should have had beer on tap though. That's kind of a big deal for me.
author: Brian C.

description:
I've driven by Dosa many a times, but never tried it until recently.  Came on a Sunday night and the place was pretty packed.  Wait for 2 people for dinner: 45 minutes.  That and when we finally got a table, it was at the communal table...

We ordered a Spring dosa to share.  It came with 3 pieces and served with 2 chutneys and a lentil soup.  I would recommend the Spring dosa if you want something not too heavy and still flavorful.  I ordered the Kerala Aviya which was a vegetable curry with grated coconut and  the coconut rice which was recommended.  The curry was a bit rich for me...but the coconut rice was really good.  My friend had the lamb kofta which was suppose to go great with the lemon rice.  DO NOT GET THE LEMON RICE!  I took a bite and it was way too lemony.  My friend took a bite of my coconut rice and stopped eating his...he looked at me and said he wanted my rice.  I was not about to trade! 

The service was a bit slow and when we wanted our food packed to go it was brought and placed in between me and the stranger sitting next to me.  We had no idea whose food it was and asked the waiter who brought it.  He said he didn't know...Umm, okay...

Bottom line: trendy place with good food, but not sure it's worth the wait nor something I would really crave.
author: Alvina W.

description:
It gets much of it's rating because I *love* the atmosphere here - it's like upscale Indian with great music playing and really amazing drinks.  I like the Emerald Sound.  The food is southern Indian so I had to learn a bit about what a dosas and uttapams are (roasted rice crepes and pancakes).  The chicken korma was quite yummy, and not at all spicy.  

And notice the floor in the bathroom ladies - you are a celebrity! ;)
author: Lara L.

description: I love dosas and was thrilled when Dosa's opened on Fillmore.  It's a fun place with a full bar.  Service has always been great and I miss their habenero sauce.
author: Suz L.

description:
My rating of this place is still the same..top notch!  My boyfriend and I wanted to celebrate his first official week of work and we were craving some high quality indian food - so of course Dosa came to our minds immediately! 

We love the chicken tikka masala and the masala dosa!! Also the chennai chicken is our favorite appetizer.  Our waitress was great about recommending a salad for us - I forget the name but it had avocados and chickpeas - so different and so amazing!! They also have a great selection of wine - our waitress was very knowledgeable and was able to bring out the perfect wine to go with our dinner.  To top things off, we had some chai.  

All in all, to us, Dosa is perfect!
author: Cherlyn M.

description:
Not bad. Five of us shared 2 starters, an entree, two dosas, a soup, and two lassies. Everything came out to be about 20 bucks per person. The atmosphere was fine, the waiter service could be better, and it's quite clean except for a moth flying around. All in all, had a great meal, would come back again :)

p.s. the lamb, chennai chicken, dahi vada, and the mango lassi were excellent!
author: Erin L.

description: The food was truly so-so (except for the kale and mungbean salad) but what made the night most unpleasant was the over-invasive waiting staff whisking away everything on the table the second they assumed you were done without even bothering to ask you. Doubt I'll be back.
author: Robert E.

description:
Take all your perceptions of Indian food and restaurants then throw them out the window before you come to Dosa on Fillmore.  This location has made eating Indian sexy in a big way with their high ceilings, large bar area and eclectic styling of their decor, giving off a intimate feel.

The food from what I understand is an authentic version of Southern Indian cooking.  While you might expect bird feed size portions, most dishes are adequate for sharing and usually are accompanied by a side of yogurt and a lentil based soup.  After two visits here, I can't say I found a dish that I didn't like.  The tastes and smells are just as vibrant as the atmosphere.  You can't forget to wrap up your meal without ordering the Gulab Jamoon (sticky, syrupy goodness) and the Rasmali (sweet cheese that sounds weird, but tastes good).  The cocktails are well prepared, with the bar stocking top shelf goodness like Hangar One Vodka.  

Dosa on Filmore will help you rethink your Indian food fears and get your evening right as a place to kick off things with a couple of cocktails and small plates or to wrap it up with a 4 course meal.  

And to answer those that are thinking you'll smell like food after coming here, well "You won't!" and "It's not that kind of place!"
author: Jason A.

description:
Let me start off by saying that I've never been to India, so I have no idea what "authentic" Indian cuisine is. I know know what I like, and I really like Dosa.

I had some friends in town and they suggested we have dinner and drinks at Dosa. We decided to do the get several things and we all shared them. We started with drinks. I had the Emerald Sound and I have to say I loved it. I don't know what my friends drank, but managed to have every drink on the menu. Some were exquisite, others not so much. That's ok, because there are many types of alcohol I don't like.

We ordered Samosas and they were tasty. We then did the uttapam sampler. The lentil dipping was incredible as well as the different flavors of the uttapam. Actually all the dipping sauces were good. We then went for the cliantro/mint dosa which was delicious as well. The potatoes were spiced but not spicy, which is my preference.

We finished with dessert. We all three had the banana cream pie, the chocolate cherry cake with spiced ice cream and the passion fruit tapioca. They were all good, but a little disconnected from the rest of the menu. While the drinks and food had a very distinct flavor, the desserts did not. Our waiter said that originally, they only had a few Indian desserts on the menu, but they didn't do that well and had another pastry chef come up with those. While they were tasty none the less, I think the chocolate cherry cake came the closest to fitting in with the spiced ice cream which did compliment the meal nicely. However, the passion fruit tapioca was light and fluffy and did suit being the finale in a spicy meal.

So, I highly recommend Dosa. I did knock off a star for high prices and not a convenient location for me, but it is an excellent restaurant for vegetarians and the drinks are yummy and original. I will go there again.
author: Bella T.

description:
I heard about Dosa from my best friend who doesn't like Indian food, so of course I had to check it out! This place is swanky and has beautiful decor, not like your typical hole in the wall Indian restaurant I'm used to. My coworker and I did the tasting menu so we could sample a good portion of their best dishes, and we were impressed! 

We started off with the chennai chicken which everyone recommends. It was cooked well - fried with good texture but still moist inside, and I thoroughly enjoyed the flavors. My coworker had the scallops which were very flavorful albeit small. Next I had the chutney dosa and he had the tomato onion and green chile uttapam. the dosa was amazing, the breading was soft, and the filling was savory. the uttapam was delicious, but those green chiles were spicy! i couldn't finish it all, i can only handle mild. our last course was the veg curry which came in a yellow curry sauce that was mild. i loved this curry, but any yellow curry is my favorite. he had the indian lamb kofta which comes in a tomato sauce. i didn't care for that one but am not a fan of red meat and thought the sauce was a bit heavy. we had amazing cardamom ice cream for dessert and i had a mango lassi which was ok, a bit thick.

overall i absolutely would come back, but more to impress a friend or take out a client. it's not an every day type of restaurant, and you can get indian food cheaper nearby.
author: sherrie n.

description:
Three words: 
Rasam "Fire Broth" 

I could swim in a pool of this amazing soup. It's spicy but not intolerably hot. I'm addicted.
author: Erica G.

description:
I finally returned to Dosa on Fillmore for dinner and left with mixed emotions. We decided to go all out and try the tasting menu which seemed like a deal at $39. For the most part the food was still fantastic - especially the Chennai Chicken which should be banned in 47 states for being so damned addictive. My Prawn Chile Fry was ok, portion seemed a bit skimpy (especially when compared to the mound of crack chicken that my friend had) I went with the Paneer & Peas mini Dosa and Lamb Curry to round out my meal - both were really good.

Let me back track a bit - the majority of our table decided to do the wine pairing with the tasting menu and all agreed that it was a mistake. The pours were pretty skimpy and while the menu said "Select one half glass with each course" it actually only came with the first three courses. So for $18 we basically got 1.5 glasses of wine...and what we got was pretty much forgettable and didn't pair well with the spicy fare. Next time I will definitely stick with beer! 

Ok, last complaint - desserts. The five of us tried three different desserts and again all agreed that they were the low point of the meal. We left the plates half eaten which never happens with our group and dessert!

Overall I actually feel like Dosa is more like a 3.5 star restaurant. Prices can definitely creep up (we spent $80 a person on dinner not counting our first round of cocktails at the bar) but for the most part the food is pretty good. My suggestion - skip the tasting menu and dessert and pick a couple of items to share...that way you won't leave disappointed as we did.
author: phil h.

description:
Came for Sunday lunch.  Slow service.  The food was good, but not extraordinary.  Decor very nice.  I would prefer more Indian music rather than the disco-thumping.  

Companion & I both had pani-puri then dosas (I had spicy garlic/chili one).  Food gave 'wind' to both of us later in the day (gassy).  And he's from India and I cook Indian food often, so it's not that we're not used to curries and such.  Usually when a restaurant has that effect, it's because not everything is freshly made.  Perhaps...

Overall, for Indian food, I would prefer a place that's not so fancy-hoity-toity, and with food that's more authentic.
author: Sloane T.

description:
The best Paratha I ever had!

I also ordered Uttapam with chile&Cilantro, paneer&pea Dosa, Channa Bhatura ( the puffy wheat bread is yummy!), South Indian Lamb Kofta. They all good, very authentic.

Minus one star because I wish they would serve some traditional dishes same as the Valencia location. The decoration was nice and good for big group.
author: Chali L.

description: The world's best sambar.   We first found the Dosa on Valencia several years ago but started coming to the Fillmore Street restaurant because of parking.  We got hooked on southern Indian cuisine because of Dosa and now, we're spoiled because we can't find an Indian restaurant in our new home, London, or other places we travel that match the complex flavor of Dosa's sambar.  So when we visited friends in the Bay Area this week, we made a bee line to Dosa on Fillmore and triple dipped into the Sambar with the Idli sambar starter, Dosa Massala and Uttapam (accompanied by their earth-moving sambar).  They also have a terrific bar and outstanding service, but the main reason why we recommend Dosa is their creation of the best sambar in the world for us.
author: Ken A.

description: Top to bottom, OUTSTANDING! From the North & South Samosa, Kerala Fish Moilee, Spicy Mung Marsala Dosa ... Up to the Coconut Custard Cake, all very-very good. A must visit in the Fillmore.
author: Patricia H.

description: Dosa came highly recommended to us and lived up to the hype. It was very crowded but we had a reservation and only had to wait about 10 minutes for our table. I had a vegetable curry dish and my wife had a dosa and both were delicious. The service was very good, the atmosphere was pleasant. I would definitely go here again on my next trip to SF.
author: Ken Z.

description:
I'm not dumb but I can't understand 
Why there's South Indian food in San Francisco's Japan
Oh my DO-SA.  Dee Oh Es Aye, DO-SA.

I had the chicken starter with the greens on the side
It had a bit of kick but tasted just right
From my DO-SA.  Dee Oh Es Aye, DO-SA.

A little lamb curry was just the right size
With a cumin kick that blended so nice
At my DO-SA.  Dee Oh Es Aye, DO-SA.

The mango lassi had fresh shredded mint inside
A chilled glass, and the perfect size
Oh my DO-SA.  Dee Oh Es Aye, DO-SA.

Then through the door
Came masala just for me
I had a bite
With the saucy treats

Well that's the way that I want it to stay
And I always want it to be that way with my DO-SA.  
Dee Oh Es Aye, DO-SA.
author: Dan M.

description:
My first dosa experience was at Dosa in San Francisco.  My boyfriend and I had no idea what to expect as we just walked in after a full day at San Francisco. We were there around 6pm on a weeknight and there was no wait.  The restaurant is very modern and servers are all very professional. 

We ordered Samosas "North & South" to start.  They were good but you only get one of each.  For our dinner, we ordered a Paper Masala Dosa and Masala Uttapam.  The Paper Dosa certainly has the wow factor!  It is rolled out to be really large and super thin.  We sat at a small table for two so it felt like the dosa was bigger than the table so it was awkward to eat.  For this reason, I like the Uttapam better as it is basically all the same flavors but all together in a pancake form.  

Our first Dosa experience was definitely a positive one.  It was great to try something new!
author: Helen L.

description:
I was so happy to see Dosa open across from the Kabuki.  What a brilliant idea.  My boyfriend and I go to Dosa every time we watch a movie and it makes for the perfect dinner and a movie date.  

The atmosphere is fun and trendy.  The restaurant opens up to a gorgeous space with high ceilings and a loft like second level of tables.  There are both private and community tables as well as bar seating, so there's something for everyone.

The food and drinks really stand on it's own. The immediate success of ths location is because the food is so good at the Valencia location which opened years ago with continued success to this day.  My favorite is the Egg Dosa w/ Cheese.  I also love the Masala and Paneer Dosa.  And don't miss their happy hour w/ appetizer and drink specials that are sure to bring satisfaction to both your wallet and taste buds.  It's a great value.
author: Van T.

description: Crowded place on a Saturday night. That said, the bar seating opened up by the time we wrapped up our first round of drinks. Tried the spinach & fennel dosa at the recommendation of the bartender. Delicious! Came with a spicy sauce, and tomato and coconut dips. Yum. Also got a lentil & sprout salad, fresh, non-oily and d-e-l-i-c-i-o-u-s. The woman next to me at the bar said that Dosa's cocktails are amazing. I was having a wine night so I guess I'll just have to try the cocktails another night soon.
author: Erin W.

description:
I keep to my word, and had a much more pleasant time!  I met up with a few friends who already sat down and saved me a spot (so I bypassed my former problem there).  The front of the house man, maybe the owner or manager was really attentive and was smoozing as appropriately.  

My favorite part about Dosa is the ambiance.  They did a wonderful job setting up the place, the high ceilings and lighting make the atmosphere relaxing and enjoyable.  Most importantly, that place is well ventilated.  I have long hair and whenever I leave indian restaurant, I smell like a spice rack.  Dosa is probably the first real Indian restaurant I've been to and didn't have to go home and wash my hair.  Thank you for that :)

The cocktails are really fun and well crafted.  We did family style so I got a chance to try the paper masala, onion rava, a curry and veggy dish.  The dips were really cool too for the dosa entrees.  

The restaurant is on the pricier side, which is understandable since the space is really cool.  I live nearby and walk past the restaurant regularly and it's amazing to see how happening this place is.  I'm glad there's an indian restaurant in the hood and I foresee this place staying awhile and becoming a Flllmore establishment.
author: Laura H.

description:
Very, very good. everything we had sitting at the bar (about 3 or 4 dishes) we're all excellent. As well the Pinot Noir was exactly my flavor. On top of that, the bartender and servers we're excellent. The bartender took the initiative and made sure we had everything we needed without asking. To me, that will make up for anything that is off... and nothing was off. Everything was spot-on.

Just get there before 6 or you will never get a seat...
author: Adam X.

description:
Well, I'm back visiting the Bay Area since my sister moved here, and she took us to this new restaurant. It was nice and clean. 

But the service was atrocious. The hostess ignored us and then the waiter rushed right past us. It took 20 minutes to get service, so I asked to speak to the manager and she berated us! I was really shocked. We said we were going to leave, even though by then the appetizers were just being delivered, and she snatched away the appetizers!

So we went up the street to La Mediterranee and it was delicious (though it took a while to get food, so we were pretty hungry by then.)
author: John J.

description: Best place to have South Indian food especially Dosa! LOVED IT!
author: R N.

description: Good customer service: telling the customer the drink total, stating the denomination of the bill he's being handed, saying to the customer what his change is, not giving the customer incorrect change, not having to be tracked down in order for the customer to obtain a copy of the bill.  These things were not in evidence the night that I visited DOSA.
author: Bea B.

description:
"This looks like the kind of a restaurant you'd find in NYC," I tell my friend, looking up at the feathery white, iridescent chandelier hanging from the ceiling.

"Yeah, totally.  Hey, doesn't that guy look like a pimp?"

"Where?"

"The one walking into Burger King."

Sure enough, across the street, A man dressed in a white suit, top hat, a red shirt and a cane walks into Burger King.

The Fillmore.  Karaoke Lounges.  Yoshi's.  Safeway.  Japan Town Center.  Pimps.  At the crossroads of Japantown, Fillmore, and Western Addition, there's little that surprises me anymore--since everything's out of place, nothing's out of place.  Dosa is no exception.

At Dosa, you'll find an affluent, well-dressed crowd, a fancy interior complete with a trendy communal dining table, and the menu to match.

But how's the food?  It's OK.  A party of 8, we all sampled each others' dishes including a variety of dosas (a buttery Indian crepe, filled with everything from chick peas to masala to cheese); curried lamb, duck, and chicken.  While some of the dishes were either too salty, spicy, or heavy on the ghee, we all agreed on the curry duck, coconut rice to go with our entrees (even though the menu sometimes suggests otherwise), and the sada paper dosa.

The bill came out to about thirty bucks a head.  I would recommend Dosa for the ambiance, but it's a hard sell when you have pimps walking into Burger King across the street.  As for the food, I've had better Indian food that tasted a lot better for a lot less.

Maybe things would be different if Dosa were here in a different time or place.  But for now, three stars it is.

UPDATE:  So I get an email from Anjan, one of the owners of Dosa, who writes, "I'm sorry we made so many mistakes with your dishes.  You should have sent them back and we would have gladly remade them for you." He continues, "We are the ONLY Indian restaurant that uses primarily organic, natural and/or sustainable ingredients, hence the higher prices."

An email like this actually means a lot to me--there have been several times when owners of businesses I've yelped either a) tell me how I should write my reviews or b) fail to address what rubbed me the wrong way.  Anjan didn't do either--in fact, gave me a reason to want to come back.  That earns another star in my book.
author: Tony L.

description: Seriously mixed feelings about this place and mostly due to service. With advance reservations and three tables empty, the hostess tries to sit us at the table by the bus area and kitchen door. Seriously?! We have to say no can we have a quieter table. I do not understand that. Then to make matters worse they take forever to bring my boyfriends drink, which means the rest of the table with wine is waiting. The tables are also very close and crowded, you have to move them so people can get in and out easily. With that being said, the food is pretty fantastic. I loved the sauces, the Dosa was great. How can you go there and not order a version? Everything we ordered was delicious and we left very full. The atmosphere of the place is great with the exception of feeling crowded.
author: Natasha M.

description:
Dosa is solid, a place you can count on for delicious cocktails and tasty south Indian food. As someone who doesn't care much for northern Indian eats, Dosa was the first southern style spot I tried and turned me onto how awesome dosas and uttapams really are, especially when served with fresh vegetables and flavorful dipping sauces. I like bringing out-of-towners to Dosa, as it tends to be a crowd-pleaser. I can't recommend the entree-type curries, but only because I stick with small plates (the fire broth and bright salads) or the right half of the menu (dosas + uttapams).

I like the communal table, I like the bar, and I like the normal tables, too. I don't like to wait here, so typically opt for one of the first two options unless we've made a reservation.

The service can be off and I've had water poured on me (and a cocktail, accidentally, too) and seen it dumped on others (as in, a full pitcher down a guy's back at a neighboring table the last time I was in).
author: Allie H.

description:
My short and sweet review:

I got here around 7 on a Thursday (with a reservation) and waited for about 20 minutes to be seated. 

Atmosphere/decor were amazing; modern, sleek and a wonderful spot for a date. Parking was decent, with free meters in the area after 6. 

Every single piece of food that my group of four had here was excellent; the waiter was informative and the appetizers/main course were great. 

If you're looking for cocktails, be prepared to pay. 

THE SCOOP: Any of the dosas are great, the prices are moderate and the ambiance is perfect for a date night.
author: Tom A.

description:
Here's how my Saturday went: First to a party in Inverness at around Noon (but not before we made an obligatory stop at Drake's Bay for some fresh oysters and hot sauce.) 

We left Inverness at 4:30 to make a 6:00 dinner reservation with 4 other friends at Dosa. Then across the street to the Kabuki to see The Reader (HELLO. Kate Winslett in multiple sex scenes), and then back to Oakland to the Conga Lounge at 11, where another group of friends thought "80s night" would be fun.  

Right.  Because I just can't get enough Toto and Styx in my life. 

I only sound like I'm complaining. Every once in a while, I secretly enjoy cramming way too much crap in to a day. 

Dosa was a very civilized bright spot in the day. I had high hopes for it since the friend who organized it is a professional chef, and another is South Indian, but he grew up in Kenya so he was basically worthless, except for tormenting the waitress with his fake Indian accent.

And speaking of the waitress, she was awesome.  I love it when servers confidently make recommendations in a place like this where the food is unfamiliar, and know the menu - including wine list - inside and out.  Cute doesn't hurt either. 

She was so good that she talked me in to the incredibly tasty Bengali Gimlet made with gin, a substance I have sworn off ever since I was 14 and drank half a bottle out of my parent's liquor cabinet.

Where is this even going? I seem to be losing focus here. 

The restaurant is beautiful.  Long silvery bar, high ceilings, lots of space. This is way more my style than the more cramped Valencia location. We had a few different dosas, all excellent. The highlight for me was the Chennai Chicken starter and the Kerala fish with coconut sauce, cilantro & chiles. Yes please. I was also happy to be able to order some leafy greens, which is usually missing from Indian restaurant menus. The mixed greens with mango & goat cheese totally hit the spot. 

Now I just want to spend the day doing nothing but watching the Super Bowl and nursing my hangover. 

Oh right.  Two Super Bowl parties.

Is it wrong to look forward to Monday?
author: Jay Z.

description:
I've been a few times- tasty food, if slightly over priced before seeing a movie at Kabuki. 

In any event, I made an Opentable reservation for 7 for tomorrow- I received a confirmation call today from Dosa, and asked very politely if I could squeeze 8 at the table. I got the least friendly response of 'Well, the reason you couldn't get an Opentable reservation for 8 is because the table only seats 7. If you are going to have 8, we will have to find another time for you to dine. It's definitely going to be later.' There was no suggested time, solution-oriented chipper tone, etc. Nada.

This is 30 hours in advance at Dosa on Wednesday night- are you kidding?

To rub it in, we literally just walked into far superior Frances this evening and had the nicest meal at the bar- appears Dosa doesn't care about its patrons; so I guess they don't care about the cancellation I just dialed in for tomorrow!!
author: Chuck H.

description:
I'd heard mixed things about Dosa but as an Indian/Paki food connoisseur, I had to give it a shot. My husband and I did the tasting menu so that we could try a little of everything and the break down went something like this...

1. The modern twist on appetizers is refreshing, fun and delicious.
2. The dosas are massive and could basically be your entire meal...they are cooked to perfection and the accompanying chutneys are the bomb (yes I just said that).
3. The curries are good, but definitely Americanized and a little too pretty for my taste.
4. The desserts are awesome. I love the cardamom chocolate gelato!
5. The service and decor are great. Really fun, inviting and good for groups.
author: Sara W.

description: I've been working with Dan, the event manager for Dosa for a few days finalizing the reservation for a large party. I have to say, it's been both an easy and pleasurable experience. He's been able to accommodate our very particular expectations and has been flexible and helpful to make sure our group has the best dining experience possible. I'd highly recommend Dosa for a large group!
author: Cong M.

description: Excellent food in a beautiful atmosphere. Service was great too. You MUST try the ISABELLA cocktail!
author: Anna S.

description:
Tried this location and it was great! The one on Valencia is more dim in it's lighting, but the food is just as good. You really can't go wrong with either one. The staff was real nice and helpful in choosing dishes since i wasn't too familiar with the menu items. 
 Tried the frankie and the cauliflower and it was quite yummy. Loved the pompoms! 
 The atmosphere is definitely a hangout for after work drinks or a nite on the town. It is upscale enough that you can be casual or slightly dressed up and you won't stand out!
author: V. P.

description:
We've had two excellent meals here.  Each dish has presented a variety of flavors, served with sauces that complement, but don't overwhelm, the main dish.  We've eaten mostly at off-peak hours; at peak hours, the cavernous space might be pretty noisy, especially if, as I've heard is common, there's a big crowd around the bar.

The decor is swanky but not overwhelming, and the wine list offers a nice variety of things to try.  Give some thought to the four-course tasting menu on the cover of the menu; a series of wine pairings is available with it.  Also, if you opt for the tasting menu, keep in mind that not everyone at the table needs to order the same four items; this is not obvious from the way the menu is worded.
author: Daniel M.

description:
Architecturally, this place knows how to make a good impression. As a confession, I didn't even know what a dosa was before coming here. I used to live in the Western Addition and have probably walked by this spot dozens and dozens of times. It's hard for me to believe that Dosa used to be a Goodwill store. Yes, its remodel really is that good. 

Luckily, its location and decorations isn't the only thing that's fabulous about Dosa - the menu definitely doesn't disappoint. I had the biggest Indian crepe, (also known as a DOSA) here last night and enjoyed my meal inside the restaurant's upstairs section. The upstairs eating section is much more intimate than the ground floor. Sitting upstairs places you in arms length to a private bar, and it gives you a great view of diners eating below on the bottom floor. 

The ambiance is dark in here, the lights are dim and small votive candles are placed at your table to give off an intimate feeling. Probably best to bring a date or some close friends. 

The culinary stars of my dinner last night were without a doubt the Red Beet Soup and the chutney's that came with the North and South Samosas. I loved the spices that slowly burn your mouth and turn your tongue into jelly. The spicy dosa I ordered was really fun to eat dipped into the lentil dipping soup it comes with. It may be primal of me, but I've just always loved eating food with my hands. It just seems like a dosa is just perfect for that since it's essentially an Indian version of a crepe. I'll definitely be back - after all, there's just so much more to the menu to try.
author: Laura G.

description:
Went here last night with a couple of friends. For a sunday, it was really busy, but then again, Michael Bauer's review did just come out in the paper giving the place an overall of 2.5 stars. 

The space is fantastic. Great vibe, cool bar area and I love the concept behind the communal table. Only drawback is that at most places with communal seating, it serves as a first come, first serve type of deal, however at Dosa, it is used for reservations. 

We started at the bar with a drink, as we arrived a little earlier than our reservation time. The drinks were nice and refreshing, really light, but not very strong. We didn't have to wait long to be seated.

Being our first time at Dosa and not really knowing what to expect, or to order for that matter, we decided on the tasting menu with the wine pairings. We all got something different, so with the three of us, we were able to taste a good amount of the food. 

Starters were good. We opted for the mung beans, crab cake and chicken. Crab cake was all crab and it came with this habanero chutney that is amazing. I absolutely love spicy food and it was soooooo good. It was so good, that I asked for a side of it (which they ended up charging me for, and took away from me in the middle of the meal as they were clearing, so that was a little disappointing). 

Next were the dosas and my friends and I have never had them before. We didn't really know what to expect, we tried 3 different ones and my favorite of the three was the Spring dosa. It was crisp on the outside and the veggies were really good. The different chutneys were good, however I didn't really care for the coconut chutney. 

For our third course we had the lamb, fish and chicken curries. The Lamb was the best of the three, but the fish was really moist and literally melted in your mouth. The lemon basmati rice is delicious. 

As for the wine pairings with each course, I probably wouldn't do it again. I would have rather gotten a bottle of a dry sweet wine for the first two courses and then perhaps move onto a red, but you could drink a white for the whole meal, since most of the meal is has a lot of spice. 

We ended with the three different desserts on the tasting menu and the best was the chocolate sorbet. The fried milk dough ball was a little too sweet and sits in syrup. On the menu it states that you get two balls, but we only got one. The rasmalai cheese dessert was not suited to my taste but you can't beat chocolate, so that's what I liked. 

Overall the meal was good. Service was good, our server knew the menu and food well. We enjoyed ourselves on a rainy sunday evening and I will definitely find myself there again. I'm interested to know what lunch is like, since the menu is a bit different.
author: Jennifer T.

description:
It is crazy to think that this swanky space used to be the grungy Goodwill. It's gorgeous! Just think NOPA gone sexy.

We popped in here to salvage a girl's movie night that had been disappointing (note: you can wait to rent He's Just Not That Into You) and Dosa left us on a high note. We walked in and were seated in under 5 minutes. I had a delicious vodka cocktail called Bollywood Hills that had a distinctly Indian Spice to it. Be warned, it packs a punch!

Once we were seated we ordered a bottle of champagne, and I had a potato dosa. I thought it was a single person serving, but it would feed at least 2! The flavor was impeccable, and all three dipping sauces it was served with offered a fantastic variety. 

I can't wait to go back for a full meal!
author: Kelly C.

description:
$5 cocktails and snacks at happy hour? why haven't i been coming here more? they do one special cocktail for the happy hour price, last week's was amazing: bourbon, maple syrup, mint and muddled blood orange. i coulda drank those honies all night. 

about 8 of us gathered here for bookclub. since we had just read shantaram we felt indian food was in order. (side note: read shantaram--it's amazing).

i've eaten at dosa probably 3 or 4 times now and never gotten around to reviewing it. every time the food is good, but not spectacular. i'm a big fan of the dosas. my favorite so far is the paneer and peas. it's kind of like a decadent indian burrito. i also loved the lamb meatballs, which are really succulent and nicely spicy. the pepper chicken dish i found a bit too salty, but others seemed to dig it. i'm not huge into potatoes in my indian food, but if you are you'll find lots of them here. they're into the sustainable movement, so you're getting quality meats, veggies and homemade yogurt which i can totally get behind. 

i have to say it's the setting that's really spectacular. it's such a gorgeous swanky-chic restaurant. i love those giant light fixtures that dangle from the ceiling like jellyfish. they make what could be a cavernous space really feel intimate and that soft lighting is helping everyone. it's a good place to get a little dressed for, altho i wouldn't call it a special occasion restaurant, more just city fabulous. 

more happy hours here are definitely in order.
author: rachel p.

description:
I have experienced better Indian food; however, it's not to say that this place does NOT deliver, because they surely do.  A friend and I went to dinner here the other night b/c both of us have been dying to try it.  It's right in our "hood" and so, why not?
I was very excited that the hosts held my table for us, as I was 30 minutes late due to parking.  FYI, if you can walk, do it.  I should have, but was being a wuss about the cold and decided to drive, which delayed our reservations by 30 minutes!

*Moving on*

My friend had the four course meal and I had a mixed salad and the Halibut plate.  I have to say, my salad was AMAZING!!  I would definitely recommend it.  It was with walnuts and goat cheese, with a cilantro dressing.  MmMMmm...
My Halibut was excellent as well, not over spicy and to me, that's a big deal when you're going Indian.  It came with coconut rice which was one of my favorite flavors of the evening!  

My friend had the lamb plate for dinner, which was absolutely fantastic!  I was a bit jealous, but I was still very happy.  We both had the dessert with cheese and cream sauce.  Starts with an "R" and I cannot pronounce it, sorry.  But, yumm...:)

Ambiance was great, it wasn't too noisy and that was GREAT!  We sat upstairs which has it's own bathrooms and bar.  Perfect!

Only true downer and that is why I am giving it the three stars and not four stars; our service.  It seemed like things took  a little bit when we asked for a refill on wine or when we asked for our check.  I don't know, call me picky, but it could have been a bit smoother than it was.

other than that, the night was fantastic, the food great and yes, I recommend it to you yelpers out there!!
author: Kat M.

description: Despite its polished atmosphere, fancy robotic door, and trendy decor, the food here is actually no frills- a homage to simple and standard traditional southern Indian fare at very reasonable prices.  This is not negative as it's refreshing to see a place that sticks to what works and not attempt another fusion experiment.  Try any of the dosas with their different combination of spices.  This is a great place for a night out with friends without breaking the bank.
author: Mike B.

description:
Don't expect your traditional "Naan and Curry" type Indian restaurant when strolling into Dosa.  First off, you'll notice the front doors swing open automatically, exposing you to a new world...

I recommend asking your server what exactly a "dosa" is.  I still have yet to understand it.  They're plates with meant to be shared, that's all I know.  Between four of us we ordered 2 dosas, an appetizer, and 2 entrees.  The food was quite interesting; unlike anything I've ever had.  They certainly put a unique twist on Indian food.  For example, I ordered the paneer with peas expecting the traditional curry dish but got a large fried, crispy sheet with peas and potatoes.   It was good, but I wanted my damn curry.  The "puffy bread" dish is quite a sight and delicious with the sauces and chutney they provide.  The prices are a bit steep for what you're getting.  

At the end of the day I prefer those hole-in-the-wall Indian dives (Shalimar, for instance).
author: Scott G.

description:
I'm always a little skeptical when a restaurant tries to be modern and hip while still serving traditional dishes.  The decor is very nice, and not what you expect out of your typical Indian restaurant.  The chandeliers are very eye catching, and you wonder if you're going to spend an arm and leg for a couple morsels of food.

We didn't really know what to order, so we asked our server for suggestions.  She was very friendly and gave us suggestions for each category of the menu.  We ended up ordering almost everything she suggested and were very pleased!

Starters:
Papadam - I think everyone gets a plate of these and they were fresh and delicious! 
Crab Vadas - pretty good crab cakes, but didn't blow me away
Chennai Chicken - the chicken is very tasty, but I wish they gave us more!
Dahi Vada - mmm, one of my favs. I love lentils and yogurt!

Dosa & Uttapam:
Masala Dosa - I like the Dosa itself, but the filling was boring
Paneer & Pees Dosa - Pretty good, I liked this Dosa better
South Indian Moon Uttapam - I like that you get a variety, pretty good, but I prefer the Dosa

Entrees:
Tamil Lamb Curry w/lemon rice: The lamb was super moist and the flavor of the curry was very good.  The lemon rice was pretty good and was a good match.
Kerala Fish Moilee: Yum!  The curry is delicious and the fish was sooo moist!  Probably my fav dish of the evening.  The coconut rice was delish too.

Dessert:
Beet Halwa & Sago Payasam - We decided to try something different, and it definitely was.  I recognized all the familiar flavors of Indian desserts - it was just OK.  I prob wouldnt order it again.

Overall the food here is great!  Surprisingly, the prices aren't as outrageous as I expected.  Although the entrees are a little on the pricey side, the portions are decent.  The service was excellent, and our food came out at a good pace.  Oddly, they were playing pop music (Bjork, JT, Smashing Pumpkins) but I guess it's ok if you're trying to attract the young hip crowd.  Seemed pretty busy for a Sunday evening, so they must be doing well.  I'll definitely go back to try some more dishes!
author: Mai S.

description:
Definitely one of the best Indian restaurant I have been to in the bay area (and you can take my word for it as I know my Indian food real good). 

The restaurant is pretty upscale and pricey but totally worth the money. The food is very tasty and pretty authentic. I wasn't expecting such good food from a pricey upscale restaurant but I was extremely impressed. I tried the Manglorean prawn curry with coconut rice and should say I give it a full 5/5.
author: Sandeep A.

description: Well - in short, it's a place that's trying to be what it is not. The setting and ambience are definitely good, and the servers try to be at their best, but I couldn't care for all the hype if all your genuine attempts still fall short. I tried the Rava Dosa, which is my barometer for how good you are at dosas, and it was a 3/5 - which is, not too bad. Next was the Hyderabadi Chicken Biryani - which was not even a 1/5. Too salted, no biryani flavor, et al. All this would have been still fine if the servers hadn't taken over 5 minutes to re-fill my glass with wine, as well as just taken the glass away after 2 drinks without caring to ask if I'd like some more. So, overall, meh. There are tons of better Indian cuisine options in the bay area without the pretentions and hype that this place fails to deliver on.
author: V K.

description:
Dined here with 8 colleagues recently (may-2012). Reservations are necessary for a larger parties. For this big a group they have space on their second floor. Menu is filled with South Indian dishes with a choice of rice or dosa or uthappam. Among the eight of us, we ordered a variety of dishes, such as lamb, chicken and duck. Although the preparations were great (and very spicy), I was not thrilled at all by the presentation of any one of our dishes. Food was extremely spicy, and little appalling to us was that our server did not tell us about the spice level or did not give us a choice to decide. Rice that came with the dishes was great testing. In all, for the non-Indians among us, the food spice level was little troubling.
Cocktails at this place was out of this world: we ordered Moksha and Divya: without knowing much about them from the names. But both turned out to be too good. They were truly work of arts.
In short, I would return to the place to try out other dishes, but not truly impressed by the hype, and the cost is not justified unless it's a corporate dinner. And, to be frank, if you want to impress your corporate guests, you would be better off having cocktails here and dining at Amber India on 4th/Market st.
author: Achal P.

description:
My friends put together a fabulous bachelorette party dinner for me here, so I guess I should be writing a Yelp review of my friends. Since I can't, I'll just sing the praises of the "new" branch of Dosa. 

Yeah, yeah, the food is somewhat "nontraditional," but it's GOOD. Cheers to this Dosa for having a full bar with yummy cocktails (I had far too many of the Bollywood Hills, but they were so good!) and for the beautiful space.

Great date spot!
author: Vandana M.

description:
So its 09 now. Time to get cracking on the resolutions. 

1. Lose 30 lbs this year. 
2. Save a bunch of $$$. 
3. Do more community service. 
4. Get to REALLY know your friends. 

Well Dosa won't help me w/ most of those, but at least I know where to go in case I feel like cheating. ;) 

So I'm here to kick it w/ the wonderful Linda T, who is visiting from So Cal. I have never had south Indian food, so I didn't know what to expect. 

First impression. "Wow, this place is posh." Brand spanking new everything. Clean as a whistle. Huge interior w/ high ceilings. 

The place was full of people, but it didn't see too cramped for me; nobody looming over the table, nobody giving the evil eye when we were chatting over dinner, no waitress taking plates off our table prematurely. This was a plus. 

So I decide on having the Paneer and Peas Uttapam (sorta hard to describe, but it tasted like a potato pancake w/ farmer's cheese and peas. Served w/ some great sauces. It was light and tasty. The sauces were each very different. The white sauce was sweet w/ a slight coconut milk taste, the orange sauce was more tangy w/ a taste of curry. The soup-like sauce was well....soupy *Dam, I should have taken notes*. Despite it being completely vegetarian, it didn't lack in flavor at all. I was completely full after the meal. 

I wouldn't say it's a cheap place, but w/ the fresh ingredients, the time and care spent in cooking the food, the ambiance, the space, the light friendly atmosphere...you are definitely getting what you pay for. Now if only I can find a date to take here.....
author: Angelo F.

description:
