I've eaten here many many times and everything (e-v-e-r-y-t-h-i-n-g) is just fantastic. Cocktails are fabulous - Bengali Gimlet is my fave - food is divine and service is excellent. 

5+
author: Lili G.

description:
I have been neglecting my Yelp duties for the past few weeks, but with good reason I promise. My company went out of business and I have joined the ranks of the fastly growing unemployed. I recognize this should leave me plenty of time to be Yelping my brains out, however I found it depressing to sit back and review the amazing restaurants and bars that I will be taking hiatus from in my time of poverty. Sigh...

The good part about being unemployed is that people feel bad for you and want to do things to try and "help." For my friends this means either getting me good and drunk or fed...or both. A few nights ago, my best friend Billy told me he was going to succeed at getting me tossed and full of delicious food. I happily and eagerly agreed. In the cab over, I casually asked what type of cuisine we would be enjoying that evening. Japanese? Mexican? Thai? Persian? Any of these would rock my world. Billy simply responded with "You'll see." 

We pulled into Japantown and my mouth began to water with thoughts of grilled seabass and salmon sashimi, but the minute Billy held the door open to a place called "Dosa" my expression dropped.

I should probably tell you now that I generally loathe Indian food. This isn't just a disliking of the cuisine, it is a profound hatred. For whatever reason, it turns my stomach...normally. It is here that I humbly admit I may have turned a corner in my battle with Indian food. 

Billy ushered me straight to the bar and proceeded to pour bottles of wine and martini glasses brim full of Manhatten's and other delicious inebriations down my throat. He's a smart boy and knew that the only way he would survive this dinner was to start by getting me good and plowed. The bar scene is over the top Hollywood-esque. I love the energy and artwork in this restaurant. It's very visually stimulating.

Finally our reservation was called and we moved to the table. The waitress introduced herself and was extremely friendly. I proceeded to embarass Billy by grabbing her sleeve and asking her assistance in ordering as "I can't stand Indian food." Rather than turning up her nose at me, she smiled, laughed and told me she hears this multiple times a day. She quizzed me on things I like and don't like and took the menu from my hand. "I'll take care of you honey."

To start, samosas with some sort of sweet and tangy sauce that I loved. Along side, she had ordered me a salad with mango and nuts. If it isn't authentic, I don't care...I ate every last fork full. Then came what they are famous for which is the "Dosa." To me it looked like a giant empanada with three sorts of dips alongside (forgive me, half my extended family is from Argentina). One of the dosas that came out the waitress warned me was "waaaaay spicy" and contained habaneros and mango. Again, probably not authentic but I was down for the challenge as I love spicy food. I popped a bite in my mouth, and it definately came with a kick but nothing painful.

Overall I had an excellent night at Dosa and appreciate Billy for basically trapping me into trying it out. Perhaps I have changed my mind about Indian cuisine....either that or I have mastered ordering the most non-traditional items on the menu to keep me happy. 

Bonus points for being across the street from the Kabuki theater...my fave.
author: Lynsey C.

description:
My friends and I came here for Sunday brunch and we really enjoyed the food, ambiance and service. Dosa serves Southern Indian food so there is no such thing as Naan in the southern part of India. We ordered the Chicken Frankie, Chicken Biryani, Spring Dosa and Masala Uttapam. My favorite is the is Frankie (chicken, onion, cucumber & cilantro wrapped in roti bread and sauce)--delicious. The Chicken Biryani is sort of like the indian fried rice with chicken drumstick, onion and spices. The Spring Dosa is very refreshing and the vegetables (peas, carrots, cabbage and red onion enclosed in a crepelike wrapping) are very crunchy. The Masala Uttapam is a pancake with potatoes, onions, nuts and spices--very tasty.  Four stars for really tasty and flavorful food.

The ambiance here is really nice with Chandeliers and beautiful hanging golden leaf displays (4 stars.)

Service is good the waitress kept on coming back to ask if we needed additional food and refilling water. Did not get to try the dessert because we ordered quite a lot of food and the portions are large (4 stars.) I will definitely come back next time to try dinner.
author: Allison H.

description:
FLAMING HOT.

That's how I would describe the habanero mango dosa.  Thinking it'd only register as pleasantly hot given my penchant for spicy food, I inwardly smirked when the waitress paused to warn us it was very spicy.  She wasn't kidding.  I think that starter seared a tastebud or two; I nearly asked for a bucket of ice to cool my tongue!

Thank goodness for the Bowler cocktail, which provided a little liquid relief from the burning.  It was a little sour for my taste, so I'll try something else the next time I go, but I'll give them credit for their inventiveness.  My friend's Batsman was more to my liking.

For entrees, we ordered the duck spinach masala & paneer and the tamil lamb curry, with a side of lemon rice.  It was extremely tasty.  The duck and lamb were both soft, moist and succulent, and the spices lent to the rich savoriness of the dishes.  Lemon rice was the perfect compliment, adding a nice brightness to balance out and complement the rich, spiciness of the main dishes.

The restaurant is definitely a place I'd go back to for ambience and cocktails, and higher-end Indian food.
author: Janet L.

description: Cocktails are amazing but you do have to pay for them! Ginger anti is one of the best drinks I've ever had. Tre spicy basil Dosa us do good wf had to order two extra orders! This place is beyond good! A little pricey but I would come back.
author: Julie B.

description:
A Review of the Tasting Menu at Dosa:

Abby and I live down the street and decided to choose Dosa as the site for a special celebration dinner. Seeing as it was a special occasion we opted for the four course tasting with accompanying wines.

While the tasting was fun and allows for a lot of freedom in choice (each person can order different items and wines), nothing that came out really lived up to the price tag, and as a whole, when I picture all four courses together they just don't equal what we paid for them in their quality, presentation, or originality.

The dosa was great, but was not enough to carry the meal. Plus, you can get the same dosa on their lunch menu (exact same dish) for pennies on the dollar. This was my main problem with Dosa's tasting menu, it wasn't anything special, it was just more money. Step it up!

The other dishes, a curry, some shrimp, two bland desserts, were ok, but not the kind of thing the price brings you to expect. Another fault was the seating, when you make a dinner reservation and are enjoying a four course meal you (or at least I) expect a table in the restaurant, but to my surprise we were seated in the bar, which might be great for sharing a few appetizers but is quite unsuitable for an actual dinner.

At the e end of the day the dinner for two consisting of four courses and matching wines (no dessert wine though? WTF!) put us back about $200. Its not that this is a crazy amount to pay for a meal, but in San Francisco there are just too many other great establishments that do a much better job for much less. A fact that makes it hard to stomach paying out such cash for a few tender tandori shrimp and micro greens.

That all said the food is good, and if you go at lunch or brunch you can get the same food we paid top dollar for at a much more fitting cost. And seeing as they make a delicious curry bloody-merry I am sure I will find my way back at some point, just not for dinner.
author: Alex D.

description:
So, after 4 visits to Dosa on Filmore, I had to make a decision as to just how much I liked the place. 
Food ~~ It's good. It's a little different than the mom & pop Indian restaurant. Is it great? Well, it's good, have I raved about it? Not really. If it comes up in conversation, I say it's good, I love the chandeliers, you know, the two that look like jellyfish floating over you... Do I say great things about the food. Not really. I like it, it's tasty, the Dosa is different, the drinks are good, and very interesting. 
Service ~~ so this is where the hit points come in. Service has been (believe it or not) spotty. As an example. We dined there last night. Our server says to us, that he thinks he waited on us before. My partner agrees it's possible. The server as he's talking to us I feel the spray of spittle on my cheek. Now, this happens in life. We all have those embarrassing moments where something like this happens. I KNOW this, so I say nothing, and after he leaves, I wipe my cheek, and enjoy my drink & conversation. The server returns later in the evening, and yes, low and behold it happens AGAIN! OK, so this time I'm a little concerned b/c it happens so frequently. I tell my partner who is immediately grossed out. As it is, the server happens to have the table next to us too. He is telling them about how the owners of Dosa follow Yelp regularly. Our server never comes back to refill my water (ever), and until after I'm done with the main course does he happen back to ask if I want another drink. 
NOT very good service. It he really waited on us before, and did this poorly prior. I doubt I would have come back. I'm amazed that he talked about the owners being concerned by what was said on Yelp, and still he did a poor job with service. 
I guess his bosses read Yelp, and he doesn't.
author: Jim H.

description:
Tasty dosas, beautiful light fixtures, hilariously loud hand dryers that sound like jet engines, and a friendly and pleasant owner can't make me come here again.

Charging 20% service charge (i.e. tip) for parties of five or more.  Yes, five people not the usual "parties of 8 or more".
Paying sales tax on said service charge.
The 4% tacked on to the bill for the SF health care surcharge.
In addition, there are the usual things that accompany anyone not from SF dinning in the City: toll booths, traffic and finding parking.  

There is a restaurant that serves roasted crab in garlic butter in the City that is so good and no other place I've been comes close to it.  I have and will continue to gladly deal with traffic, tolls and parking for that dish.  Good dosas aren't hard to find on my side of the bay.  I read the reviews.  I knew finding free parking would be difficult.  I clicked on Dosa's web link from their Yelp page and they are upfront about the various charges.  If your wondering why I still ate here it's because a dear sweet Yelper was in town for a visit and we wanted to have dinner with her.  The restaurant location was perfect for her and she enjoyed the food.  The company I was with and the entire evening (we hit a lot of other places in the Fillmore that night) was five stars.

So Dosa when it comes to the trouble I need to go through to get the food compared to the food itself  "I'm just not that into you."
author: Rachel R.

description:
Hmm... 3 stars or 4... tough decision.

The not so good:
* Our first attempt to eat here was thwarted by a ridiculous (1+ hour) wait.  Our second attempt, I made a 10 PM reservation, and we were still seated late.
* You can get cheaper, less Americanized Indian food elsewhere.

The good:
* Despite the fact that the food is not what I expect from an Indian restaurant, it is still very delicious.
* Everything is so pretty, from the chandeliers to the artwork.
* The mixed drinks are delicious and very interesting.
* They use real saffron!
* I enjoy going somewhere that merits wearing a dress.

So I'll give them four stars for making it a lovely date night for my boyfriend and me.  Try the paneer and peas dosa.  Their paneer was incredible!
author: Christena T.

description:
Wow.  What a pretty restaurant.  And what amazing food.  I really loved this place.  Worth mentioning: I am *no* expert on Indian food.  That said, every bite was so flavorful & delicious.  We started with some interesting cocktails.  The two winners were the Bowler, a pisco cocktail containing mango gastrique among other things which was in no way sugary sweet and the Juhu palm, a gin cocktail with coconut milk, kaffir lime & chili (again, not sugary sweet).

We had the cochin calamari appetizer and we pretty much wolfed it down.  Soooo good.  Next was south indian moons, 5 varieties of uttapam served with three dippers...a coconut goo that was epic, a tomato puree with some bite and a lentil soupy thing...I just wanted to stick my face into each one.

Following that came channa bhatura, chickpea masala that came with a giant puffy bread thing.  Omg, this was sooooo good, I was eating giant scoops of it.  A teeny bit spicy, which was fine with me.  I like my food VERY hot.

Next was the bagara baingan, an eggplant puree that I could eat every day.  We had it with a plain dosa, which was perfect.

At this point, everyone was pretty much stuffed, so we bagged the final dosa we orignally ordered, the spicy mung masala.  But based on everything else, I would so just go for it.  The food was really, really good.

Oh, and I just noticed upon googling them to view the menu that they do a BRUNCH.  Whaaaaaaa?!?!  I'll defs let you know.
author: Emily T.

description:
The last time I was in the Dosa building it was a Goodwill (now across the street), so it was a bit of a shock to see it so completely transformed. It's funny to think that I used to try on clothes where the kitchen is now located. The current space is beautiful, with gorgeous lighting and atmosphere. The obvious money that went into it seems to be worth it, because even late on a weekday evening it was so crowded that we had to sit at the communal table in order to avoid a 20-minute wait. 
Having been to the Valencia location, I thought I knew what to expect food-wise. Maybe I ordered the right dishes this time, but it was much better than I remembered. I had the masala uttapam and my boyfriend had the spicy lentil dosa, and they were both excellent, with just the right amount of spice. Plus, the prices were more reasonable than I had remembered. Overall, a winner.
author: Rachel J.

description:
1. Make a reservation.

Ok, this place was great! It is total class right down to the mammoth chandeliers. It is somewhat restaurant/club with the swank attire of the patrons, the decor, and the club music. The food was extremely vegetarian friendly and nondairy. We did have to pay a $25 corkage fee, but it was worth it for having a bottle we knew that we would enjoy. 

I wish they had a location in Chicago, but this is the best Indian food that I've had in a long time. Highly recommend.
author: Michelle S.

description: I know there are some Dosa haters out there. But I am not one of them. (I'm only docking a point for the sometimes ridiculous amount of time it takes to wait for a table.) I have been to Dosa several times (this place is 2 blocks from me) ,and I'm never disappointed. I am stubbornly predictable each time... corn soup, chennai chicken, lamb kofta. If I'm with a larger group, I'll throw in the ridiculously addictive paper dosa. My favorite dish, however, is hands-down the lamb kofta. I could drink the thick, spicy tomato sauce that it's served in. I will literally use the dosa to wipe clean the entire dish. If you like Indian food (read: heat), then don't listen to the haters and take a chance on this upscale street food. Trust me.
author: shabnam m.

description:
I thought the company was the best part. Oh and the decor of Dosa - very lovely. 

They seated the 4 of us at a tiny table (in the front) where we were hardly able to place all the food on the table.. They had to bring it out in intervals. I mean really!

The service was mediocre. I think she forgot about us a few times. 

The food was just ok. I won't go back. Too many great places in SF, no need to return to this one.
author: Monica S.

description:
DOSA stands for Delicious Outstanding Superb Amazing

I had never eaten South Indian Cuisine before and I was absolutely thrilled with everything I tasted. The samosas were just spicy enough, and the dips were delicious. I had a basic dosa, the masala, and it was huge! I ate the whole thing though.....  

I loved my diet coke, it was a little bottle of something that wasn't a name brand, just loved it! The ambiance is really nice, I was with some girlfriends and we could talk and laugh without worrying about other people listening or getting upset that we may have been too loud. 

I like the fact that a lot of the food on the menu is vegetarian. I'm always on the lookout for good vegetarian places, I do eat meat but it can be so easy to cut it out too. YUMMY
author: Gabrielle C.

description:
Meeting up with my high school best friend after being away in HK for 5 months and getting totally spoiled by this renowned culinary capital of Asia...It was lunch time and we're gonna watch Moonrise Kingdom at Kabuki theatre, so she suggested Dosa right across the street. 

It was a little past noon and the place was already half full. I was still full from my late breakfast, so I just ordered an appetizer: Watermelon, Paneer and Mung Sprout Salad. My friend ordered the mini mustard green dosa. 

Here's what made my experience not so great: I requested to have my salad without the coconut and the waiter said "OK!". Then the salad came with the coconut. I wanted to complain but everyone seemed really busy, whatever...it's just a small salad.

My friend really liked her mini dosa though, and I may go back again to try that (that's what you're supposed to have when you go to a restaurant named "Dosa"...)

The dessert was very very interesting. It was made of vermicelli, raisons, spices in a pool of milky sweet coconut 'soup'. Again, I don't like coconut...so I'm probably not the best judge. I took a few bites and left the rest to my friend.

Good thing that I wasn't hungry..but I'm sure that my next trip here will be better, unless the waiter messes up my order again.
author: Lily X.

description:
i finally got the opportunity to dine here and it was a fun double date! although we had pretty late reservations (8:45pm on a friday), we still had to wait another 15 min or so before we were seated. this place is packed and def much larger and nicer ambiance than the mission location. we shared the dahi vada starter (lentil dumplings, topped with cool strauss organic yogurt, piped with tamarind & mint, mildly spiced), 2 types of dosas (masala and spicy mung), 2 south indian entrees (lamb curry and mango jumbo prawns), and the spring uttapam. my favorites were the veggie uttapam and dahi vada appetizer. the dosas were also tasty but i'm not much of a potato girl.

worth checking out but i may just stick to udupi palace for the raw deal.
author: Helen Y.

description:
Wow - so many things just busting up in my mouth! LOL  Dosa is off the hook.  

Starting with a bottle of Coume del Mas Quadratur Grenache.....Yum!....this dining experience only heightened my anticipation for the Harry Potter premiere i'd be attending across the street.

The flavors mixed up in the crab cakes and the calamari were incredible.  Being hispanic, i'm quite familiar with, and fond of, cumin and I always forget the large amounts used in so many Indian dishes.  

We split the chicken biryani which coupled with the yogurt "sauce" was absolutely perfect.  The flavors were mild and the chicken was tender and juicy.

We also order the chile & cilantro uttampam (?)....  oh.  my.  god.  it was good and the spiciest thing I have ever had in my life.  Even spicier than my homemade pozole when I go chile crazy.  I couldn't handle it.  Steer clear unless you've got an extremely high tolerance for pain.
author: Jimmie L.

description:
I went to Dosa for brunch and had a good experience. The decor is really amazing and I would imagine it is a great spot to go for late night cocktails or dinner. Brunch was just ok. There are only two items on the brunch menu that have meat in them which was a little disappointing. However, if you are a vegetarian this is the perfect spot for you. Prices are very reasonable and the service was ok. I had the chopped salad which was awesome and some sort of pancakey dish which was good. I would like to go back for dinner before forming a final opinion. But I think it will still stand with a solid 4 star rating.


Overall, it's a beautiful atmosphere, prices are good and it's right across the street from Kabuki. Definitely go into the bathroom because the choice of tile is really amazing. Be careful with the hand dryer. It's so powerful it just might rip your fingers off.
author: Kandace K.

description:
Interesting venue, great ambiance and decor, and good drink menu.... 

Went there on: Saturday
For: Dinner
# of ppl: 2
RSVP for the tables were fully booked so we grabbed a seat at the large table by the bar where we can enjoy the full menu.

Pros:
Exotic, interesting original cocktails, all pretty stiff too!
Crabcakes appetizer was quite tasty.

Cons:
Very loud and packed.  Was hard to have a conversation with my friend.
Their food are, IMHO, not worth the hype.  I had the duck paneer with the recommended lemon rice, and my friend had an uttapan.  My duck paneer was too heavy and salty to eat on it's own and the lemon rice was WAY to tart, so I had nothing to cleanse my palette.  I complained and got plain rice on the side, which helped me finish the dish.  My friend's uttapan was very interesting, kind of tasted in between pancakes and potato pancakes, and came with two bowls of what resembled chili.  they were all tasty, however they were not shockingly delicious, and my friend actually burned her tongue severely with one of the chili-looking things because it was piping hot, although, strangely, no steam was coming out from it.

All in all, this place is a fun place to come with a small group of girls to enjoy their cocktails and have a light meal (apps, dosa, uttapam, etc) but I wasn't too thrilled with their "south indian" entrees selection nor my paneer dish, and while they were spicey and heavy, they didn't quite fill my stomach in a satisfying way.

I actually very much enjoy the Indian buffet place a few stores down much better that's not at all fancy but run by Indian family and tastes like Indian food.
author: Sascha O.

description:
just stick to dosas which r fabulous.

Fish Moilee had the same tamarind base as the sambar which reduces the fish moilee to a sambar gone wrong. If you can't make Fish Moilee then don't call it Fish Moilee!

And who puts over sugary carrot halwa into over sugary payasam! Bad fusion!
author: priya j.

description:
I am fully aware that Dosa does not in any way rhyme with Rhonda....however, "help me dosa, help help me dosa" is what popped into this little head of mine as i began writing this review.

expansive and pretty dining room....subpar service (minus 1)....and a 40 tasting menu...YUM.

the chicken appetizer was spicy deliciousness and the dosa...ooooh delicious delicious dosa...i had the spring one (yum) and also the potato one (super yum)....followed it up by lamb curry (absolutely unappealing to look at but delicious) and coconut sorbet was a refreshing and light end to a delicious meal.
author: Brooke M.

description:
Seriously, being a south Indian I know what good south Indian food is, and dosa definitely was a big let down!! I read a lot of rave reviews so decided to check it out. I have been to dosa a couple of times now and feel that its way over priced for south Indian cuisine and whats really terrible is the fact that none of the dishes come close to authentic south Indian cuisine!!

If you are looking for a fancy place and south indian food for the sake of it then go for it. But otherwise, invest some time and head off to any south bay restaurants- way cheaper and tastier food!
So they 3 stars- well, great ambience and good service- pity the food is so unimpressive!
author: Dee N.

description:
Yay:
-Tasty food (Lamb kofta, coconut rice)
-Good acoustics (with the amount of people in there, I thought it'd be louder)
-Tasty drink (Ginger Ante for me)
-Got our food REALLY quickly

Not-so-yay:
-Duck was a bit salty
-45 minute wait. Would not take reservations from us while we were parking. 
-Lemon rice: too intense

Overall, a wonderful birthday date :)
author: Patricia E.

description: one of my favorite restaurants; the food is one of the best Indian foods and they have gluten and dairy free menu. I think the owners have done such a great job building a beautiful place and picking the menu. just love it
author: Maryam Z.

description:
Having just bought the tickets for "Slumdog Millionaire", we stepped outside the Kabuki theater to head towards our favorite pre-movie dinner spot. That's when I noticed "Dosa", right across the street and on the corner. 

Having had mixed reviews of the first location, best described as "having a heart of gold but sometimes walking with two left feet", we decided there was no better time to take that long overdue second chance, than at the second location. 

Here, the lights are dimmer, the ceilings higher, and everything is just so plush in hues of dark brown, gold, and warm orange. Huge icicle-like chandeliers hang from the ceiling in a multitude of tiny lights. Intricately designed metal carvings create texture along the walls. This is definitely a spot to see or be seen in. Elegant and trendy but in a good way. 

Tables are crammed up near each other so conversation can be a little difficult. Staff orchestrate themselves well across the narrow isles, making sure to tap their co-workers on the shoulder or back as they pass to avoid accidental knocks and spills. They were courteous and had a pretty good hand at knowing their wine selection and describing the dishes. Servers still needed a little nudge before they remembered to explain each uttapam that came in the "South Indian Moons" (chef's selection of 5), because god knows I can't deduce from plain sight, and the menu was taken away a long time ago. 

AND YES, YES, FINALLY THE FOOD... The food is self-described by website as "Southern Indian" with emphasis in dosas (like flat wheat-like crepes, lightly crisp, stuffed and rolled with a variety of fillings like paneer and spiced lentils) and uttapams (slightly thicker and smaller than dosas where ingredients are cooked right into the batter). These selections average $10 in price and come with a side of tomato chutney, coconut chutney (heavenly), and sambar (spicy liquidly lentil-flavored mixture). 

Basically if you're looking to drown yourself in thick curries, they have some on the menu, but the whole point is to expand beyond that and enjoy the adventure that ensues. Bring friends and order family-style, this food is best when passed around and shared. 

Looking back on our experience, we may have to change our pre-movie dining habits now... 

because this place is simply awesome.
author: ChiYan T.

description: Authentic food as well as great ambiance and service. Their cocktails and wine selections are very good as well.
author: Vijay D.

description:
I get asked occasionally for Indian restaurant recommendations, but am no help. For one thing, I don't see how anything can possibility beat my mom's macher jhol and my mashi's moog dal; for another, most of the Indian places around here are heavy on the North Indian cuisine (tandoori, creamy sauced curries, etc), which I avoid if possible.

My first and best memory of South Indian food was in Visag; the RKM guesthouse food was simple, but so fresh and flavorful that I've never forgotten it. I've tried the Udupi Palace locations in Berkeley and SF, as well as the Dosa on Valencia, but nothing matched up; my hard-to-please dad and forgiving-mom both said the Dosa on Valencia was okay, but didn't come close to this little Calcutta hole-in-the-wall where they used to go on dates. Yeah, right, because being in love had nothing to do with their happy memories!

Anyway, back to the review: I'll be glad to recommend Dosa on Fillmore to anyone who asks! The meal was consistently good; we liked every single dish and enjoyed all the different flavors.

Items sampled:
Bengali gimlet cocktail
Bollywood hills cocktail
Leek soup
Rasam
Samosas
Eggplant dosa
Paneer dosa
Mung dosa
Tamil veg curry
Pistachio gelato

My friend and I were unsure about the curry-flavored nectar in the gimlet, so the bartender let us have a taste. It was sweet and spicy and totally tasty, so I decided to get the gimlet. Actually, I started drinking my friend's bollywood hills cocktail by mistake, and then when I switched to the right drink, I couldn't really tell the difference. Most of that is due to inexperience -- I apparently can't differentiate between gin and vodka, hello -- but the overwhelming flavor I remember from both was lime juice. Which is delicious, particularly kaffir lime, but I wish the curried nectar was stronger in the gimlet.

The leek soup was creamy and delicious; the rasam was fiery and cleared up my friend's sinuses (I tasted it and was glad it wasn't too strong with the tamarind). The samosas were ehhh, good enough, but the two chutneys (tamarind and cilantro) were brilliant.

All the dosas were really tasty, although the eggplant seemed a little overwhelmed by potato. I enjoyed the presentation; the eggplant was a triangle, the paneer was shaped like eggrolls, and the mung was a traditional cylinder. Getting to eat with my hands and alternating with the tomato and the coconut (my personal favorite) chutneys ... so good.

Since it was my birthday, I said yes to the pistachio gelato. I don't really like kulfi, because of the problem with ice crystals, but the creamy gelato texture and rich pistachio flavor? Utter bliss. I thought about getting the rice pudding, because of the birthday "payesh" tradition, but I'm so glad I went with the gelato. If I had to pick a favorite part of the meal, this would be it.

Don't get me wrong, the whole meal was generally very strong. I wish I saw the final bill (my friends hid it), but I think it was about $140 for 4 people (including 3 drinks, tax, tip). So this qualifies as a once-in-a-while treat. I'm glad for the owner's sake that Dosa is so popular; however, I'm thankful that we went on a low-key Monday evening and missed the suffocating bustle of the hip and trendy. Anyway, I'll definitely come back, and bring my parents too. I wonder what they'll make of the Bengali gimlet.
author: S R.

description:
Interesting place, but quite honestly....Indian food should never be this pricey.  The Valencia location is nice...kinda intimate and calming.  

But the Fillmore location is exactly what I would expect the owners wanted it to be:  trendy, hip, loud, kinetic. Whether this translates into yet another ephemeral dining establishment or not remains to be seen.

The drinks at Fillmore: most are downright bizarre inventions.  Warning: the coconut milk martini-thingy sounds good....but....let it be a lesson:  crushed hot chili peppers in a milky cocktail just don't go together.  Stick with the more in-the-pocket drinks.

Kudos to:  their Pimms Cup drink (of course, they have to all it something else because calling it a Pimms Cup isn't hip enuff....but that's exactly what it is).  I think they call it a Smoky something-or-other....

Maybe the only place in SF which actually knows how to really make one of these  (besides 83 Proof)....

The staff:  nice, although I DO get a kick out of the fact that there is a traffic jam at the host station...and the jam being caused by the number of hosts/hostesses....not by awaiting customers.

The service:  depends.  YEOW, on a busy night (most are)....man...the kitchen goes seriously into "the weeds", as they say in the cheffin' biz.  

And once they go there, they are there for the night.  Dishes getting served to the wrong tables....dishes never appearing...dishes served out-of-sequence.

A note: the staff rushes you out.  I am guessing for a circus of this calibre, they need fast turnaround.  But if you are paying as much as you are for a meal here, and you have had to wait as friggin' long as you had to wait...you damn well deserve to sit at your table for as long as you like....and the management should well respect this.  Slow it down, folks...you make a killing either way.

The food:  yummy, but overpriced.  South Indian food is very different from what we all are used to....and it's quite good.  But, as for the authenticity of what Dosa serves...well....that's a bit dubious.  
It is, in my book, what much ethnic cuisine in SF is:  a dressed up, precious caricature of the authentic, real thing.  It's tasty, but gentrified; it's not quite the real thing. But worth trying nonetheless.

The architecture is cold and eccentric.  Nicest area to eat is the bar and bar tables or the loft.  DON'T allow yourself to get stuck at the long, bench-style table.  It's near enough to the door that a cold draft just hits it every time someone walks in  (you'd think for the $ they spent on the interior of the place, someone could have figured this out).  Also, nothing I like more than blowing $120 on a meal for two and having to sit "family-style" with a bunch of beautiful, buzzed, overdressed 20-something plastic people you don't know or have anything in common with (other than the fact that you ALL fell for the undrinkable coconut-milk-with-chilies cocktail for ten bucks)

Make sure you get a real table.  Go once...if nothing else than for the experience.  But if what you wanna do is have a nice meal at a nice place, go to Valencia.  Although, just for the experience of the generally chaotic, crowded yet visually/bizarrely stimulating atmosphere of the place, it's probably worth one trip. I guess that's about the best thing I can say about the Fillmore location...other than the obvious fact that it has made the Valencia a much nicer, calmer place.
author: El K.

description:
Dosa is certainly the trendiest Indian restaurant I have ever patronized, and I appreciated the nice ambience.  This, along with the endless plate of pappadam, earned Dosa a fourth star.  I tried both the sweet lassi and chai tea, both of which were as good as I've had at my favorite Indian restaurants.  

The rest of it was enjoyable enough.  The dosa and uttapam selection is wider than usual (as can be expected given the restaurant's name), and there were some interesting unique entrees, but all of that seemed to cut into the selection of the dishes more traditionally found on South Indian menus so that I found myself forced to try things I wouldn't normally try, which worked out fine, but not memorable (i.e., duck spinach masala & paneer).  

The dosas and uttapams are good.  The Chennai chicken is not as good as advertised.
author: Alice C.

description: Really like sitting at the bar and getting a few drinks / appetizers before heading across the street to Kabuki or around the corner to The Fillmore.  Really enjoyed the samosas, this tomato "salad" thing, lamb kafka, etc.
author: Kate B.

description:
I had a wonderful time, the wait staff was plesant, and the the food was very tasty. 
the only draw back is that the food was expencive for the portions.
however i will go back because i love indian food and the quallity is great.
author: Steve M.

description:
I must admit having traveled in Southern India to Bangalore and Kerala my first taste of Southern Indian cuisine was native.  So when I was told that the menu at Dosa was based upon the food of Southern India I was very pleasantly surprised and delighted.

My dinner date and I only had appetizers (heading to the nearby Kabuki Sundance Cinemas for a film afterwards) and so my review is of the appetizer section only.

I ordered Idli Samba and Vegetable Samosas with a side of Basmati Rice.  The food was, well, just okay.

Frankly, the dumplings in the Idli Samba were so heavy I thought that there was a Jewish mother in the kitchen and I might be at Max's Opera Cafe.  The broth was a bit thick as well, and there were these twig things that were inedible and frankly a bit awkward to prod from my throat across a dinner table.

The Samosas were not light, they were heavy, and soggy.  The filling was more potato than anything else, and the sauces were unique.

What made the experience nice was the ambiance and service.   

I think that Dosa is less and less about food and more and more about being a social place to hang for cocktails, the food seems to be a lower priority these days from the reviews I have read in the past.

5-stars for service, 5 stars for ambiance, but only a couple for Indian Cuisine.
author: Andrew G.

description:
We arrived 10 minutes late, which was not our fault, and they gave our table away.  But that wasn't the issue.  It was the incredibly annoying hostess who was so full of herself telling us that there are people who have been waiting for hours and hours.  It was bizarre.  She said she would do her best to "fit" us in.  I kind of looked at her side ways and said, "so, how long would that be?"  Hours and hours?

She sighed heavily and asked for a minute.  Then, looked up at us and told us we would get the next table for two.  Why the drama?  It's so silly.

We got a table upstairs.  The restaurant is gorgeous and we got to sit upstairs.   The staff was way overworked running around.  Luckily, the waitress was very pleasant and got us our drinks.

We had the 4 course tasting and enjoyed most of the food, especially the dosa and the third course fish dish.  My friend ordered so I don't know what it's called but it was amazing.  The wine pairing was really nice too.

Some of the staff were just running around, grabbing dishes before we were done and looked exhausted.  And some were very pleasant.

I don't think I'll be coming back.   I will let the people who like waiting for hours have my table.
author: Ayelet B.

description:
Good place to go if you're looking to impress a date or take some out of towners to.  The scene is very "LA", apparently some people buy into that shit.  **This is me sneakily alluding to how "I'm so pretentiously above superficiality, but I'm really just a judgmental narcissist".   I kid, I kid... (maybe).**

But, overall the food is fairly mediocre.  I'm pretty Indian food savvy and left a little disappointed.  A bit... underwhelmed.  We had the crab cakes, duck, spinach, and paneer curry with lemon rice, and the masala dosa.  Again, all "ok" at best.  

I usually give a higher rating for mediocre/borderline almost good food, but the value is just soooo off.  One of my biggest pet peeves is when restaurants nickel and dime you for EVERYTHING.  This was certainly the case at Dosa.  Extra for rice, extra for the health insurance thing (I still don't know where I stand on that...), extra for sauce, etc.  

I guess if I were one of the people that could be wowed by atmosphere alone, then maybe I would grant more stars.  But alas, I was just a girl looking for some good curry.
author: Sammi C.

description:
OK, there are qualifications to my review. 1) the food was good 2) service was good except for one absolutely huge failure (see below) 3) I will return to see if they can increase their rating. 

Reason for the bad rating: 
1) Everything was fine until the near end of our meal, 10, 15, 20, 30 minutes went by until we realized our server had gone home for the night without giving us our check, or even saying anything to us at all. We had to knock over (and I really do mean knock over) another server to get a bill and then have them pick the bill up. When we spoke to the management about our "abandonment issues", they basically started to give us excuses ("oh we were really busy tonight"), wrapped in apologies. We paid out check and walked out in a huff. 

2) The 20% mandatory tip on parties of 5 or more. Listen, I can buy 18% on parties of 8 and even 6...but this is just getting greedy isn't it? Dosa - Let me decide how much over the standard 15% I want to tip (generally give 18%) and on parties of just 5! This will for sure keep me away.

All that said, love the space! :)
author: Jason P.

description: Wow!!!!   What a fabulous meal all the way around, the food, the service, the exquisite decor could not have been better!!!!  Very impressed and will definitely be back.  The flavors of all the dishes we tried were fantastic, bursting with flavor!  Cannot say enough about this wonderful discovery for us in trying out Dosa on Fillmore.
author: Lisa N.

description:
Not impressed. I had heard great things about Dosa and I came here for Dine About Town lunch and while I had a good experience here the food was only mediocre. The service was excellent, our waitress was super attentive and helpful. 

For $18 we were given a selection of 3 starters and 3 entrees to choose from. I chose the beet soup, my friend the chickpeas salad, and the boys the chicken dish which they all enjoyed. I'd say the beet soup was the highlight of my meal, it was a sweet pure of beet topped with creme fraiche, perfect. For my entree I ordered the restaurant namesake, a chutney-mint dosa. The dosa was bigger than the plate it was served on a filled with potato and mint, a soup and 2 dipping sauces accompanied the dish. I wasn't so impressed, but maybe it was because I was expecting something totally different. I thought the dosa would be hot and crispy but it was mushy and limp. 

Perhaps the DAT menu didn't showcase the restaurants all star dishes, I'll have to try it again.
author: Nicole L.

description: Love, Love, Love, Love, LOVE! This place is amazing. Make sure to get an assortment of the breads, they are delicious and freaking awesome. I absolutely love poori :) The prices are good, the food is incredible the service is fantastic & overall just a great place for a date. Takes ressies too!
author: linda t.

description: Well designed South Indian spot, been to many around the world but this one has style.  The decor was classy, observed crowds from across the street for movies. Had the Paneer & Romaine Salad and Cilantro-Mint Masala for dinner - unique fusion and delicious.   I'm definitely going back here with company, to enjoy the food.
author: Manny F.

description:
The Good: 
1) Food. well spiced and hot. Some unique dishes that are fun to try.
2) Service. Bus boy cleared plates while still chewing on last bite
3) Low noise levels so can here accompanying party, lighting romantic.

The Bad:
1)  Pretentious people.

The Ugly:
1) Cocktails on the menu. BF and I didn't like ours at all. I would recommend playing it safe and ordering one of  your classics.

Go for a date, or pre-drink before the Kabuki.
author: M B.

description: Hands down the best Indian food in sf! And this is from the biggest south Indian food critic!
author: snigdha v.

description:
Torn on this place.  On my three visits here, the food was uniformly delicious, and the drinks perfectly paired and great.  Pricy, especially for indian food?  you bet.  But on the merits of the food quality, I'd give it a 4 stars, maybe a bump more.

Service, on the other hand, is rather abysmal.  On all three occasions, the servers were inattentive in the first part of the service sequence, and then overly attentive when not necessary.  We waited extraordinarily long to be greeted by our server (and to be offered water and orders for another round of cocktails which had been drained by the time they sauntered by), who disappeared for long stretches during the time he should have been around to take orders.  On one occasion, the dining room was humming and I could imagine that either the server was stretched, or the kitchen asked to put a hold on orders, thus precipitating the deliberate slow-down...not so on the other occasions when a 1/2 full house provided no such excuses.  

Ordering drinks is also a bit of a chore, as getting the attention of the server is challenging and it takes 8-12 minutes to get your cocktail thereafter.  Plan, therefore, accordingly, lest you lose your buzz between drinks.  

After the deliberate inattentiveness in the beginning part of the evening, the sudden ubiquitous presence at the end seems a little out of place, even if you're desperate to turn a table.  You know, you could move along a table just as quickly if you front-load your speed of service and get them rolling faster up front rather than wait for the end.  It's just like it's wiser to start bailing out your boat if its got a hole in it rather than wait until the water is up to the gunwales just because presumably, it's easier then to bail the water over the side--that's just the fallacy of laziness.

At any rate, service here hovers around 2...not a jailable offence, but not by much.  

Ladies and Gentlement of Dosa, you do so well with the basic purveyance of food and wine, why not do us better on the service?  Also, it would make the final bill go down just a little bit easier at the end.
author: Kosuke I.

description:
Excellent all-around.  The design and layout of the space is quite pleasing.  It's got a very open feeling.

The servers were tremendously helpful in explaining all about dosas, how to order and even how to eat them.

The menu was particularly exciting.  Having eaten at my share of Indian restaurants in the area, most menus do not differ from one another too much.  But practically everything on this menu was new to me.  And there was plenty to choose from.

Our dosas were savory and delicious.  The presentation was simple but elegant.  The food did well enough on its own not to need extravagant presentation.  Two of us shared two dosas.  That plus a beer and dessert was plenty.

This restaurant is rated at $$$ I believe.  But ordering a la carte didn't seem too expensive.  The prix-fixe four course meal, with wine pairings was $60 per person...that seemed like the most expensive way to go.  VERY tempting it was...must return to try that sometime after skipping breakfast.
author: Ken B.

description: The food was good, but the staff was unpleasant. For the amount you pay at this place the least you can ask for is the staff to smile at you or accommodate your needs. Definitely not going back.
author: Neha D.

description:
4 stars for decor

2 stars for food 

2 stars for the waiter who while looking somewhere else was answering my questions and giving a real general answer.  

I have had better DOSA in New York, and better service but it was an over all decent experience in a city that has not disappointed me much.
author: Lucie T.

description:
After seeing all of the stellar reviews, it's painful to follow with something that's a downer.  This place exudes posh and great service with the bells and whistles that you throw down a nice chunk of change for a great experience.  Unfortunately for me, this was not the case.

Came here on a Friday night just to get a drink after watching a movie at the Kabuki and this is not what you expect the service to be:

1. Line for the bar, 1.5 people deep.
2. There were 4 bartenders.
3. Wait time, 30 minutes for the bartender to finally acknowledge your existence.

The people sitting at the bar were trying to flag down their bartender for service.  Someone who finally got their drinks had to help themselves for water.  I just find it amazing to see that many people staffed and not providing expedient service at the bar.  It just does not help add up.

Drinks were good, at $12/piece, but definitely not worth the 30 minute wait time.  I'd rather go somewhere else where they know what they're doing -- like acknowledging their customers.
author: Mei C.

description:
Still the best for South Indian food in the city! The ambiance is upscale, but it's still casual, and they have wonderful art on the wall and lighting.

For food, first make sure to order one of their delicious cocktails and then dig heartily into their four course tasting menu or I highly recommend any of the following:

- Mung sprout salad
- Chennai Chicken
- Prawn Chile Fry
- South Indian Samosa & Potatoes Peas Croquette
- South Indian Bhel Puri
- Idli Sambar
- Channa Bhatura
- Kerala Fish Moilee
- South Indian Lamb Kofta
- Masala Dosa (but you really can't go wrong with any of the dosas)
- Poori and a healthy side of raita on the side
author: Stephanie V.

description:
So...I've eaten here at least a dozen times since my initial assessment. Everything has tightened up. The bar has gotten faster. The waitstaff is having fun and is sure of what they're doing. The menu is still terrific. No downside other than it's getting pretty crowded. Time your dining and drinking around a movie at the Sundance Kabuki and you have a great night out. 

5 stars.
author: Gary C.

description:
As Dosa on Valencia's biggest fan and frequent stalker, I have been anxiously awaiting it's sister location on Fillmore. I heard it was going to be BIG, that it was designed with all energy-efficient and recycled materials, and that they would have new dishes and a FULL BAR. Even knowing this and that the owners Emily and Anjan wouldn't do anything unless they could do it well, I was awed by the results of their efforts at the new Dosa. 

I was first struck by the amber lighting, cast by different, beautiful chandeliers hanging at various heights from the tall ceiling. Take the time to absorb the powerful photography, made even more so for us as we learned that same day of the terrorist attacks in Mumbai. 

As enchanting as the decor is, I go to Dosa for the unequalled South Indian food, so I would have sat right on the floor of the old Goodwill at this location and enjoyed the coconut and red bell pepper soup, cauliflower dosa, and (I couldn't resist my old favorite) rich lamb curry and enjoyed it just as much. The new halibut dish was also perfectly spiced and will be on my must-order list. You will be pleased to know that the prices remain very reasonable. 

Don't miss the signature cocktails--the creamy, not-too-sweet Juhu Palm being my favorite so far. You can't get fresher ingredients than these. Being winos, the hubba hubba hubs and I also had to try every new red and white on the list (and you wonder why you couldn't shake your hangover the next day, my green-eyed boy?), which were all stellar accompaniments to the food. The bar manager and wine connoisseur Jonny did a superb job! 

All of the servers, reflective of Emily and Anjan themselves, are warm, gracious, and extremely knowledgeable. Our server was clearly honored and excited to be working there. As frequent diners know, this makes a the difference between a meal and a memorable night out. 

So if you need to get ahold of me, just look on Valencia or Fillmore, where I will be dividing my stalking time between the two Dosas!
author: Gretchen T.

description:
It's pretty funny to order dahi vada in an Indian accent, and have the server say, "Oh! Daa-hi vaa-da."  The dahi vada was really good, though.  And it was presented in an uber-trendy manner.  It's a puffy salty cake sort of thing with yogurt, cilantro, and a couple types of chutney, in case you didn't know.

That's the appeal of dosa overall.  It blends an authentic South Indian flavor with a hip, metropolitan vibe.  Sure, the $5 dosas coming out of stainless steel platters in the South Bay are delish, but the $11 dosas at Dosa are just as good, and worth the upgraded price for the pleasant decor and ambiance.  A dosa, by the way, is like this big hulking savory crepe.  The crepe can be of different consistencies, and you can get an optional potato stuffing, which would make it a masala dosa (or masala rava dosa, masala paper dosa, etc. The paper one is the thin and crispy kind, which is my fave).

The Madras coffee is pretty awesome too.
author: Leena K.

description:
Dosa is one of my go to places for dinner and I have been 4 times since moving to the city in November. The last time my boyfriend and I did the 39 per person for four-course tasting We had:

Starters:
Seafood Vada South Indian crab cake spiced with chiles, pepper, onions, coriander & cilantro

Chennai Chicken Boneless organic chicken marinated in Straus organic yogurt with coriander & cumin, fried

Mini Dosa:
Paneer & Peas Dosa filled with spiced, grilled farmer's cheese, peas & cilantro

Spring Masala dosa combined with fresh vegetables including peas, carrots, cabbage & red onion

South Indian Curry:
Chicken & Eggplant 'Baingan Bharta' Organic boneless, Fulton Valley, roasted & pureed eggplant, peas with lemon rice

South Indian Lamb Kofta Natural, free-range lamb meatballs, creamy sauce of tomatoes & spinach, lemon basmati rice & raita

Dessert:
Gulab Jamoon Soft, lightly-fried milk and dough balls served in a warm, cardamom flavored sugar syrup

Gelato ( chocolate)

I love the decor and the staff. Every time they have been friendly, attentive and knowledgeable. I enjoy sharing and trying the other dishes with my boyfriend. I will deff be back again and again!
author: Alexa V.

description: Beautiful place, attentive service, interesting food.  Great for groups.  Sadly, I thought the food was a little bit rich and light on veggies, and normally Indian food is my very favorite.
author: Stephanie S.

description:
Location and space are no longer an issue as Dosa is now close enough and large enough to where there are no excuses for me to not have ventured here.  Hearing constant praise about their Mission location has led to much anticipation over their second locale sprouting up in the neighborhood.

For a moment, you are whisked off the lower end of Upper Fillmore and transported to another dimension.  The Burger King across the street seems worlds away.  The music is eclectic--not the usual bhangra you'd expect.  The servers are polished.  Sit upstairs for a more intimate setting, downstairs where the action is happening.

They do take reservations for all parties here, and while diners were sparse when we entered not long after they had opened, the place was packed by the time we left.  The food and wine are above average in taste, but what you're really paying for is the experience.  You're certainly shelling out more than at a casual joint like Udupi Palace, but prices are on par for more personal service in a more upscale atmosphere.  Its corner spot right across from Kabuki makes for the perfect cliche of dinner and a movie.
author: Marsha Z.

description: My new favorite go - to.  Only downside is takes the fun out of "my favorite indian dive" as this is no dive.  Great vibe, love the dosas, love the drinks. Finish it off with a movie at the Kabuki and its a perfect night.  If you are like me and has a family member who "doesn't like Indian food".. take them here. They will convert on the spot.
author: Nora F.

description:
Came here for dine about town. 
I would have to say I'm a little disappointed! Firstly, everyone else around us had the little vase of water, n two glass of water! The waitress, actually offers that to her clients, vs. Our server.... who asks can what can i start you off with, vs. when other dinee's came in and the server ask, "can I start you off with some water?"
Two, I guess growing up in Chinatown... Fine dining... And UN-authentic food really makes it feel and taste ugh! 
I'd much rather spent my money on nann n curry, and eat yummy authentic food! 
Overall, place is too upscale, I duno, just felt treated differently...whereas, compared to Ruth Chris Steak House:  I didn't feel any inferiority
author: Monika T.

description:
I went here for my birthday with a few friends.  The food was incredible, and we left absolutely stuffed.  I don't think you can choose a bad dosa, but the wait staff are really helpful with suggestions.

I can't wait to go back!
author: Brendan B.

description:
It's been confirmed.  My friend who is originally from S. India gives this place the thumbs-up.  Trendy it may be but because they converted the old Goodwill to a beautiful restaurant that serves quality and true-to-its-region dishes, I am a fan.

Pass on the calamari and order the chennai chicken.
author: A W.

description:
The Valencia Dosa has been Hot on Yelp for quite a while.  However, dragging my fat butt to the Mission is not high on my list of things to do.  Therefore, I was terribly excited when Dosa on Fillmore opened.  Especially since it is across from the Kabuki theater!  Dinner and a movie is my favorite thing to do.  Especially if the movie involves cocktails, as a movie at the Kabuki often does.

I went to Dosa two times in one week.  I love the atmosphere here.  Very hip, without being too trendy.  The design is well suited to a number of activities.  There are booth tables, corner tables with chairs, and an upstairs balcony area, which could be conducive to a small party.  There is also a shared bar table, although I hate eating at shared bar tables, for those unafraid of communal dining.  It may be difficult to get a table here, so there is a bar with unique cocktails to order while you wait.  We were told that our table would be ten minutes, but sat at the bar for over an hour.  

Is the food worth the wait?  Yes, as long as the cocktails are abundant.  They also have a nice beer and wine list that pairs nicely with the spicy food.

The first time I came here, my friend and I ordered a la carte and I left very satisfied.  For two gals with large appetites, we shared the beet soup, which was a warm beet puree with a lovely pinkish color.  I enjoyed the originality and the light flavor of this dish.  We also shared the Chennai chicken, recommended by our waiter.  It is fried, so if you like deep friend food, try it.  The mango shrimp was sweet and the shrimps were succulent!  I also enjoyed our choice of dosa, which was paneer and spinach.  Most of the dosas also come as an Uttapam option, which is a thicker version of a dosa.  The dosas also come with two dipping sauces and a soup that is very spicy.  They bring a carafe of water which helps with the spice.

On the second visit, my friend and I tried the tasting menu.  I probably wouldn't do that next time, because it is a bit expensive and the choices are a limited version of the a la carte menu.  As an appetizer, we shared a salad and Cochin calamari.  I like the calamari because it is not deep fried.  I enjoy sauteed Calamari.  We also shared two mini dosas which were delicious.  For our main course, we enjoyed the mango shrimp and the Kerala fish Moile, a light fluffy fish, both refreshing.  For dessert, we shared Gulab Jamoon, fried dough, and Kulfi, and Indian ice cream.  This meal was probably too filling for me.  I definitely recommend ordering single dishes, which seem to be more value for the recession minded.

I will definitely be back here.  The food is flavorful and unique, nothing like it in San Francisco.  Atmosphere is great for a casual meal, or a date.  My friend and I conjectured that there must be an aphrodesiac in the food because there were several couples snuggling and kissing.  Go here if you want to seduce someone.
author: apple r.

description:
Who designed this place?  Tell me?   

I am so amazed at this space I want everyone to know about it but then I will never get a seat at the bar again! 

Went to see Slum Dog on Sunday and thought about Indian Food. Wow it was perfect...Dosa right there out the door!  I will tell everyone about this space.  

They change shifts between brunch and dinner on Sunday.  There is about a two hour period that they will not serve food.  We got there and they were right at that cusp and without hesitation told us we needed to hurry up if we wanted a snack.  I wasn't expecting miracles but they came through.  Certainly it was because I get the kitchen switch...I have worked in a kitchen. 

I was so fixated on the black man in the corner with the Bob Marley look.  I felt like he was sitting there enjoying his cocktail saying "man has this hood changed and how cool is it!"  What I am getting at is this place had a nice diversity to it and that is due to the amazing designer who took the chance of designing this amazing space on a corner that borders the Fillmore, Japan town and lower wannabe Pacific Heights.  

Do yourself a favor and check out a movie at Sundance and then go to the bar at Dosa.  You will get laid for sure!
author: Scott P.

description:
Loved our dinner tonight. The food was excellent and so was the atmosphere. We had the spring dosa, masala uttapam, and 2 of their curries. Soy chai was quite yummy. The dessert menu needs some work. One was the tapioca and i forgot what the other was called... 

Would have enjoyed it more had we not been so rushed by the waiter. Plates were taken away quickly, even with that last piece of the dosa.
author: Kerry W.

description:
Delish! The ambiance is wonderful, food is great, drinks are unique and tasty, staff is friendly... Great spot for a date or night out with friends. 

Some food recommendations... Dahi Vada dumplins, Chutney Dosa with eggplant, Channa Bhatura (fried wheat bread with garbanzo bean dip).

Drink recommendation... Juhu Palm -- made with gin, coconut milk & other fun flavors, this drinks is sweet with a touch of spice.
author: Amber Rae L.

description: First of all I don't understand what is the big hype of this place! I have been to this place on several occasions with my family and have had the same mediocre service. Their food I feel like is to Americanized for the Indian tongue. As a Indian I expect having some tradition and love when eating my native cuisine. Dosa does a C- job on that. However I do find their Masala Dosa decent and their Mango Laasis top notch. I do appreciate the ambiance and hip urban feeling (due to the fact that it is located in a upcoming hip neighborhood). Another complaint I have is their prices. Overly expensive especially due to the small portions they serve. I would prefer to go to a small Indian restaurant where they give bigger portions and hotter food. Also the desserts are always cold and bland. I will only come back to this place when I have out of town guests dying for some Indian food. Other than that, won't be stepping into the doors for quite some time now.
author: Krishan S.

description: SERIOUSLY AMAZING FOOD. Don't miss out. The dosa with truffle oil is particularly badass.
author: Elizabeth B.

description:
Went here recently after a late movie at Kabuki.  And all-in-all, it didnt' live up to expectations.  Bf and I had snacked beforehand at the Sundance Kitchen (we were hungry and it was quick), so that may have contributed.  We decided to order the paneer and peas dosa and the chicken briyani.  

Paneer and peas dosa - was recommended (along with the Marsala dosa) by our waitress.  It was good, and the sauces were good (the lentil soupy thing was tasty; but I didn't like the yellow sauce - wasn't sure what it was - b/c it had kind of a gritty texture).  Regardless, I think it could have been spiced up a bit and made more punchy.  The flavor was very mellow and lacked the pungent spices that I've come to expect from good indian food.

Chicken Briyani - it was a definite let-down.  Flavor was OK, but the rice was a little mushy, and I had an issue with everything being the same color and texture.  The chicken was cooked well (it was well braised...  Not all that hard to do).  It would have been really nice to add some cashews and golden raisins to add some contrast to the plate.  

Dosa's most redeeming qualities were definitely the drinks and the atmosphere.  The house cocktail menu is really exotic with tinctures that I've never even heard of before!  Very flavorful, although probably not very strong...  The decor is also very chic, comfortable, and pretty.  It's kinda fun that this place is hopping for dinner service even at 10pm.  I would go here again for a happy hour.

Admittedly, maybe bf and I ordered the wrong things when we went here.  OR, maybe I'm just not a fan of southern indian cusine?
author: Stephanie P.

description:
oh yes. Dosa has done it right this time. i stopped in for dinner Friday evening after going to see 'Milk' with a friend at the Kabuki just across the street. what a nice surprise to find out we were there on opening night! and it was busy. already! they didn't even need to have the sign up yet outside. not to mention it was a holiday weekend with lots of usual city-dwellers MIA. 

i've been a fan of the Mission location since they opened (and a fan of south Indian food in general after spending a summer in the south of India). but frankly...they have outgrown that space. over the few years Dosa has been opened, it has become quite popular. for good reason: fresh unique south (and a bit of north) indian-style dishes with a fancy flair. something that was badly needed in San Francisco. 

as far as the new locale: i fell in love with the space upon entering. (i think it used to be the goodwill which now sits caddy corner?) high ceilings, gorgeous hanging chandeliers, perfectly dimly lit, a paint palette and walls of art that suit the vibe and cuisine...and of course the alluring smell of the food. this location seats 130-some odd guests, between the main floor, balcony and large communal table in the bar area. and of course then there a full bar and the menu has a nice list of some India-inspired cocktails as well as a good wine list.

the menu appeared basically the same, therefore i had a hard time steering away from my favorite Dosa dishes (like the Cochin calamari). but we did try the paper Masala Dosa as well as the five moons Uttapam which were both AMAZING. i cannot say enough good things...congratulations and THANK YOU Dosa.
author: Isabel C.

description:
4.5 stars. I was so excited when this location opened in my neighborhood! I had heard the food was great but that it was practically impossible to get seated in the original location because of the small space and no reservations policy.

Yay for Dosa on Fillmore! The restaurant is huge, takes reservations, and has lovely decor. The place is very loud and the food is excellent. I had my birthday dinner here and we all really enjoyed the food. It took a little while for our server to take our orders, but after that our waters were consistently filled and she checked on us periodically.

The chili prawns are delicious. The samosa appetizer includes one sweet and one spicy samosa. The spicy samosa was especially yummy and quite spicy. The mung dosa was good but it was all about the uttapam! We could have grubbed on the uttapam and channa bhatura alone and been very satisfied. All of us are meat eaters but that channa bhatura rocked. 

We also tried the mango prawns (very good) and mustard halibut (good but definitely not the best part of the meal). We washed down our food a good amount of tasty Indian beer (Taj Mahal). 

Not the cheapest Indian food but certainly of a very high quality. I am excited to return. As my friend  (Lezlee C.) said, more uttapam please!
author: Jenny K.

description:
First, the good.  The ambiance is amazing and so are the drinks!  I wish I could say the same for the food.  The dosa itself isn't bad, but the stuffings aren't very good and neither is much else on the menu.  Being that I'm Indian and I LOVE south indian food...the food has much to be desired.  This is the second time I've tried it and my experience with the food was the same.  The rasam was gritty and didn't taste the way it should.  The samber was below mediocre.  The vegetable curry was so spicy it was inedible and I love spicy food.  All in all, the food was just not very good, I would rather drive to the burbs for great South Indian food.  All that being said, I would go back to sit at the bar, have some drinks and snack on a samosa and the chopped salad.  I really wanted to like this place because I was hoping to find some good South Indian in SF :-(

ps- the hand dryers in the bathrooms are reason enough to at least check out the place...i could not stop laughing at how loud and strong they are...they definitely will dry you up in hurry!
author: Shalini H.

description:
A great place to eat before enjoying a movie in auditorium one at the Sundance Theater (upstairs with reserved seating and bar service).   

The Fillmore street Dosa is completely different than the Valencia Street version yet they both serve the same food.   This place is elegant, upscale, with large two story floor to ceiling windows, packed bar and huge dining room.   Dosas are southern Indian cuisine and a challenge for the novice to navigate but the informed staff will keep you on track.   We went with the prawns, fresh corn soup, saucy lamb, peppers and one gigantic paper dosa (sour, crispy and the length of the table).    All for around $100 for both of us (with two glasses of wine).
author: Roger B.

description:
Nice lighting fixtures. Ugly ceilings. The rest of the interior is pretty nice and comfy.

The staff still needs to come together, nothing unexpected with a fairly new place. The hostess needs to learn to pick up her feet and stop shuffling. Major annoyance, hearing her slump around all night.

The food is good. The blackened sardines are excessively delightful, try them.
The fried onion appetizer was only so-so, but the lamb curry is delicious.

The cocktail list (understandably so) is very heavy on the gin, which this vodka girl doesn't like, but at least they are interesting concoctions.

All in all: yummy yum yum.
author: Tatjana G.

description:
I'm just going to confess right up front that I'm one of those freaks of nature that doesn't like cilantro. And, I know, Indian food is not the best choice for someone like me. I get it! But I manage to eat lots of Indian food all over the city, and would go so far as to say that Indian is my comfort food. I could seriously eat it every day of the week.

My main problem with Dosa was that the food was only "eh," and we had been expecting "POW!" My friend and I each ordered the tasting menu with wine pairings, and then swapped everything back and forth. I didn't, you know, spit anything into my napkin. But I didn't want to fight his fingers back with my fork so that I could hoard something especially tasty for myself either. And several things I pushed aside after just a bite or two. (My friend, who is far less picky than me, was similarly underwhelmed.)

My picky issue comes back to the cilantro thing. The one item on the menu that I was dying to try was the pea/paneer dosa. I asked our server immediately if it had cilantro, or could be made without cilantro. I was told yes, and no. So I ordered a variety of other things -- many of which came out covered in cilantro, as if they had put extra cilantro on just for me. I was supremely annoyed that the server didn't warn me, especially after I had already asked for a dish to be made without it. How hard would it have been to say, "I hate to break it to you, but our kitchen is very cilantro centric, and we can't customize dishes"? At the very least I would have expected her to ask the kitchen to exclude the cilantro GARNISHES, which were obviously added right before the plates left the kitchen.

Needless to say, we won't be headed back anytime soon. I was hoping to find a new favorite rainy day, pick-me-up restaurant, and got several mouthfuls of dreaded cilantro instead. Yuck.
author: Katie T.

description: I love south indian food. This place does it great! I haven't had a bad dosa here. Also they have great cocktails and I think the decor and ambiance is very chic.
author: Shivani S.

description:
Pretty freaking good. Would I go back? Yes...but likely only 

1) for a dinner w/ out of town guests
2) for a celebratory dinner
3) when craving fancy indian food
4) when too lazy to travel more than 100 feet after a movie at the Kabuki
5) when I need to feel cool again ;)

I believe this space was a Goodwill shop prior to being a glitzy, hip ameri-indian restaurant and bar. I've passed the Mission Dosa many times but never had the urge to explore the supposedly overly-American Indian food. But after catching my eye with the uber-cool spot on Fillmore, I couldn't resist. We indulged in a post Slumdog Millionaire dinner there and thoroughly enjoyed ourselves (No, the Indian themed night was not planned.)

Loved the...
- Channa Bhatura Chick pea (garbanzo) masala w/ bhatura (oversized, soft, puffy wheat bread - reminded me of a cross between naan and roti)
- Tamil lamb curry

Enjoyed but would try something else next time...
- Spring dosa
- Calamari
- Paratha

Great cocktails and corkage for $25. 

Try this new spot for your next dinner date, dinner w/ friends or out of town guests. You'll feel satisfied and too cool for school.
author: Deann M.

description:
3.5 stars rounded up.  I am always wary of Indian food because of what the spices do to me afterwards, but I felt great after Dosa.  The restaurant is really stunning -- I love the lighting and the decor.  Plus, you do not smell like food after dinner, which is always a plus in my book.

The food is good and yes, you can probably get something very similar elsewhere for a lot less (just not plated as nicely), but I found that I enjoyed my overpriced food.  I started with the Paneer and Romaine salad, which was fine (probably as good as any romain salad can get).  Fiance had the Fiery Fruit salad, which was very interesting.  We shared the Dahi Vada (lentil dumplings, which had the consistency of falafel), the Onion Pakora (fried onions in batter) and the Paneer and Peas Dosa (a litte too much paneer for me).  For my main, I tried the Tamil Lamb curry with the plain Uttapam, which was delicious!  I came home super stuffed...   

The service is good, the place is pretty and the food is good -- you should check it out!
author: Mitzi C.

description: Really good food that actually succeeds at Indian "fusion" and delicious cocktails as well.
author: S. L.

description:
As a freshman at the University of California, Santa Cruz, the Stevenson core course required that all incoming students read a broad variety of religious texts. Among those magical tomes was the Bhagavad Gita. Often described as the concise guide to Hindu philosophy, others have penned it as a lighthouse of eternal wisdom that has the ability to inspire any man or woman to supreme accomplishment and enlightenment.

That is basically how I felt after walking out of Dosa last night. 

Highlights:  
Paper Masala - This will blow your mind. A bazooka of paper thin dough arrives at your table with a nice selection of spiced Indian potatoes, onions and cashew nuts. MYOB - make your own burrito.

Cochin Calamari - Tender calamari, sautéed with a mildly-spiced coconut milk sauce, served with mixed greens. Delicious.

If you're feeling flush, sack up and get a Flying Horse Lager ($9). Great tasting brew from the largest democracy in the world.
author: Sam S.

description: When I'm craving spicy Indian food, I go here.  Absolutely delicious!  I've been here five times and I wanna go back again for more!   My gf and I usually end up ordering 1 item from each section which is waaay too much food but we love to have a taste of everything.  Our favorites~  Vada Sambar, Lamb Kofta with coconut Basmati rice, Spring Masala and Poori.  Wine selection is excellent with a detailed description of each bottle.  Oh and the decor is beautiful and glamorous!  I highly recommend coming here.
author: Sharon D.

description: Go for the food, never go back because of the service! The food being absolutely fabulous, both well spiced and elegantly cooked is the only reason they got even 2 stars. I went about 2/3's of my meal without anything to drink because they seemed totally averse to refilling my water or iced tea, despite my asking everyone one of the many people that seemed to keep checking up on our table.
author: Evan G.

description:
Came here for a work Christmas dinner party.  We had reservations for 9 and ended up with 12 people and they were kindly enough to squeeze us in until the table next to us opened up and pushed it together for more room. 

We started off with their Crab Vada- South Indian crab cake spiced with chiles, pepper, onions, coriander & cilantro- was expecting more flavor, it was ok.  

Chennai Chicken -Boneless organic chicken marinated in Straus organic yogurt with coriander & cumin, fried, very tasty with the slaw salad next to it. 

Samosas- caramelized onions & vegetables and spiced potatoes, these were tasty and came with great dipping sauces of mint and tamarind. 

Rasam "Fire Broth" Spicy broth of tomatoes, tamarind, lentils & black pepper- had a different taste, like grainy, not a bad thing, very flavorful and spicy. 

For dinner I got to try the Chutney Masala- Masala dosa spread with a spiced chutney of blended baby eggplant- the great big triangle on my plate was very tasty!  The crepe itself was very good.  And yes, I did use my hands to eat this dish and it made it taste 10x better. 

Pepper Chicken Fall-off-the-bone, organic chicken, crushed peppercorns, ginger, spices with lemon rice- the dish had plenty of flavors and the lemon rice made it taste much better. The rice itself was very good. 

Lamb Biryani Natural lamb, chiles, onion, garlic, ginger, spices, raita & sambar, slow-cooked with basmati rice- I thought this dish was ok, the lamb itself was tender and good, but overall dish wasn't as flavorful. 

dessert: Rasmalai-Sweet cheese patties soaked in a cool, sweet cream, flavored with rose, cardamom and crushed pistachios- different texture, but not overly sweet, good dish. 

Overall, I had a great experience here, the food was great, service was great.  They had a great wine list also.
author: Annie D.

description:
The new space is pretty sweet, although a little overwhelming - I think I prefer the Valencia Dosa a tad better for a more intimate atmosphere, although the decor is impressive with lots of natural light pouring in.

Came here for lunch and split the following:
Pani Puri - fun to assemble and eat, but probably wouldn't repeat
Coconut soup - outstanding. Insane flavors and creamy delicious texture. Overall the best dish of the meal.
Paneer & Romaine salad - tasty farmer's cheese, light & fresh.
Spring Dosa - great dipping sauces, not too heavy, rich flavors.

Between 2 of us both with decent appetites, this was plenty of food! Portion sizes were bigger than I expected. Service was pretty slow especially for a casual mid-day lunch, but hopefully this will improve as they get the hang of the bigger space.
author: Kelly R.

description:
Came down to Dosa to check out the bar and Johnny Raglin's cocktail list and immediately I knew that this place will see too much of my hard earned dough in the coming months.  If you haven't been to Dosa in the Mission, then you've been missing out on the best south indian grub in SF. So now you've got no excuse with two locations, a full bar and lunch starting next week. 

The space was formerly a Goodwill, and hopefully this won't sound too Scrooge-like when I say, "Good Riddance."  The double-decker dining room with 30ft ceilings is the South Indian cousin to Nopa on Divis. If you don't know Nopa, then shame on you. 

The cocktails are Indian inspired and solid in a classic way. They could stand their own on any fine bar menu in SF.  I tried the Bowler and the Batsman, both excellent but I favored the Bowler.
