It's a pisco-based cocktail with "Hell Flower" tincture and a mango gastrique served up with a twist of lime. It's a spicy delicious culinary cocktail that wakes you up and readies the palate. 

I look forward to cocktails and lunch at the bar starting next week.
author: Phil M.

description:
Dosa on Fillmore is such a fantastic addition to the neighborhood! I came here for the first time to mach up with a friend for lunch and I immediately fell in love with the decor. Picture modern, eclectic Indian-inspired touches with ornate, feather and glitter-infused chandeliers hanging from their 30-foot tall ceilings. [Inner voice says, "Whoa, I could live here."] 

As for the food and drink, yeeeeeeuhm yum yum!! We shared a traditional South Indian dish as a starter - they were the equivalent of bite-sized yogurt-filled cream puffs, which taste-wise resembled 7-layer dip [a good thing!]. We also had the vegetable curry and the Paper Masala Dosa - both were supremely flavorful and beautifully plated. 

I'm sincerely impressed! I was really pleased at the end of the meal, for while I definitely got my fill of food, I didn't leave feeling stuffed or heavy. Dosa is definitely Indian food with a lighter side. I can't wait to come back!
author: Katie C.

description:
This is a wonderful restaurant if you go with a small group of people. The food is expensive, but good. I've been to this restaurant many times, but the reason I gave this place a two star is because I was very disappointed in their service for large groups and I felt ripped off. I was hoping to show my cousin a good time, but instead it wasn't a very memorable one.  I made a reservation for a group of 15 people to celebrate my cousin's birthday. A party of over 8 people (forget the exact count), it's approximately $50 per person excluding drinks and it's a pre-fixed menu. The food took a very long time to come out and the food that they brought out was mediocre. Not only was the food mediocre, the portion was so small, it didn't even make it halfway around the table. We had to ask them to give us more rice and curry. Even after asking them for more food, it wasn't filling. The amount of food that we got felt like it was for 5 people instead of 15. The portion was so tiny, it was ridiculous. The bill came out to be approximately $1,500 with drinks and tips. All of us left the restaurant hungry. I remember going to a fast-food place getting a burger afterwards.

If you plan on going to Dosa in a large group, I suggest you find another place; however in a small the group, it is a good dining experience. I just can't bring myself back to this restaurant ever since.
author: Anson C.

description:
Goodwill = Good restaurant and Good food! Hard to believe this lovely space is the old Goodwill. I've been wanting to try Dosa for a while and was really excited when they opened on Fillmore, like Delfina, much more convenient for me,.

I had never had southern Indian or so I thought but recognized some standbys for me including benghan bharta - one of my absolute favorites and their version had chicken. We tried a couple actual 'Dosa's' and really liked the pea and paneer one! 

We sat at one of the bar tables and there was a strange period of service between, 4:30 and 5:30p before they start serving food but once we hit 5:30p and could order food, we had great service!
author: Sarah B.

description:
I tend to be in this area a lot, whether it's for a show at the Fillmore or a flick at Sundance Kabuki. Despite being surrounded dozens of Japanese restaurants, it seems I always end up at Dosa. 

Keep in mind that "South Indian" is not quite the same Indian food you're probably used to...but don't worry, its qualities and root flavors are similar. 

I usually start with a soup (all 3 are great and each is very different), then move on to a normal entree. Vegetarians have great options in the dosas and uttapams, which are essentially Indian crepes if you've never eaten one. 

The place is a little overpriced, but the beautiful space inside might make up for that. Some might find the dimly-lit swankiness to be cheesy and uncharacteristic of San Francisco, but I find the atmosphere very appealing. Beautiful space with high ceilings, great place for a date. 

This is a slightly generous rating for an experience that is more like 3.5; the full bar -- something that seems less and less common these days -- pushed my rating to a 4.
author: Jordan D.

description:
This restaurant is so inviting from the street at night with their beautiful decor. So inviting that I decided to make a dinner reservation for my birthday. This place was already full by the time we arrived (bef. 7pm) last night.  It was nice that we were seated right away.

The food was interesting and tasty enough. The Paper Masala Dosa was the star of the night. Nice presentation and it was fun to customize each bite. Perfect dish for sharing. The calamari was tender and flavorful. The samosas were good, but only two per order. The lamb chop entree was just so so.  We were told that there would be 4 chops, but only got three.  Didn't care for the flavor nor texture. Not as tender and forgettable. Too bad, it was the priciest dish we ordered. Had a little bite of the halibut and it was spiced nicely. The rice that came with the entrees were on the dry side. We also ordered the puffy bread which was good, but prefer Vik's version. Here it came out deflated vs. the fully puffed-out, steam-coming-out-of- the-seams we've gotten used to. 

The cocktails were great and service was okay. Somehow once you're inside the ambience was nice, but not as special as it looked from the outside. Overall it was good, but would probably return just for cocktails and the Paper Masala Dosa before a movie. It was a solid night out, but not spectacular.
author: Jane F.

description:
First off, Dosa was a lot more "Pac Heights-trendy" than my friends and I were expecting.  One of my friends had been to the Mission location before, which he said is much smaller and significantly less hipster.  There is dim lighting, a huge bar, glitzy decor, and rather than the usual bhangra or Bollywood music I'm accustomed to at the standard tiny family-run Indian joint, the song that greeted us as we walked in the door was One Republic's "Apologize."  LOL?

There were also A LOT of people there for 8:15 pm on a Tuesday night.  We were really glad we had made a reservation!  

I had never had south Indian food in a restaurant before, so I wasn't really sure what to expect.  We tried the poori (puffy vegan breads) and fire broth as appetizers; I really liked the tomato and lentil-based fire broth.  It has a smoky taste and definite kick to it from the black pepper.  For entrees, we shared the Tamil lamb curry, which was awesome with lemon rice, the duck spinach masala and paneer with plain rice, and the chutney masala dosa (Indian crepe filled with potatoes, onions, and baby eggplant chutney).  I'd say my favorite was the dosa, though the lamb was really tender as well.  Every dish had an amazing blend of spices in it.

I had the Batsman cocktail, which consists of gin, Darjeeling tea cordial, lemon juice, ginger beer, and mint.  Kind of like a South Asian spin on a mojito.  It was delicious and a very refreshing counterpart to the food, which is on the heavier side.

Pretty good service overall.  Thumbs up!
author: Christina Y.

description:
I'd been waiting to try the new location for a while to avoid the crowd a new fabulous place always attracts. We finally braved the crowd and had a wonderful experience, the new location is much more spacious and holds a big crowd well, we were seated immediately (it was a monday night). The decor was lovely, elegant yet not too over the top. 

The service was excellent, I was with my sister who doesn't tolerate dairy or onions very well and the staff took special care to accommodate her needs. Most of the menu items are chock full of onions and they patiently walked us through the menu to find something that would work, they even sent a sample of something up from the kitchen to see if she liked it. How's that for service! 

I've travelled to Southern India twice in the last three years and it's my favorite region of India, the food being one of the reasons why. Dosa captures the essence of South Indian food perfectly, I loved every bite. I can't wait to go back again!
author: stephanie h.

description:
Love the food and how they can really bring out the flavors. 

Ended up dropping a star as they are NOT kid friendly.
author: N G.

description: Everything was pretty good here during my last visit.  The staff were all very nice and friendly, nothing absolutely spectacular, but nothing really to complain about either.
author: Nathan J.

description:
Minimal, spacious, and very elegant. The food pops with fresh spicy and exotic flavors, and the urban hip feel mixed with the rock-throw distance of the Sundance Kabuki makes for a very enjoyable evening, maybe with that main squeeze you've been hovering around? 

I decided firmly that Indian deserves Indian aspirations and so I decided to go redhot that day. Best mistake of my life(next to my fiance that is ~ I kid I love you very much!). I chose the Habenero and Mango Dosa, which if you know your peppers was sweet, sundered , then a fight for the glass of water.  The meal came with the dosa, which I was completely foreign too (being the plushed San Franciscan that I am).
 
I was all too well familiar with Naan, chutney, and other yummies of the Indian landscape, but this was a marvel of taste and construction for me. A crepe with the mindset of Indian food? My God. Tasty, simple, exquisite, and filling are the words that come to mind. 

Enough of the food, Fine dining isn't just about the food alone of course; dining is also about atmosphere and ambiance! 

The waiters/waitresses were all too helpful and gorgeous I might add, they were incredibly friendly, informative(on the dishes that is!), and all but most important when I dine is that the wait staff was patient for myself and my spouse. For we were t3h noobs of eating at a place that was unnamed for the beginning of its life span(Did anyone else notice that?)

The inside decor was minimal, nothing special, but I'm sure it would be quite a sight at night(we went in the afternoon).  

Location is perfect, close to Japan Town, Kabuki theater, Vaness, Downtown(38 bus ride away!), the beautiful and hip Fillmore area, and of course my own bachelors pad for myself to watch you eat through the voluminous and stifling windows of Dosa!

Price is what'd you'd expect, a generous helping w/o alcohol(do they even serve it? Not sure) with appetizers and a generous lunch came out to 42-45ish, I dont recall.  A little pricer for lunch, but hey, you get to say you ate there at least!

P.S

I used to come to this very spot all the time to buy old videos when it was a GoodWill......oh how times have changed.
author: Jimmy K.

description:
I've been here twice and have not been disappointed yet.    I will concede that I ate at the bar both times, so I cannot comment on the dining room service.  However,  the place is visually stunning with an interesting mix of traditional indian and contemporary music.  

The food is delicious and very well presented.  The bar also prides itself in its colleciton of gins.  It's a martini lovers paradise.  

A bit pricey but you are paying for ambiance as much as for the good food.  Awesome vibe for a special night out.
author: Kurt L.

description:
We were given a window table facing outside, 
but turned ourselves around because the view is far better looking in.

Went in for brunch, and loved the whole experience. Food was great--all the flavors were amazing--and the staff was super friendly and nice. Only bad part was paying the check at the end. :)
author: K. C.

description:
This place is the sister restaurant to the famous Dosa on Mission !

It's opening just before Thanksgiving so get ready for LONG lines and terrific food .

I love Dosa and believe they will do itself proud in this new location.
It's where the former Bank Of America was on Fillmore.

A good friend is a server testing out the dishes now and she raves everyday about what she gets to try . Can't wait.

When the doors open I'll be the first.
author: Katherine N.

description: I had heard a lot of good things about this place (from Yelp reviews and word of mouth), but in my mind I had this notion of Dosa being an American restaurant with great decor and ambience with a wannabe Indian theme and Americanized Indian food. So, when I stepped into this place, I was completely expecting myself to be ripped off and leaving the place with a dissatisfied palate. BUT I WAS SO WRONG! Everything from their menu, to the presentation of the food to the quality and taste of it was simply spectacular. Not only do they have the traditional varieties of South Indian Dosa, they also offer some delightful fusion hybrids. Their menu explains how dosas are to be eaten - not with a knife and fork, but with the hand, dipping each piece into the bowl of Sambhar.  Unlike many fancy restaurants in the city that 'claim' to be Indian, Dosa is the real deal! 12 dollars for a tasty dosa and a magnificent ambience - I'll take it any day! The only problem with this place is that it's always full, and you can't eat here unless you make an advance reservation or are prepared to wait for an hour or two.
author: Srivatsan S.

description:
Had dinner here with the bf on a sat. night and we made reservations in advance. It was my first time trying southern indian food so i was excited.
We ordered the chicken and eggplant with lemon rice, it was good it was kind of spicy and i love spicy foods! BF had the uttapam with onions, it was okay dont think i will order that again. Will come back to try the dosas.
author: Jennie L.

description:
I can only rate based on a single cocktail after a movie at the Kabuki - and that cocktail was deliciousiousness served Up.  
Not to mention the space is gorgeous. 

The food being brought to the tables looked tasty - next time we'll try it, or maybe we'll have another cocktail.
author: Robyn C.

description: We had heard all the buzz about this place and grabbed whatever reservation was available (5pm instead of 7:30pm?... yes please!). And we were not one bit disappointed! The food was just amazing! A bit on the fusion side, but so very flavorful. The staff was super friendly and nice and the decor was classy. The coconut custard dessert was amazing... not simply because I like coconut everything. This was just divine!
author: Viv O.

description:
Thank god!! You take reservations now!!  I had been to the Dosa in the Mission last year and really had enjoyed my meal, but couldn't stand to go back and deal with the excruciating wait (it'll be ten more minutes...yeah, ten more minutes...).  So I was really happy to see that both this new Dosa and the one in the Mission now take reservations.  That completely changes the story.

Dosa on Fillmore is quite a different dining experience.  The place is huge, and the architecture and decor give it the odd ambiance of an upscale Cheesecake Factory.  But the South Indian food is still amazing.  Dosas, lassies, and Uttapams.... mmmm!  And some restaurant management guru must have come in and trained the staff because this place is being run extremely efficiently now!  We were in and out in less than 45 minutes, which was perfect to catch our film across the street at the Sundance Kabuki.  And that location of the restaurant, along with the new ability to reserve a table, will ensure that we'll be back for many more dosas in the future!
author: Kimberly G.

description:
I would give Dosa a 3.5 on food quality and my overall experience - but because I think it's overpriced, I'm choosing a 3 instead of a 4 as 3.5 isn't an option (Yelp should really change that anyways.) 

I really love Indian food, so I was super excited to try Dosa. I had heard great things about it. I also heard that their drinks were amazing, and I love a good cocktail, so once again, I was really looking forward to the meal. Maybe it is because I had such high expectations for Dosa - but I wasn't really blown away. I've eaten a lot of Indian food, and Dosa is good, no doubt about that, but it isn't really great.

First, I ordered a cocktail (I can't remember the name - sorry), but it was one of the ones that was spicy. I don't know why I thought I would like this, but I just don't like spicy cocktails. Especially when Indian food is spicy - then the spicy cocktail doesn't quench your thirst. To be honest, I didn't even finish my drink, and THAT is crazy for me. On top, my friend didn't like the drink either.

For dinner, my friend and I decided to split everything. For our appetizer, we ordered Chennai chicken and the scallops - and both were pretty good, the scallops were my favorite part of the meal, but I just love scallops. I would definitely recommend them! 

For our main course, we ordered the prawn massala and the regular dosa. The prawn massala was good, but I'm still debating whether it was worth the price. Maybe I just don't like Dosas (then I guess it was a mistake going to a restaurant named after them), but I was unimpressed by the Dosa we ordered. Sure, it wasn't bad, but my goal of restauranting isn't to leave saying "not bad" - I should be in awe of their culinary skills. 

I would go back to Dosa, but I wouldn't actually have a Dosa. Their menu looks really good, so I would order to scallops again, and try a different main course.. and order a different drink. I'm not giving up yet.
author: Ashley H.

description:
Before last night, I had only been to Dosa for brunch and had a great experience. My friend and I went to dinner and ordered off the sample menu - $39 for your choice of 4 dishes, or $59 with wine pairings - a great deal!

We started off the night with two cocktails, of which there was a large list to choose from. I ordered the Silver Fizz (because I love drinks with egg whites) and it was light and refreshing. My friend got the South Indian crab cake appetizer, and I ordered the chili shrimp. Both were delicious and flavorful and plated very elegantly. A waitress (not ours) brought our first wine pairing and set it down on the table and walked away, until I stopped her to ask what the wines were. She said mine was a Torrontes, and wasn't sure what my friend's was. She came back a minute later and told him it was a Riesling. We both thought this was kind of weird, considering we paid an extra $20 for wine pairings. 

For our second course we shared a paneer & peas dosa and the uttapam, both served with the same three delicious dipping sauces - a spicy orange sauce, a coconut-yogurt sauce, and a thick lentil sauce that could also be finished like a small cup of soup. We mixed the orange and coconut sauce on top of the dosa and it was perfect! For this course I had a Miner Sangiovese and my friend had an Iron Horse Chardonnay - both went very well with the dishes!

I had the Lamb kofta for my third course, which was spicy and savory! It was paired with lemon basmati rice and raita. I just mixed it all together and devoured it. My friend ordered the prawn masala and he asked for it extra spicy. Considering it was one of the most mild dishes on the menu, the cooks hard a hard time ramping up the spice, but he admitted he should have ordered something more spicy to begin with. I forget what wines we had with the third course (probably because I was immersed in my lamb dish).

We finished off the meal with some tangerine and coconut sorbet, which was the perfect pallet cleanser. 

Surprisingly, there aren't enough high-end Indian restaurants in San Francisco, and this is definitely one of the best! It's a great spot for a date, a group, or a night with a friend.
author: Kelsey M.

description: Loved the paneer and peas dosa and the chicken appetizer.  Everything else was tasty, but didn't blow me away.  Easy to find a table!
author: Anna V.

description: I went here to see what the hype was all about, but my mistake was to listen to non-ethic people saying this place was great. The food was not at all good, the dosa and uttapam where drenched in oil and placed on an actual pancake and chile to cover the lack of taste and spice. The paratha was so greasy and oily  that that too tasted like paper. The rice and barayani was flavorless, cold and drench in oil, the fries and other appetizers where drenched in oil and layered with spice again to cover the lack of taste. Overall I agree those other yelpers that the food is over priced for food that lacks flavor. I have been to other south indian or other Indian places and honestly stick with the less ambiance places. I was fooled to read all the yelp reviews of how great the food was, but when you look around both on the reviews and in the resturant, the majority of the people are nothing but non-ethic people and a couple of asians.  But overall the food lacks taste and they spice up their food to cover up for the lack of taste. I highly recommend not coming here, you will be pissed for paying a fortune here for food that is only worth $10. No good!
author: Sara A.

description:
Fantastic!

I've never been to the Valencia restaurant, but can confirm that they've done a great job on Fillmore. The space is gorgeous and inviting, and it was exciting to be in a San Francisco restaurant on a Tuesday night that was bustling after 9pm!

The menu can be overwhelming for first-timers. I'd recommend the tasting menu (at $39, it's not particularly cheap - but nothing at this restaurant is) for your first go. This will give you a good idea of the flavors and types of dishes DOSA serves - and it's a lot of food. 

Our waitress was very friendly, walking us through the menu and pointing out some of her favorite dishes. Our table didn't feel rushed at all. The same can be said for the hostess, who had no problem with a couple of us in our party arriving 10 minutes late for our reservation. No one seemed pretentious at all - perhaps some of the negative feedback along these lines from other Yelpers is being generated predominantly by the dreaded Thursday-Saturday nights? No excuse regardless, but again, I had no such experience.

The bar is also really beautiful here, and their signature cocktails are quite interesting. I could imagine dropping in here just for drinks, and perhaps some dosas at the communal table.

The only dull light for me was the dessert menu, which doesn't surprise me. The item on the menu that sounded like yummy doughnuts definitely was, um, not. But all in all, a great place, especially for those who have been there/done that and looking to try something different - particularly great for group dining.
author: Kiesha R.

description: This is the only restaurant that I have given 5 stars to. I absolutely LOVED the food. Not only is their food delicious, but the ambience is great and the decor of the place is so beautiful.  We had to wait 30 minutes to get seated because we didnt make a reservation, so I would definitely make a reservation, even if it's a week night. We sat down and they gave us papadum to snack on. We were so hungry we demolished it. We ordered a Spicy Mung Dosa, Chili Uttapam, and a prawns masala with lemon rice. The dosa was perfectly crisp and the stuffing with potato was almost as good as my mom makes, ALMOST. :) I must say I don't usually love South Indian food, but the sambar chutneys and entrees were to die for. They serve their dishes with coconut and tomato chutneys and a cup of sambar which is a slightly sour spicy soup. The Chile uttapam comes with four different types of chilis. Including habaneors and birds eye chilis. If you can't handle spicy food I would not suggest ordering it. It was FIRE, even for me. Regardless of the pain from the heat, the uttapam was delicious and I finished it. The prawn masala was also really tasty. Definitely not very spicy and sort of creamy. Good match with the lemon rice. I think this is probably the best South Indian food I have ever had outside of being homemade and I suggest it to anyone who likes dosas or wants to be adventurous. I'm sure you will love it.
author: Neha H.

description:
Just went here for the first time last night.  The food was excellent, the service was prompt and the restaurant was beautiful (its HUGE, the biggest restaurant I've been to in SF).  Great place to go before a movie or a show right down the street.

Everyone got the 4 course tasting menu, which was reasonably priced.  I got the Prawn Chile Fry - very good, nicely spiced; the Dosa was good with fun dipping sauces.  Really very good restaurant and I will go back when I'm next in the mood for higher-end Indian food.
author: Clay G.

description:
This is a lovely establishment. However, I found the wait staff and one of the bartenders to be bland...not wanting to make suggestions, awkward smirks. It just didn't seem like they enjoyed their jobs.

Anyway, the drinks were a little too ambitious and had a lot of traditional Indian spices added to them. The food was good, but one word of warning, if you don't like, "make you sweat" spicy, you're going to need to tell them that when you order. 

So the reason I'm giving 3 stars is because I came here with friends to celebrate my b-day and one of my friends brought me a cake. We've all heard of a corking fee, but have you heard of a $3 a plate cake fee? Our waiter wanted us to give him $3 each so he could serve us my cake!!
author: Benita S.

description:
This place is sweet-- just as my friends and Yelp promised.

Unfortunately ever since moving to the east coast I haven't had much time to frequent San Francisco's dining establishments, however, when I was back in town this past weekend my friend managed to assemble a group of 20 of my nearest and dearest friends to check this place out. His selection process: it had rave yelp reviews.

As it turns out, this restaurant's opening was this past Friday and we were one of the first nights that they were serving to the public. As such they were still working out a few kinks. However, I didn't notice  any of them. 

Their food-- was fantastic. While we each ordered our own plates we could have definitely done family style. Portions were average and prices were between $10-$16 for the most part.

As far as the drinks go--- those were AMAZING. I got this Batsman drink which was Gin and Gingerbeer mixed with several other components, and was completely blown away. While prices were a bit higher than I would have liked the drinks were darn tasty.

The decor, as you can see from the pictures, was great. Very trendy and tastefully done. We sat on the second floor, which was great for our loud and rowdy group.

Finally--- the service was very friendly. A bit slow but it was completely understandable--- they were packed!
author: Rebecca M.

description:
Been to both Dosa but went to this one for lunch and had a birthday cocktail. Man, I don't remember what is was but it was good. Food is good and you can get combo, a little bit of this a little bit of that, but that cocktail is what sticks in my mind. Maybe it was the fact that I got to have some booze during the middle of a work day but as I'm writing this all I can think of is how good that cocktail was.
Nice cool decor, good service (our waitress was really helpful with selecting the right items) and tasty cocktails.
author: Wendy B.

description: I liked every item i had here. My fav is the kheema dosa. Service is also great. I wish they are open more hrs as i am in sfo but could not visit them today as they were closed
author: San M.

description:
This was my second time to Dosa, and I have consistently recommended it since I first came here over a year ago.

We began the dining adventure with a glass of Prosecco. A lovely way to toast the evening. 

For our dining delights, I will describe in further detail below. However, I am confident that everything you order will be enjoyed.

Dahi Vada: The lentil dumplings are wonderful, but the yogurt and mint sauce are even better. You will want to soak up each but of the sauce with some bhatura.

Channa Bhatura: The chickpeas were served whole and the sauce in which it was delivered was delicious. Sometimes I am not a chickpea fan but I was on this occasion. It has a nice bite to it.

Spicy Andhra Prawns: They were spicy, and I do like spicy. I think though that they were a little overcooked. They come surrounded in a tomato based sauce and I feel as though the heat that they were immersed in, overcooked them.

Paneer & Peas: The dosa's are lovely, and they are consistent with their crepe preparation. I enjoyed the sauces that accompanied the dosa. Specifically the yogurt based one. 

Bhatura: Order it so that you can soak up all the sauces and dressings that accompany the dishes you order. It is also comical to watch you diners attempt to deflate this bread.

The servers are knowledgeable and accommodating. Only gripe is that we ended up pouring our own water and refilling our Prosecco glasses on our own. However, they did redeem themselves when I had left my ticket to a concert at home and they printed it out for me. I just forwarded it on and the gentleman came back a few minutes later with it.
author: Megan H.

description:
I came here with my mom for a birthday lunch, and WOW, this place is amazing!  I left so full I didn't know what to do with myself, but I'm allowed to be gluttonous on my birthday, right?  

I found a parking spot right in front (score!) and walked into a beautiful room.  The hostess was friendly and let me pick which table I wanted.  I think our server was new as she was a bit unsure of herself and had odd timing, but that was no big deal to me.  

We started with the Chopped Salad, which was super fresh and delicious.  I loved all the carrots in there!

Next we shared a Masala Dosa and the Tamil Vegetable Curry.  The Dosa was something I had never seen before.  Kind of like a giant pancake, and it reminded me of Eritrean food as you rip pieces off with your fingers and dip it into the sides.  The spiced potato filling was super yummy too.  The Curry was spicier than we expected, but it was really good too.  The Coconut Rice that accompanies it was really unusual (to me) and complimented the flavors of the curry perfectly.

For dessert we tried the Pistachio Gelato.  Not my favorite flavor, but my mom loved it.  We both had the Monsoon to drink, which is a non-alcoholic juice concoction.  Their cocktail list looked really interesting too!  I can't wait to come back here.

Oh, and bonus points for being vegetarian/vegan friendly!
author: Lindsay B.

description: I went to Dosa with a friend of mine as we were rushing off to see a movie at the Kabuki, which is across the street. The service could not have been better even due to lack of seating and a policy not to serve food/appetizers on the "bench" while you wait for a seat. They did end up serving us very quickly and we happily headed off to our premiere.  This is where the plot thickens...on our return and fully aware of what the bar seating policy was, we made the mistake of returning. The manager was the most rude and arrogant being on the planet! He discouraged us at every point and said that despite the "regulations" in the bar zone, it did not apply to where we were trying to sit. He even had the gall to say that if we stayed we would not be served! Description of this creature is: bald, six feet talll and spits in your face as he turns you away on a Friday night across the street from the Kabuki and playing by their rules of seating mind you! Never again and not even a great spot if it were not for its' location.
author: Catherine H.

description:
Absolutely fantastic. 

Went opening night. I happen to be an "event hag" so that worked out. The waiter was extremely helpful with explaining the process and translating the Dosa slang....i like.... 

Chickpea curry + warm, soft, fluffy flatbread = delicious. I still dream about it. (sick, i know. there goes whats left of my fake online reputation) 

Calamari starter = sauteed, fresh, delicious, a touch citrus-y and healthy! Whats not to love? 

Have a nice Sav Blanc and enjoy a recession-savvy bill.
author: Carrie R.

description:
Great cocktails with a swanky bar and crowd.  The wine is a good direction as well.

The food is so delicious- especially the curies and dosas. The waiters might suggest you order too much, so don't get carried away.

It isn't impossible to come in without a reservation, but I would suggest trying to get one beforehand.
author: Peter G.

description: Went there after having a positive experience at Dosa on Valencia - for some reason, their Dosa was much greasier and that didn't leave my tummy feeling good.  Also it was a bit more spicier.  The venue however was larger and scenery than the one in Valencia.
author: Elizabeth B L.

description:
We were able to get reservations and they helped us immediately. I can't believe this was formely a goodwill!!! The decor was really nice and I love the lighting.

Tables were a little close together, but I'm not clausterphobic and it gives you a friendly kind of feeling to it. Plus, you get to see what your neighbors are ordering and if it looks good..you can ask them about it!

I did like the "bread" before you got your main dishes..but the suggestion of the waitress to get the Tamil Vegetable Curry was very disappointing!! I ordered per the recommendation with the Coconut Rice. The curry was salty, where I didn't eat much of it. I ate from my bfriend's dish instead which was the farmer's cheese dosa. Delicious. He also ordered the rice with yogurt. This takes some getting used to but it was really good. By the end of dinner, his dishes were gone and my dish that was recommended by the waitress was still sitting there. 

Our server was definitely not attentive nor the bussers. Our water was always dry and the waitress NEVER came back to check on us, until she brought the check!!! So i didn't even have a chance to comment on the saltiness of the curry!!!

Would I come here again, probably just to give it one more chance. But I won't be ordering the Tamil Curry again. BLAH! And maybe next time, I'll have to wave the waitress down to complain.
author: Quynh L.

description:
Delicious, fresh and creative menu. I believe they roast some of their spices in-house, which makes for bright, rich flavors.

Be sure to order at least one of the dosas. I like the classic Masala dosa, but if you want to make a statement, order the paper masala dosa. It is wafer thin, crispy soft and fun for sharing.

The Fillmore branch is more formal, trendy and exotic while the Mission branch is a bit more casual and cozy. You can't go wrong with either one since their menus are nearly the same.
author: Jocelyn F.

description:
I have never been to an Indian restaurant that has Duck and Calamari on the menu! 
Had Samosa, Dosa (Chutney Masala) & Uttapam (South Indian Moons), which was good. For desert I had Toasted Coconut & Saffron Barfi (grated coconut rolled in filo pastry, fried, served warm with mint & Kiwi caramel), but I didn't like it at all.  
Overall, it is a trendy restaurant, and it was not the best Indian food I have had AND I did not get the feeling of eating "Indian".
author: Bogee B.

description: Authentic, creative, but pricy South Indian food. Fun decor and ambiance. We end up eating here every second or third visit to SF.
author: V R.

description:
What can I say?  I would be fine if the whole city was overrun with DOSA mania.  The DOSA is the best thing to hit since the chalupa drove America collectively loco around 1999.

Everyone who worked there was extremely accommodating as I shifted my reservation around in time and number.  And, when the food (chicken chenai + dosa masala) arrived, it was exactly what I've come to expect from DOSA -- mouth wateringly good.
author: Tim G.

description: Really delicious blend of Indian and California flavors (mango, etc)!
author: Leo R.

description:
Last year I went to ChoSun Kalbi in K Town LA.  Before going I kind of wondered what would constitute Korean "Fine Dining".  Better food, better Service, better decor / atmosphere or just Higher price?  Turns out it was all of those things.

I went to Dosa with a similar sense of wonder.  As soon as I walked in I had very high hopes.  The place just looks and feels incredible.  It is stylish and very well thought out.  Suffice it to say I'm a huge fan of the aesthetics of this place including the music.  

The service was equally good.  Bussers, servers and receptionist were friendly, helpful and efficient.  I'm a big fan of good service and my experience was excellent.  Even though we sat at the communal table, we were very comfortable and not treated like an after thought.

I really really liked the food.  The spring dosa and crab cakes.  Both very good and tasty.  But the Jumbo Prawns Masala was soooo goood with the coconut rice.  The combo of the two was just amazing and I highly recommend it to anyone going there.  

Price wise it maybe more expensive than your average indian restaurant but for a nice night out in SF it was right in line.  This is a terrific date place or group dining place.  There is a lot to talk about when you're there and you just feel a little more cool and hip without any pretense.
author: David C.

description:
Dosa is more "Fillmore" than "Japantown" -- I was frankly surprised to walk into the swank two story bar with contemporary chandeliers, two blocks from the Kinokuniya Japantown Mall parking lot (very reasonable btw).  Tuesday 7pm dinner for two and we were able to be seated immediately, though there was a good scene.

My friend was a returnee so she picked and we shared.  Mango and goat cheese salad was fresh and good sized.  Chennai chicken had a good kick, I like the spice.  Then we went for the Uttapam rather than Dosa - a bit thicker, we got the paneer and peas, yum.  Comes with three chutneys

We told them that we had a movie to catch in 45 min, and service was quite fast (and we made it) :)
author: Aki N.

description:
I came here on Saturday for lunch.  It's been a while since I've been here but their southern style Indian food is still excellent.  In fact I have an Indian friend that told me that Dosa is the only good Indian place in SF.

Dosa's food is favorful without the mouth burning peppers (aka naan n curry style)
author: David L.

description:
I'll try to keep this short:
Food: Good quality
Value for price: OK
Ambience: Chic (maybe too chic for Indian food)
Menu selection: Standard to special (they have the basic masala dosa, along with unique, California style variations)

The place is going for a very different vibe than most Indian restaurant; more of an Indian Bistro type feel. It reminded me of eating Indian food in 5star plus restaurants in India, where the food was definitely tailored for foreign visitors.

The quality of the food (Masala Dosa and the Chutney Dosa) was excellent. Portion size was great. The Sambar, and the two chutneys served as sides were decent. However, as an aficionado of Indian food, you are definitely paying for the ambience and the feel, more than you are paying for the food. 

They offered an extensive wine list, and even have suggested wine pairings to go with the prix fix menu. However, I would always recommend Kingfisher beer with any Indian food.

Decor was classy and elegant. They might play less samba and more Indian (or Indian-ish) music to give it more of an Indian feel (or not...) 

Overall, a good experience, but would definitley ONLY have the dosas there. Other appetizers and entrees seemed overpriced.
author: T C.

description:
Dosa, Dosa, Dosa, what can I say about you. I am a bit torn about this place because I am not used to spending this much money on Indian food. You are paying for the decor, the nice electro-house-soulful music, the type of crowd that this place attracts, the service, etc. but still I am torn. It's not the most expensive restaurant on the block but let's put it in perspective. If you are in the mood to have a nice dinner, people watch, have good intellectual conversations, and have good indian food, go here. If you just want indian food and you have your nice conversation with good friends at home, then go to Shalimar. 

This is a nice date place. It's perfect for eating before a movie at the Sundance Cinemas or even to have a drink and snack afterwards. For two people, we spent almost 70 bucks with a glass of wine and beer. I would also recommend this place for first time indian food eaters. The waitress had no problem describing all the different options for dining as well as doling out recommendations for both food and drink. 

What we ordered for 4 people:
Indian moon uttapom
some sort of dosa
chicken biryani
lamb tindali??? some sort of lamb dish with lemon rice I can't remember
the calamari
some crunchy dish
chicken chennai

I had a hard time stopping myself from eating the food. If you aren't afraid of spices and bold flavors in an upscale setting go here now!

PS I like this place better than Amber India hands down.
author: Charlene C.

description:
I have  been living in SF since 1994. I am well aware of the Healthy San Francisco health plan and it's requirements. It doesn't require employers to share the cost with community as you put it on your website. ( "requires that we share this cost with the community" ).

I guess, it's not illegal, just not ethical, in my opinion. If you want to have a business in SF  you SHOULD consider yourself being part of community and TAKE your responsibilities for yourself, not SHARE them with a community. Not cool at all...

P.S. We did ask for the mild dish.
author: Tatiana G.

description:
Dosa on Fillmore is worth every bit of five stars. We went the first time a week after they opened and then a week later. Both visits were amazing. The actual space is beautiful; love the decor and the ambiance. 

The food is AMAZING!  I could go on and on about each dish we tried but really you just need to go for yourself because it's hard for us to believe that any item would disappoint.  

The service on both our visits was excellent. The servers were familiar with the menu and were very attentive and did not rush you through your meal.  

We cannot wait to go back; THIS IS A NEW FAVORITE! They take reservations on Open Table (which we recommend); however they do keep some tables available for walk ins.
author: Romeo And Lola K.

description:
Dosa on Fillmore is incredibly beautiful: open, airy, gorgeous chandeliers, and rich colors to match the hustling and bustling atmosphere. 

We had once attempted to do a walk-in, and the hostess smiled and told us that it was no problem, the wait will be about an hour. Um, nevermind. 

This time I made a reservation for a Monday night and it was still packed. Prices are as reasonable as the location on Valencia. Dosas are all about $10. And they are quite large and very filling. 

I also ordered a chai that was really delicious. 

Service was very efficient and fast. About two seconds after we ordered our dosas, the dishes came. Some magic must have happened in the kitchen, or they are mind-readers and figured out what we wanted before we actually ordered. 

Anyway, I am sure Dosa will stay busy for a long time to come. And if I ever want to come back, I better plan it well ahead of time.
author: Candice B.

description:
This restaurant is meant to be looked at as much as tasted.  It's big, it's loud, it's sexy, it's cool.  It's not your "neighborhood" Indian place.

The menu is WAY too long.  It takes forever to decide what you want and many of the dishes are nearly identical.  That being said, the food is solid.  The flavors really come through and the textures of the dosas make it a pleasing overall meal.  Good place to go before seeing a movie at Kabuki or a show on Fillmore.  I would totally avoid it during those hours if you aren't seeing a show/movie though.
author: Tom R.

description:
Date: 2/12/09
Company: Jonas, Sameer & I
Time: 8:30
Menu:
- Lamb curry - 4 stars
- Lentil salad - 5 stars
- Peas & Paneer Dosa - 100 stars
- Lentil Dumplings (Voda something) 3 stars. 
Drinks: Malbec (they only have one on the menu by the glass and it's so tasty!)
Topics: Life, current events, work and all that good stuff. 
Advice: If you haven't been there already try it, I think you'll be blown away by the food. 

Cheers!
author: Nez B.

description: Yelp, I'm very upset with you for misdirecting me. This place is all flash with no substance. The trumpet mushroom uttapam was tasty. Greasy but tasty. Not exactly fitting for a restaurant of this sort of flash, but delectable nonetheless. The salmon curry dish was where everything went wrong. The dish, described as containing coconut milk (which tends to cool things down), was overpoweringly salty and acidic, as if it was made entirely of tomatoes boiled in vinegar. It was very hard to eat, never mind enjoy. We're chicken about complaining and simply hate food waste, so we swallowed the thing. Honestly, we just wanted to get out of there and get to our show. Around us, two service mistakes were made at the tables adjacent to us. No one looked happy. As far as the dosa and the uttapam dishes goes, they are good but really not worth the price or the pain of sitting through a restaurant trying to convince you they can churn out 5 star fare.
author: Brittany Y.

description:
Girls and boys - let me just say, the hype is real.

The restaurant itself is really nice. With soaring ceilings, intimate lighting (they dimmed the lights halfway through our meal!), multiple levels and floor to ceiling windows, you'll find the perfect level of sophistication without presumptuousness. Perfect for either a date or a catch up dinner between two friends =)

Our waitress was very helpful in helping us decipher the menu and after a lot of puzzled reading and mispronouncing we decided to just opt for what she had recommended:

-The "bread" was more like a cracker but with these crazy spices in it that made them taste amazing! As you chewed on it the flavor would completely change.
-Samosas: Very traditional - we ordered it because my friend had never tried samosas before. They give you both a Northern India and Southern India samosa and it was fun to have them side by side to compare and discuss.
-Paneer and Peas Dosa were highly recommended and we found it to be really delicious. For this one the paneer and peas were stuffed inside the dosa and we had three different sauces to try. Very good for the dosa novice =)
-Kerala Fish Moilee: DELICIOUS. Also highly recommended and although it was the more expensive things on the menu we were lured by the thought of black cod. I would suggest that you give it a try! Not only is the fish amazing but the moilee (Kind of similar to curry? But totally different flavor and less texture) really enhanced the flavor. There is no way you can go wrong with black cod!!

All in all a great experience and with the two of us splitting we ended up with a bill of $29 each (tip included). Totally reasonable! I will definitely be back as this is the new default restaurant I will be bringing my visiting friends. As a foodie I am always looking for new foods and flavors and am excited to explore everything that is offered on the menu at Dosa!!
author: Christina L.

description:
I highly recommend ordering the Signature Four Course Tasting with the wine pairing. 

It was one of the most enjoyable and the most excellent dinner experiences that I have had in quite some time. The wine pairings were simply perfect.
author: ruby h.

description:
Great food, great service, and what a beautiful restaurant!!!! Thankfully, we had a reservation - the place was packed on a Saturday night. The waiter was even flirty, which made for a fun meal!

They have at $35 tasting menu which was fantastic. One appetizer, 2nd course, and main course.

I got a salad for my appetizer, which was tasty. It was an interesting mix of greens, roots, and some crazy pears which were spiced, and didn't appear to be pears at all.

I had a dosa for my 2nd course - super tasty. One of the sauces was SUPER spicy and I had to order a beer because my tongue was burning off.

The main course was a veggie curry, which was delicious!! 

We had a chocolate cake for dessert, with vanilla ice cream, which was yummy too.

Their specialty cocktail menu is also interesting...some spicy drinks, some sweet drinks.

I would definitely go back.
author: Pam W.

description: The most exquisite south Indian cuisine I have ever had in or outside south india in a restaurant along with great quick service, and, mind it, am a south Indian :) Period.
author: A C.

description:
The great thing that really surprised me about this restaurant was their service. The host remembered who I was and called me from the bar after a 30 minute wait. The servers knew everything about the menu and I never had to ask for anything. Our cups were always filled with water and when my fork fell the floor someone grabbed it off the floor before I could and replaced it. Great Service! 

The food was great, curries were delicious, and dishes i had never tried before. The decor of the restaurant was really great and i remember seeing some awesome pictures from india up on the wall. I can't believe this space use to be the goodwill.
author: Charlie L.

description:
Mr. Dosa, this is going to be a love-hate affair.  I gave you another chance after the Fillmore Jazz Street Festival, and surprisingly the food was much better than my first time there.  I was so hesitant to bring friends ... but, you did well, exceeded the expectations from my first visit.  The service still needs to worked on a bit, felt rushed to get out and waitress was not nice.

Overall though, dosas are REALLY good here.
author: Mayah C.

description:
Dosa was delicious.  My girlfriend has a food allergy (Celiac, can't have gluten) which prevents her from being able to have most breads.  Not the case with the dosas (south indian style crepes), as they are made from rice and lentil flour.  And they were FANTASTIC!

We opted for the 4 course meal.  Food was served very promptly with little waiting between the courses.  For the appetizer, we had the curry prawns which weren't too spicey, but very good.  For the Dosa course, I had the Paneer and Peas Dosa (amazing!) and the grilfriend had the Potato dosa (equally amazing).  The dosa portions were large and we'd probably go back and order these individually next time.  After the dosas, it was on to the main course.  I ordered a halibut and the GF ordered a Vindaloo style Chicken.  Both of these left something to be desired.  By the time the halibut reached the table, it was room temperature and had to be sent back.

Although the main course wasn't as good as it could have been, the dosas themselves made this place worth going to.  We'll be back next time we go to SF!
author: David M.

description: Dosa is awesome.  The food is good every single time no matter what you order. Anjan, the owner, always comes by to say hello and the bartenders rock!  Highly recommend and definitely going back!
author: Ava D.

description:
Went here for dinner on Valentine's Day.  The food was superb...  I did the special Valentine's Day four-couse tasting and my date ordered off normal menu.

For starters, I got the Butternut Squash Soup and my date got the Dahi Vada.  The Butternut Squash Soup was roasted and puréed w/brown sugar, cumin, and served with a cilantro coulis.  It was fantastic but almost a little too spicy -- the squash kind of got lost in the heat.  The Dahi Vada was amazing: lentil dumplings topped with cool Straus organic yogurt, piped with tamarind & mint, mildly spiced.  It was an incredibly well-balanced, beautifully-presented dish, and I'd definitely recommend it.

For our second course, we shared the Paneer & Peas, which consisted of a Dosa (a savory rice-lentil crepe) filled with spiced, grilled farmer's cheese, peas & cilantro.  This course was okay but nothing to write home about.  The best part of the dish were the three sauces they gave you to dip the Dosa into, but I could have passed on it.... minus 1 star for a not-so-fantastic dish.

For the main course, I ordered the Eggplant Kofta and Kate got the Channa Bhatura. The Eggplant Kofta was spiced and cooked to perfection -- one of the best meals I've had in SF.  It consisted of eggplant and potatoes shaped into delicate 'meatless' balls, in a rich eggplant sauce, and served with lemon rice.  The 'meatless' eggplant/potato balls literally melted in your mouth, and the rich eggplant sauce surrounding them was blissfully delicious.  Two thumbs up.  The Channa Bhatura was also good -- a chickpea masala served with an oversized, soft, puffy wheat bread -- but the Eggplant Kafta was definitely our favorite of the two.

For dessert we ordered the Passion Fruit Custard with Coconut Tapioca... but to be honest, we were so full from our meal that we got it to go :)   Oh, and I almost forgot... If you're looking for something to wash the food down with, I recommend Maharaja --- an Indian Pilsner, light style with hoppy & oaky flavors from Navi Mumbai, India.  Most light beers are also a bit too light on flavor for my liking, but this one managed to be light, refreshing, really flavorful, and a good way to balance the spicy dishes.  

All in all we had a great experience at this place.
author: Shawn R.

description:
I had so much fun at Dosa!  The atmosphere was awesome, service was on-point and food was excellent!  We spent several hours there as we had a few drinks, an appetizer, dinner and then some tea afterwards.

Many, if not all, of the dishes are "family-style" so we just ordered a few items and shared.  We decided to try: Dahi Vada, Channa Bhatura, Raita, and Marsala DOSA.  All were fantastic!

This is one of those restaurants that I will compare my other Indian restaurant experiences against.  I will definitely be back to visit the next time I'm in SF!
author: Justin L.

description:
I've been twice here so far, once for lunch and once for dinner.

The Good: The food is good, the drinks are good, and I seriously hope the interior designer got a bonus cause this place is beautiful. The Masala dosa, bhatura, and vada sambar are things I've been craving since going. Prices are fair and not as high as you'd think judging from the looks of the place.

The "Eh": Like many reviewers have already said, even with a reservation, there will still be a wait, and some of the servers lack knowledge of their own menu (this was a lunch experience). Not traditional fare in any way. When was the last time you saw an egg section on the menu at Naan 'N Curry?

The Bad: Your food comes out fast and hot, but once your order is finished, don't expect to see your server unless you're good at catching fireflies (Sorry, Dosa, but I personally think it a failure when water glasses are left empty, especially if you're serving spicy food). And the jumbo jet-engine hand dryers in the bathroom might've blown my first layer of skin off.
author: Sachi T.

description: This South Indian delight is a food allergen sufferer's heaven. Dosa has a menu for Special Dietary Needs which conveniently charts the allergens in each dish.
author: GlutenFree G.

description:
I horned in on a friend's dinner plans the other night, and he was gracious enough not to call me out on it. They were going to Dosa after seeing The Watchmen (bastidges saw it without me!), so I met them there at 7:30 on Saturday.

The res was for 8, so we knew we had time to kill; we made our way to the bar and had a round while we waited. Very creative and yummy - although I'm personally not a fan of gin, which is the base for most of their specialty drinks.

Despite the crowd, we were seated on time, if not a few minutes early! We were seated upstairs, so we had a great view of the place - really added to the experience! The light fixtures are beautiful, and the overall atmosphere is fairly right on.

The five of us agreed to do the 4-course tasting with wine, and the food was truly delicious. We actually loved the "crack chicken" (aka channai chicken) so much as starters that we ordered another round for the table to share! So 2 orders from the tasting menu, *and* an additional one! Yowza.

The rest of the food was quite good, but the desserts were disappointing. I understand it's a different kind of sweet, so perhaps that wasn't the fault of the kitchen but more a question of incompatible palates.

Even more disappointing, though, were the wine pairings! Perhaps they should rethink what they're offering: maybe just do white wines/cocktail or beer pairings instead? None of the wines I had was particularly complementary to the food; they might have been fine on their own, but the point of a pairing is to bring out the flavors of both - right?

I'll definitely try again, but probably forgo the tasting menu - and certainly the wine pairings and dessert!

Oh, and the meal ended up being a little more expensive than I expected, especially considering the wine/dessert situations. Our bad for not voicing our dissatisfaction at the time.
author: Madeleine K.

description: If I'm going strictly for the food, I usually wind up at the Valencia location because it's small and comfortable and walking distance to great Mission bars. But if you're going for ambiance, Fillmore is your spot. The decor is as gorgeous as the clientele. The food is just as good at the Fillmore location as it is on Valencia. I would recommend a reservation at either location.
author: Kimberly Y.

description:
I love authentic indian food and was very disappointed in what I ate at Dosa -almost impossible to find a whole vegetable dish and they wouldn't change any existing dish to my taste-it felt like pre-packaged dishes serve to a hip crowd.
However, they have some interesting recipes and mostly the decor is worth having a drink.
author: Chloe L.

description:
The food is heavenly.  Think of something you usually enjoy, say a mango lassi, then come here for the best one around.  I also love that they don't fear a little spice in the food, I had a pea and paneer uttapam, it was a tiny bit greasy but in a way that totally hit the spot.  I can't stop thinking of the coconut chutney, I wish they served it in giant bowls.

I love the design, sleek modern with lots of banquets and wood.  And the people watching, well, I'm from Seattle, I've never seen people with diamond rings that big.
author: kat s.

description:
This review is about my experience In January.  A friend invited me along to take advantage of San Francisco's "Dine About Town." Being the closeout weekend of this culinary citywide celebration, I gladly obliged. The restaurant we agreed upon was Dosa at Fillmore. He had been to the Dosa at Valencia and wanted to see if this newer location surpassed his experience at the former.

As I stepped into the airy interior of the restaurant, I was greeted by warm, earthy tones of color. The restaurant space is large and industrial, with massive windows that reach to the ceilings and an impressive-looking bar area. It was hard to miss this large, imposing restaurant on the corner of Fillmore and Post. Yet once I sat down, the overall feeling was one that was inviting, because of the balance of the contemporary and traditional feel of the decor, accentuated by a nice gold mezzanine area.

I sat down to meet my friend, who was already enjoying a thick Mango Lassi. We took a moment to peruse the regular lunch menu, especially chock full of salivation-inducing concoctions of veggies and spices, before asking for the "Dine About Town" menu. For $17.95 we had the choice of one of four starters and one of four entrees.

We chose the Red Beet Cumin Soup and Chennai Chicken to start and the Paneer Dosa and Mint Cilantro Masala Dosa as our main dishes. A delicately thin and lightly fried appetizer occupied us as we awaited our order.

The soup was exquisitely delish. Dollops of creme fraiche adorned the perfectly pureed beets. It was a perfect palate primer: light, warm, and soothing in my mouth. The Chennai Chicken had a tangy touch of spice. I usually do not opt for the salty, fried fare, but the accompanying yogurt dip complemented it very well.

This was my first time experiencing South Indian cuisine. The namesake dish, dosa, is popular in the region, and I was excited to try it as soon as I caught a glimpse of the numerous versions of it being delivered to the mostly 20s/30s patrons throughout the restaurant. Dosa is a rice and lentil crepe, filled with hearty goodness such as potatoes and other vegetables. The Paneer Dosa was stuffed with farmer's cheese, peas, and cilantro. It came plated in several individual rolls, ready to be devoured with your hands. The Mint Cilantro Dosa, with its soft, curried potatoes, had more warmth and kick. It was served flat on a large plate.

Both dosa dishes included on the side a cup of sambar (a lentil and vegetable stew with tamarind for dipping) and two servings of chutney: a slightly spicy tomato chutney and a fresh coconut chutney. The mixture of ingredients and textures was refreshing. Like the contemporary and traditional components of the ambiance, the different elements of the dosa and dips (sweet and spicy; crisp and soft) complemented each other in surprising and very pleasing ways.

Our experience at Dosa was exceptional. The service was prompt, attentive, and non-pretentious. The pricing is reasonable for the quality of food received, although it is a bit of a splurge for those on a student budget. I recommend this place for anyone who has not yet experienced this South Indian specialty. It might even be a good consideration for a soon-to-be-scheduled romantic lunch or dinner...
author: Mads M.

description: americanized but still good dosas and dahi vada, nice sit down place
author: Niket B.

description: Cool spot , great food, the old fashion was on point , try the masala dosa and the lamb chops .
author: Makism Z.

description:
Whoa! This is good, very good!

Love at first light! From the door to the wall, the place just welcomes you! The service is outstanding. 

Unlike the other Dosa location (I have not been there in a long time), the acoustics here is good. You can hear the guy (or girl) across the table.

Oh, about the food - wonderful. I am used to high-end places not delivering on authenticity. But this place rocks on that count too. Go for the Habanero Dosa if you got balls :-)
author: Guru T.

description: Definitely on point with the South Indian food.  We had the mango lassi, paneer and romaine salad, curd rice, egg poriyo dosa, and habanero dosa.  The dosa and salad were a mini version and totally worth the price and quality.  The ambiance was great too - spacious, and beautiful.  I definitely wish this place located itself to New York so I could visit it again!  The rest of the menu looked delicious as well - and its located close to the 38 bus (two blocks away) that goes on Greary Street.  Service was on point, too.
author: Namrata A.

description:
Loved everything I ate and drank here. 

The music, ambiance and service were all great too!
Romaine salad with toasted farmer's cheese=refreshing and delicious
Crab cakes=UMMMMMMMM (fresh, crab-filled & and spicy)
Cilantro fish=Perfection
Dosas with lenti and chutney=Hot, rich and satisfying
Maharaja Beer =perfect compliment to a mildly hot (for me) dining experience!

I will return

Only drawback is service can be erratic...
author: Agent F.

description: Ok food and decent service.  They have a few good dishes (e.g., bhel puri, vada pao).  However, their main dishes are just average. Ambience is good and the seating is spacious.  Waiters are courteous.  Overall, a decent experience
author: S S.

description: Went for dinner without a reservation on a Monday night at 7pm.  Lucky I supposed, because it filled up quickly after we were seated. Very nice and helpful waitress.  She recommended delicious cocktails and explained how the menu works and what was what (for first timers to Dosa like myself).  There were only two of us, but thankfully we were seated at a bigger table for four people.  This was good to accomodate the array of dishes we shared.  One of the apps comes as a slider, you can get 1 or 2.  If you're sharing apps, I would highly recommened not sharing this and getting 1 for yourself to enjoy.  My friend and I were both in agreement when we come back (bc we WILL be back) we would order a lot more of these and then maybe another app or smaller main course.  Basically the potato-like pancake thing that comes in slider form is amazeballs.  The special dipping sauces we recommened too but we felt were unecessary bc sauce comes with everything.  I had a cocktail with some ginger beer and real ginger in it-yummy and strong!
author: Chantal B.

description:
First trip to Dosa Fillmore last night (a Thrs). Was first struck by the space. It's huge compared to Valencia and gorgeous. It's got an 'upscale Indian' sensibility. The monster windows are fantastic as well.

Hostess service was great. They greeted us with a smile and were happily offered to take our coats and seat us.

Our server left a little to be desired. She was very disinterested and once entrees were served was a ghost. We gave the benefit of the doubt but still had to ask a busboy to get her so we could order another bottle of wine. I think this was a unique experience based on watching service at other tables.

Food was excellent. We started with the North-South Samosa's the HOT sauce was great. The Chile Prawns were also very well prepared, not too hot but enough kick to be interesting.

Our entrees were Peppercorn Chicken and the Duck Spinach masala. The chicken was awesome...Highly recommended.

We had a couple of $36 bottles of Pinot that we were very pleased with. They have a well rounded wine list that's a plus.

Quick recap
Decor *****
Hostess *****
Server *
Busboys *****
Food *****

Definitely will return and recommend!
author: Sonny Y.

description:
My first experience at the Valencia Dosa was so good, a rich memory even years later. And I've always wanted to try their brunch, so it was perfect chance to go to the new location on fillmore. After weeks of nagging anyone who would listen, finally made it this morning.

I'll get this out of the way - definitely prefer the mission location. Maybe it's my need for a little urban edge in my surroundings, this Dosa was just too, um, sterile. Massive, almost cavernous, I think you could fit three of the original inside. Didn't add to the ambiance at all. And the music was an odd mix of indian and pop. Odd.

But forget all that, because the food was awesome. To start, we split the fruit napolean, a sweet uttapam (thicker dosa) topped with fruit and and complemented by strawberry chutney and yogurt on the side. Delicious. For my main I had the egg poriyal dosa. Was initially bummed that 1) egg whites were not an option and 2) they couldn't take the chiles out (something about it being pre mixed), but I ended up being rather impressed. Not oily at all, and as the waiter promised, it wasn't really spicy. I got three filled dosas and some soup concoction on the side. For $10, it definitely felt worth it.

Final verdict - a mediocre ambiance (my opinion) with terrific food. If you are only going to do to one, I highly, highly recommend the original down in the mission, but food wise, you can't go wrong either way.
author: Jason B.

description:
A Saturday night at 9:30.

Ratings from beginning to end:

Arrived a few minutes early for our 9:30 reservation, the table was ready, they sat us right away. 
Host who sat us, not great, not offensive.  
Service was terrific.  
Food and cocktails really good.
Prices, as expected.
The room and lighting, really good.  The two amorphous fixtures in the front windows are really fantastic.
Ask for a table upstairs, on the rail that overlooks the restaurant.  
Fun.
author: Gary H.

description: Excellent! one of my favorite restaurants in the city. Consistant quality & Nice wait staff
author: Leslie E.

description:
Beautiful Bollywood interiors, super cool bar. The food is excellent, different from other Indian restaurants in SF. I always order the paper dosas. 

The service is uneven. One of us ordered a cocktail which took forever to arrive, then the person serving us was replaced by someone else who did manage to get the bartender to finally make the drink. Phew! These personnel mishaps should not be happening anymore in a restaurant that has been open for many months.

Read the rest of the reviews here, it seems management has a management problem.
author: Esme V.

description: mmmmmmm i dont know about this place. We went for my dads bday because he really wanted to try it. I've never tried Indian food before. We went on a Sunday night and the place was CROWDED, very surprised. We had to call 1 week in advance for reservations and they only had 1 table left, so it's very popular. I really didn't like any of the food, wasn't surprised that I didn't. However their salad was really good and the lamb was good. It seems like a lot of people like this place, so i'd suggest for anyone who likes Indian food to try it out but if you have never tried it before, don't waste you time.
author: Alyssa R.

description:
I am in love with this eaterie.  My only recommendation is don't allow them to seat you by the kitchen.  You'll be in the path of the staff going back and forth and it can get annoying.  

Great for happy hour!  For dinner, I recommend asking to be seated upstairs.  It is cozier and the service is excellent!  The food is out of this world - lots of chutney choices and lamb and chicken.  The wine list is extensive and they have awesome original cocktails.  Or go for a beer.  Either way, you will be impressed.
author: Arturo S.

description:
Excellent food.  Efficient kitchen.

Hipster vibe.

LOUD.  

Tables upstairs are very close together.  I ended up 'listening' to the kids sitting next to me on what seemed to be a first or second date, based on their conversation. Unfortunately,  I could hear them better than I could my husband sitting across from me.
author: KanakaWahine C.

description:
What I loved about Dosa unfortunately, was not the food, but the restaurant accomodations. The cozy decor, the ambient lighting, the spectacular chandeliers, the high-backed chairs, the sparkly bar... all together make for a beautiful restaurant experience. But the food didn't impress me much...

We ordered the Masala Dosa - had never had one before, not even when I was in India! When the dosa arrived, there wasn't a lot of food on the plate. The curried potatoes were good and the flaky bread was fine but it looked as though they forgot to fill the plate with the rest of the food! I wanted more! Also had the Crab Vadas and again.. it didn't impress.. I've had much better crabcakes. 

I also had the Tamil Vegetable Curry which had a very off color - it was the color of gray brain matter... no joke! I thought to myself, "Ok.... interesting color... maybe it's good... I'll give it a try." It was bland and there weren't enough vegetables for the amount of curry that was in it. I had to nibble off of Ryry's delicious Magalorian Prawn Masala to try to make my meal a complete one. Ryry's mom loved her Tamil Lamb Curry. Too bad I don't eat lamb.

For the prices that they charge, the food should be better and there should be more of it! But I guess, again, I chose the wrong dishes =/ Any suggestions?
author: Christine C.

description: The Dosa= really really great. The entire meal was excellent. Although we had a prior reservation, the hostess told us we had to leave by 7:30 (our reservation was at 6:15). I thought this was pretty tacky for this type of restaurant
author: Danny L.

description:
Came here after swimming and was starving!  The wait was a bit long and mostly in part from some staff inefficiency.  There were tables available but no one was clearing them.  I think we must have arrived at the end of a big rush and the staff was going into "whew that was a big rush, lets take a break" mode.

Food was great and the restaurant is very comfortable to be in - good vibe.
author: Kristine K.

description:
LOTS OF TLC !!

A magnanimous space that allows beautiful daylight to stream through enhancing the grace and beauty of the well thought lovely design.

creative dishes, luscious flavors, gorgeous presentation and abundant portions.

some favorites - warm beet soup, the habanero dosa, mango shrimp and the coconut rice is out-of-this-world!

these folks deserve some BIG props ! Keep up the great work......
author: debora s.

description:
My first question to alot of people who reviewd this place. 
What the hell were you doing eating LAMB KOFTA and CHAAT in a place called DOSA?! Go eat the dosa and the uttappams people!!
Jeez!
Anywoo, onto my humble opinion about the place.

I kept hearing Dosa this and Dosa that from a bunch of my friends and my husband and I thought to myself, "Hmm, must go check this place out".
So, I wheedled my husband into making reservations for the 2 of us, call it a date night, if you might! (Hey, that rhymed!)
I hadn't expected it to be a fancy shmancy restaurant, honestly. I just thought it'd be like every other South Indian restaurant in the bay, ergo, small, shanty, packed with desis and the likes.
To my pleasant surprise, it IS this fancy shmancy place with a bar and a whole bunch of non-desis walking about! I felt under-dressed (All I wore was a top and a pair of jeans and flats!) :o)
Now, my husband and I are both south Indians (we hail from the same city as the chefs!! :o) ) So when you say the menu has Dosa, we know what to expect and how it should taste.
And I fell in love with it. Closest to home made dosa in taste that I have eaten in the Bay area. Their dosa and uttapam platter was just perfect and hit the right spot. However, my warning to those who are willing to experiment with Indian food outside the likes of Chicken Tikka, the dosas here are on the richer side, ergo, ooze with love (read butter/oil). Which is not the usual case. But hey, I am hooked! We ordered their Uttapam platter, which is basically tiny uttapams, the size of your palm with different garnishes, making each one taste a little different from the other. We also ordered their Chennai Chicken, which brought back memories from when an aunt of mine made it for me and I just went kookoo over it! Delicious!
Their sambhar was PERFECT. Not too watery (like most places here make it) and not too thick either. We had their tomato pepper rasam, called the Rasam "Fire Broth" as an appetizer, and I think it could have used a little more boiling. 
Their alcohol menu is a little off the hook. It's not your standard alcohol menu. It's the Dosa menu, so off the hook. I would suggest you give their  Peony a shot and also the Bollywood Hills. Splendid!! 
We didn't have any dessert as we were stuffed from all the food we'd ordered and I instantly slipped into a food coma.

Their service was muy excellente. We were constantly asked how our food was, whether we were enjoying the experience etc etc etc without them sounding imposing or anything.
If I want good dosa, I know where to head.
Now, if only they opened one in the East Bay.
author: Ranjani S.

description: Lovin' this Indian cuisine! Don't ask for the Naan cause there isn't any....instead this southern indian cuisine is anything but northern! The Tamil Lamb Curry was divine and their Uttapam is light and crepe like!!!! If you don't watch yourself you could easily eat a whole plate! Yum!
author: Nell C.

description: Great twist on modern Indian cuisine. Every dish we ordered was flavorful and refreshing. A must for every food lover.
author: Gopi V.

description:
We had dinner there last Monday before a concert. Three of us shared and there was plenty to fill us up.
We got there a little before the dinner hour and sat at the bar and had a drink. The barkeep was busy chatting to another couple at the bar and said we'd have to wait. He acted like he couldn't be bothered. If he thinks he is being suave he is sadly mistaken. He acted like an idiot being nonchalant to the point of rudeness. It wasn't busy at all and we were not served until a *nice lady* came out from the back and got us our drinks.

Appetizer: Prawn Chile Fry - flavors were good, but the prawns were overcooked (hard and very dry) and rather too salty.
Bhatura: I am not sure what the point is of this puffy bread. It was kinda flavorless.
Dinner: Bagara Baingan - I am ambivalent when it comes to eggplant, but this was absolutely delicious. *drool*
Chicken "Dumm" Biryani - also very good.
I will definitely have to go back and try the Uttapam and Dosa.

I ordered a beer with dinner, Pinkus, from Germany - a Hefeweissen which was excellent. Even at $9 a bottle, I found myself having a second!! 
We sat at a table in the bar area for dinner and the waitress was very attentive and super nice. She got an extra tip for getting our order in and bringing our food quickly.
author: Kipp P.

description:
Cool decor n ambiance, but the hallmark of a good restaurant is the food... And this place was a notch above ok. I got a lunch dosa with a lemonade. My paneer and peas dosa was greasier than it needed to be and the lemonade came in this scrimpy glass that I managed to finish in 2 gulps. I know i know, these upscale places give the "proper" portions n what not ... but I felt a cool drink on a hot day could have been at least the size of the water glass. 

I'll still go back and try more things, but wouldn't go out of my way for it.
author: C C.

description:
The decor is beautiful, but it can get quite loud in here.  However, I was part of a 15 person party, so maybe we were the loud ones??

It should be noted that my experience of Indian food has not gone further than Chutney (in the TL), Spicy Bite, or Naan & Curry, so I've never really had higher end Indian food.  Nonetheless, I enjoyed it.

I had the $39 4 course:

First Course - Fiery Fruit: This dish caught me by surprise.  I wasn't sure how fruit and spices would taste together, but it actually tasted great!  Just don't imagine it as fruit with hot sauce all over it, as I thought that's what it would be.  But rather, it was fresh fruit that was gently flavored with a light and tangy sauce with a hint of ginger.

Second Course - Chutney Masala Dosa: Yum!  The skin on the dosa was perfect - not too thick or thing.  And the potatoes were perfectly seasoned.  There were supposed to be cashews, but I didn't taste any...

Third Course - Peppercorn Chicken: This was my favorite dish of the night.  The chicken was tender and fell off the bone (as described in the menu).  The lemon rice was tasty too.

Fourth Course - Gulab Jamoon: My least favorite course.  The dish would have been better had the syrup been drizzled over the dough balls.  Instead, they were soaking in the syrup, making way sweeter and heavier than I prefer.

Overall, it was a good dining experience.  I hesitate to give it 5 starts because I've only been here once.
author: Dorothy T.

description: This was my first time at Dosa, and I had heard and read good things about the place. Well, I have to say that the first impression was positive: the entry, the decor and the service were great. Very pretty wall coverings, chandeliers, etc. Servers and busboys always attentive.
