I was looking forward to the food, and though it was tasty, it was not enough for a 4 or 5 star rating.  Dosas were crisp and light, but the fillings were bland...and we tried three different ones!  The sauces were so-so. My companions loved the sprouted mung bean salad, my fruit salad was pretty enough, but too spicy, despite my server assuring me that it wasn't.  My mint lemonade was good, but not great, and more ice than drink.  The desserts sounded tasty, but we were full after our lunch and declined.  I have to say, the music in this place was jarring....way too loud and techno.  Probably a fun night scene, but not so pleasant for a Sunday lunch.  All in all, I enjoyed our lunch, but not sure I would recommend or come back anytime soon.
author: Colleen B.

description:
Overall this is a pretty cool place. Totally trendy decor but I admit, it is pretty awesome. The place is large but I would recommend getting a reservation as it can get crowded. They have some of those "community" tables which can be fun but I've found the service is not as good here. Try their Dosa, it's great (what a shocker, right?)!

I think this is a good date place as well as a good group place. The prices are reasonable...if you like Indian food (South Indian I believe) you will be happily surprised...plus it's cool to finally visit an Indian restaurant with such modern decor!
author: Amber P.

description: Went for NYE dinner.  Food was great and service was ok.  BUT.  We had a NYE reservation for 8 people, 4 couldn't show up as one of their relative was admitted into ER all of a sudden.  Dosa could put 2 of our cancellation spots to use by 2 new customers, BUT, still charged us for all the 8 spots.  I understand that they should charge something for the no shows on a busy NYE dinner, but since they already had 2 of the spots re-sold, they shouldn't have charged us for those 2.  They did give us a $100 gift card, but charging $500 extra instead of $250 wasn't fair in my opinion.
author: FastRod X.

description: You must try their prawn curry and other curries away from the typical dosas if you are going there again. Get the coconut rice with it. Also skip appetizers as they are tiny and can;t be shared and go directly to the main course.
author: Priyanka T.

description:
Dosa was AMAZING! Everything from the service, to the food, to the drinks, to the atmosphere was amazing from the minute that we walked through the door. 

We got to Dosa later in the evening; therefore we only had to wait about 15 minutes. In that time we grabbed a drink at the bar. I had one of the best lemon drop martinis that I have ever had. The bartender was also very knowledgeable and friendly. Warning: the drinks are strong, but since they are mixed so well you won't even notice. 

Moving right along, the food was the best that I have had in the city so far. I didn't know what to expect; therefore I asked the waiter plenty of questions and he was very helpful. I ended up with the spring dosa and it was delicious. My boyfriend had the chicken and eggplant baingan bharta and his mom had lamb curry and they both agreed that their dish was great, but the spring dosa was the winning dish of the night. We also had the onion pekora and the chennai chicken for an appetizer and they were both very good and the right size for an appetizer; not to small, not to big. We finished our meal off with the toasted coconut and saffron barfi dessert. Despite the weird and slightly disgusting name the toasted barfi was very tasty! 

The service was the best in any restaurant so far. The seating hostess was great, the bartender was knowledgeable as well as the waiter. My boyfriend dropped his fork on the floor when he sat down and he didn't even have to ask for another fork. Within minutes one of the wait staff came over with a new fork and replaced the fork that had been dropped! The bussing staff removed plates and refilled water so smoothly and efficiently that you would hardly notice what they were doing. They were great at their job. 

Lastly, the atmosphere was very nice. It was dark, but not too dark. They had a nice selection of music that was at the right volume. I have been in a lot of places where the music is so loud that I can hardly hear myself think, but Dosa was not one of these places. 

I will return to Dosa for more dosas and you should definitely give it a try!
author: Carly W.

description: Food is a solid 3 stars perhaps even 4...we started with the samosas which were ok, the sauce that came with them were much yummier than the samosas!  Then we shared mango shrimp curry and the white truffle dosa with a side of coconut rice.  The food is flavorful, well spiced and oh so tasty.  The reason I couldn't give it 4 stars is the service or lack there of.  The waitress took our order and we never saw her again until she brought us the check.  A little weird for a nice restaurant like Dosa, I expected a bit more service.
author: Mao K.

description:
The space and atmosphere in this restaurant is incredible. I especially find it enjoyable because it is a creative re-use of a former Goodwill store, which was a former bank branch if I am not mistaken.  The result is an open atmosphere that is modern yet comforting at the same time. 

I am not a huge Indian food connoisseur, but that has not kept me from eating my fair share of it. I must say, that the food at Dosa feels fresh and made from quality ingredients. I went on a random Monday night pretty late, so didn't have to wait, which probably greatly increased my enjoyment factor, but make a reservation and grab a drink at the bar if you have to wait. I probably would make your reservation a little before the time you usually reach starvation status because nothing makes me crankier than waiting once I am hungry even if the environment is cool and the drinks are good. 

I will definitely be coming back, and I think this place will do good things for the surrounding area, which makes me enjoy it even more. Props to the owners of this place for bringing something new and nice to Fillmore.
author: Matthew F.

description:
Ive been to both dosa's and both are excellent, but decided to review the fillmore location since I just went there a couple weeks ago. We made reservations in advance and were seated fairly promptly...maybe waited 10 min. We had really fun cocktails at the bar. This location is very hip and larger than the mission spot. 

We took my brother and sis in law who came in from Scottsdale, AZ. They love indian food and south indian is different than the usual fare, and a definite treat for out of towners.

We tried pretty much every section of the menu and every single dish was excellent. All the food was spicy, flavoful, and really fun to eat...playful but not messy. One standout dish I keep thinking about going back for is the chili spiced corn on the cob. It is so incredible. You have to try it. YUMMY!!

I cannot wait to go back to DOSA. I only wish this location was walking distance to a bart station.
author: susan c.

description: Brilliant place!..amazing ambience..good service and definitely the best dosas in the western hemisphere!!....and the in-house cocktails are brilliant as well!..the chennai chicken and lamb kabobs always hit the spot
author: Nav N.

description:
If you're thinking that Indian places look or feel like the black hole of Calcutta, think again.  Dosa is large, bright, modern in every sense.  The food is nice although not to my taste.  I especially liked a salad of mung sprouts that was filled with lentils: nice, clean and light.  How they get the dosas so thin I would not venture to say, but these are interesting. A fruit Uttapam was a favorite for the child at the table and the adults liked it as well.   

If you have a youngster arrive when the place opens and you can get in and out for brunch on the weekend before the place fills.  Now that's an option that many will find attractive.
author: David D.

description:
At first glance, this upscale rendition of its Mission District ancestor seems to cater to the chichi Pac-Heights/Marina white folks (I'm one of them, so I can say that!) who wouldn't venture down into the more "vibrant" parts of town for good eats.  Thus, for our group of four (who have all been to the Mission Dosa multiple times) the expectations were cautious.

In spite of the gorgeous decor and well-dressed clientele, this new Dosa continues to deliver the goods of its edgier Mission cousin: Tasty and innovative South Indian food with subtle California twists.

The Bhel Poori appetizer was excellent, as was the Cochin Calamari.  I had the Habanero-Mango Dosa, which had just enough fire to scare away spiceophobes, but not so much that it was uncomfortable (being a spice lover, my tolerance is above average). My wife had the Onion Rava dosa which was delicious and large enough to share the leftovers for lunch the next day. 

The mango lassis and non-alcoholic German beer were also excellent.

The desserts were quite good: Gulab Jamun served warm the way we like it, and although I'm not a Rasmalai fan, the three other diners (all of South Asian heritage) raved about it being "absolutely the best in the city." 

Not lost in all of this was the excellent service.  We were visited by no fewer than four different staff members who ensured that our food was fresh, finished plates were removed, and glasses were full.  

The only drawback was that, in spite of having made OpenTable reservations days in advance (don't even try to get in without them), we were seated at a small table near the bar, which did not seem to have the same amount of space as the 4-tops in the main dining area.  Thus, even with only three appetizers on the table, it was exceedingly crowded and took some maneuvering just to pass dishes without knocking anything off the table.  

Dosa would do itself a service if it replaced these smaller tables with dinner tables.  Next time, I will request a full-size table.

Another improvement would be the music selection, which seemed schizophrenic and distracting.  Dosa should really infuse more contemporary/modern South Asian music and less Billboard Top 40.  The visual atmosphere is far too pleasing for such audio dissonance. Between the loud bar area and even louder music, be prepared to speak up in order to hold any type of conversation with your dinnermates.

Nevertheless, we foresee this becoming our neighborhood haunt (it's about time this neighborhood got some palatable South Asian food!), and suggest that you check it out immediately.  There's also a small, upper-level room which looks perfect for cocktail parties.

Make a reservation, insist on a full-size table, and enjoy!
author: Sharand N.

description:
I heart Dosa!  The food is delicious, the service is quick and attentive, and the venue is gorgeous! 

I love the Masala Dosa with all its flavorful dipping sauces.  The vegetable curry with the coconut rice is divine.  The wine and cocktail list is thoughful and tasty.

I didn't give Dosa 5 stars because their brunch menu is misleading- it's the regular menu served at 11:30am.  If you're going to say "Sunday Brunch", you should probably have a Sunday brunch menu, eh?  Oh!  The curry bloody Mary - not so good.
author: Zaneta C.

description:
Two girlfriends and I ate at Dosa on Friday night around 6pm.  I'm glad we got there early because it got crowded really quick.  We ordered  the Chicken Korma, the Rava Masala dosa, the Carmelized Union uttapam and a nice bottle of white wine.  The dosa and the uttapam came out first and they were both delicious.  The sauces that came out with each dish was such a great compliment to the dosa and the uttapam.  You can definitely taste the quality of the food.  It sure ain't no Naan N Curry!  By the time the Chicken Korma came out (which honestly was a long time after the first two), we were pretty full.  The Korma was ordinary but nice to try.  Next time, I'll stick with just the dosa and uttapam.  

Our whole meal was about $80 but it wouldn't have been too bad if we didn't order the vino.  Service was good and the highlight of the my dining experience was definitely the ambiance and decor of the restaurant.  So pretty!  I will definitely be back to try more!
author: Helen V.

description: BEST Indian food I have ever had in my life. The dishes are unique and not the boring run of the mill dishes. They are all spiced perfectly. There are a few vegetarian options as well. Wait staff is very friendly. On weekends it gets packed so make a reservation or go early. Drinks are great as well. It is pricey, but you get what you pay for! Great for date night!
author: Erin H.

description:
I used to like the intimate, warm confines down in the Mission.  So I brought the family to this one, thinking, hey, this will be great.  Wrong.  Here's what I didn't like about it:  
Price.  
Quality. 

Here's what was okay:
Service. 
Drinks.
That appetizer with the fried falafel-analogue in yogurt sauce, which was also good at the Mission incarnation.  

Expensive Indian food is like expensive Mexican food.  There's no point.  The cuisine is just as good at more modestly priced establishments.  

So basically, this yuppie Dosa helped me realize that when I worked and went out in the Mission a few years ago, I had poor taste in food, clothes, friends, place of work, and well, everything.  Except sex partners.  There are lots of good sex partners the Mission.
author: Ed F.

description: Great food, but way too expensive, especially when I know that what I'm paying for is the ambiance (which, granted, is also beautiful, but I don't want to pay extra for a cool chandelier and some mood lighting). How do I know this? Dosa On Valencia.  Heading there next time - same food, without the hefty price tag :)
author: Priya R.

description: Great south Indian food.one of the best I have had in the USA..if you in SfO do not cross this off your list..must go for sure!!
author: Rujul S.

description: I've been wanting to try this place for years now and finally made it here last Saturday night. The ambience was classy and the lights were dimmed down low. I had seriously under-estimated how busy it would get and failed to make a reservation. Luckily for my husband and I though, we were able to get in at 10pm. I tend not to dine this late, but since the movie theater was one block away we managed to grab a movie and make it in good time for dinner. So anyhoo.... the dosa's were phenomenal! They had every variety you could think of and the accompanying dips and the poppadoms were divine! We of course ordered the most expensive stuff on the menu - the vindaloo duck, the lamb curry and one of their stuffed dosa's - of which I forget the name. Everything was delicious, expecially the lamb. Would definately go back, particularly as this is a great place to dine with friends and family or on birthdays. It's kinda pricey though, so I'm tempted to try their other location on Valencia for a cheaper treat! So worth it though and definately hit the spot! Drooooooooooooollllll!!! Since it was so dark in there I didn't get to take a pic to share on Yelp.
author: Sabina H.

description: pretty shi-shi place, good food, nice atmosphere, and pricey...but hey its SF :)
author: Syed A.

description:
I went here last weekend for dinner with the bf (on a Saturday at around 6:45).  I had been wanting to try this place for a while, partly because it looks gorgeous from the outside, and I'd rubber-neck this place every time I passed it while riding the 22.  Upon entering, the decor blew me away - the chandeliers, tall ceilings, long banquet tables, and dark decor told me I had entered Swanksville, and would be in for an elegant meal.  

We hadn't made a reservation, but the hostess told us we could wait for 20-30 minutes and grab a drink at the bar.  We obliged, and the wait turned out to be only about 20 minutes.  While we waited, we sipped on unique, exotically-spiced cocktails served up by a super-serious-about-his-job bartender.  It was really amusing to watch him mix a couple drinks - he does NOT play around and used very exaggerated gestures as if he really was putting on a show...Tom Cruise circa 1988 release of 'Cocktail' - eat your heart out!

After the bar entertainment, we were seated at the end of the banquet table in the main room.  Our waitress was really helpful and recommended some items on the menu.  We ended up getting the four-course tasting menu, at $39 a pop.  Among other things, we had spicy lamb, spicy pepper chicken, and delicious dosas.  If anything, you cannot leave here without tasting the dosas (an Indian crepe) along with the scrumptious dipping sauces.  One thing to note is that our waitress was really upset when we were accidentally served a spicy prawn entree that we hadn't ordered, and she made sure that we were comped for that dish...so the bf got lucky and ate 5 courses!

The desserts I could have lived without, but I give them points for originality - we had fried donut balls in a syrupy sauce and a very interesting kaffir "ice cream" [quotations used because the consistency was not that of typical ice cream - it was super frozen].

All in all, the experience was unique, and even though I'm by no means an expert on Southern Indian cuisine, I can tell when a meal is fresh and delicious, and Dosa's certainly was!  *Caveat: will have to limit my trips here to special occasions only because the total tab (including two drinks each) came out to over $150 for two, so the lack of the fifth star is due to the fact that it wasn't the most reasonably priced meal...
author: Kira K.

description: My favorite restaurant in the city!  Reminds me of the best restaurants I went to in Mumbai!
author: Leanne B.

description:
We were up visting the in-laws for Christmas and after a day of shopping needed a place to eat.  Based on Yelp reviews AND after we found out that Original Joes had a fire a month ago and was not open -we found ourselves at Dosa.
We waited 20 minutes on a Sunday - not bad.
We have never had Dosas or Uttapam before, we had no idea what they were to tell the truth.
Our server was great - very helpful and we ordered the: 

Duck Spinach Masala and Paneer
Masala Dosa
Egg Uttapam

It was all very good but the Egg Uttapam was our favorite.  It was sort of like breakfast for dinner but we loved it.  
We werent crazy about the sauces other than the lentil but the food really didnt need a sauce.  It had a ton of flavor all on its own.

We had a great time - the place is beautiful, the servers nice and even tho they were busy, service was pretty quick.  I didnt mind sitting so close to our neighbors because sometimes its fun to listen in to conversations. :0
author: C W.

description: amazing food..amazing service...will definitely go back..try their dahi wada for one of the most exquisite dish presentations..
author: Sriganesh R.

description:
after going to dosa on valencia a few years back and walking away less than satisfied, i was somewhat hopefully when coming back to the newer spot on fillmore.  after all, i've heard very nice things about the new location and word had it that the food was better than the valencia location.

we had a large group celebrating a friend's b-day and we were seated promptly upon arrival.  our waitress overall was very friendly and helpful along with being very attentive.  since we had a large group we had to do the tasting menu.  i had the following for each course:

course #1:
prawn chile fry - three small pieces of shrimp and a salad.  the shrimp were a tad over cooked and i didn't dig the flavor.  the micro greens salad was pretty good.

course #2:
spicy mung dosa - this was the highlight of all the courses.  the potatoes inside were very nice and the dosa itself was cooked just right with good flavor thanks to the mung.

course #3:
halibut arugula curry - huge disappointment.  while the halibut was cooked nicely, the arugula curry wasn't my thing.  the accompanying tomato rice was overcooked too.

course #4:
chai cola float - i was hoping for a bit more but i didn't find this to be anything special.  the ginger-cardamom ice cream was tasty but i didn't like the spiced cola part.

there were a few glaring issues when food was brought out.  i was expecting for all dishes to come out at the same time as you would normally expect of a tasting menu but there were delays in the dishes coming out to the entire group for each of the courses.  we mentioned this to the owner and he walked in mid-sentence.  great...

most glaring of all was when the birthday girl had dessert come out for her and we started singing happy b-day.  at that same time the staff, mid-song, came out with the rest of the desserts and started to ask people, as they were singing happy b-day, which dessert was they ordered.  first off they interrupted us and secondly they should know which person gets which dish.

one thing for the restaurant is the absolute gorgeous interior and great cocktail selection.  i've been here before just for drinks and hanging out and for that it does a very good job.

for the food, i'm still not convinced that it's better than other south indian restaurants of the bay area.  from a service standpoint, a lot of work is needed to make group dining a cohesive experience.
author: Swarup B.

description: It was just o.k.. I read about Dosa on SFGate. It was listed in the Top 100. I am a chef and maybe a little more critical, but I hope this is not a top 100 restaurant in one of the richest food areas in the world. The Dosa were nice and Kale Slaw was interesting, but certainly nothing fabulous. For what you are getting the price is about 20% too high as well. With all of that said, we had an excellent waiter and the restaurant had great ambiance.
author: dan s.

description: Excellent. Never really had Indian food before. I expect that I'll be spoiled now and  nothing will live up to this. Great flavors in the dosa and potatoes. Dessert was incredible as well. Excellent atmosphere and good service as well.
author: Jon E.

description: I always love Dosa, but this was my first visit to the Fillmore spot. I love what they did to the former Goodwill locale. We had great service and a great meal. It completely exceeeded my expectations, and I will be back.
author: Sean Q.

description: Beautiful space and some really tasty (albeit very spicey) Indian food. Service was excellent. The $35 tasting menu is overall good value. The standout dish for me was the Pistachio Dacquoise with Chocolate Chile Mouse. Very rich but really rewarding.
author: David W.

description:
This was our second trip to Dosa. We enjoyed it so much we wanted to take our twentysomething daughters.  The food is delicious for meat-eaters and vegetarians alike. It's a great place to order many dishes and share.  The service has been excellent during both our trips.  However, on this second trip there was one major hiccup. We ordered a bottle of wine and after my husband barely sipped it he realized that it was way beyond its prime - vinegarish.  We told our waiter, who stated that he would get the manager.  Now here is what we had a problem with- the manager acknowledged that the wine had "lost its fruit" but insinuated that it was our lack of sophistication that was the problem (we had ordered a wine beyond our ability to appreciate)  and he would recommend a more fruit forward wine.  
We are not trained sommeliers but we do know good wine and BAD wine.  Poor handling of situation that could have exemplified great service.
author: Julia R.

description: Beautiful ~ food, drinks, building and people...  balancing.
author: Amy T.

description:
the venue is beautiful.  MAKE RESERVATIONS.  party of 6 was seated promptly at 645 (when our reservation was).  couples and groups were commenting that they were quoted 1-1.5 hour waits for tables.  

to break it down we had cochin calamari and onion pakora for starters, paper masala dosa, carmelized onion uttapam, a fish curry, duck curry, and some other spicy curry that i've already forgotten what it was, but was incredible nonetheless.  I'm pretty much convinced that anything here would have been great, as each description just makes you hungrier and hungrier.

the wait staff was incredible, and most restaurants should model after the friendliness and promptness of this staff.  the food is like small explosions of flavor in your mouth.  there wasn't anything we didn't like, and i'm not sure that i've ever had south indian food before.  

i will be coming back, and i will be taking more people here (with reservations of course).  i remember when this used to be a goodwill, i can honestly say, you would never know . . .
author: Jason J.

description: Great experience, GORGEOUS decor, yummy food!  The sprouted lentil salad and the lamb are amazing!!!
author: Rebecca W.

description: Love Indian, a few times of month for the last 30 years..  I have been wanting to go to Dosa for awhile...   tried 5 dishes between two people and not one was very interesting.   We tried a few of their trade mark dishes recommended by the server and few other ones.   Flavors were too watered down.   If you like strong Indian curry's would not recommend....   Reasonably priced for the setting only if the food had more of a punch to it.
author: phil b.

description:
Simply beautiful decor and super friendly bartenders that mix amazing drinks!!! (loved the Ginger Ante) 
We ordered an array of appetizers and main dishes, small plates and shared everything...and all were just outstanding!!
author: Cheryl C.

description:
what happened to this place?  the food is still good, but the portions have gotten smaller.  the dahi vada used to come w/ 2 vadas and now it comes w/ one, and the prawns in the prawn dish used to be bigger.  also, we got the mango and goat cheese salad, but it was a big bowl of lettuce w/ tiny pcs of mango and goat cheese.  in fact, i didn't see any of the mango or goat cheese at all.

the biggest kicker though is that you have to order the rice separately from the curry, which is an additional $3+, yet the price of the entree has stayed the same.  it would be better if they just included the $3 into the price of the dish and included the rice rather than calling it out blatantly.
author: Helen T.

description: DOSA is very delicious!!! There is a lot to choose from but everything i have had so far seems top notch. The wait staff has been very friendly to me and helped me out a lot during my visits. The selection of beers is rather large and tasty but their cocktails really don't suit my taste. They are a bit too exotic. This is a great place for early dinner because the atmosphere is eloquent, but my only complaint is that the place really packs you in tight. Sometimes it's as if you are sitting at the same table as the people next to you. To me the food is worth the sardine feeling... other's may disagree. It's best to get there earlier than later.
author: Hitomi M.

description:
Having to pay a 20% gratuity for a large group, a 4% fee for employees health insurance, and waiting over 60 minutes for our reserved table did not make for a happy camper! 

Food was fine. But, selecting a 3 out of 10 spiciness was still a little hot!
author: Beau H.

description:
Great Food-the dosa with potato filling is yummy 
everything else was great too
big portions
friendly staff 
nice atmosphere
will go again 4 sure
author: Alaine L.

description: The food? A-mazing. The service? Lacking on Friday night 9/30/11-- hotel/corporate-type service: bussers bringing dishes to table not knowing who'd ordered what. Dishes piled onto table without taking empty glasses and plates away to make a minimum of room. Also! Had to flag our friendly waiter to take our wine order after a good 10+ minutes. I mean, that's the first thing you get your table to order and get onto the table, right? It was a packed night, but still. The food is amazing though.
author: lance l.

description: Rude, pedantic, unaccomodating service, especially at the host / hostess level. Food not worth putting up with it. Avoid, go to allspice in San Mateo for your indian fix.
author: Pranav V.

description:
fantastic.  i like this location better than the one on valencia.  the decor is great and it is nice and open.  AND they have a kick ass bar.  tried many of there cocktails.  all of them were good.  the best was the juhu palm.  it had coconut milk, gin, spanked kaffir lime leaf, lime juice and chili.  the service was excellent.  prompt and attentive and friendly.  now onto the food:

crab cake:  was one of the best crab cakes i have had.  it didnt taste fishy at all.  texture was nice.  it was served on two different sauces (a cilantro and a tamarind, i believe) along with a dollop of habenero for some heat.

spinach and fennel mini dosa:  very nice.  the fennel was fennel root actually and was not overly fennel-y which is something i was concerned with when ordering.  spinach kind of a supporting role in this dish.  was spicy, but not nearly as spicy as the spicy mung dosa!

jumbo prawns masala:  the highlight of the meal.  sauce was very delectable and refined and the shrimp were perfectly cooked.  i would definitely order this again.

rasmalai:   i was surprised by this one.  a really soft cheese in a sweet cream sauce.  it was flavored with cardamom and other spices.  really tasty.  not as heavy as you would think and finishes off the meal nicely.

prices are expensive here, but i feel is totally worth it.  probably my fav indian restaurant and i cant wait to come back.
author: Christian C.

description:
Went here on a Thursday night for drinks and dinner - made a reservation and was so glad we did! There were quite a few people waiting! We had a drink at the bar as we arrived a little early and the cocktails were delicous! Perfectly refreshing!
We were seated and enjoyed our pleasant servers greeting and recommendations on the menu - we went for a lamb dish along with a vegetarian dish as she recommended. Everything was so yummy - we will definitely come back! 
This was definitely a great restaurant - I would give it a 5 star rating but my one complaint is that my boyfriend and I had a table that basically you have to slide real close to another table to get in and out - this was the case throughout the restaurant - as I understand they obviously want to feed as many people as possible!
We will definitely return for some more drinks and dinner - great spot - if you love indian food I would defintely recommend trying it out - and making a reservation when you do!
author: Jennifer T.

description:
Went there for dinner with my parents who are visiting from the east coast. Did an early dinner because of baby Noah. My parents loved it when they were here last time (in the Mission), so I insisted they see the new spot.

Service was excellent - very patient and accommodating with us having a baby at the table.

Food was outstanding, I've always liked the food, but tonight I ate something that is now my new favorite menu item: Kerala Fish Moilee. This dish has a perfect combination of heat, sweetness and creamy texture. For dessert I tried the Rasmalai and this was unbelievably good.

Anjan came by to say hello and let us know that there is a changing station for the baby in the bathroom. Little gestures like these make a world of difference. 

My parents LOVED their food and commented numerous times on the beautiful decor.
author: Lori G.

description:
What a disappointment! Could not get our food right. They missed  every request including mild instead of spicy, One of us dropped a fork and it took three  times before someone finally remembered to bring us one.
Tecno music way too loud.
To top it off they charged 20% tip included ( for party of 5 and over) .....for a terrible service.  I still believe we should be  deciding the % of the tip based on the service we receive, I guess I am part of the "old school".
The food was also very mediocre much better Indian restaurants in SF.
So thankful to live in SF where  we  have so many choices much much....much better that DOSA on Fillmore.
author: lucia f.

description:
We couldn't get a last minute table dinnertime at the first place we tried, so having passed by Dosa earlier in the day on Saturday, Gf convinced me to try it. I was *not* sorry!!! They couldn't seat us at a table due to our lack of reservations, so we ate at the bar. A bit cramped, but the food was oh so good--well worth a bit of inconvenience. We started with a stout from North Coast Brewing Co. & a mint lemonade, & ordered three small plates plus an entree. The small plates were incredible--Fish Pakora (crisp, fried, sustainable fish with two delicious, not overly spicy sauces); Grilled Calamari (in a light cilantro-chile-cumin-chile-onion-lime sauce); and the vegetarian "sliders" (Vada Pav)--spicy potato patties served with ghee (clarified butter) & "gunpowder." Effin ay--beware of this "gunpowder"--you mix it in with the ghee, to taste. I mixed in too much, we spooned some ghee-gunpowder sauce onto our sliders, and our mouths were on fire. Ouch! (Nothing that a mango lassi can't cure.) Finally, we had our entree--the Masala Dosa. Almost anticlimactic, but still quite good. A dosa, in case you're wondering, is in this case a big, crisp, pliable rice & lentil "crepe," served with fresh green coconut & tomato chutneys & sambar, a lentil "dipping soup." Tasty as all hell. 

 Dinner menu at http://dosasf.com/fillmore_menus.htm
author: J R.

description: I ate here last night with some good friends. The food was great, but I think I prefer northern Indian food. This was the first time I had ever had a Dosa, and it was definitely good, but I really love curry, and I really love saag paneer. It was nice for a change, but I'll stick to my usual Indian cuisine. Amber India is still the best in the city.
author: Alfredo A.

description: Not outstanding but good. I'd go elsewhere for a great meal at a lower price. Dosa paneer wad adequate but unremarkable. Too mic cheese and too little anything else.
author: Tim H.

description:
I'm extremely hard on places like this.  Many visionaries try the concept and many fail.  The concept of taking street foods and common dishes moving them to America into the palacial fine dining palace of millions of dollars of renovations, foofy named cocktails, fusion music blaring over carefully arranged decor.  
So when my boss asked me to make a reservation for 'Dosa' on Fillmore, I asked if had heard him right.  
Upon entering I almost rolled my eyes at what was seeing.  Ohh I could not wait to try the fare out at this jaunt.  
Regardless my boss and our guest are from S.India, was unlikely we were going for 'four course meals' and 'wine pairings'.  They do not drink and did not need menu's.
The namesake itself, 'Dosa's' are nice.  I had the 'Five Moons' which were five diff Uthapam's dished up with sambar, coconut and tomato chutney.  Discussion of idli's with our server was almost too endearing to educate him a bit..   The sambar oddly was very salty that eve and surely an 'oops' as that is not common.
In this lavishly decorated, almost packed and nice ambiance space on Fillmore.. my airline size Diet Coke that was served to me aside a glass of ice made me giggle a bit.   
Overall it is a very nice place to unwind by yourself or with friends, that special someone.  Depending on who you are, only you would know if to bring your visiting parents.  They either are going to fall over converting the prices or go back home bragging their kid is soooo rich he/she spent blah blah dollars on DOSA!!!  
We will be back to try out everything else on the menu:)
author: Tee S.

description:
SO Good!

Really great Indian food, but the highlights are definitely the dosas.  I had paneer and pea, my brother had roasted fennel and my bf went with the traditional potato and pea.  All three were really great.  For the uninitiated, think Indian crepe.  I especially loved the paneer and pea AND the roasted fennel.  Also all three come with dipping sauces and chutneys.  One curry based, one tomato chutney and one coconut chutney - all three excellent!

The night we were there they had a five course tasting menu available and everything was delicious.

Next time I'm in San Francisco, I'm going back!
author: Heather G.

description:
Dosa was awesome!

I went last night with some peeps after a grueling day at the office.

 We arrived at 6pm-ish, and asked to sit at the tables in the bar area which is in a lot of ways, nicer than the main dining area. Dark, romantic lighting, a towering chandelier, leather chairs - it totally sets the mood. Premium cocktails for $5 - I recommend the "Mood Indigo" which is a citrus-y type drink. The drinks are very strong - I threw that baby back and relaxed immediately. Silly giggling ensued.

Chennai Chicken is excellent - think Tandoori Chicken without the bone and a side of yogurt sauce. Even the slaw salad that accompanied it was good - there's a bevy of Indian spices mixed in - dare I say cumin and curry powder? Whatever it was, I will be ordering that again.

Mung Salad - it's mung beans (or lentils) sitting on top of a mixed baby greens salad. It was good, but unsatisfying. Not good for guys. :)

Cochin Calamari - delicious if you like spicy, curry / cumin spiced braised calamari. Soft and tender, moist and not at all chewy. Delicious, but if you have to choose between calamari and chicken, get the chicken.

Now on to dinner - 

We got the Channa Bhatura and the Masala Dosa. We would have ordered more, but we got carried away with the cocktails. The Channa Bhatura was GOOD. It's a soft flatbread served with a side of chickpeas in a tomato-y, curry-like sauce. Excellent!

The Masala Dosa was a dosa (ultra-thin pancake) filled with a potato/lentil filling with a side of 3 sauces. Very good as well.

Dosa's strength is their ability to get the flavor of the sauces and curry spot on. Just the right amount of spice, saltiness and sweetness rounding out each tastebud, hitting all the right notes. Dipping dosas quickly becomes addicting.
author: D N.

description: somethings will just never be the same without her.  i came up on a work trip...and i only knew the city from her eyes, she always had the most endearing taste.  i wanted to relive every moment and try to forget the amazing times i had but it was too hard...so i went to what i knew and i ended up here.  i sat in the corner of the bar by myself, order the same things i had from before...i even recognized the bartender from the other Dosa restaurant as move to
author: Saga D.

description:
Love the food, love the atmosphere, love the location...loved it all! 

I went here with my mom and aunt and all three of us ordered something and shared family style. It was the way to go so that way we could try all of the dishes. We had dosas, uttapam, and a shrimp curry dish. The dosa was my fav for sure! 
I thoroughly enjoyed ripping off pieces and dipping them in the three different chutneys. 
All and all a great experience! 

For sure going back! The lighting was amazing!
author: Janae L.

description:
Fantastic. Seriously. This is my new favorite restaurant in San Francisco. Dosa, how I love thee, let me count the ways:

1. Open til midnight

2. Ambiance is dim and cozy with gorgeous chandeliers

3. Soothing music at perfect volume, no need to shout to hear people talk

4. Unusual and delicious drinks - with ingredients such as yogurt and spices such as cardomon

5. Focus on organic, bio-dynamic and sustainable ingredients and products. 

6. Food is beyond delicious:

    - Mungsprouts Salad - "a scrumptious mixture of frreshly sprouted lentils, tomatoes, cucumbers, ginger, grated coconut, chiles & mustard seeds", 

    - Peppercorn chicken - organic chicken, crushed peppercorns, ginger, spices, 

   -  Uttapams and Dosas to die for - so many different fillings and spices. 

Prices are high yet the portions are appropriately generous

7. Servers are attentive yet not overbearing. No pressure/rush to move through meal

An interesting mix of 30-something types, some hanging out and eating and/or just drinking. The table to our left was a group of French women who kept skipping out to smoke their "American Spirits" while intermittently talking about people in the restaurant. On our right, the intensity of 2 men in the midst of a breakup added a touch of drama. 

All in all, I am enamored with Dosa.
author: Maren P.

description:
More like 3.5 stars. Not bad!! Tall ceilings, nice atmosphere, friendly waitstaff.

I got the 4-course meal. Started off with the red beet cumin soup, which was creamy & delicious. Was a bit spicy, but it went well with the creme fraiche. Then got the chutney masala dosa & loved the different dips and sauces. This particular dosa, I believe, was larger than some of the other ones. had some potatoes and eggplant it in. Yum. It was surprisingly spicier than I expected for something served to the general public without fair warning. For me, it was the perfect level of spiciness, but I could see it being intolerable for some people. Then, I got the Tamil lamb curry. The lamb meat was super tasty and soft, yet chewy. Not tough at all. Just perfect. And I got the little indian doughnut in syrup, which was much better than I'm used to at the little greasy indian buffets. Topped it off with their chai tea, which was milkier than I expected, but I love milk, so, I loved it! 

I don't know how authentic the food here is; it's obviously a lot fancier and schmancier (not to mention pricier) than the average indian buffet grub that i'm used to. however, change is good sometimes. in fact, it's so fancy that i saw people taking pictures of the ceiling and wall decorations! of course, they looked asian and touristy, but still.
author: Verna L.

description: Dosa has a great atmosphere and is conveniently right by Kabuki, but with the terribly long wait, it need not be your go to destination.  While the vegetable curry was good, everything else was mediocre.  I'd pass and go elsewhere.
author: Alice Y.

description:
Beautiful ambiance and a great place for groups to meet up.

However, the food is only ok - had the fish pakoras and the paper masala dosa.  The bread part of the dosa was too salty and the masala itself hardly had any cashews though that was how it was described.  

That being said the dark chocolate cake was delish.
author: Cathy L.

description:
Absolutely fabulous!!! I am so thrilled to have an amazing Indian restaurant walking distance from my house. I believe that it will do a lot to clean up the area even more. With the Kabuki Theaters right across the street, which has a more upscale demographic now do to the independent films and higher costs, it makes for an incredible date.

I have been wanting to go to Dosa in the Mission forever but it is out of the way and once I saw it on fillmore I went the first week and it was so amazing. They even take reservation for 2 people, the other location took 5 and up and I did not want to have to wait for an hour for dinner no matter how good the place is.

The décor is incredible but the service does have room for improvement. But they just opened so they are entitled to a little bit a slack. (I was a hospitality major so I have a little compassion)
author: Kimberly H.

description:
Great Ambience. Good Food. A little bit pricey. We loved it.
Ps: madras coffee is not bad :)
author: Satish D.

description:
Dosa with the Mosa!

Mmmm, I've been dying to go here since hearing of the newly opened, green, chic sister restaurant. And last night my wish came true. The three of us opted for the tasting menu and paired wine. I'd highly suggest doing this, especially if you are going for the first time. 

Spice, saucy, rich. Hello, heaven! Dosa is like a crepe (if you didn't know) and my eyes were bulging with jealously as other tables were receiving theirs -- until mine came. My very own. I'd definitely go for the lentil soup for mixin' and pairin' as its flavors give the rest of the ingredients a better level of richness.

Also, stick with the less-sweet wine pairings as my friend didn't seem to find them as complimentary as mine (he was jealous as I gulped mine down). 

Why am I not giving five stars? I'm a big fan of paying attention to people when they say they are allergic to such food items as shellfish. They came out with shellfish and because of the heavy sauce, it was nearly engulfed. EEEk. Not OK. But what was OK, is that our waitress felt so bad she gave us Port pairings with our dessert. 

Delish, Dosa, delish.
author: Sara W.

description:
Great place!
The atmosphere here is really expansive and hip.  However, the seating is not so expansive, and we really had quite a small amount of personal space at our small table for two.  
Cocktails were amazing - we had the Peony and Anjuna Beach.
Server was very friendly, but didn't introduce his name.  Service was very efficient - maybe too much so.  We had the three-course seasonal tasting menu.  By the third course, we were getting really full, but they just kept on coming,  Could have used a little break to settle my stomach.
First course:
Her - Chennai Chicken.  Tasty, but mostly just a spiced fried chicken
Me - Grilled Calamari - delicious and cooked very well
Second course:
Her - Paneer and Pea Dosa - classic and apparently very authentic!
Me - Truffle and Masala Dosa - gotta love that truffle!
The Pea dipping soup that comes with the dosas is fantastic!
Third Course:
Her - Prawn Masala 
Me - Duck Spinach Masala and Paneer
As I said, we were really full by this point, but these were both very tasty.  However, for as much sauce/broth as is included, there was very little rice.  The meat/seafood was cooked perfectly!
author: Tim G.

description:
This is one slick looking restaurant. The space is quite large and the lighting is beautiful with large chandeliers and large booths throughout the restaurant. I had a meal here with some friends on a Friday night. Between the Kabuki theater and Dosa, the area was very crowded. 

The food was wonderful. The menu itself is a but overwhelming because there are several choices and many categories. Because I was with three other people we were able to order tons of food, which was great because I had the opportunity to taste everything. The favorite of the table was the dosa - duh. I am of the opinion that if a particular dish is in the name of the restaurant the you MUST order it. The dosa was large and filled with delicious curried potatoes. The dosa and all of our apps came with several dipping sauces. I also loved the spicy prawns, they were so red that they really did look angry - but boy were they tasty. My friend who does not like shrimp even tried one and she loved it too. 

The curries are delicately flavored and many packed a punch at the end. The rice here is flavored and I much preferred the coconut rice to the lemon rice, but both were good. The samosas were good, but nothing too special (particularly considering the price). Good service and the food came out quickly, which was great since we were so hungry.
author: Dana H.

description: Finally experienced the much-anticipated culinary delights of Dosa on Fillmore and came away very impressed.  Conquered my first dosa on my first visit--might think twice before eating an entire roll again in one sitting.  The lamb was incredible--very tender and full of flavor.  Like most SF restaurants, it can become hard to hear your partner-in-culinary-crime once the restaurant gets full.
author: Scott A.

description:
A totally unexpected place in the neighborhood. A converted old Goodwill store - this place has gone through a whole transformation.

I had to reserve a table a week in advance to make sure that my friends and I could get a table here for dinner. The ambiance and decor of the place very modern lounge. One thing that seemed out of place was the music selection that switched from techno beat indian music to pop top 40. wah happen?!

A fan of spicy food, I found apps and entrees pretty good. Nothing really stood out to my taste buds except for their cocktails. I recommend checking out the Bengali Gimlet - it has a nice curry kick to it a unique flavor to a classic drink.
author: Gabe H.

description:
This is a restaurant you just have to try period! I went and got the paper masala which was fun and delicious! Although it was enormous and there is no way i will ever finish one this is a new favorite of mine and i will be returning. My friends highly suggest the chutney masala so that will be my next test! 
My recommendation: order a beer with your dosa, it has spice and beer was a great compliment to it and order the Bhatura before your meal.. so tasty and fun to eat.
author: Barbara C.

description:
7x7 list - http://www.7x7.com/content/eat-drink/big-eat-sf-100-things-try-you-die

#64 - Paper masala dosa......I love dosa and the potato stuffing with it! 

This location is beautiful and the space is so much nicer than their 1st restaurant in the Mission. On this visit, I also got to try:

* Organic Greens, Goat Cheese, Mango Salad - Mixed Greens with Radish, Goat Cheese, Toasted Walnuts, Sweet Cilantro Dressing....it was alright

* Samosas North and South - Savory Pastries filled with Caramelized Onions and Vegetables (South), Spiced Potatoes (North)....both good

Finishing it off with a mango lassi ends the meal perfectly.
author: Katie K.

description:
This restaurant is not great.  Completely overrated!!!
The service was horrible.  The guy that served us was a lot more worried about rushing to the next table that helping at all.  
Once the food arrived it all tasted the same!  The coconut rice was not possible to eat.
I wish you could have the same quality and care that you do at your original restaurant.  Please train your waiters!
author: Santi S.

description:
I think this is the best Dosa as far as space and decor go. 

I went to this location 2 times within the past 2 weeks and both times were excellent. 

The Kerala Fish Moilee is TO DIE FOR - seriously, some of the best fish curry I have had. 

I also love the Tomato and Onion Uttapam and Crab Vadas. 

Best cocktail: Bengali Gimlet

I do not like being charged $0.50 for extra coconut chutney, so I dock one star. And the Ras Malai - just not the same as homemade! 

A solid meal, great atmosphere, excellent, well informed staff.
author: Katherine B.

description:
I thought the ambience at this place was great, with very unique food and presentation. 

- I tried the Dahi Vada, which I thought was just okay
- The Veggie Uttapam (I got the sampler plate with 5 different flavors) was fantastic
- The paper masala dosa was also really interesting looking and not bad in taste as well!

One more thing checked off my list of 100 Thing to Eat in SF before you Die (as a SF native I can firmly endorse this as a fantastic list!) 
http://www.7x7.com/content/eat-drink/big-eat-sf-100-things-try-you-die
author: Amy M.

description:
Went for lunch with 2 girlfriends and introduce them to Indian food.
Our waiter, Leonard was great!  its a five star service.  Everything we ordered was so good.  My friends wants to go back again soon.
It was a very good experience for all of us.
author: M s.

description: We went to DOSA last Saturday before the Jackie Greene show at the Fillmore. What a great experience! We sat at the bar before our reservation and had drinks and samosas. The samosas were very tasty. We were seated almost immediately after checking in and had great, very attentive service. We each had the tasting menu ($35) and it was quite a bit of food, especially after the samosas. The calamari first course was delicious! The curry entrees (vegetarian and lamb) were perfect. And, of course, the bread! We ended with the "honey and fig" gelato (we ate it in a daze, just coming out of our food coma). It was fantastic!
author: Nicole D.

description:
Just a delightful dining experience, through and through.  The interior is pretty spectacular.  And even though the joint was heaving like a co-ed after a night of keg stands, we were seated promptly and at a great table to boot.

The food was exceptional.  Great selection of dosas.  Incredibly tasty.  Great sauce.  Amazing yogurty rice dish too.

The service was brilliant.  Attentive but not at all intrusive.  And when the bar was backlogged, the management rolled up their sleeves and delivered drinks to those in need.

Also, the toilets have Accelerator hand dryers.  That shit is crazy.  You put your wet hands underneath and the hot air effectively blasts your digits off.  Amazing!  Not really a reason to go out and drop coin on a fancy Indian dinner, but if you're there anyway there's no harm in killing 20 minutes or so just watching the skin on your hands move around from the sheer force of blowing.
author: David K.

description:
Items Ordered

1. Bagara Baingan - Baby Eggplant, Andhra peanut sauce, sesame, and tamarind + coconut rice $15.00 (neutral)
2. South Indian Moons - 5 mini assorted Uttapams $13.50 (yum! gimme more)
3. Raita $4.50 (yum! kinda bank for such a small portion)

Atmosphere 

Chill, relaxed, swanky, posh.  The setting didn't match the type of food they serve.  Dosa is supposed to be fast food, I've only ever had dosa in hole in the wall dives, so this restaurant was a little fancy and pricy in comparison.

Service

1. Called 30 minutes ahead to get a table for 2 (5:30pm on Sun nite), reservation guy said no can do, suggested we walk in for 15-20 minute wait.
2. Walked in at 6:00pm, lots of empty seats, hostess pointed us to the bar due to no tables.  We looked around and the place was more than half empty.  Not happy, but we made the trip all the way out, so whatev.
3. Sat at the bar, the bartender was SUPER NICE and very helpful, looked around the restaurant after 15 minutes, place is now 80% packed.  OK, at least they didn't lie.

All in all, I would come back strictly for the dosa and uttapam only, the sambar and chutneys were extremely delicious.  I would have rated a 4, but subtracted a star because they have Cheese Dosa with Cheddar, Mozarella and onion on the menu...WTF?!
author: Burrito M.

description: saturday eight:thirty dinner reservation...sardined near bar...$four beer and $dollar tip...waiting for arrival of others....upstairs and table set...$forty-five prix fixe for simplicity...large group and turning into a calculation nightmare in end adding to cost....the food?...no complaints and decent...preparation, presentation and portions at par...dosa masala spiced and cooked tasty....refreshing chutney saucing and lentil dip....lemon basmati rice extra tangy and a wake-up to taste...odd, but simple lemon rice the favorite standing out....curry to share and fairly standard in taste...nice soft simmered meat chunks...finding dosa on fillmore good, but feeling nothing special about the meal to justify price....fancy facade with standard indian fare..
author: Hen A.

description: In comparison to Dosa on Valencia, definitely sub-par. First visit... they served entrees literally 30 seconds after serving appetizers... I sent them back and they came back another 30 seconds later... food was fine. Second time... came with a party of a whopping five people, and service was okay overall. Dosa had essentially no salt, however. For appetizer, ordered and elaborated to waiter that I wanted two double vada pav and one single vada pav ($26) but was instead charged for five single vada pav ($30). It wouldn't be a huge deal, but if you're charging me a mandatory 20% service fee because of my large party, your service should probably warrant it. Not worth the wait for the "ambiance" of the more hip location... I'd rather go to Valencia for better execution and better food.
author: Tom H.

description:
I had never really had a Dosa prior to my visit, so I can't say much more than, "it was real yummy."

I can comment on the specialty cocktails as I am an expert on those.

I have a soft spot in my heart for things that are crafted, and boy-howdy were our cocktails crafted. 

While we were sitting at the bar waiting for our table, the three of us ordered up some of the interesting drinks listed on the menu. The bartender took his time, made each drink with great care and even made sure the presentation of straws and garnish were perfect.

We weren't disappointed. All three drinks were very tasty and very interesting. They're not cheap, but it's worth a try!
author: Ed K.

description: Keep in mind that dosas are street food in india.  the menu is somewhat inventive, but realistically it's akin to putting lipstick on a pig, as they say.
author: eshwar k.

description:
i met a friend here for pre-dinner cocktails.  i have not stepped foot in this building since it used to be the old goodwill.  it is a beautiful restaurant with a nice ambiance.  i am utterly in love with the feather chandeliers, and the paintings on the walls are beautiful.

we enjoyed our drinks, and were tantalized by the aromas of the restaurant. i saw a dosa order come out, and it was definitely 2 feet long, if not more!  i will definitely come back for dinner.
author: Sheri N.

description: Dined at this location twice with a large party. Food is wonderful and the staff is fantastic.  Both times the server selected our dishes eliminating a long ordering procees. Huge success. Will definetly be back.
author: Karla D.

description:
I never really loved Indian food until I moved to the Bay Area.  I've been to some really fantastic Indian restaurants - now the list includes Dosa.  The restaurant used to be a Goodwill store before they converted it.  They did a spectacular job - the interior is beautiful. 

We ordered the Chutney Masala Dosa (rice & lentil crepe filled with potato and eggplant) and the South Indian Moons Uttapam (thicker, pancake style similar to the dosa...this dish is a sampler...there were five different uttapams!). 

Personally I liked the uttapam better than the dosa. The dipping sauces for both dishes were the same - tomato & coconut chutney & the soup looking spicy dipping sauce called sambar). 

It was my first time trying Indian crepes and I loved it! I'd definitely go back (especially with a larger group) so that we can order more dishes to try. 

The service was great.
author: Connie W.

description:
Best South Indian food you can possible find anywhere. I think the Uthappums here can compete with the best in India. Try their Chef's selection of Uthappums that comes with 5 mini uthappums on a plate. I also like the Idli and Onion Rava Dosa here. You can book this restaurant on OpenTable and parking is easy in the parking lot across the street. I like this place better than the Dosa on Valencia because its easier to park here and the ambiance is better. The food and the service are equally good.

I actually have also been here for brunch and really liked the unique egg-based Uthappums/Poriyals. I once tried their Chicken Biryani for lunch and thought it was too South Indian in taste (had mint leaves, etc.) and not what I was expecting from Biryani (mostly cooked in North Indian flavors/spices), but it was tasty nevertheless.
author: A C.

description: The food is great and the ambience is too good for an indian restaurant.We went there for our dinner and had Chennai chicken for appetizer,South indian moons,Bhatura,Hyderabadi chiken biriyani,Prawn masala and Tamil lamb.The South indian moons had 5 different uttappams - Masala,Onion,Paneer,Rainbow chard and .It comes with sambar,coconut chutney and tomato chutney.If you are a non-veg then u should definetly try the chicken biriyani,it is one of the best ones i have ever had.Prawn masala and the lamp curry was also so aromatic and flavourful.
author: Teenu R.

description: There's a very interesting ambiance to Dosa. However, it is difficult to hear in such an environment as Dosa's.
author: Samantha S.

description: I had lunch yesterday for the first time with my friend. My friend from London is very familiar with Indian food, as there are so many Indian people and restaurants over there. She said some food (sauce and others) are a little different from the ones in London, but still the food at this place is pretty good. I ordered mini dosa & salad on the lunch menu. You can pick one soup from 2 kinds or one salad from 2 kinds, and one dosa from several items. I picked mung salad and masala dosa. Not heavy and very healthy. I loved dosa, which is crispy outside and soft inside with right amount of salt. The filling (potatoes masala) was delicious, too. The service is great and the interior of the restaurant is beautiful.
author: Foomin U.

description:
I should have known something horrid would happen when I had to call 6 times to get a reservation for my group. 

By the time we got seated, I was so stressed I don't even recall WHAT I ate, let along what I ordered. My guests tell me that theordered/ received correctly ratio was 0. It all tasted ok, but.... 

I'm sure it's all fine for parties of 2, but NEVER book for an event.
author: Vikki J.

description:
"A" for the ambiance...especially in comparison to most Indian restaurants I've experienced in America.

Food?  Drinks?  Disappointed. :(  

Since I'm not a huge gin fan, asked if they could please sub vodka for the gin in one of their signature cocktails.  "No, we don't do that."  Hmm....well, something tells me I would have liked the cocktail better with vodka instead of gin...and that I would have been a happier customer...but, okay. 

Basically,  just "there."  Not worth returning.  Too many restaurants in this city with equally pleasing ambiance AND ultra-impressive food.
author: Elle S.

description:
I had very high hopes for Dosa.  Gorgeous restaurant, beautifully decorated.  They have the most interesting cocktails- I watched the bartender making them, it's truly an art.  A lot of their signature cocktails have gin in them, which I don't like, so I had one with vodka.  It was such an interesting flavor- like none other I've tasted.  I had a sip of my friend's gin drink (can't remember the name, but it was pink) and it was just lovely (and I don't even LIKE gin!).  

We started with a chile rubbed shrimp, which was really tasty.  We had to try a dosa, so we ordered the one with garlic.  Ok, I adore garlic, but I didn't see that this one is very, very spicy!  Way too spicy for my taste, so I only had 2 bites.  My bad.  Even with the yoghurt sauce... still to spicy.  We also ordered the chicken with rice, which was good.  Nothing to write home about, but still very good.  We finished with the mini donut pastry, which were sweet and a nice way to end a flavorful dinner.  

The service was excellent, they even put up with my high maintenance sister trying out several of the wines before choosing one (ughhhhh).
author: Sarah F.

description: Food is pretty good but the price is a bit expensive.  I've had pretty good dosa at other places for cheaper.  the ambience is very nice so not sure if that's what one is paying for.
author: Pma E.

description:
We were given a really bad time by a stuck up receptionist the first time we were there so we walked out. This time I went on my own just in case that was a one-off instance. Did get a helpful e mail from the owner regarding the incident. This time round everything was perfect. The receptionist (clearly someone else) the waitress ( perfect) and the Indian food on par with the best of London. Sometimes instead of "I will
 never go there again" it pays to pay a second visit.
author: andrew f.

description: I love Dosa. The service is always excellent: prompt but not overbearing. The food is awesome. The uttapam, Chennai Chicken, Chicken Korma are wonderful. The Paneer and Peas Dosa is one of my favorite foods on Earth. It's expensive, but a great place for a date night with a great guy.
author: Elizabeth B.

description:
Went to Dosa with a few folks and with a reservation, we were seated fairly quickly, despite it being a busy night.
Environment was great, although we were seated on the second level which isn't nearly as sexy looking as the ground level.  But when you walk in, initially, you immediately appreciate what's happening, from a design perspective.  It's well-lit, but moody and it's very warm feeling.
Waitstaff was nice.  Polite, chatty and although I didn't get the impression that they were all that knowledgeable (we asked, specifically, about cocktails), they seemed to do their best.
We shared lots of plates - Dosa, Poori, Naan and I'm embarrassed to say that I don't remember exactly what I ordered for appetizers - it's been about a month since I was there. Food was good - we had an eggplant dosa that definitely was light on the eggplant and left you feeling a little confused about what you just paid for.  
I've eaten my share of Indian food, spent weeks in India and I wouldn't say that this is truly authentic Indian food.  It's sort of Indian fashion-food.  It's tasty and it's gourmet, but it's by no means what  you have when you're in-country or even at a small neighborhood Indian spot.  The drinks were delicious and although a bit crowded, I enjoyed myself.
author: Natalie B.

description:
The ambiance and decor was beautiful. 

I thought the food was okay- there is too much use of potatoes and not enough other ingredients.  My friend and I each ordered something different to share and both dishes tasted the exactly the same. 

We were with a group for a friends birthday so when the desert (cake we had brought) came out, I accepted a piece. I don't even like cake I was just being polite. They charged us something like $3 per person (or piece of cake cut) that is just ridiculous- I've heard of a cake cutting fee but not per piece. There were 6 or us $18 to cut cake is not okay in my book.

I have friends that still rant and rave and swear by Dosa, but I probably will not be going back anytime soon.
author: Melinda Q.

description: Beautiful space and delicious food. Particularly great for gluten free -- I asked about options and they handed me a pre-printed gluten-free menu! Much appreciated. And better yet, nearly everything was GF already. Wonderful and yummy.
author: Kathryn D.

description:
This place is good but not AMAZING.  Also be aware that Dosa is South Indian food which is different than the Indian food most Americans are accustom to.  The chicken dish on the starter menu had great flavor and the lamb curry was also outstanding.  For the price, the portions were slightly on the smaller size but the great taste of their food was hard to beat.  The $9 "Blue Lake" beans starter consisted of 5 beans - I would pass on this one.  The atmosphere on the other hand was very nice and the drinks were awesome.

Update - After submitting my original review I was contacted by one of the owners who was extremely nice.  They really go the extra mile to make sure you are happy.
author: P T.

description:
lamb chops are perfection -- marinated over night in yogurt 
wait staff make the meal when they care to help get you to your movie!
author: Caroline L.

description: Great ambiance and a non-spicy version of South-Indian food. Love it!
author: B K.

description:
really SF?!? this place is one the to go places in SF.. wtf?! 

this is the indian version pf chang's.. overpriced.. food was nothing special.. and the club music was irritating.. i'd expect this crap in south beach.. but but this place is horrible

the prawns were tiny little shrimps.. 

all the sauces and chutneys were rather flavorless.. 

seafood vada was disgusting.. more filler than crab..

the samosas were overcooked and dry..

the dosas were ok.. but most decent indian places can make one for less than half the price..

the lamb kofta was disappointing.. when the best thing on that dish was the rice (lemon or coconut).. you know you have problems.. the meatballs were dry.. the tomato sauce could have been ragu

avoid this place unless you like expensive mediocre indian meals
author: Stan L.

description:
i dont know jack shit about indian food. 

but i know what i liked. 

i liked.

more importantly, getting to the highlight of this place. holy shit. the bartenders know what the fuck they are doing. 

peony. 

thank me later. 

i think i had four of these last night. SOOOOOOO good. 

like really, im writing this at 7am the next morning and all i want is another four peony. 

its good to see something new in the hood. i grew up in jtown. im happy to see this place here. i just might have to deal with the crowded bar full of white people just to get my peony fix.
author: Euge L.

description: I like the restaurant's decoration, and their poori.  Other dishes were just alright.  I like Amber much better.
author: Elena L.

description:
It's cool to see how they turned what used to be a bank, then a Goodwill store into a restaurant. The atmosphere/ decor is really nice and when you walk in, you wouldn't know that it used to be a run down thrift store.

The service was really good. This is the type of place where you may need some help understanding the menu so you know how/what to order, and the servers are very helpful without making you feel like an idiot. 

The food is fun and everything we ordered was really good.  I would suggest making a reservation if you are going with a lot of people. We (4 of us) came with a res on a busy night, were seated, served, stuffed, and made it out the door on time to see a movie across the street at the Kabuki! 

-minus one star because the tables are really close together. We kept talking to the people at the table next to us because we could hear each others conversations.
author: Katie I.

description: This is the best high-end Indian restaurant that I have been to that serves authentic South Indian food.
author: S D.

description:
Dosa is a swanky place for some really good Indian cuisine. Went here to celebrate my new condo. Will have to come back again to see if it warrants another star or two. Ate upstairs, and Anna, our server, couldn't have been more professional, polite, and helpful. A+ on her part!

Tried the $39 four-course menu, which was tasty. The lamb curry was out of this world as was the coconut sorbet for dessert. Other courses were good, but I don't recall what they were called as I'd had a couple of glasses of tasty white wine and was on cold medication. Oh well.
author: David G.

description:
Exactly what I want out of a SF restaurant in this economy.

   Twelve bucks for lunch!?! Awesome. Love, love, love Dosa. When I arrived I had already decided I was getting the Mini Dosa and Salad combo. What I didn't count on was the fact that I had the hardest time picking what salad to choose from. After a split second decision made at the arrival of our server I chose the sprouted lentil salad and the paneer and pea dosa. Both were amazing. The amount of food was perfect and I liked nibbling on the (forgive the spellling here) pompadums they give you before your meal. The sprouted salad was crisp and refreshing and also had a beautiful presentation. The dosa was surprising light considering the ingredients and the peas inside were fresh. 
  I already have dinner plans for next week so I can take the drink menu for a spin. All of their gin cocktails were calling my name and maybe an anachronistic Curry Bloody Mary may be in order. YUM!
author: chelsea b.

description:
This is one of my favorite places to go. I recommend grabbing a couple of friends and filling the table with great food to sample from. Be prepared to spend $35-50 depending on how much you drink.

Oh, and try their signature gin & tonic!
author: Andrea S.

description:
Do NOT have a large party or get together here!!!

We set up a birthday party here for my wife with 18 people.  Because of our party size, they required a pre-set menu and said the charge would be $45 dollars per person.  This was already a little steep to ask all our friends and family to pay, but we went for it.  The management assured us that there would be plenty of food.

I had 2 main issues with this place.  One of them alone is enought to kill a resturant for me.  Combined, they are the kiss of death for any repeat business from me. 
1) Portions
2) Price

Portions - By now, I'm used to going to restaurants is SF and getting what I would call FuFu portions.  But this was just criminal.  When they brought our the Masala Shrimp, it was in a bowl slightly larger than a typical cereal bowl.  And it had only 8-9 modest sized shrimp.  They only placed two bowls on the entire table, meaning that each bowl was expected to feed 9 people.  If you were ordering this from any other restuarant and they brought this plate out to you, you would think it would be good to feed 2-3 people.  It was that small in portion.  Unfortunately, this was the common theme throughout the entire dinner.  And each and every time, we had to complain to the waiters that there wasn't enough food.  Do you know how irritating and repetitive that can be when all you are trying to do is throw a fun party for you wife?!   I was surprised in that they actually did bring more food.  Unfortunately, when they would bring more out, it was even less than the first bowl they brought! 

Price - Again, we had been given a quote for 18 people at $45 per person.  Now, the food portion of what we got was probably worth $15-20 per person (even factoring in SF pricing).  It would be assumed the rest was for service charges and restaurant profit. But no....at the end of the night they tacked on an extra $200 for service charges and $40 for the SF health charge.  I have NEVER gotten a "per-person" party quoting that did not include these charges already into the pricing.  Did I specifically ask? No.  But again, I have NEVER had anyone even atttempt to do this.  When you are getting a "party quote", it includes these types of charges.  That is the industry norm.  I know...I worked in restaurants for 6 years including a place that would host parties all the time.   This brought the price up to $60 per person.  Remember, I was already worried about the $45.    I personally felt especially shafted because I decided to pick up the nearly $200 in drink charges just so that all our friends wouldn't freak out any more than they already were.  

So if I disliked it so much, why the 2 star? What food they served was actually very good tasting. The Dosas were probably my favorite thing, which is appropriate given their name. The Masala Shrimp that was pretty good.  Also, my wife's cousin, who recommended the place, told me that eating there for a normal (non-party) meal is actually much better.  So for that, I am trying to be fair and give them a second star.
author: James L.

description: I would give Dosa five stars for ambiance alone, but when we're factoring in wait time and the close proximity of tables,  it looses a star. That's not to say that it isn't worth it. I think it may be the fact that it's Southern Indian food, but somehow it just makes me tingle at the very thought. Fresh, delicious food and a beautiful restaurant too!
author: Michelle K.

description:
Amazing Food, Service and Wine List.    I am a fan of Indian food, but Dosa is off the chart in terms of quality and service.  The food was spiced perfectly, nice portions and the prices were very good.    Not the mainstream Indian Fare, a nice change.  

The wine list was outstanding, one of the best in San Francisco, the Big guys need to take note and learn how to put together a wine list.  All boutique brands, excellent quality, and paired perfectly with the food.  No wine PR Brands will be found at Dosas a nice change from the San Francisco Drab Wine Lists.  

I Highly Recommend this Restaurant.
author: Don M.

description: For a starter, I tried the samosa small plate. Although good, it wasn't anything different from what I have had at other Indian restaurants. For the main entree, I had the prawn masala and coconut rice. I also tried the poori. While the coconut rice complemented the masala well, I just didn't find them to be anything special. The poori was quite delish, though. There definitely has to be better Indian food in San Fran at a better price point. Coming here means paying for the ambiance.
author: Stephanie G.

description:
I had been to the original Dosa once before (including the hour plus wait outside) and had adored the experience. During that trip, we waited double our quoted time, but were given papadam on the street by the hostess to tide us over and a free appetizer for our patience. Not to mention, the food was wonderful.

This new Dosa is a block from my house, and since I adore Indian food, this seems like a dream come true. Knowing this was opening week, my boyfriend and I headed down around 6:45 on a Wednesday for dinner. 

Walking into the restaurant, I definitely was wowed by the decor. The place was spacious and lovely. Very trendy, reminding me of New York, but not pretentiously so. I approved. I asked the hostess for a table for two and she told me that there was a wait, around 20-30 minutes, and told me to have a seat. 

I didn't mean to be rude, but I gave a shocked look around the restaurant, which was less than half full. I didn't ask why, on opening week just before 7 they were making people wait when they had a ton of open tables, even though it was clear that every person who walked in after me wondered the same thing. I did have to wait the full 30 minutes for a table, and for this fact alone I almost gave the restaurant 3 stars. I have no idea why they kept so many 2-tops open for 20 minutes and made everyone mill at the bar, other than to sell a couple cocktails and give the strange illusion of being busy when they clearly were not. 

I figure coming here on the weekend will always entail at least an hour wait, but that's how the last Dosa was, so come prepared to stand at the bar and sip a drink.

We ordered two cocktails at the bar, and they were nice. I can't say great, but interesting. Mine was spicy and full of mango, and I didn't really fancy it (the spiciness got old faster than I would have guessed) but that might just be because it was so different from what I usually drink. I also didn't think the drink was very alcoholic, which was a bit of a shame, given the price, but that also happens at restaurants. I would not recommend coming to this place planning on getting buzzed on two martinis. It might not happen. 

When we sat, service was very slow in the beginning. It took at least seven minutes for the waitress to come to us, but she was nice, took our orders, and the dishes were served promptly and were well-spaced. We got Samosas, a Masala Dosa, and the Duck Curry. All of these dishes were drop dead amazing, and it was more than enough food for two hungry people. And while we thought the end price would be expensive, the meal was around $40 all told (not counting our drinks, those would be an extra $20) which to me is more than reasonable for the quality of food we got. 

I will definitely be coming back to Dosa. I would like to say a lot, but honestly, the wait might make this be more like a once-a-month trip instead of a once-a-week. However, all the food is top notch, interesting, and affordable, especially for the atmosphere and quality.
author: Elizabeth T.

description:
really expensive for what it is.  
if you're looking for white tablecloth indian then this is your place.  But you're paying a premium for that.
author: Mitch M.

description:
Dosa is absolutely delicious!  It's South Indian food and it's like no other Indian food I have ever tried, but I loved it!
