Unfortunately, if you have over 8 people (which we did), then you have a fixed price menu to choose from.  I was skeptical about the limited menu for groups, but there were still tons of options, large portions, and everything was delicious!  My favorite dish was the Dosa (hence the restaurant name), which I highly recommend.  Dosa also has a really great ambiance and delicious unique cocktails. 

I would give 5 stars, but even though I loved the tasting menu, I don't think they should force large parties to be subject to it.  Also, we had reservations at 8pm, which we had to make weeks in advance because this place books up so quickly and they didn't seat us until around 8:40pm.  And that's after we had to bug the hostess a couple of times.  They could've at least comped us some appetizers, but they did not.  

I would definitely go back though---maybe large parties are just difficult for this restaurant.
author: Danielle J.

description:
This has got to be the most gorgeous Indian restaurant that I have ever been to in my life!

About the food, I think the flavors were just tooo strong for my palate.  
I had the following:

1. Chennai Chicken: My friend put way too much yogurt sauce for me.  The yogurt sauce is quite strong & would definitely recommend to start off with just a dab to see if your taste buds agree with its flavor.  

2. Chutney Masala Dosa, which was not that bad at all.  I loved all the different textures of the potatoes, cashew nuts & baby eggplants.

3. Tamil Lamb Curry, which was very delicious.  The meat was very soft & tasty.  

Dosa's an awesome date place before hitting up Yoshi's.
author: Sheryl S.

description:
Dosa is certainly one of the most unique Indian restaurants in the Bay Area, for both good and bad.      They are doing some really interesting things here, pushing spices and flavors into realms which Indian food doesn't traditionally go into.   Plus, the fact that they have tasting menus makes it kind of an oddball in that right too. 

Good things.  Fiery fruit was an interesting mix of sweet and spicy for some simple items which was pretty unique and tasty.  The paneer/pea dosa was surprisingly large and really tasty, mixing somewhat mild cheeses with spicy and flavorful sauces and soups.   The chicken dish, was sadly, kind of a let-down, as it didn't stand out from any run of the mill Indian buffet place.  The gulap jamun was pretty great, even though it was twelve thousand degrees.      

The drinks were bad, though.  Every one of them.  After several, I just gave up and went to beer instead.  Every one had some sort of bizarre after taste or just didn't even taste good to begin with.    Also, the tab was kind of pricey and it didn't feel like it was worth it in the end. Still, an interesting and somewhat tasty Indian place.  I'd give them another shot, albeit a cautious one.
author: chris c.

description: The lunch service, even late (1:45) in the afternoon was awful. It was 40 minutes before we got our food. They comped us the lunch, but that didn't make it a pleasant experience. Next time we'll get ramen in J-town.
author: Michael M.

description:
My husband and I finally made it to DOSA and had one of the best Indian meals ever!!!!!  First off-- the place is beautiful inside.  The wait staff was very helpful (recommendations on what and how much to order!).  We had the mango and goat cheese salad and then the grilled calamari and the scallops (from the Street Food starters).  One of the best things was the vegetarian "Sliders".  Delicious.  Then we ordered one DOSA-- the portion was very generous and the one we selected was delicious.
To end the meal we had a coffee and a chai (best ever)
Oh and I forgot-- the cocktails are amazing.  My husband wrote down each of the ingredients so he can figure out how to replicate at home.
We went on a Wednesday-- made the reservation on Open Table and had no wait at all.
We would highly recommend and can't wait to take some of our Indian and vegetarian friends for dinner!!!
author: Jeanne F.

description:
The reservation was made for 9pm but didn't get seated till a little pass 10. It's definitely not a good place for a big party of 12. Despite that, the ambiance is great to hangout with friends. We were here on a Saturday night and the place was crowded and it could get pretty loud. I couldn't quite hear what my friends were saying without moving my ears close to their lips. 

We ordered some chennai chicken and cochin calamari as appetizers. They were pretty good. But the best must be the dosas. I had the Rava Masala ( A wispy dosa made of semolina and wheat, served with spiced Indian potatoes, onions and cashews). It was wonderful. The dosa was crispy. The potatoes just melted in my mouth. I literally drank the sauce. 

I tried a bit of other stuffs like the lamb curry and chicken curry. They were decent. I still would go for the dosas. 

I would come back to try a different type of dosa again and the dessert.
author: Irene C.

description: I ate here a while ago with my boyfriend and we loved it.  The spiced cocktails were to die for, their dosas are out of this world and their galubjamun is divine.  Unfortunately, it is a little pricey and hard to get a private table (hence the four star rating), but I will definitely be going back and recommend you try it out too!
author: Jessica H.

description: I love this place. We been here three times - twice for dinner and once for lunch. Loved their lunch menu and it's much cheaper too with less crowd during lunch hour. I'm giving 4 stars because sometimes the food can be bit spicy and they don't offer mild curry since it's pre-cooked.
author: G N.

description:
Had dinner here in a party of 6 last night. Reservation was made, so we were seated promptly upon arrival. Even though it was a Sunday evening, the dining room was busy (probably due to the Cherry Blossom Festival). Service was great. The Waitress we had was attentive but not too much. Waiters bringing us food were eager to teach us how to eat some of the dishes. Decoration was to our liking as well, very modern.

One good thing about dining in a big group is we got to try a lot of dishes :)
Appetizer: Crab Vadas, Cochin Calamari
Entree: Jumbo Prawns Masala, Chicken "Dumm" Biryani, Kerala Fish Moilee, Masala Dosa, Paneer & Peas Dosa, Masala Uttapam
Dessert: Toasted Coconut & Saffron Barfi, Shrikand & Diced Seasonal Fruits, Sweet Pongal

Food was overall delicious - especially the fish dish. Rice was cooked with a little too much water, so the biryani turned out mushy. I've been to Coimbatore and Chennai so wouldn't call this place authentic. But again, would I go to Osha and expect authentic Thai?

Will definitely consider coming back for the next special occasion.
author: Lois W.

description: For sheer atmosphere (awesome light fixtures!) and cocktails. Next time: food!
author: Maximillian M.

description:
I was told the habanero/mango dosa was "intolerable" in terms of spiciness. So, of course, I ordered it.  I also ordered the tomato soup which was quite tasty. The dosa, when I cut into it, was a bright fiery red (think spicy cheetos) and stuffed with a potato filling.  If you're eating just the crepe part, smeared with red, with no potato, it's definitely pretty potent. My tongue was tingling and my eyes got a little watery after the first couple bites. Also, you can smell the damn spiciness off of the dosa itself.  However, once you get to the part of the dosa w/the potato stuffing, and you put some of the sauces and the chutney on top of the bite you're going to eat, the heat is extremely reduced. really good either way.

Overall, I'd definitely like to come back here and try the other types of dosas they offer. And, I'd recommend the habanero one if you like your stuff spicy.
author: ML N.

description:
This place is just gorgeous inside....great ambiance with beautiful chandeliers!  But still a fun feel...

I had to change my reservation and the restaurant was really accommodating when I called, but they still made us wait 20 min. for our table!

We ordered the Dahi Vada appetizer, which was good but nothing special.  The real treat was with the Dosas!  I had the Paneer and Peas Dosa, which was wonderful.  We also ordered Bagara Baingan with coconut rice.  It had lots of booming flavor and the coconut rice was unlike anything I've ever tasted, it really added something special!

The bread pudding dessert was nothing special, but the Indian ice cream is definitely worth trying.  It was a fun treat and had beautiful presentation.
author: Britt M.

description:
This is the first time I've tried Indian food at a restaurant. (I know, I'm a late one!)
1. The ambiance is amazing
2. The restaurant is always packed = must be good
3. The hostess was really nice, and recommended dishes we should try
4. The food was the BOMB

It's pretty pricey, but you really do get what you pay for
author: Jennifer C.

description: Start with a cocktail, they are delicious.  We always get the Dahi Vada lentil cake covered with yogurt with tamarind and cilantro sauce, and the grilled lamb chops.  Everything we have tried has been really good.  The place fills up fast so make a reservation well in advance.
author: Alan L.

description:
Very cool vibe. (such a great use of the space - would never know it was the Goodwill spot!)  Flavors were not s bold and rich as I expected, but the spice was definitely there! Dosas are great; Chicken Biryana and Lamb Curry were good, but very spicy so other flavors did not come through that strongly (and we ordered it mild, btw, and are not spice wimps), 

Service was not memorable. Hostess service was a bit put upon.  (It's busy, nothing new there).
author: Danielle R.

description: Good atmosphere and signature cocktails.  I heartily recommend the vegetarian sliders and lentil dumpling appetizers--they're as pretty as they are delicious.  Dosas are hearty and big and possibly an acquired taste.  A warning: I don't believe they've tempered their spices to american palettes, so when it says "hot!" it is for real hot.  I've gotten my wife to enjoy spicy fare over the years, and after bragging about her newfound temperament she ordered the roasted chili and garlic dosa.  She took 1 bite and could instantly see through time.  Had to send it back--even I wouldn't have finished it.  Consider it a challenge.
author: Ian S.

description:
Cool décor, great service, awesome food - good mixture of swank and funk.

Ate here with a girlfriend, and the fact I didn't care for my coconut drink wasn't enough for me to regret trying a new and different cocktail. The lamb curry was truly delicious - some of the most tender lamb I'd ever tasted.

The service was fantastic. Despite the overly dim lighting, the motif of the main room was unique and eye-catching and the feather chandeliers made me drool.

Minus one star for the wait and limited bar area, but I would definitely return, whether it was for a date or another girls night out.
author: Fräulein J.

description:
My buddy and I went in for a few drinks and appetizers, not a full-blown dinner.

Space:  It's a beautiful dinning room.  Very well decorated; clean lines, and gorgeous chandeliers and light fixtures.

Food:
Crab Vada- Two crab cakes with the typical Indian cilantro and tamarind sauces on the plate in a yin-yang pattern.  Presentation was very nice.  However, the crabcakes, though had a great consistency and full of flavor, had very lttle crab flavor.  It felt like crab in one's mouth, but the crab taste was lost. Overall, there was nothing memorable with this dish; it simply lacked the "wow" factor that would make anyone carve for it or order it again.

Blackened Sardines- Excellent mix of flavors.  Not blackened in the cajun "burned" sense, but that was for the better.  They were not fishy at all and had great consistency, not over or undercooked.  It came with a cucumber, red onion slaw which was actually quite spicy.  Overall, this dish is highly recomended.

Chennai Chicken-Strips of white meat with that red tandoori coating.  Unlike tandoori, these were fried, not grilled, but no coating or batter but it was not oily.  It was served with a yogurt sauce that had cumin and cucumber.  It was also accompanied with a slaw-type sala consisting of red cabbage, red onion, and carrots, shredded very thinly.  The slaw had a sweet dressing and sprinkled with crushed peanuts.  The dish has to be eaten with all components together; chicken, yogurt sauce, red onion slaw, otherwise, the chicken itself is quite salty.  Overall, this dish is an 8 out of 10.  Tasty.
author: Jon B.

description: Hands down great south indian food. Taste very close to authentic, this is coming from Indian with very flavorful palette. They have variety of twist (pumpkin, paneer, basil, etc) on typical dosa recipe. Vibrant ambiance, loud but fun for a night out. They have a upper level which is quieter. I recommend to make reservations.
author: H P.

description:
Certainly a beautiful space....but:

Dear bartenders: you have a fabulous collection of whisky and bourbon. Now please, for the love of it all, when making a manhattan or similar blended drink, DO NOT SHAKE THE LIVING HELL OUT OF THE CONCOCTION! I ordered a $10 Manhattan with Blanton's Bourbon. I watched as the bartender shook it wildly for 20-30 seconds. As expected, it arrived with the top completely foamed up, a bruised and battered shameful waste of good ingredients. Gently sitr the whisky or bourbon drink. It should be brown and clear, no foam. In addition, the already small martini style glass was about 68% full.  If it's gin, vodka, tequila....shake it. Bourbon and whisky...NEVER.  Fill my glass, and make it right, please.

The Manhattan:

"Add liquor/bitters mix to the shaker and stir dreamily. A Manhattan, that noblest of cocktails, is like a baby-it must NEVER be shaken. If you want a bubble infused drink with a head on it, have a beer."
author: Jeffrey B.

description:
Until I get to visit India and eat my way through the north and south, there will be Dosa, among others.  Such potential for a five!  But our waiter was unusually ambivalent, the Rasam "fire broth" totally forgettable, and the prawn appetizer a complete miss (for my part, never had a great Indian shrimp dish).  

Otherwise! the beet cumin soup was brilliant - bright red, tasty, served hot and a nice surprise; but is this South Indian or just fusion? Yay for a super thick, super mango lassi (we got covetous questions from neighboring tables ;), and big yay for the Masala Dosa, although we ordered the eggplant version. Wow, it was a ghee infused crispy pancake (guilt) with buttery potato and onion fill. Heaven, accompanied by tiny ramekins filled with coconut and tomato chutneys, non spicy.  Overkill was the lamb curry, in a super powerful spice mix, but the chunks were pretty darn soft; LOVED it. 

The Laughing Lassi I thought was gross, but I don't drink, so what do I know?  The BF thought it was great, but chased each sip with my lassi. Can't wait to go back!
author: Conifers J.

description:
Date night at Dosa! I made a reservation on OpenTable for Friday @ 8pm. We walked in at 8, and were seated immediately. I was impressed to say the least as the restaurant was buzzing with patrons. Our waitress was very attentive and knew the menu extensively.

We started off with a glass of champagne and a beer for myself. The Taj Mahal is a great choice for those beer drinkers. We ordered the Crab Vadas as a starter. It was great! The mint sauce was very well done.

After being overwhelmed by the menu, the waitress suggested we get a Dosa and an entree as the portions were perfect for two. I was hesitant as I have read the reviews about the portions, but rolled the dice. We decided on the Spring Dosa and the Peppercorn Chicken entree (with lemon rice). 

The Spring Dosa was great! Perfect for two people. The Dosa had three rolls with dipping sauce and two chutneys. The Peppercorn Chicken was pretty good but I had some issues with cutting good pieces of chicken off. I kept getting bombed with chunks of peppers or herbs that were used to cook the dish. The sauce is very thick and it makes it hard to distinguish. The lemon rice was great! I'm not sure I'll order the Peppercorn Chicken again.

Overall, it was a great place to dine and even on a Friday night, the service was impressive. We got out of there with a couple rounds of drinks, starter, dosa, and entree for less than $70. safe to say I'll be back.
author: Trevor F.

description:
Great Gin and special Dosa Tonic

Delicious and creative meals - enjoy the prixe fixe.

Wonderful place for group dining as the music is beautifully played on low and easy to hear everyone

Decor - lovely to browse

Great Bar

Service!!!!!: Poor and Poor again!!  Wow - for the price of the food and the beauty of this place - you would think they would have the service dialed.  My group of 7 was dismayed.  Occasionally we were flocked by a team delivering food, but more likely we were ignored.  Noone was paying attention to clearing plates, additional needs like drinks, forks and knives - and they flat out forgot about delivering drinks right up until the end with our teas with dessert!  A real disappointment as they have so many other things nailed!
author: Jezy D.

description:
So tonight we tried Dosa for the first time. 

I didn't really know what to expect, to be honest, I didn't even know the cuisine before we went.

We got there at 6:50, on a Friday night, and the host told us it would be about a 45 minute wait.  We had a late lunch so we agreed and took a seat.  At first, I was a little anxious.  I noticed the long bar height community tables - not a fan.  It was also quite loud.  I anticipated being seated at the community table and having to ask for a private table and possibly wait even longer.  

To my pleasant surprise, after only 20 minutes, the host welcomed us to a table and in my opinion, it was one of the best in the house.  It was in the bar section but in the back corner and it was seated for four - perfect for just the two of us.  The chairs were super comfy and we had a great view of an entire half of the restaurant, it was quieter and really just what I was looking for.

Our waiter came by quickly, gave us some recommendations and we ordered.  We ordered a peppercorn chicken curry, lemon rice and a masala dosa.  The lemon rice was sour, and disgusting, so we quickly asked to change it to the coconut which was nutty and delicious - not too sweet.

The Dosa was excellent.  A slightly thick savory crepe with a potato filling and a trio of dipping sauces.  Along with the coconut rice, the meal was pretty good.  

Service was quick and attentive.
The restaurant was clean and well run.
The food was better than most Indian places and was served quickly.  
Our requests were met with a smile - what more can you ask for.

The Check.  With all that food (we also ordered an extra bread), tax and health care premium added, our check only came out to $34.00 - very affordable!

The only reason I didn't give this place 5 stars is that I don't  feel compelled to return often.  I think it would be a great place to take some friends, especially for a drink.  When I really want to have Indian food, and I want the best, only Roti will do.  While the service often stinks at Roti, and the atmosphere is way too loud and cramped, the bottom line is their food is incredible.

I would recommend you to check out Dosa, I'd certainly go back and the Dosas would be at the top of my list for things to order.
author: Aaron B.

description:
First of all the service was fantastic.  All the staff were attentive, quick and curteous.  

Unfortunately all the food wasn't as great as the staff.  We had the following
1.  North and South Samosas
2.  Bartha Bangnin
3.  Masala Dosa
4.  Pander Dosa

The Samosa's and the Bartha Bangnin wee nothing special.  They are pretty much the same as what you would find at any normal Indian takeout place.  

The Dosa's were amazing.  Definitely the highlight of the meal.  If I go back I would only get the Dosa's and a salad.  The entrée's didn't seem all that great.

If the entrée's were better I would give this place 5 stars.
author: Peter C.

description:
This is my 2nd time to Dosa within a 1 week span.  

The first experience deserved a 4 star.  We were promptly seated by the bar (no wait!) as we didn't mind sharing a long table with other eager diners.  I had the lamb curry paired with the uttapam bread (great combo), and  friend ordered the prawns.  Both dishes were warm, inviting and delicious to the last bite.  We loved the atmosphere and the decor of the place.  It was highend and elegant. Great place for a group outing and/or a date, altho' it could get noise.

But the second time around, not so charming.  We were seated upstairs, which I didn't like as much as downstairs.  The waiter was decent at servicing us but pushed a little hard for us to order drinks.  I got the Chutney Dosa dish this time and it was a little disappointing compared to the solid curry dishes I was used to.  

As we came for a friend's birthday, a cake was brought in to celebrate the festivities.  The waiter told us there was a $3 charge per plate for cake cutting.  That's outrageous and unheard of!!!

Dosa, you're doing somethings right but I would keep working at your quality of service and make sure you're never in the caliber of being  "too good" to keep each and everyone of your customers happy and satisfied at all costs.
author: Jackie G.

description:
So happy to have a Dosa closer to my house. Perfect location close to the Kabuki Theater too.

Went on a Sat night had reservations and still waited about 20 minutes, the place is pretty packed and super busy so be prepared to wait a little.

Started out with some sparkling Shiraz from Australia that was amazing.  Had the chilli fry shrimps (kinda small only about 5 shrimp but tasty) and the Masala Chutney Dosa (AMAZING) for appetizers.

For mains we split the Kerala Fish Curry that was the best thing we had all night. It has an awesome pungent peanut sauce with coconut flavored rice on the side. We also had the Paneer Duck which was ok really spicy and tender duck but only about two legs and a boring side salad (will def try another main next time).

The desert was the Coconut Barfi which was kinda like an egg roll filled with coconut and kiwi and raspberry sauce on the side. It said caramel in the description which is why I ordered it couldn't taste any caramel. Would prob try  a different desert next time.

But overall the look and feel, service, drinks, and food quality will def have me coming back. I really enjoyed it much more than the Mission location you have more room and it feels more elegant.
author: Katie M.

description: By far the best Curry I have had in my life, and I'm a big Indian Food Fan.  I had the Coconut Prawn Curry with Cocunut RIce, and WOW, it was amazing.  Full of flavor.  I wasn't sure what to expect with "coconut flavored" rice, but it was actually really good.  As an appetizer we split a paper masala dosa.  It was also good, but definitely not sufficient as en entree.  Good to share to start.  Will return as the food is good, restaurant is nice and atmosphere is upbeat.
author: Jonathan L.

description:
My newest coffee table book is on famous chefs' final meals. It makes you think... "what would mine be?" 

Well, I've revised my menu after visiting Dosa Fillmore. If I were going down, I'd want to have their chickpea curry as part of my bon voyage meal. It doesn't sound like something that would be last meal worthy, right? Wrong, it was more flavorful than many of the meat dishes I've had lately, and it's served along with the most amazing huge puffy bread. This is not to even mention that the atmosphere is one of the best in the City, the scene is buzzing, the rest of their food is delicious as well, or that the wine and cocktail list are creative and top quality. Forget all that... just go, get the chickpea curry, and die happy.
author: Shoshana D.

description:
Went here late on a Saturday, didnt really know what to expect but it looked nice. The space is very nice, good feel overall. 

Our first server was I believe just getting off work, because after asking for our drink order we saw her counting cash near the kitchen, completely ignoring the fact we were ready to order. Finally we got a new server who came over and helped, but she seemed like she didnt want to be there.

Think it may have just been a bad night, will have to try it again.
author: Jeff W.

description:
Came here for dinner tonight and had an absolutely wonderful time. After we got back from rock climbing we decided we wanted to go out to dinner, so automatically I started sifting through my yelp bookmarks to see what fit the bill. We decided on Dosa, and were originally going to try out the location on Valencia, but due to some last minute hookah plans, chose the Fillmore location for convenience. I went to opentable.com at 8PM and made reservations for 9:45 and sat around and waited patiently at home nursing my sore muscles. 

We arrived right on time by sheer luck, and were seated right away despite the place being packed. First impressions were that of excitement, after briefly skimming their menu online and reading some other yelp reviews I could seriously not wait to get my grub on. We ordered the Dahi Vada and a Paneer and Peas Dosa as our appetizers and the Tamil Vegetable Curry and Channa Bhatura as our entrees. I choose to go with the wine pairing with the Curry which was a Malbec and fit complimented my food wonderfully. 

As we waited for our food we laughed a little at the decor, most of which is nice but some seemed a little kitsch-y. Overall the impression was that they hadn't quite decided upon a decor they liked yet. We also spied on those around us' food. When a giant plain dosa came out we were all but ready to steal it before our own food showed up. Our appetizers were delicious, the Dahi Vada tasted exactly like some other food we eat, but neither of up could place the taste. Our entrees then arrived in  a very timely matter ( you definitely wont waste too much time here waiting around for food) and we were excited as ever to dig in.... except that both of us were already pretty full. 

I ordered the Coconut Rice with my curry which complemented the spices in ways I did not know were possible. I managed to eat half of mine before realizing that it was unwise to try to eat anymore. Thinking that if I got up and used the restroom I would have more room to eat, I discovered the really fucking awesome hand dryers in the bathroom. Now I normally the hand dryers, you stand there forever and your hands just never get dry. But this was a jet dryer and your hands were dry withing seconds.... very cool. 

We ended up getting a doggie bag for the rest of your food, which will make a wonderful lunch for tomorrow. In hindsight, I think we should have only ordered one entree between the two of us, because if you want to eat appetizers a whole entree is just out of the question. I am looking forward to bringing friends back here again soon!
author: Allyson S.

description:
If you are looking for a fancy evening out with awesome cocktails and ok indian food, I recommend this place. I would give it 5 stars for the ambiance but the last time I was there 2 things bothered me about the food: 1) they have altered their menu from about 2 years back and removed items that I really enjoyed e.g. tamil lamb curry 2) the taste felt worse than the same items at their Valencia location.

Hence the overall 3 stars. I would give their valencia location 4 stars.
author: Siddhartha S.

description:
This is an exorbitant place with tasty food. Seems to me more like a special day restaurant than a"when I am  craving for S.Indian food, I will go here" kind of restaurant. I am a South Indian, so I guess, my standards are stricter and makes it hard for the very few South Indian restaurants in the valley to match up.

Taste 4.5 stars 
I had utthapams( good), south Indian bhel (yummm) and rasmalai (yumm). But I think the chutneys were so and so.
My friend had the paneer dosa(okay) and rasam (tasty but lacked the kick).

Authenticity 3 stars
I believe this is more californian style, mixing up American and  North Indian with South Indian cooking. Frankly, paneer dosa is a sacrilege in my opinion. I am sorry! Some of the best dosas in Madras, India are found in the street side shops. Pair it with some idly sambhar and you will get the real punch.

Price and quantity 2 stars 
Expensive and portions do not necessarily match.


For authentic-close-to-home South Indian fare, try Dakshin (previously named Annapurna) at San Mateo or Saravana Bhavan in Sunnyvale.
author: Rashmi V.

description: Stopped by here for dinner before a show at the Fillmore. Had the samosas followed by the pumpkin dosa. Food was delicious, atmosphere and decor were great. Staff were attentive - will definitely be going back!
author: Clare M.

description:
Can I just say how excited I am that Dosa has made its way to Fillmore street!  I have been going to the Dosa on Valencia for a while and I loved it from day 1.  I think the same can be said for the new one on Fillmore, although even better.  They have made a great use of the space and have kept the prices reasonable.  Also, this one has much more space and what looks to be a great happy hour bar/space.    

As for the food, I don't really venture out of my comfort zone because I just love the Dosa.  Now that it is in my hood will probably be able to go more often and update with my recommendations.

yay Dosa!
author: Christina W.

description:
My sister lives near this place and did all the odering so i cant say what it was that i ate, only that it was all delicious, and everyone's food around us looked delicious as well.  The scene was energetic and youthful (dare i say 'hip'), but not too loud or night-club-ish.  Staff was very friendly and prompt in refreshing my vodka gimlets.

would love to go back.
author: Seth S.

description:
Are you a veggie kid, and do you want to have an amazing date night? If so, go here and get the signature four course tasting menu with wine pairings, bien sur. This can be done vegan, and you can even get two different sets of four courses, so you and your date can share! Btw, I love that their menu says things like "ask about our vegan options!" It's so adorable. 

Highlights: the coconut & roasted bell pepper soup was creamy and spicy and a bit sweet and paired beautifully with a lightly sweet sparkling wine from Argentina. The Channa was seriously some of the best I've ever had, and I've had lots of channa, since it is often the one thing on the menu sans ghee!  It paired so nicely with the Beaujolais Gamay they served it with. They even had a lovely vegan dessert, which was a rich chocolate sorbet, made by Coco Bella. Good god, I left feeling happy and charmed.

One of the fabulous things about wine pairings is they are great conversation starters. Just look up some of the basics before you go to dinner, and discuss the pros and cons of pairings with your date. It's sure to impress.
author: Jeani H.

description: Dosa on Fillmore feels so much more open than Dosa on Valencia. Also lots of natural light and a beautiful bar. Generally easy to get seated without too long of a wait. They do switch up their menu from time to time but the new items can be a hot or miss. I tend to play it safe and stick to the traditional south Indian dishes like the masala dosa's (spicy mung) and uppams. The drinks are fun; and pricey too!
author: Summit S.

description: This place has a great, swanky atmosphere with high ceilings, two floors of seating, and a happening bar scene (thirty-somethings crowd). Great place for a date or to have a Sex and the City-esque night with your girlfriends. the cocktails are creative, though some of the ones using Indian spices tasted a little funny. The dosas there are good, but though I'm no expert on Indian cuisine, I think this place hits higher notes for its atmosphere than the authenticity of the food. Still good, though. Would definitely come back!
author: Duncan G.

description:
We had an excellent meal at Dosa this past Friday. We ordered the spring and the habanero dosas - both excellent, the lamb curry - yum! and the chicken byriani - which was a little dry, but in all fairness, the server warned us it was going to be and brought us a sauce that came with it to moisten it. 
We also got the crab cake, which was also rather tasty. For dessert, we were not so impressed with the rice pudding, but the coconut sorbet was out of this world. 
I am certainly going to return to this restaurant.
author: Jana C.

description:
This is the nicest Indian restaurant I have ever set foot in. 

I stopped in to have a look and a drink at the bar and I was very pleasantly surprised when I walked in the door and I wasn't overwhelmed with the smell of curry cooking. 

The interior is very nice and there is a nice bar. They also have a second floor dining level. Some of the folks at the bar were dining and their food looked and smelled wonderful.  I cant wait to go back to try the menu.

I loved the ladies loo with it's shiny silver tiled floor and red rose wallpaper.
author: Flower P.

description:
Both Dosa on Fillmore and Dosa on Valencia serve really good food though the atmosphere is different; I find Filmore to be a bit more trendy, two great ceiling cascading fixtures that are really beautiful.  Went there on a Sat. night without reservations and had to wait about 20 minutes.  No problem and we ended up at the communal table which is a great place to see what everyone else is ordering and make friends - hey there Peace Corp and Napa.
First the drinks, they make their own gin and their own tonic and together its a rather tasty gin and tonic.  The peony was also flavorful and rich (which you'd expect since it includes coconut milk.)  I also had a cocktail which was real heavy with ginger; a bit more than I'd want in a drink but I still drank it no problem.
Food we had the bhel puri which had the right amount of heat, lots of different textures, puffed rice, thinly sliced beets, and lots of other stuff.  The cilantro chutney and tamarind chutney worked well with this dish.  The basil dosa is simply wonderful.  Dipping it into the soup, spooning on more chutneys make perfect bites, Actually didn't need the smashed potato that is in it.  Finally had the lamb tamil with lemon rice.  The lamb itself was tender but its flavor and texture was overpowered by the spices it was cooked in.  It felt a bit mushy though it did have a nice spice to it.
A great place to go, share some food and have a pleasant evening.
author: Andrew C.

description: This is an upscale Indian Cuisine restaurant, with a nice ambiance and a good menu to choose from. Many choices if you are vegetarian. I have returned several times because the food is always good, the servers nice and helpful and I haven't had to wait long to get a table.
author: Lindsay K.

description:
I am a frequent guest - each Sunday, Chris and I are eating dosas.... 

This restaurant is very crowded, I often forget to get a reservation, so we eat at the bar - and I actually enjoy it at Dosa.
author: BARBARA G.

description:
The food here is pretty awful. It's not authentic at all, not tasty at all, and on the greasy side.  It's very overpriced for what you get.   I had heard to so much about it and was excited to try this restaurant, but I soon learned that I wouldn't ever go back.  The decor is nice, yes, but that's about it.

The yogurt/rice was not authentically made, the dosa was greasy.  My friend who is not the type to ever complain sent his chili/garlic dosa back, saying it tasted bitter and burned.  I had the sampler uttapam -- the sambar was not edible, the chutneys were bland.

Overall a poor and disappointing experience.

For authentic S. Indian try Vic's in Berkeley.
author: Reenu S.

description: We brought a colleague from India. He liked it and so did we.  A bit spicy for me, but not over the top. The location on Fillmore is much nicer than Valencia - trendy decor, open floor plan with high ceilings, large space, clean, good neighborhood, plenty of parking. It's so nice to know there is a tasty non-divey Indian spot.  I only wish they would open one in the East Bay.
author: Sharon M.

description: Really delicious, reasonable prices, and comparatively much more classy vibe than on valencia.
author: Healey C.

description:
4.5 star.. I wanted to try this place for a while and it live up to the hype!
we ate some veggie dishes, Pav Bhaji + Channa Bhatura, both dishes were pretty authentic and had a fresh taste.

I really want to go back and try more items on the menu, it looks hella good! def worth a visit.
author: Vimal P.

description:
This was my 5-6th visit today. Each time I have felt Dosa @ Filmore is not as good as Dosa@Valencia. I ordered chili-cilantro Uthapam, clearly the one server last week @ Valencia was orders of magnitude better.

Chicken 65 was authentic Hyderabadi-Chicken 65.
author: Gaurav G.

description:
I had never been here before and was interested in seeing what the place looked like as I knew it was housed in the former Goodwill space. Online the place looked nice but that doesn't really mean much. My sister looks good online too. 

When I got there I was blown away by how much time and money they spent fixing up the place. Floor to ceiling windows and a new upstairs  and the decor and the lighting was just right. They didn't over do the Indian thing and the lighting wasn't as dim as a dark bar or as bright as a Denny's.

For those of you not in the know a dosa is an Indian dish, that is flatbread stuffed with things depending on what kind you order and depending on what kind you order it's either shaped like a slice of pizza a calzone, or a rectangle.

You eat it like Ethiopian food and tear the bread and dip it into this Indian gravy and then chutney or another kind of sauce. I found this too time consuming and was really hungry so I just dumped everything on top of mine and tore into it with a knife and fork.

They had the usual apps, samosa, pakoras, papadums etc. I also had this lentil dish covered with yogurt that was really good. I also recommend the chicory coffee. If you go there stick to the dosas and away from the main dished the dosas are a good value at about $10 each. The main dishes you can get a most Indian restaurants and the prices were a little on the high side. My only complaint was that the waitress forgot to bring out plates for the apps and it took a while to get them but other than that it was all good. This would be a good spot for a date and they have a full bar, the beer was a little pricey $6.50 for a Kingfisher, but you're there for the food and not to get drunk.  Definitely make a reservation as I went on a Sunday Night and the place was packed.
author: Steve Q.

description:
Had to come to try the paper masala dosa and will be returning to try everything else! Everything on the menu was really tempting. We got whatever their version of crab cakes was - and that was ok. The paper masala was great and all the dipping sauces were very creative. I personally loved the coconut spread. We shared an entree of prawns in a rich red sauce. Everything was spiced perfectly and the portions were a very good size. 
Back to the paper masala. It was HUGE could easily split between 4 people. It was slightly greasy, very thin and I've never tasted anything like it. I probably won't order that again, next time we'll try the regular dosa. 
The price was really good. We didn't have drinks so of course that helps keep the bill down but for both of us, we left pretty full the total was only around $40. We were expecting much more for the beautiful decor and swanky ambiance. Thx for the suggestion 7x7 - it's been a great find for us!
author: Audrey V.

description: We came here for Julia's Dirty Thirty and I am always weary about Indian food.  One of our friends had worked with the restaurant and we had cute little drink menus just for Julia's Birthday with a Dirty Thirty Martini and Cougar in Training option.  The food was delicious - everything we ate was great.  The drinks were definitely good and fun because of their names.  The restaurant itself was beautiful and would be a great spot for all dinner options - whether it's a date or a group night out.  The only complaint was the server who was very slow and had a little attitude - but I won't fault the whole place for him being a dud.
author: Arica V.

description:
Five stars for ambience... really nice!
Five stars for the creative cocktails!
Four stars for the food... I am not generally a lover of Indian cuisine, but everything was extremely fresh and tasty... but a bit heavier than I am used to- again the Indian cuisine thing... But... when any of my friends wants to eat Indian food, this is where I will suggest we come.
Three stars for the service... our server was professional, but not outstanding. No complaints, but no raves either.
Overall a really nice place that I would absolutely frequent again.
author: susan a.

description: Yeah - Stan L said it best: this place is like an Indian PF Chang's. Definately overpriced and just so-so food. I don't get the rage...but then again -- foodies are ever searching for a new place to adore.
author: Dan E.

description: A dinning experience. Beautiful atmosphere. Amazing Indian dishes with great presentation. Spirits and more! If your looking for some authentic south Indian cuisine come and have a Dosa.
author: Charlene K.

description: The food was good.  I am not qualified to say if it's genuine or not, but the taste was good.  I loved the various condiments and spices used for the entrees.  The ambiance was nice.  The service was not as good as I would have liked.    I would definitely go back.
author: H S.

description:
Wow!  I love Dosa in the Mission with a passion, but this location takes the cake.

It's such a beautiful space!  and I love that they take reservations.  The food is equally as good as the original location, which tends to not be the case when restaurants open new branches.  I can't think of anything bad to say!

I can't wait to go back.  Dosa on Fillmore is by far my new favorite restaurant in the city.
author: Alyssa W.

description:
We were struck by the transformation of this space into a modern and well-lit Indian restaurant.  The prices were moderate and the selection, while not as extensive as the anything-goes places, was tasty and different from your usual fare.  The interior is well appointed, the service was attentive, and the ambient music of sufficient volume (though my husband disagreed and thought it loud).  This is not a restaurant that caters to heavy meat-eaters, but I would challenge anyone to walk away unsatisfied.  The plates are very filling and there is good diversity of spice and texture to the dishes we tried (chef's selection).  

A treat for those Fillmore strollers looking for a good reason to venture further down towards Japantown than usual.
author: Jim W.

description:
I was thrilled to find out that one of my fave spots in the city was opening a location in my hood. hooray!

Back in November, my boyfriend and I arranged a night out for a bunch of friends and ended up picking the new dosa for dinner. As it happened, we stumbled on opening night! Since then, I've been back twice... once for drinks only and once for dinner with some people from the office.

The service has steadily improved, definitely symptomatic of the growing pains of any new restaurant. The food is really good and so are the drinks. The green building conversion of the old Goodwill space was extremely well done. It's gorgeous!
author: Claire G.

description:
Went to Dosa on Fillmore for dinner last night - thought it would be a nice place for a dinner date and it was close by to an after dinner Japantown kareoke birthday party that we had planned to go to. 

My review of the restaurant is mixed. We ordered a starter (the calimari), a South Indian Entree (the lamb curry), and a dosa (the cheese and peas one) to share. This was what the waiter recommended we do. For two people this was a whole lot of food - we were both hungry walking in and yet ate only a little more than half of the food. Indian food tends to expand in your stomach and it seemed like we were more full an hour after dinner than we were when we left the restaurant.

I'd be interested to learn more about the different between North Indian and South Indian. The waiter briefly explained that North Indian has more entree style dishes (I think that's what she said). And, I am more used to things like Indian curries and I love biryani. So, the lamb curry was excellent - a little spicy, but not too much. 

The starter was also good - also a little spicy, but not too much. The dosa was really different than anything I had eaten before. It's like a cross between a crepe and a burrito. It came with two chutneys and a dipping sauce, two of which I enjoyed. 

But, I didn't leave licking my fingers and immediately wanting to go back. Perhaps I just prefer North Indian food, but I would much rather get a $10 plate of lamb biryani at Pakwan than go to Dosa again. 

I will say that the atmosphere is really nice - especially the upstairs, which feels a little more intimate. The downstairs is much more open and spacious which kind of gives it a lounge-bar feel. So, it's nice to have both in one location.
author: Matt N.

description:
As visitors to the "big city" from small town San Luis Obispo, this restaurant delivered everything we look for in an urban, swank dining experience.  We dropped by at 8:30 pm on a Friday evening, and put our name on the list for a table.  The hostess said come back in an hour.  It was very crowded at 8:30, not so crowded when we returned at 9:30 pm.  We were given a wonderful corner table with a great view of the restaurant.  The whole interior space is wonderfully designed and gave us a lot to look at.  We were quite hungry at that point, and everything on the menu sounded great to us.  As vegans, we were gratified that the menu was very vegan-friendly, with hardly a mention of meat or dairy on the menu.  The waitress also was very receptive to our dietary considerations, and provided us with a supplement "cheat sheet" showing which menu items contained what.

We ordered the Mung Sprout Salad (excellent -- we are going to try and replicate this at home), the Samosas North and South (containing eggs and dairy), the Bagara Baingan baby eggplant Entree with coconut rice (pretty good -- I found the eggplant a little chewy), and the Spinach & Fennel Pooriyal Dosa (delicious).  Our waitress indicated the dosa are made with ghee (clarified butter), but they could make them without ghee if we truly wanted a completely vegan dish.  These four dishes were ample food for us, and we had enough left over to take home for a snack.  We had dark chocolate sorbet for dessert -- not on the menu, but possibly their only vegan dessert offering.  It consists of dark chocolate and sugar in a water base, with no milk whatsoever (dairy, soy, or coconut).  It was excellent, and could pass for chocolate gelato.  

The service was really outstanding -- friendly and attentive, with no pressure to order any more food or drink than we wanted or needed.  We found the prices quite reasonable -- most dishes are priced around $10 to $12.  Our total bill with tax (before tip) was $61 for a very nice dinner out.
author: Matt and Rita C.

description:
My review for Dosa is already biased. We wanted to go for Dine About Town, but apparently they don't offer that menu on Saturdays. Womp. We also had a reservation for a group, and had to wait between 20-30 minutes to sit down. Double womp.

By the time we sat down, we were restless and annoyed, but they did offer us an appetizer as an apology.

The place is really fancy schmancy if that's what you like. Extravagant decor and an elegance about the place. The food was solid, although combining curries makes your palatte all messed up. We got the shrimp masala and a chicken dish. At the restaurant, we thought the shrimp masala was way better, so all our chicken was left untouched. But as I ate the chicken leftovers the next day, I found that it was also pretty delicious.

We opted to get dishes and share, instead of their $40 pre-fixe menu. Total wasn't too bad considering we had cocktails too. It ended up being around $40 per person including tax and tip.
author: Jeanne C.

description: If you want to try Indian food, start here. Delicious. Great service and wonderful food, beautifully presented. Bonus - parking is simple in Japantown parking. Another bonus, you can shop afterwards at Japanese Grocery store.
author: Cate M.

description:
Menu - same as Mission + a few more meat dishes + killer cocktails.

Vibe - 'same' as NOPA + darker loungey lighting that changes colors.  Same big bar area, communal table, split floors.  More mixed crowd.

Prices - still cheap!

Service upstairs can be slow, but they comp'd our entree when it took forever.

Cocktails were super delicious!  Bowler, mmm, spicy.
author: Melanie C.

description:
LOVES IT!

but only for food.  i've been here 3 times since it opened and my opinion of this place is like a roller coaster.  the first time i met up with friends for drinks and a little bit to eat at the bar (it was really crowded).  my boyfriend got this drink the bartender suggested.  i can't remember the name but it has curry powder floating on it.  he really like it and i was intrigued by how subtle and delish it was.  for food, we ordered the mango shrimp dish and even though it was 10:00PM and i just had dinner not long before that, i devoured it.  so i went home and raved about this place to everyone i knew...

2nd time i went, i brought the people who i raved about this place to and i have to say, we were all disappointed.  we went for drinks and dessert (since it was going to be 2 hours before we were able to be seated, we ate somewhere else and ended the night here).  We all got that bollywood something drink, the one where the description has the pickled mango in it...ok, well, i'm chinese and im a big fan of funky preserved fruits, but this drink was GROSS with a captial G!  my bff wanted the fried milk balls because she really liked it from this other place where she first tried them, but those were bad too....unless you like soggy and tooth achingly sweet stuff.  no thanks, not even for this sweet tooth.

the third time i went back for brunch.  i ordered the half dosa and soup thing and decided to try the mango habanero dosa thinking it can't possibly THAT spicy because i have a VERY high tolerance and love for spicy food.  i've met my match!  this thing was so spicy, i was sweating!  it was tasty, but not very sexy.  the soup was the coconut and roasted red pepper soup.  all i'm going to say about that is, i want to bathe in it! (my roommate's glad we don't have a tub.)

finally, i want to say the 3rd time was the charm.  it wasn't only because of the fiery delicious morsels in my mouth, but also because of the service.  mind you, i'm not speaking about my server, she wasn't really there, but the runner.  i dont know his name, but here's my shout-out for him...

Mr. runner man with the corn rows, you are awesome!  this man brought me the dosa and knew that no matter how tough of a cookie i am, that no one could eat this thing without sweating (a lot).  so he brought me a side of yogurt and came back later with a little plate of cucumbers and lemon.  just in time before my tongue melted off from the habenaros!  so, sir, thank you :)  **btw, whoever the OTHER waitress is in there with reddish hair who couldn't crack a smile to save her life and who "pulled you aside" to snap at you for "talking to her table", she can suck it!**  at least you were doing something she was supposed to do!
author: Sally T.

description: Could be a great place to eat but, eating there on a weekend was crappy. I made reservations so I didn't have to wait but, I was disappointed with almost everything that hit the table. The food wasn't horrible but, not that good. The wait staff tried but came up short. Worst factor? The NOISE! When that place is full, you have to yell.
author: Robert M.

description:
I really enjoyed the place...

Beautiful space, although the bar is very bright mid day, and you need sunglasses...

Dosa and salad was a good choice and the spicy one was awesome. Service was good, and it was a perfect meal for after the movies.
author: Danielle V.

description:
Chic and classy interiors..great tasting food. Slightly on the pricey side, but expected given the location and ambience.
I tried the scallops, the chennai chicken and the kerala fish curry with lemon rice. Each dish was perfectly done and tasted great. My fav was the chennai chicken..spicy and crunchy.
Will definitely go back again and try more dishes.
author: Tina S.

description:
We ate so much here and all of it was great..Service was friendly and fairly fast. The place has great atmosphere.

Had the blackened sardines which were perfectly flavored, and the crab cakes to start. Then we shared the potato dosa- very filling with good flavors. The masala whole fish was perfectly flavored and I understand the lamb was very good too.

All this can be washed down with some unique spiced based cocktails- you have to try at least one..

Were too full for dessert, so Im sure we'll be back.
author: Tom L.

description:
I finally visited the famous Dosa a couple weeks ago.  The food was good.  I hadn't had dosa before and enjoyed it; the offer curry we had was good too. The service was fast and they have a great drink menu.
  I did think the place was way too crowded, in that the tables being so close together, and being jammed in so close to other customers, particularly if the people next to you happen to be loud douchebags, takes something away from the ambiance in my book.  I also don't get why all these "hip" places insist on playing the music so loud that you can't talk to the people you're with without yelling at them.
   Still, I would return, because there are so many other dosas there I want to try.
author: A J.

description:
Very tasty food!
Very Costly as well!
Nice Place to dine and meet people!
author: Sri R.

description:
Awesome decor. The bar is WEIRD. We tired ordering normal mixed drink and they couldn't do them? WEIRD. The prix fixe is good, but if you're in a group and into sharing, you're better off just ordering some stuff. The food is pretty delish, but get a group of 5 and make a reservations, waiting is for losers! ;)

please check out my food blog for a full review with photos!
author: Lily K.

description:
Since my visit to the other Dosa was excellent I gave this one a try too.  I  went there for Valentine's day with my husband. 

One star off for food that did not impress... Not sure what happened because I loved the food at the other Dosa.

Another star off for the terrible server!  She was really really out of it.  Not friendly at all, and it took forever and a half to get her attention.  She was really messing up at the table next to us.  Served the guests the wrong bottle of wine.

Maybe I ordered the wrong things, maybe the server was having an off day.  I'm willing to give it another try.
author: H K.

description:
Nice place to eat before a movie at Kabuki. Not knock your socks off yet good. Still in search of outstanding. 
Still, we'd come back.
author: Dan B.

description: Our food was great. This restaurant is a lot of fun with a cozy environment. We went on Thursday night and had to wait approximately 45 minutes to get a table. I believe that you can make reservations, and I would advise to do just that. I am a vegetarian and there are plenty of vegi choices. We ate 2 dosa plates, and I had the vegi dish with chic peas; everything was very tasty! This South Indian food is a must, at least once if you live in SF. Finally, it is important to note that this is a pricey restaurant, not your typical Indian cuisine prices.
author: melissa c.

description: Thanks to Dosa I am a believer in fish curry and a fan of ordering wine by the bottle, especially if your date makes you nervous.
author: Y K.

description:
Surprisingly filling meals in a spectacular location.

Came into Dosa on a Monday night around 9pm, it was surprisingly full, which is always a good sign. The interior is amazing...the lights are well thought out and still maintains a classy feel.

While the wine list is superb - the prices are a little on the high side. We ordered a bottle of the Cape Mentelle Shiraz for $52 - that's a hefty chunk of change.

Started with the Chennai Chicken ($9.50) as an appetizer. It was very nice, bite sized chicken bits. Then had the Mysore Dosa ($10.50) which was decent, and a lot more filling than what it looks. Lastly had the Prawn Masala with coconut rice ($17) which we could barely get down because we were already so full. A little overpriced for the 6 or so prawns you get.

Final bill for a table of two on Monday night was $114, half of which was a bottle of good wine - but still a place I would go to again.
author: Joseph T.

description:
Went here the first day it opened. Service was great, food was tasty and atmosphere is fabulous as it has a great decor... We sat upstairs and could people watch.

Be careful if you have nut allergies. Our guest does and even though they were very careful... the wait staff tried with consulting the kitchen, they were not as familar with the ingredients and our guest had a reaction. Most of the sauces and foods contain cashews, so please be careful if you have this type of allergy... I had to run to the corner store and fortunately, they had Benadryl...

Food was great and they comp'ed our meal due to the nut allergy... can't ask for more.

Pricey...
author: Debbie C.

description: Love this location better than the one in Valencia, have more space, Valencia location made me feel like in the can. The lunch menu is awesome, pricey but ok I guess...the problem I'm not give 5 stars because when me and my co-workers got lunch yesterday, there's some construction happened right in front the entrance door and so noisy...
author: Marsaulina V.S V.

description:
I am so pleased that this place opened up much closer to my house so I don't have to trek my ass down to the Mission. However, I had failed to eat here in all the months that it has been open because I am rarely over on that side of Van Ness; however, today I went for the Bliss package at the Kabuki Spa and continued the bliss with lunch and a cocktail at the bar!

The space is beautiful, one would never suspect that it used to be a Goodwill! Though I did buy an awesome lamp here 10 years ago when it was one. It's modern and elegant but also has a lovely casual feel. The service, which I have always found hit and miss at the Mission location was spot on. 

I had the lunch special which was a "mini-dosa" (quotes because the thing was more than filling) and side salad special for $11. You get to choose your dosa or uttapam and one of their salad or soups so there are plenty of options. I went with paper masala dosa and a the greens with mango and goat cheese in a light vinagrette. Both were spot on and filling. I chased it all down with the Bengali Gimlet which was awesome and when I shared with the bartender that I was planning in Oscar party where everyone had to bring a cocktail based on one of the nominees and I was doing "research" for maybe doing a drink based on Slumdog Millionaire (or one of the three documentary shorts set in India!) he shared with me how they make their curried nectar;

All and all a great experience and one I will definitely be repeating soon.
author: Tara A.

description: have had the dosa a couple times. it's good. i've had better idly and vada (it's softer than I like). great atmosphere but kind of pricey
author: Aneesh S.

description:
delish drinks, delish food, friendly staff, gorgeous interior... yay! 
i like!!! :)
author: Ilovelife Z.

description: My husband's cousin came to town with her beau who is from South India. They ate here, and said that is was amazing. So, we tried it! I was having a low blood-sugar moment when we walked through the door, but they were so nice and professional, and made sure to bring some water right away. The food was out-of-this-world yummy; I can't wait to bring friends here!
author: L T.

description:
Yes, you can get cheaper masala dosas at most hole in the wall South Indian places. So I wanted to dislike this place. But it was great. Here's why

- Ambiance. Just awesome. Beautiful spacious. No offense, but as an Indian myself, I am appalled at how awful the ambiance and setting is at most South Indian restaurants. Not here. Gorgeous.
- Creativity. The spring dosa and paneer dosa were creative, original, and well done
- Presentation. The food looked beautiful on the plate/

All of the above usually means a $35-40 and up main + starter anywhere else. Here, you can easily get a meal for under $20 (no drinks). 

The food itself was excellent as well, and the service was great too. All around, a great addition to your "must dine at" list and 4 stars from me.
author: Sai S.

description: Had a great meal at Dosa! A great way to end an evening after a show at the Kabuki. The restaurant decor is beautiful, the service was great and the food was delicious. Being Southern Indian, I wasn't familiar with many of the dishes or how to order...our waitress was very nice and helpful. I will definitely go back.
author: Shelly R.

description: Awesome indian restaurant. Best ambience of all the indian restaurants I have been to in US. Great service. It is a bit costly, but its worth. Food was very good and tasty. Authentic south indian dishes.
author: Pravin Babu K.

description:
This was my 2nd time at Dosa!  I've been to Dosa Valencia as well, which was not the best experience.  Which location should do I start with?  First, I would like to disclose I was born in Kerala and grew up eating Dosa's for breakfast several times a week with my Dad's family.  And Dosa's are for breakfast and brunch:).

Dosa Fillmore has a nice atmosphere, but this is good as it added attention which diverts ones attention from the non-authentic and awful food they serve.  I was disappointed and embarrassed as a Keralite/Malayalee of what Dosa has concocted to present the general public and taking non-Indo consumers lack of knowledge in what true South Indian cuisine is all about, especially Dosas.

Walking into Dosa Fillmore, one obtains a good look at the high ceiling tall glass windowed atmosphere filled with sunlight.  The atmosphere is very nice as anyone would say.  We sat down and my friend chose the Masala dosa, and I chose the fusion dosa dish version which was eggs, veggies, and cheese.  Well, I'm not sure which Dosa dish I received as the waitress brought out the wrong order, I didn't complain as I was slightly disappointed with the chai I was drinking.  Long story short, both dishes were not great, especially mine as it tasted horrible.  After effects was that my friend ended up being sick from the food for several days, and I became immediately sick right afterwards.  I am not sure what took place that day with our dishes, but certainly both of us getting sick is not random.  Sign their kitchen processes or methodologies are not up to par or they simply use cheap ingredients.

When went to Dosa Valencia, the dishes were far from authentic.  One of  the dishes I ordered was Kochi Calamari, the dish came out all gooey and tasted no where never a dish from Kochi, Kerala.  The place super loud and could hardly hear my friend, not mention asking her several times her eggplant dish was, when I could tell she was not enjoying it.  Wouldn't recommend this location either.

If you want true authentic south Indian cuisine, try other places.  From a South Indian born cat, and having had Dosa's all over Kerala and the east coast, Dosa is not the place to experience having your 1st or certainly not your last Dosa.  They have good branding that's it, don't be fooled.  Branding good, product(s) not good.
author: Indo N.

description:
It's hard to believe this was ever the goodwill! They did a gorgeous remodel. 
I went on Friday with three others and we got a bunch of different dishes. The lamb chops were so yummy! I loved the samosas as well. The only thing I didn't care for was the lentil dumplings, but I'm not a lentil person...
Great drinks that you would have never thought would be good like the bengali gimlet - gin, curry, lime...fab! Oh and the juhu palm - coconut milk, lime and gin, really good. 
I say try it, it's a cool spot and the food and service is great.
author: Shelley M.

description: White people's take on south indian cuisine. Some things are too salty, other things are too bland, but at the very least, the room itself is gorgeous.
author: Sabbies B.

description: I think this is the best Indian food I've had! The cocktails were interesting, and not overly sweet. The menu is a bit overwhelming if you've never been there and you're not familiar with the food, but the server pointed us in the right direction. Dinner entrees are generous in portion, so we happily left stuffed. Vegetarian-friendly, but pleasing to the meat-eaters too. I can't wait to try their brunch!
author: Lucy M.

description:
The food was good but I think the price far out weighed the value for what we got.  Four of us went on a recommendation and all had the four course tasting menu.  
First course, Chili Shrimp (2) - Tasty, I did enjoy it
Second Course - Paneer Dosa - Tasty, very good flavor
Third Course - Chicken Korma - Very disappointing!  Small portion
Fourth Course - Coconut Sorbet - Very good but how can you screw up sorbet.
Price after for all four $232.00
Not worth the price, Mehfil is 1000% better and costs less than half the price.
author: Andrew D.

description: Finally...after all these years I've finally made it to Dosa on Fillmore.  It seems like everyone I know has been here.  It's perfectly placed if you're headed to the Kabuki for a movie or the Fillmore for a show.  We had a reservation right when it opened at 5:30 and when we got there the place was already pretty buzzing with a lot of people and the bar already full.  The inside is decorated very nicely.  I think we had about four to five different people serving us through the night but it tended to work.  We asked for suggestions on what to order and everything they suggested was delicious.  We got two appetizers (scallops and Dahi Vada) to start and the sauces were great and had a nice kick to them.  For the main meal we had the peppercorn chicken with the Spicy Mung Masala Dosa.  Everything was delicious.  For dessert we had the banana cream pie and it sounded a little off on the menu but it was so good and a greta way to end a very nice dinner.
author: Blake B.

description:
its Indian food, but not like the rest of Indian food that you tried before. as far as i can remember this is the best Indian food that i tried.

they have great selections of German beers, and great lovely staff, its might be a little pricey but its just once in a while.
author: Bin K.

description: Beautiful atmosphere, beautiful food. Worth the trip for the dosas alone. My friend and I also enjoyed the channa masala and the spicy coconut shrimp. I can see myself returning to Dosa again and again to try everything and anything on the menu. One drawback: service  was a little snooty; we'd never been there and asked a lot of questions, and our waitress acted as if we were wasting her time.
author: Beth T.

description: Excellent ambience at this new Dosa place. Much less crowded and noisy than their original Dosa at Vallencia.
author: Mak J.

description:
One of the most impressive interiors to a restaurant in the city, IMHO...You don't feel like you're in SF when you're here.

Great use of space, lighting and decor...Couldn't really stop checking out everything...Everything except for a large sized photo on one of the walls that both seemed to be out of place and placed too low for such a large wall & restaurant.

Service and getting a table is not the best aspect of this place...If anything, it feels a bit disorganized in that respect.

Bartender was great and made some great recommendations both on drinks and the food.

Not the most impressive dosas, especially considering it's named after them, but the overall quality of the food and portions were pretty good.

Some things were hit and some things were miss.

The Chennai chicken is a starter but the oil was the predominant taste we got from them...Either go larger pieces of chicken or dial back the oil would be my recommendation.

Dahi Vada was recommened by the bartender and a good choice...Pretty tasty but think it could've been better if it had a bit more kick from the chutneys and perhaps were warm instead of cold.

Favorite dish by a landslide was the channa...Perfectly flavored and reminded me of some of the best Channa I'd ever had...Just delish and would definitely return just for that.
author: Barca F.

description:
Refreshing alternative to the many Northern Indian restaurants in SF, possibly the glitziest and busiest Indian restaurant in the city.

MUST order one of the dosas and a side of coconut rice (*droooool*).... we also sampled the Caramelized Onion uttapam and Mango Jumbo Prawns - both were outstanding. Generous portions, fresh ingredients and a tantalizingly varied menu - what's not to like?

Service is excellent - the staff graciously accommodated a tomato allergy (thankfully not mine!) amongst our group.
author: Melissa S.

description: This place is nasty! I love indian food but this establishment is a sad excuse for one. They use the same spice and flavoring for a lot of the dishes. I ordered the palak dosa and also the samosas. They samosas were over fried and the oil tasted old. They were dripping in it. Then the dosa came and the lentils etc on the side to dip in were less than appealing. The dosa itself didnt even have melted cheese in it. Needless to say I felt very sick upon leaving this location and also when I got home, certainly had traces of food poisioning as I was vomiting all night. Save yourself the aftermath, and the money, and go somewhere else!
author: Alana C.

description:
Those of you that are not a fan of really spicy food  here are my recommendations ...have you guys tried the "frankies" ??  really good. 

make sure you ask any of the cool bartenders their own drink specialty that is not on the menu. they never dissapointed me.

my favorite's are 
Mung sprouts salad and Paneer romaine
masala uttapam, 
chennai chicken
blackened sardines
paratha
fish moilee -
author: Carrie F.

description:
Great food. Huge place with a fun atmosphere. Service was wonderful and our waitress was attentive but not overbearing (even though we took over 20 minutes to even open the menu!)  

I've been twice now and was happy with both my experiences.  The South Indian menu is different from the normal Indian food I'm used to.  The dosas are in essence stuffed crepes that you can tear off and dip in the variety of sauces.  The uttapams are similar, just thicker...more like a pancake.  

My favorite item was the Channa Bhatura which is a chickpea masala dish served with a huge puffy bread.  The Prawn Chile Fry was also fantastic - my friend commented that they were the best prawns she had ever eaten!

The cocktails were terrific and seem in line with the SF upscale cocktail trends.  The wine selection is broad and all designed to pair well with the food.
author: Todd S.

description: DOSA is still my fav place!! It's my first time to the fillmore spot though.  It's really a bit too big for me but I LOVE the food nonetheless.  I was gonna give it a 5 star, but the drinks takes longer than the food to come and the fact that they gave us the wrong check kinda set things off a bit. It's a really busy spot. So be prepared to wait unless you have a reservation!
author: Cathy Y.

description: I must say this is one of the nicest decorated Indian restaurants I have been to in my life. The atmosphere makes you want to eat here. This place specializes in South Indian cuisine hence the name Dosa. It was absolutely delicious. I had the lamb wrap which was spiced to perfection and filled with taste. The dosas here were crispy and the sambar and chutney hit the spot. Our server even though not Indian seemed well informed about the menu. The menu is a little pricey and the service was a little slow but overall great feel, great company and great food. :)
author: Pooja B.

description: Excellent food; lively ambiance.  Could not ask for more.  Oh, and they live up to their name - the dosa's are the best!  The only reason I did not give them 5 stars because I have only been here once and I'm not sure about all of the dishes, consistency of service etc.
author: Allen T.

description:
I don't really give out many 5 stars but dosa gets one for being a unique place as well as delicilous.

There are not many fine dining Indian places that are swanky, sheik and modern. They really pulled it off here. 

The cocktails are creative and not foofy.

The fire broth soup is just what you will crave the next time you succumb to a cold.

The fish with coconut sauce was flakey and perfectly cooked. Not to mention pleantiful

The coconut rice was so light and fluffy I could stuff my pillow with it and slip off into a deep sleep.

The service was great, our server cute and sweet.

The place was full but you could still hear yourself talk without raising your voice.

Thank god they put this place in ... the Burger King and the Goodwill on opposing corners were creating a homeless vortex :)
author: Jeremy R.

description: You guys suck, came in with a group of 15 with a prefix menu. Our tab was around $2000 and the server gave us so much crap for splitting it on a few credit cards. Are you kidding. Your sales for the night were mostly from us, a Wednesday night, EFFF YOU
author: Anthony L.

description:
Nothing gets me off like a warm, buttery, gluten-free dosa. NOTHING! Savory, perfectly seasoned masala filling...oh, and the chutneys? Divine, orgasmic inspiration. 

Dosa, you are nothing short of earth-shattering perfection.
author: San Fran O.

description:
Excellente!!!!! 

The food was delicious, and it came out really quickly. 

There are two parking garages close to the restaurant, so parking wasn't an issue. 

Only concern: If you plan on going out after dinner, reconsider the choice of cuisine. You will smell like Indian food once you leave the restaurant, and any alcoholic drinks with tonic may lead to unpleasant burps. But it's all fine if you plan to repel the opposite sex. 

By the way, this is suppose to be a positive review. 

I definitely recommend this restaurant.
author: Cheryl C.

description: How many times have you looked at a plate of food and said holy moly? They brought out my paper masala that measured a good foot and half and 3 inches around and I nearly fell off my stool. After I recovered from  my intial shock the food was mighty tasty and the mango lassi thrilled me.  Simply beautiful surroundings that are swanky and romantic.
author: Sophia C.

description:
Let me start saying that I am a huge fan of Dosa Mission.
But when I went to Dosa Fillmore the first there I wasn't disappointed 
at all. I loved it.

The food is amazing as always, plus the full bar is a big plus.
It's a great place for a lovely dinner or just a quick stop before going
to the Sundance.
The decor is great and the acoustic is really good (better then Dosa Mission).
Music in the background is always interesting and groovy.
Service is also outstanding.
author: Gianmaria C.

description: Dosa is good and fun for a night out, but I am used to intimate curry restaurants where I know the chef and feel like I am eating a family recipe straight from India. This is definitely an SF take on curry, and the food is delicious, but it doesn't seem authentic. I'd go back, but I'm still in search of my favorite Indian restaurant in SF.
author: Katie M.

description: Loved everything about this restaurant. Great energetic vibe, excellent food and very helpful staff. We ordered family style - so we got the opportunity to try many different items off of their extensive menu. Very impressed with everything we were served.
author: Lauren C.

description: Excellent food, genuinely good cuisine and great service! Me nd the family were visiting from DC and this was a real treat in SFO!
author: Vikram K.

description:
This place is really great, with the exception of our waitress. We were seated quickly, the hostess was super, and the food was delicious. Just would have enhanced the experience if the waitress smiled or didnt seem so cold. I felt uncomfortable asking her for anything. 

Other than that, i like it here very much. :-)
author: Lady L.

description:
Boy how was i wrong about this one. In the Valencia Dosa wars, i was planted firmly in the corner of Uddippi Palace. Dosa was the roger federer to the nadal of Udippi Palace. I scoffed at the elegant effete charms of the former, and argued firmly for the less pretentious charms of the latter. The hipsters flocking to Dosa certainly didn't help (Dear straw target hipster: you may know your arcade fire, but you don't know jack about south indian food, so please don't pretend you do -- I GREW UP EATING these before your kind thought multiculturalism was cool.)
But one fateful night after a late  film in Filmore, I gave in, comforted by the knowledge that none of my family knew of my treacherous venture into enemy territory. Verdict: Best Masala Dosa I have eaten in this country, and would rival anything I would eat back home (i.e. Bombay -- and no, please don't "correct" me or show off that you know it's "Mumbai now). My family might disown me if they knew I was writing this, but I would say it's better than the Vik's dosa. The dosa texture is both soft and crispy and I can almost swear they use Amul butter for further authenticity. The sambhar is spicy, and I can taste the curry leaf flavor, which is SO important to me.
I can't bring myself to try the fusion stuff -- so no white truffle dosa or sunchoke filling dosa for me, thank you very much. I'm too much of a traditionalist when it comes to south Indian food. 
Another stand out dish are the idli fries (which aren't at the Valencia location) -- again, great chutneys, and the crispy fried curry leaves fill my heart with ecstasy but also an aching nostalgia for home.
author: Crushed Wi Cardamom C.

description:
I was lucky enough to discover this restaurant soon after moving to the city.  This is one of my favorite places and I would eat here once a week if it wasn't a little too expensive.  Don't take that to mean I think that they are overpriced.  The food is fantastic, the staff is great, the atmosphere is great for a fun date night, or just dinner with friends/family.

Every time I eat here I have to have a dosa, preferably the chili garlic.  The last time I ate here I brought my parents who were visiting the city.  They both had a great time and loved the food.  The only thing I had been disappointed with was the level of spiciness in their "spicier" dishes.  I requested a serving of the chili chutney, which is usually just layered in the dosa, this was the key to getting that burn I love.
