I did not deduct any stars for the spicy level as I think this is just a matter of tolerance.  I know I can handle a lot spicier food than most, especially of the reviewers on Yelp, so I have to forgive places when they don't make me sweat.

Overall, a great place for some delicious Indian food, be aware this won't be a cheap night especially with drinks.
author: Thomas J.

description: I love coming here for happy hour.  They always have a delicious & unique cocktail on the menu for $5.  I highly recommend it!
author: Liz Y.

description: Dosa was a fun Indian restaurant to try. The atmosphere is hip/chic/Indian.  The food was a good play on traditional Indian fare.  I had the special 3 course meal.  It was a good way to taste a little bit of the different types of dishes.  I wanted to start with the lotus stem day boat scallops but they were out of scallops so the waiter recommended the chennai chicken which turned out to be my favorite dish of the night. It was very spicy but flavorful.  My companion started with the organic greens with spiced mango and goat cheese.  I thought it was fine nothing special.  For course two I chose seasonal spring uttapam.  Again very spicy but good and came with 3 dipping sauces.  My companion had the white truffle masala dosa.  I thought that was a little flat in flavor. I don't think I would order that again.  Finally I ended the meal with Tamil lamb curry which was over the top in flavor but very very spicy. My companion had the prawn masala and it was spicy too.
author: Julie M.

description: Dosa is an overly hyped restaurant on Fillmore. It's probably sought after because it's one of the few South Indian restaurants in the city serving dosas. Assuming that the restaurant is famous for dosas and looking at the reasonably large variety of dosas on the menu, we ordered 3 types of dosas - paneer, potato, vegetable. All of them failed to meet the expectations. Food is so not palatable here. The dining experience is not great, either. The tables are so small and the place is so congested and noisy.  I won't return.
author: Gayatri K.

description:
Scrumptious!! The food is amazing. I am a southindian and i can say the food verymuch gives the southindan favour although i only saw non-indians managing and maintaining the  restaurant. Its very good for dating, birthday dinners and good southindian food. 

We went there for my birthday dinner. One of my american friends suggested this place. And I am so glad my first visit to DOSA is on my birthday otherwise I would have a tough time digesting the bill was 200 bucks for 5 people. Drinks are fine!!The service was very cordial. I liked the atmosphere as well.

Overall, I feel its totally worth 200 for the food and experience.
author: Rashmitha M.

description: Great ambiance and killer cocktails. Mung salad was delicious with a great flavor combination. The dosas were good but wish they were a bit more crispy. The chennai chicken had good flavor but a better quality of meat such as breast would be great to make it less chewy. Hubby had banzino which was good but didn't expect a whole fish.  Food was good but didn't walk away with that out of the world experience. Be warned it is on the spicier side.
author: Asha G.

description: A lot of asian fusion restaurants are over-priced and the food is just okay, but I had a great dining experience here! Not what I expected at all.. Being Indian, I've had some pretty good dosa and I thought the food here was great. I thought the chef did a good job with experimenting with traditional Indian dishes, but the spices and flavors are authentic. If you like spicy, I highly recommend the Spicy Mung  Masala dosa. And for appetizers, try Rasam (soup) or the Vada Pav (sliders). I didn't try the cocktails but they look great! The interior of the restaurant is gorgeous with high ceilings, large windows, and cute decor.
author: Ayesha B.

description:
I was super excited when Dosa opened on Fillmore and had been really looking forward to trying it. Finally last week my boyfriend and I decided to try it out. First of all it really is a beautiful place.  We had a drink at the bar wile we waited. bartenders were amazing, drinks great. We were seated 10 min later, great, at a group table...kinda odd.  It would have been fine had we not had the most annoying couple across form us, but not Dosa's fault. 
This is when my review starts to go south. Our waiter was a jerk. He came to take our order, we told him we had never dined at here before and asked for suggestions. We got "everything is good"  not super helpful but ok. So we decide to do the set menu. He asked if we wanted to order all at once? I was kinda confused and replied "yeah is that ok?" The waiter comes back with a snotty remark and "that what normal people do." At this point I should have just told him no thank you and asked for the check with our drinks on it. But we stayed and it just got worse we waited way to long between courses and our waiter continued be be less than nice. He never brought the check and when my bf finally flagged him down he said nothing. OK? It was weird. Then the check magically appeared below my bf's arm. No hope the food was good, no have a good night, no nothing. Just weird.
My food was good, my boyfriends was not. The experience turned out to be very disappointing epically because we dropped around $150. I'm really sad, I was looking forward to finding my next go to restaurant but I will not be visiting Dosa again.
author: Ashley W.

description:
Seriously love this place.  I've never had a bad dish, the only regret I have with my most recent entree was ordering the "hot" option - it was way too hot for my inexperienced self.  I ate the whole thing and it was delish, but my mouth was on fire.  Last time I think I'm cool enough for Indian spicy!

The ambiance is amazing, such a well done job.  High ceilings, cool fusion art, nice crowd.

Every time I've been there there have been many tables of Indian people dining there -- seems like it's a hit!
author: Sarah M.

description:
This restaurant has one of the better dosas that I have had on the West Coast, but it is so, so expensive!  Okay, a dosa won't set you back more than $10 or so dollars, but you add drinks and another dish plus rice to the order and your bill will near $100.  Last time I was there we ordered the Kerala Fish (about $30) and it was very fishy and not very impressive.  I could have made a better dish.  The rice was kind of cold too!  I wish this restaurant would open a cafe or to-go window and just sell dosas.

That said, the customer service is very very good here.
author: Jessica P.

description: With tickets in hand to see a movie at the Kabuki, I suggested Dosa to  my husband and daughter. Husband recently went vegan, daughter is a recent college grad foodie. We had a blast. The highlights: The waitress being totally chill and bringing us a food chart of every ingredient in every dish, not 'upselling' us when we ordered moderately and the great sparkling Pinot Noir on their wine list. The Spring Dosa comes w/a fantastic, spicy lentil soup, the cardoman ice cream is fabulous. I'd skip the 'dosa sampler' and the mung salad was refreshing and v. interesting. The stylish decor makes the experience fun and the prices are really reasonable.
author: joan g.

description: Tasty food, great scene, reasonable prices, good drinks - all-around solid choice to meet friends for lunch or dinner.  We sat at the common table in the bar and it was a unique experience, catching snippets of interesting conversation and having plenty of it ourselves.  The dosa are easy to split and portions are ample.  I enjoyed my taster plate of Uttapam (the "South Indian Moons"), though I think the dosa are more my thing, with a little less breading.  They have a host of other offerings outside their namesake dish, like the vegetable curry, which was delicious and gave us plenty leftover to take home for a snack.  Fun place!
author: Amanda M.

description: Great Indian food with a twist, ambiance was classy and lively, service is attentive while also friendly.
author: Elliot S.

description:
Went for a late lunch to Dosa before a movie at the Sundance Theaters. Enjoyed the very different vibe and ambiance in comparison to the sister restaurant on Valencia. The new place is very spacious with a loft area as well. The floor to ceiling windows made for enjoyable people watching, but I enjoyed looking at everything inside as well - the lamps, designs on the walls, and golden floor tiles in the ladies room!  

Service was outstanding. Informative and friendly without being cloying. Food was quickly served, hot and delicious. 4 of us shared 3 different dosas and an uttapum. The sambar rates amongst  the best I've had. The dessert menu was really intriguing but we were unfortunately too full to sample anything. Loved the fact that there was complimentary still and sparkling water.
author: Ash A.

description: Here is a well-designed space to have a drink/nosh in the bar to the right; or a full, favorful meal on the left.  It's a comfortable, inviting fully open room.  We went during DineAboutTown.  Our succulent spiced lamb and the moist, grilled seafood combination both had three contrasting sauces.  This made for an adventure in flavors from cool (yoghurt/cilantro) to heated, complexity (sweet red peppers, hot chiles, tomato).  The rice was flavorful, chewy, with just-right level of   The true 5 part is the Management, overseen by the gregarious General Manager, Dan.  He, alone, is more colorful than the scene; and truly loved making us welcome.  His sincere love of his work was clear.  His desire to know and "presto" take care of our needs and questions was authentic; really added to our decision to return soon.  He took care of everything, down to the details; ilke an orchestra conductor getting the best from his team.
author: Paula H.

description:
I went there after having read many reviews on yelp. It was my last evening in SF so I wanted something special in terms of food and of place. and I was delighted by both. This is not the Indian at the round corner, this is a real nice place with a nice trendy decoration where you can go for a special diner with someone or with a group of friends. The staff knew that it was a special moment cause I said it during my reservation and they give us a really nice table on the mezanine with a perfect view on the the huge dining room downstairs. Highly recommended!
We ate the south indian lamb kefta as recommended by a native indian on yelp and it was delicious. I will highly recommend it! if you like spicy food, you will be served (not too spicy but at least a bit).
And for the desert, our first thought was to only take the gulab jamoon but the wise waiter highly recommend us trying also the rasmalai ... and guess what? It has been such a long time that I haven't been astonished by deserts!!! you have to try it, honestly it is so tasty, such a greed must be eaten! and be sure that I am really picky about desert.
The service was great, not asking every 5 mn if everything was OK but respecting our privacy! An excellent service and staff!
Two minor negative points: 1) a bit disappointed by their rum cocktails (ginger ante: too bitter so not really emphasizing the quality of the rum according to me and caipirhina: not that great ), however the wine was good. 2) the ceiling should be decorated to hide its white and impersonal color which works again its warm ambiance given by the deco, maybe some both dark red and orange curtains....
author: Guillaume C.

description:
A few months back I went to Dosa on Fillmore and had a TERRIBLE experience.  You see, I'm incredibly allergic to peppers (the vegetable) - bells, chilis, you name it, I can't eat it.  While the wait staff was very understanding, the chef REFUSED to accommodate my severe food allergy.  Please recognize that I wasn't insisting that certain dishes be made pepper-free; rather I literally said I would have anything they could make without peppers.  Even then, when things came, they had peppers.

If they can express such arrogance, especially in this recession, they clearly deserve my one star rating and I strongly urge all to dine elsewhere - where they don't take their patrons for granted.

Thank you for listening,

Steve
author: Steve B.

description: AMAZING.  sheesh.  I'm a fan of hot foods, and this place (as well as the Valencia location) hits the spot.  Super big fan of the Taj Mahal too.  The taster menus are more than enough and for such a great deal too!  I must keep going.
author: Ivy R.

description: Love this place, love the food, the ambiance and the service is top notch.  I especially like going there for lunch on a nice SF day.
author: Orpheus M.

description:
This one's going to be quick. Went to Dosa for friend's birthday. We all ordered the 35/person extra value meal four course thing and it was a mistake. We rec'd very small dishes (they're half the normal size of a standard dish) and it felt like something silly. We could very easily have ordered a lot more food for the money and shared it amongst the table. In general the food tasted good. Calamari appetizer was especially good.

The service was mediocre. I know, it's difficult to serve a large table, but hey, it's the big leagues. Let's go for it. While the downstairs was interesting and club-like the upstairs felt like the farm team. Nice people, but a bit overwhelmed. Again, group was large. By the end of the night, it was difficult enough for them to smile much less give good service.

I'd like to witness Dosa once more, but I'm not likely to do it soon.
author: Thomas R.

description: this place was not bad for "fancy" indian food. i unfortunately don't think that the food is worth the price. don't get me wrong...the food is good and definitely a good take on classic indian street foods. the place does get very crowded and loud and hard to actually carry on a good conversation with whoever you come with. overall, good for food if you want to wait.
author: Anish P.

description:
The ambience was great and food was amazing. The best Indian food I've had till now, in US.
If you like spicy food, I'd recommend "Chennai Chicken" and "Prawn Masala with Coconut Rice". I could taste every bit of spice in my first bite.

I'd suggest them to increase the choice in cocktails though.
author: Abhijeet P.

description: Best Indian food ever! One of my favorite restaurants of all time. And I eat at nice restaurants A LOT!
author: Janet P.

description: Service, food, decor, ambiance all excellent.  Vegans have lots to choose from here.  While I prefer to support Udupi Palace due to its being all vegetarian, Dosa's food is better as far as my tastes go.  A similar meal at Udupi would have been about 40% less expensive, though.
author: Bob G.

description:
Ironically, the main problem with this place is the dosa.  I've had plenty of dosa in the past.  These are not good by any means.  The waitress felt the need to tell us to abandon any ideas of what we thought Indian food was because this was going to be different.  She was right.  The memories of dosa I had in the past tormented me as I tried to eat this lame imitation.  The only other time in my life that someone had told me to abandon any ideas of what I had before was when I went to buy underwear in Nicaragua.  The new underwear gave me a permanent wedgie.  Somehow the experience I had at Dosa reminds me of that.

   The place and the decor is very pretentious.  I expected Perrier to come out of the faucet in the bathroom, but it was just tap water.  What's up with that?

   If you want good Indian food, there are plenty of places around that are cheaper and that have good food.  If you want to sit around in a pretentious atmosphere, then you should go to Dosa.
author: Mister M.

description:
1.  We were 20 minutes late.  Called and asked them to hold our table (on a busy Saturday night).  No problem.  Walked in, place was packed.  As soon as we walked in, they showed us to our table.  I was shocked they held the table.

2.  We were late for a show.  Told our waitress we were in a rush.  5 minutes after we ordered, our food showed up.  We were flabbergasted.

3.  Food was awesome.  I would return any day.
author: Thi T.

description:
On a whim we switched dinner plans after finishing a movie at Kabuki and decided to give Dosa a try. Plus, # 64 on 7x7's 2010 SF Big Eat List: Paper masala dosa was served here. The presentation of the paper dosa was amazing itself- in a shape of long, hollow log of wood- it took our breaths away.  It was lightly crispy on the outside but soft inside so you can fold and dip it into the coconut & tomato chutneys and sambar.  It was definitely a hands-on kinda dish. It was enough to share, and I recommend ordering a side of meat dish to go with the dosa as eating the dosa alone can feel a little redundant.  The Chennai boneless chicken starter was marinated in Straus organic yogurt.  The warm and cold sensation was a good combination.  We also shared the Paneer & Peas Uttapam which reminded me of a big, round egg omelet with shredded farmer's cheese, peas and cilantro. We came when they were promoting the Yelp special where certain drinks were only $5!

Save room for dessert or tea.  Our dessert wasn't the best- you can forgo the Gulab Jamoon, which consisted of two fried dough balls literally drenched in sugar syrup with cardamom flavoring.  It was too sweet for me.  However, our friends got the Banana Cream Pie and it looked indulgent.  Loved the authentic chai tea that comes unsweetened but definitely had a strong cardamom flavor. 

Overall, I enjoyed dinner here-- nice intimate atmosphere but don't worry about getting dressed up because I observed people on the casual side in larger parties and even families with children. Stunning light decor and overall good service.
author: Lisa C.

description:
So, I'll start out by being honest, I really wanted to hate this place.  I like hole-in-the-wall Indian food places, the kind you stumble upon and feel like you're the only one who knows it.  In my mind, fancy Indian food is just an excuse for being let down.....but, I was wrong.
We started with wine, and they have an excellent wine list.  Albarinos at an Indian restaurant?!?!  Whoo hoo!
We then moved on to Samosas.  They provide two different types, a Northern and Southern samosa, and I was surprised at how different and delicious both were.
We then ordered the dosa with spinach and fennel and the veggies were fresh and tasty.  The dosa was pre-cut, which made me sad because I like when this huge pancake-looking thing comes to the table, but it was still very delicious.  We also had a lamb curry which was good, but my least favorite dish.  The lamb wasn't the most flavorful.
We passed on dessert, but I learned a lesson.  Fancy doesn't mean crappy Indian food...I may even come back (when my wallet recovers).
author: Jessica L.

description: Best place I've been in a loooong time! Great ambiance, wonderful service, amazing food, delicious drinks. Doesn't get much better than this! Can't wait to go back.
author: Katy M.

description: This place has one of the best Dosa's I have ever had!  The spicy moong and the wheat dosa's are amazing.  The sambhar and coconut chutney are both very tasty
author: S P.

description: Southern Indian food - very good.  But don't expect your standard nan and chicken tikki masala.  Menu is quite unique and food very good.  And pretty good service.
author: Bozy B.

description:
What a disappointment!!!!!!
I was so excited to have dinner at this restaurant for my birthday.
The food is not good (I go out to good restaurants every week and I know what good food is) and the prices are a joke for what you get. We got the lamb brianni and there was 5 tiny pieces of lamb in a bowl of dry rice for I think $19!!!!!!!!!! the Dosas are so blah. The dessert was the worst part of the dinner. The rice pudding is awful. We sent it back and still got charged. I would never go back here so disappointed.
author: mojgan v.

description: Impeccable food, everything you want from high-class Indian cuisine.  The cocktail menu is awesome too--don't order your standard jack and coke, step out of your comfort zone and try one of their drinks--the spicy one with the tequila is great.  Great atmosphere and ambiance.  Although they forgot to bring my salad I ordered, the manager came by, apologized, and gave us free dessert.  Definitely going back.
author: Ryan H.

description:
Went in knowing that the ambiance is better than the food. However the service was a bit sloppy & my picky indian palate left much more to be desired.  Nice tall ceilings & lovely chandeliers & art work.

Appetizers : 
Chennai Chicken - the bestest. lipsmacking. Must get. So flavorful it did not need any added chutney
Crispy fish pakora - meh.  well I am not one for this dish, but Ash who ordered it also didn't care for it.

Entrees : 
Prawn Masala - good. Could be spicier. Maybe we should have gone for the Andra version.
Lamb Kofta - curry was too mild & tomatoey. Lamb meatball was good
Mung Masala - meh. Quite disappointing. We also asked for the masala on the side & that request didn't make it through. Also the dosa was warm. For a place named dosa, it needs to do more justice to this dish
Lemon rice - yummm

Drinks : 
Paramour - loved it. Got it for the curry leaves touch. 
Emerald Sound - Ash didn't like it & not much liked by others. I don't like rye, so not a fair judge
Ginger Ante - good. You must like ginger & spice
Batsman - eh ok.

We had two waiter changes & one was un-announced.  One left us while we were deciding v/s helping us. Expected better service.
author: Nilofer M.

description:
This review is for Dosa on Fillmore.

Dosa on Fillmore is in a neoclassical bank building--return of the Raj?  It's grand.  But it's also extremely noisy.  The crowd at the bar appeared well groomed and self consciously slender--or were they just starving due to the 40 minute wait even after having made reservations.  

The hostesses were all smiles about it, but my friends and I had to keep moving out of the way for the busboys and, of course, we had to shout to get drinks--which were pricey even by Fillmore standards.  

Food was generally okay, but that's because the appetizers raise the average.  I recommend sticking to the small, pretty and tasty appetizers because the main courses are only so so.  The breads seemed more for show than flavor.  

In summary I think that characterizes Dosa for me:  more show than flavor.  Nowadays I have to look for more value.
author: Archie G.

description: Decent spot - had a great waitress, super on top of getting us everything in time for our movie, that was terrific.  Food is good, but felt a bit pretentious.  Space is huge and feels a bit soul-less, but I was in-and-out of there, so might need to check in on them again.
author: Justin M.

description: The place is ok.  Most of the food is drenched in lime juice, so If that is not your thing then do not go here.  Service was good.  The main reason for 2 stars is because I did not feel well for 2 days after going here.
author: Julie G.

description: This is the best indian food in San Francisco! The restaurant is good for vegans and meat lovers - all are very welcome. The masala dosa is so good with coconut dip! I crave it all the time. They have a very interesting menu, organic salads, few kinds of seafood, brown rice, perfect for healthy eaters! We also got I think all the desserts from the menu - their dessert chef is very talented! The decor is beautiful, people are very nice, full bar... must try!
author: SFlover D.

description:
Tasty food, fast service, semi-reasonable prices.

Awful eating environment. Tables are too close for comfort and fire safety code. Trying to enjoy a romantic anniversary dinner sandwiched douchebags, hipsters, and mail-order bride perverts, is not an experience I'd repeat.
author: David K.

description: Namesake INDIAN, its  seems they don't appreciate indians coming to their restaurant. I tried to arrange a lunch party and called them several times , they take the message but no one calls back. So i went to the restaurant again they take the message but no one calls back. Its been more than a month since i've been trying to contact them. The reason iam trying so hard is not because  the food is great its only because of the space. The indian restaurant next door has a much better quality and and taste then dosa.
author: Jada S.

description:
Too much hype = bad service.

Although the food is still good, I'm updating my review based off the service. The bartender is a B#$%^& and the wait (even though we had a reservation) was 30 minutes. Took over 15 minutes once seated to be acknowledged and our waiter was a snotty-wannabe-hipster having a bad day!

Go on a slow night if you must!
author: Jen L.

description: Dosa was my first dose of Indian food--pun intended ;-) and I really enjoyed my first taste.  My friends informed me that Dosa is a very modern twist on the traditional dining experience. Nonetheless, I loved everything that I tried at Dosa was quite tasty. I especially liked the masala mini-dosa dishes that we all shared. That is another aspect that I loved about the restaurant and Indian menus in general, that it is all about sharing your meal with your great company.  All and all Dosa was great and a fun place to take friends from out of town or just for a date night meal. Whichever side of the spectrum that you are on for your night at Dosa, you will not be disappointed.
author: Nichole P.

description: Not just one of the best Indian dinners that I have enjoyed but one of the best dinners I have enjoyed in a long time. Fantastic food, lively atmosphere with excellent service. I can not wait to go again.
author: Mark A.

description:
Really 4 stars? Hmm, either I just went there on a really off night, or this ethnic restau is suffering from the "PF Chang's Effect".  Which is... trendy/appeasing ambiance and mediocre food then touted by patrons as "the best or awesome". 

The cocktails were pretty good, I had the Lesson Park and was reminded of the rattlesnake at Beretta. If you're in the mood for a bold cocktail, this is the way to go. Unfortunately, the food was unremarkable, we sampled six or seven dishes. Two of which that were quite good: the chicken appetizer with yogurt sauce and the banana cream pie. The Spicy Sweet Scallops were overcooked, but did have good flavor. Everything else, I feel I could have gotten from a "mom and pop" Indian Restaurant. 

Where Dosa really falls apart is service. They (Dosa) set an expectation eg. assumption of great service and wait staff based upon ambiance, decor, staff size, reputation, etc. So... when you walk in and your reservation was scheduled at 7:35 and you don't get seated until 8:10, they don't live up to the hype they've established. This hype is further degraded while you're standing at the bar and every member of our party (there were four of us) gets run into by wait staff and subsequently have drinks spilled and only 50% of the time are apologized to. Finally, you get seated... order... then a food runner brings you food that you didn't order, adding insult to injury, our waitress not only informs us that we didn't order it (we knew this), she also mentions that the dish isn't what it's supposed to be and that it's incomplete. What if we did order it? I seriously doubt she would have let us know.  Then a couple of fundamental serving errors like, if you're serving a 12oz beer in a glass that's larger than 12oz, show me the bottle and pour THE ENTIRE BEER IN THE GLASS, or hand me the bottle. Don't leave me with 1/5 of the beer in the bottle, which means you don't get the standard half inch of foam or head out of your beer, and you lose table space. Lastly, DON'T SPILL WATER ALL OVER THE DAMN TABLE. That's nice that you're helping us pour water, only you just spilled on someone's phone... and after your "oh, sorry", show absolutely no sense of urgency to wipe up the mess. 

Bottom line, if you want Indian that'll knock you on your ass. Head to Spicy Bite save some money on dinner and use the rest on drinks at Beretta or ice cream at Bi-Rite.
author: Douglas L.

description: Drove all the way from East bay to SF to eat here. In a nutshell, it was worth it!
author: M D.

description:
Great place to have some south Indian food and intriguing cocktails.  
We started with Dahi Vada, a sort of big lentil burger (more than a dumpling as indicated in the menu description) topped with yoghurt, piped with tamarind & mint, mildly spiced: a delight both for the eye and the palate. A "classic" Masala Dosa with spiced potatoes and a Chef's selection of five different mini-Uttapams followed.  In particular the second offers a good overview of the Uttapam "concept" and I highly recommend it to novices. The accompanying tomato based chutney and the spicy sambar, a flavorful lentil dipping soup made with vegetables (carrots, zucchini, etc.) are absolutely fabulous. The coconut-based chutney, on the other hand, tastes kind of weird, at least for me, but is somehow interesting. Lightly-fried warm milk-dough balls soaked in cardamom syrup as dessert concluded  with dignity our experience. 
If you are undecided about which cocktail to choose,  the lime-biased Bolliwood Hills is my recommendation.
author: Andrea L.

description: Kevin is a superstar!  Give this man a raise!  I am very pleased to report that Dosa is equally as awesome as it's employee.  My husband and I went to Dosa on Sat night.  We were overwhelmed with the menu, mostly because we wanted to order one of everything.  We sat at the bar and Kevin guided us through and made it such a nice experience.  Thank you Dosa!  I will definitely come back!
author: Kattya B.

description: We had a wonderful experience last night at Dosa. Tasty food indeed (day boat scallops, spicy chile prawns, a chicken curry) with one slight misfire -- a vegetable curry heavy on potatoes rather than actual vegetables.  The music was initially loud, but we asked our angelic waitperson to turn it down and he did.  What sets this restaurant apart from other South Indian / Indian places we've tried is the emphasis on lively flavor, very fresh high-quality ingredients (including yummy coconut rice) and SUPERB service.  Our server, whose name I write in capitals, MICHAEL SMITH, was witty, gentle, solicitous without being cloying -- and since my fiancee has some food intolerances, he was more than helpful in guiding us through the menu to make tasty choices with no eye-rolling.  We would go again without hesitation, and hope that Michael was on that night. The food is not cheap, but first-rate ingredients are never cheap . . . and multi-layered cooking, full of flavor, is not to be found at the local eatery.
author: Michael S.

description:
Great and tasty food.  Nice ambiance, clean and good location!

I will be back soon!
author: Urittnaz J.

description: I work at UCSF Mount Zion location and my office of 4 women orders a bunch of food to-go for lunch on a monthly basis.  Today, my roommate and I went here for lunch to help her knock off the paper masala dosa from her 7x7 list.  We walked in around noon on a friday and it was pretty empty.  The restaurant is very spacious and beautiful inside.  We ordered the south indian mung salad, the south indian bhel puri, paper masala dosa and green mango & panner uttapam.  The food took a very long time to come out, which was surprising since there weren't that many guests, but when it did arrive, I forgot all about the wait.  I love love love their food.  The mung salad was very refreshing and tasty, the indian bhel puri gave me new flavor explosions in my mouth with each bite, and of course, the paper masala dosa with the sauces and soup is always delicious and very 7x7 worthy, in my opinion.  The ONLY reason why I can't give this place a 5 star rating is because of the service.  Even though our waiter was very attentive and lovely, the food did take a while to come out.  Our uttapam never arrived, (which I was thankful for in the end because I was so full), but the waiter kindly removed it from our bill.  This place is a must-go!
author: Sarah C.

description:
Absolutely brilliant. The south indian dosas are very authentic. The improvised dosas like habenero-mango masala dosa is superb. 

Fusion drinks such as laughing lassi was excellent.
author: Chet M.

description: I am always impressed with a restaurant that manages to serve spicy food while preserving the complexity and delicate balance of flavors in their dishes. In addition to a great menu, Dosa is also my favorite place for cocktails now. The skilled bartenders are great at combining exotic flavors and spices into drinks like you've never had before. I even started to kind of look forward to the long wait because (if you're not famished) it is an excuse to hang at the bar and have 1 or 2 (or 3) delicious cocktails. The only note of caution is that you should plan your time accordingly even if you have a reservation because after 7:30 pm there always seems to be at least a 20 minute wait.
author: Jeni K.

description: The reason for the 2 stars is due to the fact that my food was contaminated! When I go out to dinner, I do not expect to find plastic in my dish! I also do not expect the GM to bluntly brush that off, by telling that it's a garlic peel! Furthermore garlic peel is not 3 inches long, and may I also add that no restaurant pays a prep cook 10$ an hour to peel garlic! The server was also an A-hole! Instead of apologizing she made it seem like it was my fault that my dish was contaminated, ridiculous! The setting was OK nothing spectacular, and the food was So So I've had better. Customer service is horrendous. I would not recommend that place.
author: Elizabete Maria T.

description:
I love the setup and the décor!

 the food is not the best Indian I'd had... 

Love the full bar... 

hate how expensive it is... 

It is the kind of place you might want to take a date to OR you might want to take your white in-laws who are scared of anything third worldish to-- it is a good place to break them in!
author: Maddy S.

description:
I visited this place based upon a recommendation from a friend who has lived in San Francisco for a few years and is a pretty picky vegetarian.  I went for lunch and was really impressed straight away with the atmosphere of the restaurant.  It could easily serve for a nice evening out, but still retains enough laid-back ambiance that I didn't feel out of place with casual attire.

I had never tried dosa before, and the server was really helpful in sort of explaining how it's made and how it is to be properly eaten.  

Based upon her explanation, I wasn't really that excited, but was definitely curious.  And then it arrived... I ordered the Chile & Cilantro Uttapam (pronounced Ootapahm), which was accompanied by three different sauces.  The uttapam is slightly thicker than dosa, so it's almost like a savory pancake.  It was so delicious and so filling!!   The thing that I really liked about it was the fact that it was flavorful on its own, but also came with three different sauces, all of which were completely different but worked so well with the uttapam.   So there are a ton of different taste options available to you with just one entree.

The service was great, and the food is unbelievable.  I could see Friday and Saturday evenings requiring a reservation to play it safe, but otherwise it's not bad at all.  Even if you find yourself waiting on line, stick around.  You'll be glad you did.

I would recommend this place HIGHLY to anyone curious about South Indian food.  

You should check it out... I can't wait to go back.
author: jeremy c.

description: Great place!  It gets 3 dollar signs, but really isn't that expensive for brunch.  The dosas are really good, and the coconut curry is actually the best I've ever had.  Very beautiful inside, I will be coming back.
author: Phil J.

description: Spring Masala Dosa is freaking amazing. It's veggie & it's my favorite here! Dip it in the fresh coconut & tomato chutneys, and you're all set. My brother and I had the coconut sorbet for dessert and it is just as amazing. Might I add that it's right across the street from where I live. Sigh, I'm never going to save money at this rate.
author: Angellica Y.

description:
I love Dosa.
The food, drinks and service are always top notch.
Sometimes the wait can be long but it is always well worth the wait.
I've been to the one on Valencia many times and the Fillmore location only once but I'm looking forward to going again soon. 
The ambiance is so perfect at both locations. 
Definitely one of my favorite SF restaurants.
author: Jason A.

description: A hot spot with a great vibe for 3-4 star, extremely overpriced Indian Food.
author: Pug P.

description: I personally think this restaurant serves the best (Northern or Southern) Indian food in the bay area ... and I live in Fremont!
author: Latimer L.

description: Wow!  My husband and I eat Indian food frequently where we live, but never have we had such delicious food.  (I think about Dosa often).  We were visiting San Francisco (elopement/honeymoon) and this was the restaurant we went to on our first night.  We were looking for a romantic ambiance, great wine selection, and delicious food and got exactly that at Dosa.  I am officially in love!!!  p.s. Try to Dosa Paneer & Peas.... to die for!!!!
author: World T.

description:
Had a dosa + fish moilee. Fish was really really good - but it better be at $25 for a tiny portion of fish curry. Dosa was better than average, crispy on the outside but preparation was a little sub-ideal.

So good; but portions are small, it's expensive and the Dosa's are good but not great.
author: Jay T.

description:
Wow this place is seriously good.  Starting with the cocktails (I got the Bowler, unexpectedly spicy.  I loved it) and through the appetizers and main courses, every single thing I got was a winner.  Then it was time for dessert.  Jeffrey Steingarten, in one of his hilarious books, compares the flavor of Indian desserts to face cream.  I must say, the sweet cheese that I got was 100% Oil of Olay.  

But everything else was really spot on.  I'll definetely return.  I liked this DOSA even better than the one on Valencia.
author: Jocelyn K.

description:
The atmosphere is warm and inviting. (Note: Review is for brunch) Food is fresh (thank you for my Strauss yogurt)...Dosas are tasty. Although you pay a slight greater amount to say Udupi Palace - you are paying for a slight higher quality in ingredients as well as atmosphere. I liked how everything was generally spaced out and didn't have your typical SF crowded establishment, although this may not be as economical. Our server was friendly and food came out rather timely. I wasn't a big fan of my peas & paneer dosa, but I felt it was more of the fault of mine vs. theirs. The skin of the dosa was perfectly crispy and flavorful. Note: The mango lassi is super thick and very filling. 

I'll be back....
author: Jeannette L.

description: Very nice decor... great wine.. great crowd. The waiters are very helpful when it comes to explaing the food and helping you decide what would be best for you. I went with a group of co-workers and we decided to order different things are share them.  All the food was very tastey. Making a reservation is best so you dont have to wait very long.
author: Sukie H.

description:
Love, love, love this restaurant.  The decor is beautiful (unlike most Indian restaurants), the service always good, and the food fantastic.  I've never had anything that wasn't above average, and I've been at least 10 times.  Always start with a Ginger Ante to drink, yummy!  We've introduced Dosa to numerous friends - both locals and from out of town.  

I highly recommend this place!
author: Kat W.

description: meh.  yeah, it's good, but definitely not amazing.  My wife argues that Dosa on Valencia is much better (which, being the original, I can believe) - but I really get the feeling that eating here is like paying $25 for an American hot dog in India - you picking up what I'm putting down?
author: Lane K.

description:
4 stars.

wow, what a beautiful place-- make sure to come for dinner because the lighting alone does wonders for the decor. there is a reception area right through the middle of the bar/dining area and the lower dining area (one seating option are retro chic high back banquettes). darker woods and iron wrought stair railings. huge capiz shell cascading chandelier above the entrance, shimmering a pearly iridescence. vibrant photos and accent walls, fresh flower bouquets and bustling staff.  equally colorful hot plates as they're being dispatched to the drooling masses. scents that trail and linger, blooming into the air in phases, elusive. all this, with a soundtrack consisting of a mixture of dub, acid jazz, indian classical-- aka the lounge aesthetic. dosa feels like i stepped into another ecosystem.

i admit that most of my indian dining experiences are mostly dishes from the north, so i found myself looking for my favorite dishes-- curious about the other selections, i tossed the idea of clinging dearly to the familiar and ordered the following:

- drinks: mango lassi (thicker than what i'm used to), "juhu palm" (spice route specialty drink), gin&tonic
- food: samosas (1 from the north and 1 from the south), spinach fennel dosa with sambar, peppercorn chicken with coconut rice, and prawn masala with lemon rice

i went a little tame ordering because one of my friends is a fickle, terribly picky eater. blah. anyways, the food was unexpectedly mild for what i'm used to. not really good or bad, but significantly different from other indian dining experiences. it seemed a bit too... "corrected"? *shrugs* my favorite was the prawn masala with lemon rice and the spinach fennel dosa. beautiful food presentation and lightning-quick service. amiable, helpful servers.

i'd definitely be back for the yummy drinks, shared plates, and the great energy and atmosphere. a great addition to the city! also, per anjan-- they validate at the fillmore garage!
author: Vanessa D.

description:
We had reservations for 8pm and of course they told us that it would be a few minutes.  A few turned into 10 then to 20.  Luckily the manager was very apologetic and offered to get us 2 appetizers on the house.  Once we got to our table, we were greeted by the most fabulous waiter ever!  His personality was stellar and just put us all in a delightful mood to set the evening.  I ordered the lamb chops which themselves were tasty, but I felt that the sauce was too spicy.  My friends got the duck which I was lucky enough to sample and I thought that was much milder in flavor, but absolutely deeeeelish.  On a side note, we waited an extremely long time between courses.  It was bad enough that we waited a long time for our table, now the overall service was moving at a glacial speed.  Unfortunately after our main course, our fabulous waiter had ended his shift and passed the baton onto the most brash, abrasive, non-friendly waitress we have ever had.  She literally threw the dessert menus onto our table and didn't even make any suggestions.  Once we ordered dessert it took forever!!!  We ordered the passion fruit custart which most likely had been sitting on the pass-through for longer than necessary because the texture was completely foreign.  Finally, I practically had to jump up and down to get her to notice that we were ready to pay.  Ugh, we were all disappointed because our fabulous waiter had left us with this awful lady.  Oh well.  

I am not a huge Indian food fan, but I did enjoy the meal here with the exception of the horrific service.  I can't say I'd go back unless someone invited me for a party or something.
author: Karen C.

description: I went here for after movie snacks and drinks with my wife and some friends.  The bar area is swank (never know it used to be Goodwill), but the service is down to earth.  I had fire water soup.  If you like spice, this is the soup for you.  Check out the cocktail menu--lot's of unique gin drinks.  Perfect spot before or after a movie at Kabuki.
author: Jason S.

description: Though the atmosphere is very hip and beautiful, the food and the prices are  NOT.... Long story short, the drinks are outrageously priced, but even more expensive is the food.  We had 2 drinks, an appetizer and 2 dishes and the bill was over $100.  Did I mention that I left hungry as well?!?  Basically, if you are both rich and on a diet, then Dosa is for you.  If not, I highly recommend going somewhere else.
author: K. N.

description:
The new addition to the neighborhood is more upscale than Dosa #1 by far... but it was nice to see they kept the prices pretty comparable. 

We did have to wait 30 mins to get seated even though we had a reservation- but they comped us desert which makes me think they are trying...

I'll go back when I want a nice night on the town... otherwise I might stick to the more low-key Mission version for a regular dinner spot.
author: erica g.

description: This place was amazing! Their dishes can be pretty pricey, but their food shows customers their money's worth! All their dishes are vegetarian and delicious. Make sure to make an appointment because it can be crowded a lot of the times.
author: Chau T.

description: I loved the 4 course meal - smaller portions of appetizer, dosa, a curry and dessert. Eat a little bit of everything is my favorite eating method.  I would pick chennai chicken, mung bean dosa, sauce from the prawn masala but lamb from the lamb curry and pistachio kefir if I were to do it all over again.
author: Wakako U.

description:
What you pay for:  really beautiful interior, cleaniness, good service.
What the money isn't going towards:  the food served (especially if it's sea food)

The menu has a lot of food items, so just wanted to state that I'm basing this review on my one and only visit to Dosa.  Also, did want to give props to Dosa for having a Pre-fixe menu.   My husband and I ordered and shared the following:
*  Prawn Chili Fry:  The spice was really good.  Unfortunately, the prawn was seriously overcooked so that it tasted like spicy rubber.
*  Vada Pav (Vegetarian Sliders):   First off, it's ONE slider.  So they should really remove the "s".  However, it's the BEST thing that we had.  The patty was a perfect blend of spices, potatoes, chick peas, lentils and onions and the bun was soft and a perfect compliment to the slider.  If this was all I got, I'd be sold.  Unfortunately, I ate a whole dinner.
*  Tamil Vegetable Curry:  The sauce was SUPER heavy but overall the dish was good.  This is a good dish if you want leave feeling like you have a brick in your stomach (but a tasty brick).
*  Coconut Ginger Fish:  As opposed to our experience with the prawns, the fish was WAY undercooked and had absolutely NO flavor.  Thank goodness there was a sauce that was served with it because otherwise, it would have been wet, flavorless, undercooked fish with "coconut rice" that tasted like rice with parsley in it.  This was SO not worth the $29 charged.  
*  Paneer and Peas Dosa:  The filling was really good.  However, the crepe was more like, well, a crepe.  It was a thin pancake (not crispy at all) with filling.  What do they call that?  Oh yeah, a crepe.  It's served with a coconut, tomato and sambar sauce.  The Coconut and Tomato sauce was quite good.  The Sambar was burned, to the point where I could smell the burnt-ness when spooning it to my plate.  Yikes!  For your namesake dish, it should be more authentic.  

Because my husband commented that the Sambar was burnt, we got a free dessert:  Passion Fruit Custard with tapioca.  It was the second best thing we had all night.  So if you go there, my recommendations would be to order about 3 Vada Pav's and the Passion Fruit custard, and you'll have a good dining experience.  Anything else we experienced was meh at best, and MEH for the prices they charge.  

If you want really good Indian food at a cheap price, Vics Chaat Cafe in Emeryville fits the bill.
author: Ria D.

description: Went to Dosa a couple weeks ago. Love the decor!! Beautiful chandeliers and the artwork is gorgeous. Bit of a wait for a table but otherwise the food was great! the drinks even better!! Will return again!
author: Kristi G.

description:
This is what I get for trusting my cell phone for restaurant advice. Sure the place is gorgeous but the whole vibe is entirely too pretentious in a "we're completely oblivious to the irony of white people and house music serving food from a region previously ravaged by colonialism" sort of way. Honestly, they play up the orientalist vision of exotic India without having any real grasp of authenticity.

I stopped in, craving some alu paratha, and being a tourist i thought it was a stroke of luck to have a place just around the corner from my hotel. Aside from being ignored for the first 10 minutes by the staff (I'll give them the benefit of the doubt  and say it was because I was alone and not because I was the sole non-white patron in the whole restaurant) I was initially excited and intrigued if a bit annoyed by the decor.  The waitress sat me on a bench crowded by couples and abandoned me for another ten minutes. Over the course of the meal i ordered a divya cocktail, duck vindaloo, coconut basmati rice, and two orders of paratha. When i asked what sort of paratha they make (hoping for my tasty alu) the waitress looked at me like i was rude and repeated the menu description of a basic WHEAT. When my food came and i began to eat it (correctly) one handed by picking hunks of duck, rice, and sopping up curry with my bread, the patrons around me as well as the staff looked at me like a heathen. 

Was the food good? Meh. I've had way better for a lot less pretention. If you're looking for some place uptight to impress someone, dosa is for you. As for me, I'll never eat at another restaurant where the clientele and staff is so...um...unvaried.
author: Keala R.

description: I love South Indian!  Dosa on Fillmore is my favorite place for dosa.  The location in the Mission is great too, but I like the design/layout of this one better.  It's definitely a lot bigger.  The waitstaff is extremely helpful in identifying which items are vegan (or can be made vegan).  The have a large selection of vegan options.  My favorite is the Mysore Masala Dosa.  Perfectly seasoned and the dosa just melts in your mouth.  If they were 100% veg, I would give them 5 stars.
author: Dana P.

description:
I really had high hopes for this place with all these great reviews.  At the end, the experience was disappointing.  I ordered curry lamb, the waitress recommended I get the lemon rice with it.  My husband ordered the duck and also got the lemon rice because it was recommended.  I guess it's our own fault for not reading the menu more carefully, the lemon rice was $3 extra each.  The lamb was tender, but the sauce was too thick.  The duck had bones in it, with all the thick sauce around it, it was very hard to eat.  The favor was just ok.  They are not worth the money.

Don't order a martini.  It's the worst I have ever had.
author: Mary D.

description:
After all my friends and colleagues recommended me DOSA I finally went to DOSA at Fillmore. I was in the city at around 10:30PM and DOSA at this location is the one that was open until 12:00AM during the weekends which the first thing that I liked about DOSA. Not a lot of restaurants are open until this late.

Once I entered DOSA I loved the ambience of the restaurant. the look with dimmed lights gave a very trendy yet very cozy look to the place. Coming to the food we ordered Rava Dosa, Roasted Chile & Garlic Masala Dosa, Nilgiri Chicken korma and Golden Trout Baked w/ Cilantro-Chile Chutney. With all 4 dishes we have ordered the presentation gets very high point to start with and the taste gets much higher points. All the 4 dishes were simply superb and especially the trout, is to die for.

Once we were done with the main course we wanted to try some deserts and we ordered Rasmalai. I was so surprised on how tasty it was. I have eaten Rasmalai a zillion times in India and in US and never tasted one as I tasted in Dosa. It was soo fresh and tasty and just melts in my mouth. 

Hands down the best Indian restaurant that I visited in United States. So I would definitely recommend this restaurant to everyone.
author: Raja D.

description: Arguably the best indian restaurant in SF and additionally one of the few indian restaurants in SF that offer excellent south indian food.  As the name suggests the best of their food picks are in the dosa variety. They have numerous offering most of which taste authentic. The side chutney's and sambar which are critical for any dosa eating experience are well made and compliment the food. They have both south and north indian cuisine but i recommend sticking to the south indian for the best food. Additionally it is a excellent sit down restaurant and good ambiance and decor if you are interested in those. Its pricier than most indian restaurants and one would probably require at least a couple of dishes to have a hearty meal.
author: Arvind V.

description:
This place looks nice but the food is just mediocre. Our waitress was kinda of condescending to my boyfriend. Maybe I'm not used to eating southern indian food but it jsut tasted blah. we orderd the jumbo prawn masala with cocount rice. the rice is so cocunutty i thought it would be just a hint of it. it comes in a heaping bowl too big for a person to eat! also got the masala dosa. I really like that sauce that comes with it but i wouldn't get this dish again and also the lamb curry was lacking so much flavor. I guess that's what you get from such a commecial looking place.

I don't understand the service of this place either. my bf brought me a birthday cake to the restaurant and it takes them forever to bring it out then when she finally comes out with it theres no forks or plates and then she asks if I want it cut. Well duh...at least she put a candle on my cake.
author: Crum B.

description:
mmmm, mmmmm delicious!   I was watching an episode of "Globe Trekker, food edition" and they were featuring southern indian cuisine.  I was so impressed by all of the preparation and detail that goes into each dish, I couldn't wait to go down to Dosa and check it out!   
I sat at the bar and was greeted promptly.  I had no idea what to order so my friend and I just sat back and let the bartenders decide for us.  Everything from the drinks, to the wine, to the food,  was perfect.  
The drinks take a while to make because they are hand crafted specialty cocktails, but once it hits your lips......so worth the wait!
I couldn't believe how fast the food came out- order extra raita  if you are sensitive to spice ;)
We got just amazing service!  The bartenders were friendly and entertaining; the somm was unpretentious and spot on; the hostess smiling; and the runners informative and polite.  
Did I mention that they are open 'til midnight on the weekends?
The only problem I have is that I am now addicted to dosas!!!!!!
I get cravings for them and have to stop by and pick one up after work!! 
Coolest thing about dosa: There is an actual brown person bartending!  It is so nice to see that they are not all doctors and accountants these days.  ( little poke for the newest busser in training, Vineet)
Yum-Yum, go to Dosa now! And bring your appetite!
author: Juju C.

description:
Had never experienced southern Indian food until finding this place...it is unbelievable.  No need to say anything else than try it...you will leave more than satisfied for less money than you would expect.  I'm sure they are cheaper restaurants comparable but you obviously have to help them pay the real estate and decor costs.  

We love the Paneer and Peas Dosa, the Bhatura, the Pepper Chicken, the Samosas, and just about anything we've ordered.  If overwhelmed by the menu just ask the friendly staff and they are great at recommendations.
author: Willy C.

description: SOOOO NOT LAME!!!! That potato pizza calzone (sorry cant remember what it's called, but you'll see) It's freaking awesome. And the best part is you eat with your hands!!! :D
author: Mar C.

description: Expensive considering how cheap the ingredients are, but it's a beautiful space and the food is very tasty. We had the dahi vada, and the yoghurt mint sauce really hit the spot on a hot day. The cilantro masala dosa was light and crispy. They make a great cup of chai, very soothing. Will definitely go back if I'm in the area and want something other than sushi.
author: Sam Z.

description: There are large differences between this location and the original location on Valencia.  This location has a full bar also it's spacious which almost gives it a clubby feel.  Overall I thought the dishes were quite good except the dosa which to me was a big shock.   How can you brand yourself after a dish yet do not make it well?
author: Jay A.

description: Oh Dosa:)  How you saved the day.  My honey and I went there after I had a really rough week.  I went in there as surly as a hungry pit bull.  We sat in Leo's section and he took such amazing care of us, helped us order, helped me discover a new favorite beer, and completely turned around what was fixin' to be a terrible weekend.   I will request to sit in his section every time I go. The food was fantastic.  We had the green curry fish, a peas and paneer dosa and an appetizer that I can't even remember except for the smile on my face!  LOVE!
author: barbara m.

description: Had a very nice lunch but would NOT recommend the chennai chicken which many people here did. It's like fried buffalo wings or fried spicy tenders-not great unless that's what you're into. The not fried Dosa which you stuff was amazing and the vegetable curry a winner too.
author: Debbie D.

description: We were visiting San Francisco for a few days and wanted to try something different.  This place was recommended to us by a tour guide because it was near a show we were going to.  We were very pleasantly surprised.  The decor was gorgeous; very modern with interesting artwork and a beautiful bar.  The service we received was exceptional.  I've only eaten Indian food a couple of times so I'm not an afficianado but I took a chance on several things and everything was fabulous.  I especially liked the dosa course.  I would definitely go again1
author: Dianne C.

description: I really like their drinks- and such a great location. Perfect for a slight buzz before a movie.
author: Anna B.

description:
I was torn between a 2 and a 3 for Dosa.  It's not bad and some things are good, but overall I think it's overrated and overpriced.

Some items, desserts, dosas, veggie curry are delicious and reasonably priced.  Others .....are not....like many of the appetizers.  We ordered fish that was $30.  It was so bland - there was nothing special about it and the sides were equally as plain. I don't know if they think wrapping it in a banana leaf justifies that price!

My biggest complaint with this place is that I ordered a drink, at the bar, from the bartender (it was not busy) and asked him to use Makers Mark instead of Jameson's.  He told me they don't really do substitutions and not on that drink.  WTF?!?!??!  This is a real bar, right?  You are a real bartender, right?  I couldn't believe it.  I understand an upcharge for a liquor substitution and I'm happy to pay for it, but telling me I can't substitute a liquor?  What is this....pre-made punch at TGIFriday's?  

The place is also a bit pretentious.  Service is good "enough" and they are nice "enough" but not to warrant the prices.

I've been to the one in The Mission once and it is less pretentious, but the service wasn't very attentive.  We weren't in a hurry but we had to ask for everything.
author: McKenzie M.

description:
Beautiful decor, much more spacious than the sister Mission location, yummy and creative food.  

Downside was that they sat 4 of us at a bar sized table crammed in a corner even though we had a reservation -- since we wanted to share food, there wasn't enough room on the table for all of the plates (the waitress ended up setting our wine glasses on the windowsill ledge!).  No sign on the front door also made it a tiny tricky to find.

Definitely more of a 'scene' than the Mission restaurant and seems to have lost some of the personal charm.  But great food!
author: Tamra K.

description: Kinda like Buddha Bar goes to Southern India.  An entirely new twist on Indian food for me.  I make it a point to eat here whenever I am in the City.  The staff was really helpful in pairing the appropriate wines with the dishes.  The flavors are less "hot" than the more common Northern recipes, they are every bit as flavorful and leave one completely satisfied.
author: William H.

description: The cocktails and the food are fantastic!  I usually get the Charlie Chaplin with the Spicy Mung Dosa.
author: Kristine E.

description:
I really enjoyed the food here, but unfortunately have to give them only 2 stars b/c of the service.  I will give a disclaimer that we went within a week of it opening, but still...the service was embarrassing.  11 out of 12 of us got the tasting menu, one girl got a solo dish.  They didn't bring her the right dish that she ordered.  The tasting menu thing was  a disaster.  After we picked what we wanted, the waiters brought out our first course, and put them all in the wrong spots.  So the waiters kinda revealed our "seat numbers" to fix the situation.  Well, the next course was brought out by some different waiters, who then counted us with different seat numbers, and still put the food down in front of the wrong people.  Finally that last one came, and it was just a joke by that point.  Of course they got it wrong again.  I am really surprised at how many different ways there were to give us seat numbers, and still biff it, but hey they managed.  The service was a total disaster.  The only thing that made it less of a disaster was the food was good, and the wine paired well.  The drinks are also fun, with theme names "Bengali Gimlet," etc. 

I've heard the have since gotten their act together, but alas I'm not regularly in SF anymore.  The food was delish though.  Yummy!
author: Nikki C.

description: I am very sad when I pay $12 for lunch and I leave looking for someplace to eat. I was unimpressed with the mango, goat cheese salad. The service was good and the place is comfortable, but the menu options could be a more satisfying.
author: Colleen B.

description: No complaints.  We had the same server both times for brunch and she was great.  Love the curry inspired bloody mary.  The red beet and cumin soup with crème fraîche was delish.   Although it didnt look it, the tomato, onion and chile uttapam, served with two over-easy eggs was quite filling.  Loved the chicken biryani.  The mango lassi is like a dessert, but we saved room for dessert, too--sweet cheese in a sweet coconut syrup.  Yum!
author: brewgirl b.

description:
We had dinner here and it was off the hook!
The restaurant is really big and the decor is awesome...the chandeliers are Chihuli-esque and there is a big Shiva statue in the center. Me and my three ladies got a table by the window. The seats were so comfortable (huge for me). The menu is very overwhelming but the waitress was very helpful and attentive, really great service overall. 
And now for the best part...the food...it's different than the Indian food we are used to eating. My friend traveled around south east asia so she told us a lot about the food and that was cool.
The presentation was spectacular and made us ooooh and aaahhhh...one of the breads was big and puffy, one was so long it took up the whole table..it was just this extravaganza of sights and flavors
They all got different cocktails which I of course tasted and didn't like any of them. I got a mango lassi and it was epicly delicious.
Then came the calamari appetizer...it was SO good! The spicyish sauce it came in was delish....
author: Dana C.

description:
Idli obsession

Dosa has wonderful idli sambar on the appetizer menu.  I love idli, those spongy, white, slightly sour, steamed cakes made from fermented rice and dehusked lentil batter immersed in perfectly spicy sambar (veggie soup) and slathered with Dosa's awesome coconut and tomato chutney, also perfectly spiced.  It's the ultimate comfort food and only $7.00 which makes it a good light lunch. Even though Udupi Palace in the Mission has cheaper idli sambar, I prefer Dosa's for the more complex and deft spicing which gives more heat and assertiveness to their food without over powering the ingredients. You can sit back and enjoy the lingering impression of heat  in the mouth.

I also love the rather larger than expected serving of Tamilian veggie curry with two dish-sized, flaky, buttery parathas. Expect alot of heat, but in a clean and good way. Coconut milk, normally a very dominating note, is here nicely merged with other ingredients to leave the mouth feeling stimulated afterward instead of dull and coated as can sometimes occur with ingesting spicy, rich foods.  A mango lassi or a darjeeling iced tea is good for helping with the spice.

Have not tried any of the larger entrees or cocktails yet but am eager to soon.
author: Tara W.

description:
# Babes: 6

This is a great restaurant for indian food. Is it southern indian? I'm not sure.

I'll let other's comment on the atmosphere - the flavor of the food is what will bring me back.
author: Joe P.

description:
When they first opened I tried and tried to get in here without reservations and was unsuccessful.  I recently wandered in with a friend on a Thursday night and was finally able to try it out.

The decor on the inside is simply stunning.  Beautiful light fixtures and a chic yet not stuffy vibe.  Service was impeccable.  We were seated right next to the kitchen so it was pretty hard to miss us but I felt that our server was extremely knowledgeable about both food and wine and I ended up taking all of her suggestions regarding menu options (which were all great).

Even on a Thursday the place was jam packed with people at every table and a full bar.

We tried:

Chennai Chicken starter
Spinach and Fennel Pooriyal Dosas
Manglorean Prawn Masala. 

Paired with a glass of Malbec which was surprisingly tasty

All were delicious, but the dosas were exceptional, hence the name.   I am looking forward to many future visits!
author: Brenna C.

description: The best dosas I've had in a restaurant in US. We tried egg dosa, masala dosa, onion rava and rava masala dosa. All of them were excellent. The potato masala was done well & cocunut chutney and sambhar were also good. But I still miss mom made dosas!
author: Govind R.

description: I thoroughly enjoyed Dosa. I'm no expert on Indian food but I quite enjoyed both the appetizers (can't remember what we got) and my main course of masala dosa. Reasonable wine selection. Beautiful restaurant. Fun environment. Great walking distance from downtown (about one mile). Block away from The Fillmore. Highly recommend.
author: Buck J.

description: Very cool location.  Airy and such high ceilings!  Fun place to grab some drinks at the bar. As for the food, it's pretty good but pricey. So, for a nicer indian dinner, this would be a good spot.
author: Ka C.

description: It could only get better. I love eating at the bar.  The wine selection is so spectacular.  And that soup...pepper, yummy don't want it to end, yeah, that's what its called.  Can't wait to go back again.
author: Angela N.

description:
This place has an amazing atmosphere, the food blew me away! In fact it was so good, I had to return for a quick lunch before I left town, after having it the night before for dinner.

I recommend any of the dhosas, and if you want it to be spicy ask the wait staff for the chef to crank it up, I assure you he/she does deliver. I noticed a lot of the other diners ordered the lassi, but I never actually tried some but I think giving it a whirl won't be a bad idea, it is a very popular drink.

The chicken frankie was delightful, bit oily, but eh, you're out to eat, indulge your self a little. The spicy garlic dosa was what my girlfriend order, and we almost got into tiff cause I couldn't stop myself from having some of her food. It was on point, I wish they had given more sambar (warm sauce they give with the dosa) though.

Overall scout report - If you love South Indian food, you have to try this place when in San Francisco.
author: J P.

description: Oops, I accidentally slipped up on my "Dosa Strike."  ...Well they have added 1 more shrimp to the dish so I am adding one more star.  Tit for Tat Dosa, Tit for Tat.
author: Lynn S.

description: Not great, not bad.  My date and I ordered a spring vegetable dosa, which was nice and refreshing, given that it wasn't heavy, like so much Indian vegetarian food is.  However, our waiter was kind of rude, which detracted from the overall experience.  I want to go back, to try some more things on the menu, but will probably go to the one on Valencia, to try and avoid rude staff.
author: Adam T.

description: Yummy yummy South Indian food! It's also the best place for gluten-free. I like to get the paneer dosa and the dahi vada. The fillmore location is larger than the mission location so it's great for groups or a bite to eat before or after a movie at the Kabuki. The wine list is A-mazing-- the staff knows it pretty well too. I've been here many a time and it's hard to hit up a place more than once in SF with all the great restaurants. A definite must try!
author: Keegan M.

description:
Tried out their Dine About Town 2009 lunch menu. Food was okay but service was TERRIBLE! Reservation was at 12:15 and we were seated promptly. My friend and I didn't order until 12:35. Mind you, I had to ask the bus boy to tell him that we were ready to order, as it wasn't his job. 

Here is a breakdown of courses between myself and my friend: 
First course - coconut soup and chopped salad 
Second course - chutney masala dosa and cilantro/coconut fish 
Third course - sweet pongal and coconut sorbet 

The dishes were ok, as I've had better Indian cuisine. The coconut soup was very light but almost watery. The chopped salad was merely something you could do yourself. After the our first course, we waited (and I'm not joking) 40 minutes for our second course. Were they trying to kill the chicken? The wait was absurd! We weren't the only ones who had to wait on our dishes. I noticed that our neighbor kept on asking their waiter about the status of their dish. 

40 minutes later, our last course came, before our second! I snapped and said, "We didn't even receive our second course!" He apologized and quickly came with our second course. The chutney masala dosa was okay. There was an abundance of potato. If you're a vegetarian, then this is the dish for you. I'm a meat eater so I was disappointed with this. However, the chutney was okay. The cilantro and coconut fish was excellent. Yes, the restaurant receives a point for their fish as it was very moist and flaky. 

Our last course came literally 2 minutes after our waiter cleared our second course. I sarcastically said, "Wow, I didn't even have to wait for my dessert!" The rice pudding was okay... something I personally would never order again. The thought of roasted lentils and sweet rice does not make a great pairing. On the other hand, my friend had the coconut sorbet WITH saffron threads. I was surprised with the saffron threads as it is an expensive spice. It tasted interesting along with the sorbet. Our neighbor who also had the sorbet, didn't have saffron threads. We spoke to them and they agreed that service was very lousy. They were foodies so they know their culinary stuff. I told her to get the saffron threads so she could get her monies worth since my friend had saffron threads sprinkled on her sorbet. 

Our bill came and the total for two footed to be $49, without tip. With outstandingly TERRIBLE service, I did not hesitate to leave any tip. $0 tip for lousy service and we just walked out. 

In essence, the restaurant is overrated and you can get awesome Indian food else where. Extremely terrible service. They pay no attention to their customers. Nothing memorable, except for me not leaving a tip. I don't recommend this restaurant at all.
author: Reviewer Z.

description:
Food was excellent - I'd give it 5 stars!  Drinks were pricey... more than the food tab.

The service was a 1 star.  
I made an 8:15pm reservation for 4 people through Open Table.  We weren't seated until 8:50pm. If you're going to take reservations - please honor them.  We weren't even comped a free appetizer!
Our waitress was incredibly rude and absolutely horrible!!  If I ever see her again, I will request that we not be seated in her section.  (In case you're wondering, she's the tall middle aged blond one with a lot of attitude and I do come here a lot).  First, I was there with out of town guests that were clearly foreign and did not speak perfect English.  But, they were understandable.  Every time they asked for anything, she made them repeat their request, then she shouted it back to them, and then rolled her eyes.  2) Took her forever to bring out drinks and dinner.  And, she never bothered to check back on the table.  3) Whenever I asked her for anything (rotti and drinks), she glared back at me and very coldly said "it's coming".  Come on!  If you're going to work at a restaurant, at least pretend like you care!  Don't ruin our dining experience for us! 
Luckily she left at some point between dinner and dessert (of course she didn't bother to tell us that she was ending her shift like most other waiters would have).
Last gripe - the tables are tiny!  We dropped three utensils on the ground... every time I go here, someone at the table loses their utensils.
author: As T.

description:
i appreciated DOSA's romantic and modern decor and although it looks pretty swanky, the atmosphere is chill. 

the server was quite friendly.

however, the food was just too salty for my taste buds. my mouth was screaming for water by the end of the night. nevertheless i still enjoyed the food and my stomach didn't complain at the end of the night. i would like to come back just because i want to try more of their menu. the menu at the fillmore location seems to be more extensive compared to the DOSA on valencia... or is it just me?
author: Mayson J.

description:
my girl friend and i had a "date" here friday night. we arrived early so we decided to grab a drink at the bar. 

i had the Emerald Sound and she had the Bengali Gimlet. my drink was good. reminded me of a mojito but better cuz it's with whiskey. one drink was pretty strong (maybe i'm just a lightweight). 

before we knew it, our table was ready. we were hungry. we had our eye on 4 dishes... 1 starter, 2 dosas, and 1 masala. luckily our waitress told us it was way too much food for the 2 of us girls and she was right!

overall the food was really good... very bold flavors. the only thing that would stop me from going back is that it's a bit on the pricey side. but i think that's due to the fact that i'm unemployed right now. so once i'm fully employed, i'd come back with no hesitation.
author: Mei N.

description:
everyone talks about the beautiful decor of dosa.  i had lofty expectations of the menu as my line of sight climbed, taking in the grandiose height of the space, and terminating at several ornate chandeliers.  the floor to ceiling windows let in the fillmore street glow and passers-by's stares.

sascha and i decided to dine at the communal tables as an alternative to waiting an hour and a half for a private table.  i didn't mind eating at the long, narrow table w/strangers, but i WAS annoyed at the fact that we were seated in close proximity to the bar, subsequently creating a narrow walkway.  our purses that were hung on our chairs frequently jabbed us in our sides, due to the patrons trying to make their way through.  (yeah, i suppose that we could've put them on the floor, but the high bar stool chairs unfortunately promoted inaccessibility.)  **dosa, move your communal table a bit towards the center.  you certainly have plenty of room to do so.

*indigo moon - included bourbon, jackfruit marmalade, bitters, and champagne.  pretty good, although, i wish there were more vodka cocktail options.
*crab vadas - delicious!  i favored the green sauce over the tangy brown sauce.
*duck - have had better.
*south indian moons - liked that i was given five different uttapams.  **HOWEVER, the channa was EXTREMELY hot (temperature-wise).  there was no steam emanating from the bowl, so, i assumed that it was at the same temperature as the uttapams and the sambar.  i burned my mouth pretty badly, and informed our waitress that, in the future, patrons should be warned of the heat of the channa.  (FOUR DAYS LATER, the burns in my mouth are STILL healing.)  

the hand dryers in the bathroom have more power than a car wash's drying feature, and are SO terribly noisy.  one of the faucets was stuck on pretty hot water, but luckily, there was a second faucet w/working controls.

definitely not a place that i'll frequent.  was good enough to try at least once, i suppose.
author: Ting A.

description: I loved this restaurant! Before this, I seriously was NOT a fan of Indian food at all. I only liked Samosas and only Samosas. I hated most Indian curries in the past because they all looked very unappetizing. But after my experience at Dosa today, my feelings about Indian food has definitely changed! I ordered a Batsman cocktail and it was very refreshing and tasty. The Behl Puri salad was good too. We also ordered the Goan Prawn Balchao, Chicken Korma, Samosas, and the Masala Dosa. The Prawns stood out for me the most, very juicy and fresh! Absolutely loved it. I officially love Indian food!! and... what I loved even more was the ambience of this place and the presentation of the food! made the experience even better!
author: A L.

description:
** Update: one of the owners was responsive to this post and offered to look into it...  we didn't really want to get anyone in trouble...  but appreciated him reaching out **

The service at Dosa is lacking  goodwill...  

We walked in ready to like the place, sat down at a table by the bar and...  waited...  waited while waiters walked by...  waited for a bartender to appear...  waited until the hostess was done having a heated conversation with one of the waiters...  we finally flagged down the hostess and she said the reason we weren't getting served was that we hadn't checked in at the front desk.  

She said "we're not the kind of establishment where you can just walk in and sit down"...  (In the bar...)  Basically, they were passively-aggressively punishing us for not checking in...  

So still working the kinks out.  Right now the impression the customer service leaves is one of busy, angry inefficiency.
author: Sharif E.
