description: We were lucky to get a table straight away considering it was the fillmore jazz festival.. very friendly service.. considering we had two 3 year olds that were hyper..not really kid friendly but who cares in this city..  the decor is amazing but the food was very average.. basically it is american food covered in all the same curry sauce and don't let the server tell you how much to order.. he told us to order more than we need and it wasn' t cheap either... we had aussie accents so I assumed it thought were tourists and because there were 6 of us.. 4 adults and 2 kids (really)...  they added the tip to our bill..idiots.. they only did %15  we were going to pay at least $25 because of the mess the kids made but we just stuck with the original %15 due there point that our kids made up for the  6 "adults"..  wouldn't come back again...
author: Tiffany S.

description: One of my favorite SF restaurants for sure.  It's the place I take all visitors!  I've been to both Dosa locations on several occasions and loved each time.  The food and service are consistently great.  I prefer the Mission ambiance and the Fillmore menu, which is a bit expanded.  For upscale and delicious Indian food that never gives you a tummy ache, this is the place!
author: Kelli G.

description:
COLD FOOD.  CRAPPY WAIT STAFF. NOT WORTH THE HYPE. READ ON....

I was so excited to check out Dosa's new spot.  I loved my experience the first time I went in the Mission and left wanting more.  

Unfortunately, this experience did not meet my expectations and Dosa has morphed from a dining experience to a factory.

Yes, the decor is sleek and appealing.  Cool lighting, open space plan, balcony seating, and on and on.

Now for the dining experience.  We had a 9:15 reservation and were seated at 9:30ish - not too bad.

Our waitress approached us immediately asking us if we wanted tap and if we were ready to order our drinks - this while I was still taking off my jacket.  While this was not my first time at Dosa, it would have been nice if the waitress asked us if this was our first time and is we needed help with the menu - as Southern Indian Dosas are still a novelty.

We ordered the samosa appetizer, spicy lentil dosa, lamb curry and two drinks and then the night fell apart, as such:

1) The appetizers came before the cocktails
2) The appetizer was compeletly different from the one I had at the Mission - my fault but I was looking forward to that the most.  The one I remember had the samosa sliced in half over a yogurt sauce...it was amazing!  This one was good, but my expectations were different.
3) The first entree, the spicy lentil dosa, arrives before the appetizer is finished!  And, the food runner told us that we will need to open the Dosa up and spread the filling as it was plopped in the middle.  I asked her if it was supposed to be spread and she said it was but the kitchen didn't do it.  
4) Our second entree arrives 15 minutes later.  The dish was cold, the lamb was chewy and I sent it back immediately.  Second time around - another ten minutes - the dish was good but by that time we were too full from the other food.

If you want a factory-like experience, please go to Dosa on Fillmore.

I will try the one in the Mission in hopes it will be as I remembered it - but not for a long while.
author: Howard G.

description: Went here at 3:04 pm on the day after Thanksgiving with two hungry kids. Was told that the kitchen was shut at 3 pm - literally few minutes earlier and shown the door. Hardly the hospitality one would expect. Their attitude definitely sucks - no matter how good their food may have been , why would anyone want to go to restaurant where the people are clueless about hospitality?
author: S S.

description: This place is great. Good food and good drinks. I recommend going to this location due to the availability of liquer in the mixed drinks and they take reservations. I have yet to have a bad dish.
author: Nick H.

description: Gosh I love this place. It's definitely some of the best Indian food that's ever hit my lips and I love the stuff. The only thing negative to say is that I eat with my eyes and not with my stomach. All the entrees and dosa portions are generous can easily be split among a couple of diners. My current crushes are the fennel dosa and the veggie curry. Delish!
author: Jessica H.

description: Outstanding and unique Indian dishes.  Cool and classy decor.  Top notch cocktails.  Open late (by SF standards).  And a hip, stylish, sexy crowd that put some effort into looking nice before coming here.  The space is a bigger than I tend to like, but still one of my favorite new spots in SF.
author: Eli B.

description:
GOOD FOR GROUPS and sharing. Right as you walk into Dosa on a Friday night, you know that you will have a good dinner. The atmosphere and ambiance is really cool. It has very open feel but not empty. Great Service and help from the waiters. 
The food is different from most Indian Restaurants. Dosa's are big crepes with Indian Ingredients. Great for Vegetarians.
I would recommend getting the Chennai Chicken as a starter, Dahi Vada, and a Spicy Mung Masala Dosa. They were all very tasty and different.


Went in to DOSA the other night with 2 friends and we split a masala dosa before going to a movie. It was very convenient and we sat at the bar so they didn't mind the fact that we didn't order much.
author: John c.

description: Delicious Indian cuisine in an exquisitely decorated space.  From the paint on the walls to the chandeliers hanging from the ceiling, the decor exudes elegance and beauty.  My friends and I shared the samosas, paper masala dosa, the chef's selection of uttapam, and a chicken with rice dish.  The samosas were pretty good, one was northern Indian and the other was southern.  The paper masala was nice and thin and served with what seemed like a curry mashed potato, along with sambar and another sauce.  I loved the selection of uttapam and drenched it in the sambar for some heat.  The chicken with rice dish was also very flavorful.   My favorite part of the meal was the sambar, which I can eat just as a soup.  I am definitely returning to indulge again in some sambar and tasty Indian cuisine.
author: Linda P.

description:
granted, i like things that are fancy.

dosa makes my favorite indian food.
author: Gina K.

description:
After I returned from an extended trip to India last year, I was really missing the amazing cuisine I experienced while in the south of India.  I tried a few Bay area restaurants that were recommended to me, but none of them delivered what I was looking for...that is until I found Dosa.  This restaurant, owned by a hip Indian couple, has taken South Indian cuisine to the next level.  Here you will find many inventive twists on old favorites, not to mention the focus on organic ingredients.  Dosa really hits the sweet spot between the food and flavors we know and love from India,  a brilliant nod to its California influences, a focus on fresh local, organic products (for example, they use Straus organic milk for their raita, and serve freshly made papadum as a treat while waiting for your first course), and an amazingly sophisticated atmosphere.
Aah, finally an Indian restaurant in the States that I can sink into and enjoy...When I can't make it to India, Dosa is a really lovely consolation prize!
author: Suzie S.

description: Went for a Saturday brunch, the food was phenomenal, the service was great and the space is beautiful.  Really fresh ingredients and a very thoughtful menu.  The spring mini dosa and the mung salad we huge hits!  Can't wait to go back.
author: Bronagh H.

description:
i was so excited to see that the spot vacated by goodwill and the roving thread lounge was being taken up by dosa!  a long time complaint of mine has been the dire lack of good indian food in pac heights.

my colleague and i finally stopped by during lunch yesterday to check out our new neighbor.  the space is beautiful--it's so seldom a good indian restaurant is actually *nice* inside:  soaring ceilings, elegant decor my friend called "indian art deco."

service was prompt, helpful, and super friendly.  we declined the dine-about-town menu in favor of the regular lunch and ordered the following:  dahi vada, iddly sambar, egg poriyal uttapam, and rava masala dosa.  the dahi vada was spectacular, the iddlies soft and moist, and the sambar perfectly spiced.  the uttapam was yummy and wholesome (as were the chutnies in accompaniment).  the rava masala dosa was good but a little bit over-seasoned (too much salt and herbs) for my taste.

still, and *excellent* meal (with plenty left over to dine on for a few meals to come)!  welcome to the hood, dosa!
author: Roshni R.

description: Been to both Dosa on Fillmore and Dosa on Valencia.  Can't go wrong with either one.  Both had wonderful food and above average service.  I read the other reviews for Dosa on Fillmore where they mentioned slow or bad service.  I didn't notice anything negative.  In fact, our server, Leo, was great with his attentiveness and recommendations.  Dosa on Fillmore is in a bigger space and has a good vibe.  Dosa on Valencia is smaller, more intimate, and feels like a neighborhood restaurant.   Would be back to both, no question!
author: Bay Area G.

description: Decent food. Funny cocktails. Used to think the chandelier was awesome and while the design is still cool, it's greasy-looking now.
author: Heirloom Z.

description:
seeing dosa here its hard to visualize that the space used to be a goodwill store. rich wood accents, high ceilings, muted oranges and greens, and amber lighting all create such a pretty environment. while the menu is similar to that of the original dosa located in the mission, the vibe is definitely more upscale.

after an evening spent getting our faces peeled and picked, two girlfriends and i hopped over here for a late dinner. despite it being 9pm on a monday, there was still a buzz of people. we were seated on the mezzanine level, which not only had it's own bar and a view of the dining room, but is a good area to be in if you have red splotches on your chin or  swollen eyebrows from waxing. it's also a semi-private area perfect for a birthday dinner or group event.

it was difficult to flag down a server to assist in food related questions and overall, it took quite awhile for our cocktail and food orders to be served. i'm not sure if this was due to a shortage of staff, being seated upstairs, or just an off evening. as for the food and drinks, the cocktail menu is inventive with many options that read almost like an entree. they were all so tempting, but since it was a monday, i had to decide on just one. i ended up with a mood indigo, a boubon drink with jackfruit and champagne, and i stole a sip from m's ginger beer cocktail. both of them were yummy and quite unique. it can be a bit difficult navigating the menu, so many options, all of them equally tantalizing. for three girls, the tasting menu was a little excessive, so we ended up ordering one dosa, one vegetable dish, one chicken dish, and one appetizer. it was more than enough.

a combination of location, food, and atmosphere usually determines whether a restaurant ends up being on my favorites list or just another so-so establishment. dosa seems to have the formula down and i can't wait to return...hopefully without red splotches on my face.
author: helen l.

description:
Beautiful restaurant.

Bland service, however, the bus-boy service was great and you could tell they knew we were getting bad service from our waitress so they paid extra attention to us.

We could have used advice on the ordering, we said we were somewhat inexperienced with Indian food but we got no advice, and had to wait 20 minutes before the waitress returned before we could ask another question.  We had been seated about 40 minutes before she returned again and we finally ordered.  Our appetizers came out within 3 minutes, which was kind of strange -- she had just left the table and they arrived.  The calamari took longer though, and was my favorite of the appetizers.

Two of us had Dosa, one having the paper thin Rava variety, which If I was our server, would have warned us about as it is very difficult to eat -- it broke apart to the touch.   

I had the lamb curry, which was good.  

Another one of us had the peppercorn chicken, which she said was just "ok". 

In the end, I was pretty disappointed from all the good reviews I heard about Dosa.  I've had much better Indian food at much cheaper buffets, and again the service was just terrible.
author: Adam C.

description: I went to DOSA for dinner with a group of gals. Our first impression was that the ambience rocks! We got seated and as we reviewed the menu we got super excited about what was ahead of us. We all decided to do the tasting menu which was a great idea. The food was fresh, spicy and full of flavor. Only downside to this place has no privacy. Tables are crammed next to each other. As a matter of fact when I went to the bathroom I bumped the table next to me with my butt and I am not that big. I think this is a great place to go for a special occasion with lots of people but not a place to go if you are on a date and looking for romance. I would highly recommend going to the bar and checking out the cool surroundings.
author: Jessi H.

description: This place is so gorgeous - I am completely smitten with the decor. And the food is pretty unbelievable, too. Just WOW, really (at least the few times I've been there).
author: Wonder P.

description:
Update: Feb. 2009
....It's OVER. Dosa. Since most of your waiters or bar backs don't speak TAMIL, my suggestion NUMBER your items.
Okay walk in at lunch and order a Masala Dosa. Hardly anyone at the bar or the communal table. Blah expressions on customersand DOSAites...expected to see smiles and laughter. Check comes and following ensues:

Waitress: That'll be $11.28

Me: ok. (Give her $20. and 30 cents...one quarter and a nickel.

Waitress: Do you have THREE CENTS?

Me: I don't need the pennies, and doesn't 25 plus 5 equal thirty? Are you using somekind of DOSA math?

Waitress: Oh.....  (She gives me back $2.00)

Me: The change is WRONG. Why don't you just give me back $6.00

Waitress: (She supposedly Thinking ...sheet this customer discovered the DOSA self tipping system calculated at plus 80%, if a customer orders $30 worth of stuff, charge them $80 each , especially when they are in a group of four, that's a quick $100 for me..  haha...this is lower Pacific Heights..suckaaz.)

Me: GOODBYE...DOSA......!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!! The crowds at lunch are non-existent because they have seen the light finally....including me....and by the way, the DOSA was NOT crispy, it was SOGGY.sad...sad...sad... DOSA-Fillmore, you no longer impress. Udupi Palace is return to you .

Go for lunch...(less of a scenester-meet-the-meat-balls-feral-prairiedogs of bridge and tunnel screamers IMHO). BUT TOOOOOO pricey for a thin rice cake that is called "DOSA", know what I mean....it is for showing off at the new place of the moment and getting an expensive cocktail, without any live musical entertainment.....namaste...

Okay....end of November 2008...baaayyyybeee...get yo Dosa on that  thin rice pancake Masala wave of hot fabulosity and to think that last year the Goodwill store encompassed this very same space. BA ATM to be found on Post Street side. You will need to get your $300 cash withdrawal from the ATM because DOSA is NOT the tikka masala place in the 'loin...This is the lwrPacHeights version of ValenciaMamma and the COCKtails alone will get the higher thirty some-somesugar daddies to be hangin it with their shorties. Get the Pappadam with your beet soup because the soup is verrrryyyy sweet....tooooo SWEET. Calamari also is a nice spicey contrast to the beet soup...actually yummy with the DOSA. But just focus on the DOSA. That is the $10 deal.

Crowded from 7pm-9pm. (Pass on SOME of their frozen pre-packaged RASSMALAI Indian desserts.) Got the pistachio-ice cream- all of six tiny ten centimeter sticks with saffron, some kinda viscous basil seeds and mint on top...rough...not worth it..  Came to  $180 for three of us.

HUGE...and it is GREEN...not the color..the whole take on it's interior, paints, material used in remodeling...solar tinting on the windows, eventually or maybe even now, a solar power voltaic plant with a 580 gallon tank preheating water. Uniforms being made from whatevah cotton T shirt of the moment. "Bamboo floors". (Dosa green-aware designer Jim Maxwell.....)

according to sfgate.com

"Jim Maxwell of Architects II to transform this former Goodwill with floor-to-ceiling windows into an airy, sophisticated space, with timeless elegance and South Indian flair. Handcrafted chandeliers by Sharon Marston cast a warm, dark mustard  hue over the room while recessed walls contain Mary Brogger's steel fabrics inspired by Indian patterns. There are also several large photographs by Olivier Follmi and Anthony Kurtzillustrating South Indian culture. The large bar area is"  NOT "ideal for moviegoers stopping in for a quick drink and bite before going across the street to the Kabuki Theater." IT IS CROWDED now. Try in six months around May 2009. 

Dosa on Fillmore, 1700 Fillmore St. (at Post), San Francisco; 
(415) 441-3672 or dosasf.com. 
Starters, $7-$9.50; entrees, $16-$26; desserts, $6-$8. Full bar. Reservations and credit cards  NECESSARY.

Dosa started out on Valencia and now it has got a bigger Part Two on Fillmo..sometimes worth someone's time and palate....BUT what is with that HEAVY, hard to open front door? And once inside, why not have a nice brocade panel to the sides of the entrance to carress you as you enter and keep the waiting public not staring at those at the tables? Just a wondering thought...When it is windy in this foggy city, it felt as if someone was pulling the door shut on us and that it was no longer open for more fans...but they want to be open from 5:30pm to midnight for the 11:59 pm screamers...I am not a screamer...I know the meaning of the word meditating on the word composed sophistation and avoiding the whole turning into a pumpkin at midnight thang.
This is some additional info I found on 7x7 blog...
http://www.7x7sf.com/eat_drink/blog/28417984.html
"Southern India  It has a diverse geographical terrain. For example, Kerala where it gets very hot, has very mild coconut milk-based dishes and Andhra Pradesh probably has the spiciest cuisine of South Indi
author: miriam b.

description:
So delicious.

My good friend said you can tell the if an Indian restaurant is authentic by their Samosas. Dosa passed the test with flying colors.

Drinks- delicious 

Dosa - HUGE

EVERYTHING IS DELICIOUS.

Best Indian in the city.
author: Shannon M.

description:
This is as good as it gets in Bay Area. After my favourite cook, Empress of India (Santa Clara), retired, eating out Indian food in Bay Area had become impossible until now.

Since every Indian restaurant has been a disappointment in the last many years, we resisted for a long time.  But now that I have been there, I would go back for the drinks alone. Or the dosa or the curries.

For details:
http://naantherapy.wordpress.com/2010/06/07/fillmore-jazz-and-dosa/

If you are lactose intolerant, this place is divine. Almost all food is made in coconut milk - typically Indian restaurants add a gallon of cream to every dish which is not at all traditional.

This place is hip, the neighborhood is perfect, service is friendly and the decor is suited for high end business meals. The flavors are authentic, the tastes are bold, the dishes are cleaned up .... finally an Indian restaurant that meets the requirements for the palate and appearance at the same time.
author: Mishti D.

description:
what a beautiful space!!! the owners deserve ALL the accolades. the food, the drinks, the atmosphere, ALL make this one of the hottest restaurants in the city.

my first bite into the habenero-mango dosa brought back high school memories for me. literally, every single bite had me going ohh & ahh...loved it! the fish moilee was another great dish. the flavors were all so delicious. the coconut, the mustard & spices blended in very well. a must order if you love fish (as someone mentioned, the coconut rice which accompanies this entree can certainly be eaten as a dessert, lol.)

i'm a big fan of borscht, so it was a good treat to start w/ beet soup here at Dosa. it was creamy, and done well. to finish off, settled with rasmalai, which is basically cheese patties in cream, flavored w/ rose water & garnished w/ pistachios. this one was ok. it's one of the hardest desserts to make, cooks master this one back home. there have been only 3 places i have had fabulous rasmalai, and none are here in the U.S. having said that, this is the best rasmalai in SF.

i also had two drinks recommended by our lovely bartender, Suzanne. the first was a cocktail -the Bengali Gimlet. the curry flavor made it interesting, but it was a little too sweet for me, and i would go easy on the lime juice next time. or simply, gimlet for me, has to be made w/ vodka! the second was a glass of Riesling. which was well chosen by our bartender, and generally the best wine to go w/ indian food. it was perfect!

(as a disclosure, i'm in the restaurant business & have a couple of indian restaurants myself here in the city. i have to say Dosa is by far one of the best in the business -i.e. after my two restaurants :) )
author: Sha A.

description: We casually dropped into Dosa on New Year's Eve.  A special meal was being offered prix fixe (complete meal of several courses) for the evening - but we weren't interested in a multi-course meal that night.  Luckily, we were offered a chance to order a la carte off the menu in the bar.  We were not disappointed...I'm happy to say that we had a wonderful dinner that evening.  Also, we were interested in getting naan - which wasn't being served that evening.  I'm happy to say that the restaurant accomodated our request!  Extra points: 1)  Great club background music, 2) gulab jamun (excellent).
author: Randy D.

description:
with only 2 weeks under it's belt...this place is still fine tuning it's speed.  so far an eclectic mix of people - some curious tourists and some locals who stumbled in.

there is no sign outside except for a beautiful oversized door.

the lighting is chic and warm.  perfect blend of exotic and modernism.   it reflects the same cut out feel of the screen like artwork and staircase.

the only disappointment was the gold leafed floral design at the entrance.  it was almost stencil yourself at home kit like

once you  arrive, the spicy southern indian scents hit you with a whallop as you enter the space.

since i already had dinner i could only nibble on raita and a bread similar to naan but much lighter.  

i'll have to come back and try out all the different dosas and judging from the looks on the fellow diners, it looked promising.
author: Anh V.

description: The drinks are amazing, which certainly takes the edge off of the always long wait. An awesome gluten free find, as all of the dosas but two are gluten free (and vegetarian, too)! Perfect portions, and the dipping sauces are so good, I'd like to bathe in them.
author: Sara B.

description: Ok, the food is "good" but I just can't say great?  The ambiance is wonderful- they really did a beautiful job with the decor.  The space is open and trendy.  We had the prix fixe menu which I would not recommend cause the food we saw on other tables off the regular menu looked far better.  Our starter and dessert left us wanting more(literally...they could've added one more shrimp and one more ball...who serves ONE gulab jamun ball!) , but the middle was pretty good.  The crepes are amazing and my entree- the fish, was rich and mmm good.  At the end of the meal, we looked at teachother and said, "eh, it was good...but not worth $39 pp."  My husband and I would rather eat our Indian at AslamsRosoi on Valencia.
author: K S.

description: This place is great!! Its very posh inside...the decor is very nice and the food is delicious! Everything is full of flavor! mmm! I would suggest calling in ahead of time for a reservation because they are always packed. I would really recommend the Chennai Chicken -- Boneless organic chicken marinated in Strauss organic yogurt with coriander & cumin, fried. It's a little spicey but its really delicious! The Cochin Calamari is also a great appetizer as well. The Masala Dosa ...it's the classic dosa filled with creamy spiced potatoes, onions, and cashew nuts (masala). They also carry a variety of Indian beers and a great variety of good wines that really do go great with the food at Dosa.
author: Valerie F.

description: Yummmmm. Everything here is delish!  BEAUTIFUL venue, something out of a movie, so lavish....Service is okay and my only real complaint is the lengthy wait times for a table.
author: Gohar J.

description: This is a fun, trendy place to get a great cocktail, catch up with friends and eat a delicious dosa. The space is beautiful - high ceilings, sleek decor, not too loud, not too quiet. They do a great job explaining the menu and making recommendations. The food is a good introduction to newbies and certainly good enough for the seasoned palate who wants to spice it up. Great variety and they also have a decent prix-fixe menu if you're up for 4 courses.
author: Kathleen H.

description: Fine cocktails, refined Indian dishes,  good service and nice design/decor.  A place i would bring visiting friends to illustrate how awesome and international SF can be.
author: Damien J.

description:
Excellent food, attentive smart service, great modern balanced wine list, wonderful space and decor, super music - a landmark San Francisco dining experience. The Dosa menus are easily the best I have tasted outside of some of the leading London Indian restaurants. San Francisco doesn't know how lucky it has got, to have such a perfectly eclectic approach to Indian cuisine. This was my third visit since opening in November and all three were very close to perfect as dining experiences. I was with two business colleagues from Madras and I let them take me through the menu and choose the dishes. They were impressed - almost reluctantly, as if they hadn't expected such a treat far from home. We shared 5 "starters", three main dishes and three puddings, the best way to sample through the menu. I will spare you the details or you will be reading for another 30 minutes :-) 
Here is what the Madras colleague emailed me back - "" It was a pleasure to finally meet you in San Francisco!  The DOSA restaurant was really really good.  I showed pictures of the restaurant (from the website) to couple of my colleagues here in Bangalore -- none of them guessed that it was a Indian restaurant!!  This one is really different - good choice! ""
author: Vera N.

description: Last night we went To Dosa for the first time.We were trying to catch a movie.I want to say the food was excellent,and the service was even better! The waiter was informative, knowing everything about the menu! We had the tomato salad and the lamb chops and halibut!!!Thank you to Frantz,we will be back!! Effortless!
author: Mattia C.

description: Dosa, dosa, in a roll, who's the tastiest of them all?  If you think you know the ins and outs of Indian food, you don't.  A dosa is so perfectly everything that is Indian food like your western eyes have learned to see it, but so completely different...  While you're here ask the bar tender for his secret Shalamari Dream cocktail.  It's the most amazing curry flavored cocktail you've ever tried...  And, perhaps, the only.
author: Mason G.

description:
#64 on the Big Eat SF List (2009) - paper masala dosa

took my mom when she was visiting. I was looking to use the dine about town menu, but the waiter said "it doesn't start till the 15th (it was the 16th) and confused me, then I double checked the next time he came and he apologizes and said he meant Monday (19th). that's fine. but why would they ignore the start date od dine about town, and just decide to do it later? weird... to make up for it, he did give us complimentary cardamom ice cream! good effort.

The sambar is a huge serving. the chutney is good. there's a LOT of potato, be prepared!

However, my mom says says home town (San Diego) South Indian restaurants do it better! 

nice ambiance tho
author: S V.

description:
Good ambiance...that is all there is to it.
I am from South India and I can tell you the food is terrible. 
Overly salty and the food doesn't seem fresh. 
If you still have to pick Dosa, then the one on Valencia is slightly better when it comes to the food.
author: carmel t.

description: Kind of an interesting experience I had here last night.  First, we made reservations through Opentable for 8PM.  When we got there, we still had to wait about 20 minutes for our table.  There were a lot of service type things that annoyed me.  When we were ordering the waitress kept telling us we needed to order more.. After ordering (and not picking about 2 dishes she said to order) we found out that we had more than enough food by the end.  They also ran out of 2 things after ordering, the Scallops and the Chicken Biriani, which was a kitchen communication issue.  Then after we ate we asked for the check and the waitress still put down the desert menus.  Wow, it's like, dude, you really need to spend more here!  We noticed too (without her telling us) that they added the tip in (we were 6 people so it's reasonable) but at least tell us and don't include another tip line in the check like "oh I forgot to tell you".  Just found the whole experience to have a bad taste in my mouth.  Overall though, the atmosphere is cool there, but a little loud.  It was really hard to read our menus too, because we were upstairs and it was a little too dark.  The food was good though, so overall I'd go back but hopefully get a better server.
author: Mitch A.

description:
Dosa on Fillmore has a beautiful high-ceilinged interior and a hip and swanky atmosphere.  This place is nice enough to come on a date, as long as you don't mind some smelly post-dinner breath.

I've always been promptly seated here with or without a reservation.  Service is pleasant and efficient.

The menu still confuses me with its many options but I always get the paper masala dosa.  The South Indian Moons is also a good way to try a variety of uttapam.  If you're only dining with 2, I'd suggest getting a dosa and then something else like a curry, since the dosa and uttapam came with the same chutneys.  The food doesn't look like that much when it comes out, but it's quite filling.
author: S L.

description: This restaurant is truly special. The food is SCRUMPTIOUS and the atmosphere is cool.  Every time I go to Dosa, I try a new dish. I love it all so much that I'm sad when the dish is gone! And OHHHHH how the coconut rice lifts my feet from the floor. It's the best I've ever tasted. Dosa on Fillmore is my favorite spot in the city!!! They serve dinner late, which really works for me :O) I also LOVE that they are environmentally considerate in their approach to business. Thanks Dosa!
author: Tara E.

description:
After eating at two "high end" Indian restaurants in the last few weeks (the other being Amber India) I was surprised at how differently I felt about the two. Both were beautiful restaurants with great service but I really felt like Dosa was trying too hard. It was like it was trying to be pretentious to attract the Pac Heights/Marina crowd who wouldn't venture to the original (and better) location in the Mission. Sad. I also felt weird that we were eating in the old Good Will location. It was just a weird juxtaposition. 
That being said, I do feel the food has suffered with the expansion. I remember eating at the original years ago and enjoying it much more. I've eaten at Udupi palace recently and have to say their dosa is better. Actually I prefer the uttapam which isn't as well known as the dosa but is like a thicker, savory pancake. Anyway, the new restaurant is pretty nice but it kind of lacks some heart in my opinion. The food was good but not as complex in flavor, the overwhelming impression I got was spicy without all the wonderful flavors I normally taste in Indian food. Overall I left Dosa feeling like I was wanting more.
author: Cathy T.

description:
I've been to a bunch of hole-in-the-wall Indian joints and know my Indian food, so when we decided to go to a "fancy" Indian, place I was a bit skeptical.

The atmosphere was nice, but it felt a bit cramped.  There were people constantly walking all around our table.  There's one main seating area to the left and a big communal table on the right.

The food was definitely good, but not spectacular.  The range of flavors in the dishes we got was very nice.  I especially liked the spring dosa, the paneer uttapam and the heirloom & iddiapam. 

One of the weird thing about this place is the wait staff.  They knew their stuff but couldn't pronounce half the dishes, so it took away from the authenticity of the place.   

It was a good meal, but I probably wouldn't go back.  It's hard to bring myself to pay that much for Indian food when you could get most good Indian meals for a fraction of the price.
author: Jim F.

description: Kinda over-rated in my book.  The food was fine - nothing particularly memorable.  But I guess it is one of the few places in the city to get southern Indian food, so that counts for something.  The design of the interior is impressive - I especially liked the staircase with a sweeping view of the downstairs dining room.  For me, this is the type of place I would go for cocktails and snacking on dosas.
author: Eric C.

description: We just discovered Dosa has a breakfast/brunch menu items, and mini-dosa with soup/salad specials at lunchtime. A great deal, and both the food and service are excellent.
author: Steven G.

description:
I really like Dosa. I've been to both. The one in Fillmore is more than twice the size. It is not as cramped so you can go with more people or take food adventurous kids or a baby. The dosas are all wonderful. I love the spring and masala (the regular and the paper masala). Also tried the spinach and leek, which was very good. Yummy fun to dip the dosas in their delicious sauces and lentil soup. Yummy. The curries are also good. The lemon and coconut rice are both delicious. The chicken byrani is good. All of it is good for sharing and experiencing with others so go with at least two others. Oh and my favorite is the dahi vada starter...lentil cake thingys covered in yogurt sauce! That is delicious. The persimmons salad also yum. Pretty much everything is YUMMY.

Good wine selection and interesting beers. I've never had the desserts, because I am always stuffed after dinner. Service is good. The server we had last time tried to discourage us a couple of times from ordering just dosas, which was a bit annoying, but I think she was just trying to upsell and get us to all order mains along with dosas. Supposedly they are known for their mains, but I enjoy the dosas more. Especially if you are veg, you can't go wrong with the dosas. The best thing to do is go with others and try it all!
author: Jaime S.

description:
my friend brought me here for my birthday 'cause i had always wanted to try the place. 

for the price, the food was not only good but service and ambiance were great too! my friend thought everything tasted great but i thought it was a bit TOO salty for my taste buds. however, i thought dinner was a success! would like to come back again
author: Erin M.

description:
This restaurant is vastly overrated.  I took a group of 4 on a Satruday night.  Despite our 8pm reservation, we were made to wait 35 minutes before seating.  And this was only after the owner intervened!  The menu is difficult to decipher and many dishes were way too spicy (some were so hot, they really should have had an alert on the menu).  Our chicke dish was undercooked (according to my friend) and the food just wasn't that good.  For example, I have had better Indian food at Curry and Naan location in Berkeley (no connection).  The server got a A for effort but her lack of knowledge about the wine list was disappointing.  The one bottle we wished to order was, in fact, out of stock so we had to go with our second choice.

I certainly won't be returning and I predict this location will not be in business for long.
author: D G.

description:
I came here with my uncle for DAT.

We both ordered the chicken channai for our appetizers.  It was SO GOOD.  The serving size was surprisingly large for an appetizer, especially since it was from the DAT pre-fixe menu.  It was spicy but the yogurt sauce helped cool my mouth.  It also came with a small slaw salad.  For my entree, I ordered the lamb kofta.  It was SPICY but very tasty.  I only managed to eat a few spoonfuls and two meatballs before I had to call it quits.  [I took the rest home and ate it with big cups of soymilk.]  My uncle got the chicken frankie and said it was good, too.

I would definitely come again to try their dosas but I'm planning on checking with the waiter on how spicy the dishes are BEFORE I order.  The papadom is really cripsy and yummy too and a refeshing change from the typical baguette you get from other restaurants.
author: Denise C.

description: While the dosas are good, the cocktails here are a thing of beauty.  I have been thinking about the cocktail with coconut milk, kaffir lime leaf,  red chili and gin almost daily since I last visited Dosa.  Make sure you have reservations or you might end up at the communal table with some Sex and the City-style Pac Heights singles who namedrop and talk about how fat their "good friend's" wives are...
author: robyn s.

description: Service, food, and cocktails are all amazing!!! Especially the food and especially the drinks. I had a peony cocktail (it's pink and foamy and delicious) Probably not for guys, but for the ladies its yummy.
author: Olga S.

description: I went a couple of weeks ago for brunch with the girls. The food was ok, the thai tea was different and I would have appreciated a tip on how it is supposed to be enjoyed "properly". I ordered the Seasonal Fruit Napolean and it was ok. I don't know much about Indian Food, but it did not leave a lasting impression. I would go again if invited, but would not initiate it as a place I need to try again.
author: Conny F.

description: So I went here for a friend's birthday party and really enjoyed almost everything. Since they won't seat you without the whole group there, they need to offer more standing or sitting room by the bar. My friends and I were ready and willing to spend money on expensive libations, but were pretty annoyed not to even be able to have a comfortable spot to sip our drinks. It's a huge spot for San Francisco, so they need to take advantage of the space. It used to be the Good Will spot. Anywho, the food was pretty darn good. I was also surprised with the size of the portions,  big, and not as expensive as the decor leads you to expect. One last remark, for such a large spot, it should offer more seating...
author: B K.

description: Had a great dinner here when visiting SF.  Everyone at the table did the tasting w/ drink pairing and loved it!  The tasting menu is a steal and the food is delicious.  Just the right kind of spicy.  Great vibe and very good and knowledgeable service.
author: Catie B.

description:
The food is average and pricey.  
The drinks were nothing worth writing home about.

However, the ambiance is terrific.
author: Paolo B.

description:
I wish that I could give separate ratings for food and for service. I would give four stars for the food and two for the service.
Last night was my first time there. I have heard many great things about the restaurant and was looking forward to the dinner.
The experience started out alright with the server helping us choose numerous dishes that we planned to share. 
The dishes came out in a logical and timely fashion. It was in the clearing of them that things started to break down. The servers and bussers were overly anxious to get dishes cleared. Several times they took things away before we were finished with them. Annoying and, quite frankly, amateur. 
Things really got janky at the end. After we paid the bill the server made continuous intrusive sweeps through the table clearing things. Again, many of which we weren't finished with. Water, for example. The kicker was when the server took my wife's glass of wine with wine still in it!
On top of that, as she cleared our glassware she stuck her fingers down inside the glass so that she could get two or three at a time. That's just plain damn gross! She stuck her fingers down into our dirty glasses and then just kept on serving food. 
A good start and a crappy finish. Definitely not up to the standards of our stellar restaurant culture here in San Francisco.
author: F B.

description: Really enjoy my meals at DOSA. Great food, good ambiance. Haven't had to wait too long to be seated (although 10 minutes or so is the norm, even with a reservation). The tasting menu is the way to go, and gives a great overview of what DOSA has to offer, from appetizers to entrees, desserts, etc. It's a bit pricey, but what isn't in SF? Overall, a very enjoyable meal.
author: PM M.

description: Food is good and dining room is large w/ great light, but prices are pretty high. Cocktails are tasty and there's a $5 happy hour menu at the bar - that's probably the better bet if you're watching the wallet.
author: hunter w.

description: Really creative cocktails. I don't even like gin and they only have gin cocktails but I still go there for this purpose. The JuJu Palm is nice and spicy. The food is unbelievable. I got the roasted chili and garlic dosa crepe. Really good.
author: Nisha M.

description: I was really impressed by the beautiful decor of this restaurant. Super tasty and exotic drink menu. The food was delicious, flavorful and spicy. Potato Leek Soup, Crab Vadas, Samosas 'North & South', and Mangalorean Prawn Masala were all delicious though the portions were on the small side. I will definitely be back!
author: Johnnie T.

description:
Dosa's ambiance is quite lovely, and it's a pleasant switch from the usual decor in Indian restaurants.  They also use high quality ingredients in prepping their dishes and that quality is apparent when you taste it.  The best thing we ordered was the duck in spinach sauce.  The flavor was fantastic and the duck was cooked to tender perfection.  The idli was also quite yummy and it was great that they used Strauss creamery yougurt, as you can really taste the difference.   The service was also quite good.  We were a party of four, sharing each of the dishes we ordered, and they timed bringing our food out to us so that we could share the "courses".  

Our party was very disappointed with some of the other things we ordered, however.  Given the name of the restaurant, we had high expectations for the dosa, but if fell flat.  It was puny and soggy, and although the sambar was delicious, the dosa was so soggy it couldn't stand up to being dipped.  We were equally disappointed with the chana bhatura, the chick peas were pretty good, but the bhatura was also greasy and soggy.  The crab cake appetizer had good flavor and very fresh crab, but the texture was also soggy on the exterior.  The chicken biriyani was good, but not good enough to justify the price of it.  

For either dosa or bhatura, you're better off going to Vik's in Berkeley.  That place certainly lacks Dosa's ambiance, but those particular dishes, Vik's are three times as good at a third of the price.
author: amy b.

description:
Let me start by saying that I love Indian food. I always joke that I either must have been Indian in a previous life or preparing to be Indian in my next life. At this new DOSA, the food is very good, but it's South Indian food and I don't think it lends itself very well to a fancy set up. Their menu struggles with the price points. On one hand $10.50 for a Dosa is fine, but on the other hand, $9-$10 for a chaat (appetizer) is too much. May be it's ok for dinner but it's the same on their lunch menu. I would prefer if they had some lunch special where you get one vada with your meal for instance. I felt a bit odd seating in this fancy super nice and very designed interior and eating my dosa with my fingers. And I was frustrated that I wasn't comfortable spending the money to try their appetizer because lunch shouldn't be $20+ for this kind of food. On the plus side, they take reservations. I like that because I hate the hour and a half wait at the Valencia location. Bottom line: it's just OK for  me.

PS: Watch for the heat on the Habanero Dosa. My husband can eat very spicy and he could not finish his.
author: Elsa T.

description:
If you love DOSA on Valencia, then DOSA on Fillmore will blow you away! The food at both restaurants are uniform in taste and presentation. I did notice one new dosa on the menu that I had not seen at Valencia, which could have been updated, and the habanero mango masala dosa created some beads of forehead sweat! We also ordered the regular masala dosa and an uttapam. Same sambar and dipping sauces. The bhel puri is a blend of bhel and sev puri, as usual with the sweet brown and mint chutneys. For the first time I tried a curry at dosa, and the lamb curry is an absolute knock out, perfect to share for three people. That dish will now be my staple order at this restaurant. The wines still serve as great pairings with the fragrant dishes. And there are some new cocktails with plenty of Indian spice flair.

Lastly, everyone notices the decor. The amazing chandelier train vividly points out the high ceilings which makes for a spacious and classy restaurant. Valencia is more on the casual side as most people with parties less than 6 are walk-ins, and the bar is always jammed pack. The Fillmore location, takes RESERVATIONS on OpenTable.com for parties of all sizes. Without reservations, slum it at the roomy long bar! If you are luckier, score an immediate spot at the long communal table that may seat about 15, but it is quite tight. There is definitely plenty of eye contact and eyelash batting at this communal table. * wink * wink * If you are a people-watcher and conversation-listener like me, topics around this narrow stretch of wood can be quite...interesting, to say the least. For example we were debating the merits and credibility of YELP *ahem* and the waitstaff happened to pass by and over hear with a smirk on her face. I cringed hoping that the rest of the evening would not involve a swift kick to the butt and boot out of there. Needless to say, it was a great dining experience.

Parking can be quite difficult in Pacific Heights proper, but the location is a few blocks further, across from Japantown. I found free street parking after circling thrice around the block for a peak 7PM Sunday dinner. If I were to circle once more, I was more than willing to drop off my guest and head over to the Japantown parking garage. My convenience balance sides with Fillmore.
author: Cathy H.

description:
Fantastic South Indian food. For those who are not familiar with the difference between South Indian and North Indian food, which may explain reviews of this restaurant for not being "authentic", they are about as different as New England vs. Southern American cuisine. North Indian is what you tend to get in almost all Indian restaurants. It is heavy on cream and butter. Southern Indian tends to be much lighter, heavy on spices, sometimes quite hot, with one of the traditional dishes being the Dosa. The Dosa is a paper thin crepe made out of rice and lentils which is then stuffed with various vegetables. Our favorite is the Masala Dosa, which is the potato and onion Dosa. You then have three sauces to dip it in (read: control the spiciness level). We eat here all the time, have gone through almost the entire menu, and have never had anything that wasn't good. Some of our favorites: their fire broth, a super spicy tomato broth, chenna chicken, chickpee curry, and the masala dosa. Their wine list is excellent, seriously, and very unique.

The negative: they don't take reservations for parties of four or less. And this is new, we have gone there with over six and they wouldn't take a reservation. The place is PACKED, particularly on the weekends, which means you end up waiting for over an hour at the bar. Oh, and the place is very noisy - bad acoustics. It's also not cheap. This is NOT your neighborhood curry house - but it is worth every cent.

As for not being "authentic" we just left the place this evening and at the line to pay for the parking ticket we ran into one of my husband's coworkers, a South Indian man. His family was visiting from Southern India and wanting to take them to the best Southern Indian restaurant in San Francisco he took them to Dosa. They loved it!
author: Natasha Anna A.

description:
We've been to Dosa twice. Each time we've been seated near the busing station at the back of the restaurant, where it is breezy and cold; we wore our coats throughout our dinner. I'd like to deduct half a star for this.

That said, the food at Dosa is delicious. We always leave stuffed to the gills with food. You can come out relatively cheaply if you can avoid drinks and appetizers. The restaurant itself is pretty swank and apparently always busy. 

I definitely recommend this restaurant, but dress warmly or you'll freeze.
author: Steve H.

description:
Took my mother here for her birthday.  Overall, a great experience.  The service was excellent!  The food is always interesting and tasty.

We also all had a good laugh when my step-dad, who forgot his reading glasses and couldn't read the menu, asked if they had reading glasses.  The waitress replied "Of course we do, we'll bring them right over."  Sure enough, she did!
author: Jeremy R.

description:
holy crap dosas are amazing
their curries are spicy and the mustard halibut is only ok
the weird drinks are super good
mine had curry and coconut milk in it

super cute decor
author: Christopher L.

description:
Beautiful place!! Love those chandeliers and lights!
Since I am not a big connoisseur of Indian food, I will give it 4 stars: presentation, ambiance, service and great tasting food.
The drinks are excellent, have some zing to it ( I mean, enough booze!) and very exotic. We chose the set menu, four courses for 40, and tried a few different items. All tasted very good. Have to say Indian food is not something I would eat every day though. Have to get used to it. And I like this cuisine better than The cuisine at Amber...
Service was excellent, always checking on how we were doing, if we needed more drinks. By 8PM, the place was completely full, the waiter got busy, so we had to wait a bit ... But overall, a great experience.
author: lovetoeat a.

description: For those of you who are not familiar with south Indian food, this is a really good place to start. South Indian food, unlike food from the northern part of the country tends to not be cream based (yeah for you lactose intolerant people!). I would recommend most things at Dosa, but for you new comers this is not your chicken tikka marsala place you think of with Indian food. The dosa are basically huge crepes that they roll up and give you with spiced potatoes and some curry and chutneys to either dip it in or to wrap up in it (you're choice!). The uttapam are what I imagine would happen if a pancake and a hashbrown had a baby - and you also get some dipping sauces and curry with them. Personally I love the paneer (mild Indian cheese) and pea uttapam. Try this place out, it's a great introduction to a "new" type of Indian food for most people!
author: M M.

description:
I never thought an Indian restaurant could ever look THAT beautiful...the chandeliers took my breath away. Granted there was little that was actually strikingly Indian about the whole decor, but it was a nice modern take. I just wish there were more Indian paintings of culture, besides that one huge picture at the back left. 

The dosa itself was like anything else I could find in any other South Indian restaurant back in Southern California, so the food did not disappoint me. The taste of the chutneys are considerably milder, however, but it caters to the crowd that comes here and that does not mind paying more than they actually should for South Indian food.

But I gotta say, although South Indian food is normally not the most expensive of all cuisines, the price was fitting for the beautiful atmosphere and the experience. In fact, I am surprised that with such a classy-looking restaurant, it wasn't even MORE expensive! But I don't want to place ideas in the owners' heads now...

I would come back for the new twists they take on traditional Indian food that make it gourmet. I would also come back for the bar and the atmosphere if I wanted to show it off to some friends or a date. But for completely traditional South Indian food, I would go to the ones in LA that serve the same tasty dishes for even cheaper. But the one thing this place has accomplished that no other Indian restaurant has (and I am saying this as a "North" Indian) is that it finally places South Indian food on the map. No more naan, k? For that, I give it 5 stars. BRAVO!
author: Neesha M.

description:
We came here for dinner following a great movie at the Sundance and some good drinks-I love that place ;-)

The interior is modern and clean in design however the seating is somewhat tight if you're sitting on the bench. A little too close for comfort for my taste.  It was hard to have a conversation since both of the tables next to us were quite loud and we were able to listen to there conversations-of which we had no interest!  It was unpleasant but thankfully they both left by the time our food came.
I would recommend more space between the tables maybe remove some altogether to provide some privacy.
The service was excellent thanks to our waiter Jason K. ;-)
On to the food...it was excellent.  We had a Taj Mahal and Aventinus and they were good accompaniments to the our meals.
We had the Andhra prawns with a side of coconut rice-very good and flavorful meal all around but spicy.
My hubby had the Lamb kofta with a side of dosa and that was excellent.
We finished with the rasmalai dessert and it was perfect!

Overall a good experience and we'll return to try other items on the menu.
author: Lizete S.

description: Dosa combines tasty food and perfect decor while providing a great array of drinks from their bar.  I have yet to have a dosa that wasn't delicious and I am often please with most everything I get there.  I highly recommend the paper masala dosa as a delicious and unique option.  The only dish I would avoid are there Indian crab cakes.  It's not that they were bad, but they simply didn't bring the complexity of flavor I was hoping for.  Overall, Dosa provides a satisfying and enjoyable dining experience... at a cost.
author: Mike G.

description:
A prosecco is a sparkling wine, but the one I ordered lacked any "bubbles" which meant it had been opened a while back and should not be served. The prosecco was completely "still like a wine" so I related this to the waiter. He came back with a tiny sample of prosecco in another glass, this time with bubbles and insisted both were from the same bottle. I drink prosecco frequently and travel to Italy annually. I declined the drink, rather than argue over the matter. 
  The food is unremarkable; I feel it is overrated. Needless to say, I would not recommend this place.
author: elizabeth f.

description: We had such a fabulous dinner at Dosa last night that I don't even know where to begin. We let our waitress, Christine, guide us through our selections and it was the smartest move of the night. She was INCREDIBLE! Starting with the spiced pear and avocado salad with escarole and very light on the dressing, we knew we were in for a sumptuous night.  We had the typical sambar & dosa (can't remember exactly which but it was all right on) but what was the best were the scallops and then lamb chops. Out of this world!!  Service is impeccable, water is constantly refilled (luckily as some dishes are spicy but not over done), little touches as to things to tone down the spiciness is giver to you too.  Hostesses were so friendly and helpful as well.  Wonderful night!
author: P G.

description: I didn't know what to expect heading into this experience since I am not a huge fan of Indian food. However, with all of the raving reviews I was intrigued to see what it was all about. Such a neat place with an impressive decor. I really enjoyed brunch here. My table split the Seasonal Fruit Napoleon Uttapam and the apple pieces added a distinct flavor to the dish. A strawberry puree also accompanied the dish nicely. For my main entree I opted for the Egg Dosa with cheese. There was too much cheese for me and if I went back I would probably choose no cheese, but regardless, it was still tasty. Service was good, we were provided a few recommendations and the server was very friendly. I definitely want to go back and explore the dinner menu.
author: Jen B.

description: Spectacular! First off, the space, decor and ambiance of the new Dosa is amazing. It makes going out to dinner feel like a night out on the town but not in an obnoxious way. It is sleek and sexy. The bar area is spacious and happening and you can still keep tabs on what is going on from the dining room area. I went with my good friend Liz, who knows the owners and a two other girls. We had delicious mung bean dosa filled with warm, spicy potatoes and served with a cool cucumber raita, the ultimate comfort food. We also shared the spicy prawn appetizer, lamb curry with the most aromatic lemon-basmati rice, and an extremely tender chicken dish. Many times Indian food can be too heavy, not the case here. The food is spiced perfectly and it tastes so fresh. Thank you Anjan and Emily for a great evening and treating us so well. I am already planning my next visit!
author: Laura Gardner S.

description: Came here on a Friday night around 11:30 PM (closes at midnight) and we didn't feel rushed at all - great service!  We were able to order drinks and an appetizer (Chennai Chicken) & a large plate (Paneer & Peas Dosa.)   We were seated right away and given water and drinks pretty quickly.  1st think I noticed is how beautiful the space is.  The place has high ceilings, two stories, and a nice bar.  I've walked past this restaurant a few times and would have never guessed it looked like this inside!  The Chennai chicken is pretty amazing.  I wish it was a larger portion because it was so good.  I asked if they could make it mild, but it wasn't possible due to the seasonings, but it wasn't too bad and I'm a whimp when it comes to spice.  The Dosa (1st time having it), was good.  It comes with three different sauces.   I can see a small intimate dinner here or even a large group.  I definitely want to come back and try more.
author: Neville B.

description: Service wasn't great. Food was really good though. Calamari and Chicken for apps, and the halibut, marsala dosa, and uthappam sampler. Drinks were very interesting, with some real different flavors, but were good. 3 stars because of the service, 4 stars on food alone. There's a 10 dollar all you can eat indian buffet 3 doors down, I tempted to try that one.
author: Mike C.

description: I am so excited for the new Dosa.  i had appetizers and drinks at the Mission spot around the time of the opening and have been meaning to go back.  But eating within the ambiance of this beautiful new restaurant tonight makes me think I need to return to the Fillmore location first!  It is delicious food and the service is as fast as you want it to be, but not hurried.  Whoever said it's very NY without the pretension is right on the money.  The next guests who come to town may be dining at Dosa with us.  No other Indian restaurant will lessen my love of Mehfil, but for a nice night out Dosa is a great spot!
author: Denise G.

description: We went again for dinner (rather than lunch like the previous time), and while everything was still good, the food was just not quite as savory as the first time. Inconsistency? It was enough to make me rethink laying down a fat wad of cash for food that didn't live up to my memory of it. Perhaps (when someone else is paying) i'll give it another shot, but I prefer to return to certain 5-star places only. After all, I don't think I could ever run out of places to try in the Fillmore area.
author: Shaina 'Occasionally Rahn' K.

description:
OMG. I am a south indian and I hail from the place were dosas and sambar were first made. This is the food I used to eat daily at home in India. I cannot believe how authentic the food was here! My husband and friends (all from s. india as well) were bowled over by the taste and richness of flavor. Trust me, this is as authentic as it gets! I felt like i was back home, eating my mom's food. yummm...I have been to the old dosa as well as this one several times. The food's awesome, service is good..what can I say..I love this place. 
Everything tastes good here, ofcourse, but we really enjoyed the different varieties of dosas and coconut rice. 

But it is almost always crowded and the waiting time can get really long. It is best to call ahead and make a reservation.
author: Rt H.

description: Had brunch here today and loved it! Delicious food, great mimosa, gorgeous interior and friendly, helpful service. Prices are very reasonable too. I'd eat here all the time if I lived close by.
author: Maria V.

description: Very tasty and appropriately sized meals.  The ambiance is nice but you are a little close.  If you have space issues this may not be the restaurant for you.  The service is okay, felt a little rushed like table turn over was a huge deal.  My rating though is based on the quality of the food which was quite good.
author: Halima T.

description:
me and my friend have been wanting to try this place for a while. i finally decided to make a reservation on july 4th.. it was a girl's day! i am sooo glad we came this day because the fillmore jazz festival was going on too.  

i ordered the paper masala and steph c. got the lamb curry.  i loved the paper masala!! it was huge too!! the potato was hella good. all the sauces were hella good! damn. i am kinda drooling just thinking about it! i cant wait to come back! =)
author: JUDY L.

description:
Previously reviewed Dosa in the summer of 2009 after my first visit to the restuarant.  I recently went back with a group of people and my experience was a bit better - though still not great.  

We arrived very early, so had a very attentive waitress at the beginning of the meal.  By the end of the meal, it was only the busboys coming by regularly.   My main complaint, and it was same last time I came, is that they load up the tables too much.  Rather than condensing some things together, we had to be constantly moving the plates around.  They left bottles of water on the table, and yet kept coming by to fill up the glasses.  During one of the passes, one of our full drinks was knocked over and while they cleaned it up very quickly, they did not bring another drink to replace the spilled one, and we were charged for the spilled drink.  Whenever this has happened ( not often, mind you) at a nice restuarant, they usually replace the drink.  

 I concur with some of the other reviews that they started taking plates off of the table while some of still had food on our plates.  Overall, food was good, but it would still not be my first choice Indian restuarant.  Just a little bit too much attitude.
author: Anne F.

description:
Very arrogant ! Called to make reservations for 6 and I was asked to give them a credit card number to hold the reservation. Their policy for charging $10 per head for parties of 5 or more for cancellations prior to 5pm same day is just ridiculously arrogant.

I never cancel without giving plenty of advance notice. But this is just insulting. Since when is a party of 6 a big party ? They just lost my business. Plenty of other places in the city where I don't have to put up with this attitude.
author: Atish S.

description: They've worked the new-restaurant kinks out - and it's back to being my favorite Indian restaurant in the city.  Love it!
author: Rose S.

description: I love dosas, I used to go to Udupi Palace in Bellevue, WA and loved it.  This place had great decor/feel to the place, but really the food (I had the Chutney Dosa) wasn't any better than the one in Bellevue which had tacky decor, and there was less food with less sauces for more cost.  Humm.  Not that impressed.  The host and waitress were friendly, but the wait on a Saturday night was over 30 minutes.  Good for those who want a swanky atmosphere or like South Indian (haven't found another place like that in SF yet) and don't mind lines and high prices.
author: Cara J.

description: I am not totally negative, but it is I think it is mostly show - kinda like a glorified I-Hop with some decent sauces.  Not an expert on South Indian food, and I have to give these guys credit for opening such a well done place and for doing well with it, but I am not sure I get the dosa thang.  The duaghters love it, but I have not been impressed with the food or price value.  Don't get stuck sitting upstairs - death.  The main room is fun and they have a good bar.
author: Glenn S.

description:
A 20-40 minute wait for a table turned into 1 1/2 hours with nary an apology.  The poor service took things downhill from there.

The food was mediocre at best.  A rare case of where SF is easily bested by S. Bay when it comes to tasty, authentic ethnic cuisine.

Too expensive for what you get.
author: RJ M.

description: You pay for the environment not really the food. Came here for the first time yesterday for Dine About Town and ordered the 3-course menu with the wine flight. 2 of the 3 courses were good, and 1 of the 3 wines was good. The atmosphere is cool. There are all sorts of people: business professionals, yoga students, friend groups, family groups, cute couples on dates, shoppers eating solo, etc...There is also nice music and a lot of attention (service), though it felt a little rushed for one that really likes to 'dine.' Basically, the food didn't deliver too much on taste, just presentation. If you are coming here for authentic Indian food look elsewhere. If you are coming for a chill place to grab pricey food then you will be content.
author: Meixing L.

description:
dosa on valencia was one of my favorite restaurants in the entire city.  but we didn't go too often because it is far away, it's such a long and annoying wait, and it's so expensive.

now a new dosa has opened up on the same street where i work.  i can go to dosa whenever i want.  for lunch, it's totally empty and even for dinner you can make reservations and you never have to wait outside in the cold while the hipsters pass you by.  the menu is pretty much the same but now i get to try more of it because even if i get something less than stellar i can always come back a few days later to atone for it.  the paper masala dosa is STILL my favorite but i've tried a bunch of the uttapams and other dosas and even some appetizers (the northern samosas are vegan and probably the best i've ever had) and all are delicious.  haven't tried the drinks yet as the liquid lunch is not condoned by my workplace.  

thank you jebus for answering my prayers and opening this restaurant in my neighborhood!
author: kate s.

description: This place is delicious.  Good menu, fresh food, good wine and a good atmosphere.  indian has to be one of the hardest styles of cuisine to get right and this place has nailed it on the head.  I would eat it every day if my tongue could handle the heat.
author: Sean M.

description:
Wait, this used to be a Goodwill store?!  When you walk into the new Dosa location in lower Pac Heights, you will be blown away, especially if you remember what it was like as a Goodwill.  The attention to detail from the lighting fixtures to the wall decorations are stunning.  There's a large print of an Olivier Follmi photo on the back wall that is breathtaking.  Anjan and his wife Emily have really outdone themself with the transformation of the space.  They even managed to add an upper level that's perfect for private parties.  No this is no shill, I've only met Anjan a few times and met his wife Emily last night, I'm just a huge fan of what they've done by elevating ethnic food and adding a contemporary flair to it (one day secretly hoping to do something like this for Chinese food myself).  They are both really warm hosts and I would love to see more restaurant owners interacting with their clientele like they do (the Quince owner was also very friendly).  We got to the restaurant and were seated right away (I made a reservation on OpenTable but it looks like there were still seats available since it was a Sunday night and I don't think people know it's opened yet.  

Now on to the food.  I am a big fan of the Valencia Dosa and had to introduce my friend to the dahi vada (lentil dumplings) and the dosas and uttapams.  This time I tried one of the many new additions to the menu that aren't available at the Mission location.  There are several new South Indian starters and entrees like the halibut from Anjan's mother's recipe.  We tried the crab vada which were South Indian crab cakes that were very flavorful and unique.  You could taste the spices infused with the crab meat with each bite.  We also went with the fish moilee which was a very nice mild curry that was slightly sweet from the coconut milk.  The two starters, the entree and the paper dosa were more than enough to fill both our tummies with South Indian heaven.  Total damage with glass of wine and tip was around $85.  Not bad at all.  The servers were definitely attentive as it's only their second week open and it seemed like there were 10 of them running around taking orders, serving food and filling water glasses.  Beautiful ambiance, delicious food and gracious hosts, you can't ask for much more than that.
author: Dave L.

description: What can I say that hasn't already been said?  Maybe a word of advice. Don't be put off by not having a reservation. Just show up and try to score a place at the bar.and enjoy an entertaining vibe from the mixologists and eat the same food from the menu.
author: graham h.

description: Wow, I was blown away, the service and food were delicious!  I don't know very much about Indian food, but our waitress couldn't have been more informative, without monopolizing the conversation, which is kinda a good trait after looking at the extensive menu.  I started with a non-alcoholic drink which was a wonderful mango/mint blend, the spicy shrimp starter and then a cilantro/mint dosa?  I would go back and try some more stuff - aside from that I was starving and they served us right away...kinda made me think of "fast food Indian"? - good?  yes! The atmosphere was beautiful...then you can walk across the street and catch a movie!
author: Heather P.

description:
My random thoughts on Dosa include:

1) How out of place is this place?  Huge vaulted ceilings, fancy lighting and decoration, lounge/techno music in the background...and a BK across the street that you can see through the oversized windows.  You can practically wave at the King from your table.

2) You must go to this place if only to try the turbocharged bathroom hand dryers.  In fact, if you go to a movie at the Kabuki please do the following.  Step 1: purchase large soda, or better yet, go to a movie in theatre one and consume 2-3 alcholic beverages during the movie.  Step 2: squirm in your seat during the last 15 minutes of the movie.  Step 3: Go across the street to Dosa for "a drink" and utilize the facilities.  Step 4: WASH YOUR HANDS PEOPLE!  Step 5: Utilize the hand dryer.  Step 6: Go to Mt. Zion Hospital (convienently located just a few blocks away) to have the skin from your hand reattached.  Cheers.

3) The food is good.  Very good in fact.  Buuuuttttttt so are a bunch of Indian places in the city that charge far less.  So, while you'll eat well here, you do pay a premium for the lounge/techno music playing while you eat.

4) Can't say I cared for the staff.  Our waiter was a little too opinionated about what we were ordering ("Wonderful Choice!"...."Uh, ok, if you want that...") and the hostess was less than stellar.  After telling us our table wasn't quite ready for our reservation, she invited us to grab a drink while we wait.  Fair enough.  10 minutes later it occurred to me that there were 243,123,552 people (numbers approximate) hanging out around the bar and I didn't see the hostess wading into that mob to grab people for their table.  When we went to check on the status of our table, we were told it was going to be a while.  I then reminded her that we had a reservation, at which point we were immediately seated.  So, while I've had much worse experiences and while I somewhat sympathize with the poor girl (there were A LOT of people trying to get seated) it wasn't the most professional experience I've ever had.

Peace
author: Jason S.

description:
as a lover of Indian food, i was curious to sample this regionally specific cuisine in an atmosphere quite unlike your more "typical" buffet-style Indian restaurant...
*bright, lovely dining room.
*delicious un-sweetened (soy) chai.
*classic samosas with tasty chutneys.
*scrumptious egg dishes are perfect for "brunch" - generous portions mean you may want to skip appetizers or share!
author: Anna S.

description: Awsome place! Definitely a must to visit at least once! Great cocktails, really good food, friendly servers... Yes, a little pricey, but it's worth. It deserves 4 stars. Go!
author: Mike S.

description: The food quality is very consistent with its sister location in the Mission. The one big difference is the ambiance of this location, which is far more modern and trendy. I can see myself hitting this trendier looking location for some cocktails after work.
author: Sandy Y.

description: This place is brilliant.  Many of the chefs are from my town in India.  I tell my friends that this place is better than most Dosa joints in India.
author: Radesh G.

description: South Indian Moons with Fire Broth to reap the taste whirlwind.
author: John M.

description: I liked the food but felt everything was overpriced.  The portion was kind of small for the price, too.  The price would be more like for the venue (It does have a nice atmosphere)...
author: M Y.

description: I LOVED this place. We did the tasting menu and it was delicious food, and good sized portions. I would go back to this restaurant in a heartbeat. The atmosphere was pretty hip and although it was crowded, the wait staff took their time explaining the menu. We loved their cocktails although they were $10-$15 bucks. Can't wait to go again.
author: Susan C.

description:
This place is fabulous! I think the best Indian I have had in SF to date...You must try a dosa, which by the way, I had never had before going to Dosa. 
The plates are not huge but very filling so dont over order like we did...unless of course you like left overs...I usually never take home left overs, but it was so good that I felt obliged!
For the doubters....just try it!  It's worth it!
author: Caroline K.

description: I just got back from Dosa's NYE dinner at Fillmore.  This was my first time at the new location.  All I can say is WOW! WOW! WOW!  Both the food and setting are amazing here!  Sorry Valencia but I am sticking with your sister location, Fillmore, even though it is further away from where I work and live. Unlike Valencia, they take reservations for ANY party size.  Anjan and Emily, you have done a fantastic job with the place!  The only thing I would suggest is maybe putting some wall art and paper towels in addition to the fancy hand dryers in the bathrooms. I can't wait to entertain my family and friends at this location.
author: C L.

description: Dosa's great. We come sometimes after the Sundance. The room is spacious in a warm way, and the food is tasty.  I like a lot of things but the only ones I can remember at the moment -- and they don't sound too good together, I'm not recommending that -- are the beet soup and the coffee. Some of the tables are really close so sometimes you'll get stuck next to someone who you'd wish would just not go on and on  louder and louder as he worked his way through one drink after another...but that was only once.  There is a real mix of people here, perhaps b/c of the movie theatre, but usually that's a good thing.
author: jen n.

description: Dosa's impressive size makes a statement as much as its menu. If you're gonna reshape a former Goodwill into a restaurant, this is the way to do it. The atmosphere is comforting and the service attentive. The food: delicious. We started with the chopped salad, the samosas and the dumplings in yogurt. The salad was refreshing and the dumplings and samosas were perfect companions. Next we had the masala dosa and baingan bharta. The chutney's accompanying the dosa were beyond comparison. Another plus is their wine list, which is well-paired with the menu. My only gripe is they were out of Kingfisher. Really?
author: Jason A.

description:
What a great space, high ceilings that go up past the second floor dining room. Big bar, large dining space and a communal table, too. All in all, a very grand feel, quite different for the small cosier space of the restaurant's Mission location. Now on to the food - Very good, well presented, clean and fresh... a little on the pricey side. The samosas were great, as was the goat curry with lemon rice. But the star was the masala dosa. So delicious, I need to go back and try their other dosas. And very large and filling too. 
Beers are a bit high priced for what they are (a sierra for $6?), but you are paying for the space and the atmosphere, I guess...
And the music was club-y the night we went... I hope it's not like that all the time...
I would probably just opt for their other location next time. Equally delicious food without the club atmosphere... 
Still a very good overall dining experience.
author: Chris D.

description:
For my money I'll take traditional Indian over this pricier, Southern-Indian restaurant any day.  
The food was good and fresh but did not blow me away.
We started with a garbanzo/asparagus salad.  It was nice and fresh, but nothing I couldn't create at home.
Next came the Cochin Calamari.  Probably the highlight of the meal.  I love grilled calamari and the sauce that came with it was nice.
For our mains we got the Spinach/Fennel Dosas, Chicken & Eggplant 'Baingan Bharta, and the Mangalorean Prawn Masala.  Nothing blew me away.  Everything was good but nothing gave me that "melt in your mouth" flavor that traditional Indian does.
My major gripe was the Bhatura.  I love naan and this stuff didn't come close.  It was chewy and didn't complement our meal at all.  I love soaking my bread in the yummy juices at the end of a good Indian meal and this was not possible.  
We got the dessert, nothing special.
