The service was okay.  We asked for our leftovers to be boxed up and they didn't bring them back.  Probably wouldn't have eaten them anyway...
I will be going to my local family run Indian joint over Dosa from now on.
author: Peter H.

description: Beautiful atmosphere and attentive service.  The food was better than average, but I kind of expected the food to be excellent.  The Chicken Korma was a little bit too salty.
author: George S.

description: We love this place.  The best part is that we bring out of town clients and guests to the Fillmore location.  Both sets of people are always impressed.  The rest of the reviews regarding the food speak for themselves!
author: R and S.

description: I had dinner here with a few friends and the place is beuatiful - open and bright with a great ambience. The food was not a disappointment either. It was alittle different that some of the Indian food that I have experienced in the past - but I'm Italian, so what do I know? All I know is what tastes good and this place def. does. I loved the dosa's (it was my first time eating them) - here are so many to choose from. I also introduced my table to Paratha and Raita - which were both excellent here. The lamb chops (app) were equally yummy - juicy tender and tasty. Yum. This place is worth the trip - excellent for a group of friends or a great date night. OH! I also forgot the drink menu! I am slipping in my old age :-) IThe menu is full of fun creative cocktails that are STRONG. I downed a couple "Bollywood Hills" - hmmm...maybe that's why the food tasted so good...
author: Jess W.

description:
I had lunch here today with a collegue. I was initially shocked at the decor and ambiance.....when I lived near Fillmore a few years ago this area was pretty spotty to say the least.  Well this restaurant really spruces the intersection up.
I had a lamb 'frankie' (sort of a lamb meatball wrap) and the gunba nanoon dessert.  Delightfully different and tasty all at once.
I want to go here for after work drinks...
author: Craig M.

description: Dosa is one of my favorite restaurant in the bay area, they really know how to take care of their customers and keep the real authentic taste with the charming cozy upscale decor...I CAN NOT wait for them to open up in pac heights! Its a week after thanksgiving!! Check it out
author: Natasha R.

description: Think "Madras Cafe" with a great ambiance and that's Dosa on Fillmore. The look-n-feel of the place was quite impressive and for a moment we had to double check if we had entered a wrong restaurant (if you visited any of the Indian restaurants in the South Bay, you'll understand what I'm talking about where the focus is solely on the food and very little on the aesthetics). The menu was typical South Indian --- it had dosa and curd rice among other things : - ). We had the masala dosa, which was decent. It actually looked more like a wrap of some sort than a traditional dosa. The sambar and chutneys were okay. The best part was that it was open quite late and we went there at around midnight after attending a show in Oakland. This place is good for a one-time visit - no regrets.
author: Sridhar D.

description:
Hmmm...

1) I felt like I walked into a restaurant inside the Venetian Hotel.  Too trendy and I expected to see P Diddy in the corner at his reserved table with a bottle of Ciroc Vodka...the lighting was great, not the lights.

2) Now onto the food.  Do not order the Dahi Vada unless you like to poke around for dumplings buried in two inches of heavy sauces overpowered by sour yoghurt.  The Kerala Fish Moilee coupled with coconut rice was exceptional and for what we ordered the saving grace of the meal.

3) The service was really attentive and fast.

I would go back if it were a "paid for" meal with friends or a business meal, other than that it's not worth hunting for street parking and spending over $100 for two (2 glasses of wine, 2 apps, 1 dosa, and 1 main entree).

-RileyOman
author: Riley O.

description: This place is a perfect blend of Indian and Western culture. You'ill never feel like that you are away from home, infact this is home away from home. Whenever i visit SFO, i always make sure to make atleast one visit to Dosa.
author: Ro R.

description: Cool space and set up. I like the higher ceilings and decor. The food was ok... the dosas were quite good but everything else I ordered was mediocre. I guess overall I'm not the biggest fan of South Indian food. I loooove Indian food but I enjoy meat way too much and South Indian food is definitely light on the meat. The dahi vadi (lentil dumplings) and chicken biryana were ok... probably wouldn't get them again. If you're in the mood for vegetarian then great, otherwise you've got a limited menu.  The service was good though and I did enjoy their curried bloody mary.
author: shadi m.

description: A group of us met there for a business reunion last night had a great time.  The service, food and wine were all awesome.  The staff was gracious and patient as our group slowly arrived, many of us coming from out of town.  Our meal started with calamari, samosas, lamb kebab all good...we had a variety of delicious curries and dosa that I can't name since our waitress picked out most of it for us.   We also had a great bottle of 2004 Barolo that she picked for our table! Who knew an Indian restaurant would have such an eclectic wine list.  At the end of the evening our waitress said that she was off and someone else would be taking care of us.  When I told her we would like to close out with her she said that they were a 'pool house' so it was unnecessary.  She even came back to make sure we were ok and gave us Scotch suggestions. Perhaps more restaurants should do this to ensure good service.
author: Lib H.

description: AWFUL SERVICE. Waiter's name was Zach and from the get-go he made us feel rushed and he would shake his head when we wouldnt order exactly how he suggested. We wanted the DOSA first for our group and he said that is not the way its done there (with attitude). Then he told me to put my phone and camera away to make room on table! Mind you, the camera and phone are super slim and were not in the way.  He set a very negative and rushed tone. You can tell he just wanted to get us out so he can get another group in.  He never checked in with us to see how we were doing.  It was such a shame that gratuity was included in our bill because he did not deserve it. Totally put a damper on our girls group dinner!!!! I will not go back again.  The manager did not seem to care very much when I spoke to her. She did get us a round of drinks but that was not the point. Waiter acted like if nothing the remainder of the evening and did not apologize.
author: Veronica P.

description: I've been to both the Fillmore and Mission locations and absolutely prefer this one, more space and a better vibe. No matter how often I go I still cant understand the menu, but the servers never steer me wrong and I always get to try something new! Fun place to take out of towners because it feels 'different' from traditional Indian fair. Love it and I'll be back (to the Fillmore one at least).
author: Carl M.

description: Great food.  I knocked off a star because it's pretty expensive.  The shrimp tikka masala is friggin great!
author: Jeffrey H.

description:
the food was good. i ordered the veggie curry. all of my friends ordered dosa. all the flavors were yummy. but nothing to brag about. although i did love the chips they give you.

the service sucked! our waiter didn't even tell us his name or smile once. it took him forever to take our order, we finished our appetizers before we even ordered our entrees. he took forever to bring our cocktails and took forever to come check on us, to see if we liked our food. 

they also seated us in the middle of two tables, leaving no space for anyone to walk thru, causing the to ask my friend to move so they could get by! wtf?!? isn't that a fire hazard? 

i will not be coming here again.
author: Kristine T.

description: Best Indian food in the bay area! Lots of vegan options! knowledgeable staff, great food, great atmosphere.
author: Critic M.

description: I heart this place. The ambiance is super classy, the service has always been great and if you can't get a reservation you can always kick back with a few Bengali Gimlets at the bar. What not to miss? Laura F. and I dig that red beet cumin soup and just tried the garbanzo and avocado salad for the first time last month and it was really light--but still filling--just the type of combination I'm looking for. Added bonus? Last time I was there the people watching was fab, think: furrys and sailors.
author: Somer F.

description: Could it be that this location on Fillmore isn't run by the same folks that run Dosa on Valencia?  What a difference!  Yes, the menu items seem almost the same as at the Valencia location and they serve some interesting mixed drinks at this site, but the food quality was so disappointing.  For example, the calamari dish had been one of my favorites at Valencia, but it wasn't even lukewarm this night.  Perhaps we would drop in for a cocktail in the future, but skip the food next time.
author: John G.

description: DOSA has opened a second restaurant on Fillmore and it is spectacular. The menu has more items than before. There is a full bar. The décor is amazing. The space is wide and has a great open feeling. There is a very large communal table. Of course, the real reason to go there is for the food. I have been a loyal follower of DOSA since it's opening in the Mission. FYI, I am a south Indian and the food tastes like "mama used to make!" I can't get enough.
author: Sirish M.

description: I somehow have not come to this Dosa, loving the valencia spot since it opened never thought to come to this one, as if I am here I am eating other places...but the time had come and in we went to the one time salvation army headquarters on Filmore...BTW they are across the street now...salvation army that is...nice space, dosa not salvation army...busy-both...great cocktails! some interesting ideas on the list and very helpful waiter who seems to like to drink here as well... ..ummm that sounds like he was drinking on the job..not...just seemed to actually have had the drinks I ordered... to the food... hmmmmn... sadly not up to the motherships flavors but...it has been 2 years since I was at valencia so maybe I am wrong or mis remembering? the Pakoras this day tasted like mrs pauls fish sticks in pakora batter... the masala dosa was ok VIks Chaat better.. the squid ...I want some tentacles with my tubes...the sauces were fine the uppadum was just ok but...this was good Chaat from south india and I am just being picky... I wont repeat this location but that doesnt mean you shouldnt check in here...
author: Ricote F.

description:
I am wanting to give this new Dosa five stars, but three of my dining partners all tapped out on the lamb curry, so the sampling of the entrees was less than global.  What was served was splendid.  My samosas were fresh, clearly quick-fried in clean oil (don't take that for granted in some of the less-pricey indian joints around the city).  The spring dosa was scrumptious, in a word.  The dipping sauces balanced and intense.  I had a gin cocktail (I still can't spell, but it should be the name of a recently formed country of the former Soviet Union.   I'm not a gin fan, but this was subtle, infused with mint and darjeeling tea.  This could so rock a summer party...  Seriously.  I felt positively Raj sipping on the drink and noshing on my dosa.  The deserts were classic indian and light years above what get in less-expensive restaurants.  The rosewater syrup for my golub jamuh finally made sense after the hard crusted variations that haunt all-you-can eat buffets.  The syrup was complex with hints of cardoman and cinammon (but only hits) and the dough itself was light and airy... and warm.  Makes all the diff.

Our waitress was prompt and friendly, dispensing much menu wisdom and was greatly appreciated.  The front of the house got us to our table 10 minutes after our reservation (and the place was packed).  It loks good and the Sundance is just across the street.  

All in all, a splendid addition to a slowly transforming Lower Fillmore area.
author: philip c.

description:
i love the decor of this place and it's spacious! had the Blue Lake Green Bean 'Bhajia for starters - good because of the dipping sauces that came with it, but prolly not get it again. nothing special. and had the Jumbo Prawns Masala and a dosa (Masala) and it was really yum! the dosa was my fav - would love to go try other options on the menu. 

knocking off a few stars because while the environment is nice, i've had better indian food elsewhere (in a more ghetto setting, but still). and also, the service was TOO attentive. i met a friend for dinner and we didn't see each other for a long time so we had a lot of catching up to do! we were in very serious convo but was interrupted a gazillion times by the waiter. now, i appreciate good service but it was overly annoying that night - the waiter literally came every 10 minutes or so.
author: Lucy C.

description: I finally got to try this out (drinks only) last week.  Visually, it's beautiful-- as my friend said "it looks more like a club than a restaurant".  The drinks were yummy. We came in for just one and ended up trying 2 each, then topped it off with Dosa's yummy rasmalai dessert.  Great addition to the area-- can't wait to go back.
author: shoba d.

description:
Nom-na-nom-nom-nom.  Yep, that pretty much sums it up!

I went to Dosa last weekend with my boyfriend and his family, which allowed us to sample many things on the menu.  First, the food.  As an appetizer, we shared the Spinach and Fennel Porriyal Dosa, which came with Sambar (lentil dipping soup).  The flavors were numerous and complex, but not too spicy - I could definitely eat the Sambar on it's own!  We also shared some Paratha - so buttery, and just fabulous.  For dinner, we shared the South Indian Moons Uttapam (chef's choice of 5 different Uttapams), Bagara Baingan (Baby egglant with peanut sauce, sesame seeds...) with lemon rice, Chicken Korma with coconut rice and a duck/saag dish (cannot remember the name).  There wasn't one dish that we didn't like - I didn't find the food too spicy at all, and never felt like the flavors were "too much" or overloaded.  I balanced my palate with some mint lemonade - which was very fresh, and not too sweet.  Unfortunately, we were too full for dessert.  Overall, the food was amazing, came in good portions, and was served such that it was easy to share.

The restaurant itself held a certain ambiance to it that was very welcoming.  We were lucky and had dinner early, before the dinner crowd rush, so it wasn't too loud or busy.  The chandeliers added to the ambiance, as did the colorfully painted walls.  Definitely enjoyed the whole visual and food experience at Dosa.
author: Shannon W.

description: What a wonderful restaurant on Fillmore St.  This was my first time dining at DOSA, and as soon as I entered the doors was greeted by friendly staff.  The inside of the restaurant is gorgeous, with exaggerated ceiling height and beautiful lighting.  The food - simply delicious.  It has been too long since I have been to a restaurant and enjoyed everything I tried.  We were a table of five and ordered a variety of items including the Dosa, chutneys, seafood, duck, uttapam, and coconut rice.  Everything has vibrant flavors and perfectly complimented one another.  The duck vindaloo had a great kick and tons of flavor.  By far the stand out of the evening.  Service could not have been any better.  Very friendly, knowledgeable, and attentive staff.  Aside from not having one dish that I was really looking forward to (sardines marinated in chile, cilantro, and turmeric) the experience was the perfect beginning to a San Francisco evening.  Highly recommend.
author: Tye B.

description:
This is a great date place. The ambiance is very nice. I took a first date here and we both had a great time. I had read the reviews about the place being loud, so when I made a reservation I asked about it. The lady was very accomodating, saying they had some tables that were quieter than others and that she would us there. The table was great, right in front of the windows, and while there was one occassion where it got difficult to hear, overall it wasn't too bad. The overall ambiance more than made up for it. The service overall was phenomenal, and the food was very good. We did the price fixe for 4 courses, which was plenty enough food for us even though it is smaller portions. The service was amazing. They continuously filled our glasses with water and checked in on us, and we were there for over 2 1/2 hours during peak time without feeling rushed in the least.

The music in the background is top 40ish which seems odd for the ambiance. We noticed it and it made us chuckle.

Parking is a challenge! I looked for over 20 minutes while my date waited inside. Valet would definitely make this place better. I couldn't even find a garage, so locate one ahead of time. Even with the parking, the experience was worth the trouble.
author: Ronda B.

description:
My wife and I arrived yesterday night at around 5:30pm asking for a table for 5. Our friends were in the area looking for parking and we were hoping that we could sit down first. Although the restaurant was nearly empty, we were asked to wait for about 15 minutes instead of getting seated right away. I felt like Ben Stiller in "Meet the Parents" in the scene where he was asked to wait to board the flight when no one else was getting on the plane! Of course, in the meantime, we were badgered by the hostess confirming with us whether or not our friends were on their way. When our friends did arrive, and we were by then deciding whether or not we wanted to just eat at the bar or do a sit-down dinner, 2 hostesses and a waiter were pushing us to have a seat at that point! Needless to say, my first impression was not very good as the staff were interrupting a quick conversation among friends deciding what we wanted to do. I understand they wanted us to sit down and get that mandatory 20% tip for parties of 5 or more, but c'mon! They might as well have acted like the hostess at Claw in the movie "Date Night" where they would answer their telephone by saying, "Welcome to Dosa, you're welcome!"

The food is good with small portions and pricey, but that is what you would probably expect here given the decor. Our wait staff was friendly enough, but she was obviously displeased when we were just having appetizers and drinks (hey, we wanted to sit at the bar!).

So overall, the food is decent, albeit pricey, but the hostesses could definitely do a better job at being a lot less snooty! It could have been a one time thing given the other reviews, but I'm not planning on going back anytime soon.
author: Anthony W.

description: Came back recently and sat at the bar.  The service was vastly improved and I'm hoping its not just because I was right in front of the bartender.  I still found the food somewhat bland and overpriced.  I was also very impressed that the restaurant contacted me to let me know they'd discussed my concerns regarding the service with the staff.
author: She-Ra ..

description: If you have food sensitivities, Dosa is your friend. I'm gluten and dairy-free and eating out is tough. Not to mention eating great food can be tough. We went here for my birthday, and my husband noted that I was GF and DF when making the reservation. They discreetly included a special menu listing everything they had on the current menu and whether or not it had gluten or dairy, or nuts...It was so helpful and I didn't have to feel high-maintenance and ask what I could eat. It was so nice. Our server, Kelly was so nice too. Every dish was delicious. We never felt rushed and the space was big and roomy but never too loud. Loved it! Will definitely go back for more.
author: Lindsay H.

description: Came here for a birthday lunch. Gotta say that I like how the place look.. modern Indian! Ha!, but they have a little cozy corner with some kind of couch. Cute.  The food is pretty good and the prices are good (cheaper) during lunch time. Me and a friend shared everything and we were really full afterward. The drink... could be good, but mine was too strong!!! It was like drinking bourbon on the rock! But, like I said.. came here for the food and I am a fan!
author: Daisy S.

description: Dosa totally changed my perspective view on Indian food.  I usually refuse to eat any type of Indian food at all, due to me disliking the strong smell of the spices they use for Indian food.  But Dosa totally changed my view on Indian food, and I gotta say it's actually one of the best food I have in the city. Definitely a place to comeback  to when I'm around the neighborhood.
author: KC K.

description:
Suggested that an out of town cousin passing through San Francisco for the day meet me for lunch here.  I'm not a huge fan of Indian food, but I do like lunching on Fillmore Street.  

What a great space!  This place is beautiful... high ceilings and huge windows to allow the flood of sunshine permeate a spacious and warmly decorated interior.  I felt so classy here!

I enjoyed the chicken biryani, but not enough that I would want to come back to this place just to have it again.  I think the ideal would be to come here with a smallish group of people (maybe 4-6) including someone who knows Indian food well enough to be able to help order for the table.  The server was friendly and encouraged me to try the biryani, but I almost feel like she would have been positive about any dish I would have asked about.  I really don't know too much about Indian, so I think that significantly impacted my appreciation for a meal here.

In general, this is one of the more respected places for Indian cuisine in the Bay Area, so I think it's probably just as good as it's 4-star rating.
author: Lindsay M.

description: Simply put, it's Lovely.  Dosa on Fillmore ranks as my favorite restaurant in the entire city, and it's had that distinction for a few years now.  And it's for good reason: The food is Excellent; beautifully-prepared, the service is wonderful, and it's an absolutely beautiful space: lighting, decor, furniture, setup.  All the stars are in alignment.  Every person I've ever brought here (and there have been a few) has become a convert.  I can't speak highly enough about it.  It never gets old for me, and that's good, considering how frequently I go there.  So glad that this place is within walking distance from my apartment!
author: Eric H.

description:
Ambiance:  Very nice setting and atmosphere, with big windows looking out on to the street and seating on the 2nd floor.  

Service:  Waiters were very helpful on giving us good recommendations and made sure all of our food tasted good, bad news: we had a reservation at 7:30, got seated at 7:50.

Food:  Food was excellent, all of our dishes tasted great.  Although I recommend Aslam Rasoi over this place though, for even better food.
author: Bryan T.

description: I have been here twice. The first time, I went with someone who lived in India for eleven years, she said that it was pretty authentic. We went again a couple of nights ago and had the veggie dosa and a chicken curry. I personally thing that everything is a little too salty and pretty spicy. It was pretty good while we were eating but later we both had tummy aches. Not good! So a mixed review on this one. Convient location and decent food but made me sick!
author: Lauren M.

description: Today was my second time having dinner at Dosa... the food is incredible!! Their wine selection is pretty good as well... I was in heaven... Went with my mom who have never had Indian food before and she loved it! We had the spring dosa and tamil lamb curry yummmy! Ah! it is very affordable as well...
author: J S.

description: This restaurant is so spacious and I love the decor. Definitely does not feel like you are in San Francisco. The chandeliers and the capiz shells are beautiful. This location is definitely more airy and amped up from its Mission location.  The food is also very delicious. I didn't do the ordering, so I have no idea of the names of the dishes that I had. The dosas with potatoes were yummy as well as the eggplant and boneless chicken curry dish. We asked for coconut rice but they gave lemon instead, which was just fine. The crowd is very pac heights and lower pac heights.
author: Natalie S.

description: My family and I were intrigued by this restaurant because of it's beautiful exterior, and the extravagant chandeliers you can see through the windows.  The restaurant was completely filled; the bar area and the whole dining area.  We were all excited to eat because of how lively, packed, and extravagant the restaurant was.  We ordered our appetizers and were kind of shocked at how spicy the calamari was!  I understand that Indian food tends to be on the spicier side, but this was uncontrollable.  We were hoping the duck, shrimp and chicken plates we ordered would make up for the appetizer but sadly they did not.  The duck plate only included the leg meat which was upsetting because of the high price we paid for it.  The chicken was way too spicy and the shrimp was the only satisfying dish.  My dad actually talked to the waitor because of how little duck meat we had in our 'duck dish.'  On top of all that, each of my family members including myself became sick when we got home.  Great place for drinks/bar scene but I wouldn't recommend for actually eating there.
author: Francesca M.

description:
A solid three stars for me.  We had 8:15pm reservations for a Friday night.  We couldn't find street parking so settled for parking in the Japantown garage, which we hadn't been to in years.  We were at the restaurant on time and it was packed in there.  Tons of people at the bar, communal table full, people milling around the entrance.  We worked our way to the hostess and were told our table wasn't ready because they were running behind, but there were quite a few tables paying.  So we found a seat at the end of the long bench they have running from the entrance to the back of the restaurant.  We weren't sure the hostess knew where we had gone and were wondering if we should go back and let her know after we'd been waiting 25 minutes, but someone came over to us and let us know our table would be ready very soon.  That was very good in our book.  We were seated very shortly after that to a table that was kind of in the middle of everything.  It was 3 of us at a table of 4.  Because there was that one empty seat, everyone, and I mean EVERYONE, decided that was the best place to walk through.  I can't begin to tell you how many times our table was bumped or I was hit with someone's bottom or someone's purse.  THAT wasn't very cool.  The tables there aren't that close together, but I guess they were close enough that everyone decided they can only walk through the middle where our table was and bump into it.

The food was actually pretty tasty.  The chips they give (rather than bread) was a nice touch.  We ordered the calamari starter, which was very small, but quite tasty.  We ended up dipping our chips in the sauce, which was really good.  For my entree, I had the masala dosa.  I'd never had a dosa before so I figured I'd go with the classic.  When it came, it was HUGE.  Our server was really nice and explained how we were supposed to eat our dosas.  We really liked her.  She came to check on us often and was especially nice.  I forget what we had for dessert.  It was like coconut and saffron in a philo wrap with some candied kiwis or something.  That was pretty interesting.  I'd have to say I liked the kiwis the best out of the dessert though.

AMBIANCE:  Very nice.  You'd never know it used to be Goodwill.  They really did a great job with it.  And I love the lighting!  There's an upstairs section that we didn't go to, but I'd love to see how that looks as well.

To sum it up, I might go back.  It's not too expensive and the food isn't that bad.  I'd definitely want to be seated somewhere where our table wasn't constantly being bumped though.
author: Kris L.

description: I can't get over how much I LOVE the lemon rice. Unfortunately, I'm not that big of fan of the dosa's but I think it's more of a preference thing. What I absolutely enjoyed were the entree dishes--cilantro and chile fish, curry lamb, and peppercorn chicken. Service was friendly but not that attentive; we had to ask for plate change and the wine list after we finished our glasses but our server did look really busy. Decor is gorgeous. Beautiful art work all over. Very different vibe from Dosa's in the Mission District, Dosa on Fillmore definitely is more modern but maintains the same delicious food.
author: Royce L.

description:
Having failed to get in to a restaurant down the street, my party happened to walk by Dosa at just the right time, and we were seated immediately during the dinner rush on a Friday night. Very lucky!
The place was packed, but our service did not suffer much. We ordered a round of their specialty cocktails; the flavors were fun and unique even if a little unexpected. One member of our party was surprised to taste the bright acidity of a gastrique in his mango beverage.
We started with two soups: the beet soup was rich, smooth, brightly colored, and tasted just as it should have--like beets. I preferred the roasted red pepper and coconut milk soup, which tasted like a Thai curry without the rice. I liked it so much I had a hard time sharing.
The dosas were wonderful, even by the strict standards of our Indian friends, who grew up on their mother's homemade dosas. My duck, spinach, and paneer entree was good, though perhaps a little heavy on the cloves and anise. I tried with with both the lemon and coconut flavored rices, and found that the flavor of the rice made little difference to the assertive curry. My husband's fish entree was a bit lighter, and was wonderful with the coconut rice.
Overall, the decor and ambiance combined with the pulsing techno music made this place a little too trendy for me, but I'd love to try the other location sometime because the food was great.
author: Courtney K.

description: I went to Dosa for a drink with friends. I was surprised by a very nice bar space and a great place to mingle. The appetizers were delicious and the drinks were well made. This place is a nice place to stop by before a show at the Filmore. I cannot wait to try a dinner here.
author: alex l.

description: Great food great loacation. my trip to  kaibuki theater also include dinner at dosa.
author: Jong L.

description: After I came back from India my friends really wanted me to try out this restaurant and tell them whether I thought it was authentic, because they had fallen in love with it. We waited FOREVER to get a table (like 1.5 hours), drinking Kingfisher at the bar (authentic), and by the time we were seated, it was totally worth the wait. We ordered a masala dosa, the Indian crispy "crepe" with spiced potatoes inside, and a curry that was divine with the perfect mix of spice and buttery creamy goodness. The dosa was very similar to what you would get at Chutney's in Hyderabad (minus the banana leaf serving platter), and this restaurant did a good job of South Indian in a more upscale atmosphere. I would definitely recommend this to any Indian food-lovers in the city who haven't already tried it.
author: Ashley R.

description: I've been going to Dosa for a few years now. I've been a huge fan of South Indian food for the past decade. Unfortunately most of the Indian restaurants in the bay area are North Indian. I've been going to Dasaprakash in Santa Clara all these years, but it's nice to have something closer and in SF proper for a change. Dosa is a bit Amercanized, but I like their take on it, especially considering they have a full bar and trendy ambiance. I have yet to be disappointed with the food, but I will say that I don't like the reservation process. I've waited 30-45 minutes on multiple occasions when I've had dinner reservations. Lunch is less chaotic. I was there this past Friday and it was super chill. We started out with mojitos from the bar, Mango & Goat Cheese salad, Prawn Chile Fry, & Samosas 'North & South'. All very good and highly recommended. For an entree we shared the Paper Masala which is huge. Between 2 people this was plenty of food and we even had some left overs. We had a couple desserts as well, but I can't remember their names. One had pistachios in it and the other was  something with passion fruit. Both very good, but on opposite ends of the taste spectrum. The passion fruit was very tart and the pistachio one was sweet/blandish. I probably would pass on the pistachio one next time. Otherwise everything was great. Hope Dosa sticks around for a while.
author: S A.

description: It's a beautiful restaurant. The food was good. Good because I've indulged in mouth-watering Indian meals at hole-in-the walls in the tenderloin. The one memorable thing from our meal was the Belgian Lambic raspberry beer. *Salivating*
author: Ramona P.

description: Mmmmh. This place is so tasty. It's definitely 'in fashion' so the crowd is according, but I won't lie to you, the food is great. Also it's really convenient for dinner before or after your movie in the Kabuki.
author: Alexandra D.

description: Great ambiance. Their dosas and uttapams are great. I wish their sambar had a few more good bits of yummy veggies in it-- it's a bit watery. Service is good. It's also a bit pricey.
author: Sue P.

description: Way to open a second location, Dosa!  And bigger IS better
author: Nicole K.

description:
The hubby and I came here the other night for a date night... we wanted to try something different and hey... we hadn't been to Dosa before. In fact, I haven't been a huge fan of Indian food. Probably because I haven't had great Indian food.

Until that night.

The dinner started of fantastic. Our server (I'll call her "A") was warm and friendly and really seemed confident in her menu knowledge. She was great in guiding us as far as how much to order. We started with these delicious crab cakes and the duo of Samosas. Yum. The habenero sauce was a bit (no wait, way too) spicy. Egads. Then we shared the lamb curry with lemon rice and the spring dosa. I LOVED the spring dosa. It was fantastic. The lamb curry was good, but too spicy for me. At some point during the dinner Server A let us know that Server B was going to take over. Server B, barely checked in on us. When someone else walked by to see how things were we told them that the lamb curry was a bit spicy. They offered some yogurt raita to cool it down. How nice! What wasn't nice was they neglected to tell us it was $4.50 for that. I don't care if it Strauss or whatever. It's yogurt. A small side isn't worth $4.50.

We opted to skip dessert, so no comment. Nothing looked that appetizing.

In the end, I liked the food but the service was a bit all over the place. I can't say if I'll be back or not.
author: J B.

description: Paneer & Peas Dosa was excellent. They also have very original cocktails. Exquisite ambiance.
author: Thomas K.

description:
Dosa is in a great location across from the Sundance Kabuki Theater. It is always busy (reservation recommended) and I thought we should try it. So here's the good and bad in a nutshell:

The good: The ambiance - The restaurant is beautiful and stylish, with two-level seating. A great place to take your date.
The service - these servers were on fire! Constantly refilling waters, folding my boyfriend's napkin when he left to go to the restroom, great food descriptions from our server.
The price - really reasonable for the dosas (avg. $10), okay for the curries (avg. $15)
Nice touches to the food - Organic chicken and real shaved coconut in the rice.

The bad: The overly salted food. We had the Chennai Chicken (appetizer), Chutney Masala Dosa, and the Chicken Korma. All the dishes, especially the chennai chicken and the dosa with it's various dipping sauces tasted like someone had upended an entire bottle of salt onto each of our dishes. We absolutely loved everything else about the restaurant, but were sorely disappointed by this! 

That is why it gets 3 stars. After all, what is a restaurant if its food doesn't taste good?
author: Holly G.

description: This place is fantastic !   I absolutely loved the decor, the bar, and the menu !!!  it is a great location next to the Kabuki theaters which makes for a fun evening of dinner and a movie.  Again, the food is to die for.
author: jennifer w.

description:
Ambiance was off the charts awesome.  Service at bar a little spotty. Bartender didn't notice empty glasses.  No share plates with an item she recommended which was very saucey... and dripping all over the bar as the two of us tried to eat it.  really?  
Then the chana masala: great flavor, but felt strangely bloated after only a couple bites, maybe it was the deep fried bread (which was orgasmic).  Felt grossly full all night, even though we only shared 1 app and 1 entre.  Then the next day... strange gastrointestinal issues.  I have an iron clad stomache and can eat half a horse, so this was a very disappointing reaction to their food.  I wish I could rave about it, cause the ambiance and flavor were all spot on.
author: mike t.

description: food is really tasty. ambience is good too. must try for everyone.
author: Shiva P.

description: We were lucky to be there on their opening night.  My mate and I were just passing by before we hit the late night movie and looking for the place to eat. It is a beautiful place especially inside and do go there with your date!!  I don't know what does it (probably the lighting) u and ur date will look 1900% more attractive. It does not hurt that their food is very delicate and I am sure u all enjoy great customer service and jet handdryer/blower in the restroom which make your hand dry in matter of 2.8 seconds.
author: k o.

description: Went there last night to celebrate a friend's upcoming wedding.  The staff were great, especially our server Chris who treated us like royalty. He put the bride-to-be's flowers in a vase on the table, comped us dessert, came up with an appropriate quote about marriage and even donned one of our extra feather boas when he took our order :)  The building itself is stunning. They've done a wonderful job with the rennovations and interior design. We started off with drinks, my favorite of which was the Juhu Palm - delicious if you like coconut milk and spice.  We got an assortment of food all of which was tasty and well spiced. Enjoy!
author: Rakefet L.

description: What a fantasic resturant...another reason to be a proud resident of the ever popular NOPA-Western Addition neighborhood.  After a long awaited opening, they have created a fantastic addition to the Fillmore resturant row.  I was already a fan of the Mission location, but the staff and decor have really raised the bar.  The food is similar to the ones served in the Mission, albeit a bit more refined in presentation...mmmm pillowy, indian crepes.  I love carbs.
author: Vince B.

description: Really nice atmosphere, yummy food, creative drinks, good service.  I like everything about DOSA except that it runs about $80-100 for dinner for two, and that's withOUT drinks - ouch.  I recently decided to go for the "tasting menu" which is cool because you get to try four different things in smaller portions.  It's a great way to experience the menu if it's new to you.  I've been to DOSA at least a dozen times and my favorite dishes have been the Chennai chicken, the dahi vadas, the spring dosa, and the prawns in curry.  The owners are super nice and they did a beautiful job creating the ambience at the Fillmore location.  Thumbs up, especially for special occasions when you want to splurge.  They also do a really nice job with private parties - if you want to go all out, they'll even print special menus for you and your group.  And, they have a fun brunch menu - including an "uttapam" - a traditional South Indian dish - on top of an egg!  Creative twist and definitely worth checking out on the weekend when the brunch menu is offered.
author: Molly P.

description:
i love the hostesses!  it was an hour and a half wait on saturday (which we expected and were OK with) and the hostesses were so considerate and welcoming.  they took my cell # and said we could go for a walk and they'd call us when our table was ready.   as we were heading out for our "walk" (aka to slam a couple beers at the Boom Boom), one of them ran after us and offered us the option of the "community table" at the bar.  we appreciatively passed, but i thought that was so accomodating of them.

excellent food - we had 4 entrees to share. the tamil lamb curry blew my mind.

our waitress had a lot of spunk and took good care of us.

the mission location has a totally different (but good) vibe, so don't expect the same ambience.
author: Julia J.

description: I have eaten here many times. The food is consistently great. I haven't found anything I don't adore! We are Indian food aficianados and Dosa is at the top of my list. The decor is beautiful, certainly one of the best in the ciity. My only real puzzlement is the wine list. I have never found a wine I like. And its a shame because I really like to have a glass of wine with my dinner. I have given up. Every time I go, I inspect the wine list in case they have changed it, but am consistently disappointed. I noticed all the other critiques don't mention wine, so it's not just me. I guess you can't have everything, but it would be nice!
author: Eileen C.

description:
This isn't so much a review, but a word of caution about checking the bill and your order. Our party of 4 went to dinner at dosa over the weekend, and all seemed to be going well. The starters were popular, the server seemed prompt and courteous. After the mains arrived, we realized that one of the dishes was incorrect. The waiter apologized profusely, and offered to bring us the correct dish to make up for his mistake: Great! Or so we thought......
When the bill arrived, they charged the bill to a credit card that we had earlier left behind the bar (after telling the waitstaff that we did not wish to do this in advance), and charged us for the dish that the waiter had been so apologetic about getting wrong.
When this was flagged up, the waiter rudely informed us that as we ate the dish that we should pay up.  That takes some gall!  If they offer to correct their mistake, then some good PR would go a long way. After we politely remonstrated, the manager then deducted the wrong dish of the bill. 
What a shame, as this ironically could have been a 5 star review if they had been less disingenuous and honored their attempt to make amends.
author: alex b.

description: The ambiance, service, and food were all great.  Dosa's were good and the food was seemingly authentic with a sophisticated flair.  Great for a nice evening out with a cuisine that is usually not featured as fine dining.
author: Sun M.

description: Best cosmopolitan beautiful tasty aromatic south indian food money can buy in a 50 mile radius.
author: Sujoy G.

description:
this place is pretty good

but its expensive.  a lot of white people like to eat here so i would guess thats why its expensive, gotta keep up appearances
author: Jonathan W.

description: the food was okay.  I remember the food at the one on valencia tasting much better.  the tea was bad, with the water tasting funny.
author: Audrey L.

description: This a a beautiful restaurant with great service, but the food, generally not special.  Certainly not up to the decor.
author: Barbara M.

description: The food and drink here was spectacular. The Samosa are amazing and the curries are great. A little pricey, but, doodie, you gots to pay to play!
author: Chris G.

description: went here with some friends, i thought i was going to eat curry but it was a different type of indian food with crispy crepe . I was amazed it was delicoious. had the mushroom truffle dosa very good! the lamb was tasty well. the crepe was the best part i can eat that by itself all day.
author: Christine L.

description: Went to Dosa for the first time with a group of gals before a movie at Kabuki.  Have heard great things, and it did not disappoint.  Great atmosphere and extensive menu.  But in one word, SPICY!  I'm not an Indian food connoisseur by any stretch of the imagination, but yikes, I was in for a surprise.  Service was awesome and they were very attentive to our movie time.  Love it, and will be definitely be back.
author: Lauren M.

description: The place is pricey and it's not the food you're paying for but the rent and decor. Been here for lunch and more recently dinner. Service was meh. Ordered the dosa sampler and can't say I was at all enthralled with any of them. I like flavorful food and just found it to be bland. Would give the Mango lassi a 2 star as well. Just found the place to be a letdown. Would rather go somewhere with tasty food. Left feeling cheated.
author: Harry K.

description: excellent place...  the food was really good, and the service even better. Our waitress was the best (her name is Leah).
author: jaime b.

description: Very solid restaurant. I was really impressed by their interesting wine list. I had a glass of wine from India, which was quite unusual and it was acutally good. I sat at the bar because I was really unsure about the "community" table that had seats available. I think it would be kinda awkward to be sitting at a table with complete strangers. The bartenders are super nice and really knowledgeable about the wines and the food. The food came out hot and at the right times. All the dishes I tried were really fresh and tasty. It's the kind of meal where you can eat alot without feeling really full or guilty becuase the food is pretty healthy.  The only negative thing is that it is on the pricey side, but well worth it.
author: Summer R.

description:
Got there early and had a couple of drinks at the bar. Cool bartender and good/quick drinks. It seemed more upscale from the outside, but it's definitely okay to dress casual--most people were. 

The lamb curry was nice, but not much different from others I've had, but the chicken was excellent, as were the dosas and all else. 

Everything we had was good, atmosphere is nice, the place feels clean and everyone was very attentive and friendly. We'll go back for sure.
author: Gym W.

description:
Without a doubt, the most stunning Indian restaurant in the city, and probably anywhere in California. The chandeliers were particularly beautiful, as were the unique art installations and stencils. I cannot express how good it feels to eat quality Indian food in a setting that lives up to it. Refreshing in a city of budget options from the subcontinent.
And given the ambiance, the prices are no higher than the Valencia location, which is a nice plus. We sampled a huge variety of dishes, listed below:
- apps: chennai chicken (a standby), the calamari, and the coconut cauliflower soup (now becoming an addiction)
- entrees: kerala fish moilee was the hit of the night. Chicken baingan bharta and lamb curry were runners up. Paneer and peas dosa was excellent.
- dessert: pistachio kulfi and rasmalai. Good but can't match the rest of the food.
- Wine: Margerum M5 from Santa Barbara. Without a doubt our favorite wine to accompany Dosa's menu. Has become the standard wine order. 
Only issue was the dosa that arrived a half hour after the rest of the food, pretty much bringing the meal to a grinding halt, leading to this four star rating. 
No doubt we will be back though, late dosa or not.
author: Purnima M.

description: I took a group of 4 here for an evening dinner. We had to wait a few minutes for our table which was fine. We wanted to sample their specialty cocktails at the bar anyways. Their list is filled with spiced cocktails that would fit most palettes. Mine just so happened to burn the hell out of my mouth, in a good way of course. We then sat down to dinner in the balcony section to a great view of the restaurant. All the food we ordered was very tasty and easily shared by the group. It's a great place to order a few entrees and dive in to whatever is on the table. Every dish was well portioned and filled with flavor. I have recommended this place to many people and will continue to do so. Keep up the great work.
author: Dave B.

description: I went by for a drink after seeing "Benjamin Button" at the Kubuki.  The place looks great.  They have a huge space in a great building that used to be a Goodwill store.  I had a fancy mezcal cocktail from their menu and it was all right.  I am not in to this crazy cocktail mixologist/startender trend.  I would rather just have a beer or a good glass of wine.  Every once in a while, something looks good and I will give it a try.  Dosa has some nice options, if you are into this kind of thing.  I tried one of their starter dosas and it was excellent.  It was huge and came with 3 different types of sauces.  I will be back.  The new Dosa on Fillmore is here to stay.
author: Ezra Y.

description:
a new outpost for the mission's popular indian spot.

wandered in for drinks on opening night after a movie.  located in a spectacularly renovated space previously occupied by goodwill (which has relocated across the street), its the perfect location to compliment movie night at the sundance.

the menu (both food and wine) are consistent with its sister restaurant, and there's a ~$40 four course menu (+$15 for wine paring) that gives a good spread of options for people new to indian cuisine.  didn't dine, so can't comment on the food.

the gin-centric bar offers interesting cocktails prepared with care.  lots of exotic flavors and unique combinations.  the space is truly impressive, and offers a open layout downstairs with a more private balcony that is likely best for larger parties.  large bar area is good for grabbing a small bite, or just a cocktail.  scene was quiet (opening weekend and all) but i imagine this place will soon be a solid oasis for movie goers and fillmore street holiday shoppers alike.
author: Matt G.

description: My girlfriend and I went here for our anniversary and were not disappointed.  The food was excellent, the service was excellent, and the timing was, well, right on time !  Our favorite cocktail was the Bengali Gimlet, and our favorite dish was the Bagara Baingan.  The Dosa was really really good too.. The best part is that the restaurant is totally affordable, despite its classiness.
author: stian r.

description: The food is amazing! It is one of those places that you wish its popularity would wan over time so it is easier to get  table...but that will probably not happen soon...its that good. SO if you don't have a reservation, get there early!
author: Carlie W.

description: Went here with roommate. The food was good, but not great. Overpriced Indian food is what it all comes down to. The restaurant looks very upscale and nice.
author: Prescott T.

description:
very good, and personable service, although very expensive for indian food

i came for lunch, and got their samosas, dahi vada, and habanero dosa.

samosas: good, but you only get 2 (1 north, 1 south). i would have preferred 2 of each, just smaller size... but im being nit-picky...

dahi vada: refreshing! good

habanero dosa: well, let me talk about the filling and dipping sauces first: the coconut dipping sauce was very tasty and balanced the dosa well. the potato filling could have been a meal itself, it was so good.

the "dosa": oh my goodness, when they say that it is hot, they mean it. the waitress warned me before i placed my final order. she said that "some people say its so hot they feel like their face melts off." well, it was hot. it burned going down, and, well, it caused me to spend a good half hour on my throne later. it was good, very good, but definitely not for the faint-hearted or anyone who wasn't raised with sriacha in their baby bottle like i was.

ill be back here
author: suz s.

description: Dan the manager is the best!!! He made us very happy, ensuring a great meal for the whole party. You should just come to Dosa for DAN.
author: V J.

description: Great food, great ambiance, great bar, great service.  It isnt the Indian food I traditionally expect but very good. The only thing keeping it from the 5th star was the food-- when I pay more I expect more from the chef.  But I will definitely be going back-- nice place for a date night too (especially if you can get a cozy place upstairs.
author: N A.

description:
Yum yum yum. Went here on a Friday night around 7pm without reservations (3 of us) and had to wait only 30 min. Had a great table upstairs. Our waitress was very nice, helpful without being too overbearing or absent. 
We ordered 2 apps- calamari and fried asparagus, both delish although on the smaller side. Only 4 asparagus spears on the plate, normal to small size. Small plate of calamari, too, with a little slaw, but great flavors.
Then, we had the masala dosa, another pancake-like dish with caramelized onions, a slow-cooked chicken dish with the lemon rice and a puffy fried wheat bread. The dosa was my favorite, reminded me of a doughy crepe. The lentil soup that came with both of the "dosas" was quite spicy. Portions seem to be average, not huge but not small either. Oh, also had a diet coke that came in a small glass bottle, no refills :(. 
Loved the decor! Super clean bathrooms. Would take out-of-towners here in a heartbeat!
author: Heather I.

description: This is a combo Indian restaurant.  Food was average as it is neither Indian or American.  Puri was good.  Soup ok. Other than that is a matter of individual taste.  I like spicy food. This is not for me.
author: Noor s.

description: Been to the one on Valencia and wanted to try the one on Fillmore.... love, loved the food. We had the Dosa Marsala.... came with a curry potato filling and 3 different sauces, the samosa's... 2 per order... quite big so you can cut in half...also a chicken dumm biyani... i didn't care for the chicken much but I loved the rice..... people sitting next to us had the lentil dumpling.... looks so good.... I'm going to try it next.
author: Jay S.

description: I went there recently for a friend's birthday.  The food was tasty, the servers great, and the space cool.  However, what I really want to rave about are the cocktails.  In a town where you usually have to specify a gin martini so you are not automatically given the travesty of a vodka martini, the gin cocktails here were a surprise and a delight.  Three cheers to the mixologist and to the bar staff.  The Batsman was refreshing delicious and Bengali Gimlet with its "curried nectar" was a revelation.
author: Annette K.

description:
In December, Anjan and Emily Mitra opened a second branch of their South Indian eatery, DOSA on Fillmore.  They brought their executive chef, Senthil Kumar, from Valencia Street to run the kitchen in this bright, spacious building that has been beautifully transformed from its former Goodwill digs.  

My father has enjoyed traveling to India, so I invited him to sample DOSA's dishes.  Once we ordered, our server gave us a plate of papardam, large black pepper crisps made with lentil butter.  We nibbled while listening to an interesting mix of American pop and traditional Indian music in the background.  We shared Blackened Sardines ($9.50), a pair of deliciously crispy fried sardines rubbed with green chiles, coriander, cumin, pepper, chopped greens and onions accompanied with lime and a cucumber, tomato and red onion salad.  The Chennai Chicken ($9.50) came out next, organic chicken marinated in organic yogurt with coriander and cumin, then fried.   It packs a perfect amount of heat from all the spices.  It came with a slaw of cabbage, carrot, beet, red onion and spinach lightly dressed with a sweet cilantro vinaigrette.  There are a variety of Dosa, or savory rice and lentil crepes, and Uttapam, a slightly thicker pancake version of Dosa, to choose from.  Both come with three condiments - a fresh tomato chutney, coconut chutney, and sambar, a warm lentil dipping soup made of assorted vegetables and spices.  My father had the Chile and Cilantro Uttapam ($10) with green chiles, onion and cilantro which was tasty but much milder than I expected.  I ordered the Spring Dosa ($11), crunchy veggie rolls filled with fresh cabbage, carrots, red onion, peas and typically, cashews, but I opted to go without.  They delivered a Spring Uttapam by mistake, but quickly replaced it with a Dosa, and plated it with an extra piece to make up for their error.  We tried Coconut Basmati Rice ($3) cooked in a myriad of flavors including coconut milk, yellow lentils, mustard seeds, red chiles, and South Indian drumstick leaves which are mostly strained out before serving.  It was interesting, didn't love it, didn't hate it.

Today, DOSA on Fillmore was a sunny, quiet setting for a liesurely lunch, but I hear it packs a weekend crowd who enjoy the dinner and lively bar scene.  Speaking of the bar, we each enjoyed a signature cocktail.  The Bengali Gimlet ($10) was a refreshing blend of Tanqueray Rangpur Gin, "curried" nectar, Kaffir lime leaf and juice, served up with a lime wedge.  I tried the Mood Indigo ($10) with Buffalo Trace Bourbon, jackfruit marmalade, Angostura bitters, chilled and topped with sparkling wine which was fruity with a nice bite from the bitters. 

All in all, it was a pleasant dining experience.  Despite being a little heavy on the fried treats and a tad steep for everyday lunching - our total bill came to more than $70 -  this is a fun place to go occasionally with family or friends when you are not in a big hurry.  Good variety for vegetarians and wheat and gluten-free eaters.   Lunch is served daily from 11:30am-3:00pm.
author: Dina B.

description:
3.75 stars

i've been to the dosa on valencia numerous times but finally had the chance to try dosa on fillmore.   i came here with a friend expecting to be a similar ambience as the one on valencia, and was a bit surprised to find it much swankier.  this dosa is much bigger, louder, darker, and just a bit trendier.  i guess they gotta appeal to a different demographic near pac heights.  fortunately, the food is as good as the one on valencia.  we both got the 4 course tasting menu and were quite full by the end.  we shared chennai chicken and potato and pea croquette for appetizer which were both very good.  for the mini dosa, we had the masala chutney and paneer and peas.  being it a tasting menu and having the course referred to as "mini dosa," the portions were surprisingly huge.  the masala chutney was pretty much the same size as the regular dosa i normally order.  for entrees, we had the lamb kofta and prawn curry which were both great.  unfortunately, we were too stuffed to really enjoy this dish.  we had the gulab jamoon and chocolate chai gelato for dessert.  the gulab jamoon is always too sweet for my taste and the chocolate chai gelato tasted pretty much like chocolate with a hint of spice.

 i was a bit disappointed because i had requested via opentable that the dessert come with a birthday candle for my friend.  i even followed up with a phone call to the restaurant a couple hours before our dinner to confirm and was assured by the reservationist they would do that.  unfortunately when the dessert came, no candle!

overall, solid meal. i prefer the dosa on valencia just for a more laid back ambience.
author: Helen T.

description: Great food and friendly staff! We always stop there before catching a movie at Sundance!
author: BARI P.

description:
Desi Junta, this is an A+ ambience, classy restaurant. Super food for sure. Very nice Utthapams and Sambhar is unbeatable. Complimentary papad does help ;-). On the costlier side, but worth going once.
Street parking around it is find-able if you are ready to put in the effort. Other wise garages are around.
author: suri s.

description:
Wow the food and ambiance were amazing. Went on a Wednesday  not expecting a crowd, but was mistaken packed out the door, luckily we were able to sit at a community table and only had to wait 15 minutes for it. 

We started with the Mango and Goat Cheese salad, it was okay- not out of this world. The Chutney Masala Dosa was heaven- I didn't want it to end, so tasty. Tried the Lamb Curry which was also amazing. 

It is really beautiful inside but it definitely is a hustling and bustling atmosphere. Not so conducive for an intimate conversation. But hey, who wants to talk while eating any ways?
author: sarah s.

description:
The chai is to die for and the food is scrumptious.

I took off a star because of the crowds and the price.  We waited over an hour for a seat at the "community dining table."  This is basically a very large table that can seat many people.  When I am in an anti-social mood, I feel very awkward sitting shoulder to shoulder with strangers.  But I suppose it is a small price to pay for excellent food.
author: Onki K.

description:
very good but

do go for the food and the service- our person was VERY helpful and kind with the menu - without acting all "you should know this" kind of stuff- we felt like rockstars! 
food- DELISH - wine faboo- didn't have coctails - 

anywayyyyy - the only downside was that while we were having a drink at the bar we felt REALLY in the way- ** the bartender was supercool- but the bar was full of patrons having dinner- and we kind of had to hang out behind them and be all in the way- 

It is not a bar
but a RESTAURANT
soooo keep that in mind
JR
author: Joel R.

description: Great space.  Amazing food.  Good service.  I have eaten here a few times, and it never fails to impress.  Go there now!
author: Scott L.

description:
for some reason the food at the valencia location last time knocked my socks off and the fillmore location didn't. I'll go again. Maybe it's a consistency issue.  Their sweet mango lassi is really good.  The decor is beautiful.  much fancier than dosa valencia.  Can't believe this used to be the stinky goodwill store.  

The shrimp with mango dish was so so. Shrimp was overcooked so disappointing.  Chicken fingers -like appetizer had good spices. yogurt sauce was good. but basically flavorful chicken fingers so I'll try something more unique next time.  The dosa with the eggplant was bland.
author: Yelper S.

description: Had been really looking forward to this but found myself underwhelmed. First, I'm pretty sure my waitress didn't smile all night which really does affect the evening. Second, my friend and I stated that we wanted to get a bottle of wine, but asked two questions in choosing the bottle. She seemed peeved and pawned us off on someone else.  As for food, we indicated that we wanted to order a lot of stuff because we were eager to try but she really didn't seem interested in helping us. She was not working other tables that I could see so it's not like she was too busy. The samosas were great but the other two dishes were meh. I think I missed the point but she didn't help me get it. I actually don't like banana cream but the dessert was good! Overall, I really don't care if I go back which is sad because their menu looked huge and good.
author: Laura G.

description: I previously gave Dosa a mediocre review because I felt that SF's long-awaited entre into South Indian cuisine focused too much on the novelty and scene while missing the mark on seasoning and texture.  That was back when the Mission restaurant first opened.  The owner reached out to assure me that they've made improvements so I decided to give it another shot when the new Fillmore location opened... Well sir, I think Dosa might be my new favorite Indian restaurant in the bay area.  Classy but fun atmosphere, unique cocktails, and a varied spread of south Indian dishes that deliver on flavor, texture, and authenticity.  With the exception of the pista kulfi which I found a little too icy, I wouldn't change a thing.  5 stars well deserved.
author: seema s.

description: I came here a couple weeks ago and its amazing! I love the interior design its such a cool place. The samosa was a huge hit I highly recommend. If you go you must get drinks! Their cocktail menu is really impressive and even educational. Definately one of the best indian restaurants in town if you're in japantown looking for dinner maybe give this place a shot over sushi.
author: Kelsey L.

description: We sat at the bar and found that by 6:00 PM the place was hoping and it was a Wednesday night.  The bartenders were quite accommodating to our food and drink requests and even joined in on our conversations about Indian food.  The masala dosa was better than I had expected, still not as good as in Kerala, but best I have had in the city.  The speciality cocktails are awesome and well worth the cost.  Sit at the bar, enjoy the atmosphere and some great food.
author: Runner G.

description: Reasons that you should try Dosa at least once: good cocktails, great dosa, even better service, flavorful food, and wonderful ambience.  It's no wonder that this place was busy.
author: Jeanne L.

description: Went for a late lunch.  Service was very good, they weren't too busy, but may be because it was pretty late in the lunch hour.  It is nice inside, lotsa light, wide open spaces and tastefully decorated.  All the food was really, really good. Very tasty and not swimming in oil or as heavy and rich as I am used to in restaurants with similar cuisine (which I guess is more Northern Indian). We had samosas, fire broth soup, masala dosa and onion dosa. We did have the malai ice cream which was small, but very good.  I might skip the samosas next time, $8 for samosas. Overall a little pricey, but very yummy!
author: Kathleen Y.

description: OMG! What a find!!!  Everything was delicious!  I normally don't get this excited about food, but it really was good.  The appetizers were sooo good!  I had this chicken with a yogurt dipping sauce and then this salad with 2 difference sauces which was like crack.  The flavors are super fresh, I mean seriously good.  Plus I liked the wine list!  A new addition to my SF favs!
author: Caroline S.

description:
It was the sweet chandelier that brought us in.

My dad and I actually had no idea what kind of food we were getting ourselves into upon walking in. (We're new to the area) 

It was great to be sat right away. I think we were under-dressed, but maybe that's cause it was mother's day and people might've been out celebrating, but the beautiful inside kind of makes you feel like you need to be dressed for the red carpet.

I've been to restaurants where the tables were close, but I'd never before seen the hostess need to pull a table out to seat the couple next to us once we were snugly in place. I don't mind the closeness, they seemed to  a little bit though, as it was clear by the hand-holding what kind of intimacy they were looking for.

The rest of the environment was great -- an awesome, mellow soundtrack paired with the dim lighting and dark, warm colors and topped off with gentle laughing from others enjoying their meals. 

Our waiter was GORGEOUS, and very polite. There wasn't a whole lot of interaction with him (unfortunately for me), but I think that's part of the swag-style ambiance of the place. Actually, come to think of it, the whole theme of the employees was to downplay customer interaction -- they all didn't really say much, which kind of felt like they were being short, but they were still really polite ... maybe it's the influence of the asian-concentrated local ... or maybe that's a totally wrong stereotype. Whatever. Back to the pretty guy, I liked his service, but I had wished I had more water.

I had two cocktails, a great one with mango, and another that I really wanted to like for its flavors, but it was really, really spicy -- it was different though, so I enjoyed it even though my throat burned. 

My peppercorn chicken dish was great, which I paired with the suggested lemon rice. I'd never had lemon rice before, but I think it's my new favorite food. Num nums. The presentation wasn't anything special next to the dishes of those around me who had decided on the huge dosa things... those looked pretty cool. 

I wish I'd had room for dessert, they seemed to have some pretty interesting concoctions. I'll have to come back. Maybe have dessert, definitely drinks, and definitely to check out the hott server dude.
author: amber f.

description:
why did i wait so long to go to dosa?  well i've been wanting to go for a long time... even when only the valencia location existed, but just never got the chance as a lot of people i'm around don't want to go for 'indian' food...
but finally tonight i was able to go!!
it was so delicious.
wow so crowded on a tuesday evening.  our server was kinda swamped but luckily the manager was available while she was tending to her larger party...
so we had a cochin calamari appetizer, baigara baingan baby eggplant dish with lemon rice, jumbo prawn masala dish, and paneer & peas uttapam... it was a lot of food for two but we wanted to taste a few different things.  needless to say, i've got a lot of leftovers now :)  i'll have a delicious breakfast!
for dessert we shared an order of gulab jamoon... which was super sweet so i'm glad we shared it cus one of those deep fried milk balls was more than enough... 

i love the interior of the space.  wish i could have their chandelier... 
can't wait to go back and try their other dishes....
i think it would be a good idea to go with at least 3 other people who like to share food so that it's possible to taste several items from the menu.
author: charlotte s.

description: I took my son to Dosa's on Easter Sunday. Because we had no idea what to order on the overwhelmingly HUGE menu, we asked for help from a somewhat reluctant server.  We coaxed a few recommendations out of her and ended up having a really great dining experience.  The food was unique and interesting. For our appetizer,  We liked the puffy bread dipped in the lentil dumpling sauce.  For our main course we enjoyed the masala chutney dosa and the paneer dosa.  The masala chutney dosa had a comfortable amount of spiciness, while the paneer was a bit too spicy.  Also had a great glass of chardonnay, the only one on the menu.
author: Sharie M.

description: A couple friends took me here for my birthday. Dosa was indeed enjoyable. As for my first time having Southern Indian cuisine, i thought the food was great. I liked the Bhel poori and the chennai chicken alot. Also this coconut soup was delicious too. I loved their cup of hot chai and coffee. Their coffee almost tasted like milk tea but with a different after taste to it. Very classy and elegant. Cool atmosphere. The space and colors of the interior. along with the nice decorations are warm and welcoming. Be sure to make reservations.
author: stephanie n.

description: Wonderful pre-Kabuki theatre dining spot with exotic cocktails.  The dosas are the size of your head so you may want to share one and get a couple of apps as well.  I've been several times for dinner and once for brunch.  The brunch was a bit spotty service-wise, but the dinner service does not disappoint.
author: Alex M.

description: Went the first week they opened. Great lighting, nice bar but uncomfortable stools. Food: fair not that exciting. Servers and bartenders: wonderful. Birthday party beware, they charge $3 for slicing your cake. I wouldn't mind getting a cake from them but they have nothing to offer.
author: anne c.

description:
Oh man. So GOOD!

We came with a large group, so we got the prix fixe menu. It was tough to make any choices with the offerings they had, but eventually we all decided, and the delicious, delicious food began to arrive.  Everything was amazing, service was top-notch, drinks were excellent. 

Prices were high, but that was expected.

Incredibly convenient location for the Kabuki, as it's just across the street.

Bonus stars for vegan options.
author: J N.

description: We went here on Sat night for a bday celebration w/ one of dearest.. Excitement abounds; mommy pals out for the eve is a serious impetus for toasting! The structure of a fab dinner were all in place-- organic meat and local sourced produce? Check! Innovative cocktail menu with random "tincture" ingredients thrown in? Double check! Big cosy booth that lends itself to a "sleepover" sort of intimacy? The trifecta! So why less than stellar outcome? Well.. service was that flawed combo of pushy, but lacking in precision. When you ask a server for recommendations, you don't need a slippery fish, you need succinct decision-making. Sometimes that means a willingness to slam a few items to illustrate their point of what really is advised. In this case, everything was rosy.. but nothing really clear. And descriptions were off-- Me: is the crab cake breaded and deep fried? Her: NO! Not at all.. pan fried, much crab.. and then a deep fried potato pancake basically appeared a few minutes later.. ahem. Also, they didn't carry Belvedere vodka, which makes a liquor snob a little grievous. And while the food gets points for innovative, (i did like the mung bean salad and the lentil dipping soup), the other dishes lackluster.. heavy and spicy, but not subtle or elegant. I don't know, maybe the waitress just uber annoyed. At the end of the meal to move on along the push was enormous.. which my mommy friend needed none of.. and a 2nd cocktail wasn't ever solicited! So you see, i may take my weekend eve enthusiasm elsewhere..
author: Rachel S.

description: One of the best dosa in the bay area, rich delicious food. Great ambience, good service. Awesome food, must visit. Have tried the cilantro mint, moong dosa, chile and garlic, cholle bhatura, rasam, s.i. moons, bhel :) :) :) its all GOOD ! have them make paneer dosa spicy !
author: Niki V.

description: great food/ambiance! love their DOSA but not to fond of their dessert menu
author: Tess C.

description: I have only been once but I loved this place. The space itself is super cool and the food is DELICIOUS. I liked all but one dish, and I think it was just a personal taste preference. You won't be disappointed.
author: Kally S.

description: the restaurant is beautiful...ambiance was nice.  there were really dressed up patrons as well as super casual -- anything goes here.   each person in our party ordered the prix fixed menu and it was A LOT of food (4 courses for $40)!  after 2 courses, i was already feeling pretty full.   the food was good - but then again, i haven't eaten too much indian food so i don't think i can truly appreciate it.  but everything was good...especially the passion fruit custard with coconut tapioca..yummm
author: betty w.

description:
I like this addition to the neighborhood. 

Authentic or not I don't know but an Indian chef of a four star restaurant in the city recommended it. He said the food was very good and now that I've had it I agree. 

We couldn't get a reservation and the place was extremely packed (to be expected since its new and getting buzz). We patiently waited for a couple "squatters" to leave and then ate at the bar though which was just fine. 

Bartender was very friendly, attentive, and patient even though it was busy. He also comped us a glass of wine for accidentally ringing up one wrong item which they brought to us but fixed very quickly. 

Chicken Biryani, Somosas, and Wheat Dosa were all excellent, and portions were big by SF standards. All round great but not perfect service made even better by how they treated their mistake.
author: Pete L.

description: Totally lame. But let me start with the positives. Awesome that the owners are trying to introduce south indian food to the masses. The dining room itself is nicely done although transparently trendy in kind of a lame way. I took my south Indian boyfriend and....we were dissapointed. The price is way too high for what you get, spices are toned down for a western palate and the service SUCKED. They seated uis late, the women servers had snobby whiny voices and the food seriously was mediocre. SARAVANA BHAVAN in Sunnyvale is what incredible South Indian food tastes like. Granted, it is not at all hip but it is all Indian folks, cheap and the real deal. So if you want to be seen at the newest place go to DOSA. If you want good value and food, I would pass.
author: Livia W.

description: Where to start? Was definitely excited to be eating here, having heard about it from friends. Went with two young children. Big mistake. We eat in lots of Indian restaurants with our daughter, this one went out of its way to be not kid-friendly. Fine enough, their choice, but even alone we would not have been happy. Tables way too close together, food not authentic (that was not a samosa), food too spicy for most of our friends, let alone the kids, and nothing was exceptional. We've had way better and won't be back for any more of this.
author: Diane B.

description:
i'm a huge fan of indian food and was really looking forward to Dosa.  i was not disappointed!!    the staff, while somewhat inexperienced and not really sure what beers and vodka were available, were very friendly and attentive.   

i wanted a chicken dish that was spicy (hot) and there were no menu items fitting that bill.   the waiter asked the kitchen to spice up the chicken and eggplant dish and it was amazing!!!!  it couldn't have been better and i was sufficiently roasted, from within, which is exactly what i wanted.    

i'll be back even though the prices are a little high.
author: kevin d.

description: Basic Indian Food that is dressed up with atmosphere.  Service is weak and menu is confusing.
author: steven y.

description: As someone who was born in Madras (Dosa capital of the world) I can vouch for the authenticity in their taste. Sure they have made some improvisations, but it tastes great. Most South Indians places are a hole in the wall types, so this makes Dosa rare rare place. I went their first time with a friend. We kinda thought this place would suck in their food but went mainly for the ambiance. We were both pleasantly surprised/shocked at how good the dishes were. Dahi Vada, Tamil vegetable curry were awesome. Some hole in the wall places in sunnyvale charge 3/4 their price, for arguably more authentic dishes but substandard veggies/meat. So I would highly recommend this place. I loved it...
author: Anand K.

description: What a treat to have such a classic South Indian restaurant in the city! The taste of the dosa's and sambhar is really authentic. I would recommend people to try Spring dosa, its just too good! The ambience & service was very very good. Just loved the place!
author: Shilpa A.

description: it's hard for me to give this place more stars when i know that vik's exists in berkeley.
author: Jamie C.

description: If you're looking for non standard Indian fare then this is your place. They have LOADS of vegetarian options, really inventive cocktails, and a wonderful wine list (new fav: Chakalaka). We like to go before a show at The Fillmore or a movie at the Kabuki. I can't resist ordering the Channa Bhatura each time I go... I love that bread and chick peas.
