The atmosphere is fun and beautiful. Great for parties, special occasions, out of town guest, etc.
author: Stacey B.

description: nice bar setup and good place to lounge.  however, for a restaurant it feels like it's missing something and the old location on Valencia is notably better.
author: Ric S.

description: Keeps getting better!  Love this "newer" location, very well done - stylish and hip decor, cool music, a nice bar - a very open and inviting setting.  That said, the food is what matters, and it shines!  The dosa's keep getting better, and the starters are fantastic (esp love the Prawn Chile Fry and the Mung Sprouts).  The food is fresh and there's as much effort in the execution as you'll find anywhere at this price.  The Spicy Mung Masala dosa fires on all cylinders.  Friendly staff, and surprisingly attentive and accommodating service at the bar as well.  I would like to see a broader wine list (more interesting European whites please!).  Overall, consistently a good experience time and again, I will keep coming back!
author: B M.

description: The food was really mediocre.  We had the spicy shrimp app (so-so), lamb curry (overcooked and too much cardamom) & mysore dosa (nothing special).  If you are all about decor then you'd love it - the space is beautiful.  Well except for the ladies room which was filthy - sinks were dirty, toilet paper all over the floor.  If you are a foodie I'd say this place isn't worth it.  Go the Shalamar - the food is 100% better.
author: Alicia M.

description: Food is  good.  Dahi Vada to start was excellent, and great presentation on it.   Chicken Bagara, Tamil Lamb Curry, Masala Uttapam, all good.  My only complaint is corkage fee.  $25!!  That's extreme.
author: Jim K.

description: I just went to this spot last night! First off the service was fantastic, when asking for a beer to pair with my dish and the waitress handled! I ordered the cilantro mint dosa which was delightful! It was refreshing and and filling at the same time well worth a try!
author: William N.

description: I love indian food but been here twice and it's stodgy as far as I'm concerned. Service just ok.
author: Jason E.

description: Dosa the disappointing! We had heard lots of raves about this place & were really looking forward to eating here. What a letdown! We had nice drinks at the bar & service was pleasant- one star for this. Food was "not bad", (weak praise but there's the other star). We were seated with reservations on time but the tables were so close my neighbor's butt was in my plate when she had to get up. Music in the restaurant was most times too loud to hear anything anyone was saying at our table. We could however hear everything to the right & left of each other because we were so darn crammed in near other tables. An extremely uncomfortable evening. Will never go back.
author: Colleen A.

description: I had dinner at this place on 12/302010 with my husband.  We had an 8:45pm dinner reservation.  We came 1.5hrs early hoping to get seated earlier.  A party of 13 people came who accidentally made their reservations for the day before.  They were accommodated and seated within 45min.  I watched and listened for 1.5hrs as smaller parties of 2-4 people (who came on time) were made to wait another 15-20min.  The hostess used the excuse..."I'm sorry for the wait.  People are hanging around the tables longer"  That wasn't the case.  I understand that a large party will equal a bigger bill and  more money for Dosa, but smaller parties who come on time shouldn't be penalized for this.  I didn't think  Dosa was the kind of business that functioned this way.   A professional business should honor a reservation that's been made and make every effort to seat that party on time.  BEWARE THE NEXT TIME YOU ARE MADE TO WAIT..... THEY COULD BE PULL ONE ON YOU...AND IT'S NOT FAIR
author: jenny s.

description: I have been to the mission place but this time went to the Filmore. This is a really great restaurant. I always enjoyed coming to the mission restaurant as the Owner was always hospitable.  The owners really did a great job in decor and selecting the right architects and ambience for the Filmore restaurant.  I love this place!!!!!!!!! Try the prawn masala curry or the lamb curry. I am indian and still can highly recommend these curries - and I know my curries.  It's worth it.  Also, what is great about this place is that anyone (artsy or professional) can go to DOSA and there isn't a dress code or snobby attitude here. It's very friendly and bay area down to earth.  I grew up in the bay area and love places that are earthy like this restaurant..
author: Razz T.

description: Very nice meal at Dosa on Fillmore. It was last week on Friday and I am going again. Hope to go every month. Nice place. Good food. Like it.
author: Niraj P.

description: Yes yelpers, the food is really good...but the fact is that the place has the sexiest lighting in SF.  Seriously.  I'm middle aged and I look good sitting at that bar around twilight.  They could serve slop (which they don't - the curry is awesome and I had these beet fritter things that blew my mind), but I'm so happy sitting at that bar feeling wrinkle free that it doesn't even matter.  Bring a date (or your husband of 20 years) and feel the effects...
author: Michele M.

description:
this was my third time to dosa and each time has been ok.  i rate the food a four and the service a two.  atmosphere is great and the place is not too loud which is great.  last night we arrived around 9:15 post movie at the kabuki.  no available tables, so we put our names down and hovered around the bar/bar table.   i was seated at the bar and ordered drinks for our party.  the five of us were talking - some standing, some sitting - when the hostess came up to me and said, "can i ask you to give up these two bar seats as i have a two-person party that would like to sit and eat at the bar."  we all looked at each other confused.  give up a bar seat while drinking?  besides, we were waiting, and wanting to eat and were about to order some appetizers.  i agreed - begrudgingly and after standing around for another five minutes or so we got out table and ate some very good food.  but then another strange thing happened.  we were given the check and the waitress told us the tip was included on the bill - for a party of 5???  yes, if our party was large, i could understand, but not for five people.
dosa has great food but when the bill comes out to almost $45/pp, the service/customer engagement has to be better.
author: John A.

description: Delicious x2! I can't wait to go back. The food was absolutely splendid; everything we ate (Garbanzo & Avocado Salad, Dahi Batata, Tamil Vegetable Curry, Masala Dosa) was phenomenal. The menu is a bit pricey. Décor and ambiance was on par with the meal (however we were seated at the window with a view of Burger King, we ended up rearranging our table so that we faced into the restaurant, a much nicer view). Definitely looking forward to visiting again.
author: Veronica G.

description: nice decor and friendly service.  has a good bar and a sophisticated feel.  the food was the let down...it wasn't bad, just not great..tasted like Whole Foods from the self serve bar...some food seemed too greasy and the lamb wasn't as lean as i'd like.....maybe i just ordered the wrong thing. will go back and give it another try.
author: Greg A.

description: Went there for the first time this weekend and the food is great and excellent service. The bar menu is also great. Would recommend this place any day.
author: shaila r.

description: Dosa is a fantastic restaurant with awesome sound Indian food.  Of the dishes I've tried, I really like the Duck Sag Paneer, the paper masala dosa, and the chana batura.  Service and cocktails are also excellent.
author: Raman R.

description: the food is on the pricey side for indian cuisine, and there are lots carbs (bread and more bread) in the menu, therefore, it can be filling. it is a perfect place to grab a bite with your date before hitting the show at the fillmore theater.
author: Connie H.

description:
i would give this restaurant a 5 if it wasn't for our waiter.  basically the food was great but the service, not so much.    

first time trying out this place which is a block away from my place.  heard lots about it and passed by it many times as it is always busy and had no doubt this place is something special.  so finally had a chance to try it out.  first of all, the food was great.  nothing wrong there.  but as a customer, restaurants isn't all about the food but the overall experience.  i don't know what was going on with our waiter that day, as he was clearly favoring the customers who was sitting in front of me as he came by to them frequently to ask if everything was ok, pouring water when my glass an inch from theirs, was empty.  also the menu stated that when ordering a certain type of food, you are required to choose a side.  after ordering and when the food came out, we requeted that we wanted to order a side which he didn't ask but a side already included.  when questioning, the waiter said any extra side will be extra cost and the side that came out is included with the meal and left.  i checked back the menu which clearly said otherwise.  when the waiter returned, he told me that the extra side that we ordered, he wasn't going to charge.  oh wow, how convenient!  he knew we were right and he was wrong.  he tried to save his ego and pride by giving us something free when in fact was already free.  i didn't expect this type of service at restaurant of this quality which was very disappointing.  maybe it was just that day, or just that waiter.  but there is no excuse for this type of service especially to just me,  for it becomes personal.
author: Mac Y.

description: have been here more than twice....wonderful for a first time experience...fusing an indian experience with a western touch..this restaurant is definitely an insane addition to the trippy street called fillmore...i hear quite a few rave reviews about dosa hosting short film fests..an amazing social experience...try the grilled octopus!!
author: Kartheek S.

description: really interesting, hip, indian... pretty pricey
author: Cass M.

description:
We have definitely already been big fans of Dosa ourselves. Our friend who just so happens to be one of the managers there told us about their first public opening yesterday and so we came to check him out and support his new gig.  We were presently surprised to see this huge, well-lit, poshy, upbeat, simply indescribable venue.  Everything in this place is just gorgeous and almost transient and engulfing.  From the huge opening doors with bamboo looking silver handles, to the amazing chandeliers, to the metal leaf artwork on the left and the white marble topped bar on the right.  If I had to decorate a restaurant, I want to get some tips for whoever put this one together.  I don't think I have been this excited about just an ambiance since I first walked into 1300 on Fillmore.  

Using our connections, we were able to get one of the best seats in the house, on the Mezzanine level, looking down towards the bar area.  Walking up, I was immediately struck by how beautiful the bamboo hard floors were and once we actually got upstairs, the entrancing artwork is just breathtaking.  I think I could go on and on about just looking at this place and we hadn't even tried the food yet.  

We knew from our past experience that Dosa was just delectable.  We started off with the Northern/Southern Dosa with the cilantro and tamarind sauces. YUM YUM. Spicy and hot.  It was a shame we only got 2 on our plate.  The onion pakora is perfect. Wish they had a side business of selling just those, it would replace any chip addiction I've ever had.  Next we each had our main courses: the lamb chop, perfectly cooked.  The sauce according to the Mister was a bit on the heavy side, but delicious.  I had the Tamil Vegetable Curry with a Dosa and that was consistently great. And our cousin had the calamari which was probably the most delicious thing we all had.  We also ordered some drinks: The Bowler which I had, which tasted a bit too "tequila-ish" for me, but that just went against my own personal preference. I do think it was a greatly put together drink though.  The cuz got the Batsman which was delicious, light and airy almost like a cooler.  The Mister got the Taj Mahal beer which he seemed to enjoy.

I want to give this venue the last star, but again coming on opening night, there were just a few wrinkles that I think will be ironed out in time. Really minor things like having a steak knife for the lamb, small plates for the appetizers and one of the waiters not counting positions so he could give each of us our order correctly.  Seriously minor stuff that would not keep us from coming back.  

Plus we found out from our friend that the venue itself was made with some environmentally friendly materials, including the paint.  
And, when we all went to the bathroom upstairs, the floors were golden textured with swirls. The walls were also golden with flowers imprinted on it if you looked close enough. It was really kept clean, AND the a huge plus was the monster air machine that blew the water off when you washed your hands. This machine made me feel like my hands were going sky diving it was so strong! 

The greatest part is that we were introduced to the owners which were 2 just beautiful spirits that seemed to be a power couple! I have some positive transference with these 2 folks.  Congratulations guys...the restaurant is simply beautiful!  What a risk to take in the economy we have... yet so worth it!  I'm sure I'll be editing this review again in a month to give it that last star!
author: The Dreaded Critic S.

description: I love the style of the place and always enjoy going. -- However, during my last visit (last week), the food was overly salted. In particular, the coconut chutney. I found the tomato chutney (some creamy kind of  tomato chutney) to be quite lack luster, as well. I also thought the 7 moon Uttapam did not bring any excitement to the palate. Sort of like Indian latkes; even though each has somewhat different vegetables in it -- they tasted nearly the same. However, the rasmalai, sorbet and gelato are quite yummy.
author: Meredith L.

description: Dosa was yummy, service was excellent and friendly, the place is stylish and well done, and the bill was reasonably price.  What more could you ask for!
author: Paul C.

description: The atmosphere is great, but the food is mediocre.  I didn't find the dosas to be anything special.  I actually like the curry more.  The coffee is really good.
author: Wendy C.

description: Dosas, sambar and chutneys exactly like I remember from my first trip to India 2 years ago.  The flavor and spices are divinely authentic!!!  OK, so it's a little weird to have dosas which are not a fancy food in such a chic, upscale ambiance.  But how can I complain, an ultra kewl modern city interior with the ultimate in comfort (south) Indian food.  I was a little disappointed that some of the dosas come cut in pieces, like little burritos.  This makes the eating easier, but I still like the dosa better when it's served in one piece, so I tend to order the mung masala dosa.  There are two others that come in one piece, I believe....the paper masala and lamb dosas.  The service is fast and hospitable, which is amazing considering that it's a mad house in there -- it's so busy, people are like vultures waiting for a seat!  What can I say....the dosas are REALLY divine!
author: Leigh K.

description: excellent souther indian food.  the classic dosa is the best and the coconut table is great.  late dinner avail.  fun, swanky atmosphere and a good casual cosmo feel.  very fun on any night.  go with an empty tummy!  fun! fun and a great date or bday party place!
author: lux j.

description: The food and service here blew me away, although I was already in a great mood because of the hottie I was having dinner with that suggested it.  I'm definitely returning!
author: J C.

description: overwhelming menu....need some type of "guide" for this menu....gorgeous interior..very fancy....
author: Liz D.

description: We ended up here for some dinner prior to heading over to the Filmore for a show.  The restaurant was buzzing for sure which gave me hope that this would be a great meal.  The bar was great with good cocktails and in about 40 minutes we got a table(make reservations on busy nights if you are going).  We ordered the fire broth soup, masala dosa and mung spouts which were all excellent.  Then our entrees came and this is where it went down hill.  The lamb chop came highly recommended so we order it and was not impressed.  It was over cooked with the thickest most over powering paste that tasted more like a coriander spice jar that took over everything on the plate.  With it came the spiced potatoes that spent way to long in a warming pan.  Next was the kerala fish moilee and the mango jumbo prawns.  Maybe just an off night but the seafood was not the freshest I have seen.  The bagara baingan was probably the most satisfying dish that came to the table.  I will go to the Valencia location because I was told the dishes coming out of the kitchen are a little more solid.
author: G... D.

description: I've eaten at both the Dosa on Valencia and at the one on Fillmore.  The food is great at both locations, but the decor and ambiance at the Fillmore location is nicer with more of a loungy vibe.   It was Saturday.  My girlfriends and I had just finished watching a late movie at the Kabuki.  It was almost midnight and we were hungry.  So we headed across the street to DOSA.   We ordered the crab vadas, the regular masala dosa, and the chutney masala dosa to share.  The chutney dosa had a light spread of eggplant on it, but the difference between that and the regular masala dosa was very slight.  I loved the sambar that they provided with dosas for dipping.  It had a bit of kick to it and lots of flavor.  Everything tasted great.  Even my friend, who was not a fan of curry or Indian cuisine, enjoyed everything.  Between the three of us, the bill came out to $34 plus tip.  Not bad at all for a filling meal.
author: Cindy G.

description: The service was good but the food was only so so. I've been to the Dosa on Valencia three times and enjoyed the atmosphere and food much more there.
author: Yelper S F.

description: I've been dying to try this well talked about restaurant and I was excited that they opened one closer to my hood - Fillmore St.  The first time I attempted, happened to be their soft opening night for a private party.  But I finally made it here and we decided to sit at the bar.  The atmosphere is fun, and a little ethnic w/ a modern touch.  The bar is well stocked and their mixed drinks looked delicious.  We started w/ the Chennai Chicken which was good and a great recommendation from our waiter.  I wanted the Mango Jumbo Prawns, but the server misheard me and instead we got the Starter - Prawn Chile Fry (wouldn't highly recommend).  Our waiter also recommended South Indian Moons Uttapam - in which we would've been able to taste a variety as the menu stated.  But it really was 1 kind that came w/ the different side sauces.  After, I heard that the paper masala dosa is what people rave about - wish I tried that...next time.  Overall, I'd probably come back for a cocktail or if I was headed to Kabuki, but it's not cheap and there's a multitude of great restaurants in SF that I'd rather go to before coming back.
author: Meredith K.

description: I've heard a lot of positive things about Dosa (from my Indian friends too) but I hadn't eaten at either one before last night - I wasn't disappointed!  We shared some crab cakes, a spicy mung bean dosa, Goan prawns (w/ yogurt rice), and a chicken korma (with coconut rice).  The crab cakes were pretty bland and uninteresting, but everything else was very flavorful.  The prawns had quite a kick to them but not so much so that you couldn't taste the spices (and it went well with the yogurt rice).  Chicken korma is normally not my thing but my friends are generally picky and they really liked it.  All this for $26 a person (not in including drinks) was not bad at all.
author: Irene W.

description: My wife and I were headed to Kabuki for a 7:35 showing on Saturday night, and we walked into Dosa at 6:45 with no reservation.  They were pretty packed, and we almost gave up before even speaking to the  hostess. She suggested we grab a drink at the bar and see what happens.  At 7:05 the hostess let us know that 2 seats were ready at the community table.  With 30 minutes to movie time, we thought it wouldn't work, but she assured us it would.  I just want to thank her for that.  We had a phenominal dinner, and the food came out so fast, you'd have thought the chefs heard us order.  Moreover, the hostess had made the servers aware of our time constraints, and sped everything up accordingly.  We walked out of there at 7:30 and were settling into our seats as the last preview came to an end.  All in all, a great dining experience for the wonderful food and equally wonderful service.   Thanks Dosa!
author: Brian S.

description: well, the decor is good..food is good..quality is good..quantity??hmm feels like french portions..hahaha..i was very disappointed with the quantity..if only they cld fix tht i wld bump them to 4 or 5 stars:(
author: Ranjitha S.

description: Yummy, yummy, yummy: prawn chile fry, asparagus bhaji, beet soup, spring and masala dosas.  Amazing: rasmalai (this dessert was shared with two girlfriends and I was soooo tempted to order another one just for me!)  Not so hot: toasted coconut barfi (a very strange tasting dessert) and the bollywood hills cocktail.  Service: eh... good not great.  All in all a very tasty dining experience.
author: H G.

description:
I don't eat Indian food often because I can't usually handle the spice. But some friends wanted to try this place. It was dimly lit, but very elegant inside. And surprisingly full at 8pm on a Monday night. We sat at the bar and waited for a table. My friend decided to try the Maharaja Indian beer, which he said wasn't bad. Then they seated our party of four on a small, round table that I would normally be used for 4 people in a bar or coffee shop (definitely not enough room to put all the food we were going to order). So minus 1 star. 

We decided to order several items a la carte and share instead of going with the $39 pre-fixe menu. We first started with 2 appetizers: Chennai Chicken and Chochin Calamari. Both were pretty tasty, and a tad bit spicy. We then ordered 3 entrees and 1 dosa (Jumbo Prawns Masala, Spiced Lamb Chops, Kerala Fish Moilee, and Spring Dosa). My favorites were the prawns and the spring dosa, although the lamb and fish had good flavor. We also had sides of lemon rice, coconut rice, and cilantro rice and one bhatura (which was yummy with the curries). Now with all the food mentioned above, it was quite a feat for us to try to squeeze it onto the table. It was a little annoying that the wait staff did not offer much help in trying to accodomate the small table they gave us with offereing to transfer items to smaller plates (but the busboy was helpful). Also, the waiter knew we were sharing items, but they only gave us small plates during the appetizers and then cleared them away (although we wouldn't have room for additional plates). My boyfriend and I ended up using the empty dosa plate and eating off of that. I was pretty stuffed by the end, but we ate pretty much everything.

For dessert, we had the Gulab Jamoon and Toasted Coconut and Saffrom Barfi. Unfortuantely I wasn't a big fan of hte Gulab Jamoon (I don't really like my friend things all soggy with syrup) and the Toasted Coconut was tasty, but reminded me of a Chinese bun that I can get easily. So next time I'll probably skip dessert.

Lastly, when we received the bill, there were 2 drinks on there that we did not order. We flagged down a waitress, who took about 10 minutes to get us the correct bill (and she was not our original waiter because he was nowhere in sight, and I'm assuming she took over his tables because she took the order of the table next to us and took our bill when we were ready to pay. But I guess I'll never know for sure because our waiter wasn't around for the last 20 minutes we were there). Bill came out to about $200 ($50/person). Slightly more than exprected but the meal was pretty good.
author: T C.

description: So last night I went to Dosa and was really impressed. First of all, the space is amazing. Very cool, very hip, and not pretentious at all. The specialty cocktails are really good, if not a little pricey, and the food is not only great but also in my opinion a great value. I started with a Smoked Cup (cocktail) which was really tasty, and had a bowl of the beet soup to start. I am a total fan of beets anyway, but this soup was fabulous. Progressing to the main course, I had the paneer and peas uttapam with a side of spicy achar. Also fabulous. But at this point I was getting kind of full (although I managed to clean my plate, achar and all). So my friend Tasha was taking a little longer than I to finish, and as is our custom I sat a little impatiently while she picked at her masala dosa, which she also loved. While I was waiting I decided to order a cup of chai to give me something to do. The chai was delicious but drinking that cup of hot tea-flavored milk sent me over the edge. I left the restaurant super uncomfortable because I was so full, but vowing to come back. Good thing for the 6-block walk home.
author: Sarah K.

description: The atmosphere and decor was really nice.  We ordered samosa app, calamari app, lamb curry, and a dosa.  It was a little pricey, but if you want dressed up indian/pakastani food in a nice restaurant setting, I think it's worth it.  King fisher beer goes nicely w/ the food.  The wait staff is overly attentive and very nice.  I'd come back again.
author: LT B.

description: This place has way improved! The only funny thing was the service which was awkward and intrusive. The puri though with the channa masala was fabulous. Wish there were some more inexpensive wines on the list to really give the option of having a super reasonable meal.
author: B.M. B.

description: Attractive light-filled space; very tasty dosa (I had the Masala) and condiments. The free papadums were a nice touch too.
author: Katherine F.

description: Had dinner here, loved everything - we tried a dosa, and a lamb curry with uttapam. flavorful food, good portions, good service, good ambidence. Can't wait to go back!
author: ou-dan p.

description: Had dinner here tonight and was very pleasantly surprised.  Everything was excellent: food, service, atmosphere.  The lighting is pretty cool and the super high ceiling (18' or so) makes for a dramatic space.  Didn't like the acoustic-like tiles on the ceiling, though.  Enough about that, let's get to the food: shared everything and got to eat with my hands, which I love.  Before we ordered, they brought out some pappadam (this may be misspelled), which I could've eaten until I turned into the blueberry girl on Willy Wonka -- it's so yummy.  Started with the organic greens, mango and goat cheese (light and tastey), and the prawn chilifry (nicely spicey).  Then had my first dosa: went with the basic masala style, which was quickly consumed by the two of us.  For our main course, we had the Bagara Baingan with coconut rice.  This seemed the most typical (yet delightful) dish of the four.  The place was quite busy on a Monday evening and the music was present but not overbearing.  I will definitely be back.
author: Kevin M.

description: Prohiitively expensive making one think twice about going there. We once took my brother and sister in law in addition to our family of four and walked out after paying nearly 200$  !! The food and decor are great though, as well as the attentiveness of the staff. I guess you do have to pay for all those factors.
author: Kala S.

description: Finally, an indian restaurant where the ambiance is as good as the food.  We had excellent dosas and starters.  The owners are very friendly and it is right across from sundance.  So movie and dinner!
author: Sunil M.

description: This is my new favorite restaurant in SF!! There are so many restaurants in this city that do the same thing... French-Californian over and over. We keep going back because these places have nice atmospheres, good service, good beverages, and decent food. Well Dosa takes it to a whole new level! They have the great atmosphere, great service, really great cocktails and wine selection and the food is FANTASTIC! No more of the bland French-Californian mediocrity. The flavors, combinations, and presentations of the food are unlike I've ever seen. The food is just as good if not better than the Valencia location and the atmosphere is 10 times better. Not to mention the creative cocktail options they have introduced. I had some sort of cocktail with gin, lime, chili, and curry that had more levels of flavor than I have ever experienced in a cocktail. I also highly recommend the duck spinach with paneer masala!! PS the prices are very reasonable. I will be recommending this place to all my friends!
author: Barbara N.

description: Been twice in the last two months, first for dinner and today for lunch. Most memorable today was the "Prawn Frankie," tender pieces of shrimp in a light "tomatoey" curry sauce lovingly wrapped in roti. Super yum. I'll be back for that.  My two friends and I  shared the avocado and chick pea salad, not bad considering I don't much like either. The  surprise hit was the banana creme pie that's served with a heaping pile of cooked sweet bananas. My friends said the hot  chai they ordered was a tad on the weak side and well, looked as much. We also had a fantastic dosa filled with a potato, cilantro and onion mush that was incredible. So good! Our server today was busy doubling as the bartender but he was warm and knowledgeable. He even told me where to find a portable blow torch to make creme brulee when he overheard me say how much I loved that dish. This place also has great drinks. My fave is the Ginger Ante.  Parking can be a challenge but there's a garage right across the street that charges $2/hr on Saturdays.
author: Helena B.

description: don't get the chef's tasting menu; probably just wanna stick with dosas; the rest of stuff taste like white boys cooking indian food, just average
author: Peter L.

description: from moment of entry:  hostess greeting  . . .etc . . . laughable pretention; perhaps, too much loft in the place.  glad we came, glad we left, glad Valencia remains.
author: Kathleen M.

description: Food was great. Let's be clear on that point. The fried bread, Bhatura, was out of this world and has completely spoiled me for ever on delicious fried doughs. But I am very disappointed in their wine situation. Do NOT, I repeat, DO NOT order wine by the glass from Dosa under any circumstances. They have the smallest pours of any restaurant I have ever eaten at in my entire life. All 3 of the glasses of wine my dinner party ordered last night were ridiculously tiny. We're talking maybe 4 oz at best. For a $8 to $12 glass of wine, that's just plan disrespectful of your customers and honestly, despite the wonderful draw of their food, makes me not want to return. I don't think a restaurant that can't find it's way to pouring a decent size glass of wine, given how much money they already make off wine and spirits given the serious markups they have, deserves my business no matter how fabulous the food. So be warned. Dosa short changes you like nothing I have ever seen before when it comes to wine. OH and side note, their Raita is good but not fabulous and certainly not worth the $4.50 for the tiny cup they serve you as a side order. It's quite absurd.
author: Jennifer F.
